title: Characterization of Materials
reviews: Be prepared to have a lot of laboratory time with the different microscopes and spectrometers.
Go for it.
Good alternative to minicourses on each individual instrument.
Hands-on experience in microscopy techniques is very useful for those engaged in experimental research.
I would definitely encourage another student to take this course. It is a very practical class.
I would recommend it, particularly if you are an experimentalist.
I would recommend the course.

I would recommend this class to anyone considering using any of the microscopy techniques for their research.  I would not recommend this course to anyone who is moderately curious just because it is a significant time commitment.
If interested in using microscopy techniques, take this class!

If you are interested in SEM, TEM, XRD, AFM, FIB, sample prep, or confocal microscopy or see that you will use these in your research, TAKE THIS CLASS!  It is a great way to learn the science behind these techniques, which will help you get better data, and Professor Yao is great.  It's a very relaxed environment where you can just learn and use the machines.  I'm glad I took it.
If you want to become trained on the IAC microscopes, definitely worth taking this class.
Pretty low workload. Great lab experience.
Strongly recommend this course to anyone wishing to pursue research related to materials.

This is a vrey unique opportunity.  I cannot think of another program that allows free hands on training for this array of microspopy instruments (for a semester!).  I feel like anyone who is doing or plans to partake in quantum scale experimental research should take this course.
Very good course! Very efficient way to get trained on the instruments.
Very useful and practical

You can learn a LOT about different forms of microscopy with a lot of hands-on experience.  This course is very relevant to anyone interested in material science.  It also has 3 hours/week of lab that is not mentioned in the course description.
take it! be engaged, ask lots of questions, etc.
descrip: A multidisciplinary course offering a practical introduction to techniques of imaging structure and compositional analysis of advanced materials. Focus on principles and applications of various characterization methods. Covered topics include AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, EDX/WDX, EELS, Confocal Microscopy, sample preparation and image processing, etc. Hands-on experience is emphasized.

title: Ecohydrology
descrip: A description of the hydrologic mechanisms that underlie ecological observations. The space-time dynamics of soil-plant-atmosphere is studied at different temporal and spatial scales. A review is done of the role of environmental fluctuations in the distribution of vegetation. Emphasis is made in the dynamics of soil moisture. The signatures revealing fractal structures in landscapes and vegetation are reviewed as result of self-organizing dynamics. Unifying concepts in the processes responsible for these signatures will be studied with examples from hydrology and ecology.

title: East Asian Humanities II: Traditions and Transformations
reviews: If you are interested in east asia definitely take it, it is highly enjoyable, the material is mostly great, lectures are really interesting and it's not too much work. Amazing EM
Stay on top of the readings.
TAKE IT!!!!! All of the readings are FUN and ENJOYABLE.

This is a great HUM course in the EAS department, and I would recommend it to anyone who is interesting in learning more about East Asia. Guest lecturers are experts in the material, so it is a great way to get to know many different professors.
descrip: This is the second half of a two-semester sequence introducing the humanities in East Asia. The course begins roughly around the fourteenth century and covers the arts, philosophy, religion and literature in China, Japan, and Korea. Lectures are given by specialists in the departments of East Asian Studies, Comparative Literature, Art and Archaeology, and Religion. Classes will be complemented by museum visits and performances.

title: Algebra II
reviews: Do you want to learn math? Take this damn course already, its foundational.

If Zsolt is teaching and you are interested in Algebra, make sure the material will be interesting enough to motivate you throughout the semester. If Raicu is teaching you should take it. Generally speaking specific interest in the material is important regardless of who is teaching (other than just taking it to see how what it's like)
If you don't learn Galois Theory, you aren't a real math major.

If you're a math major, take this even though you can get away with just taking Algebra I. Galois Theory ties it all together. If you aren't a math major and are just interested, I highly recommend it anyway - beautiful stuff.

This course does a good job tying up some of the ideas of Algebra I and explaining how to apply them to other structures.  Go to class.  The textbook is ok but the lectures provide a deeper perspective on the material.

This is a really interesting course.  You can finally tell your friends why they can't solve all quintic polynomials by radicals.  We covered rings, modules, fields, Galois theory - fairly standard material for an algebra class.  This course was a bit harder than Algebra 1, but it was worthwhile.
You should take this class if you're planning to be a math major.

You will take it eventually if you are a math major. You won't if you aren't. If you are wondering "as a math major" whether "now" is the right time to take it, I suggest you do ASAP - the material you learn in this course is essential in almost every part of mathematics.
Zsolt is a stud.
prereqs: MAT345 or equivalent..
descrip: A continuation of Algebra I, this course will cover the basics of ring theory, module theory, field theory, and Galois theory. Topics include structure theorems for modules, polynomial rings, field extensions, and solvability of polynomial equations by radicals.

title: Ancient Egyptian Art
reviews: Definitely take it! The material is very interesting and Professor Lizska is fun and engaging.
Take it! The class is a lot of fun, and the professor is extremely knowledgeable.

Take it. If it's Dr. Liszka teaching, regardless of the subject matter, sign up for it. She will make discussions entertaining and lively. Her's is one of the few classes where I didn't feel I was wasting my time by showing up.
Take this class before Prof. Liszka leaves Princeton. FULL STOP.
descrip: Art in ancient Egypt is a window into its society, religion, and history. In this class, students will survey major themes and debates in Egyptian art, such as composition, portraiture, artists, and the integration of art and writing. Students will also investigate ancient Egyptian art as a reflection of its culture from c. 5000BCE, when it was a series of disconnected polities, to c. 200CE when it was a province of the Roman Empire. They will examine major pieces of art, private tombs, temples, pyramids, and the sphinx. During the precepts, students will interact with objects at the Princeton Art Museum.

title: Laboratory in Plasma Physics
reviews: Hint: Don't collaborate on the reports. It's not as great as it seems.
This is an excellent, interesting course.  You will learn a great deal.
descrip: Develop skills, knowledge, and understanding of basic and advanced laboratory techniques used to measure the properties and behavior of plasmas. Representative experiments are: cold-cathode plasma formation and architecture; ambipolar diffusion in afterglow plasmas; Langmuir probe measurements of electron temperature and plasma density; period doubling and transitions to chaos in glow discharges; optical spectroscopy for species identification; microwave interferometry and cavity resonances for plasma density determination; and momentum generated by a plasma thruster.

Don't take this class unless you want an easy A.

descrip: This course will examine different crises confronting cities in the 21st century. Topics will range from immigration, to terrorism, shrinking population, traffic congestion, pollution, energy crisis, housing needs, water wars, race riots, extreme weather conditions, war and urban operations. The range of cities will include Los Angles, New Orleans, Paris, Logos, Caracas, Havana, New York, Hong Kong, and Baghdad among others.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Advanced Programming Languages Theory
reviews: Definitely take this course if you've done a UG level PL course
If you are interested in this area - take it.
Take it!  It's rarely offered, and it provides insight into many interesting areas of programming languages research.
prereqs: COS 441, 510, or equivalent, or permission of instructor. For overview of necessary background materials from COS441, see textbook "Types and Programming Languages", chapters 1-11, 13, 14, 22-25..
descrip: Course surveys advanced material on the theory of programming languages. Topics include linear, polymorphic and dependent type systems, type and effect systems, module systems, parametricity, logical relations, dependent type theory and bisimulations. Classes will be split between lectures that introduce foundational material and seminars that discuss research papers.

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - Violence
descrip: Violence is at the heart of much of politics. State formation, civil wars, ethnic conflict, and the illicit, for example, can be partially defined by their explicit or threatened recourse to violence. This course addresses theoretical debates about when and why violence is so prevalent across these issue areas. Under what conditions are states able to establish the legitimate monopoly on the use of force? Why are some civil wars more violent than others? When/why does electoral politics result in violence? When/why do illicit organizations give rise to heightened violence? What are the implications of violence for democratic citizenship?

title: Topics in Analysis
reviews: The course is mostly about differential equations and inequalities concerning norms of functions. If that interests you, go for it.
This course is interesting but difficult and largely self-motivated. Be prepared to work outside of class and find supplementary PDE books you can learn from.

This course is very fast-paced. I would recommend having very solid knowledge of analysis fundamentals (up to real analysis), having taken ODE, and seen some of the harmonic analysis stuff before even considering taking it.
prereqs: MAT320 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Introduce students to basic topics in modern analysis such as distribution theory, fundamental solutions, interpolation theory, basic calculus inequalities, Calderon-Sygmung, Littlewood-Paley theory, etc. Also, discussion of some of the basic notions in the calculus of variations and applications.

title: The Structure and Meaning of Words
reviews: Certainly not a general interest course, but if you're a linguistics nerd and love thinking of examples and counterexamples and analyzing things like reduplication in Tagalog, this course is for you! you learn a lot about language and Williams is such a nice guy.

I thought the material was very interesting throughout, but then again I can see how if you're not into linguistics it might seem a little bit dry at times. Very good course, definitely a lot more fun and a lot less stressful than I expected. It's the only course I've taken with him, but I think you can't go wrong with Professor Williams.

It's an interesting overview of morphology in general.  Professor Williams is a good professor and the material is incredibly interesting.  The main issue with the class is it's kind of unpredictable when it comes to assignment and assessment difficulty, so it's hard to know how well you're doing in class.
Pay attention and read the book; don't be afraid to ask questions. Don't take unless you're genuinely interested in the subject, or your attention will drift.
Take it if you are interested in the topic, otherwise, pick another more accessible/non-linguist class like "imagined languages".
The work may need more time than you expect to give it, but then it is very rewarding afterwards.
You need to be interested in the material to enjoy this class, but if you are interested, it can be good. Background in Linguistics would also probably be helpful, but probably not 100% necessary.
idk
prereqs: LIN 201.
descrip: The course will treat the structure of words and the structure of the overall lexicon for human languages. Topics included will be: the rules of word formation; the relation between syntax and the lexicon; the psychology of the lexicon, including an examination of studies of the storage and access of lexical items; the semantics of complex words; the phonology of word formation; lexical redundancy and the learning of the lexicon. Students will prepare one short class presentation on a topic in consultation with the instructor.

title: Contemporary East Asia
descrip: This course is an introduction to the societies, cultures, and politics of contemporary East Asia. The rise of East Asia has inspired Western observers to reflect on the ways in which capitalism, democracy, and modern social relationships can unfold in different ways. It has also prompted debates about the development of political systems, about the most efficient and just ways to organize economic growth, and even about what constitutes Asia. Although the course will focus especially on China, Japan, South Korea, and Vietnam, we will draw special attention to issues that cut across national boundaries.

If Rosen is teaching, take this course! He is a fantastic lecturer and makes a really dry subject genuinely interesting. Problem sets are 20 percent of the grade; they can be tough and tricky, so be prepared to go to McGraw or work with friends. The midterm is 30 percent of the grade, and the final is 50 percent. Both are about 3/4 multiple choice and 1/4 free response. They are quite tricky but not impossible; Rosen likes to test concepts in ways that you haven't seen them before. Case in point: we discussed Pigouvian taxes in class, but on the exam we had to do a subsidy instead. Don't take this class and expect to get an A; only 25 percent of the class gets A grades, and many nasty, hypercompetitive Asians are enrolled, even though they got 5's on their AP micro exam. A very good option as a PDF, as you can learn great material without freaking out about your grade. To sum up: if you can, take Micro with Rosen; you won't regret it.

Take this course with Harvey Rosen, he is probably the best professor I've had here so far. I'm pre-med and just took this course out of interest and I couldn't be happier that I did. The class is extremely fair.
Take this course with Professor Rosen. He is a great lecturer.

Take this course with Rosen! He's a fantastic lecturer. His lectures are very clear and as a plus he's really funny. I also think he did a good job keeping politics separate from the subject. Taking this class as an engineer, I thought the math was really easy and problem sets took no more than 2 hours.
Take this course with Rosen! Really great
Take this course! I'm not an econ major, and I traditionally had a difficult time understanding a lot of econ concepts, but Professor Rosen does an amazing job at communicating information across.
Take this course, and take it with Harvey Rosen. Even if you're not interested in Economics, this is a great course to take.

Take this course, it is great with Rosen. Take it with him if you have to. Tools are taught that you might need regardless of what job you end up going into. Get ready for the exams, as they are very hard with Rosen.

Take this course. You won't regret it. The p-sets and exams are fairly easy. The lectures are amazing and not to be missed. Harvey Rosen is as good (if not better) than everyone says he is. Just make sure to pay attention; you never know when you'll get called on. If you're worried about grades, Harvey makes it clear at the beginning of the course that he has no qualms about giving everyone A's if they deserve them. If you put in the effort (and it's really not that much), it will pay off.
Take this. It's should be a required class for all princeton students. I'm sorry I waited so long to take it
Take with Rosen! Amazing lecturer and super clear

The course is very easy, but Harvey Rosen is a fantastic professor and makes lectures very enjoyable. There is no one else who could make a 400 person lecture hall pay attention, laugh, and even participate the way Rosen did. I have a good understanding of Microeconomics after taking this course, and although there was no calculus, I feel informed and prepared.
This class is fair in its grading but don't be dissapointed if you do not get an A.  Do the readings and attend lecture.
This class is great with Professor Rosen. I would highly recommend taking it.
This class is interesting but keep up with the readings!
This course is a good one, and, if you prepare for it correctly, you should do well in it.

This course is a great introduction to microeconomics, and, from what I've heard from others, it is also helpful even to those who have taken microeconomics before. Just be sure to keep up on the readings, as the lectures will be more helpful that way!

This course is quite different from a high school AP Microeconomics course. Do not think that you will easily ace this course just because you got an A in your high school class or a 5 on the AP.  The material is very different.  It will still be a challenging course.
This course was as expected--problem sets and two exams, very straightforward.

This is a good class to take. It's something everyone needs to know. The beginning of the semester is pretty doable and it gets harder after the midterm when you have to apply the concepts to different situations. Read the textbook and skim the articles listed in the syllabus because apparently there are questions on them in the final, even though you don't really need to know them during the semester. Work on problem sets in a group after you attempt the problems yourselves first. It's often difficult to just get the problems started, so form a study group or go to McGraw study halls at Frist. Very helpful.
This is a great class to take, it will be applicable throughout your life.
This is a great course to have taken before you graduate!   It has good life knowledge and isn't overly difficult.  If you take it with Rosen, lectures are fantastic.
This is an excellent course. If you are interested in the subject or are taking it as a departmental, make sure to take it with Rosen. Even if you are PDFing, take it with Rosen.
This is one of my favorite courses I've taken while I've been at Princeton. If you want to learn a new way to think about decision making and how the world works, this is the place to be.
Took for an easy SA.. worked out for me
Wait for Rosen -- it's worth it (plus, I've heard all the others are terrible).
Wait until Harv teaches it

When working on the problem sets, do not over think the questions. Most of the questions and concepts in ECO 100 are intuitively based, so using your intuition is the best way to approach the questions. And, although I was not engaged or interested in the subject, the course is a decent one if you are looking to satisfy a distribution requirement. The only challenge is the curve on exams because the course is generally really popular, so don't expect a big boost from the curve.

While Rosen can make the lecture nerve-wracking with his habit of calling on students at random, he allegedly is much better than all the other Micro teachers.  If you need Micro as a prerequisite then I suggest you take his class.
You can't get by ECO 100, but Rosen will make it a much more enjoyable experience.
You must take this course. Don't miss out.
You should probably take this class, even though it is difficult and pretty broad.
You should take it because it's just a necessary course, but the course itself isn't inspiring.

You will have problems with the course for one of three reasons:
1. You have too little grounding in economics and mathematics, so you will have trouble keeping up.
2. You have too much grounding in economics and mathematics, so you will find the course too easy and not stimulating enough.
3. You will be one of the few people who has the right amount of grounding to take the course and enjoy it, but the complaints of the people in groups 1 and 2 will detract from your enjoyment of the course.
You'll probably have to take it. If you don't have to take it for a grade, don't.
You'll probably have to take this course at some point. Take it with Rosen.
be ready for the challenge but definitely take the course
definitely take it with professor Rosen
do the readings!
do you best on the exams because those are really the only grades you have

descrip: Economics is the study of how people and societies deal with scarcity. This course focuses on the advantages and disadvantages of market systems for allocating scarce resources.

title: Seminar in Political Theory - Executive Power
descrip: This seminar examines an important conundrum associated with the theory of executive power. Political theorists have long recognized that as the laws cannot foresee every contingency, men and women must rule when necessity demands. However, entrusting men and women with such discretionary power is problematic because they might abuse it. We will study how prominent theorists of executive power, including Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke and Publius have attempted to solve this conundrum. Drawing on secondary literature as well as documentaries and news reports, we will also analyze the feasibility of their solutions in the modern world.

title: Social and Personality Development
descrip: Major issues in social and personality psychology examined from a developmental perspective, with emphasis on developmental processes and change. Data on children, adolescents and adults will be considered. Topics include: attachment, self-concept, self-esteem, achievement, gender roles, moral development, prosocial behavior, and aggression. Particular attention to role of culture.

title: Special Studies in Medieval Literature - Love without Object
descrip: Moving from negative theology to fin amor to late psychoanalysis, we will explore the question of how love is possible when its object is unknown, unknowable, or impossible. We will examine attempts to represent a love without object, from Augustine to Chaucer; the pressure it puts on theories and practices of signification; the emergence and development of the romance and love lyric; theories of object relations, lack, and desire in, among others, Eriugena, Ramon Llul, Albertus Magnus, Marguerite Porete, Heidegger, Lacan, Kristeva, Badiou, and Irigaray.

title: Race, Social Inequality, and Education
descrip: Education is becoming increasingly important for upward social mobility in the U.S. and abroad. Education has been linked to societal inequalities in health, income, and other life-chance measures. This course will focus on the role of education in both the production and amelioration of social inequality. Particular attention is given to racial achievement gaps. By engaging both quantitative and qualitative studies, you will acquire 1) knowledge of the historical trends and understanding of racial differences in achievement, and 2) a broad understanding of the current issues/debates in the literature.

title: Readings in Modern Korean l
prereqs: KOR 402 or instructor's permission..
descrip: The 5th-year Korean course is designed to advance students' reading and writing skills to the superior level and to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, and history. Readings cover various types of authentic materials (e.g., newspaper articles, editorials, think pieces, essays, and literary short stories). Discussion and presentation skills in formal settings (e.g., academic, professional) are also emphasized. Class discussions are conducted in Korean.

title: Neuroscience of Being Human, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Starting, Building, and Operating an Architectural Practice - Business and Legal Issues in Architectural Practice
reviews: Definitely a must for any student considering establishing their own practice in the future.
Have fun!

I absolutely recommend taking this course.  Prof. Hillier is an incredibly astute and entertaining lecturer, and class assignments and projects are all valuable.  The class entails semi-weekly assignments, which could be completed quickly, but a student wouldn't really benefit from a rushed assignment in this class.  A student's effort becomes evident during class presentations.

Take this class!
I'd definitely recommend for students to take this course.
If you want to take a course that gives your practical insight at a school that focuses primarily on history and theory, then take this class!
Remember to go big when you do presentations!
Take this course
Take this!!
You just should take it.
descrip: Review and analysis of the dynamics and process inherent in starting, developing, managing and operating an architectural practice, including marketing, finance, human resources, project process, liability, insurance, and general management. Areas of particular emphasis include project accounting, public presentations, and the development of a business plan.

title: Chemistry, Structure, and Structure-Function Relations of Nucleic Acids
prereqs: General chemistry and one semester of organic chemistry. Open to juniors, seniors, graduate students in Molecular Biology, Chemistry, EEB, Physics and Chemical & Bioengineering. Others by permission of the instructor. Suitably prepared Freshman and Sophomores have often taken the course..
descrip: The chemistry and structure of mononucleotides, oligonucleotides, and polynucleotides and their helical complexes are presented as a basis for understanding and predicting the structures and structure-function relations of naturally occurring DNAs and RNAs. Functions to be considered include fidelity of DNA replication and transcription, mutagenic mechanisms, molecular evolution, roles and mechanisims of action of recently discovered small RNAs, and nature and organization of the genetic code.

title: Readings in Early Modern Korean History
descrip: This course provides a survey of major issues and debates in the historiography of early modern Korea, and introduces the major English language works on Choson history as well as some key primary texts from the Choson period in classical Chinese. No previous knowledge of Korean history or language is necessary, but a working knowledge of classical Chinese or classical Japanese (kanbun) is required.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
reviews: A fairly good way to expand the vision of plasma physics research
Take this course if you're required to.
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-temperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.

title: Industrial Organization
reviews: If you like it, take it. If you didn't like ECO 310 part 2, you'll definitely get bored.
Not great, but not so bad. The problem sets are difficult but the exams are fine. Just a more confusing extension of ECO 310.
Was hard, but one of the very few classes I have ever taken that seemed relevant to the real world
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 and MAT 102 or MAT 103. Not open to freshmen. Students should be comfortable using basic calculus to solve problems..
descrip: This course studies firms, markets and competition. We will study the theory of industrial organization, focusing on analyzing the way firms make decisions, as well as the impact of those decisions on market outcomes such as market prices, quantities, the type of products offered and social welfare. The goals of the course include the development of intuition for firm strategic behavior, such as pricing, as well as the development of skills for the analysis of formal models.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Seminar in Literary Theory
descrip: An examination of several fundamental concepts including Capital, Power, Ideology, Alterity, Trauma, Melancholia, History and Memory, as theorized by Bourdieu, Foucault, Althusser, Freud, Lacan, Levinas, Derrida, Paul de Man, Ricoeur, Hayden White, Zizek, among others.

title: Replication and Movement in the Renaissance - Matter & Materiality
descrip: Examines how the materials of Renaissance craft- azurite, gold, paper, blood, ivory, ash, bone, acid, wax, etc. - impacted early understandings of the artwork and its theories. The relationships between "material" and "theoretical" art history in a Northern European context are a main concern. Topics include: alchemy, the studio, early atomistic theories, restoration, animation, authenticity, archaeology, motion, science. Course includes trips to labs at the Philadelphia Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Creative Writing Workshop in Spanish
prereqs: Completion of a 200-level Spanish course is recommended. The course will be taught in Spanish.
descrip: The writer Julio Cortazar once said the novel wins by accumulating points, while the short story has to do it by knock-out. This workshop is designed to clear the way to self-expression, wiping out the myths that link writing with inspiration. We will use a wide array of tools that will trigger the student's narrative instincts emphasizing the notion of process. We will learn to discuss literary craft in a constructive way and to read as writers, not only reading each other, but also through dissecting successful short stories and texts by writers on writing. We will learn how to write a publishable short story that wins by knock-out.

title: Introduction to Analytic Combinatorics
reviews: Look. Just take it.
Mathematically, having some background in series manipulations and basic probability theory is helpful for taking this course.
Take it if you are interested in the subject matter (it's fascinating!), but expect to a do a lot of self-learning from Coursera videos. The actual in-person classes are pretty useless.
Take it. Extremely useful for anyone interested in CS or probability

The material isn't easy, but the assignments are generally doable, if you give them enough time. It's definitely more of a math class than a COS class. At least this semesters, the lectures were all videos online, which is nice sometimes, but I would probably have preferred live lectures.
prereqs: COS 226, 340 or equivalent background in mathematics..
descrip: Analytic Combinatorics aims to enable precise quantitative predictions of the properties of large combinatorial structures. The theory has emerged over recent decades as essential both for the scientific analysis of algorithms in computer science and for the study of scientific models in many other disciplines. This course combines motivation for the study of the field with an introduction to underlying techniques, by covering as applications the analysis of numerous fundamental algorithms from computer science. The second half of the course introduces Analytic Combinatorics, starting from basic principles.

title: Algebraic Topology
prereqs: Topology MAT 365 (formerly 325) and Algebra MAT 345 (formerly MAT 322). For advanced level undergraduate and graduate students. Undergraduates must obtain permission from Instructor..
descrip: The aim of the course is to study some of the basic algebraic techniques in Topology, such as homology groups, cohomology groups and homotopy groups of topological spaces.

title: Imagined Languages
reviews: DEFINITELY take it! It will seriously enhance your Princeton experience!
I would recommend that any students interested in language or the various facets of language should take this course.
If you have the chance, definitely take this course. Even if you don't have the chance to take it, try and wait around until you get one. It's worth it!

It seems it's impossible to come into this class adequately prepared - as a start, go learn the history of everything. This class is a lot of fun, one of my favorites at Princeton, and Katz and Gordin are wonderful professors. They really feed off of the energy of one another. Come to class prepared for discussions, and don't be afraid to experiment with wild ideas.
It's easy to get behind on the reading- try to keep up or you won't get as much out of the class. It's an incredibly interesting course though.
Michael Gordin and Joshua Katz. This is the Dream Team, and you would be absolutely insane NOT to take this class.

Not only have I not taken, but I could not "imagine," a class more interesting than this.  The class dealt with every aspect of language, but delved even further into various other fields.  It explores the entirety of a fascinating, and ever expanding, field of creating languages.  The lectures, readings, discussion, project, and even the paper and weekly assignments were always the most exciting thing I had to every week and never remotely dull.
Press the enrollment button really, really fast. If you don't get in, go to the first two classes, anyway, and the teachers will absolutely let you in.
See how amazing this class looks in the description? It's better than that. You can't even imagine (hehe) how great it will be. Just take it.
TAKE IT.

TAKE IT. And if you're on the waitlist, don't give up hope! It's fantastic and the workload is manageable and well worth it. Seriously, it's so much fun, AND I feel like I learned a lot. Using Imagined Languages as an angle into some linguistics and history in general is really cool.
Take it take it take it!!!!!
Take this class! The workload isn't light, but it's incredibly interesting,thought-provoking, and sometimes very fun.
Take this class.
Take this course no matter what interests you.
Take this course without hesitation. It will no doubt be one of the best courses you will take here.

Take this course, you'll love it and never want to stop talking about languages XD. Really think carefully about what you want to do your project and final paper on, because it's important and can be really really fun or really stressful.
Take this. Even if you don't know any thing. Take this.
The best class I have ever taken at Princeton. Amazing professors, fascinating material, and where else at Princeton are you going to learn Klingon? TAKE IT, TAKE IT, TAKE IT.

This was one of the best classes I've ever taken at Princeton. Both professors are amazing - witty, interesting, knowledgeable, and genuinely caring. You have to work hard, but it's so much fun that it doesn't feel like work. You don't have to be a linguistics student or even have background in linguistics to enjoy and succeed at this class. I loved it.
WHAT ARE YOU DOING!? PUT THIS IN YOUR COURSE QUEUE RIGHT NOW AND GET READY TO HIT ENROLL AS SOON AS YOU CAN! DON'T HESITATE!!!!!
descrip: This course combines historical and linguistic analysis in an attempt to understand how and why people are sometimes moved to try to transcend the languages to which we have natural, or at least relatively easy, access. Among the examples we will consider are Esperanto, Klingon, Middle Egyptian, Linear A and B, Cornish, Fortran, and Proto-World. Taking a view that is broad both geographically and temporally, we will explore, in an interactive and collaborative way, the philosophical and sociological implications of constructing and reconstructing languages for purposes that range from the political to the literary to the simply frivolous.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Subwavelength Nanophotonics and Plasmonics
reviews: This course provides a good introduction on modern nano-photonics and plasmonic.
descrip: An introductory course for the 1st and 2nd year graduate students to understand the theory and application of the photonic devices which have feature size smaller than the wavelength of light, termed subwavelength photonics (SWP) or subwavelength optical elements (SOE). The devices include those with metallic structures, namely, subwavelength plasmonics. The course has three main sections: (i) rigorous Maxwell theory and mean-field theory for SWPs, (ii) non-resonant SWPs and resonant SWPs (photonic crystals), and (iii) applications of SWP.

title: Topics in Science Technology and Environmental Policy - Biotechnology Policy
descrip: This course provides in-depth analysis of selected topics in biotechnology that are currently the focus of intense debate in the public and policy arenas. Topics include genetic modification of plants and animals, genetic testing in human populations, stem cells, cloning, and advanced reproductive technologies. Each topic is examined from the perspective of potential commercial applications, risk/benefit analysis, impact on individuals and society, the viewpoints of supporters and detractors, and the political response in the U.S. and other countries.

title: Golden-Age Prose - The Rise of Romance in Medieval and Renaissance Spain
descrip: How was the Quijote possible? Despite the novel's unquestionable originality, it did not arise ex nihilo. In fact, sixteenth-century Spain was fertile ground for literary experimentation, the rise of hybrid forms, and the creation and the re-creation of new genres. This course will explore such genres as the sentimental romance, the picaresque, and the byzantine novel as well as such sui generis works as Delicado's La Lozana andaluza.

title: The Holy Roman Empire, 1495-1806
prereqs: Proficiency in German is recommended..
descrip: This seminar covers major themes in early modern German history and is intended to help students prepare for examinations and independent research in the field. Topics include: the institutions and political culture of the Holy Roman Empire, confessionalization, the Great Witch Craze, The 30 Years' War, German home towns, Aufklarung, and the French Revolution in Germany.

title: Digital Neurocomputing
reviews: Be prepared before class. Do ask LOTS OF QUESTIONS!
Take it or leave Princeton with regret.
The material is interesting, but it's a hard course to follow because Kung, while still sharp and critical, has grown older and slower.
descrip: Machine learning algorithms allow us to induce rules based on empirical training data. The course will establish statistical and algebraic foundations essential to kernel-based learning approach, for vectorial and nonvectorial data analysis. More specifically, it covers: (i) aptive techniques for feature selection and dimension reduction; (ii) unsupervised cluster discovery: K-means, SOM, kernel K-means, kernel SOM, and hierarchical clustering; and (iii) upervised learning algorithms: Fisher discriminate analysis (FDA), kernel ridge regressor, upport vector machines, and ridge-SVM.

title: A Sense of Place in Cinema
descrip: What does it mean for a film to be embedded in a local tradition, language, and landscape, while being challenged by a global culture with an increasingly homogenized taste for the films of Hollywood? With the help of Nossiter's 2004 provocative documentary, Mondovino, we will explore the possible analogy between the theory of terroir (a sense of place) in wine production and a theory of local-vernacular filmmaking by comparing classical Hollywood studio films with films of Italian Neo-Realism and works by the highly controversial Danish filmmakers Vinterberg and von Trier.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Political Science
descrip: This seminar is concerned with the professional obligations of political science researchers. This course is designed to raise those concerns and develop in students an appreciation for the issues that they might confront as they do their work. Topics addressed includes the relationship of political science as an academic discipline to democratic politics and institutions, advocacy and objectivity in political science, plagiarism and academic misconduct, human subjects and fieldwork in research, institutional review boards, funding sources and intellectual integrity, collaboration, and mentoring.

title: Ethics of Human Experimentation, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: General Computer Science
reviews: A great course to take, I highly recommend it. Help is always there if you need it. If you've taken computer science before, the topics covered are still cool and engaging.
A lot of students had programming experience, and I had absolutely no background, which made the course quite difficult for me. However, I do feel like I learned a lot. I'm glad I PDFed though.
A lot of work, but very useful and organized.  Lots of amazing resources ready to help you.  Very hard to make a good grade in without experience or COS talent.  No curve.
Always practice programming even if you are done with the assignments. It helps on the exams. And also go to office hours begin assignments early.
Awesome
Awesome class, would definitely recommend it! Workload is not as bad as some people say.
Awesome course! Highly recommended even if you have no interest in pursing COS (or you might even find you do!)
Be sure to commit a lot of time to the course.  Requires much more time that other courses.  Make sure to start assignments early.

COS 126 is a great course. You don't want to miss out. It will probably change the way you think about computers and logic, which is a very good thing. Be prepared to spend 3-6 hours on the programming assignments, most of it debugging.
COS 126 is a lot of work. While the assignments aren't so bad, the exams are difficult and require a lot of preparation.
COS126 can be time consuming but is very interesting and well taught.
Challenging if you have no programming experience but definitely do-able and worth taking. Fairly time-consuming but very interesting!
Class varies greatly in time commitment. Not a great way to fill a QR.

Coding (and knowledge of computers to that extent) is an extremely useful skill that I think everyone should know about. Definitely take this course and take it seriously - you'll be very satisfied by what you learn, and in the future when computers become more and more part of our lives, you won't be left behind, as you'll have at least a tiny bit of computer knowledge. Lastly, I advise students to use the availability of the piazza resource. It was instrumental for me in getting through this course.

Computer science is a great subject to know about, whether or not you are an engineer! Take the class. It's interesting, the structure is well organized and thought through, and the class is well taught. Be sure to at least skim the textbook or lecture slides before the lecture if you can't read the text. It definitely helps with learning the material during class. I've heard tales of ineffective preceptors, but I think most are generally good, so if you don't like your preceptor, shop precepts at the beginning of the semester.
Computers are an increasingly important part of this world, so understanding a little about how they work certainly can't hurt you.
Cos 126 is a wonderful course for people who have any interest in learning to program. It is impressive for its accessibility to non-programers, and I found the projects to be quite fun.
Cos could be very interesting if it were well taught.
DO NOT BRING YOUR COMPUTER TO LECTURE OR PRECEPT.  You don't need it and you WILL get distracted and sucked into fb just like any other class.

DO NOT TAKE THIS IF YOU ARE A BEGINNER AND CANNOT DEDICATE MOST OF YOUR TIME FOR SCHOOLWORK TO IT. It was very difficult for me, and I honestly don't even know when I'm going to use this knowledge again in the future.
Definately take this course if you want to learn to program, but be prepared to devote a significant amount of work to the assignments!

Definitely go for it! Whether you have to take the course or not, it's good stuff to know. You'll have plenty of support and resources if you need them. The first half of the semester isn't too time-consuming, but the later assignments do take a while so leave time for debugging.
Definitely take COS 126. Programming is a great skill to have and the course is taught very well.
Definitely take it! If you study even a little for the exams, they're not that hard.
Definitely take it. I recommend it to ANYONE, BSE or not. Though be prepared to work hard, and rewarded hard.
Definitely take the class!  Even though lectures aren't the most interesting, computer science is a great skill to learn at some point, and it may even make you consider computer science as a major.
Definitely take the course if you have never tried cos. It is a fun experience.
Definitely take this class.  It's a lot of fun, and you don't need any prior experience to enjoy it.
Definitely take this class. Go to all the lectures at the very least and try to read the textbook before the lecture.
Definitely take this class. Keep up with the work and don't fall behind.
Definitely take this course unless you are absolutely certain you do not need to know anything about computer science in the future.

Definitely take this course! Even if it's not required as a distribution or departmental, it's very well-taught and is a useful skill to have, especially as technology becomes ever more present in our lives.
Definitely take this course, even if you are not BSE and don't plan to pursue anything computer-related. Useful skills and a way of thinking that everyone should be exposed to.
Definitely take this course. It is a lot of fun and you learn a lot.
Definitely take this course. It may take a lot of time but it's very useful and you'll learn a ton.

Do it! Don't be intimidated by people saying it's hard if you don't have prior experience. It's an intro-level class and the professors and preceptors are always available to make sure you don't fall behind, as well as the lab TAs who are wonderful for debugging programs etc.
Do it.
Do the readings and pay attention in lecture! Don't hold off until the the last couple days to do the assignments (especially in the end) so you don't spend half the day freaking out.
Do the readings before going to lecture. The extra exposure will be very helpful for understanding the material
Do the readings thoroughly and start your assignments early.
Do the work with as little help as possible to maximize your own understanding.
Don't be afraid to ask for help. It's not a knock to go to office hours, the TA lab, or Piazza.
Don't bother going to lecture, it's useless.
Don't go to lecture; I went to every lecture, and I probably failed
Don't take it if you don't have to.
Don't underestimate the course based on the first few assignments. Start with plenty of time to debug. Go to the lab ta's if needed. Generally, they are really helpful.

Even if you don't have prior programming experience this is a very do-able course. They start at the beginning but get to doing some pretty cool stuff quickly. There's also a lot of help available if you need it. Try to take it with a friend so you can do the pair assignments together.

Even if you have never used a computer in your life, I would ask you to please give this class a try. TAKE IT. It is easily the most organized and polished class I have taken at Princeton. Don't be surprised if you get hooked.
Even though its not pdf, you should still take it, its not that hard if you are willing to work ahead and give yourself time to conceptualize the more abstract stuff.
Everyone should take this course. Sorry it is now npdf.

Excellent course to take, whether for general interest or because you know you want to go on in COS. Don't be afraid that there is no longer a PDF option. Everyone thinks they will need to use it, but if you put in a bit of effort it is unnecessary. Take with Doug Clark, his lectures really make the class.

Excellent course. I learned a lot about computer science for one semester and had plenty of support when I needed it. The material was surprisingly engaging, and several of my friends are now pursuing COS majors of certificates because of this class. It was, however, a lot of time for me, especially with the two part exams and a Dean's Date assignment.  Overall a great course, but be prepared to put time into it.
GREAT CLASS! really interesting! I am so glad i took it!

Get into Donna Gabai's precept. David Pritchard is probably just as good but maybe a little less funny in class. Christopher Moretti, if he teaches it again, is probably also really worth going for. If you are an undergraduate student at Princeton, this is the number one course that you have no reason not to take. Do not avoid it and do not be scared of it unless you are absolutely positive that you will have a very hard time. Otherwise, challenging as it is, there is always a lot of help available. This course might not be PDFable in the future so if that really scares you that much sign up for it and seriously use the shopping period to consider staying in it. Also, do not rule out the possibility that you end up thinking the material relatively easy (take more COS if that happens.)

descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The goal of the course is to teach basic principles and practical issues, while at the same time preparing students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis. Two lectures, two precepts.

title: Algorithms and Data Structures
reviews: A great, interesting course. Definitely take it if you liked COS126 and want more. Beware that the programs are not as straightforward as they were before. There is definitely good reason to start early on these.

Start the assignments early if you are new to programming. Always go to office hours or TA hours if you are confused. Don't skip precept; they outline what to do for the assignments and you'll just end up wasting time trying to figure everything out on your own.
Start the assignments early, but that applies to just about any course. Also, take it with Josh and Arvind. They are probably the best lecturers I've ever had here.
Stay on top of knowing how the algorithms work, you get exposed to a lot of algorithms each week.
Stay on top of things. Prepare for the exams with ample time. Don't just gloss through the material; make an effort to really learn what's going on as we are actually learning the material.
Study hard for the midterm and final, and don't be fooled by the ease of previous years exams. Exams all around are becoming much tougher than in years past.
TAKE IT!!  It's interesting and applicable.
Take 226, especially with Arvind/JHug as lecturers. They were great!
Take it Josh/Arvind if you can, don't take it if it will be flipped lecture style.
Take it because you probably have to, and because the algorithms are very useful to know.
Take it even if you're not a COS kind of person. I really learnt a lot and it was fun.
Take it if you like COS.
Take it only if you're really interested in programming. The assignments, though not conceptually difficult, can be quite tedious.

Take it with Josh and Arvind! They are such wonderful lecturers and they make the class, they understand the students, and they represent the next generation of computer scientists. One of the best classes I've ever taken!
Take it! A good course.

Take it! COS 226 is an easily recommended class for anyone remotely interested in learning more about the algorithms that were briefly mentioned in COS 126. It is an extremely well-taught class headed by two young, energetic, occasionally hilarious professors.
Take it! Just be aware that it is a time commitment.
Take it! You learn pretty cools stuff!
Take it, but go to lectures and make sure you understand the material thoroughly.
Take it, never procrastinate since there is a ton of material to learn.
Take it.

Take it. Great class in almost every way. I'd would definitely recommend taking a class with Professors Arvind Narayanan or Josh Hug in the future. HOWEVER, I could see this class becoming very boring with an average professor.
Take it. It's interesting and fun. Josh Hug is fantastic. It's a bit more conceptual than 126 or 217.
Take it. It's something you should know in this era.
Take it. Just stay on top of your work and reading, and you'll love the class.
Take this class if you want to do something programming related, or have the option.  It teaches you the fundamentals of computer science that lets you pass pretty much any COS interview.
Take this class whether you're a COS major or not.

Take this course before 217 if possible. 217 is a more difficult course and after having it under your belt, 226 is pretty straightforward. Overall, interesting course even though the material can be somewhat dry at times. I recommend Dushyant Arora as a preceptor, he basically spoon feeds you all the answers to the programming assignments. Do take, not too much work.
Take this course if you enjoyed COS126. It's much more work, and it may take up the majority of your workload, but it's so worth it.

Take this course if you're interested in COS. You cannot piggy-back off a friend because you will do extremely bad in the final and now you can only work with the same person 3 times. It's also npdf. This is unfortunate because a lot of students who are genuinely interested will no longer be able to take the course but I can see why it had to be done.
The material in COS 226 is a little bit dry but the class is really good and the amount of applications of the algorithms and data structures we learn are staggering.
The material itself is fascinating, and it is presented well and clearly in this course. Take it if you have any interest in the subject.
The programming assignments are fun, but prepare to spend 2-3 entire days on each one!

This a great course to follow COS 126 with if you liked it. I'm not a computer science major but found the material pretty interesting and very applicable. The exams can be pretty tough, but if you're worried about the grade, just P/D/F the class and you'll be fine.
This class demands a lot of attention, but it's worth it. Some aspects of execution are a little mechanical, but the broader picture/algorithms you learn are really interesting.
This class is much harder with Josh Hug and Arvind Narayanan than it was in previous years
This class is not too bad, just do your work and study for the tests by doing practices and you should be fine.
This class is very difficult and the grading is set to high standards. The average for most projects throughout the semester is a 38 or 37/40.

This course is a great survey of important algorithms in computer science that helps develop practical programming skills. If you're interested in computer science from 126, definitely take it; it's the closest thing to a continuation there is.
This course is incredible and most definitely should be taken.

This course teaches interesting and practical material and teaches it well.  Be prepared for some frustration in the highly theoretical exams and weekly exercises.  However, coding assignments are both cool and instructive.

This is a departmental for me, but I thought it was well-taught (both Arvind and Josh are great!!) and organized.  The programs are much less time-consuming than COS 217's, and the whole course is on Coursera so you can learn at your own pace/make up for missed lectures.

This is a hard class and you're going to spend a lot of time on it if you want to do well on the programs. That being said, it's a very interesting class and I definitely recommend it if you're at all interested in Computer Science. The algorithms and data structures you learn are very applicable to the real world and this course is very well taught.
This is a lot more interesting that COS126 and definitely worth taking!

This is a solid course - it's pretty interesting and generally well-taught. A lot of underclassmen will take this class without many other difficult classes in their schedule, so if you're going to take it and try to get a high grade be prepared to be a bit of a perfectionist. Everything else about the class - the assignments, the teachers, etc. - were solidly good.
This is a solid introduction to algorithms.  There are a lot of assignments for the class, but none of them are incredibly hard. You'll cover a lot of interesting material, and it will be fun!
Try going for solo programming, it's more fun
Will take work and effort, but if you're interested in computer science, definitely worth it to take it!  Josh and Arvind are lots of fun.
You absolutely DON'T want to walk out of Princeton without doing COS 126, 226, and 217.

You don't really need to go to the actual lectures. Just follow the video lectures on Coursera, and play them at 2x the speed! (Think of all the time you can save this way.) The assignments are interesting, fun, and easy.
You should take it. It's interesting.
do the reading.
make sure you take this class seriously from the get-go; there is no PDF option anymore!
take it!
take it. you gon learn.
take this class! start programs early and study hard for tests. algorithm design questions are very difficult so make sure you look at old exams.
prereqs: COS 126 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.

title: Comparative Political Economy
reviews: Despite all I said, keep in mind this course is difficult. The midterm is a reality check.
Interesting course, deceptively hard.
Interesting material, Very easy (if you have a calculus background). Professor Londregan is the nicest guy and will go out of his way to help you learn concepts! Great PDF

Its hard and a bit more math than I expected but it was fair and pretty straight forward. Go to office hours if you need help on the problem sets, Londregan is very helpful and explains pretty much everything.
Take if you enjoy math models.
Take it but be prepared to work hard
Take it if you have any interest in political modeling.
Take this course if you have any interest in political economy, especially if your are an economics major. Londregan is a great lecturer and a very nice guy.

This class is quite interesting if you're good at manipulating variables and models.  Professor Londregan does a great job of explaining math concepts that you don't understand, but everything is much easier if you have a math background.
prereqs: Students are expected to have had ECO 101 and 102 and MAT 103 (or the equivalent of these three courses). Students who have taken ECO 300 (or ECO 310) will find the material in this course to be more transparent, and students who have not already taken POL 347 are encouraged to enroll in it concurrently..
descrip: This course forms part of the political economy core, and it introduces political economy models in the context of comparative politics. The course will emphasize the interaction between political institutions and economic goals and it will illustrate the application of the analytical and empirical methods developed in the other core courses in political economy. The course will apply the tools of political economy to understand the reasons for the differences among countries' levels of economic and political development, and to explain the interconnectedness of political and economic outcomes.

title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: A practical course devoted to scholarly writing intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets every two to three weeks. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.

title: Problems in Greek and Roman Philosophy - The Greco-Roman Medical Tradition
descrip: This course is an advanced introduction to the ancient Greco-Roman medical tradition, beginning with the Hippocratic Corpus and extending to Galen and Galenism. The course combines a study of the most important doctrines and debates within the tradition with a consideration of key anthropological, socio-cultural, and philosophical topics and problems (e.g., the nature of medical knowledge and expertise, the composition and functioning of the body, the relationship of body and soul, the physician-patient relationship). The course runs in tandem with a seminar at the University of Pennsylvania, culminating in a mini-conference in early May.

title: Fundamentals of Engineering Statistics
reviews: A good, if uninspiring, intro to stats. Bubeck is a good lecturer with a bit of a sense of humor. The slides available on blackboard are good enough that you wont really need to read the book, go to precept, (or as an extreme, go to lecture) every week. And there isn't much content over the course of a semester when compared with a math or cos class for instance. The psets are easy but annoying because there is no collaboration and not always well written. Everyone does well on tests since they aren't that hard. If you're interested, probably worth taking.
A solid introduction to the basics of statistics. If you take this class with Bubeck be prepared for a tricky derivation on the final. Rigolet's finals are much more straightforward.
As others have mentioned, it's a "lose-as-few-points-as-possible", just like COS 126 and MAT 202.  Don't mess up your calculations and the curve won't hurt you that much.

Be prepared for the vicious curve. There isn't a lot of R, and if you've taken AP stats, then you've seen all of this material before, but it is definitely difficult to get an A in this course because the average on the tests is often very high.
Be very thorough in your work. Make sure you know all assumptions when you perform various calculations.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. A WASTE OF TIME IF YOU TOOK AP STATS AND IF YOU DIDN'T, NOT THE MOST HELPFUL COURSE. TAKE ECON 202.

Definitely go to precepts, as they were extremely helpful. Also, if Lu Xia is still teaching next year, definitely try to get into her precept. As for the final, it was very challenging and kind of unexpected.
Don't take this course. Other courses teach more R and teach statistics better.
Go for it. The material is not so challenging that you can't wrap your brain around it. Bubeck is pretty good, just a tad boring.
Good class.
Good intro stats course, relatively easy material and problem sets to other stats courses or so I've heard.
Good stats course to take.
Grade deflation is not your friend in this class.
I don't know how good the other stats courses are, but the best reason for taking this one is if it's the only one that fits into your schedule. It's fairly redundant if you've taken AP Stat.
I enjoyed it. I thought the material was interesting and very useful.

I enjoyed this course as a basic introduction of statistics.  I had never taken stats before, so I don't know how much review it would be from other courses, but I found that the material went slowly enough that I could really absorb it, in contrast to other courses I have taken for my chemical engineering degree.  If you want to learn basic stats, take it, it's a good class.
I had to learn almost everything by myself with the textbook.
I learned a lot in this class.
I think taking it in the fall is better, because the final questions seem to be more regular.

I took this class with Bubeck and I recommend looking into taking it with Rigollet. I don't know how Rigollet's teaching is, but Bubeck is not a good lecturer. His pace is very slow, he covers the same material multiple times, he proves formulas rigorously (while no one follows along), and is not the best at answering student's questions. In fact, he sometimes even brushes the question off with "it's obvious that..." Bubeck's tests seem to always have a proof-based question out of nowhere, which I feel like you can't exactly know how to do by studying stats. Rigollet's exams seem more straightforward stats, even with its challenging questions. Read the textbook and lecture slides and you'll get the concepts you need (beware of Bubeck's lack of skill in making concise lecture slides). Attend precepts as they are helpful in how to approach stats problems.

I would not recommend taking this class.  I am a physics major who was looking at other potential fields.  This class was basically rote memorization and plugging in to formulas.  If you didn't get near 100% on everything, you would be destroyed by the curve.  I didn't really learn anything useful, and the class wasn't geared to teach anything useful.  If you're an ORF major, I guess you have to suffer.

I wouldn't recommend taking this course unless needed. It was quite easy to complete the work which is a bonus, but overall it's rather frustrating for an upperclassman who has taken much harder courses.

If there is one course I would have every Princeton student take, its this one. It's not tremendously complex or entertaining, but will come up again and again everywhere you look. You will thank yourself in the future for taking it.

If you are mathematically inclined and are only taking this course out of interest, I would recommend taking a higher level ORF course. What is needed from this class can be easily learned on your own.

If you have already taken AP Statistics and are not required to take this course, don't take it. If you do decide to take the course, you'll be fine as long as you understand the practice problems of each type.
If you're good at math, take it with Bubeck, and you'll get an A. Otherwise, avoid his class (mainly his final) like the plague.
If you've taken AP Stats, you shouldn't struggle too much for the majority of the class.
It has a tough curve, but definitely take it if you are interested in this.
It is not a difficult class, but it is kind of tricky.
It's a necessary class.  Piece of cake if you've taken AP Statistics before
It's an ok stats course
It's stuff you need to know, presented in a way that fluctuates wildly in how engaging it is.
Make sure to keep up with weekly readings and do the weekly problem sets, they really help in preparing for the midterm and final!

Most of you reading this already know this class isn't great, but you need to take it for whatever requirement you need. 

This class isn't as bad as most people make it out. However, it is by no means an enjoyable class; just remember to keep things in perspective and to form opinions by yourself.

Not a BAD course per se (and Lu Xia is an amazing preceptor) but if you want more straightforward exams I'd recommend taking with Rigollet. If you lean more towards proofs and theoretical understanding, then you'll probably enjoy Bubeck's class.

On the whole, the course is very interesting.  It is definitely challenging, especially with Bubeck, and how he presents the information. His lectures confused me and his exams were really challenging!  One of the midterms was easy, but in that situation, the curve is really rough because many students will get a perfect score. However, the final was very tough and required you to use what we learned and apply it to knew, never seen, situations. It was challenging but many people were disappointed.  I recommend the course because I think it does give a great basis and foundation of statistics compared to other stats courses as Princeton, WWS has much more coding which I feel is irrelevant without a proper foundation.  I would recommend this class and highly recommend focusing on the book above all in order to understand.  If you have precept with Xiaofeng be prepared to go over time and have a session that drags on, and be prepared to be confused by Bubeck.
Other than the final exam, I thought the class was very fair and not too difficult, and personally thought the material was interesting.
Precepts are the most important.
Prepare for a difficult final.
Standard intro stats course but beware of the unbelievably high curve and scores on the problem sets.
TAKE IT! It is not difficult if you pay attention in precept and read the book before tests.
Take it if you have to, and try to make sure your preceptor is Lu Xia.

Take it if you have to.  Good for MAE math elective.  Don't blow it off even though it's not the most interesting class.  It's easy to do well in if you're actually engaged in the class.  But it's very easy to let it slip by.
Take it if you need it. Better than any other stats courses... but still a stats course.
Take it in the fall if possible
Take it with Bubeck, not with Rigollet and try to have Lu as a preceptor.

Take this class if you want to get a solid foundation on the basics of statistics! Bubeck teaches spring and it's universally known that he is a harder instructor but I think you'll get more out of the class since he begins to push at more complex problems and expand upon the simple equations and concepts that are required. The curve is also more generous this semester so I've heard.
Take this course.
Take this if you're considering more statistics in the future. If not, you will probably get more out of a different statistics course.
Take this only if you're an ORF major.  Otherwise, you're probably better off taking stats in a different department, as it'll be less work.
The course can get boring sometimes, though it is important, especially for higher level courses.
The material itself isn't very difficult, but with a lot of people who have already taken statistics in this class, it can be difficult to get a high grade if you're taking it for the first time.
This course is a must-take for students without background in statistics.

This course is not going to be the most interesting course you'll ever take.  That being said, statistics are very useful and you will learn all of the important concepts.  Weichen is a GREAT preceptor.  Prof. Bubeck was a pretty decent lecturer.  Programming experiences (like COS 126) doesn't hurt since you will be using R and once you know how to program in one language, new ones come much more easily.

This is a challenging course if you have not taken AP Statistics before and are not a computer programmer (there is some programming in R involved). Be prepared to spend a lot of time studying/ going to office hours. You will learn a lot, but it is definitely a tough course. Make sure to go to Lu's precept- she is a great teacher!!!
This is a good introduction for stats as a Princeton engineer. Study hard for exams and beware of the curve.
This is a great stats course and is required for ORF majors. There is more R code in POL stats, but ORF stats is more rigorous.
Yes, a good introductory stats course
do readings, don't need to go to class
useful, and not too difficult class. what is expected is really clear, and you don't even have to go to all the lectures. not incredibly engaging or exciting, though.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Race in America
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Literature and Art in Renaissance France
prereqs: A 200-level French course or equivalent..
descrip: A survey of Renaissance literature and art in France from the late 15th to the early 17th centuries. A variety of cultural aspects of the period, including major literary and art works, will be considered, and we will intergrate the colleactions of the Princeton University Art Museum into the material under study. Museum curators will also provide assistance to students. Time will be divided between formal presentations, oral exposes, textual analyses, and discussion.

title: Germany since 1806
descrip: This course sets German history in a comparative context of international politics, demonstrating how nationalism and national unity emerged as responses to the European state system in the first half of the 19th century, how after 1871 German problems in turn affected the world, and finally why after 1945 Germany should be so prominent in super-power politics. It examines the origin of the German Revolution of 1989, and the place of Germany in Europe and the global order.

title: Interdisciplinary Legal Studies
descrip: Law in American universities is typically taught in professional degree programs. But increasingly, law has a life in the disciplines outside the law. This seminar introduces graduate students to interdisciplinary legal studies by tracing the history and trajectory of a new academic discipline of law. It traces the intellectual history of legal studies and its current state in the social sciences and humanities. Course examination will range across American, comparative and international topics. The seminar is aimed at PhD students who are specializing in a law-related field in their PhD programs and at PhD students with law degrees.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: The Experience of Modernity: A Survey of Modern Architecture in the West
descrip: An analysis of the emergence of modern architecture from the late nineteenth century to World War II, in light of new methodologies. It will focus not only on major monuments but also on issues of gender, class and ethnicity so as to cover the experience of modernity from a more pluralist point of view.

title: The Erotics of Medieval Literature
descrip: By reading a range of genres, from the concise obscenity of the fabliau through the philosophic dilation of the mystics, we will explore the principal erotic traditions of medieval literature. The interplay of sacred and sexuality, the formation and representation of desire, the categories of masculine and feminine will be our objects.

title: Enlightenment and Romanticism - Politics, Literature and the Arts between Revolutions and Empires
descrip: This seminar has a double goal: to reflect on the evolution of a multidisciplinary corpus from 1767 to 1830 and to help graduate students prepare interdisciplinary courses. The seminar will be dedicated to the connections between literature and the arts in time of political upheavals and aesthetic transformations. We will examine the concurrent development of pre-Romantic literature and neo-classical aesthetics, the evolution of political thought and the development of Romantic models, focusing on the fluidity among fields later divided into academic disciplines. Mostly in French.

title: Kiswahili Novel
descrip: Although the novel is the youngest genre in the Swahili critical tradition, it has experienced some of the most revolutionary and innovative experimentations since it gained mainstream prominence in Swahili literature, mainly during the post-colonial/independence literary revolution. This course is a reading of the Kiswahili novel with a critical analysis of the socio-political and critical trends in the literary world that have influenced the writings of contemporary Swahili novelists. The colonial/independence and post independence experience in east Africa are some of the motifs that inform the course readings and class discourse.

title: Mathematics in Engineering II
reviews: A dumbing down of important math. Easy.

Courseload wise, this course is very nice. However, it is not recommended for people who do not like math because it ends up reviewing some of the more difficult topics in Multi-Var and Diffy-Q (such as line integrals and 2-D PDE's).
Go to precept and office hours.
Good class, interesting and not much work (for the first half of the class atleast). Although you won't learn much more than you learned in MAE305.
Good if you are interested in engineering theories, but not necessary for understanding most topics.

Great class to take that exposes you to some interesting topics like conformal mapping. It isn't too time-consuming, but the material can be pretty difficult to grasp. Definitely go to recitation or office hours for help once you don't understand something.

If you are naturally good at maths and can do well in exams having only taken one or ZERO practice exam, then take the course. If not, seriously reconsider your choice. The course starts off with fairly easy materials but the second half gets a lot more difficult. Like MAT 201, 202, problem sets are textbook problems; however unlike 201 and 202 where they have practice exams dating back to 2008, this only has one. The questions on the practice final were also recycled in the problem set as "custom problems". So good luck to the people who are taking it next year!

If you enjoyed MAE 305 and managed it without a tremendous amount of difficulty, I think you'd enjoy this course if your schedule isn't already loaded.  Keep in mind that the course is more about complex analysis than PDEs, but that's OK, because the material taught is REALLY interesting.  The problem sets are all pretty manageable, yet take some time.  McAlpine is of course not is good as Howard Stone the Award-winner, yet stands as his own as an entertaining, at-times witty, and engaging lecturer (example: he does a crossword puzzle in class, no joke).  And while the exams can be challenging, you are MOSTLY pretty well prepared through HW problems that are secretly based literally off of old exam questions (the Custom problems).  If you are considering this as your 5th/distributional course, it may be too much.  But as a 3rd or 4th course to take, it's worth the time.  The material is interesting and the rest of it falls together pretty well.
If you have to take a 300 level math that isn't 305, this is probably by far the easiest. Otherwise I see no benefit.
