If you're a physics major, you've probably already learned half of the material. The new stuff is just complex integration and conformal mapping. The class is pretty easy. Psets took about 1-2 hours/week.
If you've had any exposure to differential equations or complex analysis, this class will be a breeze. Otherwise, it serves as a fairly good intro course, but there will certainly be some gaps.

Only take this course if you feel you really need complex analysis. Otherwise, take a more fun course like COS 340. PDEs are a side note in the course, and are taught more poorly than in Stone's MAE 305.
Take
Take it if you like MAE 305.

Take it, it's not as hard as you may have heard. If you have taken MAE 305 with Howard Stone, you will have already covered much of the course (probably in greater detail) until you reach the conformal mapping part.

The professor (Mike McAlpine) makes this course -- he has a great sense of humor, shows us cool demos in class rather than just writing equations on the board all day, and is very friendly & approachable. Problem sets and exams were medium difficulty, on par with an average BSE class. You are allowed a ton of cheatsheets, so no need to memorize various equations... just know how to apply everything. In closing, McAlpine was much better than the MAE 305 prof (Morton Kostin).

P.S. I was going to write some of the funny shit he says in class, but I realized it wouldn't do him justice here... his delivery is great.

This class should be called complex integrals and conformal mapping, because these are the only topics that McAlpine cares about. And neither is very useful in general. Side note: you will learn nothing about mathematics.

This class was a lie. I wanted to take a partial differential equations course and this had maybe one week of partial differential equations. The other topics, like complex analysis, and conformal mapping I had no intest in at all.

This course is really good to take after Diff Eqs (it's a lot easier) but you can also take it without ever having taken Diff Eqs. The homeworks don't ever take more than 5 hours, and the midterm and final weren't too hard.
This is a great class to practice differential equations skills and equips you with some important tools that will show up in other classes as well.

Took this as a complex analysis requirement for physics. Definitely way easier than a math class. McAlpine's a great guy, and lectures are reasonable. Problem sets are easy, exams are hard; McAlpine does it on purpose and it makes no sense.

It's really good material. Complex analysis is pretty cool, and conformal mapping is great.
prereqs: MAE 305 or MAT 301 or MAE 303.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to partial differential equations, covering PDEs of relevant interest in engineering and science problems. The material covered includes: (i) Complex analysis, including complex functions and series, (ii) Fourier series, integrals, and transforms, (iii) Solutions of partial differential equations, (iv) Conformal mapping and Potential theory, and (v) Applications of all the above. The material will be covered in three weekly lectures, plus one weekly AI session. Grades will be determined from weekly homework assignments, the midterm and final exam.

title: Studies in the Classical Tradition - Ancient Friendship and the Modern Self
descrip: We have never had so many 'friends' nor worried so much about the possible demise of "real friendship." We are in good company though. The ancient Greeks and Romans asked themselves repeatedly about the nature of genuine friendship; indeed, they taught us how to do so by way of poets, philosophers, essayists and artists down through the millenia. We will follow this legacy of writings about friendship from its origins in Plato, Aristotle, Cicero and St. Augustine, through the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Early Modern Europe, in a bid to arrive at an understanding of their contribution to accounts of the modern self.

title: Darwin and His Legacy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Criticism and Theory - Philosophical Marxism
descrip: This course revisits the longstanding issue of what makes Marxism a philosophy as opposed to a theory whose relation to philosophy is strictly "negative." We will seek to make some advances in the area of philosophical Marxism by paying attention to the following conjunction of topics: Marx, Hegel, and the ancient and medieval discipline of dialectic; Marx and philosophical materialism; Marxism and the questions of being and doing; Marxism and humanism; Marxism and the philosophy of nature; Marxism, metaphysics, and the contemplative arts; Marxism and futural thinking; Marxism, aesthetics, sensation, and phenomenology.

title: The Logic of Ethnographic Methods (Half-Term)
descrip: This mini seminar will address the central questions facing ethnographic research as it strives to be a part of social science. Among the issues we will consider are the roles of induction and deduction, generalizability, replicability, and linkages between micro and macro sociological units. Issues of ethnographic writing will also be addressed, particularly techinques for making descriptions of interactions, people, groups, networks, settings, and interactions. This is a half term course and meets during the second half of the semester.

title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition
descrip: A hands-on seminar exploring composition "in-response" to a range of music, from specific concert pieces (TBD) to un-notated popular and traditional musics.

title: Childhood Psychopathology
reviews: An amazing course. It will give you not only a great deal of "textbook" knowledge on childhood and adolescent psychological issues, but also a great deal of practical knowledge from multiple individuals involved in clinical treatment and childhood interventions. The papers require you to think critically and write effectively in limited space, but also guide you in considering a fuller range of issues than a simple psychiatric diagnosis.
Be prepared for a lot of work, but it's a great course.

DO.NOT.TAKE.THIS.CLASS.

i'm a psych major and it was THE WORST PSYCH CLASS EVER
Definitely take it if you are interested in the material.
Definitely take this class! Very interesting material and not too demanding.
Eden was a nice aspect of the class
Great course if you are interested in becoming a clinical child psychologist, otherwise this isn't the best psychology course for non-psychology majors.
Great course, definitely take it
He's a little fast, so try to keep up.
I loved it- interesting subject matter and very cool to get to go observe at Eden.
I think it depends on who's teaching it. Make sure it's someone with experience. Otherwise, if you've already taken abnormal psych, it might seem like a waste of time.
I think the class has potential, if it were organized better in future years.
I would say precepts are interesting and if you get involved you can learn a lot.
If you are interested in Autism, definitely take this class. Don't waste money on the textbook.
If you like the material, it's interesting.

It is worth taking for the Eden trips alone!  I now have a great understanding of autism and my heart goes out to parents of an autistic child.  Eden does a fantastic job and I will participate in their fundraisers!
Not too much work except for the midterm/final. A good initial exposure to clinical psychology.

Overall, it is a very interesting course if you are interested in the material. I recommend you to go to class and take good notes; it will make your life easier. Manageable course load but you will be writing a lot, but if you are cool with that, it?s a great course.

Professor Hambrick is fantastic.  He's a great lecturer, extremely knowledgeable, very open to questions, and super accessible (despite the fact that he is only on campus a few days a week). I really enjoyed every aspect of this class (especially the lectures, as he brought in many anecdotes from his work). However, there was a lack of organization at times, and he did end up changing the assignments so that they were significantly different from what the syllabus suggested. Still, a great class overall, very enjoyable, and well-taught.
Take it!
Take it! It's a nice spin on a Psychology course, I think. And do the reading before each class, since they're better as background and won't feel very fulfilling if read afterward.
Take it. Don't buy the textbook.
The lecture notes are important for the papers.
The readings were not essential but lectures were generally interesting and useful (although they were only once a week).
This class covers an incredibly interesting topic. In addition, you get to go to The Eden Institute to observe autistic children at school. Workload is reasonable, although the course is paper-heavy.

This class will give you a great chance to do observations at a school for children with autism.  It will also present extremely interesting material.  Lectures can feel a little directionless and vague, but are also humorous and insightful.
take it if interested
take this course, it provides invaluable exposure to autistic children.
this is one of my favorite classes.
prereqs: PSY 207 or PSY 254.
descrip: Examines major forms of childhood psychopathology, including autism and other life-span disorders. Issues such as childhood trauma, prevention, and continuity in the development of later adult disorders are also considered. Observations of and interactions with children with autism are also included in the course.

title: Turbulent Flow
reviews: If you take fluid mechanics and viscous flow & boundary layer, then this should be the next one. Also, for some of you who is interested in  turbulent combustion, this is also a good choice.
Make sure to use the given notes.

Read Bill George's notes in parallel with the course.

Recommended if you have a specific interest in turbulence.
Take it if you really want to begin to understand a subject that most engineers just avoid.
descrip: Physical and statistical descriptions of turbulence, and a critical review of phenomenological theories for turbulent flows. The course examines scales of motion; correlations and spectra; homogeneous turbulent flows; inhomogeneous shear flows; turbulent flows in pipes and channels; turbulent boundary layers; calculation methods for turbulent flows (Reynolds stress equations, LES, DNS); and current directions in turbulence research. This course is offered in alternate years.

title: Special Topics in Performance History and Theory - Playing Latino
descrip: This course examines how the pan-ethnic construction of Latina/o cultural identity was rehearsed in twentieth century U.S. popular performance. We will consider a wide array of popular performances and assess the ways such performances have staged shifting perceptions and presumptions about Latinas/os in the United States and how those performances have contributed to broader discourses of race, identity, culture and nation. Topics will include: heritage performance, liturgical drama, stand-up comedy, 'crossover' film/theatre, television, and visual art, as well as literary drama, performance art, and activist teatro.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
prereqs: ECO 362 and ECO 465.
descrip: This course will teach students about financial risk management through the lens of the recent financial crisis. Topics covered will include market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, and systemic risk. Students will draw on their background in economics, finance, probability theory and statistics. The class will be in seminar format and active participation in the discussion is encouraged.

profs.name: Jorge Alejandro Mendez Seijas, Course Head

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: Always attend class and make study guides for the tests because grammatical structures are important to maintain.
Be sure to participate everyday and to do the exercises every night before midnight.
Budget your time well. Don't leave everything until the end. I guess that goes for every class though.
DO RESEARCH ON THE PROFESSORS!!!!!!

Do all of the homework and don't be afraid to participate in class. This is the best language course ever, and is very enjoyable if you want to practice your spanish! I highly recommend getting Professor Moscard?-Vall?s as your instructor, she was a very kind and great teacher!

Do the assignments carefully, and don't be afraid to use a spanish dictionary when you want to spell out a complicated sentence. Don't shirk away and stick with easy sentences because you are afraid to make a mistake.
Do the homework on time and show up to class - it's the only way you'll learn.
Do the homework on time.
Do your iLrns. Work on writing and make sure that your writing correlates with the vocab. Talk with the professor if you need help.
Get Paloma.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students, especially if they are looking to improve their spanish speaking and writing skills.
I would recommend continuing with Spanish and this course in a requirement, so I guess I would recommend it.
I would say to make sure you participate in class and spend time actually doing the work, it is worthwhile.
If you take this class, make sure you go very fast on the exams. I would sometimes lose track of time and end up having to write the last, biggest essay in 4 minutes.
If you want to learn spanish, and get a decent grade while at it then you should take this class. The teaching staff is pretty good, and the grading is rather easy.
Jorge was an excellent professor. If you put effort into learning Spanish inside and outside of class, the course will be very fun and rewarding.
Language courses at princeton are way different than your high school language class. You get to learn so much and about things that you actually get to use.

Make sure to practice using what was learned in class in paragraph form, use it to write a story or discuss it with friends it helps. Also do your Ilearn a day in advance just in case you are unable to do it one day.
Make sure you take the class with Paloma Moscard?-Vall?s, makes Spanish 107 really fun.
Read your vocabulary and practice speaking outside of class.
Regardless of the university language requirement, take this course to get better at spanish! It's really useful and fun!
Spanish 107 is a good course. Everyday isn't too bad and it gives you a solid foundation in the language.
Study a little bit of vocab every night, so that you aren't trying to memorize them all the night before the test!
TAKE IT
Take it if you have interest. It's fun, although it's somewhat difficult to get an A.
Take it if you know some Spanish and need to fulfill the language requirement.
Take it if you need more grammar or if you're a beginner. If you want to improve your speaking, this could work, but maybe consider other options.
Take it with Paloma. Enjoy it, Spanish is a fun and useful language!
Take it. Not too difficult. Grading is easier than 103. Lorena is great.
Take the course, you'll love Lorena and learn SO MUCH!
Take this class if you are interested in making progress beyond grammar lessons. You will speak, interact, read newspapers in Spanish, and write! SPA 103 and 107 are great courses.
Take this course if you are interested in improving your Spanish and ability to converse, write, and read.
Take this course with Professor Amalia Lorena Camacho Guardado!!!
Take this course! It's great!

The course head, Jorge, has put together a comprensive, fun and engaging course that WILL improve your Spanish. I took Spanish through high school and learned more in one tern than in the rest of my spanish career combined.
The teacher will make all the difference so ask other students who you should try to get.
This is a really great class!
This was a great class! I learned a lot, but it was also fun.
Useful.  Definitely developed my skills as a spanish speaker and writer.
You should take it, especially if you have Lorena as an instructor.
do the homework nightly and write down all vocab words for flash cards
prereqs: SPA 102 or 103 with a passing grade or instructor's permission..
descrip: Spanish 107 is an intermediate/advanced language course that continues and reviews the introductory level Spanish, while further developing students' communication skills, both orally and in writing. This is achieved through communicative activities in and out of the classroom, as well as various types of materials, both audiovisual and written. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of the four basic language skills: listening comprehension, speaking, reading and writing. Students will also be qualified to take 200-level Spanish courses.

title: Intensive Elementary Chinese
descrip: Designed for students who already have some familiarity with spoken Mandarin. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills, and how to analyze grammar. Students who speak Mandarin with non-standard accents will be trained in standard pronunciation.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Transformations of the Self
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Random Fields and Random Media
descrip: Synthesis of methods to describe, analyze, and, where appropriate, predict and control random fields or distributed disordered systems. Second-order analysis of space-time processes. Spectral parameters, level excursions, and extremes. Discrete-unit stochastic processes. Fractal and multi-scale random fields. Simulation, parameter estimation, prediction, and optimal sampling. Stochastic growth processes.Risk assessment and management. Applications to a wide range of problems in engineering and the sciences.

title: High Tech Entrepreneurship
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologies for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Selected Topics in Optics and Optical Electronics
reviews: Great course for an overview of a broad array of spectroscopic techniques, and the readings and class presentations allow the student to pursue any topic they found particularly interesting.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in spectroscopy methods.
This class seemed to be designed for people who already work with lasers - not for people with a general interest on the topic.
This is a very comprehensive course on spectroscopy. Anyone who is interested in various forms of instrumentation of spectroscopy must take a look
descrip: Various aspects of laser spectroscopic sensing. Topics include physical principles of atomic and molecular spectroscopy, fundamentals of high resolution lasers spectroscopy, spectroscopic measurement techniques and instrumentation, laser sources and practical applications of spectroscopic sensing. Example applications of laser spectroscopy to chemical analysis and trace gas detection in fundamental science, industrial and environmental monitoring and medical diagnostics will be discussed.

title: Introductory Drawing
reviews: Definitely take this class! The work takes some time, but it's worth it.
Do not leave the weekly drawing psets to the last day. Start the day before because they take quite a while.

I really enjoyed this course, but I put neutral because it really depends on who the student is that's interested. If they have drawing experience, I'd recommend it wholeheartedly. But if they don't, I'd be sure to tell them that you will most likely not learn technique in this class. You will learn by doing and if that's something you're prepared to do - go ahead. But I think this approach is intimidating for students with no experience. There were quite a few students that dropped out after the first 2 classes, probably realizing they wouldn't "learn how to draw" in the conventional way. It all depends. If you're adventurous/have the stamina and passion for art, take this course. If not, you may want to consider something else.

I would highly recommend this to someone willing to learn more about drawing and become a better artist. Do not assume that because this is an art class that it will be easy. The afternoon and evening session feel like they take most of the day, and the homework is not insignificant.

The class is definitely worth it, especially if you have Daniel Heyman, but make sure that you are truly interested in the subject.
If you want an excellent introduction to drawing, I strongly recommend this course.
It's a fun class, take it, but realize the grading may be unfair.
It's a great course!
Life skill to be learned!

Overall, the course was extremely engaging and I felt that I learned more than I ever imagined about the classical techniques used to render form. Kurt was extraordinarily helpful and offered a lot of guidance and advice throughout the course. I would highly recommend this course, so long as you are willing to put in the time and energy.
Take it if you have a sincere interesting in drawing! Have to put in the effort though - can't really fake your homework. Rewarding and fun!
Take it.  It's fun and you don't have to be amazing at art.
Take the course if you enjoy and appreciate art, regardless of how much experience you have.
Take this course! It's for students who want to improve their technical skill. I feel that I improved my drawing skills tremendously.
The class does take a lot of time, because the class is about 6 hours on a single day (afternoon and night class) and homework generally takes 3-5 hours. But it's definitely worth it!
This class is very relaxing and you learn a lot! Take it!
This is a great course for students at any level who enjoy art. Kurt Kauper is a wonderful instructor, and I improved a great deal over the semester.
You definitely learn a lot.  Daniel is fun but has particular likes/dislikes.
You don't need to be experienced or very good at drawing, but you have to be very eager to draw.
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink, oil stick, collage, string, wire and clay. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be completed at the end of the term.

title: Studies in Religion - Holy Ordinary: Religious Dimensions in Contemporary Fiction
descrip: Through close reading and critical discussion of authors such as William Faulkner, George Bernanos, James Baldwin, and Walker Percy; and that of some contemporaries (Mark Saltzman, Marilyn Robinson, William Trevor, and Manil Suri), this seminar will focus on the moral and religious values they discover in the "holy ordinary" of their characters' lives. These works offer an alternative and often surprising mapping of the location and the meaning of sanctity, religion, and the sacred, exemplifying the insight of the 20th century French poet Paul Eluard, who once wrote, "There is another world, but it is within this one."

title: American Genres: Western, Screwball Comedy, Film Noir
descrip: Why did three distinctive American genres -- the Western, screwball comedy, film noir--achieve classic status in the same twenty-year period, 1936-1956? Part of the answer lies in global disruptions (economic depression, world war) that unsettled codes of behavior. Part lies in pivotal innovations in film technology (sound, color). But the decisive answer lies in a handful of directors who brilliantly reconfigured gendered relations in three different generic forms. And it is the surprising correspondences that emerge among these classic films, also the obvious divergences even within single genres, that will focus our discussion.

title: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Theater
reviews: Be open and be creative. Its not  a BS course. You must work and engage with your body and mind. You must know your pieces and feel them and own them. Please take this course, it was incredible!
Be prepared to try new things.
I would take this if you are interested in viewing theatre in a way that is not familiar to you. The de-emphasis of narrative that we had in this class really changed my thoughts on theatre a lot.
Not your average theater class. If you are open enough to new ideas and unfamiliar experiences, this class will enhance your ability to enjoy art of all kinds.
Rinde will give you a class like nothing you've taken before!
prereqs: Open to actors, dancers, composers, musicians, designers, directors, writers, and visual artists who are interested in working across their usual disciplinary borders..
descrip: Practicing thinking like a writer-who-thinks-like-an-actor-thinking-like-a-dancer-who-thinks-like-a-musician-thinking-like-a-painter-who-thinks-like-a-composer-who-directs. Exploring theater from all angles (words, music, movement, sculpture, design), we will be building an understanding of multi-dimensional theatrical logic over the course of the semester. We will explore, provoke, invent, and analyze the phenomenal, the poetic, the sententious, the informative, the confrontational, and the entertaining.

title: Senior Project
descrip: The senior project is a year long independent study intended for students who choose to work in teams of two or more. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Groups develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Groups develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Groups submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender History in the United States, 1940-2003
descrip: This course offers an overview of LGBT culture and history in the United States from 1945 to 2003. We will use a variety of historical and literary sources, including films and sound clips, to examine changes in lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered lives and experiences during the last half of the twentieth century. The course will encourage students to think about intersections of race, sexuality, and class, and how these categories have affected sexual minority communities. The course will also explore the impact that sexual minority communities have had on the law and culture in the United States since World War II.

title: Mind, Body, and Bioethics in Japan and Beyond
reviews: A good course, would recommend for those with interest, but v. intense for those who can only half-way commit.
Professor Borovoy is wonderful, and the readings are so interesting. You must take this class!
Take it - it's great.
Take it!
Take it, and read as much of the material as you can, not even because you absolutely need to to do well in the course, but because you will learn a lot.

This is a great class to take as a GHP elective or anyone that has interest in medical anthropology. One of my favorite classes at Princeton so far. The readings are fantastic, and Prof. Borovoy is great.
prereqs: One course in East Asian Studies or one course in cultural anthropology preferred..
descrip: The seminar will examine key concepts of the mind, the body, and the nature-culture distinction. We will study these issues in the context of Japanese beliefs about the good society, making connections between "lay culture," Japanese notions of social democracy, and "science culture." Topics include: styles of care for the mentally ill, the politics of disability, notions of human life and death, responses to bio-technology, the management of human materials (such as organs), cultural definitions of addiction and co-dependency, and the ethics of human enhancement.

title: Special Topics in Chinese History
descrip: Introduction to major classical sources for Chinese cultural history since 1000. Focus on weekly readings in classical materials accompanied by eleven (11) required library-based research exercises. The focus of this semester is on Classical Historiography and Readings, 1000-1900. Students focusing on Sino-Japanese studies are also welcome.

title: Latin American Politics though Film
descrip: See website

title: African American Literature: Harlem Renaissance to Present
reviews: Do as much reading as you can, always go to lecture and enjoy this course because you'll learn so much from Prof. Brooks.
If you're an english person you'll probably like this class more then I did.

No matter what you are studying, this course will really let you in on some major parts of American culture that you didn't know the origins of. I would recommend it to anyone at Princeton. The reading load is heavy but the workload outside of class is not bad, and the people you meet in this class are awesome.

One of the best I've taken. I'd recommend it to just about anyone, but particulalry people who are interested in interdisciplinary work--literature, but also history, cultural critique, and a lot of music too. Also I almost think everyone should be required to take some kind of African American Studies class- the subject matter is so relevant and important to modern America  that it would be great for people to have a greater awareness of these issues.
Review the texts more than once. Many of them require more than a single reading.

Take this course! Even if you aren't interested in AA lit, you can learn to think critically about texts. Also Prof. Brooks is a great person to get to know. She offers such great life, school and general advice. She's funny and really cares about her students.

This class was great. It was one of my favorites I've taken here at Princeton. Professor Brooks is great at teaching and really cares about her students. She also picks great readings - they're individually good, they tie together in really cool ways and Professor Brooks knows what to point out so you get the most out of it. She's awesome and the course is really great. I recommend taking it.
descrip: This course explores the relationship between cultural production and historical phenomena (such as the Great Migration, the Harlem Renaissance, and the Civil Rights Movement, for example) in 20th- and 21st-century African American literature. Additionally, we will consider the place of African American literature and cultural production in a diasporic context that encompasses decolonization, multiculturalism and globalization. Primary texts include novels, short fiction, drama, essays, poetry and performance culture.

title: Gendered Identities in Contemporary Korea
descrip: This course explores gender and gendered identities as produced and performed in different disciplinary frameworks and historical contexts in contemporary Korea. The relationship between gender formation and 20th century Korean history will be examined through the study of both texts (popular, journalistic, and scholarly) and visual media (films, television shows, and magazines). We will analyze the construction of masculinity and femininity in specific institutions and cultural practices such as military service, the sex industry, and marriage, as well as sports, cinema, and popular culture.

title: 1980s, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: European Social and Cultural History
descrip: A survey of recent scholarship in the social and cultural history of Early Modern Europe, ca. 1400-1800. Includes both classic topics like Renaissance and Reformation, and newer subjects like gender and the transnational.

title: What Makes for a Meaningful Life? A Search
descrip: See website

title: Science and Buddhism
descrip: See website

title: Race, Racism and Politics in Twentieth-Century America
reviews: I would suggest that other students invest in doing the readings and really be active in the conversations in seminar. If you do not participate and make a point of responding to your classmates,then you will not benefit as much

It's a class with Professor Kruse, so it's an obvious must-take, but it's different from his lectures.  He is quiet and lets us talk, but the class is an interesting person leading an interesting discussion, so overall, it's pretty good.  Lots of reading (that you should do), but the other work is very manageable!
TAKE THIS !

Take notes on the readings because you can get so much out of the discussions if you are well prepared. Start the final research paper early and meet with a library assistant to help facilitate the research process!
Why are you reading this? Go add this class to your course queue right now. TAKE IT!
Yes! If you're interested in US history, specifically the history of race, you will like this class!
take it! kruse is great
descrip: In this seminar, we will explore the relationship between race, racism and politics throughout twentieth-century America. Topics will include segregation; immigration and assimilation; the role of racial politics in World War II and the Cold War; the civil rights movement and white massive resistance; Black Power and the white backlash; and contemporary politics up to the election of Barack Obama.

title: Life on Mars or Maybe Not
descrip: See website

title: Public Leadership and Public Policy in the U.S.
reviews: Good easy course to take throughout the semester although the final paper does require a significant amount of work. Dr. Scovronick is good at leading discussions, there are movies every class (and cookies that he brings!), and he always lets you go early. However, feedback on the papers is not as good as it can be and the guidelines for both the midterm and final paper were unclear even after meeting with him.
If you're interested in leadership and public policy - TAKE THIS! Dr. Scovronick is an excellent professor who really pushes you to think critically.
THIS CLASS WAS AMAZING!
Take if you are interested in American presidential decisions or if you just want a closer look at key events in American history.  Reasonable reading load.  Lots of movies and lots of cookies.
Take it!

Take this course if you are interested in the material, but expect to have to read all of it. The assignments are not research assignments but instead force you to spit back the info - making it necessary that you read all of them (at least for the midterm and for the final).

The seminars themselves are pretty laid back - Dr. Scovronick doesn't teach the full 3 hrs; he brings cookies every day and shows movies

There's a lot of reading and papers are very demanding, but the seminars themselves are pretty chill. The onus is on you to show that you are engaged with the material because Dr. Scovronick does little hand-holding.

This is a really good class for anyone interested in major American policy decisions in the last 50 or so years--looking at events in the context of leadership is a great way to learn about what happened in the Cuban Missile Crisis, Vietnam, Iraq, etc. This seminar also breaks up the three hours and uses the time much more effectively than usual, and it's a pretty reasonable amount of reading.
descrip: This course will review key Presidential decisions on domestic and foreign policy developments such as the passage of civil rights legislation and the intervention in Iraq, and will consider the ethical, legal, and operational frameworks for effective, responsible public leadership. Students will review relevant literature from history, psychology and politics, discuss the central policy issues in each case, and evaluate the decision-making process in view of these frameworks.

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with visits by editors from leading presses). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.

title: Time Travel
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Musical Passions
prereqs: Open by application to the Class of 2003. Applications will be mailed out to all freshmen. They must be returned to 313A East Pyne by Wednesday, November 10..
descrip: See website

title: Literature and Food
descrip: Food, like books, can sustain and celebrate life. But also like books, food can serve as an agent and expression for discipline, fear, hunger, and loss. This course explores both the joyful and the dark sides of eating and traces how "taste" informs the various ways in which we ingest the world. We will consider how the meeting of food and word (in novels, poems, plays, and the cinema) informs large social categories and notions such as the nation, gender, race, ecology, family, and sophistication.

title: Electrical Engineering Master's Project
descrip: Spring course number to be used by Master of Engineering students who will be doing a project in lieu of a course.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Seminar in Pedagogy
descrip: Required weekly seminar for all English Department PhD students teaching for the first time at Princeton and scheduled to precept during the Spring 2012-13 semester. Balancing pedagogical theory with practical tips and collaborative discussion, the seminar helps students meet the challenges of their first semester in the classroom while also preparing them to lead their own courses. Topics include: integrated course design (preparing lesson plans; leading discussions; lecturing; teaching writing; assessment and grading); writing recommendations; and managing students, faculty, and time.

title: Rebellion and Recognition
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Korean I
prereqs: KOR 107 or placement test..
descrip: Advanced Korean is designed to develop fluency in both oral and literary skills. Expansion of vocabulary, practice in reading comprehension as well as active skills of conversation and writing are stressed through short readings and class discussion. Readings include different styles of writings on various topics including Korean culture, society, and history. 100 characters of Hanjas are introduced.

title: Law and Religion
descrip: This course will examine various ways in which law and religion can interrelate. Section I looks at Religion Clause jurisprudence in historical context; Section II examines how Christianity has shaped various aspects of the legal systems of the West, both substantively and rhetorically, and Section III explores various possibilities for critical or constructive engagement between normative religious claims and American law and human rights law.

title: Beethoven
reviews: Burnham is the best.
Do take this course! This was definately one of my favorite courses I've taken, and it's Beethoven with Prof. Burnham! What more can I say?
I highly recommend it.
I really enjoyed this course!  Prof Burnham is so nice!
If you in any way love music, and what it can do to you when you listen to it, take this course!
Professor Burnham is so funny! He did a really good job keeping us engaged with Beethoven 80 minutes twice a week. Take this class if you want to learn about Beethoven.
Take it!
Take this course even if you aren't a music major! You will learn a lot and will be able to tie concepts in with knowledge of European History, social history, philosophy, etc.
Take this if you're a music major, or any other Burnham course
as long as you enjoy beethoven, absolutely take it.
prereqs: Must have a year of theory (MUS 105/106)..
descrip: A survey of Beethoven's works in historical context. Questions of biography and influence will also be explored.

title: Energy for a Greenhouse-Constrained World
reviews: Take this class if you're interested in learning more about the environment. Covers a wide range of topics, and Prof. Larson is a very knowledgable and helpful guy who's always willing to help you learn more.
prereqs: Freshman physics and prior coursework in thermodynamics are required. Students from any department are welcome in the course. Graduate students are welcome..
descrip: Overview of technology challenges and opportunities for energy in the context of global warming. Physics of greenhouse warming, projected climate changes, and structure of US and global energy economy are reviewed. Majority of lectures emphasize understanding engineering and economics of low-carbon energy production systems, including solar, wind, nuclear fission, and capture/storage of fossil-fuel carbon. Energy storage and efficient energy use are also considered. Intersections of energy with economic development, international security, local environmental quality, and human behavior are also touched upon.

title: Elementary Chinese II
reviews: Absolutely take it. The class is totally engaging, and contrary to popular belief doesn't take that much outside work so long as you pay attention in class! Really great teachers who rotate throughout the week, which keeps class interesting, and a predictable schedule of quizzes and short essays so you always know what's coming.

After taking 101 you should know what to expect in terms of the rigor of this course. The coursework is about the same, but second semester, they introduce bi-weekly essay assignments. If you've come this far, I would recommend continuing. I struggled with 101, but it does get easier with time.

Although Chinese is probably the toughest language course you can take here at Princeton (it really does go above and beyond), you can guarantee proficiency and if you strive, fluency. The best teachers I've had the pleasure of having belong to this department. They are very easy to talk to and are truly interested in their students. I love how this department and its curriculum is organized so well and has many activities and assessments open to its students to improve their Chinese.
Continue working hard and paying attention to details. If you are not sure of a certain grammar structure, don't let it build up because the materials add on each week.
Don't be scared of this course. Since Chinese is on the rise, this course is really worth taking!

Don't try to cram characters at the last minute, but otherwise the workload is generally doable.  Also, don't turn in extra homework problems- if you do them, don't submit them to your preceptor, as they'll probably bring your grade down.  Definitely take this class if you're interested at all in Chinese, though.  If there's a better program out there, I haven't heard of it.

EXTREMELY well taught
Take it if you want to learn a lot of Chinese!
A little stressful and a lot of work for a language but well worth it
Go for it.
Go to every class
If you have not decided which language to take, Princeton offers a perfect Chinese course for beginners. CHI 101-102 is just too perfect.
If you have the interest and discipline to dedicate 1-2 hours each day, you can definitely learn a lot of Chinese and do very well.
If you want to learn Chinese take this course.
If you want to learn Chinese, look no further.

If you want to learn Chinese, this course (first year Chinese: CHI 101, 102) will be a solid beginning. It will be a lot of work, probably about 8 hours of homework per week. The pace is unrelenting. You really can't afford to miss class. Plan on doing Princeton in Beijing after first year Chinese so that you can -- in one year -- be reasonably functional in a language that is profoundly different from English. Be prepared for a big commitment.

If you've taken 101, obviously the natural next step would be to take 102 (to even get credit). But aside from that, this course, just like 101 is absolutely incredible! It is organized, the teachers are so friendly and willing to tailor teaching styles to each students' needs. The work load is about as much as it was for CHI 101, slightly more because of the bi-weekly short (less than 3 minutes) presentations. Whether you have a genuine interest in Chinese or are simply taking this class because it's a requirement, it's an excellent class and I'd strongly recommend it.
Intense but fun.
It can be  a lot of work, so be prepared to put in a lot of time, especially at the beginning.
It's a lot of work, but all of it is worth it, and the teachers are absolutely amazing. I loved my class.
It's not actually too much work as long as you do everything at a measured pace and every day.  The teachers are hilarious and its a great time in class.  Definitely take it!
Keep up with the lessons, listen to the recordings, and study each week's characters even when there's no Friday quiz.
Only take this class if you are genuinely interested in learning Chinese - if you are it is an excellent class
Practice and listen to recordings!
Stay on top of the vocabulary, it catches up to you in the end.

Study every single day. Don't leave the homework for Thursday night, or else you will hate yourself. Start studying the vocab on the first day of the week. Doing Chinese for an hour or two every day is much better than having it run your weekends. Just schedule your time out wisely.
TAKE IT. CHINESE AT PRINCETON IS AN EXPERIENCE YOU WOULD STRUGGLE TO FIND ELSEWHERE.
Take is without fear! You WILL learn Chinese!
Take it
Take it! :)

This language will come easier to some than others. Either way, you have to keep up because Chinese does get harder. Well, the structures do, but if you keep up, do your homework, practice speaking regularly, LISTEN to those tapes regularly, and keep listening in class, trying to comprehend everything--even those questions and statements not being said to you--if you do all this, Chinese will get easier. Just keep up the work, and you'll do fine.

While none of the material is crushingly hard in and of itself, the volume of material is both large and consistent, so be prepared to work hard. If you do, you'll learn a lot and have a very satisfying experience.
be prepared to work really hard and devote a lot of time to this course
great course, well-structured
take course if willing to put in work
very good.
prereqs: Chinese 101 or permission of the Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of Chinese 101. To develop basic competence in understanding, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese.

title: Intermediate Persian II
reviews: If you want to learn Persian, definitely take this course.
If you want to learn a Middle Eastern language that is fun and not as tough as Arabic, you should definitely learn Farsi
Take Persian at Princeton!
Take Persian!
prereqs: PER 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The emphasis is on reading modern and classical prose, and writing modern prose. Classes are conducted mostly in Persian. Advanced grammar drills and translation exercises.

title: American Art and Culture: The 1960s
descrip: An examination of the dominant art movement of the 1960's, Pop Art, through its major figures (Warhol, Lichtenstein, Oldenberg, Wesselman, Indiana, and Segal), and the interrelationships with contemporary advertising, e.g., imagery of sex, automobile culture, cigarettes and food, art and signs. The course will look at parallels in other cultural expressions, such as fiction, journalism, rock music, and film, to explore some of the defining social and artistic concerns of a very turbulent decade.

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Philosophy of Mathematics
descrip: A close reading of Euclid's Elements Book I, with particular attention to his handling of axioms, his logical techniques, and the influence of systems such as this on Plato and Aristotle.

title: Topics in International Relations - Military and Diplomatic Power: Getting the Right Mix
descrip: By means of historical and contemporary examples, this seminar will consider the balance among different instruments of U.S. foreign policy, ask whether that balance needs to be adjusted, and how to do it. Students will develop and apply a framework of values and strategic and operational principles for use in decision-making.

title: Chemical Biology II
reviews: Be thoroughly familiar with material in lecture notes for the exams.
If you like to learn more about chem bio, this is for you. Otherwise be prepared!!
It's a good course and I recommend doing all the readings.
It's a great course for the chembio students.
Take it =)
Very good course. You will learn a lot.
descrip: The course will provide an in depth treatment of protein chemistry and natural products biosynthesis. Topics include; amino acid, peptide and protein chemistry; protein engineering; the logic and enzymology of natural product biosynthesis with a focus on non-ribosomal peptide synthesis and polyketide synthesis.

title: Microeconomics for Public Policy
reviews: Definitely, and definitely take it with Sylvain. He was great at explaining the little bit of math involved, and did a great job of explaining how the key concepts would matter to policy makers.
Take it with Prof. Chassang, cool guy
Take this course, especially if you're interested in econ, or need an econ class for Woody Woo.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ECO 100. This course is not open to students who have taken ECO 300 or ECO 310..
descrip: Microeconomics is the study of how people and societies confront scarcity. This course, taught at the intermediate level, focuses on markets as a mechanism for dealing with scarcity. We will clarify when markets are expected to work, as well as reasons why they might fail (asymmetric information, lack of competition, externalities.)

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Beginning Polish II
prereqs: PLS 101.
descrip: A continuation of PLS 101. This course continues to develop and refine the four language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing), teaching all fundamental aspects of Polish grammar and basic communication skills on a variety of situations. As the course progresses, the rich Central European culture will be sampled through poetry, film and fictional, as well as expository prose.

title: Leadership
descrip: What do leaders actually do? What kinds of traits are important for successful leadership? How do followers influence the behavior of leaders? And what impact does exercising power have on your personality? The course draws from classical political theory (including Plato, Machiavelli, and Max Weber), current "leadership literature," and case studies of decision-making. Among the topics considered are expertise and collaboration, responsibility and accountability, women and leadership, and leadership in various kinds of organizations.

title: Genesis and Cosmogony in Antiquity
descrip: Ancient accounts and discussions of the world's creation negotiated fundamental problems such as the origin of evil, the nature of mankind and its relation to animals or divine beings, and the difference between male and female. Such accounts also figure prominently in probing topics central to the study of religion: the function of myths and their relation to other forms of expression, the politics of religious identity, and the transmission of ideas across boundaries. This course examines both sets of questions through close readings of Genesis and its earliest interpretations as well as other texts from the Mediterranean and Near East.

title: Introduction to Italy Today
reviews: Definitely take this course. It's a nice jump from the 100- level courses. You don't go over grammar as much, but you do review and it's totally doable coming from the 100-levels.
I would not recommend this course, unless you have to take it. It's not very engaging or fun, and there is a lot of reading!
If you've made it past 107 and enjoy the language, take this class.
This course is totally manageable and most of the topics are interesting.  I took it coming out of high school as my first Italian course here and I was able to do pretty well.
prereqs: ITA 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to familiarize the student with major features of contemporary Italy and its culture. Its purpose is to develop the student's ability to communicate effectively in present-day Italy. The course emphasizes Italian social, political, and economic institutions, doing so through the analysis of cultural and social differences between Italians and Americans in such everyday concerns as money, work and leisure. NOTE: no books will have to be purchased for this course since all reading materials will be available on Blackboard.

title: Theory and Methods of Comparative Literature: Critical and Literary Theory
reviews: If you want to get an excellent grasp on central problems in literary theory in a comprehensible way, take this course. Unlike other theory courses this one was well organized and Professor Brodsky actually knows well what she is talking about.

It takes a special kind of person to sit through Brodsky's courses. She is a genius. She really knows her stuff. Her personality takes a bit getting used to. Sometimes she may seem a bit cutting, but I definitely do not think she intends to be malicious. Take it! The readings are great. You'll get a lot out of them and they'll come in handy for other courses.
It's a great course if you are interested in the theory. There is not a lot of work and you're expected to take initiative within the class.
take this course. do the readings. prepare questions and ask them.
descrip: A course in the foundational texts of contemporary critical theory. The relationships among literature, philosophy, aesthetics, and linguistics will be investigated as they come to the fore in the intellectual development of the following, among others: modern philology, New Criticism, hermeneutics, structuralism, speech act theory, Marxist and cultural criticism, historical-epistemological aesthetics, rhetorical criticism, and poststructuralism.

title: Urban Modernism and Its Discontents
reviews: Although the structure of the seminars sometimes feels confusing and a little disjunctive, the subject is really interesting and Bruno is a fantastic professor to get to know.
Bruno was a great teacher. Very passionate about the material and very open to letting the conversation take its natural course
Great course and great professor.

If you like architectural theory, its a great class for you. Unfortunately, I found it somewhat difficult to buy into. Be prepared for pretty heavy readings. Professor Carvalho is wonderful to take a class with, but this may perhaps not be his strongest offering.
Keep up with the readings and start paper discussions with professor early.
Professor Carvalho is a great professor. The discussions are very open, but you can learn a lot from them.

TAKE THIS CLASS. Even if just the chance to listen to Bruno lecture. He is incredible and truly makes this class. As a science major who had never taken an urban class, I did not feel like I was leg down. Bruno encourages you to explore whatever areas you are interested in and is really just an amazing/ incredibly knowledgable individual.
Take it!

Take it! Bruno is great, readings are fun, great introduction to Latin American urban history and street/popular culture. One has a lot of flexibility with paper and presentation topics and Bruno will help you finding sources.

This is one of the best seminar courses I've taken at Princeton. Carvalho is so engaged and passionate about the material and allows students more freedom to explore what they're interested in than any other professor I've encountered. His expectations are very reasonable and the workload is really manageable. I really really enjoyed this class.
great course take it Bruno is the man
descrip: This interdisciplinary course explores some of the tensions between modernization projects and cultural production during the late 19th and 20th centuries, examining representations of the city in literature (poetry and prose), maps, film, painting, photography, and music. We will focus on the cultures and histories of major cities in the Spanish and Portuguese-speaking worlds. Topics include Rio de Janeiro's favelas and the potential consequences of the 2016 Olympics; the architectural history of Brazil's modernist capital; Mexico City's explosion into a megalopolis.

title: Art and Science of Motorcycle Design
descrip: See website

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
descrip: This seminar course will introduce the students to recent developments in stochastic analysis.

title: Topics in Social Stratification (Half-Term) - Race and Schooling
descrip: Education is becoming increasingly important for upward social mobility in the U.S. and abroad and has been linked to societal inequalities in health, income, and other life-chance measures. This seminar engages both quantitative and qualitative studies and focuses on 1) the historical trends and understanding of racial/ethnic differences in achievement, and 2) the current issues/debates within the sociology of education literature. In addition to considering the relative underachievement of blacks and latino/as, this course also examines the academic success of Asian Americans and Asians living within the U.S.

title: Atmospheric Chemistry
descrip: Natural gas phase and heterogeneous chemistry in the troposphere and stratosphere, with a focus on elementary chemical kinetics; photolysis processes; oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen chemistry; transport of atmospheric trace species; tropospheric hydrocarbon chemistry and stratospheric halogen chemistry; stratospheric ozone destruction; local and regional air pollution, and chemistry-climate interactions are studied.

title: Music and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Greek Historians - Herodotus
prereqs: CLG 105 and CLG 108..
descrip: The course will focus on the narrative of the Ionian Revolt against Persia to discuss aspects of Herodotus' work.

title: Special Topics in Molecular Biology - Psychopharmacology
reviews:
1) Fascinating topic
2) Professor Stock is great at explaining things
3) Far more undergrads than grad students; don't be scared by the 500-level listing

Definitely take this class. It's that sort of relaxed learning environment that every professor wants to make but few actually succeed at. I learned a lot in this course, and I think if you have interest in either the biology of the central nervous system or the medical applications of academic research, you should take this course.
Really interesting class, definitely reap what you make of it. TAKE ITT
Strongly Recommend
Suuuuuuuuuuper chill.
TAKE IT. JUST TAKE IT
Take it to learn!
prereqs: Intro Biochemistry (MOL345) or equivalent..
descrip: The molecular biology and biochemistry of pharmaceuticals and natural products that target CNS function will be examined. Specific topics include: the blood-brain barrier, addiction and tolerance, analgesia, treatments for mood disorders, cognitive enhancement, stimulants and ADHD, treatment of dementias such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease, psychotropic drugs, antipsychotics and the treatment of schizophrenia.

title: Advanced Quantum Chemistry
reviews: Liking math helps a lot.
Need a background in quantum mechanics and an open mind.
Recommended that CHM501 be taken first in the fall.

You can take this course. But you should know that actually it is not standard quantum chemistry course. The right name fro this course could be "Quantum-classical analogy". We had pure math and physics course instead of chemistry applications of quantum mechanics.
descrip: Traditionally quantum mechanics is presented as the antipode to classical mechanics; as a result, no attempt at reconciliation is made. The primary purpose of the course is to present quantum and classical mechanics in a unified fashion by clarifying only essential differences. We will also see how quantum-mechanical methods can be applied to classical dynamics and how quantum phenomena have classical analogies.

title: Aircraft Design
reviews: Buy Raymer. Talk to Gigi, he's helpful. Don't expect to get much out of lecture. For such a cool sounding class, it is somewhat disappointing unless you are extremely motivated to learn the material yourself.
Buy a copy of Raymer. It's not that difficult of a course. If you put enough in, you can get  some cool things out.

Designing anything well takes a lot of time. If you are senior, you probably won't have a lot time beyond working on your thesis. Try your best to work on this project as well as your thesis, and definitely make sure your assigned group has juniors as well.
Get started early with the project and don't be afraid to ask for help.
Good course. Workload is really what you choose it to be, especially in a group project setting. Go to Gigi early with questions.
Great design experience opportunity.
I would not recommend this course. It was not all that interesting. I did learn some useful things but overall a poorly designed course.

If you love airplanes, take this over MAE 341/342. The opportunity to engage in such an expansive, complex, and interesting design project means you can overlook some of the problems simply because there is no other school at Princeton like it.
It's interesting, you'll learn a lot.
Read Raymer and start design projects early.

Take it if you're interested at all in aerospace engineering. There is no building or machining though.  Semester long report.  Work with people you really like.  It worked out for us -- our group is turning our project into a senior project/thesis next year.

This is a design course, so expect it to be open ended.  You will get out of this class what you put into it especially since the class is helps set the class direction.  You can teach yourself a lot in the class if you have the motivation and opportunity.
Try not to take senior spring.
Very loosely structured and independent course. What you put in it what you get out, which can be a lot.
You're going to take this class because you have to for the MAE degree. That being said, expect to work hard at the end on the projects. Give yourself time.
prereqs: MAE 321 and MAE 331 and MAE 335..
descrip: This course discusses methods for the design of aircraft. Topics in aerodynamics, and structural design are emphasized in the context of a design project. Students will be required to complete a design project to fulfill the requirements of this class.

title: Introduction to Formal Semantics
reviews: AVOID AVOID AVOID AVOID AVOID

Avoid unless you're strongly interested in the subject and are willing to take the readings to heart.  As a philosophy course, it's not bad; as a linguistics course, it leaves something to be desired.
Be prepared to do a lot of independent work. If you are seriously interested in philosophy of language, I recommend the class.
I strongly recommend this course to anyone looking to take a course in philosophy or linguistics. As a warning - more philosophy-heavy than I had expected.
I would not recommend taking a class with these professors. The quality of the class itself is probably dependent on the professors.
NOOOOOOOOOO DONT DO IT
Probably don't take this course. I've heard Edwin Williams offers one in the Linguistics department which is more rigorous--quite hard, actually--but very good.

Take a different course, or, if you are intent on taking the course, make sure you have a strong background knowledge in the topics the course is covering, Unfortunately, this course has been one of my least favorite/least enjoyable at Princeton.
Take something else.  You will not enjoy it.
This is not an introductory course.
prereqs: Course open to freshmen..
descrip: We will study a formal approach to meaning that develops a technical framework for assigning meanings to expressions (primarily English ones) that makes use of functions and sets. This is a course for anyone interested in how formal methods can be applied to the study of language. The course covers material that is essential for any prospective student of linguistics or philosophy of language.

title: Genes, Health, and Society
reviews: .I wouldn't take MOL205 again but it wasn't too difficult and would probably be fine to PDF if you're interested in the material. Dante Ricci is a great preceptor.

A semi-easy STN if you already have some background in MOL (maybe MOL 101). But if not, stay away. There also isn't as much application to society as I thought there would be. But Professor Rosenberg is extremely nice and knowledgeable. Also, the visits from patients with various genetic conditions were extremely enlightening and fascinating.
A terrible course.  The "society" aspect of the class was hardly covered.  Save your 100  dollars per lecture and just buy a genetics textbook because you would probably learn more that way.

DO NOT TAKE IT. You can't PDF the class and the material is way too hard for it to be designated as an STN option for non-science majors. Prof. Rosenberg is a bad lecturer but you have to attend all the lectures because of the clicker quiz in each one (which are ridiculously difficult, even if you've done all the reading). Everyone I've talked to in the class was extremely frustrated by the level of difficulty, which made it hard to enjoy learning about the material, which was actually interesting.

Do not listen to the people who tell you to take this if you are not a MOL concentrator or a pre-med student.  You should NOT take this course if you are just interested in biology, and do not want a course of hours of memorization and frustration.

Do not underestimate the difficulty of this course. The midterm caught many people off guard, as did the strict grading of the OpEd. Take thorough notes on the textbook readings so that studying is easier and more efficient later on.
Do the textbook readings! They'll help you for clicker questions AND exams.

Don't bother reading the posted articles, they are not tested (although that may change). Read the textbook (obviously). You will eventually get the hang of what the course instructors feel is important in the material, hopefully that happens before most of the grades are in.
Don't take it.
Don't take this course if you don't know a lot about biology/genetics. You will learn a lot about basic biology but not too much about the societal implications of scientific research.
Don't unless you're really interested.  Much better ST's out there.

For a distribution req, this course demanded a lot of work.  Unfortunately, this wasn't because the material was particularly challenging, but instead because the Professor required us to memorize an large amount of obscure details for the final.  By far the worst part of the class was the boredom of the lectures.  Prof. Rosenberg only covered about 20% of what was in each week's readings, but we were expected to know all of it for the iClicker quizzes and the exams.  And in general, his lectures were just rehashing of the parts of the readings he did cover.  But there was no skipping lecture because the clicker questions were graded for each week.  In short, while this class will teach you something about genetics, it is poorly structured and lectures are hardly worth the effort.
Good STN. I'm not a science person, but I can see how the information is relevant. If you don't try or read, don't expect an easy A (and it's npdf), but a B is very attainable.
Good class. Not the most work. Though at the end of the day it is a science class where you gotta memorize.
Hopefully, either the lectures or the book will be changed. I would advise other students to make sure they have a very good preceptor, as I did!
I found this to be a very interesting class for someone who is interested in the body and genetics. I recommend it!
I highly recommend taking this class!
I would advise thinking carefully before you take this course. It is npdf which is a bit of a trap and it is a lot harder than expected.
I would urge students to read the textbook closely before lecture.
It's a really interesting way to fulfill an STN if science isn't your forte. What you learn has very palpable applications to your life and is important to know.
It's great! I really learned why it is so important to be knowledgeable about this area that is rapidly developing and becoming a larger part of everyday life.
Lectures are not necessary, but you have to show up for clicker questions.

Pretty straight-forward class. You get out what you put in, especially with readings because there are clicker questions at the start of each lecture (that seem really randomly chosen so they are either super specific or absurdly general and easy).
READ

Stay on top of the readings, as it greatly helps expand your knowledge, your attention in lecture, and your level of readiness come clicker quizzes and exams. Also, make sure to seek help in areas that you are uncomfortable with, as the preceptors are more than supportive to go through material with you.
Strongly Recommended
Take it if your'e interested

Take notes as you do your textbook reading, and follow along with them at lectures. This'll keep you from having to write down the same information twice, and Prof. Rosenberg often clarifies/adds to some concepts.
Take this course if you enjoy inheritance and medicine. It has a lot of real-world applications.

This course isn't bad, however depending on what you are looking for, I think there are better courses offered at Princeton.
If you want genetics, take MOL 342.  
If you want an introduction to biology, take MOL 215 (or MOL 214- though watch out for the pre-meds!).  
If you want a bioethics/science policy class, take WWS/MOL 320.

In particular, it seems like this class and WWS 320 are trying to do the same thing, and while both are interesting, ultimately WWS 320 is much better.  This class tries to hard to broach both the science and social aspects, and as a result does both fairly poorly.  While interesting if you have already taken the other classes, any of the previously listed courses will probably be a much better choice depending on what you are looking for.

This course sounds really interesting, and if you're really interested in the modern influence of science and genetics, it is. It may be difficult if you have no science background, but also a little simple if you know science well. It's basically completely taught from the textbook, so that's annoying, but if you do it, at least you will be able to follow along in lectures. Basically, don't take this for an easy STN.
This course was very interesting and gives a lot of good information about genetics.  Try to get in the professor's precept.  And read the textbook before lecture always.
Would recommend for distribution requirement.
take detailed notes and read each chapter each week
this course is not easy and it has a litttle work, but it is a very interesting class
this is NOT i repeat, NOT an easy course to do great in.  It is a low level MOL class which I thought as a bio guy would be easy, but the topics are pretty complex at times.
descrip: What should students know about their genes and genomes? Today, the field of Human Genetics is explored and debated like no other. To understand the medical applications and ethical implications of Human Genetics, one must grasp its scientific foundations. We will approach these topics using: lectures, textbook, journal and newspaper readings, precept discussions, and patient interviews. We will consider the following subjects: gene structure and function; the genetics and genomics of populations and of selected human disorders (cancer, mental illness, metabolic diseases); and clinical genetics (inheritance patterns, diagnosis, treatment).

title: Seminar in Contemporary Art and Theory - When is Art?
descrip: Taking its cue from the philosopher Nelson Goodman's suggestion that we ask not "what is art?", but "when is art?", this seminar explores questions related to the temporal boundaries of works of art. While we focus on case studies from the 1960s to the present that problematize the stability of the artwork (whether through instruction-based propositions, performances and practice-oriented interventions, transitory forms and materials, copies and fakes), we will also consider scholarship from disparate chronological periods and disciplines in order to theorize the multiple temporalities of contemporary art.

title: Quantitative Analysis for Public Policy
descrip: The course is designed for students preparing to incorporate statistical analysis in their policy research. In the context of case studies, it will cover the principal methods of data analysis and applied statistics in social science and policy research, including multiple regression, analysis of variance and nonparametric methods. Students are expected to have some knowledge of basic probability and statistical concepts.

title: Introduction to Archaeology
descrip: Introduction to Archaeology is intended for any student with interests in this interdisciplinary field. Lectures present the history, practices, and theories behind excavation and survey, dating techniques, archaeological ethics, and interpretations of original material sources, drawing on approaches from the humanities and the sciences. Student projects use objects, monuments, records, and equipment at Princeton and in area museums.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy Extensions: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Provides a thorough examination of statistical methods employed in public policy analysis, with a particular emphasis on regression methods which are frequently employed in research across the social sciences. This course emphasizes intuitive understanding of the central concepts, and develops in students the ability to choose and employ the appropriate tool for a particular research problem, and understand the limitations of the techniques. Prerequisite: 507b.

title: Christianity along the Silk Road
descrip: Syriac is a dialect of Aramaic very similar to the language spoken by Jesus in first-century Palestine. Aramaic-speaking Christians in the Near East soon adopted Syriac as their literary language; by the early fourteenth century, Syriac Christianity spread from the western Mediterranean to China. In this seminar we shall be exploring the origins of Syriac Christianity in the Near East and its spread along the Silk Road before 1500.

title: American Poetry - Ezra Pound and Modern Poetry
descrip: This seminar surveys the work and influence of Ezra Pound. In the first six weeks of the course, we will examine his career in London: we will read his major poetry and prose, as well as the work of his associates -- H.D., Frost, Yeats, Monroe, Lewis, Eliot, Ford, Williams, among others. In the final six weeks, we will focus on his later work, especially the Cantos, and his influence on younger poets, including Oppen, Bunting, Zukofsky, and Olson. Throughout the course, we will pay special attention to the relation between art and community, and art and politics.

title: The Literature of Fact - Narrative Writing
reviews: If you don't take a class with Evan Thomas before graduating, you will subconsciously regret it.
Take it!
Take it, take it, take it.

Take it.  Professor Thomas has a knack for zeroing in on your weaknesses (don't be afraid--he sees your strengths too) and helping you improve as a writer and thinker.  Between his guidance and the lineup of visitors, this is an amazing course.
Take this class over fiction. Take fiction later.
Take this class. Evan really cares about his students and will improve your writing.
Take this course-- you will be a better writer and a better person for it. Prof. Thomas is great.
The professor is amazing and writing is awesome. Apply for it and take it!
Write and rewrite!
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: This is a course in the art of telling true stories. We will examine all the essential aspects of successful narrative writing: timing and pacing, character development, the sharpening of conflict and plot, the art of interviewing and reporting - how to write stories that move and are human. There will be individual conferences every other week to go over written work as well as guest speakers.

title: Italian Renaissance Painting and Sculpture
reviews: Definitely recommend. Prof. Markey is a great professor - nice, engaging with students and very helpful, and the subject matter is interesting if you have any interest in art. Also not that much writing for an LA with one short paper and a longer 8-10 page research paper
Do not take! Interesting topic. Boring lectures. and just a lot of memorization instead of interpretation.
Do the readings on time.
Easy to pass, hard to master. Fun, interesting, makes you feel "cultured." Markey is a great professor. Great PDF course. Fair warning: Lots of nudity.
Go to class
Go to every lecture
Go to every lecture.

If you are interested in art history and the Renaissance in particular, definitely take this course! Prof. Markey is very approachable and runs all the precepts which is a plus. The class also gave us the opportunity to look at the museum and drawings collections which was really fascinating. The amount of work is also definitely manageable, and the smaller class size is nice.
If you are interested in the Italian Renaissance, or if you are an artist interested in learning about the roots of your craft this course is very rewarding and even fun.
If you are interested in the material, this is a good class. Otherwise, it may come off as dry or dragging at times. Usually, it is interesting, though.
If you're interested in Italian art, definitely take this class. The workload is reasonable and Prof. Markey's instructions are very clear, making it easy to prepare for both papers and exams.
Take it if you are interested.  Not too hard, and exams are mostly memorizations
Take it!
Take this--there is an expected amount of work and the material and professor are fabulous.
Totally take it. Not overwhelming, very interesting.
