You don't need to read the textbook ever and you can still do well, although it's interesting extra info if you're curious.  I loved this course and would definitely recommend it.  If you've been to Italy it's especially fun to take.
start studying well in advance so as not to cram dates and information; do all the precept reading
descrip: Lectures will examine the birth, rise and flowering of Italian Renaissance art in Tuscany, Rome and Venice from about 1250 to 1600 A.D., with emphasis on the 15th and 16th centuries. Artists and works of art will be presented, whenever possible and relevant, within their cultural, political, social, technological and/or economic circumstances. Among the major artists to be studied: Giotto, Ghiberti, Donatello, Masaccio, Botticelli, Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Titian.

title: Scientific Integrity in the Practice of Molecular Biology
reviews: Drink lots of coffee.
It's mandatory, otherwise do not come near this course!
Take notes, and write down any websites that are shown in class. These materials will become a helpful reference for the future.
n/a
descrip: This course satisfies the mandate of the National Institutes of Health for training of molecular biologists in the ethical practice of science. The nature of -- and response to -- personal "misconduct" will be a principle focus. Through case studies and class discussion, we will examine the societal framework for the public support of basic biomedical research, the rights and responsibilities of students and mentors in the conduct of that research, and the significance of intellectual property. We will also review regulations concerning research with human subjects and animals.

title: Quantitative Analysis II
descrip: This course builds upon POL 571 and introduces students to applied regression analysis in cross-section settings. It begins with the basic principles of statistical inference, and then covers various statistical techniques including linear regression, instrumental variables, structural equation models, maximum likelihood estimation, and discrete choice models. The materials are taught at the level of Hayashi's Econometrics, and Freedman's Statistical Methods. Prerequisite: POL 502 (or permission of instructor) and POL 571.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: I would recommend this course to everyone interested in capital markets and finance in general, not only to people looking to focus in Asia.

OK, so you think this course may be easy? Consider a few points just to nuance this:
1) It is not easy to make a number of relevant points in front of 60 other students when they are all trying hard to speak as well.
2) It is not easy to show Professor de Swaan that you have read the materials and get that A grade. He is very discerning and will only reward the best.
Take it
very interesting class, worth taking
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and the policy decisions faced by the Chinese and US governments relative to existing global imbalances.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Reactions and Mechanisms
reviews: Consider PDFing since it's too easy to get caught up in the minutiae of this course.

Definitely take this course over 407. The final seems scary, but it's really not, since the professor provides practice finals of 5 previous years. I learned a lot of chemistry, and learned to think like a chemist, which I really value. Things started to come together towards the end of the course, which was a great feeling! :)
Don't.  No feedback, so it's very hard to figure out how well you understand the material.  Schwartz does not do a good job explaining.
Get a study group. But make sure that in your study group, you're talking, and you're understanding why your answers may or may not be correct.
Interesting chemistry class, but oftentimes the class notes are difficult to follow.
It is hard, but worth it.
Schwartz can be harsh and at times even shrill, but this is a rewarding course that teaches you a lot about chemistry that you will have trouble learning elsewhere.
Stay on top of the material. Don't neglect the problem sets as a good way to learn.
Take it!
Take it! Schwartz makes this class very engaging and you will develop a much better sense of chemical intuition.

The course is really interesting, and Prof. Schwartz is a pretty engaging lecturer. He's a bit sassy and can get impatient with questions, but he's ultimately very helpful. If you took both semesters of Orgo, you should be fine in this course, even as a non-Chem major.
This class is DIFFICULT. It will twist your brains in ways you never could have imagined. In the end, you gain a new way of thinking. Don't use your intuition and approach everything rationally.

This class is a great class, but arguable one of the hardest and most frustrating classes I've taken at Princeton. Lectures are engaging and interesting, both because Prof Schwartz is a funny, cynical and sassy man, but also because if you so much miss a minute of it you are screwed. Take good notes, even record lectures if you have to, because there is no textbook, and the notes are not complete. If you liked coming up with mechanisms in orgo, you'll like this class, but it will be hard work. You also grade your own problem sets, which is pretty frustrating too because you really have no idea if you're including the right things until the final, which pretty much counts for everything. All that being said, you develop an intuition to think, approach problems logically, everything that 'science' is supposed to teach you.
This is a good class; it strengthens your chemical problem-solving skills, and Prof. Schwartz is great.  It's not easy, though--I recommend finding a group of people to work on the problem sets with.
This is an interesting course. You will learn both about inorganic chemistry and about how to think scientifically and critically.
take this instead of 407 but hard to do well with only just a final
descrip: Structure-reactivity correlations for inorganic complexes will be emphasized. Ligand substitution and electron transfer processes will be presented. The course will highlight applications of inorganic and organometallic chemistry to areas of current interest to both organic and inorganic chemists. These areas will include organic synthesis, "redox" reactions, catalysis, and materials. Prior completion of a full year of organic chemistry is required for enrollment.

title: Selected Architects of the 20th Century: Louis I. Kahn: The Tectonics of Ideology
descrip: A review of the development of Kahn's conceptual framework, works, pedagogical standing, and contemporary critical reviews against the parallel development of the ideology and compositional modes of architecture and urbanism from before World War II to the early seventies. Course also reviews the characteristic line of progress in Kahn's office work discipline, and examines the philosophical position that set him apart from the dominant development of the 'late' moderns.

title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - What Makes Exegesis "Orthodox"?
descrip: We will investigate major sources in second and third century tradition, especially the writings of Irenaeus, Clement of Alexandria, Plotinus and Origen, comparing these with sources that such authors tended to regard as "heretical," including writings identified as "Valentinian", "Sethian," or otherwise suspect--to see what criteria emerged to identify what later writers regarded as "orthodox" or "heresy."

title: Political Theory
reviews: Definitely read the required readings. Also- go to lecture because Professor Sagar explains everything extremely well!
Do the readings, while the lectures are helpful in picking through the readings, I don't think you can understand these theories in the same way without actually engaging with the texts.
Good course to get rid of your EM
Good if you're looking for an easy EM and/or intro to political theory
Great! Take it!
I recommend really interesting class.

I think this is one of the requirements for Politics majors. Other than that, if you have a strong interest in government or are interested in reading books by Machiavelli, Plato, Mill, etc. you will like this course. Set time in advance for readings.
I would certainly take this course, and it fulfills the EM requirement.
I would recommend it.
I would recommend taking this class if you need an EM or if you're interested in political theory.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who has the slightest interest in political theory. At first I was nervous to take the course because I didn't have a lot of background on the readers, but I learned so much about them and the formation of our government. It was really an interesting class. Professor Sagar is also a really good lecturer.

I'm not sure I'm actually allowed to say this, but I would recommend not doing the readings before lecture, but doing them after instead. I found it so much more helpful to find summaries of what we were going to discuss in lecture to read beforehand and then to listen to Professor Sagar and figure out which material was most important. It's incredibly easy to get lost in some of these texts, and it was so much easier to go back and read them with a more narrowed focus after lectures.
If you're at all interested in political theory or want to read the "classic" political theorists, definitely take this course!

If you're interested in learning about the most important writers and works of political theory, take this class! Also take this class if you're looking for an easy 5th class. You don't technically have to do anything all semester except for the midterm and the final (it's very much readings based, no essays or written assignments at all). I thought it was interesting and overall a very important area of learning for any educated person.
If you're interested in political theory, take the course - Professor Sagar is very committed to his students understanding the material.

If you're mildly interested in the course, it's probably worthwhile taking it. If, like me, you view this material as more of something you "ought" to cover in college and aren't too sure you'll love it, I recommend trying it out for the first week or two. It takes commitment to actually do all of the readings, but either way, you'll likely get a decent overview of these thinkers.
It's precisely a politics course.
Nice introduction to classic political theorists.
Sagars good
Take it
Take it if you are really interested in political theory.  Really there is no other reason.
Take it. Especially if you need an EM credit. It's a great course.
Talk in precept. Also, don't buy the books, you can find the vast majority online.
There's really no reason not to take this class to meet the distribution requirement -- it's not a bad class in the slightest.
This is an interesting course.
To maximize the learning experience I would strongly recommend that they do the reading. One has to be able to find self motivation to learn in order to feel satisfied after taking this course.
Try to get the professor for your preceptor!
easy EM requirement, but lectures and precepts can be quite boring, don't expect to get too much out of the class
prereqs: This course is open to first year students..
descrip: In a world where interests and values often conflict, how should societies be governed? Which form of government is best? Is the form we have in America the best there is? This introductory course examines these and other vital questions of political theory. We will seek answers in the writings of ancient and modern theorists including Aristotle, Machiavelli, Montesquieu and the American Founders. We will also seek to understand important concepts such as virtue, moderation, justice, and order.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: Attend the lectures.

Billington is a legend. And he's leaving. But this class actually got me, a public policy major, interested in architecture and structural design. Before, I hated anything involved with civil engineering (my parents are civil engineers). Now, I'm considering it as a career.
Definitely consider this to fulfill your lab requirement.
Do not underestimate the physics calculations.
Do the homeworks and attend lectures.
Do your labs correctly and you can get a good grade.
Don't get behind or else it's very easy to lose interest quickly.
Go to lecture.

I would highly recomend this class a lab for students are not science people. The material is very interesting and it is not overly difficult. I would highly recommend the class and if you just do what is asked of you, which is not too much, you will get a lot out of the class and it won't be too difficult.
I would recommend this class.

I would say definitely take this class. If you are interested in bridges and other structures or if you need another ST. You can a small amount of work and still have a good shot at getting an A or A-
I'd recommend it.  If you need to satisfy an STL, it seems like a good way to do it.
I'd say take GEO instead, its an easier STL. If you don't get into that, take bridges but be warned that its not as easy as everyone says - you have to put in some effort
If you want an easy STL you might want this class, you might not.

If you're a humanities student looking for an easy STL/STN - it's not as easy as everyone used to say it was. Be prepared to do some work. You definitely won't be able to glide by - unless you're an engineering student or something.
If you're looking for a lab definitely take it. I literally only went to the labs and did no readings and managed to get relatively high grades.

It can be an interesting class. I would recommend making a study guide for the final list of the structures so that it is easier to memorize them. Make sure to understand theoretical/math sides of the class. It may not be as hard as other STLs, but even if you are PDF-ing, don't slack off too much to make it easier on yourself when the midterms/test come around.
It is a classic Princeton class and I would recommend it to pretty much anybody.
It's a good class to take if you need at STL
Make sure to attend lecture
None.
Not the easiest lab if PDFing, but far from hard.
Only if you really want to understand the forces and history behind some of our worlds structures should you take this class.
Take a smaller, seminar class, where you have more of a chance to engage with the material.
Take it for an easy lab-- they are fair testers.
Take it for the easiness.
Take it if you need a lab.
Take it if you need an easy STL
Take it only if there are no other easy STs for you. This is not interesting. You will likely not have learned much at all by the time you finish the course.
Take it.

The lectures are mostly slides of pretty bridges, and the homework is reasonably manageable problem sets and load, etc. If you need to satisfy a distribution requirement, this course is an option for you.

Very interesting course for those interested in understanding how exactly a suspension bridge works, or what some skyscrapers look the way they do. You will look at your environment differently after taking this course.
dont let your midterm grade freak you out.
not too bad for an ST. fair amount of busy work, but very doable
take it.
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through laboratory experiments students study the scientific basis for structural performance and thereby connect external forms to the internal forces in the major works of structural engineers. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Covering Fraud
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://: humanities.princeton.edu.
descrip: Media depictions of "con artists" shape public attitudes and public policy. Drawing on financial history, contemporary crime coverage and practicing experts, students will learn to recognize these choices and discern the value judgments and social conventions that shape the portrayal of different crimes. We will discuss the ethical issues posed by writers' choices. In short essays, suitable for submission to white-collar crime blogs, students will expand on these topics through their own research and analysis.

title: Transmission and Compression of Information
reviews: Awesome course. Difficult, but worth the time!
Great course for information theory
Take it if you are interested in this side of EE - it's not a general enough course to take to get a taste, but it's a terrific course if you like information/ applied math.
prereqs: ELE 301 and ORF 309 are prerequisites..
descrip: Historical overview of digital communications. Introductory information theory. Data compression. Error detection and correction codes. Digital modulation and demodulation.

title: Program and Policy Evaluation
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: Audio Journalism
reviews: Definitely prepare to invest time into this course, especially when gathering audio for a story. Start on the assignments early.
Definitely worth it!
Don't procrastinate. Putting a story together with limited time is extremely difficult and stressful. More so than papers and reading because you actually have to go and talk to people.

Don't take this class if you don't like NPR, if you don't like journalism, if you don't like being challenged. If you're passionate about NPR-style journalism, then this can be hugely rewarding and land you internships and jobs.
Guy Raz wasn't a good professor but i'm sure the class would be interesting in general anyway!
I really recommend that people use this class as either 1) a way to pursue a career in audio journalism, or 2) a way to expand their mind in a completely novel way
Know NPR. If you have no real interest in pursuing audio journalism, this class is too much work to just take "for fun." If you do though then Professor Raz is very helpful and you'll learn a lot.
Start the pieces early! Getting good sound takes a lot more time than writing a print article. This will turn what you've learned about journalism upside down.
Take it.  It's fabulous.  It shows you a whole new side of journalism that will improve your abilities in any story-telling medium.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://: humanities.princeton.edu.
descrip: Students will learn how to write for broadcast, gather audio, produce radio reports and deliver thoughtful, compelling news and features. We will hear from guest speakers who shape broadcasting. Topics include the challenges of delivering broadcast news in a changing media landscape and the delicate balance between news that is "good for you" and news that is "popular." Students will acquire the knowledge, experience and confidence to produce their own NPR-style radio stories.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half Term) - The Development Challenge of HIV/AIDS
descrip: This seminar will review the origins of HIV, the multiple impacts of AIDS, the reasons for sustained global neglect, the foundations of effective prevention & treatment programs & the urgent need to improve monitoring & evaluation. Special attention will be given to the role of social factors in the epidemic. Course participants will examine the policy-making process related to global public goods & consider whether the world is better positioned to avert a resurgence of this pandemic or the emergence of the next threat.

title: Language of Love, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Portuguese II
reviews: Go for it! Portuguese is a beautiful language, and well worth learning.

I would encourage another student to use the professor's office hours if they ever feel like they do not have a grasp on any of the material. Study in small increments throughout the week and make sure to learn the grammar and vocabulary as it comes rather than letting it all pile up for later. Speak often in class and to your classmates to practice your Portuguese, and try to watch Portuguese tv shows or music videos or any media you can find to familiarize yourself with understanding different accents. This class was a lot of fun and Portuguese is an awesome language to learn. Andr?a is a really accessible teacher who is very passionate about teaching Portuguese, so she will give you all the help and guidance that you need and want.
If you want to learn a new language, definitely take Portuguese!

She is absolutely amazing, probably one of the best professors I have ever had. I would take literally any course that she taught. Professor Melloni is the nicest most fantastic person I have ever had the pleasure of learning from. Por 102 is a really nice introductory course and it helps cover all of your bases.
Take this course. The Portuguese department is amazing and Andr?a is a wonderful professor who brings so much energy and devotion to her classroom.

This is a great course in a great department.  If you are looking to fulfill your language requirement with as little pain as possible, and still learn something new and interesting along the way, this is definitely a great option.
prereqs: POR 101.
descrip: A continuation of POR 101. Students will continue to develop skills of oral/aural comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining further exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa. Students who successfully complete POR 102 will place into POR 109.

title: Topics in Musical Notation, c. 900 to the Present
descrip: This history of music notation is intimately linked with those of composition and performance. This course combines a study of musical paleography (i.e. how music is written down) with consideration of notation's broader meanings and influences in Euro-American music cultures over the last millennium.

title: Directed Research
reviews: Be proactive about your project all through the semester and begin working on your poster early so you know how it will be laid out. Do not wait until the end to put it all together!
Do research throughout the semester
It is a required course.
Make a little progress each week; don't get away from it for too long, and KEEP ORGANIZED.
N/A
Start as soon as you can.
Start working on your research project as early as you can. Put a lot of thought into planning the layout of your poster.
Students considering this course will probably be required to take it anyway.
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: The Old English Period
reviews: Have fun!
It is a very fun class, and you will not regret taking a class with professor Anderson!
Really interesting class if you're into this sort of thing, Professor Anderson is great

Sarah Anderson is without a doubt the best teacher I have had here. If you are interested in Old English and prepared to think about and discuss the oldest extant english prose and poetry, take this class.
prereqs: No prior knowledge of the Old English language or of medieval literature or history is required or assumed..
descrip: An intensive introduction to the English language spoken and written in the British Isles from ca. 500 to 1100 C.E. leading to a survey of Old English poetry and prose. Focus on the immediate manuscript context of OE works and on problems of editing and translating them.

title: Topics in German Drama and Theater - Staging the Courtroom
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent..
descrip: Since antiquity, theater has measured itself against judicial forms and sought the point at which court dramatics correspond with those of the stage. The seminar will deal with conflict resolution and systems of judgment as well as investigation and the quest for truth. Passing various historical stations, from ancient tragedy to modernity and the genre of courtroom dramas, the seminar will examine the interlacing of juridical reason with aesthetics or media, which can be understood as exemplary handling of outrageous secrets, misdemeanors, nameless crimes and great passions.

title: Technology and Society
reviews: An interesting course, but if you're looking for deep discussion rather than a survey of topics, don't bother.
Don't do the readings go to all lectures
For the T&S certificate, you must take it, but do not expect anything out of it.

Good SA for technical folks. Very interesting materials (Creager is a history of science professor); it's all looking at different technical issues in a social context. The midterm assignment is a 10 minute podcast, and the final project is a website; I thought this was way better than papers.

Good class, lots of interesting material if you're in to how technology impacts society. Just as a heads up-there are  pretty technical terms in some lectures (the financial crisis ones), which may make those lectures more confusing.

I really liked this course and would highly recommend it.  Grade deflation isn't as much an issue and the projects are really fun!  It was great to take a HIS class with not too much reading and no papers.  The final and midterm are all writing but the readings for the class aren't dry historical texts but more quasi-scientific and interesting.  A great class- a lot of information to memorize and it may seem a bit extraneous, but a fun engaging class that gives a great overview on technology and society.
I would not recommend this course, because even though it may sound interesting, the implementation of the course is lacking right now.
I would say that you should do the readings because they are not difficult.

If you're considering taking this course either for a distribution requirement or because you're just interested in the material, I say go for it. The workload is not too much (~60 pages a week of reading, two projects), and the course covers its topic areas well. Since this is an overview course, there are a lot of different topics, so if you don't like one, then it won't focus on it for more than a couple weeks. I do recommend this course.
It's a great class!

Make sure to attend lectures and stay on top of lecture material, as it bodes well for the final exams. Also, the material is very interesting, and you'll particularly enjoy attending lectures with this professor.
Make sure to do the readings they are very interesting.
Required course for ITS certificate. Interesting to see how development of technology interacts with society over time.
Take it as general intro, pretty easy and not time consuming
Take it for a straightforward history course.  The website and podcast are fairly interesting.
Take it if you need an easy fifth class.  Don't expect to learn anything.

Take it if you need the certificate, or an easy 5th class. You don't have to go lecture, but look over the lecture notes on blackboard every week, and answer all the discussion board questions - that will help you stay on top of the material.
Take it if you want a taste of various social issues related to technology in the past and present. Minimal work but will be a burden if you're not interested in the material.
Take it!

Take this course if you're strongly interested in learning about a broad set of technological and societal issues. Take this course if you're motivated enough to do some lengthy readings and invest some thought into the topics discussed in precept. Don't take this course if you intend to just read the lecture Power Points and do minimal reading (you can absolutely get by with this strategy, to be sure, but you won't get anything out of the class). There is nothing "fun" about this course. It is interesting, however, if you care about the various topics.
This is a very fun and informative, and you work on some cool projects like podcast and a website.
it's fun!
take it, attend lectures, don't put in too much effort
try to get prof. creager as your preceptor. she's incredibly nice and smart.
descrip: Technology and society are unthinkable without each other - each provides the means and framework in which the other develops. To explore this dynamic, this course investigates a wide array of questions on the interaction between technology, society, politics, and economics, emphasizing the themes of innovation and maturation, systems and regulation, risk and failure, and ethics and expertise. Specific topics covered include nuclear power and waste, genetically-modified organisms, regulation of the internet, medical mistakes, intellectual property, the financial crisis of 2008, and the post-fossil-fuels economy.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Basic)
descrip: Introduction to the processes of economic growth and development. The course examines various theories of development; poverty and inequality measurement; and the role of markets for credit, labor and land, as well as education and health, in development. The role of public policy will be considered within each of these topics. The course may also cover topics such as foreign aid, commodity pricing, and tax policy. (Prerequisites: 511b; 512b can be taken concurrently.)

title: Sociology of Migration, Development and Ethnicity
descrip: This course will be taught as a hands-on practicum on research on immigration and development, especially the former. It will supplement the Center for Migration and Development's (CMD) symposium talk during the 2012-13 academic year, which meets approximately every other week from 12-1:30 on Thursdays. We will discuss the ongoing work of CMD speakers, students, post-docs and other members of the university community that work on migration or development. We expect that participants will attend the CMD symposium talks, read the paper associated with each week's discussion and be active participants in the discussion.

title: Independent Work with Design
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principle difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principles of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Russian II
prereqs: RUS105 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continued presentation and review of grammar. Vocabulary thematically organized to include such topics as travel, city life, nature, hobbies, politics, etc. Training of all language skills in a cultural context. Vocabulary reinforced through reading of cultural texts.

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared. B.S.E. candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Health Innovation and Policy
prereqs: Introductory Biology.
descrip: This course will review the policies that influence new technology development and use in the health care sector. The course will explore how governments promote health innovation and regulate safety, and it will familiarize students with the broader social and the institutional factors that influence technology development, uptake and diffusion in health care systems.

title: Topics in American Literature - American Jewish Writers: Exiles, Citizens, Provocateurs
reviews: Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading, but don't worry. It's interesting stuff. I don't know a single person in this seminar who did not like it.
Definitely take this course! You will have the opportunity to read excellent pieces of literature and have stimulating discussions that will extend beyond the classroom.
Esther Schor is a great professor. Take it to work with her, not for the reading list
Take it!

definitely take for PDF but really hard to do well with all english majors in the class
esther is amazing
descrip: American Jewish writers are known to adopt a variety of personae: they may write as exiles, as citizens, as provocateurs, among other figures. Why these strategies--and what sort of mark have they left on the rich body of writing we have before us? On American letters? On modern Jewish literature? We'll address these questions while considering the historic sweep of American Jewish writing from the 18th to the 21st centuries.

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: As hard as this class and as impossible as it will seem at times, if you really pay attention, you'll come to appreciate probably the most beautiful subject I've learned thus far in my life.
Definitely a difficult course, but definitely interesting.

Do not fall behind. Although it is not always possible, please try to read the textbook before the lectures and the problem sets. Do not procrastinate the problem sets and try to go to office hours if you can.
Get a good group of classmates to work on the problem sets with (although try them on your own first). If you try to do this class completely by yourself, it will be so much harder
Go to office hours, and know your equations.
Go to office hours, read the text, and ALWAYS go to lecture.
Great course
I think it's important to start the homework early, and to work in groups! Group work is essential in this class.
I would be sure to read the book, go to precepts and spend a lot of time understanding psets. Only take it if you're sure you want to be CBE
If you are taking this course, it is as a departmental. It was not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, and if you stay on top of your work it will be ok. Take advantage of office hours every week.
If you're CBE you'll have to take it. It's very challenging so just make use of all the resources available to you (office hours). I wouldn't recommend taking it if you're not CBE.
It's a great course. Difficult (be prepared to spend many, many late hours in the E-Quad working on the problem sets) but rewarding.

Keep up with the material! The concepts all build on each other, so it's crucial to understand things as they are taught. Also, form study groups to do the problem sets. GO TO OFFICE HOURS. That's the only way you can get the problems right.
Office hours are mandatory to do problem sets. Quizzes were fair but the final was atrocious. Good luck.
Only do it if you need to.
Professor Debenedetti is the kindest, most helpful, and intelligent professor I have ever had.  Even though I found the course extremely challenging, he made the course bearable for me.

Put in the hours to do the problems sets. They are due on Fridays and I recommend starting by Tuesday the latest. I have done problem sets in just one night, but it is always miserable, and I felt rushed and did not fully understand the material.
Read the book.
Really understanding how to do the problem sets helps a lot for understanding thermodynamics thoroughly. Ask the preceptors lots of questions. They are there to help you.

Stay on top of what is going on in class, and if there is anything that is confusing, don't be afraid to ask for clarification. Prof. Debenedetti is very open to helping his students, as were all if the TA's.
Take it if you have to. Use another textbook and go to office hours!
Take only if you are CBE. Otherwise, do MAE or CHM thermo if you must take thermo.
Take the course. It is an excellent subject.

The concepts in this class are relevant and useful for engineers, but the class itself is very difficult. I would not recommend taking this unless you have to. Concepts are subtle, and while the professor and TAs will always be there to help out, there's only so much they can do. Homework takes literally forever, and homework problems are not similar to quiz/final questions.
Thermo is challenging, so be prepared to learn a lot of hard material. The course, however, is both very interesting and rewarding.
Thermodynamics is much more challenging than Intro CBE (245).  It is the weeding out course, so if you're unsure about the major, it's nice to take it your freshman year.

This class is very hard.  Don't take it unless you really need to or are really interested in thermodynamics.  If you do take it, stay ahead and on top of the readings and lecture notes and go to office hours!
This course is pretty difficult. Go to all the office hours, and do your reading.
This is a fun course that will challenge you.  You will learn a lot of thermodynamics and also enjoy lectures a lot.  The course is a good mix of theoretical and practical thermodynamics.

You REALLY need to get a group of friends in this class. It is nigh impossible for the average person otherwise. Office hours are also extremely important (or having one of said friends go to office hours). Start homework early, or pull regular all nighters like my friends usually did. If possible, find a different thermo book? I really disliked this one.
You have to take it; if you don't then don't. It is very hard, so if you really want to challenge yourself, then go ahead.
You'll probably take this course because you have to, so get a group of friends to work on psets. It's invaluable.

You're taking this course because it's a requirement for CBE. It's much more interesting than 245, but correspondingly harder. For an engineering class it was extremely theoretical. Be prepared to do a lot of math, i.e. multivariable calc and some simple differential equations, so much that you often lose track of what you're trying to find. As long as you try to ground the theory in its real implications whenever you can, you should be fine.
study. read. do psets.
switch out of CBE if you are interested in anything other than old school chemical engineering such as petroleum.
prereqs: CBE 245 and MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The course focuses on basic principles governing the equilibrium behavior of macroscopic systems and their applications to materials and processes of interest in modern chemical engineering. In the first half of the course we introduce the fundamental concepts: energy conservation (First Law); temperature and entropy (Second Law); thermodynamic potentials; equilibrium and stability; and the molecular basis of thermodynamics. These ideas are then applied to problems such as calculating the equilibrium composition of coexisting phases and reacting mixtures or analyzing the thermodynamic efficiency of cooling and power generation cycles.

title: Normative Ethics - Ethics and the Empirical
descrip: A graduate ethics course examining some ethical questions and the relevance of psychological studies to those questions. Topics will include: the role of intuitions in ethics and the phenomenon of prejudice.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Creative Writing courses are really one of the hidden gems at Princeton so I definitely recommend taking a class!

I'm sure most Advanced Poetry courses are wonderful.  I'd caution students about those courses taught by visiting professors; if there is more than one section, shop the visiting professor's if you can but be aware that it might be very different.
And of course as with any poetry course, you really get out what you put into the course.  This is such a worthwhile class if you use it to set aside the time to write and think about poetry.

It was supposed to be a poetry class, but instead we wrote songs. It was an interesting twist, but I felt tricked and was expecting to write poetry. The professor sometimes fell asleep in class and seemed unengaged.
Try to read on your own as there was a lot of freedom, but little guidance.
based on this course, it seems there's really no difference between intro and advanced poetry, so I would say take intro with a prof that you've heard is good.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level poetry courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Contemporary Dance: Advanced Technique and Choreography
reviews: Yes.
prereqs: DAN 409 is designed for students with minimum of two or preferably three dance program courses from the following: DAN 309 and/or DAN 319 and/or DAN 419 and/or DAN 420, or the equivalent outside experience. Attendance in all classes and completion of all work required..
descrip: Advanced dance technique and choreography, with a focus on contemporary practices. In technique, students will be challenged to expand their movement range and increase their mastery of various styles in ways required by today's dance world. Students will examine concepts such as skeletal support, sequential movement, and momentum to emphasize ease and efficiency in motion. In choreography, students will work together in movement-based laboratories to focus on collaboration and choreographic choice-making skills.

title: Documentary Film and the City
reviews: DO IT!! PURCELL IS AWESOME TAKE THIS CLASS
If you are interested in either the social/economic/political aspects of urban issues and/or documentary filmmaking, this is an excellent course.

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. But PLEASE, do NOT take it if you CANNOT make the time commitment! It is very unfair to other students when you can't show up to do your share of the work at shoots!!! It made life SO much more difficult when one of my teammates just kept canceling on us!!!!!!
TAKE IT!!!!
Take it if you're into documentary film making.
Take it! my favorite course since I have been at Princeton
prereqs: Interested students should apply by submitting a brief two-paragraph email to the instructor. Students should describe any previous experience with visual media or journalism and explain why they want to take the course. Some experience with photography, video, or video editing will be useful to students, but it is not required..
descrip: This seminar uses film to explore the social and political issues facing the post-industrial American city and examines how films employ different documentary methodologies. Students will apply these techniques hands-on, collaborating on short explorations of housing issues in Trenton. They will learn how to establish a relationship with a subject, gather observational footage, conduct interviews, and weave narrative in a visual medium. The goal of the course is to give students not only a greater understanding of urban history and the challenges cities face today but also a foundation in the practical and theoretical issues of documentary.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Analytics and Systems of Big Data
reviews: Big Data is going to be a major research area in the coming years with lots of commercial applications. To me Big Data boils down to a) the move to datacenters for processing/storage (instead of local computing/storage), and b) running computations on extremely large data sets where you can do only one pass over the data. Big Data is a catch-all terms for other large distributed system problems and even some recent theoretical problems, all of which are going to be increasingly important in the coming years. There is a lot of commercial interest in this space (many startups are already targeting interesting problems) and this course will give you the basic background on both the systems and the analytics topics. Not taking this course is like not taking a course on "the Internet" back in 1997.

Don't be intimidated if you're an undergrad. KL is nice and most topics in this class are accessible, assuming you've done the coursework of a typical UG senior. I'd recommend having taken OS and Networks [to get more out of the systems papers] and some kind of AI / Machine Learning class before taking this one, though.
Good exposure to the latest techniques to big data systems.

I think this can be a great course to take if you are interested in gaining a broad perspective of big data systems and analytics techniques. This is also a great course for diving into a few specific topics that interest you (your presentation and your group project). If the professor suggests to schedule this course on Friday afternoons for 2.5 hours each week, I suggest you strongly vote against this change. In terms of workload, the course is relatively manageable if you time things right, but things will probably get hectic towards the end of the semester when you have to finish a final presentation and report on your group project. A few last things that I would like to point out: The professor is super helpful when it comes to your group project, and especially make sure to go to the sessions with the invited speakers.
I would check the readings of this semester to see if this stuff really interest you.
I would highly recommend the course.
If you're really interested in distributed storage system then take it, otherwise maybe look elsewhere.
Surely take it.
descrip: Study of recent papers on analytics and systems of big data. In analytics, we plan to read papers in mining, search and exploration techniques for images, audio, video and network data. In systems for big data, we plan to study recent developments in scale-out systems including storage systems and search systems. Students taking this course for credit are required to present a selected paper and work on a small course project.

title: Beginning Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian II
prereqs: BCS 101.
descrip: A continuation of BCS 101. This course continues to develop and refine the four language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing), concentrating on conversational practice, advanced grammar points, oral drilling, increased reading (BCS literature, folklore, and expository prose, including works chosen according to students' interests), and viewing films.

title: American Literature: 1865-1930
reviews: Do not take this class unless you intend to major in English. You can do the good readings on your own time, and there are generally more fun and exciting ways to get an LA.
Do the readings, start the essays at least a few days before they're due.

Don't take it. Like so many other English courses, it fails to analyze the books for their intellectual content and only focuses on language rhythm, race, and sex themes. These themes are of course present, but unfortunately not worth the course's full attention when that means ignoring about 90% of the rest of the books' contents.
Final exam is fairly easy as long as you attend lecture as almost all the quotes he uses were read aloud. Go to lecture!
If you have read these books before, this class will open you up to even more ways of looking at them. If not, this course provides a great introduction to some of the greatest writers of the time.
Note the page numbers for each book! His exams are based on those page numbers.

Probably an easy LA. As an English major, I found it pretty easy and a decent, if not terribly stimulating, way to check off a departmental. Preceptor's going to make or break you though, and I don't recommend Sobel.
Read all of the books thoughtfully!
Read the books! Why wouldn't you?  They're all amazing.
Really get to know the preceptor, and engage. That makes or breaks your experience with this class.
Strongly Recommend
TAKE IT if you have any interest.
Take it if there are books you've always wanted to read in the syllabus but you're afraid you're not going to get around to ever reading them!
Take it if you're interested in an overview of the American literature!
Take it!
Take it.
Take this course (more so for the Prof. & preceptor (Sobel) than anything else).

This was an amazing class. Professor Mitchell's lectures are so engaging - I felt that I never wanted to miss a word that he said. This is the kind of course that makes me truly excited about school and learning and the myriad of possibilities that literature has to offer.
descrip: A study of the development of American literature within the context of the shifting social, intellectual, and literary conventions of the period. Emphasis will be on the artistic achievement of writers such as James, Howells, Twain, Dreiser, Crane, Adams, Wharton, Cather, Fitzgerald, and Faulkner.

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: Do your projects early! Don't procrastinate; it will haunt you later, timewise.
Don't rush on projects. Take time in the planning stages of projects to really get your head on what you really want the piece to look like at different stages of production and when finished.

It takes a good amount of time, so be prepared for that. However, it's a lot of fun and really hands on. Almost no reading, it's all about producing. And it's a great way to try out the VIS department and learn to use a variety of the many resources available to students (metalwork, plaster, wood, fabric, etc.).
Make sure you think about each project beforehand, nothing is worse than working on something you are not passionate about.
Take it if you can, super cool
Take it only to improve skills in the workshop, not to express creativity.
Take it! It's a lot of fun. But also prepare to put in extra out-of-class hours to finish your projects.

Take this course if you are interested at all in learning how to sculpt and work with wood, metal, rubber, etc. 

We do not only work with clay--this class does so much more. Also, realize, you will need to come in during shop hours (outside of class). But, in my opinion--this class was definitely worth it.

This class was great! Martha Friedman was an excellent teacher and made this class amongst my most favorite at Princeton. As a BSE COS major who really likes building things, this class allowed me to do that, but also made me think and about art in new ways and helped me communicate thoughts about sculpture. I really like making sculptures so the work load was not a problem, although I came into the shop on random Fridays/Weekends/Mondays just because I liked to work on things.
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, concept, fabrication and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on sculpture and its consequences. Students will develop an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic facilities in woodworking, metalworking, carving and casting.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Time Series Models
descrip: Concepts and methods of time series analysis and their applications to economics. Time series models to be studied include simultaneous stochastic equations, VAR, ARIMA, and state-space models. Methods to analyze trends, second-moment properties via the auto covariance function and the spectral density function, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing and of model selection will be presented. Kalman filter and applications as well as unit roots, cointegration, ARCH, and structural breaks models are also studied.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: 207 is where Spanish stops becoming a class to take for the sake of taking. It gives as much work as my other classes - it is no longer just a world language class for the sake of taking it. At the same time, it is extremely interesting and fun.
?T?mala!
Definitely take it if you want to keep your Spanish skills fresh!
Don't take Lorena's section. But this class really helps if you want to get better at spanish.

Even if one has placed out of a language, I would strongly encourage one to continue their study of that language. The classes at Princeton are stimulating, and a better understanding of another language can really help open up new opportunities in life.
Have fun!

I loved SPA 207 largely due to Lorena. She made all of the material fun, stimulating, and accessible. Keep on top of the assignments because even though each individual assignment is not worth a large percentage of your grade, they add up!

I would not recommend this course unless you are planning on getting a certificate or don't mind extremely nit-picky grading and want to spend a LOT of time on finetuning your assignments. I don't think this course did not improve my spanish that much.
If didn't take Spanish in high school and have only taken 101, 102 and 107 at Princeton, this course will be pretty challenging.

If you have a 5 on AP Spanish, chances are this course won't help you much.  If possible, I recommend trying to place into a more advanced course, especially as this course does not give distributions credits.
If you want to get the most out of this course, put time into the readings and the writing assignments- you can really improve your language skills if you do this.
Keep up with the work, start early and don't be afraid to go to office hours.
Make sure to revise your ejercicios de gramatica to check for errors!
Make sure you understand the grammar.
Only take this class for the requirement or if you're really interested in the ins and outs of grammar structure. Not a heavy culture class
Participate and don't bring your computer to class!
Please take this course! You will have fun while learning the material.

Take 207, even if you didn't enjoy 108 very much. The class is much more discussion-based (so it's more interesting than just learning grammar all the time) and your speaking skills will improve a lot.
Take it if you are interested in keeping up your Spanish and have an extra spot in your schedule, but don't expect to improve a whole lot past 108.
Take it if you enjoy Spanish.
Take it with monserrat. you'll have a lot of fun
Take it! It's not difficult, and it's super fun. Lorena is the best!
Take it. It's a good course, and you'll develop fluency. It's also not too hard or time-consuming, but it forces you to keep practicing your Spanish.

Take this course if you are interested in continuing to improve your spoken Spanish and grammar. The workload is manageable and the grading is very fair. The class is a great mix of readings, movies, short written work, and speaking. I would definitely recommend continuing Spanish with this course!
The class itself is pretty straightforward - take it if you want to improve your grammar and writing skills, but it may not be the class for you if you want to become more fluent in the language.
Whenever you're doing a lot of grammatical stuff, it ain't gonna be too fun. Otherwise, the course gets it done. As my father once told me, pimpin' ain't easy, but it's necessary.
good class
only take if you have to. just another grammar course. Same exact thing as SPA 108
practice spanish outside the course, really say everything and anything in class and visit office hours of course
yes
prereqs: SPA 107 or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score. Offered both semesters..
descrip: SPA 207 is an advanced Spanish language course. Its main goal is to increase students' fluency and accuracy in oral and written Spanish, and to prepare them for higher-level literature and culture classes offered by the Department. Although Spanish 207 is primarily a language course, language is studied in its contexts of use, as a form of action and an enactment of cultural meanings and social relations. This contextual value of language is considered through literary texts, films, press articles, etc.

title: Into the Woods! What Disney Didn't Tell You About Fairy Tales
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Ottoman Turkish
prereqs: 1. Knowledge of Modern Turkish beyond the intermediate level is required. 2. No prior knowledge of the Arabic script is required. 3. Audits require prior permission of the instructor..
descrip: In this course, students will learn how to read Ottoman Turkish in the Arabic script, acquire knowledge of relevant Persian and Arabic grammar rules, develop a basic set of Ottoman Turkish vocabulary, and romanize written Ottoman sources. The readings will emphasize variety, provided by sources such as legal tracts, histories, and biographies; as well as depth, provided by focus on a specific genre of prose fiction, the Tifli stories, showcasing developments in Ottoman language and society across the last three centuries of the empire. While most of the texts we read will be printed, we will look at some simple manuscripts as well.

title: Chinese Poetry - The High Tang
descrip: Through close readings of original sources, we examine works by major High Tang poets such as Wang, Li, and Du in their aesthetic, historical, and hermeneutic dimensions. In addition, we will give attention to the critical reception of these poets in the ensuing literary history. Secondary readings include Chinese, English, and Japanese scholarship. Class discussion focuses on issues concerning annotation, interpretation, and translation of the original texts.

title: Research in Architecture
reviews: Lots of work, but really worthy.
N/A
descrip: This is a doctoral proseminar on the methodologies of architectural history based on a close reading of major historical and theoretical writings from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. As opposed to a linear survey of histories of architecture, the seminar examines the varying theoretical positions of architectural historians towards the uses and abuses of history as well as their individual grasping of historical time. Issues to be discussed include historicism, anachronism, revival, periodization, style, transition, quotation, fiction, prediction, prehistory, and post-histoire.

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars. To apply, visit http://www.princeton.edu/writing/wse

title: Experimental Physics
reviews: Ask for more information - the lab manuals are very short and not very helpful.
If you are a physics major you will have to take this course anyways.  If you are not I can't see why you would take it, but the labs are very fun.

It's nice that you only have 1 hour of class. Your experience will vary with the labs, but most of the data collection doesn't take much time, if you know what you are doing. The lab manuals are sometimes wrong, so don't be shy about talking to Marlow, the TAs, or other students. The written reports will kinda feel like they consume your life, and you aren't sure what you are supposed to be writing. I liked the oral ones much better, which were more about how well you could think on the spot

Make sure you take data early and often. Many of the labs require several days worth of actual data taking, so waiting to the last minute will make some labs impossible. If you get a good routine figured out, though, it flows fairly smoothly.

Pick your experiments carefully.
Recommended: Interferometry, Positron Annihilation, Mossbauer, Muon Parity Violation, Electronics
Avoid: SPIN ECHO, Photoelectric effect, Chaotic Pendulum, Beta Decay
Take it if you're required too, try and get lab feedback.
This is not the nightmare core lab that people in other departments have. It's a lot of work, but the course has been reworked significantly over the past few years and it is now quite enjoyable.
This was a good course. There are a lot of topics that you can learn through the labs.
You have to take it, don't do the Holography lab, do take the time to do a good job and learn this stuff.
prereqs: PHY 103/104 or equivalent; PHY 208 or equivalent. Not recommended for sophomores..
descrip: Students work in small groups and perform four experiments and an electronics lab. The list of experiments to choose from includes muon decay, beta decay, optical pumping, Mossbauer effect, holography, positron annihilation, electron diffraction, single photon interference, NMR, Coulomb's law, and an observation of galactic hydrogen. Weekly lectures will provide an overview of various experimental techniques and data analysis.

title: Computer Architecture
reviews: Start labs early.  Start the project early.  Participate in class and ask questions.  Study hard for the exams, they really require you to know the material well.
Take it if you're interested in computer architecture and wanting to work in the industry or go on to grad school. As soon as possible so you know if you want to continue.

Take this course if you are interested in knowing how the computers of today are designed. Wentzlaff is an amazing lecturer and extremely helpful in and out of the classroom to make sure you understand the material. Start the labs early.

Wentzlaff is an amazing lecturer - he presents material very clearly and can provide real world examples and details if you have any questions. This class can teach you to write verilog like a pro. Definitely take this class as the next step after 375.
interesting course, but it's a fair amount of work.
useful, hard, not pleasant
prereqs: Permission of Instructor or ELE 375 or (COS 375 or its equivalent). Seniors and graduate students may waive prerequisites with instructor's permission..
descrip: Modern computer processor architecture. I/O Architecture. Instruction-set architecture and high-performance processor organization including pipelining and data and instruction parallelism. Cache, memory, and storage architectures. Multiprocessors and multicore processors. Coherent caches. Interconnection and network infrastructures.

title: Major Russian Poets and Poetic Movements - Golden Age/Silver Age
descrip: The Silver Age - The course will cover a broad range of texts (prose and poetry) from the Silver Age. Readings will to some extent reflect student interest. The course will be conducted in Russian, but students who so desire can present work and write papers in English.

title: American Literary Traditions - Religion in the Early Modern Atlantic World, 1500-1800
descrip: This course explores the impact of Atlantic transit on religious history. We discuss theology in relation to New World communities. We see how authorities controlled religious expression among indigenous populations, Africans, and women. How did colonial encounters transform Old World traditions? What happened as secular language philosophies replaced ideas about words as divine revelation? How do we account for the persistence of biblical allegory and demonology alongside empiricism and natural history? How did the Enlightenment foster evangelicalism? We explore how an Atlantic history of religion shapes narratives of secular modernity.

title: Theoretical Machine Learning
reviews: A course worth taking.
Definitely take it. Schapire is a great professor and this class is a lot of fun!

Definitely take this course. Schapire is an amazing lecturer and the material is really interesting. That said, this is a theory course so be prepared for some math. However, you have an opportunity for application on the final project.
Good stuff.
Highly recommended.

If you're an undergrad, only take this course if you have a strong background and interest in theory.  This is not an "application of machine learning" kind of course.  It is almost purely theoretical throughout.
If you're interested in machine learning and you have some background in mathematical proofs, I would recommend taking this course.
Professor Schapire is a great lecturer. If you are interested in theory, take this class.
Start the final project early, and don't try to do too much. Settle on a project that's doable.
Take it if you're curious in ML.
Take it or leave Princeton with regret.
Take this course when it is offered.
The material in this course is not easy, but if you're interested in the topic, it's a class worth taking.

This course has a MASSIVE emphasis on the theoretical.  I had some very smart friends drop halfway through because they found the problem sets too unapplicable to their applications interests.  I found that this trained me well, though, and that the math involved in the problem sets were very interesting.  I loved that Schapire encouraged us to do a theoretical paper at the end, and that he was totally OK with if we weren't able to prove something new.
This was an accessible course for an undergraduate with mathematical maturity at the level of MAT215.
Very worth taken.
descrip: An introduction to theoretical machine learning, including mathematical models of machine learning, and the design and rigorous analysis of learning algorithms. Likely topics include: bounds on the number of random examples needed to learn; learning from non-random examples in the on-line learning model; how to boost the accuracy of a weak learning algorithm; support-vector machines; maximum-entropy modeling; portfolio selection.

title: Seminar in Romance Linguistics and/or Literary Theory - Readings in Theory
descrip: Readings in 20th century critical and theoretical texts.

title: Topics in Regional and Country Studies - Historic Preservation, Conflict & the Middle East
descrip: The course will provide a broad understanding of historic preservation policy and the built heritage. Key concepts, instruments and practices will be introduced while looking at a variety of case studies from the Middle East. Emphasis will be placed on architectural, urban, socioeconomic and property-related conflicts that surface when preservation is an issue. Through the Middle Eastern prism, the course introduces heritage resources and the problems they present to policymakers. Comparisons with the US and other countries will provide a global perspective deliberated amongst conservation protagonists and antagonists.

title: Statistics for Social Science
reviews: A survey of Stats and R, not coming away from this with that many more practical skills but a fair amount
About as good of a Stats course as I could imagine.
An excellent introductory statistics course if taken with Professor Ratkovic!

As the class stands now, it does a poor job of introducing stats and does not support the programming part well. This was literally a carbon copy of POL 345 but with less support and unsuspecting students. Take it if you like/have ever done some stats, no programming background required but hope youre good at it, and are willing to work a lot outside class.
Attend every lecture and find out the expectations of the professor. but pests can be challenging if you don't have coding experience.
Be prepared to work, but you'll learn a lot.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE, OR ANY OTHER WITH MARC RATKOVIC.

Ratkovic is a terrible lecture, does not know how to structure a class, cannot teach statistics, has terribly unclear tests and assignments, and is a terrible professor all around.
Do not take this course. Take econ stats or something.

Do not take this course. This is by far the worst and hardest course that I have ever taken at Princeton. Professor Ratkovic is a terrible teacher and is basically incapable of explaining anything in a way that is accessible, engaging or helpful. I learned nothing from his lectures. The coding assignments are difficult and seem for the most part to have absolutely nothing to do with the lectures, so it feels disjointed and disconnected. I came into this class really excited to learn about statistical concepts and to be able to evaluate and analyze research better but this class taught me nothing. It was a miserable experience and I would have dropped it if I hadn't needed it to be a Woody Woo major. Do not take this class. It was supposed to be a statistics class designed to be accessible for people who are not quantitative, but it isn't at all. This class was a huge disappointment, and I am so sad that I wasted my time and energy on it. The best thing about it is the fact that it is now over. I hope that this course gets completely overhauled or canceled and that no other Princeton students have to be subjected to such a poorly designed and executed course.
Do the assignments the day they were assigned, go to lectures and precepts, you will still be struggling. Brace yourself.
Don't take it if you don't have to. You won't learn statistics. Take another statistics class.
Don't take it unless you have to or unless they improve the course. As it stands, it's a real headache-inducer.
Don't take it unless you have to. Even then, try not to.
Don't take it unless you're Woody Woo. Even if you are, take a good, long hard look at Econ Stats. At least they don't have coding.
Don't take it.
Don't take this class even if it's for the WWS stats requirement. Way too much work associated with coding and I didn't even feel like I learned that much about statistics...

Don't take this course if you can avoid it- definitely try to take a different stats class. Ratkovic is at times preachy, condescending, and not always willing to help. Some of the preceptors, though wanting to help, sometimes don't understand the material any better than the students.

Don't take this course.  Even if you to for WW, don't take it.  Just save yourself the trouble and change majors.  Be aware that if you do take it, you will spend all your time coding in R, and none of it actually learning statistics.
Eh, if you're taking this course you probably have to take it as a WWS or POL departmental but be prepared to cry out of the sheer difficulty of the course. If not, there are better QRs.
Essentially like POL 345, except the problem sets are a little easier. If you're more comfortable with math, take ORF 245--I learned more through those lecture slides than the ones in WWS 200.
Expect problem sets to take 30  hours to complete. BEWARE the preceptors. They were all awful and hardly understood the material. Pallavi was particularly awful and the most unhelpful person ever.
Go to lecture. You will ace the quizzes if you do. With Ratcovic this class is coding heavy and theory light.
God this is a horrible class. Take it only if you need to for POL or WWS requirement.
Good (and tough) stats overview. Stay on top of the Handouts and problem sets and you'll learn a lot of R.
Helps you to learn to code in R, but I would take ORF stats or ECO stats.

I didn't really like this course, but I had to take it. It wasn't very hard, but it was pretty poorly organized, so I struggled with the problem sets and quizzes. The lectures don't help you learn how to program, and the precepts don't explain the lecture concepts, so it can be very confusing. It wasn't a hard class, but I think that it could have been organized much better.
I want to hate it, but it's kind of cool knowing how to code. That being said, this is NOT a class I would take to fulfill a QR requirement.
I would not recommend taking this class unless significant changes have taken place from last year.
I would not suggest taking this course unless you have to. I think other statistics courses are probably more engaging and less confusing.

I would strongly recommend not taking this course - choose a course with a different professor. The only good thing about it is that I fulfilled my QR distribution requirement, but you can easily fulfill this requirement through other courses.

I would strongly recommend taking another course to fulfill the Woodrow Wilson school pre-requisite.  This class was disorganized, and lacked the necessary resources that other classes posses. I would suggest taking another class that is more well established.  The one saving - grace for this course were the preceptors, however, the preceptors seemed to lack communication with the professor, and often disjointed in their approach.

I wouldn't really recommend taking this class, especially with so many other options.  It seemed way too difficult for what it was and the resources for help were lacking.  They expect us to learn R yet don't teach it to us and won't give that much advice on problem sets.
If you are interested in statistics, it should be both informative and relatively easy. Go to office hours and keep up with readings.
If you have an interest in math, take ORF 245
If you have to take this course, go to lectures. Go to office hours for the problem sets and you'll be fine.

If you're interested in stats and its role in policy and politics, take this class. If you need a stats requirement for Woody Woo, take this class. Though some people say ORFE stats is more straightforward, this stats is more relevant academically and professionally.

If you're politics or woody wu, this is your stats course. Expect to work hard for average grades, but the misery of stats is somewhat lessened by the fact that everyone in the course is in the same boat.

If you've got some kind of coding background, you're golden. If not, be prepared to put in a large amount of work on your own. If you survive the second quiz and problem set (his weeders), you'll probably be able to pull through. Take another stats class if you're considering WWS and don't want to hurt your departmental GPA.

It depends what kind of things you like. Personally, I should have done econ stats because I like math more. This class is a lot of coding and more conceptual problems. But if you like this type of work then you might like this class!
It is like 2 courses at once the way you learn stats from the book and for the coding so it is a LOT. Definitely my hardest class.
It is primarily coding in R; if you take it, just expect to spend a lot of time figuring this out.

Look into the other stats classes. I haven't taken any others, but my rooommates said it was more involved coding than ORFE 345 and my other roommate is in econ stats and doesn't seem to have as many complaints...if you want a class like this take POL 345 and at least feel like it should be this hard.

ONLY take this class if you absolutely must for WWS requirement. understanding statistics is an important skill any major/life but this is not the class to take to learn it. Instruction was terrible, the problem sets take days to do. Take another stat class.

Only take it if you have to for a distribution requirement. Problem sets are actually pretty hard. Very little focus on actual statistics and heavy emphasis on R. Ratkovic is great one on one so go to his office hours if you have to take it.
Only take this class if you are required to.
Only take this if you have to for WWS.
Prepare yourself for a lot of outside of class work, and pushing through moments of discouragements late into the night. but take it.

Professor Ratkovic is a worse than horrendous teacher! He is bad at explaining concepts, bad at writing problem sets, and unhelpful. It didn't seem like he put much time into the class but expected the students to spend a preposterous amount of time on the problem sets. I would recommend you never take anything taught by this man. He is just a horrible, horrible teacher.

Quality was awful. My high school teacher was far better and teaching statistics concepts. There is a clear distinction between being a great teacher and being knowledgable in a particular subject area. Ratkovic is the latter. Take another statistics course that Ratkovic is not teaching.
Ratkovic is a good teacher, this is a very good introduction to statistics

SCORE messed up my formatting, so if you want to read a formatted version, go to http://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=tbTtAV4y                           

This was literally the worst class I've taken at Princeton, and indeed, in my life. I'm not upset about my grade; I'm almost guaranteed to get an A in the course, based on my grade and the curve. That being said, I would say without question that I earned this A in spite of my professor, rather than because of him.

I did well in this class for three reasons. Hard work was not one of them, though I (along with everyone else in this class) worked my tail off.
1. I had programmed extensively before.
2. One of my friends in the class took AP Stats and helped me with the concepts.
3. Some of my friends outside of the class were math majors and sat down with me for (literally) hours to explain basic concepts like density and distribution functions.

I think it speaks to the quality of Marc Ratkovic's teaching when fifty kids dropped (our class originally was enrolled at 180). I think it also speaks to the quality of Marc Ratkovic's teaching when the professor's office hours are literally fifty people at a time and the preceptor's office hours are literally fifty people at a time. Something's wrong.

The problem is that this class is completely disjointed. Even if Ratkovic could explain things well (he can't), nothing flows together.
