Ratkovic uses different terminology and notation than the book, but expects us to know his terminology and notation without explanation on his part. The problem sets and handouts were essentially just coding, and the quizzes were essentially just conceptual statistics. There was almost no overlap. So, the first time that you'd actually done much of the conceptual work was on the quiz -- there was no practice leading up to it. Moreover, the precept and the lecture were completely unrelated. Not once did we ever go over a lecture concept in precept. The precept simply existed to teach us

Since this class is required for certain majors, you must take it. But it is helpful. In order to be successful, ask a lot of questions to clarify things and go to office hours. Prof. Ratkovic is very helpful and he is willing to teach you until you understand. He even opens additional office hours on the weekends in order to help students. This class is hard, but I don't regret taking it.
Take Econ Stats or Orph stats
Take Econ stats instead if you don't want to code. This class is a lot about coding. If you like that, it's useful and pretty interesting.
Take ORF 245 or ECO 202.
Take a different statistics course if you actually want to learn statistics.
Take a different statistics course, unless you love to code, the amount of statistics I learnt in proportion to code is probably a 1:10 ratio.
Take it if you have to for WWS - otherwise, take psych or soc stats.
Take it if you need it or you want to acquire skills in statistical programming.
Take this class only if you want to Woody Woo. Be prepared to struggle. It will be hard.
Talk to the professor before you enroll to truly figure out what the material will entail. This semester, it was very misleading.
The lectures have nothing to do with the problem sets whatsoever and the problem sets will not prepare you for the quizzes in almost any way.
There are other statistics courses. take them instead. unless you have coding experience

This class literally ruined my life while I was in it. It wasn't what was described in the course offerings, as there was a last minute professor change. If I had known that I would have had to code with R, I wouldn't have taken this class. Hated it. At least I picked up some new skills that I otherwise wouldn't have.

This course is literally the worst course I have ever taken at Princeton. I have never experienced such a bad professor, bad preceptor, and bad quality of assignments and problem sets. This course does not deserve to be labeled a Princeton course! Ratkovic is by far the worst professor I have had at Princeton, and it's because he is a terrible teacher. I'm sure he is smart and a great statistician, but he literally does not understand how to teach introductory statistics to students with limited quantitative backgrounds. Not only does he ignore questions from students who struggle with simple issues, but he cannot teach concepts through a framework that allows students to understand simple statistics principles. I (and my friends) learned more from reading the book for 10 minutes than in an entire lecture. I am actually sad that I had to waste an entire course slot on this class. Please, please, please, do not take this course. It will be the worst thing to happen to you at Princeton. The only reason to take it is if you are forced to take it to be a Woody Woo major, in which case you should put on your seatbelt and hold on for dear life. I wish you the best of luck.
This course will be tough if you have no background in stats. It's a fun course but you must be willing to work.

This is NOT a general statistics class -- lectures focus on conceptual math but problem sets focus on coding. Be prepared to spend a considerable amount of time to self-teach R and work on problem sets.

This is a hard class, take it if you are interested in learning statistical programming type stuff. If you are not good with computers, DONT TAKE THIS CLASS. R is a huge huge huge part of your grade and if you cant get a grip of it, you will have a terrible time in the class. Ratovic is awesome though, so if you have to take a stats course and can use the computer well, take this class for sure.

This is a very tough course because it requires a lot of time/effort to do well against the curve. Readings, weekly assignments, problem sets, and quizzes are all important. If you need this class, or really, really don't want to self-teach R, then take it. But make sure you're prepared to put the time in. If you do, you'll be rewarded.
This is not a terribly difficult stats class as long as you have a study group. If you don't have a study group / people to collab with on psets, you will probably fail unless you're a coding genius.
Ummmmm don't take it. But if you have to, go to office hours and study hard for the quizzes which are often very difficult.

We were promised at the beginning of the course that it would be difficult, but that the tools would be given to us so that we could succeed. Instead, I found the opposite to be the case. The class should not have been difficult. The amount of statistics we covered was very small, the level to which we were expected to apply the concepts on the exams not very difficult, and the coding (with the exception of intuitively understanding loops) more about your knowledge of the appropriate commands than your reasoning. Take this course if you feel like this kind of conscious restructuring has happened. Otherwise, stay far, far away.
Would never recommend
You don't necessarily need to read FFP but go to all the lectures and make sure you understand R and how to troubleshoot.

You probably need this course for a departmental, so you're probably going to need to take it. The papers you will analyze for problem sets will be really cool and will give you some great stuff to talk about with friends, however they will be challenging. Loops will definitely be the worst of the class, although you will make it. Just work hard, and be prepared to commit a good amount of time to this course.

You will have to quiz yourself on the basics of statistics that you encounter in the readings because they will not come up again until a quiz or until you need to learn a more complicated concept that uses them.  Get help early; don't assume that your preceptor or the professor will elaborate on things that he mentions in class.
be prepared to focus on programming instead of statistics. not your high school statistics course
don't take it unless you have to
dont take it unless you are familiar with statistics and computer programming. i am sure the other wws required courses for statistics are better.
only take it if you have to
take this only if you want to learn R.  You will not learn too much about traditional statistics.
descrip: The course will consist of a brief introduction to probability theory as well as various topics in statistics and how they can be used in the public policy realm. Subject areas will include random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, and introduction to the regression model. The data sources will be actual examples taken from the public policy realm. Stata, a general purpose statistical programming package will be used to perform the statistical analysis.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Institutions
reviews: A dry course that may help you to realize you don't want to do investment banking. But it is well-taught for what it is, and certainly not overly difficult. If you like math, you won't like this as much as 362, otherwise you will like it more. You certainly won't regret taking it even if you end up not overly interested in the topic.
A great class, seriously. Prof. Sannikov is a great lecturer and almost everything you learn is applicable in real life.
A necessary course to take if you're thinking about going into finance. Relatively painless, if you are comfortable with math and critical thinking in relation to economic concepts.

An amazing class. Yuliy Sannikov is the gem of the econ department. He is an absolute genius (read his papers...!) and a brilliant educator. Take it with him, and get to know the professor if you can! This class is definitely useful if you want to work in investment banking. But more importantly, the class can also spark more interesting, intellectual discussion about corporate finance theory and more if you want to go the extra mile. Prof Sannikov knows SO much and is always happy to share. He is also just a really good, nice person, and genuinely cares about the students and want us to do well and understand the material. To warn you, the exams are fairly easy so don't expect an easy A since everybody does pretty well. Best class I've taken at Princeton, and best professor in the department!

An excellent course. The professor is great, the material is a solid mix of the theory behind finance and practical applications, and what you learn will be useful whether you are working in finance in the future or not.

Contrary to what some may think, precepts are useful. The material is a lot of real-world stuff that is more tangible than 362. If you have questions or feedback, the professor and TAs are eager to listen.
Definitely take it.
Don't take it for the grade; you're in this class to learn. If you keep that perspective, you will thoroughly enjoy it. Best finance class I've taken so far.
Good class even if you're not necessarily in it for the finance certificate.
Good material -- lectures boring, precepts okay, textbook FANTASTIC.
I would recommend really keeping up with the material and taking advantage of Yuliy's help.
I wouldn't take it if i was not going to get the finance certificate. You can take more challenging/fun courses

If you have any interest in finance, you should take this course.  You will be exposed to a ton of material, and Sannikov shows you why each and every part of it matters.  The valuation project was one of the coolest assignments I've had here.

If you're going for the finance certificate and didn't enjoy 362 very much this class is way better (if you have Yuliy). Also if you are interested in learning about IPOs, Mergers and  other financial terms that you hear about all the time this class will give you a great foundation.
It's alright, the curve is crazy though because there are lots of smart people in the class. Very straightforward class.
It's good to pay attention even when we're repeating material from 362, because if you slip you won't notice the extra material.
Its an interesting and useful class.
Just take it. Whatever major are you in. It is one of the best classes I took in Princeton.
Make sure you go to the lectures and understand the exams and are proficient in math
Material is relatively interesting if you're keen to learn more about corporate finance. Otherwise, there might be better classes out there. Prof Sannikov is real sweet though.
Most likely, you have to take this course. But the prof does organize a lot of useful material that should be very useful in the future. It's just a little boring during lecture.
My favorite ECO course so far!
Pay attention in lecture and keep up to date with material throughout.
Professor Sannikov is a fun lecturer, he makes the often dry topic of corporate finance pretty interesting. Clearly likes the material and is excited to be teaching it. Enjoyed more than 362.

Professor Sannikov is the best. He knows his stuff very well, is practical-minded (good for people who want to get into ibanking), and is funny (sometimes unintentionally so -- there were a lot of great innuendos in class). Precepts were optional. The only (minor) bad thing was that Sannikov materially changed the wording of a midterm problem, 45 mins into the exam. This caused lots of people to lose a few points unfairly. Overall, the class was easier and *much more enjoyable* than ECO 362 taught by Hong.

Really great course! Prof. Sannikov is wonderful. Incredibly useful for anything on Wall Street (or even off Wall Street if you ever end up in management in another field). Put in the work and anyone can do it. Not an easy course but not hard.
Take if you are into finance.
Take it if you're interested in the practical subject of corporate finance. It was both really useful and interesting.
Take it.
Take this class with Prof. Sanninkov. Also easily the most applicable course to real life that I have taken at this school- very practical. A must take.
Take this class. The information learned here will help anyone seeking a finance-related internship, and is useful even in completely unrelated fields.
Take this course but make sure you have the time to spend studying for the final.
The material is important to learn for anyone pursuing a career in finance, regardless of the quality of the instruction.
This is a good class to take for an ORFE departmental.

This is one of the most useful courses Princeton offers. This course is essential for understanding finance and how to manage assets in the real world. I think everyone in Princeton should take this course.
Unless you want to be a banker, do not bother with this class.
Useful material will help students of all types with financial decision making - don't discount it just because you aren't going into finance.

You don't need to have taken ECO 362, which I've heard is terrible. The material in this class was interesting and useful to me, as someone who loves Econ but has no interest in being Finance certificate. Two assignments -- the valuation project and articles assignment -- were graded inconsistently across precepts, so clarify expectations first. The other assignments were useful, and Yuliy is great and very approachable.
don't let this class drop the certificate.  it's not as bad as people say it is.
only take it if you have to
standard IBD-intro course
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 362.
descrip: This course investigates the financing decisions of companies and financial institutions in the wider context of the workings of financial markets. Topics include capital budgeting, capital structure choice, risk management, liquidity, corporate governance, and the interactions between corporate finance and the workings of financial institutions and markets.

title: Life Is Short, Art Is Really Short
descrip: See website

title: Elementary Persian II
reviews: Definitely worthwhile if you're interested in Persian. Amineh is an amazing professor

Don't take this course--its giant waste of time. The instructor was disorganized in every way possible. The textbook was not available for purchase so we had to rely on photocopies, which didn't print out correctly most of the time. Her instructions for homework that she gave in class were often different from what was on blackboard, leading to confusion and wasted hours doing the wrong assmts. She was also late to class, and it was obvious that she wasn't prepared by the fact that we would end up reading through our homework exercises during the class period to pass the time, and being assigned to teach ourselves new grammar concepts as part of our homework. She also would scold/berate students in public---if a homework was not acceptable due to whatever reason, in lieu of asking the student to come for office hours, she would just rant about the individual's assignment on front of the entire class.  This is so unprofessional and berating. I wonder if this teacher has any actual professional training for college level instruction.   Bottom line is that this class is not worth taking---you are better off taking Chinese, Arabic, or Urdu.
Take Farsi. Just do it.
Take Persian!  The classes are small and personal and you will learn a lot very quickly.
Take Persian!!! One of the best decisions I made at Princeton. I only wish I had started freshman year, but it's never too late. Even on Friday mornings this class is enjoyable
Very good first Persian course.
prereqs: PER 101 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop the skills of understanding, speaking, reading and writing modern Persian. The classes are conducted mostly in Persian with emphasis on oral drills and conversations.

title: Modern Irish Theatre: Oscar Wilde to Martin McDonagh to Riverdance
descrip: This course explores the many different ways in which the whole idea of a distinctively Irish theatre has been transformed every few decades, from Wilde and Shaw's subversions of England, to the search of Yeats and Synge for an authentic rural Ireland, to the often angry critiques of contemporary Ireland by Murphy, Friel and Carr. Plays of the Irish diaspora (O'Neill and McDonagh) are examined in this context. The course will also explore the ways in which ideas of physicality and performance, including the popular spectacle of Riverdance, have conflicted with and challenged Irish theatre's peculiar devotion to poetic language.

title: Seminar in Renaissance Art
descrip: Leonardo da Vinci is surrounded by myth and has a richer contemporary life than any other cultural figure. We will be looking at the "real" Leonardo in the contexts in which he worked. The emphasis will be on primary sources. Leonardo provides a comprehensive introduction to Renaissance painting, sculpture, drawing, architecture (civil and military), engineering and a range of what we call sciences. We will also be trying to understand the transmission and reception of "Leonardo" or even "Da Vinci" over the centuries. Who is the Leonardo of fiction? How can we define today's Leonardo in a way that is consistent with the sources.

title: Intermediate Chinese I
prereqs: CHI 101 and CHI 102 or equivalent..
descrip: While reinforcing the knowledge students have acquired thus far, this course will further develop the students' audio-lingual proficiency as well as bring their reading and writing ability to a higher level.

title: Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics Simulation in Statistical Physics & Materials Science
reviews: Don't be scared to ask questions.

I am from a biology background, and this is not much of a theory course. So I needed to struggle a bit to catch up with the class, e.g. in statistical mechanics part. But for the most part there was not much background needed. In general it was a great course and I learned a lot.
I recommend this course to any student who wants to learn the concepts and coding behind molecular simulations, although this course is a fairly big time commitment due to the long problem sets.
I strongly recommend this course; the material is well worth the students' time, and Thanos is a great professor to teach it.
I would strongly reccoment this class.
Need statistical mechanics background. It is not easy but it worths the price.
The students need to take the homework seriously. It's also good to exchange ideas about the homework with other students. One can learn much in this process.
This course was overall good and quite informative. It is challenging and somewhat time-consuming. You will be at a disadvantage if you don't know how to program.
This is definitely a great course that students interested in computational chemistry, materials science and biophysics should consider to take!

This is such an awesome course if you are thinking of doing anything related to molecular simulation. You can learn numerous simulation techniques with the opportunity to practice the skills by yourself.
descrip: This course examines methods for simulating matter at the atomistic scale with emphasis on the concepts that underline modern computational methodologies for classical many-body systems at or near statistical equilibrium. The course will cover Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics (from basics to advanced techniques).

title: Health Economics I
prereqs: Prerequisites: PhD-level microeconomics and econometrics..
descrip: Examines health issues in both developed and developing countries. Specific topics include the evolution of health over the life course; the fetal origins hypothesis; the two-way links between socioeconomic status and health; the impact of social safety nets on health outcomes; environmental threats to children's health and development; health insurance and its effects on health; the industrial organization of health care delivery; and the relationship between health and economic growth.

title: Neuroscience of Social Cognition and Emotion
reviews: Be skeptical at all times. Do not take anything for granted. Focus on figures first when you are reading research articles. Try to get a better grip on methodologies and statistical analyses - although not required for the course, it can be very useful and Prof. Hasson is probably happy to explain further.
Gives students a much needed perspective on the state of current Neuroscience research and the paradigm shift that's needed to move forward. I'd recommend this for Psych and Neuroscience students.
Great course, very interesting. I recommend you take an intro neuro course first.
If the topic sounds interesting to you will like the class.  As far as difficulty it is pretty average.  Its not particularly challenging but you do need to do just about all of the reading.
Interesting material if you become engaged in the course.
It is a good course to take if you are interested in neuroscience.
Make sure to check in with the professor and let him know if you have questions about any of the assignments or readings. He is a good communicator and responds to emails very readily
Pay attention during the lectures! A lot of students go on facebook, etc, but they are so interesting, so you are really missing out if you don't pay attention.

Stay on top of your readings. Pay attention to figures and actual results of the papers you read; never take authors' conclusions at face value. Engage with the discrepancies in findings in the papers you read. You can get a lot out of the class if you just do the readings and show up to class.
Take it if you're interested in Neuro, but be prepared for some serious science.
Take it!
Take this class if you're really interested in neuroscience. If you're not, you can probably find a better class to take.
Take this course!!!! :)
Very interesting, highly recommended. Professor Hasson is great.

You get as much out of this course as you put into it. It's not hard to coast through, given the minimal work requirements, but why pass up this incredible opportunity to gain more knowledge in the field from one of the leading researchers in it? Also, be prepared to do a presentation sometime during the semester.

overall one of the best courses i've taken at princeton. it is a unique, convincing, and inspirational presentation of the issues and promise of the field of social neuroscience. many students pursue a neuroscience certificate or are premed, but do not let that intimidate you. it is a very approachable class for any student, though basic neuroscience background helps.
prereqs: PSY 258.
descrip: This course explores the neural foundations of social cognition and social emotions. The objective is to provide a comprehensive overview of research topics relevant to the emerging field of social neuroscience. We will also discuss questions that cut across the specific topics that will be covered. Do neural systems exist that are specialized for social cognition or do the systems that participate in social cognition have more general cognitive functions? Can neuroscientific research shed new light on social cognition? How can different disciplines in neuroscience and the social sciences contribute to social neuroscience research?

title: Contemporary Issues in Spain and/or Latin America
reviews: .Although past reviews for SPA227 weren't stellar, if it's offered again by Nouzeilles absolutely take it. More of an Argentinian history class than a study of contemporary Latin America, the course offers a very nice understanding of the country's development.  Papers were generally manageable and the professor was very encouraging.
If you're interested in Latin American culture this is definitely a great class to take!
It's an okay course...don't expect to take away anything significant from it either than a credit.
Participate since the start. It is intimidating at first but it is so helpful in terms of growing as a Spanish speaker.
it was fun
prereqs: SPA 207 or instructor's permission..
descrip: The course focuses on current political, social, and cultural issues in Argentina, including social movements, the long-term effects of the 2001 financial crisis, new developments in film, tango and rock, environmental policy, international tourism, and economic changes. The course will give students an introduction to present day events and trends, mostly through a perusal and analysis of pieces from the local press, recent scholarly research, websites, short fiction, and film and documentaries.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
prereqs: REL 521.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows.

title: Introduction to Architectural Design
reviews: ARC majors are required to take this. Yet, if you're not an ARC major, be warned that it will be very time consuming.

Challenging but rewarding. Loved it. Highly time consuming, so you need to manage time wisely, but expect a couple of all-nighters, although if you love architecture, the pains you may go through only make you love it more. Gotta love that late-night studio bonding.
Definitely take it if Paul Lewis is teaching! Before you know it, you'll know so much more about architectural design!

If you think you might want to major in architecture or Civ.Arch, take this course spring of freshman year instead of spring of sophomore year. This way you will be able to see if architecture or Civ. Arch is right for you in your first year.

If you're very interested in architecture, take this course! If you're only somewhat interested in architecture, I would recommend taking ARC 206 instead (less of a time commitment).  Make sure you have a lot of time for this class, it's like two classes in one! (I spend 36 hours in one week on one project, and over 60 hours in five days on the final project!)
Take it!
Take the course out of keen interest in architectural design.

This course is a requirement for architecture majors. The SCORE course listing encourages that you take it during sophomore year, but I encourage freshmen thinking of majoring in architecture to take it, because it's an excellent way to make up your mind about whether or not you want to stay on this path, and sophomore spring is a bit late since at the end of the semester you have to decide, and you won't be able to explore your other options. Anyone looking for a course where you can interact freely and informally with both your instructors and classmates should take this course. It is truly enjoyable.

This is my favorite course at Princeton. If you are interested in design or architecture, this is the obvious starting point. It will be a big time commitment, but if you enjoy creative work it is a great time.

You should definitely take the studio with Paul Lewis. He is intellectually engaging, funny and really great to work with. Be prepare to work mostly outside the class and to not sleep very much. Also, if you feel that the studio takes  all the time in your semester, we've all been there. The experience was amazing and you get so close to your classmates that you actually feel bad when it's all over and you won't pull allnighters together anymore.
prereqs: ARC 204 is a prerequisite for entry into the departmental concentration. Students will be expected to purchase materials in order to carry out various assignments..
descrip: The first in a series of design studios offered to students interested in majoring in architecture. The course will introduce architecture as an "impure'' plastic art, inseparable from a network of forces acting upon it. The student will be confronted with progressively complex exercises involving spatial relations in two dimensions, three dimensions, and time. The course will stress experimentation while providing an analytical and creative framework to develop an understanding of structure and materials as well as necessary skills in drawing and model making. Two three-hour studios with lectures included.

title: Topics in the Formal Analysis of the Urban Structure - American Urbanism
reviews: I loved this course. The material was interesting and extremely relevant to today. It forced me to think about pressing issues - i.e. increasing populations and the role of the city, urban renewal, creating greens spaces. There was also a ton of freedom to design what I wanted, which I really appreciated. This class is especially interesting if you are interested in sustainability, green design and the technology of today/the future.
If you're interested in Urban Design it's a GREAT class to take, and you get Mario's view of the world along with it. be prepared for some repetitiveness, but the assignments are very fun :)
Mario is very nice and knowledgeable - take the class if you are interested in the topic! You will learn a lot.
Only take it if you are really interested in architecture and urbanism
Take advantage of Mario's immense knowledge and experience! He is one of the most approachable people you can find even though he is crazy busy.
This is an absolutely great way to become close to one of the best and most highly renowned professors in the School of Architecture - don't pass up the chance.
descrip: The American city has undergone a number of restructurings since colonial times. However, the mutations that occurred at the beginning and in the middle of the twentieth century not only restructured the city but also dramatically changed its configuration in a radical way. We might be living a similar situation today at the beginning of a new century, when changes as powerful as the sub-urbanization of the 1950's are generating new configurations of urban space and form that are expanding once more the definition of the city and urban culture.

title: Topics in Medieval Italian Literature and Culture - Boccaccio
reviews: If you can, take this course!!!
Take it!
Take it! Marchesi is the best professor I've had here!

This is the best class I have taken in the Italian class. Professor Marchesi is extraordinarily engaging and makes and topic you are learning about seem like the most interesting you've ever learned about.
prereqs: One 200-level ITA course or permission of Instructor required..
descrip: Boccaccio's "Decameron" is the preeminent masterwork of early Italian prose. A complex set of stories, linked by the author's convictions about literature and love, the "Decameron" offers both a panorama of fourteenth-century European society and a point of entry into some great traditions of European literature. This seminar will concentrate on a close reading of the "Decameron" in the original language.

title: Advanced General Chemistry: Honors Course
reviews: Ask more clarifying questions from the professors and ABSOLUTELY show up to the lectures during reading period. They are early and suck but they put all of that on the exam. Read your text more than I did, even if just skimming and reading the summaries. Probably do some practice problems.
Attend lectures.
Go for it. It's really not that bad

I did not like this course, and I wished many times that I had taken CHM 201/202 rather than CHM 215. Maybe 201/202 would have been too easy, but now I feel like I've been inadequately exposed to chemistry twice rather than adequately exposed once. 215 moves very quickly, and since it is such a small class there is not much support for it (only one TA, no attention at McGraw tutoring, etc.). My best advice is to pay attention during lectures and get help on the problem sets early on if you need it.
Stay on top of all of your work for this class and start studying ahead of time for each test.
Take this ONLY if you wish to fill the requirement fast- topics are not covered in depth.

This course is very fast-paced but a great review of the topics covered in AP Chemistry. You are expected to know most of the basic material that was covered in AP Chemistry before taking this course though. Reading the textbook helped me a lot for this course, and I would definitely recommend doing so, especially if a concept is unclear to you.
We had a great lecturer and TA, so the course was fine. Watch out for the curve on exams if your class is small.
prereqs: Prerequisite consists of excellent high school preparation AND placement into the course by the Chemistry Department. Please contact Dr. Robert L'Esperance, rpl@princeton.edu, for all changes in class and lab sections after the completion of registration {OR} to add CHM 215 {OR} to be added to a waiting list for closed class or lab sections..
descrip: Selected topics from general chemistry are presented from an advanced point of view. Emphasis is on the conceptual development of electronic structure and bonding, on applications of thermodynamics to chemical equilibrium, and on kinetics. A unified approach to molecular science is developed. The course is intended for serious students of science or engineering.

title: Intermediate Hindi II
reviews: Fauzia-ji is an excellent teacher! She really takes the time to teach you everything you'd want to know about Hindi and presents the material very well. Take this course!
If you are not exposed to hindi previously to the course, it may not be appropriate but Fauzia is very willing to assist students no matter what
The class will hugely depend on who is instructing it, as it is so small. Fauzia's class was very fun, relaxed, and enjoyable
prereqs: HIN105 or the equivalent level of proficiency.
descrip: Continuing from HIN 105, the course refines and expands previously acquired linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Focus on expanding vocabulary, mastering complex grammatical structures and idiomatic expressions. Use of authentic Hindi materials from print and electronic media, films, and folk literature. Equal emphasis on all skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). Activities are conducted in Hindi and classes are interactive.

title: International Institutions and Law
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of work. The material may not interest you, so unless you really like reading about international institutions and legal frameworks, you will probably be very bored. Nonetheless, Professor Keohane is an extremely intelligent and committed teacher, and I learned a lot beyond the actual material of the course.

Be warned: this course was the hardest, most intensive I have ever had at Princeton, and I hear it's the most rigorous offered by the POL department.  Seminars are excellent, and Keohane is a genius, but only take this class in a semester when you know you'll have the time to devote to it.
Excellent seminar, but the reading load is fairly heavy, the material is challenging at times, and the workload is on the heavy side. Well worth it if you put in the effort, though!
I highly recommend this course if you know that you will be challenged a lot.
Incredibly difficult but very rewarding course. Professor Keohane demands a lot of you but if you use his criticism you can learn a lot in this class.
Take it - be prepared to do a lot of work but also really learn the craft of research.
Take this course!

This is a very challenging course and one of the biggest work loads I've had at Princeton - but if you are at all interested in international relations, you owe it to yourself to take Keohane's class. He is widely regarded as the most influential IR scholar of the last 40 years and for good reason. He will make you become a significantly better IR student.
prereqs: POL 240 or its equivalent is required. Students must write a three-paragraph application of not more than 500 words. One paragraph should discuss the student's educational background and should include other information relevant to the issue of international institutions and law. The second paragraph should indicate what the students hopes to learn from the course, and the third paragraph should discuss any career aspirations relevant to the topic.
descrip: This course will focus on the continual tension between international law and international politics. It will examine the impact of tension on issues of intervention and other issues of substantive importance, including environmental protection, trade, human rights, laws of war applicable to the "war on terror," and crimes of state. It will discuss recent developments affecting international institutions and recent changes in international law, such as the changing conception of "sovereignty." The principal course objective is to help students learn how to do original research and analysis on issues related to international politics and law.

title: Society and the Witch
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Empirical Macro and Finance
reviews: This class is the most interesting class I have taken as a graduate student.
descrip: This course is geared towards (i) understanding how finance and the macro economy interact with each other, and (ii) introducing micro-empirical techniques and data sets for answering traditional macro questions. The focus of the class is empirical but we begin each topic with a discussion of its theoretical foundation.

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: Be sure to read everything given thoroughly and to just do as she says.
Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in the theatre department or acting in general.  You will work hard but you will definitely improve.
Go all out! If unclear, ask Suzie. Pour your effort into written assignments because they help you with the grade towards the end.
I like Tracy's class

I loved this course. I came to the course with virtually no acting experience and no training, and was somewhat intimidated to begin. Suzie's instruction made acting achievable and fun, and I learned a lot of great skills that will stay with me off the stage as well. A
I would recommend this course to anyone.
Not super work heavy other than setting up rehearsal times. A lot of fun, I suggest it for everybody with any interest in acting
Strongly recommend this course with Tracy. The 5 hours of class per week were 5 of my favorite hours every week!
TAKE IT WITH TRACY! It is such a great LA if you're looking for a fun distribution requirement.

TAKE THIS CLASS.  Tracy is amazing.  AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING.  It's good for people who think of themselves as non actors in addition to actors.  Tracy works really hard to make sure that she challenges everyone, no matter what their skill or confidence level is at the beginning.  I can't say enough about how wonderful I think she is.
Take it with Professor Bersley!!

Take it! Definitely worth working into one's schedule - whether simply as an LA requirement or to start digging into theatre. Suzie is great and the community that you build within the class is one of the most valuable things you may gain from it.
Take it!!!

Take this class. Tracy Bersley is amazing. Take it with her. 

With a bunch of science-ish classes, I loved having this class as a contrast. Class itself is something you'll really look forward to, and basically, I could take everything I did for this class as a study break for my other classes. Don't underestimate the work (rehearsal time and stuff) that you will need, though - or even better said, out of experience: You will get as much out of this class as you put in. And it's super worth putting a lot into.

Whether you have a lot of theater experience of have never acted before, this class will teach you a lot, and a lot of stuff you can use in your everyday life.

Again: take this class.

Take this course with Tracy!  She is so nice (and everyone seems to not like Suzy).  We spent the first half of the semester doing all sorts of exercises and meditation and character building.  Then we got to do two partner scenes at the end.  Overall if you have any interest in acting you should definitely take this!
This course really works on throwing you outside of your comfort zone intellectually and physically
prereqs: This course is by Open Enrollment until the first day of class. Enrollment is by permission of instructors during the first two weeks of class. For enrollment in Section 1 (Mon/Wed), please contact Professor Suzanne Agins (slagins@). For enrollment in Section 2 (Tue/Thurs), please contact Professor Tracy Bersley (tberslex@)..
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: The Arthurian Legend in Literature and Film
descrip: See website

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Physics & Technology of Low-Dimensional Semiconductors
reviews: Any student who wish to do research in two dimensional systems should take the course.
I would certainly recommend this class. Mansour is a great teacher and you will certainly come away with a greater understanding of the low dimensional physics of semiconductors.
If you have the background necessary for covering this material, it is definitely worth it - and even more so if you hope to be doing work in the field at any point.
If you want to do something directly related to condensed matter physics, this class would not disappoint you.
descrip: A broad overview of materials science and physics of low-dimensional semiconductor structures will be presented. Emphasis will be on the fabrication and physics of high-mobility carrier systems in modulation-doped structures. Examples include two-dimensional, one-dimensional (quantum wire), and zero-dimensional (quantum dot) systems.

title: Remote Sensing for Ecology
descrip: Many ecological issues can only be resolved using remote sensing (RS). RS is needed to answer questions such as: How are habitat features important to species distribution? At what spatial and temporal scales are these features utilized? RS is necessary for addressing practical questions, such as: Am I missing important features that can't be measured from the ground? This terrain is punishing--how am I going to collect enough habitat data for my research? Beginning with an introduction to basic RS concepts, this hands-on course will show how to overcome research challenges and improve understanding of ecological structure and function.

title: Economic Perspectives on Inequality (Half-Term)
descrip: Economics is centrally concerned with models of human capital development, educational attainment, labor market dynamics, unemployment, labor turnover, job duration, wage setting institutions, the role of unions, human capital formation, the relationship between economic status and other aspects of well-being (including health). Economists are essential partners in the behavioral study of preferences and decision making, mobility and redistribution, and the institutions of industrial relations that govern the labor market.

title: Climate Science and Communications
reviews: Be prepared for receiving arbitrary grades with no feedback or explanation. It's a good PDF course though.

I'm really sad to say this, but if you are looking to build skills, don't take it.  The professors are really really nice and you learn interesting things about climate change, but you do not learn journalism skills.
If you want to learn how to send messages take this class.
This class is a great introduction to making infographics, podcasts, and videos, and the professors are relaxed and helpful. Take it!
This course is not hard if you're willing to devote a few hours per assignment to learn how to use the program; you learn skills that will probably be useful in the future

This course needs better organization. While there isn't much homework, there are periodic projects that can be overwhelming if done at the last minute. Be prepared to not receive any feedback on projects, sit through 3 hour lectures, and make the final video with only your group. The professors pretty much disappear in the second half of the course, so it's up to your group to get together and learn how to use the video editing software.
This course was fun and interesting but felt like self taught. Don't expect much guidance from the professors.

This is a easy, interesting course where you'll meet cool people who do work in climate communications, and get a lot of hands on experience yourself. You won't actually learn too much, but it's a fun and light course. The instructors are really nice and helpful, but a bit disorganized.
This is a very chill and fun class, but almost frustratingly disorganized, so it's a tradeoff. Take it if you're interested in the course material!
prereqs: Strong interest in science and communications; no previous coursework or experience necessary..
descrip: In order to assess and address the risks of climate change, people need accurate information. Most of this information comes from the world of science and requires translation. The role of trained science communicators is crucial. The goal of this course is to give students the technical, narrative and critical-evaluation skills needed to communicate climate science across a variety of media - print, graphical, podcast, and video. The course begins with an overview of the state of climate science and communications. We then discuss critical elements of journalism. The last weeks focus on video production using Final Cut.

title: Greek Historiography
descrip: A reading of selections from Polybius' work combined with discussion of historical and historiographical topics.

title: Screenwriting: Creating Visual and Emotional Unity
reviews: Definitely a worthwhile introduction to screenwriting. You'll get out what you put into the class.
If you want to learn how to write for the screen, this course will help.

Lazaridi is a fantastic instructor and a very perceptive critic. Time in class was split between "lecture" format with her speaking to us, and student workshops in which a student would present a few pages of material and then she would guide a group discussion and provide feedback for revision. She communicates very well when "instructing," but the workshops were by far the most valuable part. That's something you'll never get from a book or a video. She's very adept at spotting the real problem in a scene that doesn't work, often an element that we hadn't even considered.
TAKE THIS CLASS FOR SURE
Take it!
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and, optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre..
descrip: This class will familiarize students with the complex use of metaphorical, emotional, and visual threads in screenplay writing. Analyzing examples of international, independent, and classical structures, students will be exposed to the rhythms and demands of the process of conceiving and writing a long form narrative film.

title: Intermediate Swahili II
prereqs: Intermediate Swahili I (SWA 105 ) or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course emphasizes conversational fluency and increased facility in reading and writing skills while introducing students to Swahili literature. This literature forms the basis for a survey on cultural aspects and more advanced grammer. Students will be able to understand and analyze the main ideas and significant details of materials in Swahili such as media articles, short stories, poetry, short novels, films and plays illustrative of East African cultural issues. Covers advanced-level Swahili grammar, as well as the development of expository writing skills.

title: Animal Behavior
reviews: All animal lovers: TAKE THIS COURSE.

Animal Behavior made me decide I wanted to do EEB. Very manageable amount of work and very interesting questions considered in lecture. Gould is an undisputed expert & pioneer in the field. Amazing to hear how many pertinent experiments had been done at Princeton.
Anyone looking for an interesting STN or interested in life on earth should take this. Be prepared for tricky exams.

Do it. The class is a lot of fun, and you will certainly learn a lot from it. Pay attention in lecture and take good notes though, because the exams are very detailed and comprehensive. Make sure to study the examples, and do as many of the readings as you can.
Gould is an awesome lecturer and the material is fascinating.  If you're at all interested in animals and how they function, take this course.
Great course!  I kept citing examples from it in my daily conversation.  Good stuff to know in general.

If you like animals, take it, lectures are hugely entertaining, funny, and enjoyable, and you learn a lot of very interesting and important things about animals and their worlds. Study for exams and go to lecture. Really good STN for non science majors
It is important to do the course readings to supplement what you learn in lecture. Go to lecture!

Number one piece of advice: go to lecture! The lecture material is the most important in terms of what will be covered on the exam. Take good notes in lecture. You could even try recording the lectures in case you want to double check things later. Pay attention to examples that show up in multiple places - the readings, the lecture, the textbook, and precept. For the exam, focus on knowing examples of all the major concepts.
One of the few EEB departmentals that I think are interesting and worth taking in the spring. If you take it, you'll learn something for sure.
Pretty interesting (if you don't mind insects), and pretty light workload.
Record lectures and try to generate a list of concepts and examples of the concepts to ace the exams.
Savour every moment
Take it and write down everything said in lecture

Take this course with James L. Gould. I'm a POL major, and I loved this. Gould is hilarious with his dry sarcasm and knows the subject very well. Excellent lecturer. He might be a curmudgeon and probably doesn't care too much about his students since he's retiring soon, but still a great class.
This course is interesting but a little dry at times.
This course is really interesting, and less work than some others. It is very important to go to the lectures.
This course was great! Gould was a great lecturer. Fairly easy workload and really interesting material.
This is a good course for both science and non-science majors.  While the tests are fairly difficult, the material is very rewarding.
This is a good pdf but if you are taking it for a grade beware that you will need to memorize a lot of small details and facts.
its very interesting but there is a lot of material
n/a
take it for a pdf
you might not be as interested in animal behavior as you think...
descrip: One of the fascinating challenges in biology is to understand the origins and organization of animal behavior. Ethology is the branch of biology concerned with the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. The course begins by examining the discovery of early ethologists of behavioral units or "programs", and relates these to our understanding of the nervous system. We look at how complex behaviors such as navigation, learning, and planning are organized. We study the social behavior of several species and end with an ethological analysis of our own species.

title: Optimization
reviews: . Well optimization obviously has many applications, so you'll likely see it again at some point. Unfortunately, the class was very poorly taught with Mulvey. It was completely uninteresting. Also there was not enough focus on the theory of optimization, on the math and algorithms. Instead we spent most of our time formulating problems in Excel. I'm sure everyone else is slamming the course in these reviews, but I still think optimization is an important subject. Maybe look for some alternatives if you're not an ORF major?

Apparently it's worse with Vanderbei, but either way I guess this course is beyond saving, which is a pity since optimization is such a crucial and potentially fascinating area. Super easy but you won't actually feel very smart. Changle and Lorenzo are THE WORST. Max is a blessing. If you're not ORF, don't take this class please. There are so many other ORF classes that are actually amazing and interesting.
Check your p-sets closely, small mistakes add up and the curve's not very generous
Definitely attend the precepts. This course is mostly about taking the extra step to actually learn, rather than regurgitate, the material.
Definitely take this class with Prof. Mulvey if possible. He is great and very interesting!
Do the problem sets well.
Don't take it unless you absolutely have to.
Don't take it unless you are an orf major....
Don't take with professor Mulvey unless you have to.
Easy workload, but you really only ought to take this if you need to.
Go to Max's precept.
Go to office hours.
Great course, although really only ORFE and EMS certificate pursuers take it.
If Mulvey is teaching, better not. If ORFE, gotta take it.
If you can take it with professor mulvey, do it because the material is not that hard and it is interesting.
If you're good with numbers this course is extremely easy. Even if you aren't it still isn't bad. Take it.

If you're interested in how to arrive at an optimal allocation, you should take this class. The concepts overlap with economics (allocation) and computer science (AMPL programming and max flow and spanning trees).
If you're not an ORFE major, don't take this course. If you are an ORFE major, maybe it's time to consider other majors instead. Or to petition to get this removed as an ORFE requirement.
It was an easy class with Mulvey (though lectures definitely aren't necessary). Not sure how the course is with Vanderbei.
It's a relatively easy course that has applications in finance and various other industries
Just get Max for precept.  Mulvey is all over the place in lecture
Only take if you are ORFE or getting an ORFE certificate.
Only take it if required, and try to avoid Mulvey
Pretty easy class with useful material. Definitely take it.
Take if required. If Mulvey is teaching, you should be fine.
Take it because you're an ORF major...
Take it if you have free time!  Easy class and cool concepts
Take it if you have to
Take it if you have to, if you don't, wait to see if Vanderbei gets better, cause right now there are just no people who teach it well.
Take it if you have to. It's relatively interesting but not terribly well-taught.
Take it! Go to Max's precepts, you will learn everything and get everything clarified there. Buy PMS with another person (i.e. share it, otherwise, maybe a little too expensive).
Take it! You won't regret it.  It's interesting, useful, and the grades aren't so bad.
Take it, it's good.
Take it. it will blow your mind away
Take the class, it's fine.

The material is a little dry but was interesting to me. I wouldn't take this unless you are on ORF major because anything you need to know you can probably pick up on your own. Professor Mulvey was usually unclear in his notation and hard to follow and the course was rather disorganized.
Unless you're an ORF student, stay away. If you want to learn optimization (very useful), you can do it by yourself or over a finance internship.
Yes. It is useful stuff, but often times tedious.
You need to take for ORFE departmental.

You won't feel like you have learned anything from this class. In fact, you could probably teach yourself everything in a weekend or two with the textbook. But it's not a ton of work and satisfies the requirements. Professor Mulvey is a nice guy, definitely give him a chance to impress.
this course is pretty boring. However it does teach you how to use excel very well
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204. Basic computer programming knowledge suggested..
descrip: Many real-world problems involve maximizing a linear function subject to linear inequality constraints. Such problems are called Linear Programming (LP) problems. Examples include min-cost network flows, portfolio optimization, options pricing, assignment problems and two-person zero-sumgames to name but a few. The theory of linear programming will be developed with a special emphasis on duality theory. Attention will be devoted to efficient solution algorithms. These algorithms will be illustrated on real-world examples such as those mentioned.

title: Rise of Asia: Political Economy of Development
reviews: A good way to get an understanding of industrial development without taking an economics course.
A very engaging course and extremely in-depth considering the breadth of the course's topic. Just remember that the take-home essay's can be brutal to complete, and the grading can be quite harsh.
DO THE RECOMMENDED READINGS YOU WILL LOVE THEM
Definitely take it.
Great course. Very focused introduction to some big issues in the economy of Asia.
If you are interested in the subject material, it is a great class!

Professor Kohli is a great lecturer, who is thorough in the material he covers and supplementing the readings with his own research and commentary rather than summarizing the readings, and who opens up the class to questions when time is available, which is a combination rare among faculty even at Princeton.  The class is intense in terms of its writing workload, but it is definitely manageable and as such I would recommend it as neither an easy nor a particularly difficult course, but definitely an interesting and engaging one that is useful for anyone with an interest in the more historical aspects of economic development.
Professor Kohli is on sabbatical for a year but definitely take a course with him if you get a chance.  He is just so knowledgeable and helpful
Take it - lectures are interesting. Not the most critically challenging class.
Take it if you are interested in Asian development models.
Take it. You will learn a lot from a brilliant professor. He will challenge your preconceptions about how states interact in markets.

Take this course if you are at all interested in political economy, development, or Asia.  I came in with no background in political economy, but Kohli is a great lecturer and I ended up writing my JP on subject matter related to class.  Try to get in to Kohli's precept- he is knowledgable and very approachable.

Take this if you're at all remotely interested in East Asian political economy!!!  Only requires basic level knowlege of economics, and Professor Kohli's lectures are organized, to the point, and engaging.
Try to take good notes on the readings and lectures so that you will be able to organize your notes into an argument quickly for the essays.
You will learn a lot of material about three different countries. There will be a lot of writing and no independent research. You learn a lot but its not that intellectually stimulating.
professor kohli is one of the best lecturers in pol dept.
take it if you want to learn about how the state was involved in the economic development of the three countries. It's more history and politics than economics.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites but students with background in one of the following are likely to get the most from the course: a prior course in the politics or economics of developing countries; or a course in the history or politics or economics of, say, one of the three countries to be studied during the course..
descrip: The economies of many Asian countries have grown rapidly over the last several decades. This course will study the political and economic pathways travelled by select Asian countries on their road to prosperity. The focus will be on three specific countries: South Korea, China and India. We will analyze comparatively the models of development pursued in these countries, especially the state's role in promoting growth and distribution.

title: Epidemiology
reviews: Amy was an awesome preceptor!!
Definitely do the Gordis readings.
Don't slack off or the amount of work in this class will catch up to you in a hurry. Try to bring your game-face to every lecture.
Go to all the lectures, don't worry too much about the readings, and start a bit early on your case reviews.

I think this course is very interesting and exposes you to a different type of thinking you may not find in your other classes. It's not necessarily very intense but there is a lot to learn quickly so I would also say it is somewhat challenging but very worthwhile and interesting.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone considering a career in medicine or public policy.
I would say do the readings and it is a great class.

If you are in GHP, this is a requirement. It's a good class though. Sometimes a lot of work but you are constantly keeping up with material because of it. Otherwise, I think that if you have an interest in epi this is a wonderful opportunity to get exposure as an an undergrad.

If you're interested in learning how to evaluate studies and want to better understand disease dynamics, take this!  This is a solid course.  Take time with case studies, and pick easy cases.  You get out what you put in in a lot of ways, but there's so much to get out.  Prof. Amon is also a great person to get to know, and he has tons of fascinating experience.
If you're taking it, you probably have to - but it's definitely not a bad class. It was more math then I was expecting, but it's not overwhelming.
It takes a lot of time and commitment to do well.
It's a really interesting class!
It's a really interesting class, but you have to work hard!
Only if you are a GHP certificate.
Only if you have to really. Not much inspirational to say here.

Professor Amon has a great sense of humour, which made learning about disease outbreaks extra-fun. Great course, even if just for general knowledge about all the craziness that is going on in the world. It will give you the tools to assess some of the casual "causal claims" we hear in everyday life more critically. Are blueberries and the mediterranean diet actually good for your health? Plus you will get to learn about the crucial SES as confounder for everything in life.
Professor Amon is so kind and sweet and cares for his students.

Skim the textbook, but really stay alert in class. The concepts may seem simple to grasp, but the substance of the class is really found during discussion in lecture. Be bold enough to answer his questions. He might shut you down, but you'll remember why you were wrong at that point. Ask him questions. Constantly be thinking from the perspective that you really are an epidemiologist on that project. Start the case studies a few days in advance so you have time to locate an article and ask your preceptor about it in advance if need be. (Be concise in those!). Take advantage of this course. It's one of the only Princeton classes that you can actually use practically in the real world.
Some good information, often somewhat frustrating.
Take this class! Fun, interesting, and reasonable!
There's no curve! Beware.
This course is an excellent introduction to epidemiology and public health and deals not only with technical aspects of epidemiology but also policy and ethical considerations.
This course is harder than it may appear.
This course is very interesting! It has been my favorite course so far.
This is a fine class. The material is relevant and useful. Lecture is not incredibly engaging.
While some people found this class dry, I found it extremely useful in developing my empirical research thesis. Professor Amon is an entertaining lecturer as well.
if you are at all interested TAKE IT, its fascinating!!
prereqs: Completion of an approved basic statistics course (e.g., ECO 202, EEB/MOL 355, ORF 245, POL 345, PSY 251 or SOC 301), or completion of an advanced statistics course (e.g., ECO 302, ECO 312, ORF 405, SOC 404, WWS 200, and WWS 332)..
descrip: This required course for GHP students focuses on the distribution and determinants of disease. Diverse methodological approaches for measuring health status, disease occurrence, and the association between risk factors and health outcomes will be presented via classic and contemporary studies of chronic and infectious illness and disease outbreaks. Emphasis on: causal inference, study design and sampling, bias and confounding, the generalizability of research, health policy and research ethics.

title: Financial Crises
reviews: Jose is one of the best professors you'll ever had.
Take it. You won't regret it.
model based course explaining crises from multiple angles
descrip: The use economic theory and empirical evidence to study the causes of financial crises and the effectiveness of policy responses to them. Particular attention given to some of the major economic and financial crises of the past century and to the crisis that began in August 2007.

title: Topics in Russian Literature or Literary Theory - Academic Russian
prereqs: Open to graduate students and undergraduate students who have completed at least one 400-level language course (permission of the instructor required)..
descrip: The course is intended for graduate students with an advanced level of Russian. It aims to improve the students' proficiency in academic language, it structure and vocabulary. An emphasis is placed on stylistic devices - words and phrases used for stating aims and objectives, phrases conveying a point of view and opinion, verbs expressing positive or negative attitudes, introductory and parenthetic words, as well as connective devices that help to create a flow between ideas and points. A large portion of the course is dedicated to an in-depth review of some complex grammatical concepts (such as verb aspect and word order).

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty member.

title: Planetary Systems: Their Diversity and Evolution
prereqs: GEO 207, GEO 255, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Examines the diversity of recently discovered planetary systems in terms of fundamental physical and chemical processes and what this diversity implies about the origin and evolution of our own planetary system. Topics include: the formation and dynamics of planets and satellites, planetary migration, the evolution of planetary interiors, surfaces and atmospheres, the occurrence of water and organics, and the habitability of planets and planetary systems. Recent discoveries from planetary missions and extrasolar planet observations are emphasized.

title: Food Matters
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Modern Chinese Literature and Film
descrip: An introduction to the major literary and cinematic texts of modern China. Emphasis will be on the close reading/viewing of these works, but discussion will also include the socio-historical context in which these works were produced and consumed. Issues to be discussed include the relationship between city and countryside, issues of femininity and masculinity, revolution as political and aesthetic act, and the global circulation of Chinese literature and film.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture II
reviews: Definitely take it!
Highly recommend
I think it is important to be on top of your work and to be diligent about completing assignments. Be ready to put in your fair share of work to improve.
Its a good class, would be good to pdf as well. A well taught, organized language class.
Take it! It requires a lot of work, but in the end it was definitely worth it.
You should take this class.
prereqs: KOR 401 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion of Korean thoughts and issues in contemporary Korea. Readings drawn from a variety of cultural and historical topics. Class discussions will be conducted in Korean.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
reviews: I would recommend to take this course to all students which are interested not only in Quantum field theory, but in other topics, like Condensed matter physics, Cosmology, etc.
If you're even looking at this course evaluation, then there should be no question that you should take this class..
Must take this if interested in QFT. Prerequisite: the introductory QFT course.

This is a great course to take after taking 509.  Professor Klebanov provides a pretty coherent continuation of 509.  Since some of us were familiar with renormalization and some weren't, he spent some time getting us all up to speed using renormalized perturbation theory and reviewing path integral methods.  Then we learned about effective action techniques, renormalization group flow, and non-Abelian gauge theories, both in the continuum and on the lattice, something which Peskin and Schroeder doesn't really do justice to.  Problem sets were usually due only every other week, so the workload is manageable.
Very interesting material. Prof. Klebanov is a great teacher and quite approachable. Definitely take it
descrip: Relations between Quantum Field Theory and Statistical Mechanics, Renormalization Group, Non-Abelian Gauge Theories, Asymptotic Freedom, Quantum Chromodynamics, Chiral Lagrangians, General Constraints on RG Flows.

title: Judicial Politics
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are interested in law and politics. It is very interesting and engaging.
Get into Kastellec's precept. Have fun with it.
I would take this course if you like models for the real world or are interested in Politics of domestic policy.
It is a fine class to learn about judicial politics. Not much relevance to people who aren't highly interested in the courts.

Overall, this was an enjoyable class. Professor Kastellec is not the most exciting lecturer, but the material is interesting and he explains it well. He is also a good preceptor and tries to keep things interesting with different games and exercises. Be aware that this class involves two exams as well as a 15-20 pages paper, so it can be a lot of work at times, but the grading seemed very fair and Professor Kastellec was always helpful.
go to lecture and precept
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the political science of law and courts. Topics typically include: bargaining and decision making on the U.S. Supreme Court; political struggles over doctrine within the judicial hierarchy; the politics of Supreme Court nominations; juries as political institutions; court packing, jurisdiction stripping and judicial intimidation.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: It's not so bad! Meet some of your colleagues while discussing ethics.
Participate in class and it will be much more fun.
Read the materials before go to the class.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies? requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: Problems in Literary Study - Style in the Renaissance: History and Prehistory
descrip: An exploration of stylistic theory in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries with special attention to the impact of recently recovered ancient rhetorical treatises, including Aristotle's Rhetoric and Cicero's Brutus and Orator.

title: Media Arabic I
reviews: Hunt down Hisham and pay him whatever he asks to tutor you.
I would strongly recommend this course. It ties together everything studied in previous years and starts to make it instinctive.
Take it only if Ustaadh Hisham is teaching it. Best professor I've had at Princeton.

This is a good class for someone who wants to use the Modern Standard Arabic they've learned in the real world context that it is used. Rather than teaching new material, it helped teach how to use knowledge that we already have.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or the equivalent..
descrip: Designed to train students to understand Arabic in television, radio and journalism. Students will read newspapers, magazines, and websites and watch online news and satellite television to develop proficiency in the Arabic of the media. The course is structured around current internet and print content, covering social, political, and popular issues. Political cartoons at the end of the term will also serve to stimulate class discussions. Translation will be emphasized as a primary method to ensure reading and listening comprehension at every stage.

title: Modern Physics I: Condensed-Matter Physics
prereqs: PHY 208 and PHY 301 and PHY 305..
descrip: This survey course applies concepts from quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics to the properties of electrons in solids. Topics include phonons and lattice dynamics, electronic band structure, the tight-binding approximation, origin of exchange and magnetism, spin waves, Ginzburg Landau theory of phase transitions, and the BCS theory of superconductivity.

title: Introduction to Financial Mathematics
reviews: A worthwhile course. It might be a good idea to get familiar with financial stuff before taking this course. I wasn't, it was okay, but I would have caught on to stuff faster. You'll notice that in many of the homeworks and exams there are questions that have you derive results in more or less the same manner as you did in lectures and the notes. So know your derivations of things like the Black-Scholes PDE. Also we had on our final a question that was also on the midterm... So take a good look at past exams, including ones you took, when preparing.
Definitely take this course, if you are thinking of going into the finance industry and may do some coding!

Didn't like it at first - being non-finance minded I struggled in the first few weeks to understand call options, being "short", market terms etc. But I quickly learned that stuff and found that the course is really a great intro into financial math (not mathematical finance!) and is clear, thorough, and straightforward. Cagin, who also precepted 309, is super nice and a great help.
Don't take it if you don't need to
Don't take it unless you love the material (or have to). It's a lot of work, and not worth it.
Good quant finance intro course!

Good to great course. Pretty difficult (the second half gets there, don't worry), so make sure to keep up with the math and stochastic calculus. Interesting, and great to learn more about finance, the crisis, etc.
Great class if you're interested in the technical side of finance and are willing to put in the time.  The class is hard though, and you'll need to put in the time to do well on the problem sets.
Great course, really well taught.

If you actually like finance take it. It's a decent amount of work and full of tools who really love finance (or at least money) so it's annoyingly competitive. I didn't like it since I don't like finance, but I had to do it to major in ORFE.

If you enjoyed ORF 309 AND are interested in finance and option pricing, this is a class for you. Otherwise, this class isn't easy and should be taken only if you are an ORF major. Sircar is a clear if dry lecturer, although he does not explain stochastic calculus very well. The precepts are not that useful except for midterm review and matlab help.
If you took 309 and have any interest in finance, you should definitely take this course.
It's not an easy course, but it's very rewarding. Prof Sircar is amazing!
Keep up with the material really well and really pay attention in class.
Pay attention. read over lecture notes after lecture
Prof Sircar is a great teacher.
Professor Sircar is an excellent lecturer, and is very easy to talk to in office hours.
Take it. This course is outstanding; Sircar is an excellent lecturer and you will get a lot out of it if you work hard.
Take this course, you will not regret it.
This class could be a lot of work but is one of the lighter courses in the ORF core classes.
This course is very interesting, but definitely requires a lot of work in the second half (rather than the first).
This is a difficult course if you struggle with finance.  Learn Matlab before taking the course as a few of the problem sets are matlab heavy.
Very difficult, especially after the midterm.
Very difficult.  Very rewarding.
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 104 and ORF 309 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Mathematics is concerned with designing and analyzing products that improve the efficiency of markets and create mechanisms for reducing risk. This course introduces the basics of quantitative finance: the notions of arbitrage and risk-neutral probability measure are developed in the case of discrete models. Black-Scholes theory is introduced in continuous-time models, and credit derivatives and the term structure of interest rates are discussed, as well as lessons from the financial crisis.

title: Computer Graphics
reviews: !!! This class is a lot of work, and you have to teach yourself everything. Beware.

A good advice is that you probably don't want to take this course if you don't plan to commit quite a lot of time to it. That said, it is very rewarding for people who are willing to spend time and make efforts.
A lot of programming but really fun class, homework didnt even feel like work sometimes.
A must take for all CS majors
Definitely a great course. Some C   knowledge is encouraged but really not required. Take it if you're interested in graphics.
Definitely one of the top courses offered in the CS department. Prof. Finkelstein shines here as a lecturer, and the assignments are top notch.
Definitely take the course if you are at all interested. Very visually dazzling, and not overwhelming in material or work (although possibly time consuming for some projects).
Everyone should take it. It has been my favorite cos so far.
