Graphics is a really interesting and rewarding class.  Everyone does incredibly well on the assignments, though, so be sure to put time in.  Assignments usually take 20-30 hours, but you have a few weeks to do them.  For exams, just be sure to make a thorough cheat sheet and look over past ones.  The book is not necessary in the slightest.
If you're willing to put in the work it's a cool course.
It will take time, but it's a fun course.

It's a good course, especially if you're okay with a philosophy of "if it looks good, it is good." Be prepared for lots of geometry and for spending a lot of time on projects. Don't take it during an otherwise heavy semester unless you absolutely have to (especially don't take it with algorithms and independent work). Precepts and readings are mostly unnecessary.
Learn OpenGL, maybe make a simple game. It'll give you a huge advantage.
Like all COS courses: start your assignments early.  Otherwise, enjoy the course.
Take it if you are interested in graphics.

Take it.  If you don't have a lot of experience with C/C  , the assignments will take you a while.  Even if you do, the assignments will take you a while.  But they're fun.  The clips in lecture are interesting, but lecture isn't necessary to do well in the class.

Take this course because you learn so much that you probably didn't know about before and you create satisfying results when you complete your assignments, but just be wary of the amount of time each one will take you.
Take this course if you're even tangentially interested in graphics! Who doesn't like pretty pictures? It's even more fun to make 'em, and even more fun than that to write programs that do so.
The assignments are a lot of fun but VERY time consuming. Take the course if you have time in your schedule, you won't regret it!! You do some realyl awesome stuff!
The course is a lot of work, but very rewarding.
The course is intense, but if you are really interested in the area, please do take it, and you'll gain a lot from it.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Introduction to computer graphics. Topics include image synthesis, 3D modeling, image processing and animation. Encourage hands-on experience.

title: Roman Law
descrip: Objectives are to understand the basic principles of a major system of civil law, to trace the beginnings of these principles in the society that produced them, and to make some comparison between Roman and modern Common Law.

title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations
reviews: Go to all of the seminars, even those that do not seem relevant to your own interests. It is great just to see what the current topics are in ecology.
You'll have to do it, but try to make the most of conversations with visiting faculty.
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)

title: Postblack - Contemporary African American Art
descrip: As articulated by Thelma Golden, postblack refers to the work of African American artists who emerged in the 1990s with ambitious, irreverent, and sassy work. Though hard to define, postblack suggested the emergence of a generation of artists removed from the long tradition of black affirmation of the Harlem Renaissance, black empowerment of the Black Arts movement, and identity politics of the 1980s and early 90s. This seminar provides an opportunity for a deep engagement with the work of African American artists of the past decade. It will involve critical and theoretical readings on multiculturalism, race, identity, and contemporary art.

title: Representing the Holocaust
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese I
prereqs: CHI 107 or CHI 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Introduction to the grammar of classical Chinese through study of selections from ancient texts. Readings include the Analects and the Mencius

title: Advanced Language and Style
reviews: I would definitely recommend it. Teardo is awesome and it's not too much work.
I'd recommend it.
Take it!
Take it! The readings aren't too long, but full of stuff to talk about.
Very predictable workload and interesting readings.  Great to improve your Italian and gain a foothold in literature by reading smaller sections of a wide variety of works.
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level Italian course or instructor's permission..
descrip: We will concentrate on the textual analysis of literary texts from the beginning of Italian literature to the present. An intensive grammatical, syntactical, and rhetorical analysis of every piece will be conducted through class discussion. Students will be asked to prepare oral presentations on the authors studied, and to write short papers on each text.

title: Architecture and the Visual Arts
reviews: As a student who has no architectural background who loves art, I did not find this course too difficult. There was a bit of a learning curve because I needed to quickly look up basic architectural concepts, but once I understood some of the architectural references the course did not seem as daunting.
Be mindful that the lectures might not be what you expected
Do not take this course

Don't take this class.  The lectures are long and disengaging.  The readings are terrible, dense and hard to follow.  Which ultimately does not matter because the midterm and final does not test you on them.  I was hoping to learn how to critically analyze the modern art and architecture and gain knowledge on the subject, but that did not happen.  If you are looking to learn about architecture and art, do not take this class.
Eh

For anyone who is not an architecture major, expect this course to be harder than you presume it to be. The kind of analysis expected in the midterm and final papers is different from the ones you are normally used to (e.g. Writing Seminar).

I am not exactly sure why this is a course.  It was a huge pain to deal with, even though I was just PDFing.  Lecture was mandatory and yet impossible to understand or gain anything from--after a full semester, I have yet to learn anything even remotely substantive.  I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this course to anyone.

I have never been so strongly displeased with anything academically at Princeton. I feel cheated that I wasted my time at this great institution on this course.   I have learned very little and have had to deal with the disaster that is this class.  Unless substantial changes are made to this course, do not take it.
I would probably say not to take it, especially if you're a senior.
If you're looking for an extremely interesting LA, this it your class.
It's a decent class, and easy to PDF.
Just do the readings. Not much is necessary for papers.
No. No. No.
Not too much reading, the lectures are very interesting, I really enjoyed this course
Spend lots of time on the essays, as they comprise the largest amount of the final grade.
The material is great and it'll really expand your perspective if you've never taken a course like this
take the class
descrip: This course will explore the relationships between architectural discourse and the visual arts from the historical avant-garde to the present. Architectural discourse will be considered here as the intersection of diverse systems of representation: buildings, projects, drawings, but also architectural theory and criticism, exhibitions, photographs, professional magazines and the popular press. The visual arts will be seen to include not only painting and sculpture, but also photography, cinema, fashion, advertisement and television.

title: Introduction to Machine Translation
reviews: 3 hours is a long time to pay attention, but the material is pretty cool. Try to pick a final project you are interested in. Professor Bangalore can be very flexible and helpful so don't be shy to ask for help or advice.
A solid linguistics and CS background (at least 1 course beyond 126) is recommended before taking this course. It's a great introduction to a very interesting field.
Although it's a very manageable amount of work, you probably won't get a lot out of it, and be very frustrated by the assignments and the professor's utter lack of helpfulness.
Bangalore is really chill. That said, take it if you are actually interested in it. It can get dry. Also, a lot of coding
Fairly difficult and time consuming, though if you're interested in MT it's a good survey
If machine translation is something that piques your interest, you should definitely at least try this course. Dr. Bangalore has a lot of experience and you'll learn a lot.
It's a great mix of linguistics and computer science and the assignments are very interesting.
Take it if you're interested in the subject.  Keep on top of the homework so it doesn't slide.

The material is very interesting, covering a nice range of natural language processing topics, building up to translation. I'd recommend having more than just 126, as well as at least a little linguistics.

Very interesting course in which you really do learn a lot about machine translation. Also the professor is very nice and seems genuinely interested that you understand the material and that you do well in the course. Just make sure that you have a fair amount of programming experience before taking the class. If COS126 is your only other CS course, you are going to struggle in this class.
prereqs: Students are required to have programming experience or should have completed COS126 (Introduction to Computer Science). TRA 200 is recommended (may be taken simultaneously)..
descrip: This course will provide an in-depth study of the MT paradigms (direct, transfer, statistical/example, and interlingual) used in state-of-the-art speech-to-speech and text-based MT systems, from computational and linguistic perspectives. Machine-learning techniques for processing human languages (morphological analysis, tagging, syntactic and semantic parsing, and language generation) will be discussed in detail. Linguistic variation across languages and its impact on computational models will be presented. Projects will involve implementing speech/text translation components, identifying their limitations and suggesting improvements.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: This second half of a two-semester proseminar for first year graduate students in anthropology continues the exploration of major theoretical currents that inform the discipline. This second semester will focus on the relation between theories of human action, consciousness, and disciplinary practices such as fieldwork, participant observation, translation, sense-making, and interpretation. Theorists or theories will often be paired with the reading of an ethnographic account inspired by them.

title: Biomolecular Engineering
reviews: Don't leave the proposal to the last minute! If you're interested in the material, tt's a really good and well-taught class.
Great class if you're interested in bioengineering at all. Also pretty light on work.
If the subject matter interests you, take it. A good class if you need something with skippable lectures post-midterm (ie you have a thesis).
Interesting material - you learn about a number of methods for bioengineering and examples of applications for each.  Not too much work.  Link is a good lecturer

Not the most exciting course but take it if you really like bio and enjoy learning about proteins. Professor Link appreciates participation in class so skim over the papers before each class otherwise it's easy to get confused.
Only take this course if you have a keen interest in biomolecular engineering research, otherwise you will not get much out of it.
Take it only if you're interested.
Take this course! Prof. Link is a great teacher and you'll learn some really cool, new topics in this class.

The class is very interesting! The issue when I took it was Professor Link's lack of engagement when class participation and attendance was low, which happened very, very often. Therefore, attend class! Don't make Professor Link sad!
The only problem with this course was that it was 10 AM MWF.  If this is changed and/or you're willing to deal with that, then I'd definitely recommend this course.

This class has no regular assignments, which is helpful if you're looking for an easy course. The classes are pretty much Link lecturing on the papers, rather than any actual discussion, which I found rather disappointing. If you're interested in learning more about biomolecular engineering topics, this is a good survey; I just didn't find it as exciting or engaging as I'd hoped.

This class is worth taking whether or not you're interested in working in bio in the future. You'll learn a lot about different techniques, both for designing experiments and specific bio techniques. Professor Link is also really funny and a great person.
This is a good CBE elective with a low workload.

This is a great course to take for CBE students who are looking for an upper-level CBE course for their requirements. Professor Link continues to be a clear teacher and makes the course more about learning without bogging students down with weekly assignments.
don't miss lectures.  take time to do background research on final.
take it! It's such a great introduction to BME.
descrip: This course will focus on the design and engineering of biomacromolecules. After a brief review of protein and nucleic acid chemistry and structure, we will delve into rational, evolutionary, and computational methods for the design of these molecules. Specific topics to be covered include aptamers, protein and RNA-based switches and sensors, unnatural amino acids and nucleotides, enzyme engineering, and the integration of these parts via synthetic biology efforts.

title: Intermediate Video and Film Production
prereqs: VIS 261 or 262 and instructor's permission. APPLICATION INFORMATION: For students who have taken VIS 261 or VIS 262 there is no interview required; you will apply to state your interest in the course. For those who have not had VIS 261 or 262, please apply and contact Professor Su Friedrich to set up an interview. Please visit the Visual Arts Program website for application information..
descrip: A second level film/video workshop focusing on digital media production. Students complete several videos during the term, of varying lengths and styles (narrative, documentary, experimental, etc.) In class, short works of film/video art are analyzed as a guide to issues of aesthetic choice, writing, editing structure, and challenging one's audience. Students also view short films and videos each week outside of class.

title: Fans and Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Controversies in Science: Past and Present
descrip: See website

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences II
reviews: It's an incredibly awesome course, you'll love it. Especially Friday, you'll look forward to it every week.
Practice presentations.
This is a required course so take what you can from it.  At least by the end you will be more than comfortable presenting in front of your first year classmates
descrip: A survey of fundamental papers in the Geosciences. Topics include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. This is the second of two core geosciences graduate courses.

title: Studies in German Film - Media in Film
descrip: According to McLuhan the content of any medium is always another medium. This also means that one can only understand the way media function through those differences which media simultaneously instantiate and themselves are. This seminar will explore how different technical and symbolic media appear in film and in the process not only reveal insights about themselves, but also about the conditions and structure of cinematic representation as such. Through close analysis of theoretical texts and films from the Weimar era to the present we will interrogate the role of painting, photography, radio, audio recording, video and virtual reality.

title: East Asia since 1800
reviews: Attend all lectures and participate lots in precepts.  This class is so worth the time.
Great introductory course into the history of East Asia.
Hope the essay prompts aren't as terrible.
I think it is a good gateway course for those interested in East Asia.
I would advise students to keep up with the reading.
I would strongly recommend this course to other students. I would advise them that even though the course is about East Asia, it is still very relevant to the world we live in today.

If you are interested in East Asia, take this course! There is quite a bit of reading, but all of the precept readings are pretty interesting, and I didn't have trouble getting through them at all. It is a bit hard to follow since the lectures jump from country to country, but I still really enjoyed the course.

If you have any inclination to learn anything about East Asian history, take this course! The professors Chen and Marcon are both fantastic lecturers and present the material really well, as well as managing to make sometimes dull sections of material interesting with their unique and rather different senses of humor. I went in to the class not expecting much and came away with a much better understanding of East Asian history and a reinforced interest in history in general.
If you want an broad overview of history of East Asia this will be good, but there isn't that much depth. Readings were very interesting though!
If you're interested in a general overview of Japanese/Korean/Chinese history, or are considering a focus on East Asia, definitely take this course.

Modern East Asian History is something that every educated American must understand in the 21st century. I highly encourage all Princetonians to take this course. It presents a systematic overview of 19th and 20th century East Asia in a very engaging, stimulating, and organized manner.

Professor Chen is amazing!  If Marcon is still teaching as well, it's a tough call whether or not it's worth enduring his lectures in order to hear hers.  Make sure you don't get Marcon as a preceptor-- he constantly interrupts students and never provides any positive feedback.  The time period, textbook, and precept readings are really interesting.
Stay on top of the readings, start the papers early, and study key terms for the midterm and final
Take it!
Take the course if given the opportunity, you will learn a lot.
Take this class- you'll definitely learn a lot about East Asia... not just the history, but the current issues faced by East Asian countries as consequences of past history.
This course is great for getting a solid understand of modern East Asia. The professors keep the lectures interesting and the readings are enjoyable.

This course was very interesting and I learned a lot. Read all the primary sources; you will learn a lot and can be more engaged in precept that way. Professor Chen's precept was challenging and great!

You should certainly take it if you are interested in East Asian history. However, both grading and the overall experience will vary significantly across the precepts, so you should be prepared for that.
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern East Asia. We will examine the inter-related histories of China, Japan, and Korea since 1800 and their relationships with the wider world. Major topics include: trade and cultural exchanges, reform and revolutions, war, colonialism, imperialism, and Cold War geopolitics.

title: Survey of Selected Works of Twentieth-Century Architects
descrip: This course is intended to expose the students to a range of major works, built and unbuilt, of architecture from 1950 to the present. This course will focus on these particular buildings as they open themselves to a textual analysis. These analyses are intended to open up issues such as criticality, autonomy and singularity as they begin to evolve in architectural building (as opposed to texts) in the last half of the 20th century. This course will concentrate on individual buildings not architects. Each analysis will be accompanied by an illustrated presentation and selected readings.

title: Foundations of Political Economy
descrip: Course focuses on modeling the interaction of politics and economics, with applications to a variety of substantive areas. Topics include: poltics of taxation and redistribution; governmental structure, political economy of constitutional arrangements, development, and growth. Familiarity with microeconomic theory and POL 575 or the equivalent are prerequisites.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Maternal & Child Health: Culture, Controversy & Policy
descrip: Despite the oft-invoked credo of 'women and children first,' policies to promote and protect maternal and child health often seem to receive short shrift in the policy arena. This course explores contemporary issues in maternal and child health, with attention to both the evidence base for policies as well as the cultural norms and values that make strategies to keep mothers and babies healthy surprisingly controversial at times. The focus will be on the U.S., although the readings will include global perspectives and students may choose to focus their course papers on other societies.

title: Advanced German
reviews: A little more time consuming than expected, but worth it!
Dedicate as much time as you can to this course and you will get more out of it. Looking back, I wish I had had the time to work more for this course.
I would definitely recommend taking this course with Professor Haag.
It's a good continuation from 105. As usual, foreign language grading can be a bit harsh, but if you want to continue learning German, it's worth it.
It's a nice course. Take it if you want to learn German
Review the vocabulary on your own time, whenever you have a chance.
Take it!
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor. Classes conducted in German..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using film, digital media, and literary texts as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Great course.  I had a lot of fun working on my project.
take it!!!!
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Physics of Polymeric Glasses
descrip: Formation of glasses represents an important transition in soft matter physics and is of enormous importance in a wide variety of commercial applications. The phys. of glass formation and glassy-state, while highly investigated, are rich in phenomena not fully understood. This will give an overview of the current understanding of this properties of polymeric glasses and the viscous liquids from which they are commonly formed. Experimental, theoretical and computational contributions to our understanding of amorphous polymers will be covered. Viscoelasticity will be discussed within the context of the glass transition and glassy state.

title: Cognitive Linguistics
prereqs: Open to students planning to complete the certificate in linguistics and/or psychology concentrators, or by permission of the instructor..
descrip: Cognitive Linguistics is a broad approach to language that places psychological reality at the top of the list of theoretical desiderata. In this course we will investigate the nature of linguistic semantic categories and the implications for theories of grammar. In the domain of semantic categories, we will study the issues and controversies surrounding frame semantics, decompositional semantics, conceptual metaphor, and exemplar/prototype/connectionist models. Turning our attention to grammar, we will focus on both regularities and irregularities, within and across languages, attempting to explain why languages are the way they are.

title: Math Alive
reviews: Absolutely. It covers some interesting topics and its well-structured.
Can highly recommend the course for future students
Do it for your QR requirement if you really don't like math
Go to the lectures and do the problem sets! This is an easy way to get your QR out of the way, so make the best of it!
I would definitely take it if you're looking to fulfill a QR requirement. Also, Ian is such an awesome guy

I would highly recommend this class to any humanities or social science major as it really opened my eyes to how math is relevant and interesting in both our daily lives and our academic fields of interest. I really enjoyed the class
I would recommend this class to anyone looking for a QR. This is by far the best option on campus.
If you need a QR, taking this class.
If you're afraid of Math you should take this course.
It is a great QR for non math students.

Not the most engaging QR, but it will get the job done if you need to take a QR and don't want to be overwhelmed with absolutely impossible problem sets and assignments. The math level is definitely appropriate for non-STEM students. The outlay of the course into different topical units keeps the pace of the course interesting, so if you don't like one unit you'll only have to deal with it for a week, or two, and then move on. Professor Griffiths and Tom Beck are very helpful if you need help.
Take if you need to fulfill a QR.
Take it for the QR iff Prof. Griffiths is teaching it. If he is not teaching it, I don't know what to tell you.
Take it if you like interesting math.
Take this class if you want an easy A and don't feel bad about learning nothing.
Take this class, if you don't feel like pushing yourself to take a competitive and hard math class at Princeton.

This class is certainly for someone with very little mathematical background, and the material is very sensitive to the students' limitations. For some, it may be boring. However, the mid-term and final allow students to pursue a mathematical topic that truly interests them?theoretical or practical. I was very grateful for this flexible aspect of the course.
if you need a qr, take this
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science, non-engineering majors. When this course has closed, please email amainzer@princeton.edu to be placed on the waitlist..
descrip: How is life different from 25 or even 10 years ago? Mathematics has profoundly changed our world, from banking & computers to listening to music. Course is designed for those who haven't had college mathematics but would like to understand some of the mathematical concepts behind important modern applications. It will consist of largely independent 2-week modules; each module focusing on a particular application (e.g., bar codes, CD-players, population models). Emphasis will be on ideas, not on sophisticated mathematical techniques, but there will be substantial problem set requirements. Students will learn by doing simple examples.

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Domestic Policy
descrip: Examines a series of major issues of policy designed to illustrate and develop skills in particularly important applications of microeconomics. Topics will include education and training, the minimum wage, mandated benefits, affirmative action, the theory of public goods and externalities, and the basic theory of taxation. Prerequisite: 511b.

title: Modern Methods for Organic Synthesis
reviews: Be prepared to work a lot for this class, but it's definitely a great next step after CHM 403 or 304. Besides, you get exactly as much as you put into it, and you can get a lot out of this course.
First half is super chill. Going to class is a treat with Sorenson, and there is no work and minimal study required for the midterm. Second half is intense but rewarding.
Get the "Named Reactions book" It's a great resource. Start working on synthetic routes as soon as they are assigned. It's easy to run out of time!
Only take this course if you are really interested in organic chemistry.

The work is light for the first half of the semester, but be prepared to work hard for Macmillan's portion of the class. The synthesis projects he gives out are extremely demanding, but highly rewarding.
This was a very fun course and Professors MacMillan and Sorensen are both great lecturers and teachers. Definitely take this course if you think organic chemistry is in your future.
prereqs: One full year of undergraduate organic chemistry.
descrip: This course will expose you to many types of carbon-based molecular structures, the transformations they undergo, and many kinds of chemical reactions and strategies that are important to the field of organic synthesis. Recent advances in asymmetric catalysis, cascade and other complexity-generating structural transformations, and powerful strategies for chemical synthesis that evolved from ideas about the structural origins of important, biologiclaly active molecules such as steriod hormones, cofactors, and alkaloids will be addressed.

title: Screenwriting for a Global Audience
reviews: Definitely take this course! Professor Lazaridi is a wonderful professor, and you will learn not only how to write screenplays, but also how to watch films and tell stories.
If you have an interest in screenwriting or storytelling, you should take this course.
TAKE IT OR REGRET
Take it just for Lazaridi she is as cool as it gets
Take it! Make sure to keep writing throughout the class and you will learn so much. Try to talk to Professor Lazaridi personally too!
Take this class! Even if you are not a writer - well how could you know if you haven't tried it? She's an AMAZING professor and will actually teach you more than you can imagine.

Very interesting class; fun way to explore new media, including video games. We watched interesting films/short films and had interesting discussions. Sometimes journal discussions went on a bit too long and the workshopping schedule wasn't that figured out so people went different number of times. Otherwise however, you get to know everyone in the class. There isn't a lot of formal training about the format for screenplays, but it isn't that hard to figure out once you start trying it. Very thought-provoking and imaginative class! Workload not too intense.
YES! vehement yes! just take it, stay patient and put the pieces together in your free time. the answers will come to you.
take it.
prereqs: By application only (no pre-requisites).
descrip: How can screenwriters create stories for global consumption? How can they remain grounded in an understanding of human nature, while working to innovate visual narrative forms? This course will analyze elements of storytelling techniques used across cultures and time, through an investigation of how the human brain processes narrative visual information. Using fairytales, films and new media, as well as scientific and technological breakthroughs in the understanding of brain function, the course will give students techniques for communicating a dramatic continuum to the human brain using traditional and cutting edge film/media platforms.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Jews and Christians in Ancient Palestine: The Archaeological Evidence
descrip: The course will focus on the range of contacts and connections between Jews and Christians in Byzantine Palestine (Western Palestine and Transjordan) as corroborated by the archaeological finds. The similarities and differences between synagogues and churches will be the focus of the discussion, but other aspects relating to demography, art, cemeteries, everyday life, small finds, and more will also be examined. Through this material we will attempt to determine the relationship between the two communities in the 4th to the 7th centuries.

title: Modern China
descrip: This seminar introduces students to major historiographical and methodological issues in twentieth-century Chinese history, with emphasis on the Republican period. Topics reflect theoretical debates and empirical questions, including: nationalism and citizenship, urban life, gender and sexuality, the Communist revolution, early People's Republic of China history.

title: The Literature of Gastronomy
reviews:
--Take it!!!!
--It's more about Italian history as seen through the lens of food, specifically food in literature, than it is about Italian food or generally the function of food in society, so just keep that in mind.
--Readings are great, I did all of them
--Go to lecture and precept
--They feed you!
--Take if you are genuinely interested in the power of food, in Italian history, in literature, or in any cross-section of these subjects.
Definitely take it-not too difficult and you will definitely enjoy it!
Definitely take it. Best LA course there is.

Definitely take this class!!! You have to go to lectures because there's sign in but you don't have to take notes in order to do well on the exams. Precepts are really valuable so take good notes there! Exams are very fair if you know the readings and paid attention in precept.
Definitely take this course!

Do the readings throughly in preparation for the precepts and the midterm and final exams. Lecture wasn't necessarily that helpful, but you should go anyway, because you might talk about other interesting topics pertaining to food (e.g. we had a lecture about nutella!).
Do the readings.
Does not require much work and has some interesting readings!
Enjoyable course and not too difficult for distribution requirement.
Extremely easy class.  Take it if thats what you want.  I was disappointed that I wasted my time in this class.

Fairly easy class if you do all the work. Don't go into thinking that there will be much literary analysis: it's mostly plot summary. Don't go into it expecting to learn much about the actual dishes and their preparation. However, Professor Frassica is clearly very experienced, knowledgeable and very personable. The preceptors are also dedicated and have a great attitude towards the class.
Fairly straightforward, fun class.
Fine class if you are not looking for much work.
For Italian department students - it is an easy departmental. Not a lot of work and Frassica is super chill.
Fun and interesting course! Take it!
Go for it and find a group to make study guides with.
Good class - easy, minimal commitment, and fun. Much more about Italian history (i.e. WWII) than food.
Good class to take to fulfill a distribution requirement.
Great PDF
Great class to PDF.  It isn't intellectually stimulating, but if you're a senior in the midst of writing your thesis, you will love this class.

I would say to definitely take the course and make sure to keep up with readings every week because it is easy to fall behind but the readings are all really interesting and you will enjoy reading them!

If you are interested in seeing how such a common concept in America, food and the lack thereof, is employed in literature, definitely take this class. It enhances your knowledge and discussing food is usually fun.
Interesting readings. Most time consuming assignments are studying for the midterm and final.

It is a good course. Not too demanding, a good LA to take. I really did not want to take an LA course (science person) but this one is one of the more enjoyable classes that I took at Princeton. Do the readings and come to lecture. Daniele is an awesome preceptor so try to be in his precept. Fun readings as well. Good luck!
It's a good class for senior spring.
It's pretty hard to fail
Learned very little, but thats b/c the premise of the course is kind of silly...probably the easiest LA you can take at Princeton, though.
Low workload, easy to keep up. Worth it for humanities course credit in a busy semester.
Make sure to do each reading
Not too much work.  Exactly what you expect.
Pretty chill class. Not much time needed to get a decent grade.
Read the materials and listen in lecture!
Take it and try and get Marino as your preceptor
Take it if you are interested
Take it if you want a pretty easy class. All you have to do is read and give one presentaton.
Take it if you want an easy language class.
Take it if you're mildly interested in food or Italy.
Take it!
Take it! Do the readings!
Take it!!!
Take it, but only if you are prepared to do all the readings (2.5 hours per week)
Take it.
Take this class your senior year!  It's interesting and fun, and not much work is required as compared to most Princeton classes. Plus you get to cook for your final project!
Take this for a fun, relatively light work class
Take this if you are going to have a busy semester??it is a great class to PDF.
The final precept is a cooking project which is delicious and fun :)
This class was fun and easy. I highly recommend it.
This course has something to offer for everyone, including non-language or -humanities oriented people. Take this course!

This course is unique in Princeton. I highly recommend that you take it. The readings are interesting and varied. The workload is manageable and Professor Frassica is a great lecturer. Wednesday nights were the very best every week for me.
This is a fun course with little work, so I'd recommend taking it to balance a schedule with more work intensive courses.
This is a really fun and interesting course if you've never taken a lit course!
Well, it's really easy, but it boggles the mind that academic credit is given for this course.
Whether or not you are looking for an easy LA, this class is a waste of your time at Princeton. If you don't care about this and you need an LA, then take it, otherwise stay very far away from it.
easy 5th course

good fifth class or pdf class. if you want to do well, make sure to participate in class. also, do all the readings! they're actually all quite interesting, and it will be important / easy to just read each week when it comes to the tests.
good.
take it
prereqs: Prerequisite: 200-level course in Italian for Italian precept..
descrip: This course studies Italian novels and short stories in English translation, works of visual art, and films which thematize food as reality and metaphor, examining how eating functions within ideological and mythological structures of modern society. Topics will include 'Futurist' cuisine as an aesthetic experience and a prophetic vision, writing during the war, and sublime and erotic cuisine.

title: Field Ecohydrology
reviews: Good course but really hard -- sort of throws you in the deep end if you've never coded before. Kelly is amazing though.
I recommend traveling to Kenya.
I would tell other students that it is extremely Matlab / coding-intensive, but it is definitely worth it, super interesting, and extremely practical.
It would be really nice if you knew how to program in MATLAB or else this course is going to be very difficult to you.

It's going to suck, but Kelly's a great professor so it balances out.  If he was not a good professor and the class sucked, I would tell you to avoid it, but it's really worth it to have Kelly.  Also, you learn a lot of things amidst your suffering.
This is tough if you have no experience in MATLAB! But Kelly and Frances are really helpful and provide a lot of guidance throughout.
prereqs: MAT 201.
descrip: This three-week course, offered as part of a four-course study abroad semester, takes place at Princeton University's Mpala Research Centre in central Kenya. The course will provide an introduction to the principles of hydrological sciences through the development and application of instrumentation for characterizing surface/subsurface hydrological dynamics in field settings. Lectures and field activities will address the theory of operation, design, and implementation of methods used to quantify hydrological patterns and processes.

title: The Universe
reviews: Go to lecture.

I would definitely recommend this class to anyone who's interested in learning more about astronomy. The workload is very reasonable and it's a fascinating topic. Recommend to science and non-science majors alike!
I would only recommend this course to a student with a strong background in physics.
If you are looking for an easy math credit, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. You are in for a terrible surprise.
If you want an easy class that has the potential to be interesting, this is for you.
If you're good with math and physics you'll find this easy. If you're not, this can be a good course for you but it's not the easiest.

Ignore the nickname, as this class is somewhat challenging and not something you can totally breeze through. But it's really interesting and accessible to non-majors if you put a little work in and an enjoyable, rewarding experience.
Interesting, not very difficult. It's worth taking.
It will be easy if you are a math/science person, like me. The material covered is a lot of stuff you have never been exposed to, but it's presented at a good and accessible pace.
Make sure you attend all of the lectures.
Take it!
Take this class if you're looking for a fun QR!  Expect to work some on problem sets and for the exam, but minimal effort otherwise.
Take this course for the QR requirement only if you at least kind of like math and science. There are other courses for people who are completely uninterested.
Take this course, especially if you have an interest in astronomy, but are not a science major.  The problem sets go along with the material taught, and there is much guidence if you need it.

This class will give you a good overview of major concepts, and the problem sets are like word problems which I have always enjoyed. Overall, a fairly painless QR if you PDF-- you will learn some interesting things

This is a remarkably difficult course for someone who is looking to satisfy a QR. I took this course PDF, and I *still* struggled! I had to work hard to get that "Pass"! That said, I learned a ton, and I think it was worth it.
its not easy
prereqs: This course is intended for humanities and social science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This specially designed course targets the frontier of modern astrophysics. Subjects include the planets of our solar system, the birth, life, and death of stars; the search for extrasolar planets and extraterrestrial life; the zoo of galaxies from dwarfs to giants, from starbursts to quasars; dark matter and the large-scale structure of the universe; Einstein's special and general theory of relativity, black holes, neutron stars, and big bang cosmology. This course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. High school physics would be useful.

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: Job, Literature & Modernity
descrip: This course explores the modern reception of the book of Job and the question of human suffering from the 17thc. to the present. Focus will be on philosophers (Kant, Hegel, Kierkegaard, Martin Buber, Ernst Bloch, Richard Rubenstein, Antonio Negri), playwrights (Shakespeare, Marlowe, Milton), novelists (Melville, Dostoevsky, Goethe, Kafka, Joseph Roth, Spark, Malamud), poets (Pope, Hopkins, Frost, Ravikovitch), and the directors of two recent films: Joel and Ethan Coen (A Serious Man); and Terrence Malick (The Tree of Life). We will also consider selected modern renderings of Job in the visual arts and music.

title: Stars and Star Formation
reviews: Avoid this class if it is taught by Professor Burrows. The material covered in his section is far too rapid and detailed to be grappled with properly.

If you have not taken an astrophysics course before, please reconsider taking this course.  It is not a good introduction to astrophysics, and there are many well-designed, well-taught courses in the department.

The pace of this course is very fast and difficult to follow at times. It requires a lot of independent work, and even then things don't make complete sense. If this course is still split into two halves: ISM (Draine) and Stars (Burrows), I would advise against it. The pace is just too fast, especially during the second half. The first half of the course covers very useful basics. It was reasonable to follow and not too demanding. I found the other astro courses significantly more enjoyable and stress-free! :)
descrip: Stars form by the gravitational collapse of interstellar gas clouds, and as they evolve, return some of their gas to the interstellar medium, altering its physical state and chemical composition. This course discusses the properties and evolution of the gaseous and stellar components of a galaxy: the theory and observations of star formation; stellar structure; the production of energy by nucleosynthesis; stellar evolution; stellar end states; and the interpretation of observations of the diffuse and dense interstellar medium. We will discuss how major telescopes and space missions might tackle these problems.

title: Communist Modernity: The Politics and Culture of Soviet Utopia
descrip: Inspired by utopian ideas of equality and universal brotherhood, communism was conceived as an alternative to capitalism's crises. This attempt to build a new world was costly and brutal: equality was quickly transformed into uniformity; brotherhood morphed into the Big Brother. The course provides an in-depth review of these oscillations between utopian motivations and oppressive practices. It will present central players of Soviet Utopia: from Lenin to Malevich; from Stalin to Eisenstein. Major political texts, key cultural documents and films of the period help us trace the emergence and disappearance of commumist modernity.

title: Intermediate Turkish II
prereqs: TUR 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: To enable students to communicate in Modern Turkish, and to read Turkish (current events, editorials, literature and academic writings) with some speed and accuracy.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I
prereqs: CHI 305, CHI 306 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion based on Chinese scholarly journals, popular essays, and newspaper articles. Students are exposed to a variety of modern Chinese literary genres, as well as some of the major substantive issues that modern Chinese intellectuals have faced.

title: Public Reason, Democracy, and Diversity
descrip: The course examines debates surrounding public reason: the idea that public officials and citizens in diverse democracies have obligations to offer one another certain kinds of reasons for law, developed by John Rawls and others. Is this a helpful way of thinking about the problem of justifying law or is it, as many argue, a recipe for unfair exclusion (especially of the religious), unnecessary antagonism, and degraded public deliberation? The seminar explores the possible moral, and also the positive or practical, contributions of norms of public reasoning. These include helping solve problems of mutual assurance and coordination on law.

title: Twentieth-Century French Popular Music
prereqs: Completed 100-level language sequence..
descrip: This media-based survey of popular music in twentieth-century France traces the evolution of music culture through intensive listening to the most influential artists from 1900 to 2012, through recorded and printed interviews with musicians, songwriters, producers, and critics, and through the analysis of music videos and blogs. Beginning with the early music hall performers to contemporary experimentations in electronic music, hip hop, and hybrid forms, the course constructs the genealogy of influence between musicians and raises questions about commercial interests, politics, and authenticity.

title: Senior Thesis with Design
descrip: Similar to 442 with the principle difference that the thesis must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior thesis with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Financial Management in the Corporate and Public Sectors
descrip: Designed to introduce graduate students in public and international affairs to certain principals and analytic tools widely used in the financial management of organizations, privately or publicly owned. Course is based on the premise that future civil servants should be familiar with this subject matter, either because they may be involved in the financial management of public agencies, or negotiate financial contracts with the private sector, or regulate financial management in the private sector.

title: Integrated Building Studios
descrip: Integrated design studios approach architecture from a synthetic perspective. Considerations of structure, environmental technology, building materials and systems, exterior envelope, and site design are integrated directly into the design process through the participation of technical faculty and outside advisors in critiques and reviews. Projects are developed to a high level of detail. At least one course is required for professional M.Arch. students.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Accounting
reviews: A fairly straightforward, boring corporate finance "concepts" class that does not teach you useful life skills like accounting or problem solving skills (given the lack of practice exercises), all of which is fine on its own, but significantly worsened when Delwin the Non-Preceptor is added to the mix. What is the discounted present value of Delwin's contribution to the class? Zero. And believe me, that's not because I'm applying a high discount rate!
D. Sraer is a good teacher. The class isn't fascinating but that's more because of the content than the actual quality of the lectures/teacher. My advice is just read the book. Is is sufficient.
Don't take it, or take it "with philosophy" if you are required to.
Finally an MFin class that actually lets students study instead of wasting their time on useless problem sets. Great textbook. Shame about the precept.
I would advise this course to other students
I would recommend the MFin students to have more emphasis on corporate finance. Taking this course is an absolute necessity. It is unfortunate that the professor did not make the most out of it.
If you're an American in finance who is good at balance sheets but doesn't know stochal, this is your chance to catch up with the foreign students who know stochal but don't know finance.
If you're interested in accounting, then this course is good.
Interesting course for corporate finance.
Intersting course for people interested in corporate finance.
It is very useful if you want to discover the world of corporate finance
It was an OK class. Worth taking. But it would be better if it was better organized.
It's ok for accounting.
Must understand material on own since not many assignments etc. that will test the knowledge of it until the final.
Please buy the textbook for a more complete understanding.
Skip it if you can.
Take this class, you will learn a LOT in corporate finance
Take this course under Shin instead.
Try to convince the professor to provide slides before lecture.
its required.
not recommended
read the book
descrip: Major topics in modern corporate finance. We will study investment policy (investment decision rules, project valuation, cost of capital) and financial policy (mostly capital structure decisions). Additional topics (private equity, bankruptcy and reorganization, merger and acquisitions) will be covered if time permits.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Seniors only (except for juniors who have completed EGR 351)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Special Topics in the History of Philosophy - Early Modern Philosophies of Science
descrip: In this seminar, we will survey some topics relating to the conception of nature, and how we can know it in the early modern period. Topics to be discussed may include method, experiment, demonstration and the conceptions of body, space, force, and the natural law. Figures discussed may include Bacon, Galileo, Descartes, Hobbes, Boyle and the Royal Society, Leibniz and Newton.

title: Intermediate Arabic II
reviews: Absolutely
Do it! Tarek is great.

Go for it! It's a lot of work, but the fun of learning about a new culture and bonding with a bunch of other like-minded students is priceless. Plus, Prof. Elsayed is an effective and hilarious teacher!

I would highly recommend this class especially with Tarek!  He is an amazing professor- he is really fun and stimulating.  He really makes going to class a blast.  Honestly, I enjoyed going to this class and it made Arabic a joy!  It isn't too difficult if you keep up and we learn a lot of useful vocabulary.  By the end of this course you should feel pretty strong in Arabic.
If you are going to take Arabic, Tarek will motivate you to go beyond what is simply on the page and learn to love the language.
Keep up with your work!
Strongly recommend.
Take it, for sure.

Take it. Arabic is a beautiful language and Ustaaz Tarek is incredible. You will look forward to this class everyday. It's ok to hand in late homework, but stay on top of it otherwise you won't learn as much.
Take this class with Professor Tarek!
Tarek is by far one of the most entertaining, nicest, and competent Arabic teachers the University has to offer.
practice often
prereqs: ARA 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Study of Arabic grammar and syntax, and use of the language in functional contexts. Reading of extra material from articles, newspapers, short stories. Discussions are held in the Arabic language to enhance the students' speaking skills.

title: Elementary Modern Greek II
prereqs: HLS 101 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: To provide the basis for acquiring a command of written and spoken Modern Greek.

title: Migration and Exile in Caribbean Literature and Culture
descrip: This class analyzes Caribbean literature, art, and other cultural products from the late 18th to the current century to trace the cultural/historical significance of Caribbean migrants and exiles. Using this lens, we explore critical moments in Caribbean and global history.

title: Intermediate Chinese II
reviews: A lot of work
Chinese is much harder than the other languages, and you probably won't get an A. That said, the instruction is phenomenal and you'll end up learning how to speak/read/write at a high level.
Definitely take it. It's not much more work than 1st year, and the first half of the first semester is all review.

I was surprised by the composition of the curriculum, particularly in regards to listening, and the fact that was not tested whatsoever. Likewise, the rigidity of the class structure disallows for the creativity and free-flowedness I feel is requisite for environment conducive to language learning.  

Woud I recommend it? DEFINITELY! While the setup of the course is not what I expected for Princeton University, I have heard that the upper-level courses are much better and in all, I did improve my Chinese somewhat. I hope. 
Besides, learning Chinese, even poorly, is a good idea given the path of the world currently.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in learning Chinese but would warn them that it's a lot of hard work.
I would recommend this course. It's a little difficult to keep up with sometimes, but if you're interested in learning Chinese, I highly encouraged you to take the course.
If you want to get good at Chinese, take this course.  If you want to take a language, but aren't up for something super intense, look elsewhere.
It is constant work, but definitely worth it if you want to improve your Chinese language skills.
Keep on top of the vocabulary and enjoy the class!
Keep up with the material and you will be fine. It's a lot of work but absolutely worth it.

Prepare to work hard and spend a lot of time memorising. Strictly not a language for the fainthearted, but if you have any enthusiasm at all for the subject, you will be richly rewarded. The feeling at the end of CHI 102 might be that you haven't learned anything at all, but by the time you have completed 107, you will be extremely grateful that you stuck with it.
Take this if you want to learn Chinese!

The quality of Princeton's Chinese classes is excellent, and language classes are a welcome break from otherwise stressful classes! If you are good with languages, Chinese will not be as difficult as people make it out to be, so take it. It helps significantly if you speak another East Asian language.
There is consistent work. You have to put in a lot of time outside of class.

This course is a ton of work, but well worth it. Princeton is known for its Chinese language program, and if you want to learn Mandarin, I am still convinced it is one of the best places in the world to learn it. If you have the time, or realize the importance that China will play on the global stage in the near future, take this class!
This is an interesting course.
This is class is definitely intense and time consuming, but If you want to learn Chinese, it's great. Yang Lao Shi is awesome.
big time commitment
study vocab cumulatively! review often
take chinese! won't regret it
prereqs: CHI 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Continuing the intensive study of modern spoken and written Chinese, this course shifts the emphasis to the reading of modern cultural and social issues.

title: Quantitative Analysis IV
descrip: An introduction to the basic analytical and computational tools of applied Bayesian statistics. Methods covered include multi-level models, mixture modeling, Bayesian model averaging, and models for missing data and causal inference; computational tools taught include the EM algorithm and the Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms. Goal of the course is to enable students to build and implement their own model in order to answer a particular research question. Course may be of interest to those in disciplines outside of political science who need to learn the basics of applied Bayesian statistics.

title: Macroeconomics
reviews: A relatively standard intermediate macro course - more conceptual than mathematical.

Avoid this course at all costs if Kiyotaki is teaching it.  I thought ECO101 was an absolute breeze but this class regularly reduced me to absolute frustration. Lectures are confusing, and I felt I could have learned so much more if the class were designed better.
Be prepared to do the reading and if you don't like your preceptor make efforts to find one that you like.
Definitely take this class in sophomore or else it will feel like a repeat of material if you take it spring junior year (and be fairly boring).
Don't take it unless you have to and read chapters before lectures.

Don't take it unless you have to.  Lectures are pretty dull.  Your preceptor might be helpful, so take advantage of that.  If you stop going to lectures, like I did, read the textbook, it's decently helpful.  And do the psets - they're similar to the exams.
Don't take it with Kiyotaki unless you need to. You're entirely on your own; problem sets come from out of left field so start early so you can go to office hours.
Don't take with Prof. Kiyotaki.
Easy course but you will need to do lots of self-learning but Kiyotaki's lectures are so confusing. He's super friendly and brilliant, and after a while you get used to the accent.

Go to lecture, give him a chance.  Ask him to speak up. Problem sets are not that difficult if you get a group together and have been going to lecture.

Nobu revamped the material this semester (Spring 2013) to be much more qualitative. As far as I can tell from those who took it before, the class has much improved as a result.

Go to office hours to get help on psets. Lectures are hard to understand and preceptors are not incredible. Work with other students and do the reading in the texts. Exams come pretty much straight off the lecture slides, so memorize those.
Go to precepts.

Go to precepts. Do all of Nobu's questions on the psets (not book questions) and practice finals and midterm exams in order to prepare for the real thing.

Take it only if it's a req.
Good course.  Respect Kiyotaki -- although he has an accent, he is a brilliant economist.

I get the feeling that this course is similar to normal Micro instead of math approach Micro. Whatever you do, don't switch between the two approaches: they're completely different and don't mesh at all.
I'd only take this course if you have to.
If you have to take it for ECO, take it, and don't led it dissuade you from majoring in economics (every major has a class like this) but be warned it's not fun.
Only take if you have to.
PDF it.  Otherwise it is a pain to actually understand the material.
Professor Kiyotaki is an amazingly talented professor, but not as engaging a teacher. However, the class teaches you a lot about macroecon topics and it's worth taking.
Study for the exams
Take 311.
Take it because you have to, that's all I can say.
You're taking it as a departmental requirement, suck it up and work through it.
if you aren't totally interested you'll be bored out of your mind
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101..
descrip: This course covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. We will focus on the determination of macroeconomic variables -- such as output, employment, price, and the interest rate -- in the short, medium, and long run, and we will address a number of policy issues. We will discuss several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Contemporary Society, Politics, and Culture
reviews: A very good course that, for students interested in the material, will be effective in improving their German while exposing them to recent German cultural texts in an engaging way. Take it.
Expect heavy workload: study of new vocabulary, a great amount of both reading and writing assignments, presentation(s).
If you have the opportunity to take a class with Christiane, absolutely do it. Great teacher and loves what she does.
It's interesting material and Professor Frey is a really great person (and a great professor).
This course is a great intro to post-1945 German history and has a well-selected assortment of readings and movies. Professor Frey is wonderful and one of the best professors in the department.
take it if you're truly interested in german culture and society.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: The course offers an introduction to post-1945 German culture, society, and politics through a number of historical documents, literary works, and films. Topics include: the aftermath of WWII (Stunde Null); denazification; the founding of both German Republics; the economic miracle (Wirtschaftswunder); the legacy of National Socialism; attempts to define a new Germany; the student revolts; pop culture; reunification; and Germany's new role in Europe. Through the close study of the assigned material, this course aims at advancing the students' competence in both oral and written German.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Chemical Dynamics and Thermodynamics
reviews: Chemistry students should be warned that this class, like 306, is taught extremely poorly. Serious students are strongly recommended to take thermal physics or skip ahead to the thermo related grad courses in chemistry, which are excellent.
Do the readings before lecture. That way you'll be able to predict what the professor will talk about next, and that will help guide your thinking.

It's a good introduction to thermodynamics. The book is great. Lectures are a little dry sometimes, but I think the material is good. Keep up from the beginning, and come to class prepared to watch a lot of derivations.
It's a very tough class, and Dr. Wang isn't a great lecturer.
It's way better than 306
Its a lot of work.
Make sure you get the theoretical stuff in the first couple weeks of the course down, because they are used throughout the course
Take it over 306. For the love of god, do it.
This class is much less work than 405 and seems like less work than 306. Take it if you want a more mathematical approach to thermodynamics

This course covers some pretty interesting material starting with the fundamental equations at the molecular level and I was pleasantly surprised when I realized that the equations can reveal some pretty non-intuitive results. Professor Wang lectures are based directly from the textbook, which some may find to be unappealing, but I ended up appreciating the fact that this meant that I did not have to read the textbook unless I needed clarification. Professor Wang is a pretty cheerful person and is very helpful during office hours. Overall, I would recommend this class to chemistry majors who are looking for a thermo class that builds on equations coming from the molecular viewpoint.
This course is not all that interesting but given that it is a departmental I feel like I can't really recommend against.
prereqs: MAT 201 or equivalent. Some knowledge of thermodynamics is useful..
descrip: This course is an introduction to statistical thermodynamics, kinetics, and molecular reaction dynamics. Following a review of classical thermodynamics, the statistical mechanics of molecular systems is developed. Discussions of transport properties, chemical kinetics, and reaction dynamics form the rest of the course.

title: Religion in the Americas Workshop
prereqs: REL 523.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Topics in American Literature - American Best Sellers
reviews: A good class for senior spring.
Anything with Gleason is perfect.
Definitely take it! Professor Gleason is amazing and the books are really fun reads.

Definitely take this course and anything that Gleason teaches. His courses are interesting, relevant, and fun. They sound too fun to be true, yet they are actually interesting and thought-provoking. It's a good way to learn how to reflect on what you read, why, and the impact that material has on you and on culture more generally. He is one of the best professors I have had in my four years.
Definitely take this course, you won't regret it.

Definitely take this course; don't leave Princeton without taking a class with Professor Gleason if you are interested in English / History (at least for this course - it was pretty historical as well which was really interesting).
Definitely worth taking it to hear Gleason lecture, to read some classic novels of American literature, or to not do too much work if you do not want to.
Definitely worth taking.
Every Princeton student needs to take at least one course with Prof. Gleason during their time here.
Fairly engaging course. Take it.
Gleason's phenomenal. Be warned -- these books actually aren't that good.
Go to all of the lectures and participate in lecture. Don't worry if you can't do all of the reading. It's impossible and most people can't do it.
Highly recommended! Fun class!

I think that any course that Professor Gleason teaches is worth taking, English major or not. He is a tremendously hard working professor and deserves to have the interest that his past few classes have drawn from students.
I would definitely advise students to take this class. And read all the books!

I would definitely take this course, and I highly recommend doing all the readings.  Most books are fairly short, but reading Gone with the Wind in its entirety was definitely worth it.  Professor Gleason is one of the most memorable professors you'll have at Princeton.

I would strongly recommend other students to take this course.  My only advice would be to take the readings seriously and engage closely with the language of the texts.  Close-readings are big in this course.
If you're a senior and you don't have a thesis to do and life to worry about, do all the reading when you're supposed to.
If you're at all interested in English, take a class with Professor Gleason. This course gives an interesting history of the development of the popular novel.

It is a great literature course to take for both humanities and non-humanities majors. It is just all around fun without being an easy, blow-off class. You shouldn't skip/sleep through lectures anyway because they're entertaining and interesting. The texts are approachable yet we talk about them seriously and intellectually. Gleason is a wonderful professor!

Learn as much about the background of the book as you can if your time is limited before you start reading it. Also, talk it over with others--you never know what gems they might have seen while reading.
Make sure to stay ahead with the readings, especially with the more tedious selections (*cough* Last of the Mohicans *cough*)
TAKE IT
TAKE THIS CLASS! Also do all the readings, they are great books that you don't want to miss!
TAKE THIS COURSE!
TAKE THIS COURSE!  Or any course by Gleason.  This one was particularly awesome, though.

TAKE THIS COURSE. The readings are fascinating, the themes are relevant to today's culture, and Prof. Gleason is one of the most entertaining and insightful lecturers at the university. Any course that can take Fifty Shades of Grey and turn it into a genuinely thoughtful and hilarious commentary on modern sexuality and the publishing industry is worth a look.
Take it! American Bestsellers was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Princeton. And don't skip lecture...Gleason's lectures are the best part of the course.
Take it.  It's a great course for anyone looking to learn anything about literature, American culture, or the study of English in general.  Take it to experience Gleason's lectures.
Take it. Or Kiddie Lit. Anything with Gleason!!!
Take this class.  Gleason is one of the best (if not the best) lecturers at Princeton, and it's not as if reading the books is a drag either.
Take this course - you will have a great time, and actually learn some cool stuff about American bestsellers through history.
Take this course!! Whether it's for general interest or for you department, it'll be a fun course for you to take and you'll get a relatively good grade if you put in enough effort.
Take this course!, even if you are an English major and you feel like you 'should' be reading 'literature' rather than best sellers or genre work.

The course is not a literature course. It's more of a sociology course, and its goal is not finding books of literary merit among popular success, but reading crap like 50 shades of grey. If you're an English major in order to read good literature, don't take this class. You'll despise it.
The perfect English class for non-English majors, but take in a semester with no other reading-intensive classes.
The readings just aren't that interesting.
This class is worth taking. This material deserves our attention and there is no one better to teach it!
This is a fun course. I think you'll like it.
This is a great English class.
This is a great course.  Take it.
Try to read all of the books.
recommend it!
take it if you have time
take it, even if you're not an ENG major, as this is a very interesting and widely appealing course
too much reading assigned and the books are bad too
descrip: Seduction, betrayal, adventure, moral outrage, mystery, romance: these are the narrative engines of America's most popular texts. In this course--a literary and historical survey of American best sellers from the colonial period to the present--we will seek to understand not just which texts have been popular but why, paying close attention to both their aesthetic qualities and their cultural contexts. What can our reading of these works today tell us about the societies that produced and then, by the millions, consumed them?

title: Readings in the Social, Cultural, and Intellectual History of the Modern Middle East
descrip: This graduate reading seminar explores important works in the history of the modern and contemporary Middle East. Weekly readings consist of scholarly monographs on a particular theme, to be read and discussed in conjunction with related articles and other readings. Students are evaluated on active oral participation, two presentations, one critical book review as well as a longer historiographical essay.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in the research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students will make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It will meet for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Poverty, Inequality and Health in the World
prereqs: WWS 507 and 511. Please see instructor to apply for enrollment..
descrip: About well-being throughout the world, with focus on income and health. Explores what happened to poverty, inequality, and health, in the US, and internationally. Discusses conceptual foundations of national and global measures of inequality, poverty, and health; construction of measures, and extent to which they can be trusted; relationship between globalization, poverty, and health, historically and currently. Examines links between health and income, why poor people are less healthy and live less long than rich people.

title: Topics in History, Analysis, and Interpretation - Musical Semiotics Bad Music: A History
prereqs: At least one survey course in music history (MUS 230 to 238). No knowledge of musical notation or music theory required..
descrip: A history enquiry into one of the defining characteristic of Western musical culture: its love-hate relationship with music, its deep sense of unease about the art, which can be traced from Antiquity all the way to current debates about music videos and their perceived connection with gun violence.

title: Advanced Japanese I
prereqs: JPN 107. Students should have completed Intermediate (second-year) Japanese or equivalent as a prerequisite to admission in JPN 301.
descrip: This course is designed to further students' reading ability. Students will have ample opportunity to hear and use increasingly more sophisticated vocabulary and grammatical construction through discussion and composition. Japanese video tapes will also be incorporated into the course. Reading materials include "Tobira" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences
reviews: A good fair course if you need it.

DO ALL THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS DURING THE COURSE, NOT BEFORE THE EXAM. it helped me a lot to stay on top of things during the semester-- I got a good grade in the end, even tho I felt sometimes that I couldn't pull it off. if you need to take it for econ, do it. it doesn't really matter who teaches the class, just the effort you are willing to put into it. if you stay on top of things, you will do better than you expect, for sure.
Difficult tests, do lots of practice problems to prepare for them.
Don't fall behind! Go to McGraw every week if you don't get a concept so that you can understand how and why you are doing something.
Go to office hours
Go to office hours and go to class! So much material gets covered in each class, so if you miss one, its hard to understand the next one. Do the practice problems. Math is all about practice.
I would make sure to take the earlier course time. Taking the class after lunch can be tough due to the structure of the lecture.
I'm not a math person but this class was manageable. Nora is awesome, take it with her. But don't take it if you don't have to.
If you can avoid taking any math at Princeton I would.
Incredible amount of material, very few examinations/quizes that make up your grade. I would think about quizing yourself every two weeks or so just to make sure you keep up/don't forget things
Only take if you have to
Only take if you have to.
Only take it if you absolutely have to.

Pay attention in class because the professor gives you help on the homework. Try to get started on the homework before Friday class and/ or office hours before the homework is due so that you can get specific help if you need it.
Practice!
Princeton doesn't have great intro math classes. If you need to get 104/201/202/175, take this class to get it over with.
Read the book.
Review notes and allow time for homework
Take this course, its great and the professors are great. Study and you'll be fine!
Unless required, I wouldn't go through the stress.
Work hard, especially for the final.
