Yes!! If you have to, take it. I'm not the biggest math fan and it's a bit tough but really well taught and teaches you all you need to know for econ I believe.
You will not learn why you're doing what you're doing, but if you want a crash course on a lot of important math and you want a terminal course, this is pretty decent.
n/a
not well taught. teacher quality was not great.
take notes in class
take this course for your major, not too hard, but helps if you've taken 104 before it
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Survey of topics in calculus and linear algebra as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, improper integrals and rates of growth, partial derivatives, gradient, Lagrange multipliers, linear systems, determinants, matrix inversion, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, as time permits.

title: Grand Strategy
reviews: A lot of readings, but it's stuff worth reading. Great course. If you don't know what grand strategy is, don't worry - that was a recurring topic of discussion.

A very interesting course, even if you aren't a politics/WWS major. Also gives a great overview of many historical empires. Requires a good deal of reading, but the exams aren't too difficult. Definitely a good course to take if you are interested in history or strategy.
Absolutely take it!
Definitely worth taking. Just keep in mind that you really have to start doing readings early in the week to keep up.
Do all the readings, attend lecture, and attend precept.  This course is amazing and you will learn so much valuable information.
Do the reading. All of it. You might not be tested on it all, but it will make you a better person.
Don't let the reading scare you away. If you are interested in history, politics or strategy, this is a must-take course.

If the course is reorganized, the course material would be fantastic. How great power try to change the world through grand strategy is a really cool subject, but if it is presented in such a disorganized fashion, then it is not worth studying at Princeton.

If you have a strong background in history and politics, you may be able to come into the course with your own angle to make it interesting. Otherwise, a lot of history and ideas are thrown at you without insightful discussion in lecture or precept, and I did not feel that I emerged from the course having really delved into the subject material. That being said, the reading list is great, and I learned a lot from doing the readings. I did not find Professor Ikenberry to be a compelling or rigorous lecturer.
Interesting, reading-intensive course with a great professor and equally great preceptors!
Really great course but be prepared to dedicate time to readings
Take it, but be weary of the amount of reading.
Take it. Get Zach as your preceptor.
Take the course but only if you have time to do a LOT of reading each week. The class is all about broad strokes, so if you are good at and enjoy teasing out the big picture, it's the class for you.
Take the course if you are interested in IR. You will learn a lot, but be prepared for a lot of reading and intense discussion.
Take this class if you are interested in international relations.  You will have to do a lot of readings in order to perform well in this class.
This class is hard.  Keep up the readings and you will learn so much.  Great intro to IR.  My first WWS class.
This course is great. Take it.
This is a great class on fascinating material. Provides a deep analysis of historical and theoretical perspectives on strategy. A must-take.
Tons of reading, and grading is pretty arbitrary.  But you'll learn a ton.
You learn a ton, but there's tons of reading. That being said, you don't really need to do all of it. Make sure you get Zack Cooper as a preceptor!
yeah, but only if they make the syllabus more reasonable
prereqs: Some knowledge of U.S. European, and/or Asian history is essential, through there are no prerequisite courses.
descrip: Grand strategy is the broad and encompassing policies and undertakings that political leaders pursue - financial, economic, military, diplomatic - to achieve their objectives in peacetime and in war.. This seminar will examine the theory and practice of grand strategy both to illuminate how relations among city-states, empires, kingdoms and nation states have evolved over the centuries and also to identify some common challenges that have confronted all who seek to make and execute grand strategy, from Pericles to Barack Obama.

title: Lebanon between War, Liberation and Political Reform (1975-2012)
descrip: Lebanon is unable to defend against regional and international influences, but its lack of institutionalism gives it a flexibility sometimes useful to overcome political blockages. The political game in Lebanon is the product of calibrated doses of local, national, regional and international imperatives addressed through rigid frames of meaning-making.This course aims to shed light on the submerged part of the Lebanese politics iceberg, and to establish its significance for the country's social and political future. Our aim here is to build a "model of Lebanese politics" and determine what it can teach us for other countries of the region.

title: Comparative Physiology
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: This course explores the mechanisms of animal function in the contexts of evolution, ecology and behavior. We will cover the physiological bases of osmoregulation, circulation, gas exchange, digestion, energetics, motility, and neural and hormonal control of these and other processes in a variety of vertebrate and invertebrate animals, thereby revealing general principles of animal physiology as well as specific physiological adaptations to differing environments.

title: Political Psychology
descrip: This course examines psychological perspectives on politics. Themes include human limitation vs. human capacity, how institutions shape or interact with individual opinion and behavior, discussion and deliberation, and the role of groups. We will also discuss methodological issues.

title: Sex on Stage
descrip: This course examines theatrical performance as a mode of theorizing about gender, sex, sexuality and embodiment. Through lecture, discussion and performance workshops, this course draws upon contemporary U.S. dramatic literature as it undertakes a multinational, historical survey of theories of performance. The course considers such topics as gender as performance, cross-gender performance, performances of sexual identity, and the explicit body in performance.

title: Iran Since the Revolution
reviews: Commit to the readings, but they're definitely worth it.
Do all the readings! They are genuinely very interesting :D
First SA class that I've taken and I loved it!  Really interesting...and welcoming to students form all backgrounds.
I think this course has a lot of potential, and as it gets edited, it will be something great. For now, it is a work in progress, with interesting subject material.
I would absolutely recommend this class. Professor Kunkler is an amazing professor and there couldn't be a more interesting or relevant topic
I would recommend attending every lecture because lectures were very helpful in clarifying readings and weekly themes.
I would spend ample time in the readings.
Take this course.
This was a very interesting class both from a specific Iranian history/politics point of view and from a political theory point of view.
You don't need to do all the readings. The course gives you a solid background in the politics and society in contemporary Iran, but if you're looking for an exciting seminar, look somewhere else.
descrip: This course examines the formation and development of the Islamic Republic of Iran in the aftermath of the 1979 revolution. It considers, in particular, how the Iranian regime has adapted to changing domestic and international economic, social and political conditions and sustained itself enface grave social and economic challenges and international isolation. Topics of Discussion include: Social Movements and Political Reform, Clerical Opposition and Dissident Theology, Changing Interpretations of Religious Law, Missed Opportunities in US-Iran relations, Iran's role in the Middle East, the nuclear question.

title: Seminar in American Politics - Racial Politics in the U.S.
reviews: Come to class prepared to engage in lively discussions- it was the highlight of the experience for me.
Do not take this class. It's one of the worst classes I've taken at Princeton. The professor is boring, the material is boring, and the discussions are boring. Absolutely do not take this class!
I would highly recommend it.
If you're looking for a seminar on American politics, or interested in modern American politics or race, I'd take it.

Prof. Mendelberg is a great seminar leader, as well as a warm and friendly person. The seminar tackled a lot of different subjects that surround racial politics, but it didn't seem to try to take on too much: it was a good balance of breadth and depth. The readings were interesting and well-selected. One caveat though: the term paper, though technically the only written work for the whole semester (except for weekly reading responses), is pretty much a JP (~20 pages). Having that on top of an actual JP wasn't fun, but the course as a whole was enjoyable.
Take this!
take it!
descrip: This course investigates the politics of race in the U. S. with particular attention to the political status of African Americans. We will cover topics including the meaning of race, the civil rights movement and collective action, gender, class and regional differences, racial prejudice, racial identity, and various public policy issues such as residential segregation and political representation. The focus will be on student participation and student research projects involving direct observation and rigorous qualitative analysis, or analysis of quantitative data.

title: Writing the History of Art
prereqs: ART 400 and four additional Art and Archaeology courses or instructor's consent..
descrip: Meant for students planning or beginning graduate work, this course examines assumptions that have troubled the writing of art history since the birth of our discipline, e.g., the teleological fallacy, which is deeply embedded in our ideas about styles and periods, and more recent notions that try to relate the history of art to some larger history by positing a metaphysical entity that shapes or directs the production of art. We want to find ways of thinking about the art of the past that give due attention to context without depriving artists and patrons of free will. Technical studies and perceptual psychology will also be introduced.

title: Studies in Ancient Judaism - Rabbis and Priests
descrip: In recent years some scholars have claimed that priests as a group remained an important force for centuries after the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE. They point to features of a variety of texts from the rabbinic era, including piyyut (liturgical poetry), targumim (Aramaic translations of the Bible), and hekhalot literature (early Jewish mystical texts), that they see as indicating priestly authorship or at least influence. This course will attempt to assess these claims through a close reading of the relevant texts. It will also explore attitudes toward priests past and present in rabbinic literature.

title: Theory of Games
reviews: The course is not too difficult and the material covered is useful, although there aren't alot of applications.
Very tough, but fair, interesting, and useful.  Well worth taking if you're willing to put up with some math.
prereqs: MAT 202, 204, 217 or equivalent. MAT 215 or equivalent is recommended..
descrip: Games in extensive form, pure and behavioral strategies; normal form, mixed strategies, equilibrium points; coalitions, characteristic-function form, imputations, solution concepts; related topics and applications.

title: Intellectual History of China to the Fifth Century
prereqs: A prior course in EAS is desirable but not required..
descrip: Critical consideration of a selection of monumental contributions to early Chinese thought, and the uses to which they were put by later Chinese thinkers. Readings will be from English translations such as: [Analects],[ Lao-tzu], [Chuang-tzu], [Mencius],[ I-ching] and secondary works. All assignments are available on reserve.

title: Intermediate Japanese I
descrip: This course aims to give a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese (Tokyo speech) by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points and more advanced vocabulary and grammar. Students will reinforce four major skills by speaking - listening drills, readings, and written exercises.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Health and Society in Latin America During the 20th Century
prereqs: The course is directed to graduate and advanced undergraduate students. A knowledge of Spanish or Portuguese is not necessary. Films from the National Library of Medicine will be included in discussions. Students must hand in and discuss with the professor a preliminary title and outline of the 20-page paper before the break of the term. Final research paper can be done on the history of health and medicine in a certain country or a relevant cross-country discussion..
descrip: Emphasizing social, cultural, and institutional dimensions, this course will examine the development of public health in Latin America and the Caribbean during the 20th century. Organized into three main sections, the course will cover the persistence of indigenous concepts and healing practices which underwent discrimination; sanitation studies of these indigenous practices as well as the "silver-bullet" eradication programs of the early and late 20th century; and the examination of indigenous resistance to official programs and of the work done by medical doctors leading holistic public health programs such as primary health care.

title: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics II
reviews: Do not take this course if you have not already taken advanced courses on Solid State Physics, Quantum Mechanics, Superconductivity and Group Theory. Basic understanding of Quantum Field Theory is also a necessity.
If you are interested in topological insulators this course is the first step to learn it!
descrip: Course introduces and present ongoing theoretical investigations of new research topics in condensed matter physics: topological insulators and Chern numbers, topological superconductors, the fractional quantum Hall effect and non-abelian statistics, as well as new high-temperature superconductors. The techniques needed to deal with such systems, such as Chern numbers, topological band theory, Berry phases, conformal field theory, Chern-Simons theory, t-J models, Gutzwiller wavefunctions, Hubbard models, are explained.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Discusses the main tools of econometric analysis, and the way in which they are applied to a range of problems in social science. Emphasis is on using techniques, and on understanding and critically assessing others' use of them. There is a great deal of practical work on the computer using a range of data from around the world. Topics include regression analysis, with a focus on regression as a tool for analyzing non-experimental data, discrete choice, and an introduction to time-series analysis. There are applications from macroeconomics, policy evaluation, and economic development. Prerequisite: grounding in topics covered in 507c.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: The Hebrew Poetry of Medieval Spain
prereqs: HEB 302 or equivalent.
descrip: Covers the rise of the golden age of Hebrew poetry in Muslim Spain; the Arabic literary background; lyrical, liturgical, and contemplative verse by great poets of the 11th and 13th centuries (Shmuel ha-Nagid, Ibn Gabirol, Judah Halevi, Todros Abulafia, etc.); and narratives in rhymed prose. Two weeks will be devoted to developments outside Spain: the 12th through 13th century martyrdom poems from France and the Rhineland, and, in conclusion, the adoption of Romance forms, especially the sonnet, in the Hebrew poetry of Italy.

title: Second Language Acquisition Research and Language Teaching Methodology
descrip: Designed to provide future teaching assistants with the knowledge and conceptual tools needed to reflect critically on pedagogical practices in the second language classroom. Examines issues related to teaching language and culture in a university setting, highlighting the relationship between theory in Second Language Acquisition and language pedagogy and helping students understand the practical implications of theoretical frameworks in the field.

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - International Migration and Public Policy
descrip: This course examines the historical and contemporary literature on international migration, the policies that enable or impede cross-national migration, and the consequences for the sending and receiving states as well as the migrants themselves. Drawing on contemporary international evidence, students will consider classical and contemporary theories of immigrant adaptation, language acculturation, and ethnic conflict from comparative international evidence.

title: Analysis in Several Variables
prereqs: MAT 215 and 217.
descrip: Rigorous introduction to calculus in several variables.

title: Controversies in Health Policy: Historical Perspectives
descrip: Examines historical pathways in shaping recent health policies. Among the topics examined: Medicare's history, failed Clinton reforms, and 2010 health legislation as case studies of diverse pathways toward reform; Ritalin as insight into FDA policy, direct-to-consumer drug advertising, and prescription practices; recent vaccine debates which sit at the intersection of science, consumer beliefs, economics, and state health policy; and physician-assisted suicide in medicine, law, and the courts. Emphasis on analyzing role of government, political ideology, consumers, industry, scientists, and regulatory interests in health policy formation.

title: Introduction to Sanskrit
descrip: This one semester introduction to Sanskrit will take the form of an intensive immersion in the foundations of Sanskrit grammar and syntax. Our primary text will be Maurer's The Sanskrit Language. Further supplemental handouts and exercises will be distributed as necessary to complement daily lessons from the Maurer text.

title: Advanced Japanese II
reviews: A solid class to improve one's Japanese skills after 301.
Definitely take this course!
Helpful
If you are even slightly considering taking this or another Japanese language course, DO IT! You won't regret it.

It's good to use the tools offered when doing homework and studying. Some of the readings are especially difficult, and for those using the electronic versions is immensely helpful for looking up words and phrases.
descrip: The course is designed to further students proficiency in four skills aiming at ACTFL-ETS advanced level. Reading materials include the Japanese anime "Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (Spirited Away)" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: The Age of Emerson
descrip: Using the poetry and prose of Emerson as a kind of measure, this course seeks to understand the governing cultural and political rhetorics through which nineteenth-century America thought about such issues as race, slavery, nationality, manifest destiny, westward expansion, and identity. Emerson's writings will be read as both symptomatic and critical of the discourses that shaped the terms of these issues and debates. Although most of our time will be devoted to readings of Emerson's writings, we also will be reading texts by, among others, Thomas Paine, Daniel Webster, and Frederick Douglass, in order to contextualize our discussions.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: Topics in International Relations - Protection Against Weapons of Mass Destruction
descrip: Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the only significant security threats to the U.S. and its allies have been from nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. Historically, the US focus has oscillated between protection via nonproliferation and disarmament agreements, and via civil and missile defense. The course assesses the threats, both approaches to protection, and linkages made between policies on WMD and perceptions of "conventional" military threats.

title: Experimental Methods I
reviews: Excellent introduction to experimental methods ! I strongly recommend the class.
I would recommend students who've had a limited or no background in electronics take this course if they're interested in learning more about the subject.
If you enjoy tinkering with electronics, this is a really nice course to take. It's well taught, and Prof. Littman and Jon Prevost are really great about answering questions.
Spend time outside of class thinking about the circuits and planning ahead.
This course is a great way to learn a lot about electronics and experimental methods through a combination of hands-on laboratory work and engaging lectures.
descrip: A laboratory course that focuses on basic electronics techniques, digital electronics, and data acquisition and analysis. Topics include introduction to digital and analog electronics, digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion, microcomputer sampling, and data analysis. There are approximately four laboratory hours and two lecture hours per week. There is one project.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Everything is Under Control
prereqs: Classes and readings will be in English. Materials in Portuguese or Spanish might be suggested, but will not be mandatory. Students pursuing the POR certificate, papers must be written in Portuguese..
descrip: Examines the appropriation of technology by low income populations and its impact to culture, economy and the public sphere. It investigates copyright and its reform, piracy, internet regulation in the region, and analyzes media structure, cultural and digital policies. Also examines the role of technology (from social networks to cell phones) to cultural production, describing music scenes such as tecnobrega in Brazil or cumbia villera in Argentina. Will discuss the efforts to create an internet bill of rights (aka an anti-SOPA law), and expose students to examples of the digital culture being produced in the peripheries.

title: Introductory Video and Film Production
reviews: Although I would recommend everyone to try filmmaking, I'm not sure if this class is the right way to be introduced to or improve yourself on that. Be warned that it takes a lot of time, and you might actually enjoy shooting films more if you are not doing it for grade.
I would definitely recommend this course but only to student with a strong interest in film. This course demands way too much from someone who is just looking for a fun art to try out.

If you are interested in film and enjoy spending time with other people who are interested in film, then if you do one thing at Princeton...
THEN YOU OWE IT TO YOURSELF TO DO EVERYTHING THAT YOU CAN DO TO GET INTO AND TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
All you have to do is give this course the time it deserves and have the ability to take constructive criticism and the rewards you will obtain will be so great they cannot be described.  What would you rather be doing with your free time on weekend nights?  Drinking your troubles away and wasting away at some club, or experiencing a new look into the world, watching your creative visions come to life, getting the chance to meet people who are just fun to be around, and literally falling in love with cinema even more than you loved it before?  You will look at movies, television, scripts, the trees, life in a completely different manner.  You will go on a fantastical journey with Keith Sanborn, who was a great dry-wit and quasi-cynical attitude that is perfect for the class, and a handful of other students who you will see grow along with you.  You will realize that pulling an all-nighter is not a dangerous travesty but a privilege and a gift if it is with work and people you care for.  Seven assignments you will have.  Seven assignments to build, film, edit, sound edit, talk about, workshop.  And it all culminates in a basically-two-month-long final two-part assignment that is worth every second you give it.  In this assignment, you have free reign to do anything, which I know seems daunting at first, but WE ARE NOTHING WITHOUT FREEDOM AND THIS CLASS GIVES YOU SO MUCH YOU WILL LOVE IT FOR IT!!!  TAKE THIS COURSE, SHOW IT LOVE, AND IT WILL LOVE YOU TOO!!!

P.S. My best friend was in the class and one person in the class became another best friend so I may be biased, but seriously you should take this class either way.
If you have any interest in film-making no matter your background you should take this class. Keith is extremely helpful in improving your work and the class really feels like a little community.
Take it.  You'll love it.
This will take up a lot of time, but is worth it.  It is satisfying to see your work on the big screen.
prereqs: By application/interview and instructor's permission. Please see the Visual Arts Program website page for specific application/interview information..
descrip: A film/video course introducing the techniques of shooting and editing digital video. Works of film/video art are analyzed in order to explore the development of, and innovations in, cinematic language. Production is oriented toward film/video as a visual art, including narrative, documentary, and experimental genres. Several short video projects produced during the semester.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Readings on 3D Capture and Fabrication
reviews: I strongly recommend this course to students with strong interests in the topic and with certain level of background.
I would highly recommend this course.
If you are interested in the related area, then it's definitely worth taking.
descrip: Read and discuss recent papers on the interface between the computer and objects in the "tangible world". Reading will cover recent approaches to scanning 3D objects and motion, as well as 3D printing devices. Students will be expected to read 20-30 papers and lead discussions on 3-4 of them over the course of the semester.

title: Topics in Economic and Organizational Sociology (Half-Term) - Gender and Economic Activity
descrip: Introduction to a gendered analysis of economic processes and institutions. Course investigates when, why, and in what ways gender shapes production, consumption, distribution, and transfer of assets. After a general discussion of gender theories, it surveys how gender works in a variety of settings and activities, such as labor markets, intimate economies, and caring labor. We end with an overview of strategies aimed at reducing gendered economic inequalities. Overall, the course attempts to strengthen intellectual bridges between economic sociology and gender scholarship.

title: Seminar in French Civilization - Writing the People in 19C France
descrip: What is the people? Much of nineteenth-century literature is an effort to confront this urgent political question after the Revolution, and to give shape and voice to this amorphous new sovereign. At once ubiquitous and intangible, the people is an unsettling power that modern writing seeks to name, express, silence, or shape. This course examines some landmark novels (by Hugo, les Goncourt, Sue, and Zola) and social analysis (by reformers, hygienists, and intellectuals) at the crossroads between politics and aesthetics. Critical texts by Marx, Chevalier, Ranciere, Foucault, T.J. Clark, Lefort, and Rosanvallon.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion.

title: Advanced Korean II
prereqs: KOR 301 or placement test..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 301. Continued development of proficiency in speaking and reading through class discussion and short readings. Vocabulary learning and discourse skills are emphasized.

title: Topics in Literary and Cultural Theory - Painting, Sculpture, and Other Things
descrip: Seminar explores roles works of art play in Rainer Maria Rilke's writings and their reception. Key case studies of Rodin and Cezanne, with additional readings on their work by philosophers and art historians whose approaches speak to concerns of Rilke's own. Conceptualization and representation of works of art and aesthetic experience in relation to other things, and significance of painting, sculpture, and other media, artistic and nonartistic, in Rilke's work. Investigation of signal instances and central issues in the history of modernism in the visual arts and literature.

title: Topics in Ecology (Half-Term) - Theoretical Ecosystem Ecology
descrip: This course is designed to teach graduate students fundamental concepts of ecosystem biogeochemistry and to model nutrient cycles in land ecosystems. The course will consist of lectures and readings as well as an independent project in which each student develops a quantitative model of a particular problem of interest. To be considered, students should send a one-paragraph statement of interest in the course, including a sentence detailing a potential topic of the independent project, to Prof. Lars Hedin (lhedin@princeton.edu).

title: Society and Politics in Pakistan
descrip: Nuclear weapons, radical Islam, military dictatorship, and war with India commonly come to mind when people think of Pakistan today. This course will examine the politics and economics of state-building in Pakistan, the impact of the cold war and hot wars, the role of militarism and nuclear weapons, the challenges of identity politics, the rise of Islamic fundamentalism, economic development and inequality, and the relationship with the United States.

title: Global Health in Africa
descrip: This seminar will examine the contemporary phenomenon of "global health" in Africa against the history and politics of health and healing. Topics include; colonial efforts to regulate race, gender, sexuality, and labor; African's responses to colonialism and missionization; the impact of colonialism on experience of health and healing; the training of African practitioners of biomedicine; the significance of healing practices to anti-colonial movements; and the relevance of these historical experiences to contemporary African public health and medicine. We will conclude with case studies of cutting-edge health issues in Africa.

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Human Rights
reviews: A very good class with a few spectacular moments. Especially if you have limited background in IR and international politics, it will really influence the way you think about the world. Even if it's not this one, take a class with Bass.
Bass is a great lecturer and the content is very applicable to current American positions and issues people should be aware of. Exams are A LOT of memorization so be ready for that.
Definitely take this course!

Definitely take this course!!! Try to keep on top of the readings, even though you can't actually get through all of them with a full course load. Make sure to spend time with the political theory readings and the general readings about International Justice and Humanitarian Intervention (A Problem from Hell, Stay the Hand of Vengeance, etc.). Most importantly, GO TO LECTURE. The lectures are by far the most engaging part of any course you will take at Princeton, and illuminate well not only the concepts, but also so many things you wanted to know about the world. This is a difficult class but it is well worth it.
Definitely take, I'm not a pol major / this is the first pol class I ever took and it's nice because it's more empirical and not super theoretical so it's very immediately interesting
Do the readings, but try to actively work the connections withim them.

Don't take Gary Bass' precept, he's a complete a**hole if you aren't chosen as one of his 'favorite' couple students. I'm not sure how the course was for other precepts but the material was very interesting.
Everyone should take this class! It's a little more work but totally worth it. Professor Bass is awesome and each lecture was awesome.
Go to every lecture, make a reading group and keep up with the readings
I definitely recommend others to take this class!!!

I definitely recommend this course. But try not to be in Prof. Bass's precept. I think I would have benefited from another instructor's perspective on the topics. It's a TON of reading -- make a reading group. But a fair and interesting course.
It is a lot of reading, but the material is so interesting and Bass is such a great lecturer that it will be worth it.  One of my favorite courses at Princeton.
Make sure you keep up on terms that are written on the board in beginning of lecture!
Must take this class!

Professor Bass is extremely opinionated. If you can get past the fact that he holds extremely strong opinions, this will be one of the best lectures you can attend at Princeton. Fascinating subject, very limited in scope. Essentially discusses human rights as: genocide, torture, and terrorism. Little introduction to economic human rights, women's rights, or children's rights.
Read everything and go to all lectures
Really depends on the student. At least give it a try if you're interested.

TAKE IT. Gary Bass is one of the best professors on campus.  Readings can be long but it's easy to skim them and get most of the ideas from lecture.  This was my favorite course freshman year and it convinced me to change my major.
Take it!
Take it!! It's a lot of work, but Bass' lectures are worth it.

Take it.  Bass is a great lecturer and Anna is a fantastic preceptor.  Lots of reading but it is all worth it and will carry over to pretty much any other politics course you take.  This class will make you reevaluate your personal beliefs, American foreign policy, and your future plans.  Best course I've taken at Princeton.
Take it. Bass is an amazing lecturer. You learn a lot. Just keep in mind that it's more empirical than theoretical.
Take it. The readings may be a lot for one person, so get a study group together. It will save you so much time and will make the overall semester much easier.
Take the class
Take the course. There are no other courses at Princeton I know of that can teach your about a similar subject matter.

This class is amazing! If you have any interest on learning about world issues and current events in the context of political theories, take it! Gary Bass is an amazing lecturer, however a bit intimidating. The lectures are really good, but sometimes make you feel terrible and you walk out being super depressed. But it is still really enlightening. Also, Rohan is a wonderful preceptor! He's the best!
This course was great and I encourage anyone to take it who is interested in international affairs, the history of violence, or just wants to have a great class.

This is one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Professor Bass is an awesome and hilarious lecturer, and my preceptor was amazing. The material is really interesting and is presented extremely well. It's kind of a lot of reading, but so worth it--you'll learn a lot!
good class for an introduction to much of recent history and some theories of IR. If you are at all knowledgable about such things, much of this course will be redundant.
none
take it!
descrip: A study of the politics and history of human rights. What are human rights? How can dictatorships be resisted from the inside and the outside? Can we prevent genocide? Is it morally acceptable and politically wise to launch humanitarian military interventions to prevent the slaughter of foreign civilians? What are the laws of war, and how can we punish the war criminals who violate them? Cases include the Ottoman Empire, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Bosnia, and Rwanda.

title: Mechanical Design
reviews: A lot of work, as design courses tend to be, but I really like this class; especially if you are interested in robotics, take this class.
Big time commitment, but very rewarding! I feel at home in a machine shop now! Much better than 321.
Don't take this as a senior unless you want a very busy senior spring. The class is rewarding but time-consuming.
Get into a good group, divide the work, and don't be afraid to put in some long hours.
I really liked it- but be aware that the second have can and probably will become a ridiculously annoying amount of work. If you care about the class trying to make your robot work will consume you.
If you have the time to put into it, it's worth taking. Otherwise it's just a nightmare.
Prepare to spend a lot of hours down in the lab
Take it.  It was pretty cool.  Not sure if it's better than trains though.

Take the course! You learn a lot that you wouldn't in any other class about topics like project management, safety, team work. Also the guest lectures and amazing and the final project is pretty cool too!

The project (the Search and Rescue Robot) is very interesting, and you learn a great deal if you work hard on the project. Prof. Nosenchuck is also very enthusiastic and supportive. The course is much better than MAE 321.
While it was a time-intensive course, I had a great experience and would absolutely recommend this class to another (engineering) student.
Will be lots of work, but you get lots of hands on experience
if you are considering taking it, you probably have to.
prereqs: MAE 321 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course builds on the technical foundations established in MAE 321, and extends the scope to include a range of advanced mechanism design. Students, working in teams, will be challenged to design and fabricate a robotic system that will draw upon multidisciplinary engineering elements. The robot will be used to facilitate common daily tasks. The selected tasks vary each year. CAD, CAE, and CAM will be utilized in the design/simulation/prototype process. Labs are designed to reinforce and expand CAD and CAE skills. A final public competition will be held among the design teams. Judges from relevant industries will be present.

title: Intermediate Korean I
prereqs: KOR 101 and KOR 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Intermediate Korean is designed for students who have learned the basics of the Korean language and want to improve their competence to a higher level. Complex sentences and grammar are covered while the basics are reviewed. Balancing four language skills -- listening, speaking, reading, and writing -- is emphasized.

title: Books and Their Readers
reviews: Do you like books? Do you like to read? Do you like history? If the answer to any of them is yes - TAKE IT. Preferably before Senior Year. This course will expose you to a wonderful and fascinating area of history you will not see in any other course here, inform you about the delights of the Firestone Rare Book collection, expose you to stimulating seminar discussions, all with an awesome professor.

Even if you just like to read twitter or comic books or road signs, take this course, or any course with Professor Grafton. You won't regret it. It's a thrilling journey from Ancient Greece to the 21st century.

Professor Grafton could be teaching a course on anything under the moon and I would take it. He is a brilliant, brilliant man, compassionate and encouraging professor and seminar leader, and all around boss. Take this class while you can!

TAKE THIS, if you are interested in ideas: at Princeton we talk about ideas all the time, but rarely do we consider how their physical manifestation (or absence) affects our understanding of intellectual history and the past in general. This was the first class I took in which I had the opportunity the work in the Rare Books Collection, which was unexpectedly delightful and invaluable. Also, if Professor Grafton is teaching something, just take it....!!!
Take it!
Take this class! It's great!
Take this class, absolutely. If you don't, you'll regret it and you're Princeton career will be a little less colorful

You will probably not be able to finish all of the readings, so glance through the books first and choose what you are going to read well and what you are going to skim. Start the assignments ahead of time, and take advantage of the Rare Books Room and of Professor Grafton's offers for extra help, especially on the research paper. If you have questions, bring them to class and ask!
take it! Even if you don't think you have interest in books/their history, it's worth chillin with Grafton.
prereqs: ECS students will be given priority..
descrip: This course will offer an intensive introduction to the history of the making, distribution and reading of books in the West, from ancient Greece to modern America. By examining a series of case studies, we will see how writers, producers, and readers of books have interacted, and how the conditions of production and consumption have changed over time.

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part II
reviews: If at all possible, let lava flows inform the design.
Start working on the final project as early and as steadily as possible!
You should keep your own pace to finish your project in a good quality.
take it if it is required.
descrip: Study and evaluation of mechanical and electrical system applications for different building types, including air conditioning, electrical, plumbing and telecommunications. Emphasis on design integration with architecture and structure within the construction process including sustainable design and energy conservation. Introduction to vertical transportation, life safety systems, and intelligent buildings. Emphasis on a conceptual approach using case studies and field trips.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Controversies in State and Local Health Regulation
descrip: This course will address state and local regulation of public health and health care. It will explore the opportunities and limits of government intervention to promote health and addressing health care deficits, with case examples drawn from New York City, New Jersey and other city and state experiences. The course combines in-depth reading, discussion, lectures, and written assignments; readings will be drawn from current health policy literature, state and local government primary sources, and news analysis.

title: Mass Media and American Politics
descrip: This course considers the role of the mass media in American politics and the influence of the media on Americans' political attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors. We will examine the nature of news and news making organizations, the role of the news media in electoral campaigns, how the media shape the behavior of politicians once in office, political advertising, and the impact of the media on Americans' political attitudes.

title: Mathematical Models in the Study of Politics
reviews: BE ready and don't fall behind.  Do not take senior spring.
Don't take it unless you love this content / need too

Don't take this course unless you have a clear mathematical mind, or are willing to put in the time and effort to go to Office Hours regularly, as the course goes quickly from being easy and intuitive to being fairly abstract and difficult to wrestle with.
Go ahead and take it- a nice choice, maybe not quite as hard as ECO 317, and with a fantastic instructor.
Great intro to game theory course! Iaryczower is really good at explaining concepts!
I loved it! Game thoery and Matias are awesome and they are even more awesome together!
I recommend this course to anyone that wants to either challenge themselves or just learn something new. This material will really expand the way that you think.
If you are interested in game theory and politics, then take the course. It is not super rigorous or anything, but a very interesting course on game theory.
If you haven't taken game theory, it's worth studying, and this class taught it best of all the times I've learned game theory.
Only take this if you have to, or if you have a strong interest in game theory.
Solid course. Not too much work, interesting content--can't complain.
Take it if you're interested in game theory, and are not looking for a proof based math class.
This course is a new way of thinking. Meaning that there is a steep learning curve.
Workload is manageable, but it would help to have some familiarity with mathematical reasoning.
eh,
prereqs: MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to the use of formal game-theoretic models in the study of politics. Applications include: voting, bargaining, lobbying, legislative institutions, and strategic information transmission. Familiarity with mathematical reasoning is helpful.

title: Race in America
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Urban Economics
descrip: This is a course in urban and regional economics. Course studies the main economic forces that lead to the emergence of cities and regional agglomeration, and the effects on worker productivity, urban amenities, and congestion. Course discusses the problems in measuring these urban characteristics, the methodologies to do it, as well as the design of optimal urban policy. Course also studies the economic theory and evidence on the internal structure of cities, as well as the policies that can enhance urban living. Finally, the course analyzes the role cities play in aggregate economic development.

title: Elementary Swahili II
reviews: A great class for students interested in African studies, development or just interested in picking up a language. Swahili is a great language to know since it a lingua franca of millions in east and southern Africa.
If the student is interested in trying out a Bantu language, he or she should definitely try it out. If, however, the student needs structure in his or her class, I would definitely not recommend it.

If you want to learn Swahili at Princeton, this is the only game in town.  Mahiri is pretty relaxed which is kind of nice, and I'm also happy in retrospect that instead of a textbook we just use our class notes as our text, since now I'll have it saved forever.  I also recommend going to his office hours if you're interested in Kenyan/East African politics, as he has a ton to say about it and every time I went we always ended up talking about Swahili for ten minutes and all other interesting things for at least an hour.  DON'T BOTHER BUYING THE EXPENSIVE TEXT BOOK -- YOU WILL NOT NEED IT!

Practice speaking Swahili with other students!! This is key! I was lucky enough to have a coworker that speaks Swahili who I was able to practice with. Form study groups and meet up on a regular basis to practice speaking.
Take it if you are interested in Swahili. It is also a very easy language to learn for your distribution requirements.
Take it!
While fast-paced compared to the previous semester, this course is interesting and fun.
prereqs: Only those who have taken Elementary Swahili I (SWA 101) should enroll..
descrip: Continuation of SWA 101. Emphasis is on increasing proficiency in reading and listening comprehension, speaking, and writing activities in Swahili. Cultural contexts of the East African societies where Swahili is spoken are incorporated in classroom activities in order to enhance communication and cultural proficiency.

title: Projects in Performance Studies
descrip: Techniques of interdisciplinary collaboration: Over the course of our twelve classes, we will create a collaborative interdisciplinary work that we will perform at the end of the semester. In the process, we will study the seminal work of several different artists including: Lee Breuer, Pina Bausch, Robert Wilson and Ushio Amagatsu.

title: Life Writing: The Art of Biography
descrip: "Life Writing: The Art of Biography" will be a sustained analysis of what makes biography, at its best, an exciting hybrid: a genre that combines the precision of scholarship--of scrupulous historical and biographical research--with the insight and narrative thrust of a good novel. Great biography tells the tale with panache, in short, while never straying from a framework of fact. The course will explore the biographer's (and autobiographer's) craft over a range of subjects and styles, and will provide students the opportunity to write a biographical chapter about a person who fascinates them.

title: The Dreamkeepers: Education Reform and the Urban Teaching Experience
descrip: See website

title: Problems of Philosophy - Topics in Contemporary Metaphysics
descrip: This course will examine a range of issues from contemporary metaphysics. Topics covered will include counterfactuals, natural properties, grounding, causation and necessitism.

title: The History of Russian Rock
prereqs: RUS101 or instructor's permission. While students must have at least some Russian, every effort will be made to accommodate varying levels of Russian, as the course could potentially benefit everyone from intermediate to advanced learners..
descrip: The course will examine the emergence of rock music in the period leading up to the collapse of the Soviet Union, and its enduring cultural and political significance in post-Soviet Russia (including recent protest movements) while developing students' appreciation of colloquial Russian. We will encounter a number of fascinating people and artists, charting their musical development, their forays into other genres (particularly film), and their political impact. Assignments will be listening to the music while studying the original Russian lyrics (with glosses and translations).

title: Beginner's Latin Continued: Basic Prose
reviews: A little more difficult than 101, but otherwise very similar. If you enjoyed 101, you will probably like 102.
Great course for beginners
If you are interested in Latin as a language, definitely take this course (especially if Aaron is teaching).
Take it with Aaron if you can
Try to do at least a few sentences per chapter and definitely keep up with the vocab because if you don't know the words then you're dead before you even start.
prereqs: LAT 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continues Latin grammar from LAT 101. The second half of the semester will be devoted to reading continuous Latin poetry and prose.

title: The Religions of China
reviews: Always go to lectures and take advantage of precepts to sort out any misunderstandings.

An easy EM, but only take it if you can deal with busy-work.  Attendance in lecture is important in the grading, as are precept posts and participation.  Overall, it wasn't hard or particularly enlightening.
Attendance is taken!
Attending lecture is mandatory, but the material is interesting. Participate well in precept, and do well in writing papers!
Do the readings or else you will miss out on valuable discussions.
Easy. PDF = no work at all.

For those who have no prior knowledge of China, this course serves as a good introduction into Chinese culture and history. The reading is on the lighter side of the humanities classes I have taken, and I think this would be a great humanities course for STEM students who are also interested in China. However, as a student with some prior knowledge of China and religion, I found a lot that I already knew here, and I do not feel that the course went as deeply into the subject as it could have.
Go to lecture and precept so as not to drop points.
Good class to PDF since no exams. However, they take attendance during lecture though.
Good course. Readings were interesting, precepts were ... precept-ish. Prof. Teiser is a good lecturer.
Great class, especially if you want to PDF. Don't miss lectures. Take it.
Great exploration of another culture and its religions. Current faculty (Stephen Teiser and Takashi Miura) are some of the best I've ever worked with.

I learned SO much from this course. But be prepared to put up with the taking of attendance, ridiculous and irrelevant quizzes, and reports. If these things bother you and you aren't genuinely interested in Chinese religion, this is not the course for you.

I would definitely take this course if you need an EM or just because you are interested in Religions of China. Or China in general. It felt more like a history class, but it had just the right about of debate versus another morals class where the debates become pointless. It's definitely manageable as a 5th class.
I would recommend this to other students!
If you're interested in the subject material, you'll like the readings, but the lectures tend to be boring and unhelpful. (Attendance is required anyways.)
It is a great low commitment class with only two papers. I enjoyed the knowledge and culture of it!
Pick Takashi as your preceptor. Do itttttttt.
Probably the chillest EM you can get, but the subject matter is not very enlightening.
Take it if you're interested in the subject. Attendance taken at lectures, but only work for the term is a midterm paper, a final paper, and precept posts.

The class is not intensive to the point where you should feel intimidated by the work. The readings are generally doable, and the professor/preceptors are helpful and understanding. 

It *does* give you a good sense of Chinese religion, so there's that.

The class is pretty straightforward--2 papers, weekly BB posts, and 2 extracurricular reports. The material can be a little boring, but Prof. Teiser is a really nice prof. and its obvious that he cares about his students. Oh, and lectures are mandatory (a sign in sheet is sent around) so keep that in mind!
The course provides interesting information about Chinese religion from ancient times to modern.

The readings were excellent, though the lectures were sometimes harder to get excited about. China's interaction with religion in general, though, is fascinating - I really learned a lot about it through this class.It was also fun to go to the necessary extracurricular events, though the two page write-ups were less fun.

This course has a relatively low workload and very interesting material.  The lectures can be a bit slow, but if you can get past that, the course is and excellent and engaging way to fill course requirements or satisfy general interest.
This course is very broad and provides a good introduction to religion in China.
This is a good EM class for those without background in Chinese religion.

This is a very interesting course if you want to learn more about religions popular in East Asia and you also learn the relationship between religion and society in the latter half of the course. It's a pretty easy course to do well in but precepts don't really add much to the course. If you want to learn more about Chinese culture with an easy class, go take this class
Yes

You take out of it as much as you are prepared to put into it. Reflect critically on the readings and make thoughtful contributions to the Discussion Board/ to precept, as precept grading favors quality over quantity.
prereqs: Open to students who have not taken prior courses in Religion or Chinese studies..
descrip: A thematic introduction to the history of Chinese religion. Topics include cosmology, ancestors, gods, mythology, ethics, shamanism, divination, gender, and mortuary ritual. Readings drawn from a wide range of sources, including sacred scriptures, philosophical texts, popular literature, and modern ethnography.

title: Advanced Finite-element Methods
descrip: The course emphasizes techniques for solving classes of linear and nonlinear elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic and eigenvalue problems encountered in structures and mechanics. It explores implicit, explicit, and implicit-explicit elements and subdomain strategies in transient analysis; stability, consistency, and accuracy of integration procedures; error estimates; approximation properties; and computer implementation. Prerequisite: working knowledge of a scientific computer language.

title: Advanced Arabic I
reviews: Take classes with Professor Hisham--he's amazing!

The 107-301 year course is great because it challenges you to improve on a steeper learning curve but covers everything you would learn otherwise in the 105-107 level without any holes in your background knowledge.
The course is good but the teacher definitely makes a difference. Make sure you see who the teacher is before signing up.
descrip: Designed for students who have a foundation in the Arabic language, including a vocabulary of around 500 words, a grounding in Arabic syntax, the ability to read intricate sentences, the ability to comprehend semi-native spoken conversation, and the ability to produce grammatically-sound sentences in both writing and speech. Course centers around the required textbook and draws from supplementary materials. Focus is on listening and reading comprehension; course emphasizes translation as a method to ensure reading and listening comprehension; emphasis on parsing, morphology, and philology, and desinential inflection.

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop II
reviews: Be prepared to work hard.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 401 or the instructor's permission..
descrip: The course is designed for students who have a working foundation in the Arabic language, a vocabulary set of around 750 words, a fertile understanding of Arabic syntax, and the ability to read and comprehend intricate sentences. The course is structured around the required texts and seeks to expose students to the traditional disciplines of the Arabic language and its classical genres. The course will emphasize translation as a primary method to ensure reading comprehension at every stage, and will place further emphasis on desinential inflection when deciphering sentence structures.

title: Narcocultura: Literature, Theater, Cinema and Music in Latin America, 1990-2012
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or equivalent. Students must be able to understand, read and write in Spanish. The course will be conducted in Spanish but the final may be written in either Spanish or English..
descrip: This course examines literature, music and film from Latin America. It will mainly focus on the recent drug wars that have isolated Latin America as well as the construction of the so called Narcoculture, with special interest in Colombia and Mexico. The course will pay special attention to the political imagination that constructs a new idea of Latin America based on the proliferation of violence and drugs, and the inability of Latin American governments to control the social issues caused by these wars. The course will explore books, TV series, and films.

title: Ocean, Atmosphere, and Climate
reviews: Definitely take it!  The field trip was really fun (even though we all got seasick) but because the class size is so small, you get to know your peers and TAs really well.
Dont let this class be indicative of other geo classes.
Go to all the lectures and start your lab reports early so you have time to ask questions about them.

If you are not a science major, think carefully before taking this course. You will learn a lot of amazing material and have the opportunity to work with MATLAB, but it is very time-consuming, and I did not spend enough time on classes for my major as a result. This is not the class to take if you are looking for an easy fulfillment of a distribution requirement. If you enjoy/ are seeking to enjoy a broad range of sciences and are looking for a challenge and something you probably didn't study in high school,  this is an interesting and doable class and you should definitely consider it.
Come to all the lectures and pay attention the whole time: this will make studying much easier. Start the assignments well ahead of time and work steadily: don't try to be a perfectionist; rather, seek to grasp and present the key concepts.
If you do all of the work and show up for all of the lectures you should do very well in the class.
If you want an interesting lab class where you learn a lot. This is a great one.  Be forewarned that the work picks in the second half of the semester by quite a bit and you cannot PDF the course.
Make sure to attend lectures, because he introduces a lot of equations, etc. that are hard to find elsewhere.
More work than you would expect, but interesting and you should take it if you are genuinely interested in geosciences and learning about ocean/atmosphere dynamics!
Take the course. Labs are a bit shaky but the material at the end is beyond fascinating
prereqs: High School biology, chemistry and calculus..
descrip: An introduction to the ocean, atmosphere, and climate from the perspective of oceanography. Covers coastal processes including waves, beaches, tides and ecosystems; open ocean processes including atmospheric circulation and its impact on the surface ocean, the wind driven circulation, and surface ocean ecosystems; and the abyssal ocean including circulation, the cycling of chemicals, and ocean sediments and what they tell us about the climate history of the earth. The final part of the course will cover humans and the earth system, including a discussion of ocean resources and climate change.

title: Metabolic Engineering
descrip: Introduction to engineering metabolism. The objective of this course is to introduce students to current techniques and challenges within the field of metabolic engineering. Specific topics include introduction to metabolism, transcriptional regulation, signal transduction, flux balance analysis, and metabolic flux analysis.

title: Elementary Hebrew II
prereqs: HEB 101 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of HEB 101 focusing on the structure, the grammar and vocabulary of the Hebrew language. We'll be reading easy texts from Israeli newspapers, from our textbooks. We'll be writing more compositions and be giving presentations about various topics in Hebrew.

title: Agriculture, Food and the Environment
descrip: See website

title: Property: How, Why, and What We Own
descrip: Where does property come from? Is it a right grounded in nature or a human invention? This class will consider these big questions as we look at key moments in the history of property. These will range from the enclosure in modern England to the very modern communist project of building a society without private property. Other episodes will include the reforms of property rights in colonial India and 19th century Japan, the emergence of patent rights and the protection of scientific innovations, the formation of laws on inheritance and the rise of new forms of property, such as ownership of genetic capital, identity, or airspace.

title: The Perception of China and Asia in the West
reviews: An easy, lightly loaded course if you distribute your work evenly.
Definitely take it if you are interested in exploring the concept of Orientalism or if you are interested in histriography. Fascinating course and very rewarding!
Figure out how you are going to pace your papers and follow a guide.
I LOVED IT! Anyone remotely interested in the topic should take this class!

If you are interested in the development of Sino-Western interactions throughout history, this is a great course to take. Professor Elman is a very well-respected and very well-versed scholar in this field, and it was a real treat to be able to take this seminar-like class with him. There's a lot of readings, but most of them are more narrative than textbook-like, so they are often very interesting. You definitely want to pay attention in class, because Professor Elman provides a lot of good insight and perspective on the readings that you might not have otherwise. If you are genuinely interested in Asia's relationship with the West, this course will serve as a very good introduction to that.
If you're deeply interested in the subject matter, go for it.  Otherwise, consider something else.
Prof. Elman is a great lecturer, and the course will indeed change how a Western student perceives Asia.
Some background in EAS (or a lot of time to devote to the course) would probably be helpful, since the material quickly becomes difficult to synthesize and keep track of.
Take it!
descrip: This course has three goals: 1) to present some of the major themes in the Western perception of China since 1250, "from Marco Polo to Chairman Mao", 2) to introduce the student to the nature of history and historical writing, 3) to challenge the student to do some critical historiographical analysis of his/her own. Readings will focus on primary sources in translation and relevant secondary studies.

title: Golem: The Creation of an Artificial Man
descrip: The creation of an artifical human being has been an age-old dream of humankind. Among its ramifications are the robot, the computer and the clone. The seminar will follow the Golem tradition within Judaism throughout history up to its modern offshoots. It will deal with its origin in the Hebrew Bible, its manifestations in mysticism and magic (e.g. the Golem of Prague), in literature, in film and on stage, in art, children books, and the history of science.

title: Design, Craft and Ethical Value
descrip: See website

title: Intermediate Polish
prereqs: PLS105.
descrip: The class will continue to improve students' knowledge of Polish through conversation and review of grammar, and it will enhance their reading skills through the analysis and translation of some Polish poetry and fragments of prose. There will be also short written assignments.

title: International Political Theory
descrip: The seminar will be devoted to the recent literature on various aspects of global justice. The main themes may include global distributive justice (Rawls's The Law of Peoples and subsequent literature); justice and global governance institutions; international legitimacy and democracy; and human rights. Open to undergraduates only with instructor?s permission.

title: Narrative Filmmaking
reviews: Be cautious of this class - it will be a lot of outside work and the actual film assignments will hit you like a train. However, Emily gives a lot of insight into what being in the film world will really be like.
One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton- hands down. An absolute must!
Take it. But be prepared to do a lot of work.
Take it. Do the readings and viewings. Get everything you can out of this class!

Take notes. Listen to the professor. Ask for even more feedback if possible. This professor is great and you should try to get as much from the professor as possible, because I don't think very many professors will be able to offer so much great advice.
The course was in its first run this semester, and rather disorganized. Good excuse to make a short, but not a great class on its own. Take with caution.
descrip: This studio course will be equal parts directing and screenwriting, with a special emphasis on social issue-driven material. Students will learn how to bring a script to life in collaboration with actors, production crews, and their fellow students. The course will also critically examine a selection of powerful narrative films and analyze their different approaches to visual storytelling. Specific topics covered will be: the basic tenets of film direction, writing for the screen, effective ways to work with actors, the post-production process, and how journalistic research methods can inform the early stages of the filmmaking process.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Economics
reviews: Some lectures are actually really informative (or at least interesting), so I would recommend actually going!
Useful.
descrip: This seminar is designed to help graduate students in economics cultivate ethical research practices they may apply in future work at or beyond the University. Students are encouraged to discuss concerns that may arise during the conduct of their research with experienced faculty and devise solutions for dealing with these concerns. The course provides necessary training for newly mandated RCR training for graduate students supported by government grants, and is required for successful completion of the program.

title: Biophysics
reviews:
As graduate-level classes tend to be, the quality and focus of the class will depend very much on exactly which professor is teaching it.

I've heard rumors that Bill Bialek will be teaching the class next year. If so, I've never had a class with him so I can't speak to his efficacy. If Professor Austin is teaching it again, how much you get out of the class depends very much on your scientific personality, how much knowledge you already have, and how much you're willing to read up on your own.

All in all, I'd say the class is a useful one. Especially, many physicists have little knowledge of subfields outside their area of expertise and biology is often looked down upon to some extent. This class is a good way to fill the requirement for all students, whether biophysicists or not, and it's always worth learning more about a field you don't understand.
General background in physics is definitely required for problem sets.
I don't recommend this course.

If there are specific subsets of this course you are interested in, consider taking a course in another department that focuses on that (e.g. there are theoretical evolution courses in EEB, computational neuroscience courses in MOL, etc).
If you haven't taken any biophysics courses before I think it's worth it for the overview it provides, but if you're doing your thesis in the field it may not offer too much you haven't seen before.
Some background might be helpful

Students need a solid mathematics and physics background to take this course, but it would be good for those students interested in biophysics research to get a general idea of how the research is going on in this area.
descrip: The course presents a broader view of biological physics. While the course starts with an overview of the fundamentals of biological physics, using Frauenfelder?s text book as a guide, the course will move on to higher levels of biological systems, using evolution and ecology as our primary organizing principles. The course will have a section on the Physics of Cancer at the end.

title: Hydrology
reviews: If its required, you have to.
If you don't need this course, I wouldn't just randomly take it
It's really helpful to know how to use Matlab or Excel well beforehand. Only take it if you are really interested in Hydrology or else it can get boring.
Most likely you have to take the course, and its not so bad so don't worry.
Start the PSets early - their length is deceiving!
Take if you think you might be interested in water or development.
Take it if you're interested in hydro.
Take this course.
descrip: Analysis of fundamental processes in the hydrologic cycle, including precipitation, evapotranspiration, infiltration, streamflow and groundwater flow.

title: Science and Technology of Nuclear Energy: Fission and Fusion
reviews: As with all technical classes, staying current with material is key. Prof. Goldston is very helpful at office hours. An enriching course for students of all disciplines. However, the title is somewhat deceptive--making the course seem less demanding than it is. The course is very math-heavy and physics-intensive. One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.
Goldston is awesome.  Take this class, but don't expect to understand everything.
Good course, good professor, but it goes rather quickly by the end.

I highly recommend this course to students who want to gain a proper understanding of nuclear energy (both fission and fusion). The class is challenging intellectually but the effort is absolutely worth it. The various topics covered are very interesting, and the link between science, society and security around nuclear energy is very well presented by the Professor.
I would warn them that it gets heavier on the math and physics than they might be expecting based on its crosslistings and advertisement as an interdisciplinary course.

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Gives you the big picture but also goes into enough detail such that you can figure out why some things are true. I think Prof. Goldston should be awarded a teaching prize.
Take the class, you won't regret it.
Take this if you are interested.  The material is inherently hard, but very interesting.

This class is great, and Robert Goldston is really great. He headed PPPL for ten years, and REALLY knows what he's talking about. Despite that, he's amazingly approachable and does a really good job lecturing at an understandable level. I was a senior in physics when I took this, so I didn't think it was overly difficult, having already taken higher-level physics (not that it's required, but it helps to have engaged with physics at a high level). I think this class would be manageable maybe even at the sophomore level.

I'm walking away from this class understanding how nuclear reactors work, and with a good knowledge of fusion research. To me, that's really cool.
prereqs: PHY 101-102 or 103-104 or 107-109, MAT 201 or 203, or EGR 191-194. CBE 246, CHM 306, MAE 221, PHY 301 prior or concurrent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Concern about climate change has driven some to support the growth of nuclear fission power. The events at Fukushima Daichi and the fear of nuclear terrorism have driven others away. New experiments in fusion energy are moving towards the realization of an alternative approach to nuclear power, with fewer dangers but not yet commercializable. In this course we will study the science and technology of both fission and fusion. You will gain a good physical understanding of how both approaches work, including their benefits and risks, through applying and expanding your scientific and mathematical skills.

title: Master of Engineering Independent Project II
descrip: Continuation of MAE 513. Directed study for Master of Engineering students. The topic is proposed by the student and must be approved by the student's research advisor and have received approval from the MAE Graduate Committee.

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: Don't take this course if you don't have a background in one of the other Romance languages (preferably Spanish).

Nicola Cooney is an excellent teacher. She teaches in a systematic and dynamic manner, enabling quick and thorough language learning. I would like to highlight her incredible energy and her ability to encourage students to leave their comfort zone, and actually take risks both when teaching and speaking. As a rather cynical graduate student I approach most lectures with some trepidation and question whether they really are more useful than a textbook / recorded lecture. On the other hand Nicola's lectures were very enjoyably and provided value far beyond what a textbook / recorded lecture offers. I recommend Nicola and her Portuguese class in the strongest possible terms.

Take it!  Professor Cooney is very knowledgeable and helpful about both the Portuguese language and Lusophone culture.  This course will help you gain proficiency very quickly, and give you access to a fascinating new cultural sphere.
Take this if you want to learn portuguese. It is a lot of work.
Take!!! Especially if Cooney is teaching!

This was a great course and a great way to learn a language, and it has the added advantage of only meeting twice a week.  As long as you keep up with the work you will do fine and have a lot of fun as well.
Would highly recommend it.
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
descrip: This seminar is an introduction to contemporary sociological theory from the mid-twentieth century onwards with the work of some earlier theorists included. The seminar is organized around several clusters of enduring questions that have been of principal interest in sociology. Throughout, the emphasis will be on ideas that can guide fruitful empirical research rather than on abstract perspectives.

title: Ottoman Diplomatics: Paleography and Diplomatic Documents
descrip: An introduction to Ottoman paleography and diplomatics. The documents will be in divani and rika scripts.

title: Techniques of Conducting
reviews: If you are at all interested in choral music / conducting 100% take this course. Gabriel is one of the humblest and yet most talented people you could ever have to teach this course.
Just take it. Gabriel is a sensational instructor and during conducting lab you will learn a great deal about how to develop your  techniques, all catered to individual styles. Highly recommended.
Take it! Gabriel is actually the best! You won't regret it!
Take this class! It has done wonders for my conducting!
Take this course if you are at all interested in becoming a better musician, particularly if you are an accompanist and/or singer.

This is a great class for anyone who wants to learn more about conducting or simply become a better musician.  Because of the way it is set up, while the beginning of the course is fairly fundamental, it quickly moves into a space where even conductors with more experience will be able to choose repertoire advanced enough to keep them interested, while less experienced conductors will be able to stay at a level more suited to their abilities.
