Though this class is P/D/F only, do not expect to get away with a light workload, Gabriel expects an enormous amount from every student. That said, this is really excellent and worthwhile class that will stretch your musical abilities in a novel way and give you a great deal of insight into choral singing.
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of instructor. Some background in music theory. Basic keyboard facility. Membership of a faculty-led choral ensemble for the semester in question. Contact Gabriel Crouch to schedule an interview..
descrip: This course will focus on: 1) the development of competency in choral conducting technique, 2) verbal and non-verbal communication in rehearsal, 3) the study of choral repertoire of various styles and genres, emphasizing analysis and interpretation and 4) the development of good rehearsal strategies.

title: Art and Value
reviews: I would definitely take this course. There is a decent amount of reading but nothing beyond what any other seminar would give you. Professors Sitney and Rosen were a surprisingly fantastic team. I enjoyed this course immensely.
I would recommend this course to other students.
Take it! You'll learn a lot from any course you have the privilege of taking with either Prof. Sitney or Prof. Rosen.

This is probably a class where the topic changes every semester. Even so, I would recommend it without reservation to any student interested in the humanities. I didn't come into the class familiar with the topic, or necessarily even interested in it, but I loved the class anyway. The HUM professors are great, the HUM students are great, and the two-professor seminar was a great setup.

This rigorous, interdisciplinary seminar--which incorporated classical and modern philosophy, scholarship on particular genres or works of art, and a diverse collection of art, music, and film--brought art to life. Prof. Rosen and Prof. Sitney are among the most knowledgeable and passionate professors I have had at Princeton. The course has much to offer to students with an interest in the fine arts, philosophy, and literary criticism. For those who have taken the HUM sequence, this is a wonderful opportunity to revisit Plato, Aristotle, Nietzsche etc. in a fresh context.
descrip: What makes good art good? This course will reflect first on the nature of value in the arts -- Is aesthetic value an objective matter? -- and then on various concrete forms of artistic value: the beautiful, the disturbing, the tragic, etc. We will examine works of art, of criticism and of aesthetic theory. Most of the questions we will be addressing are open questions, which we will try to bring into sharper focus.

title: Media and Public Policy
reviews: Great if you're interested in public policy questions related to media. The seminars can feel long because much of the time is spent in lecture, and it can become possible to neglect the readings, unfortunately. But Prof. Starr is passionate about these issues and an expert
Great way to knock out a SOC requirement if you are interested in policy.

I didn't have a general interest in media coming into this course so I think that it made worse for me than it actually is. Prof. Starr is really nice and good at leading seminar--if you like media stuff, take it. If not, maybe go for something different.
If you are interested in media, this course covers a lot of ground and will give you a good historical apparatus to understand what is happening today.
If you're looking to learn about the history of the American media and where it is going, take this class -- you'll learn a lot.

Readings are interesting, Prof. Starr is a great guy, and the seminars did touch on a lot of interesting issues. The course touched on journalism a lot. Two short papers and a final and term paper back to back. The seminar did often feel like a lecture though, as there wasn't as much discussion as you'd expect.
descrip: Introduction to communications policy and law, covering such topics as freedom of the press and the development of journalism; intellectual property; regulation of telecommunications, broadcasting, and cable; and policy challenges raised by the Internet and the globalization of the media.

title: Introductory Painting
reviews: Definitely take if you want a fun LA. Pam is great, and you do a ton of paintings in a short amount of time
Highly recommended but it is a lot of work. A great break from normal school work.
If you like painting, go for this class!! Professor Lins is such a great professor who is very friendly and knowledgeable in arts.
If you like painting, take the class.
It is a very good class, however, it was very time consuming.
Really, really great course. Definitely a plus to have painting experience. Pam is an excellent teacher, and I highly recommend taking it wit her.
Spend some time out of class working on your paintings!
Take it with Pam Lins! She is great.
Take it with Pam!!!!
Take it--but be prepared to spend a lot of time outside of class in the studio. Totally worth it, though!
This class is valuable even if you don't think of you would be a good painter. The class itself is amazing and a break from typical academic work.

This was definitely one of my favorite classes! I've never painted in my life before, and I feel like I learned a lot. However, be prepared to spend a lot of time working outside of class time (~20 hrs per week)
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and interaction with light.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: I would recommend that those students who have not taken a design studio offered by Jesse Reiser should consider working with him. Though, my experience would lead me to suggest that perhaps, due to the manner in which the studio was framed, that Jesse Reiser may be more apt to conducting undergraduate studios or first year graduate studios, not upper level studios as the nature of the design brief provides a very narrow framework fro critical investigation.
Japan trip is amazing!
You really should have your own direction to keep through the semester
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: The Origins of Rome: Livy and Vergil
reviews: Get help if you need it

Good course - Book 4 of the Aeneid is one of my favorite texts and it was interesting to read about the founding of Rome in Livy. Not really more difficult than 105, take it if you are interested in Latin.
If you're into trying to speak another language, you won't find it much here, but if you're into literature and find reading ancient texts appealing go for it
Latin readings can be fairly long, but the class itself is enjoyable and interesting.

Obviously, as part of a sequence, you have to take this class when it's offered, despite the professor. BUT if you happen to have Prof. Baraz be SO GRATEFUL. She is absolutely wonderful and your semester will be a million times better for it. Lucky you!
Take this course!
There is a lot of translation!  Beware!
This course is a great option for the language requirement. I recommend taking the Latin courses if you are interested.
This is a great course to take. If you need the distribution requirement, take it. If you don't need the distribution requirement, still take it. Enjoy the readings, do the work, and you'll be fine.
You're probably taking this course to fulfill a requirement, but take it with Baraz if she offers it and consider further studies in classics.
prereqs: LAT 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will read selections from Livy and Vergil, the masters of prose and poetry respectively in the period of Augustus. Our objectives are: to develop the ability to read Latin with greater ease and enjoyment; to improve sight-reading skills; to experience the artistry of Latin prose and poetry; and to examine some of the questions associated with the Romans' interpretation of their history.

title: Socialist Experiment and Its Legacies, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introductory Seismology
prereqs: PHY 104 and MAE 305 (can be taken concurrently), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Fundamentals of seismology and seismic wave propagation. Introduction to acoustic and elastic wave propagation concepts, observational methods, and inferences that can be drawn from seismic data about the deep planetary structure of the Earth, as well as about the occurrence of oil and gas deposits in the crust. Offered every other year.

title: Energy Storage Systems
prereqs: Knowledge of ODE/PDE.
descrip: This is a survey course on energy storage systems with a focus on electrochemical energy storage. Fundamentals of thermodynamics will be reviewed and fundamentals of electrochemistry introduced. These fundamentals will then be applied to devices such as batteries, flywheels and compressed air storage. Device optimization with respect to energy density, power density, cycle life and capital cost will be considered.

title: Topics in Algebraic Number Theory - Galois Representations
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Number Theory. More specific topic details provided when the course is taught.

title: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Thermodynamics and Kinetics
reviews: Be friends with Kelly (ie meet him all the time you can) and you'll be fine.

Course is setup well, with 4 tests of equal weight and the final not being cumulative. In fact, everything about the course - the lectures, homework, precepts - was good except the fact that we had to do biweekly (twice a week) chapter readings, summarize these readings in 1/2 to 1 page, pose a question that we had, and submit before the lecture for that chapter.

Go to office hours. Professor kelly is very helpful and he really cares about his students. Don't by shy if you are struggling. He will help you out. If you are a chemistry major, I would definitely take it. It is information you should definitely learn because it will help you understand a lot more about chemisty.
I don't know why some of the other reviews say this course doesn't need math. Either way, the book sucks, but Professor Kelly is a great teacher.

I would recommend it tentatively. It wasn't bad, and it's better than 305 from what I hear. Some of the problem sets can take a very long time, and the textbook is pretty bad. The lectures are alright, but I think the best place to learn is in precepts and at office hours.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in gaining a better understanding of thermodynamics in general, and more specifically about chemical reactions and heat flow. Dr. Kelly is a great lecturer and is very open to answering questions.

If you are interested in thermodynamics, this class is a good, overall introduction without going into too complicated math. The most difficult math required is differential and integral calculus, and you will not be expected to know how to do much else. Take it if you're interested.

If you want to do well in this course do these things at least 3-4 days before an exam. 

1) Go through the book and write down all the important equations on your cheat sheet.
2) Do all the problem sets again (or know how to do the problems) using only your cheat sheet
3) Go through all the conceptual questions in the book and make sure you understand them. 

I felt this course was very worth it, but challenging. It is also a huge time suck.
Prof. Kelly is the sweetest professor ever.  Go to office hours and get to know him- he tries his best to help.
Take it if you need a thermodynamics course. But definitely do not expect to get a good grade.
Take it. If you are a chem major you have to take it anyways so take it a bit early when you still remember AP or gen chem.
This course has a lot of problem sets, reading assignments, and exams, but in the end you will learn a lot about chemistry.
This course requires a lot of work; the material is not all that difficult, but Michael Kelly is an excellent professor and you will learn a ton from him.
This was a good course. Leaned a lot and it was much better than the CBE thermo class.
You'll probably only take this course if you're a chemistry major or it's required or you're interested in the material, but Professor Kelly is really good and the course is very well organized.
probably don't take it unless you are trying to become a physical chemist (then consider the 400 level class instead)
take this class if you love thermodynamics as much as i do
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 and MAT 104, or CHM 215, or permission of instructor. Course is open to freshmen who have completed CHM 215..
descrip: At the center of this course is the recognition of Gibbs Free Energy as a fundamental quantity describing physical processes. From this, we will develop concepts of thermodynamics and kinetics, and illustrate them with examples from chemistry.

title: Legal and Business Spanish
reviews: Definitely take this course. I took Spanish 207 before this and found that it was the right level to challenge me, but also make me feel comfortable in this class. It was more interesting because there is less of a focus on basic grammar and more of a focus on understanding the business and legal world.
If you're interested in expanding your Spanish vocab to legal and business related themes, then take it. The teacher's great, and it's a chill class - it's what you make of it.
Take it.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission); or SPA 108; or SPA 207.
descrip: An advanced level Spanish course on legal and business language. The aim is to provide students with a new vocabulary for classroom discussions, readings and practice in a guided legal and business-related context. This course enables a deeper understanding of grammatical concepts previously presented as well as the syntactical and lexical challenges typical of this specific area of the Spanish language. Students will also be introduced to the basics of a completely different legal system and different business cultures, through texts, discussions, research, translation practice, situational case studies, and videos.

title: Topics in Social Theory and East Asia
descrip: An introduction to classical social theory of modernity and an exploration of new directions in social theory in contemporary social science. Course examines the ways in which Western scholarship on East Asia has engaged with theories of modernity, at times generating new bodies of thought on social exchange, capitalism, feminism, the state and civil society, and agency and subjectivity. Texts on Japan, China, and elsewhere, moving between theoretical, ethnographic, and historical contexts, are used.

title: Special Topics in the Study of Religion - Religion and Immigration in America
descrip: Immigration is one of the major themes in American History. Except for a few classic (and outdated) works, the religious aspects of immigration have not received the attention they deserve in the study of American religion or in the study of immigration. This class focuses on immigrant religion as "map of meaning," marker of identity, site of trans-locative piety, resource for social mobility, network of transnational activity, arbiter of civic participation, and challenge to national ideals of religious pluralism.

title: Solid-State Physics II
prereqs: ELE 441 or PHY 405.
descrip: Electronic structure of solids. Electron dynamics and transport. Semiconductors and impurity states. Surfaces. Dielectric properties of insulators. Electron-electron, electron-phonon, and phonon-phonon interactions. Anharmonic effects in crystals. Magnetism. Superconductivity.

title: Topics in the French Middle Ages and Renaissance - Censorship, Controversy and Literary Debate in the Middle Ages
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level French course or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course explores medieval and early Renaissance texts that generated controversy, resistance and debate. We will read the texts in question as well as responses from readers, other authors, and institutions (church, university). We will also look at how practices such as selective translation and rewriting as a form of critique contributed to the dynamic literary traditions of this period. Finally, we will consider how fictional representations of such practices and debates reflect upon the social and intellectual life of literature.

title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Modern Electrochemistry
reviews: If electrochemistry interests you in the slightest, take this class, as Bocarsly and VanderKam are excellent teachers and you really understand why it is important and useful in science.
descrip: This course explores the theory and practice of modern techniques in electrochemistry. Physical chemistry of charge transfer is considered, as well as applications in the areas of electroanalytical chemistry and photoelectrochemistry. Key laboratory techniques, such as cyclic voltammetry, chronoamperometry and rotating disk voltammetry are a focus of the course.

title: Hellenistic Art
descrip: Survey of the transformations in Greek art beginning with the decline of the Classical period (fifth century BCE) and continuing through the period of Alexander the Great's unification of the Mediterranean world, up to and including the Roman conquest of the east. Emphasis on sculpture, painting, and mosaic.

title: European Intellectual History
reviews: Great for intellectual historians; if you aren't familiar with the field be prepared to do a little outside reading and ask contextual questions at first, but the course is well worth it.
It is not a class that aims at a coverage of EIH nor is it a ready made survey of the field but asks for independent engagement with the texts and topics.
None.
descrip: This seminar will provide an introduction to recent theoretical debates and methodological approaches to 20th Century European intellectual and cultural history. Its central focus will be on the legacy of Marx, Nietzsche, and Weber for the debates on "enlightenment" and "counter-enlightenment" during the first half of the century. Among the thinkers we will be examining are: T.W. Adorno, Hannah Arendt, Walter Benjamin, Michel Foucault, Martin Heidegger, Georg Lukacs, and Carl Schmitt.

title: Attitudes, Identities, and Social Interaction
descrip: A course on the linkages between social context, on the one side, and individuals' values, beliefs, and behavior, on the other, touching on conformity, prejudice, social influence, identity, emotions, attraction, and status. The course will also touch on recent psychological studies about happiness, and research on the impact of genetics on attitudes and other sociologically relevant life outcomes.

title: Special Topics in Environmental Engineering and Water Resources - Stochastic Hydrology
reviews: Be proactive about all of the assignments and make sure that you take the time for each one as they are the best way to learn the material.
This class is an excellent introduction to statistics for hydrology. It is very helpful if you  plan to use statistical methods and models in your research.
prereqs: Basic background in probability and statistics. Computer programming skills. MATLAB Skills or better..
descrip: Use of probability and statistics for hydrologic mideling and analysis. This methods- based course will include: probability models, including the L- Moment parameter estimation method; estimating bivariate distributions using copulas, time series analysis, spatial data analysis using kriging, as well as principle components ( empirical orthogonal functions, EOF), Monte Carlo simulation and hydrologic forecasting. The course will involve readings from the stochastic hydrology literature and hands on computer analysis and simulation.

title: Rebellion and Recognition
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Attic Vase-Painting: Style, Subject and Social Context
prereqs: A course in ancient art or instructor's permission..
descrip: Attic black-figure and red-figure vases constitute the largest surviving body of Greek pictorial imagery. Diverse in shape, style, and subject, they provide a window on Athenian society, but one distorted by the temporal and spiritual estrangement of modern interpreters. This class explores a range of issues in Attic vase-painting, with particular emphasis on black-figure pottery, ca. 630 - 480 B.C. Meeting in the Art Museum, students handle actual ancient vases in a context of guided discussion and shared insights.

title: Electronic Circuits for Biomedical Application
reviews: As long as Verma is teaching, this course is certainly worth your time.  He's got an amazing knack for breaking even the most incomprehensible topics down into tidbits that even the most junior electrical engineer can understand and appreciate.  The course does take some time and effort, and lectures really can't be skipped, but all in all its worth the journey and I would take it again were I able to go back.

BEST engineering course I have taken. Did a wonderful job of tying all kinds of EE principles together into tangible, useful concepts. 

Verma is the gold standard for a lecture (not just engineering!). He writes on the board, has very few PP slides and really engages with the students. This is a MUST TAKE course.
Good class for ELE majors to take as a departmental.
I would strongly recommend this class for people interested in circuit design.

There's a lot of material, it moves quickly, and Verma expects you to keep up. I think it's one of the most difficult classes I've taken in Princeton ELE, but Verma is also a great lecturer and makes class interesting and engaging. Would recommend if you can afford the time commitment.
This course relies heavily on MOSFET basics.  It's useful to come in with a background in this because otherwise it's hard to keep up and easy to get lost.
Verma is a good teacher. His problem sets and exams are very tough and he is a tough grader. The textbooks aren't very helpful, so you must go to lecture.
work hard
prereqs: ELE 203, ELE 208, ELE341 (recommended, exceptions by instructor's permission).
descrip: Start by analyzing biological systems to understand the origins of some of the signals that they present. Develop circuit models of these systems to determine what instrumentation circuits are required at the interface so that the signals can be reliably acquired. Study analog circuit topologies based on MOSFETs for low-noise instrumentation and processing of the signals. Study digital topologies based on MOSFETs for extensive computations on the biological signals. Analyze the trade-offs between the analog and digital topologies. Emphasis is on design and analysis using circuit simulators.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: Definitely look forward to taking a class with White.
Definitely take it! Great senior course!

Definitely take this course. It's automatic PDF. You will definitely grow as a writer and get helpful criticism to improve your work! It's a lot of fun and you get to read really fun, awesome work by others. Some of our peers are very talented writers!
Don't miss out. Take it. With A.M. Homes.

Easily one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Only do it if you really like writing / have ideas on what you want to write about, but it was AMAZING. Every class was like a study break for me, where I could escape into the imaginary world of writers!
Enjoy it! Do all of the work and come prepared and the rest will follow.

Fiction is hard, and creative writing classes at Princeton should be taken seriously. That said, if you're interested in improving your writing and working with successful, incredibly talented writers, then a creative writing class is a must.
Fiona is an excellent teacher and this course is definitely a lot of fun.
Great course for creative writers
I highly recommend this class. A. M. Homes is terrific: interesting, funny, knowledgeable, and very helpful with her feedback.

I strongly recommend this course to every Princeton student, regardless of writing ability or past writing experience. It was one of my favorite classes at Princeton and one of the few times I actually enjoyed doing the work.

I was really looking forward to taking this course, but it was somewhat of a letdown. I love A.M. Homes as a person and think that she is wonderfully quirky, but she is just too laid-back. If you really want to challenge yourself and your writing, consider taking a CWR class with someone else. However, if you are looking for a relaxed and low-pressure 4th/5th class, then look no further!

I would recommend that you deeply engage in class discussions, the weekly exercises, and the written material, because it makes the class very engaging and fun. It also helps come time to write your own pieces, as you will feel confident in the techniques and styles you have learned.
I would say don't be afraid to take risks because it's certainly an open and forgiving environment to do so.
I would take Fiona Maazel's class if you want to improve your overall writing--not just fiction, work hard, and aren't afraid of criticism.
If you think you might enjoy a creative writing course, take it.
If you're interested in fiction writing, I'd certainly recommend it.
If you're looking for a light, interesting class, take it.
It's a great course, but stay disciplined about writing, or you'll take too much advantage of the PDF-only.
Leave yourself time to do a revision before you turn your story in.
Professor matters a lot for the CWR classes.
Relish it.. it's such a treat to talk about writing every week. Chang-rae Lee is a great guy.
Spend time on each draft and read the given texts carefully. You will strongly improve your writing skills
TAKE IT
TAKE IT with Lee, Oates, Eugenides. Such a wonderful class.
Take a creative writing class! A.M. Homes is the best, and you can learn a lot from her.
Take creative writing. Edmund White is a great professor and the class is very relaxing.

Take creative writing. The experience will be as much as you put into it, so don't waste your time or anyone else's. Also, don't worry if you don't get into a section with a famous professor. All the classes I have taken have been excellent, and none of them have been the hugest names on the list.
Take it!
Take it!  You'll learn a ton and have a lot of fun in a low pressure situation while you're at it!
Take it! It improves your writing and reading skills.
Take it! You will have lots of fun and it will be something to look forward to every week.
Take it!!!! Your writing will improve, it's not too much work if you're enjoying yourself in the class!
Take it--you get a whole new appreciation for stories.
Take it.
Take it. Apply. And if you get in, then don't be afraid to reach out and jump. You might be surprised where you land. If you land.
Take the class.
Take the time to polish your piece before class

Take this course with AM. She is relaxed, realizes it is a P/F class, and wants you to merely get an exposure to creative writing. She also does a great job of playing therapist to seniors going through thesis struggles!

Take this course!
Also, don't write your short story on the last day. Revising your story over and over will make it improve astronomically. Also, LISTEN TO YOUR PEER RESPONSES. You'd be surprised at how perceptive your classmates are.
This course is what you make of it! I really enjoyed it.

White is an extremely interesting man and while I'd love to just sit with him and hear about his life, he is not a great teacher. You do not get much feedback on your work and the critiques are not very helpful.
take it
take it.
take!!!
prereqs: Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Mathematical Analysis of Massive Data Sets
prereqs: Introductory to Real Analysis (MAT 314/320) or Integration Theory and Hilbert Spaces (MAT 332).
descrip: This course focuses on spectral methods useful in the analysis of big data sets. Spectral methods involve the construction of matrices (or linear operators) directly from the data and the computation of a few leading eigenvectors and eigenvalues for information extraction. Examples include the singular value decomposition and the closely related principal component analysis; the PageRank algorithm of Google for ranking web sites; and spectral clustering methods that use eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian.

title: Theory of Knowledge
descrip: An examination of select issues in the Theory of Knowledge.

title: Visions of Transformation: Religious and Secular
reviews: A thought provoking combination of films, supplementary text, and stand alone writing ranging from Emerson to Geertz. The class is thoughtfully prepared by Prof Stout, who keeps such a diverse set of material grounded by offering coherent insights and analysis. It thus requires an equally thoughtful approach that links different perspectives and disciplines to appreciate more abstract theory with creative film (for example, the Dorsky is obtuse but amazing). The class is best if one has free time to watch the films- screenings are great- and spend time reflecting on lecture and readings. A lot of academic and general life questions: what is the world we live in, and how do we find a place in it? Worthwhile especially for the outgoing humanities senior who doesn't know what direction his life will take.
A very interesting course, but be careful with which precept you choose.

Anyone who has even a passing curiosity in the big questions of life--what is our purpose, what is "the good life"--will find the different answers proposed by the various thinkers (and the films presented in the course) intriguing and perhaps more affecting than they ever could have been when limited to the confines of a book.
Do the work! Be excited to engage with the material and you will learn a lot.
Go to lectures when you can. They are useful, and somewhat interesting. They may not be crucial, but there is no textbook for the course or movies and you do learn quite a bit.

I think this is a great course, even for non-religion majors. Prof. Stout is an excellent lecturer, and the films are really interesting. I also feel much more prepared for film classes that I might take in the future.

It's too much work if you need an EC. Stout always goes over time and is extremely strict about going to lecture. He is also rude and unhelpful. The movies are LONG and never in english and always confusing.
Jeffery Stout is an amazing teacher, and this course is the perfect introduction to religious theory and film. If you're interested in either of those topics, take this course without a doubt.

Lectures, precepts, and film screenings are all mandatory.  If you don't like attending lecture, you should probably not take this class.  However, I really enjoyed the course and strongly recommend it.
Only take if you are very interested in philosophy or it is required.
TAKE IT! THIS CLASS CHANGED MY LIFE
TAKE IT. You will learn a lot!
TAKE THIS COURSE. Princeton is about challenging yourself, and this is a course that will push you to interrogate your beliefs, and think about the world differently.

Take it if you're interested in the history of religion. Film does take a prominent role in the course but if you're looking for a course on film theory, there isn't much. Professor Stout is also an incredible and animated lecture.
Take it if you're into old, meaning-filled film.
Take it only if you want to know more about religion and film, but it is not necessary.
Take it twice.

Take this class and make time to do it the way it should be done. If you're antsy sitting through films or unwilling to read a text deeply, you won't do well and you also won't enjoy it. If you do have the resources to engage fully with what is happening, it is really an amazing course that will challenge a lot of what you think is true and open your eyes to new ways of experiencing the world.

Take this class. If you like film, or philosophy, or discussing things, or thinking about religion's social implications, or you enjoy listening to an incredibly intelligent Prof. Stout explain philosophy and film in a comprehensible and fascinating way - take this class.

Take this course. Really engage with this material because the questions it addresses are important to society. You should explore your opinions about "how should I/we live" and understand the differing (sometimes contrasting) views about the answer to these questions.

This course is not meant to be easy or straightforward, but one that really prods students to think about the films and readings as conveying messages about transformations that can't just be revealed on a superficial level.  It requires a lot of unpacking, but it's a rewarding course that I think students of all disciplines would really enjoy.  As someone who isn't particularly interested film, I found myself looking at films as being more than pure entertainment and more as vehicles to explain the complexities of human nature.
This is a must take course. One of the best

This is an incredible course for anyone interested in art, religion, film, philosophy or intellectual history. The breadth covered is astounding, but the course also offers opportunities to delve into topics that excite each student with additional recommended readings and freedom of topic choice on the two papers. Professor Stout is a really gifted lecturer and teacher, and his efforts to make this course both challenging and accessible to all are incredibly effective.

What you get out of this course really depends on who you are and what kind of class environment you like. If you're generally interested in the topics and don't mind a course that is a little introductory, but still time-consuming, I would definitely recommend it.
Work hard, take it seriously, and go to lecture!
Would note that at time, the work for this class seems like twice that of a seminar.
prereqs: Required for Religion Department majors..
descrip: An examination of thinkers (e.g. Pascal, Marx, Freud) and filmmakers (e.g. Hitchcock, Kurosawa, Friedrich) who distinguish between a way of life they regard as sinful, oppressive, and/or deluded and a process of change in which the alleged defects are overcome. An introduction to modern debates over religion and to film as a vehicle for social criticism.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Psychology and Public Policy for MPPs
descrip: A half-term course designed for MPP's to cover basic concepts and findings from psychology and their application in policy development. Topics include bounded rationality, group dynamics, conflict, judgment and decision making biases, behavioral economics, public opinion, social determinants of behavior, attitudes, and a psychological perspective on incentive structures, all of which have implications for the design of policies that affect individual citizens as well as for the functioning of organizations that determine policy.

title: Topics in Legal Thought and Legal Practice
reviews: Don't be afraid to ask questions about the readings. If you did not understand the reading, chances are no one else did either.
I would strongly consider taking it.

If your work intersects with legal scholarship in any way (and it probably does), this course is worth your while. If you're planning on going to law school or have already done so, it's a no-brainer. Take it!
Take anything Professor Hartog offers.
Take it! The material is essential to understanding the history of legal thought, and Professor Hartog is fascinating.
descrip: Seminar surveys historically significant schools of American legal thought, along the way questioning the notion of distinctive schools, as well as the distinctive legality and the distinctive Americanness of the thought. It offers an intellectual history of main themes in modern American legalism, with an emphasis on core controversies. Students will also find that the readings introduce a variety of methodologies and approaches used by historians and others who study issues of legality and law.

title: Ballet as an Evolving Form: Technique and Repertory
reviews: Definitely do it. There's really no reason not to. You get three ballet classes a week with great guest artists and Tina runs the course fantastically.

Definitely take if your technique is past a certain point of sophistication and you are ready to take on the challenge of recognized guest choreographers. This class would be very difficult without a pre-professional ballet background.
I would advise them to review the choreography on their own time throughout the semester.
If you are interested in ballet and learning choreography, definitely take this course.
If you've trained in ballet, you will definitely love this course.
Take it!
Take it!  Tina's amazing, as are the other teachers that are brought in.  Even if you're not a bunhead, this is still a fantastic course to take.
Take it.
prereqs: Application by interview/audition only. Please email instructor (fehlandt@) for appointment..
descrip: A studio course in contemporary ballet technique for advanced students. The course will consist of an advanced ballet class and explorations into contemporary choreography through readings, viewings, and the learning of repertory. The course will focus on three modern-day choreographers: James Kudelka, Alexei Ratmansky, William Forsythe. Students will be coached by three prominent guest artists: Sylvain Lafortune, Jeffrey Edwards, Helen Pickett.

title: Genes, Brain, and the Human Mind
reviews: Have a strong background in genetics and neuroscience! It's a great discussion course, so be prepared to ask questions and participate to make it a wonderful experience for everyone.
Highly recommended, a great way to start your day and for science majors, an interesting way to look at science differently.
I would definitely recommend other students to take this course.

I would definitely recommend taking this course if you are at all interested in genetics and/or the brain. The readings are very interesting and Professor Rosenberg and Professor Wang do a great job facilitating discussion and posing thought-provoking questions.

I would recommend this course because the subject matter is so interesting, and both Profesor Wang and Professor Rosenberg are great.  I learned so much in this course.  However, the course's organization is poor: there are daily quizzes, student presentations take up the entire class, there is a lack of guidance for written assignments.

If you're at all interested in the topics from the course review, take it. Professors Rosenberg and Wang offer two great points of view on neuropsychiatric disorders, their underlying etiology, and issues of research, diagnosis, and treatment. Their perspectives are often complementary, although at times they differ in opinion for a certain condition--and that's the dialogue that this field is built upon. The papers--a short op-ed written for a lay audience and a longer, review-like research paper--are tough but rewarding.
In order to take this class, you definitely need to be a morning person.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton. The topics were really engaging and relevant to the real world, which led to interesting class discussions. The 8:30 am time can a bit rough at times though.
Prof Wang and Prof Rosenberg are both super smart and although excelling in the course was tough the candid interactions with them are worth it.
This is a great course! Take it!
you have to be ready to participate a lot at 830 in the morning- think about that before signing up!
prereqs: Admission to this course requires a brief application. Preference will be given to students who have taken one genetics course (e.g. MOL101, 205, 214, 215 or 342) and one neuroscience course (e.g. NEU101 or 258 or PSY 208)..
descrip: How did the human brain become the most complex organ in the animal kingdom? How do genetic and environmental forces produce its capabilities and maladies? These questions have fascinated philosophers, humanists, physicians, and scientists for millennia and will be the focus of this course. The course will use human genetics and systems neuroscience to analyze topics including autism, Alzheimer disease, bipolar disorder and drug addiction. Class time will emphasize lectures, discussion, and student-generated presentations. The goal is to reach a modern understanding of how the human brain works and sometimes fails.

title: La Serenissima: Music, Culture, and Society in Early Modern Venice
prereqs: Previous music study useful, but not required.
descrip: In this course we will consider music, art, and society in sixteenth and seventeenth Venice. Long lauded for her singular beauty, the pleasures of her famous carnival, and the many freedoms offered by her unique republican government, Venice's rich culture was also shaped by her enviable position as a crossroads between east and west and enriched by contributions of architects, artists, and musicians such as Palladio, Titian, Monteverdi, and Vivaldi. Topics include: civic and religious ritual, courtesans and carnival culture, Venetian academies and female singers, public opera, and the female musicians at the ospedali (orphanges).

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics

title: Princeton Atelier - How to Write a Song
reviews: DO IT!
Excellent, excellent.  Make sure to get out of your comfort zone early on, because by the second half, if you haven't, you'll be contributing in what you are strong in anyway.
Its a really fun class!  You can learn a lot and get great feedback on your songwriting.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT!!!!!
Take it if you are a musician or songwriter of any level of experience. It's loads of fun!

Take this class. It will bring you together with musicians and songwriters you may never have worked with before, perhaps forge a few friendships, and give you access to one of the nicest and most brilliant poets in the world. It's what Princeton's all about.
Take this course, or any course with Paul.  He is an extremely thoughtful, intelligent professor who will help you learn about anything.
Take this course, you won't regret it!
This is a fantastic opportunity. I'd highly recommend taking it. Don't miss out on a workshop where you get to collaborate with other students and write a new song every week.
take it!
take this class! maybe this is too much to stay but it restored my belief that there are original creative thinkers at princeton that are willing to take academic and artistic risks.
prereqs: The course should appeal to composers, musicians, poets, novelists, mathematicians, andthropologists and, especially, structural engineers. Application required. Interviews, auditions and portfolios may be required. For more information consult the Princeton Atelier webpage at princeton.edu/arts/..
descrip: Poet Paul Muldoon and songwriter John Wesley Harding (who also writes under the name, Wesley Stace), will lead a course on lyrics and songwriting. Muldoon and Stace will be writing songs on these themes, encouraging students to explore their own emotional cores in what might be described as "parallel play." Various illuminati from the world of song will visit to help out with their hard won and practical advice.

title: Luso-Brazilian Seminar - Around the Margin
descrip: Levi-Strauss used to say that he hated traveling. Yet, traveling made him more aware of his own point of departure. The aim of this seminar is to explore different accounts of displacement, thus asking how writers deal with liminal spaces, and how margins make them step in new narrative forms. Through the analysis of fiction and travel books, we will look for those moments when, in Ricardo Piglia's words, "what we can imagine always exists in another scale, in another time, clear and far from us, like a dream".

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to WWS concentrators and certificate students. The course is required for concentrators, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. Junior concentrators are automatically signed up for the policy seminar as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 402. WWS juniors who are certificate students must enroll. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy seminars students work in groups first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: Land Use Policy and Planning
descrip: Examines theory and practice of land use policy and planning in the US. Explores concepts of sprawl and smart growth, then examines land use plan making, law, and regulation. Analyzes land use programs and issues at diverse levels of government, including state smart growth programs, regional agencies, fair share and inclusionary housing programs, open space conservation, and big city planning and redevelopment. Also analyzes the roles and interactions of executive agencies, courts, experts, advocates, property owners, profit-oriented and nonprofit developers, and citizens in land use issues.

title: Modern Quantum Devices: Physics and Applications
descrip: This is an entry level graduate course concentrated on physical foundations of modern quantum electronic devices that have sprung up in the last decade and will become the mainstay of electronic and photonic systems. Understanding of functionality of these devices calls for a deeper comprehension of the underlying quantum theories. Examples of the topics covered: nano-lasers, plasmonics, graphene electronics and micromechanics, single electron transistors, and other topics selected by the students. The course will include students' presentations on topics of their choice.

title: Turkish Literature in Translation: From Omer Seyfettin to Orhan Pamuk
reviews: If you're really interested in Turkish culture/literature, take the course; otherwise it might get boring after a few weeks.
TAKE IT!  Very relaxed and you get to meet some of the authors of the stories that you read on Skype.
Take it if you're interested in Turkey, or even just short stories in general!
descrip: This course introduces a concise look on modern Turkish literature predominantly through short stories. It aims to provide a sample of Turkish literary writing and basic knowledge of its actors and works. The reading list is naturally shaped by the limited number of English translations available, nevertheless it will offer a colorful picture of diverse authors, their works, literary themes and styles, as well as social, political and cultural issues in Turkey during the last century.

title: Topics in Modern Astronomy
reviews: AST 204 is a really great survey of astrophysics for non-physics majors.  If you're a physics/astro major, take this as an easy but interesting 5th class.
Don't take it unless you really want to learn about stars.
Go to class or get notes when you miss it.
Good general overview of astro
I loved this class. Great for science students looking for an introduction to astrophysics.

I would highly recommend taking this course if you are at all interested in Astrophysics! This course however does require work particularly with the problem sets, so I would highly recommend taking advantage of the office hours!

I would highly recommend this course if you are interested in Astrophysics and have some math/physics experience.  It was a really cool class, it wasn't too difficult, and I learned a lot.  I wouldn't recommend it if you are only interested in a very mathy or physicsy course, but I had a lot of fun.
I would recommend this course.  It is a fair amount of work for an introductory level course, however it is not unreasonably so and it was very interesting.

If you are coming to this course from a very rigorously abstract or technical background, expect it to be easy; if you are coming from the softer side such as humanities, you'll need to work a bit but not too much.
If you are interested in astrophysics, I suggest taking this course. It is very helpful to have friends taking it with you.
It is good! Feel free if you are interested in the universe
Read the suggested chapters and really utilize office hours to understand the problem sets.

Take this class if you want a more quantitative version of 203.  While during my year it was a little disjointed, I expect it to get better in the future now that they have had time to work out the kinks.
The course covers some really interesting material and is not a lot of work. Office hours with the TA's is very helpful. I didn't go until the last p-set, but I wish I had gone sooner.
This is basically an astro course for astro majors.  Unless you're an astro major, don't take it if you're not willing to spend the entire semester playing catch-up.
You need to go to lecture and read the book in order to do well. Interesting subject matter at times, but the course is probably better for AST concentrators than for general interest.

if you already like astronomy, go for it.  if you're looking just to get a taste of astro and you have physics background, you might still enjoy it, particularly with a good prof.
if you're just looking for an stn, look elsewhere.
prereqs: PHY 103 or 105 and MAT 103 or 104 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course will provide a broad overview to modern astronomy and astrophysics for students in the sciences. Topics include historical developments; the birth, life, and death of stars; supernovae, neutron stars and black holes; the formation, structure, and evolution of galaxies; the large-scale structure of the universe; dark-matter and dark-energy; the expanding universe; cosmology; and the evolution of the universe from the Big-Bang 13.7 billion years ago to today.

title: Literature and Society in Early Latin America
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission..
descrip: For a long time, Early Latin American History has been studied from colonial, national or Eurocentric points of view. This course will introduce the students to other insights, connected to contemporary debates and questions. We shall travel through the societies and cultures covered by the Iberian empires in order to define the modalities of Iberian Globalization. Special importance will be given to the processes of mestizaje as a crucial to this globalization. We will analyze the historical links between America, Islam, China and Christian Europe in order to open up the study of the New World to its real global context.

title: Religion in American Society
reviews: Definitely take this!
Do take this class - you will leave it with a broad understanding of the craziness that is America's religious history, and Prof. Weisenfeld is great.
Do the readings and attend lectures. They are interesting!
Don't take if Judith Weisenfeld is teaching. If she isn't, take it! Fascinating topic!
Easy course to PDF, or probably to take for a grade as well.  There are courses with less reading, but the readings are all easy.  Not a bad choice.

I would definitely encourage students to take this course.  Religion is often seen as something that's divisive, but that mostly stems from misunderstanding the basic tenets of a particular religion that inevitably leads the uninformed to categorize it as threatening to American values.  The course really helps students to think about how religion transforms America in a positive manner and how our society tries to define or put limitations on religion.
I would definitely recommend this course! all of the material is super interesting and there isn't too much work

If (like me) you think SA's are the most boring classes ever, then take this class! As long as you're with Professor Weisenfeld, you'll get a really good overview of many American religions - both the mainstream and the fringe ones. The exams are both easy if you go to lecture and take notes.

Make sure you at least read the intro, conclusion, and a couple of chapters from each book. You really don't have to read the entire thing. That can be really hard to fit in to your schedule, but if you want to that's great.
Take good lecture notes; they'll be invaluable. Try to get into Professor Weisenfeld's precept.
Take if you're interested in religious movements in America. Not too much work, lectures interesting.
Take it. It will spark your interest.
Take this course.  It is not too much work, and it was helpful for explaining certain trends in American history and religion that are relevant to today's world.
This is a really good overview of religions and would recommend to anyone with a general interest for the topic!
You have to take this class. One of my favorites at Princeton.
take it its fun
descrip: This course explores the dynamics of religion in contemporary America. We consider such themes as religious encounter and conflict; patterns of tradition and change; the relation of religion to broader political currents and debates (including race, sexuality, gender, science, economics); "secular" spiritualties, the challenges of religious pluralism; and religion and popular culture.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The objective of this course is to study the essential techniques of pricing financial derivatives. These techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), binomial tree method and risk-neutral valuation method. We will also discuss extensively trading strategies, associated financial derivatives for different purposes, and potential problems that can arise in the application of financial derivatives. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and Excel spreadsheet programming.

title: Seminar in Academic Writing
descrip: A seminar designed to examine and cultivate scholarly writing. We will consider examples from the historical and analytical writing about music and related disciplines, including more traditional and more experimental models. Students will critique one another's papers and dissertation chapters, focusing on form, content, methodologies, and analytical strategies, and will have the opportunity to present work in progress. Recommended for post-generals students in both composition and musicology.

title: Readings in Classical Japanese
prereqs: JPN 403 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Selections from outstanding works of Classical Japanese prose and verse from Nara to early Showa period, particularly in the genres of history, philosophy, and poetry.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced Italian
reviews: Definitely take this class if you are looking for a more rigorous immersion into Italian.

Definitely take this course! If you seek to improve your Italian, this will do it. The reading, writing, and speaking exercises are fun and work to your advantage. The professors, all of them, are phenomenal- you really can't go wrong with taking this Italian course.
Do all of the reading and speak as much as possible during class.
I would absolutely recommend taking it.  It is 2 credits, but still the work for 1 class.  The professor rules, and you'll learn Italian while having fun.
I would highly recommend this language for students looking for an accelerated language program. The workload is very manageable, and you learn a lot in a short period of time.
I would take this course, because the professor is wonderful at teaching the material. Also, this course is a lot of fun and very helpful in learning Italian.
Learn the expressions well.
Take it!

Take this class. If Prof. Spinazzi is teaching it, you're guaranteed to have a blast. It's more work than 101, but it's by no means close to overwhelming, and if you pay attention in class, you'll never be stuck with more than 1 hour of homework a day. Don't shy away from the challenge of 1027 because it counts as two courses. As Nike says, just do it.
prereqs: ITA 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Italian 102-7 is an intensive double credit course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Reading comprehension and oral proficiency as well as reading skills and grammatical accuracy will be developed through various activities. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be familiarized with various cultural aspects of Italy through readings, cultural videos, and films.

title: Advanced Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: A pretty good balance between computation and proofs. More interesting than 202, not as involved as 217. Good middle ground in my opinion. But only take it if you like/are good at working on proofs.
Be prepared!!! The course literally got more difficult every week. That being said, you will learn a ton of linear algebra as well as some really interesting applications.
Definitely take 204 over 202, especially if you are coming from 203. 203 more than prepares you for 204, and it will be very engaging.
Depends on professors. Work load is not too much but still a lot compared to lower level math courses if you haven't taken linear algebra before.

Don't take the course if you are more interested in theory of linear algebra. This course is very heavy on application and computation. The prove-based questions are quite easy. Take 217 if you like theories.
Good course, worth taking if you're doing any sort of scientific or engineering courses.

If you don't want to just memorize concepts and formulas, take this over MAT 202. I can't comment on how this course compares to MAT 217, but it definitely was more interesting and rewarding than MAT 202. But run away if MAT 201, for example, was plenty challenging for you, if you don't like proving things, or you don't have experience with doing math, because the course definitely assumed prior formal mathematical experience.

If you took 203 and liked it definitely take this course. There are more proofs but it was computationally much easier. Having seen some work from 202, I think 204 is actually computationally easier than 202. The problem sets are useful but are graded harshly.
It is a good course and you can follow the classes easily. The problem sets are not so hard, but they do take some time to finish.
Make sure you understand all the theorems well before each test.  Tests often tested understanding more than computational ability.
Much more rewarding than 202. 202 is manual labor.
Read the book and go to lecture
Recommended for some math-savvy people who are not math majors..
Take it if you're willing to spend about 5-10 hours a week on problem sets. Very insightful.
Take it. Don't be scared by the "advanced" in the course name. It is doable without any knowledge of multivariable calculus - I am taking it before taking MAT 203.
Take this course, but be ready to work hard. You really have to master the art of counterexamples and examples for this when compared to mulvariable.
This actually does focus on proofs, unlike 203 my year; a decent amount of work, but not too bad

This course is a more theoretical approach to linear algebra, and I recommend it for any engineers or scientists over MAT 202.  There are definitely still applications in this course, and there are a lot of numbers in the homework.
This is a good math class, especially if you want to go into some conceptual stuff, but not too deep.
Unfair grading, terrible teaching by Micah Warren. Take MAT 202 or MAT 217 instead, either one will be more rewarding.
dont take it.
go to mcgraw!
descrip: Companion course to MAT203. Linear systems of equations, linear independence and dimension, linear transforms, determinants, (real and complex) eigenvectors and eigenvalues, orthogonality, spectral theorem, singular value decomposition, Jordan forms, other topics as time permits. More abstract than MAT202 but more concrete than MAT217. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics. Prerequisite: MAT104 or MAT215 or equivalent.

title: Does Poverty Have a History?
descrip: See website

title: Egyptian Colloquial Arabic II
prereqs: Completion of ARA 307, Egyptian Colloquial Arabic I, or NES permission..
descrip: A continuation of ARA 307. The course focuses on the informal Arabic dialect of Cairo. Students in this course are assumed to have a basic working knowledge of Egyptian Colloquial Arabic, having completed ARA 307. In this second term, students are trained to use Egyptian colloquial at higher registers, including discussions and debates on politics, religion, culture, history, education, and famous Egyptian and Arab personalities. In addition to the textbook, excerpts from Egyptian television, radio, film, music, and theater will be used as means to enhance students' understanding of Egyptian and Arab culture.

title: Narrative Prose in Latin America - 19th Century Caribbean networks
reviews: I would recommend this course with absolutely no reservations.

Just be prepare to read a lot (you would like to read more than what the professor is giving to you, that it is already more than enough: about 200 pages per week). This is a course that will demand from you a lot of attention and in which you would like to be very well informed in every topic. But you know what? You will need to relax and focus in some of the areas that you are interested in. You will not have the time to emulate the readings and spectrum of our professor.
Take it.
take i.t
descrip: Course couples readings in network & systems theory with an examination of crucial networks defining the 19th century Caribbean and its literature: revolution, gossip, {masoneria} and {Abakua}, slavery and anti-slavery movements, romanticism and affect, burgeoning print culture and censorship. How do period genres feed & respond to such networks?.

title: Saints and Martyrs
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This lab course complements NEU 502A and introduces students to the variety of techniques and concepts used in modern neuroscience, from the point of view of experimental and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include electrophysiological recording, functional magnetic resonance imaging, psychophysics, and computational modeling. In-lab lectures give students the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs, but the emphasis is on the labs themselves. Second half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: Chill course. Nice fifth class! Not as disorganized as people say it is. Don't believe them. Brooke is an amazing preceptor.
Don't take it unless you absolutely have to. And if you absolutely have to, consider switching majors.
Fairly solid and straightforward QR. More computer based (you will use R a lot), so take this course if that's something you'd prefer rather then paper / pencil math.
Good place to get an intro to stats.
Great for an intro stats and if you have never taken stats before.

Honestly, I've heard some people don't like Conway but I seriously think he's a decent dude. He has some lame jokes and some funnier ones, but overall he tries to be as engaging as one can possibly be about statistics. If you need a stats, it's not hard at all
I don't feel like I have mastered stats at all.
I would recommend it as a useful QR for independent work in the future.
If you need a QR, this is a good one to take.
If you're a psych major, you have to take it. If you're not and need a QR, take it. A statistics course is great knowledge to have.
It is not bad at all and the grading is quite good.
It is not time consuming. If you are pre-med this stats is a super easy class. It is even easier if you took AP stats.
Lecture is much more important than the textbook readings.
Make sure to review your notes and ask questions, as the lectures can move quickly.
Not terrible, not terribly fun though either
Pay attention in lecture and lab. Don't be nervous about the midterm and final!

So easy. Take the quizzes seriously. Especially if you're cocky like me and know that this stuff is easy. You'll bomb the first quizzes and it'll come back in the end to haunt your grade. There is no curve. All EEB/quantitative/math people should find this ungodly simple. Yet, you still might not get an A if you don't respect the class itself.
Take it if you need to, most people take it because they need to. Its painful but if you have to take statistics this class is just as good as any.
Take it only if you have to and if you do make sure to keep up with the textbook reading!
The QR aspect is handy to this course and could be used in a pinch, but I would only recommend as necessary for a stats class.

This course is good for those who do not like math and want a qualitative overview of statistics. It is not meant for those who want to gain a rigorous understanding for the applications and uses of statistics.
This is a very manageable QR! I promise!
Very basic statistics. If you memorize stuff, you'll get the grade you want. It wasn't too bad.
Worthwhile if you're a psych major. There's a reason it's a departmental pre-req.
easiest stats course at princeton
i would take this course definitely. don't worry about reading much. make sure to ask questions! Professor conway is very approachable and helpful
if you need to take a stats course, this one is really easy and you get the basics down pat.
just keep up with the stuff in R
lots of liberal psych people.
only if u need to
take it
would not take unless you must for the department
descrip: The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic techniques of statistical analysis used in psychological research. Students will learn the logic underlying the statistical techniques and learn how to perform statistical analyses and interpret the results.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A full year study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering culminating in a senior thesis. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written thesis, poster presentation, and oral defense required. The senior thesis is recorded as a double course in the spring. Departmental permission required.

profs.name: Rodolfo Antonio Rios Zertuche Rios Zertuche

title: Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: A lot more theory heavy than multi-calculus was. if that s your thing/

A normal engineering math course. Probably easier than 201 for most people. Find a good group to check answers to hw. Definitely worth reading ahead by one lesson at all times and going to every lecture (even Fridays). The difficulties of exams and quizzes will vary but chances are you will score the same no matter what relative to the class and get a grade you expected. Prob not worth taking for fun for those not needing it in future courses.
AMAZING CLASS! VERY INTERESTING!
As an engineer you have to take this class.  Let's just say the tests suck.
Attend all lectures. Do practice exams, however, because the flavor of exams is different from the homework.
Be prepared to go through all the practice exams to learn relevant topics.
Be ready to learn the material on your own.  Fortunately, the material is very interesting and worth learning.
Be sure to do a lot of practice tests before the midterm and finals! The level of difficulty of problem sets do not reflect the level of difficult of the midterm and final.
Computation-based class.  Conceptually straightforward, just don't mess up your basic arithmetic on the exams and you'll do great.

Course is very cumulative! Do not fall behind. In fact, every 2 weeks, review the past 4 weeks or so. Read the textbook thoroughly and read it before class, otherwise the teaching won't make sense. Linalg is very useful and fun / interesting if you understand the basics strongly.
DO IT AND DIE. THE CURVE IS INSANE

Definitely do all of the homework assignments as it will help with the quizzes and exams. Also, do not fall behind as doing so can be very detrimental when it comes to the midterm and especially the final.
Definitely go to every class and do lots of old quizzes/tests before taking each of those.
Do not take this course unless you have to
Do practice tests.
Don't fall behind, but it is not too much work or time.
Don't fall behind. Also it may help to make a study guide as you go along with all of the key formulas, as you WILL need to be very comfortable with all of them for the proofs.
Don't take it unless you have to, but if you're looking at this you probably have to, so good luck.
Don't take it.
Don't take this class unless you have to, or if you really love Math and are good at it. Actually, you might screw up the curve, so take MAT204 instead. Thank you.
Don't take this if you're not an engineer....
Don't take this unless you actually have a specific interest in linear algebra.
Exactly what you expect--survey course for linear algebra. Tests are somewhat easy.
Find a good preceptor.
Form a study group, read the textbook, and make sure you understand proofs.
Get ready to learn a lot of theory. Taking this course instead of MAT 204 will not help you escape from theoretical math.

Get ready, and get a tutor early. Your preceptor will likely not be very helpful and you will not understand stuff the first few times through. You might never understand it. it's most likely that if you're taking this class, it's because you have no choice. If I didn't have to, there is no way i would have taken the course.
Go to all of the classes and read the textbook before class.
Go to lecture
Go to office hours and do practice exams.
Good luck.
Great, take it with Professor McConnell.
I enjoyed the material, it's very useful.
I liked this course. I found matrices to be interesting topic and really liked the structure of the course and the way the professor presented the material.
I mean, you have to take it anyway.
I think overall it is more abstract than MAT201 and requires more time to have the same mastery of the materials.
I thought this class was hard. Other people think it was easy. It's really up to you.

I would advise students to ensure that they have been placed into the correct Maths class particularly if they have done exams in school other than the AP exams. I would also advise students to do the problem sets because they really help when revising for the exams and quizzes!
Enjoy it!
I would say that study of the textbook is necessary, and to attend class.

If you are a fairly good mathematician, consider taking a higher-level linear algebra class. This one runs the risk of being so boring as to negatively affect your grades as well as your understanding of the subject matter.

If you are a person who's comfortable studying on their own, then don't feel pressured to go to class. Which sounds like bad advice, but studying on your own can be much more efficient sometimes. If you feel like your grades are going down because of that, then GO TO CLASS & OFFICE HOURS.
If you have to take it because you're required to, I guess you don't have a choice; otherwise, please don't.
If you have to take it, you have to take it. It isn't so bad.
If you have to take this course, I would highly recommend Professor Fulger.  In addition, I would take advantage of office hours and be sure to look at the old quizzes and tests when studying.
If you like math, this course provides a solid understanding of linear algebra and is a bit easier than 201. I would reccommend attending classes as this really helped me to learn the material.
If you take this class, make sure you get Mihai.

If you're BSE, you'll be taking this. Put the time in and actually learn the material before precept instead of coasting by on homework and cramming for quizzes like I did, you'll be so much better off for it. Go look up Adrian Banner's review videos and watch them, they're super helpful for reviewing the material.
Interesting but quite a bit of work. Make sure you stay on top of your work and study hard for the exams.
Interesting course, but make sure to keep up with the material on your own.
It was very difficult for me, but it was a much better course than MAT 201.
It's a requirement. I got through it basically on my own. Interesting, but difficult to tie together.
It's a requirement. Just take it, I guess. Not unless you have to.
It's important not to fall behind.
It's not as bad as MAT 201. Don't be afraid. Take it if you have to.
It's okay, probably have to take it for a requirement. The material is a bit easier to understand than MAT 201 but the tests are more difficult.
It's useful to know linear algebra.
Just take it. Make sure you understand all the concepts though; it's easy to get lost in Linear Algebra. Keep on top of everything and you'll be fine.
Just try and perservere!
Keep up with the material! Do a little bit of the problem set every few days. Go to office hours and ask questions. Make sure you understand the basic concepts. It's a lot better than 201.
Keep up with the problem sets

Linear Algebra is a very valuable class to take, and I would recommend it regardless of whether or not it is a requirement for a student's major.  Finding a group to review the homework with is a very good idea, but it's definitely not necessary for doing well or understanding the material.
Linear algebra's extremely useful, so take this!
MAT 202 has a harsher curve than MAT 201. Keep up with the material and read the book to get a grasp of the theory.
MAT 202 is your typical mathematics course. The material is boring, but helpful and necessary for later engineering coursework.
Make sure you do the homework, pay attention in class, and get as much out of the book conceptually as you can.

Make sure you either are really good at math, or have enough time to devote to this. Stay on top of everything because the concepts really just build on top of one another. Try to memorize all of the theorems because to be able to randomly recall some relationship or other is essential to do decently well on any of the exams. Don't take it for fun.
Make sure you keep up - it piles up fast.
Make sure you understand the material as you go along. Study for exams from old exams.
Mandatory

Math 202 is a solid course and will provide you with a relatively good grasp of linear algebra. Don't expect an frills. It's pretty dry. Otherwise, it's worth it to take it if you need to fulfill a distribution requirement (BSE) or have a general interest.
Math is hard.
Maybe look outside the textbook for better explanations. The material itself is very interesting.
McConnell always gives clear lectures.  Go to office hours if you're confused.  Psets are easy, tests are tough but reasonable.
Mihai is without a doubt the best teacher for this class!

Most people are taking this course because they have to. The quality of the class is highly dependent on the professor. I would not recommend others to take this class unless they have an interest in math or are required to take a linear algebra class.
Not too hard, workload is not too big, not too small.

Obviously take this course if you are an engineer. I would recommend 204 over 202 if you are interested in going on to do more theoretical work. This class basically relies entirely on computation, which can be obnoxious and error-prone when it comes to exams. I took 203 in the fall and liked the format more than 202, even though 201/202 is probably easier to get better grade. Just be ready for a terrible curve and be extremely careful with your calculations on exams.
Office hours are helpful
Only if you have to.

Only take it if you have to.
