Only take this class if you absolutely have to

Only take this course if it is required and you are not too interested in the material. If you are interested in the material, MAT 204 and MAT 217 are a lot more in-depth. If you are in this course, make the most of it by keeping up with the textbook and making sure you understand all of the material. The tests and quizzes are (mostly) fair, so as long as you understand the concepts, you should be fine.
Only take this course if you are required to.

Pay attention in lecture and spend a reasonable amount of time on the homework. Not all of it is clear and a lot of it is tedious and you will thank yourself when your hand was been trained to quickly go through complex problems on an exam.

Pay attention/take notes during the lecture to develop a good understanding of the concepts (there are a lot of definitions/rules to know). Solidify this understanding with the homework or extra reading if necessary. This should make studying for exams more of a review than a stressful relearning experience.
Practice the past year papers. You learn alot more.
Probably have to take it. Tough Nugs.
Read the book, and take good notes.  Review often and prepare early for exams.
Read the material before the class and you will gain so much more from listening to the teachers. Shop your preceptor.
Read the textbooks before each class.
Shop around for a good preceptor. This will make or break your MAT202 experience.
Shop preceptors!!!
Some people don't like it. Some do. So, if you want to take it, take it. And if possible, try to be in a "good" section like I was in.
Standard math class with problem sets, quizzes and exams. Take it if interested, not a bad class depending on instructor.
Start the homework early and make sure you understand the theory, and you will do fine! Have fun!
Stay ahead in the class.

Stay on top of your work. Do lots of practice. This is a course with a lot of theorems and proofs, so you really have to understand the concepts. Similar in format to MAT 201, but much more interesting and easier to grasp, though your grade probably won't reflect that because it's on a curve (so don't expect a massive increase in your grade from MAT 201, but do expect to feel a little more grounded in the concepts and actually being able to understand things).
Study a lot.
Study. Don't fall behind.
Take if needed or if interested in gaining an introductory exposure to linear algebra. Somewhat straight-forward. Textbook is very useful; class attendance is not imperative for doing well
Take if you need it for a future career or class; otherwise, it might not be worth it.
Take it because you have to. Try to find a clear instructor! Really depends on whose class you're in.
Take it if you are interested in linear algebra and like math.
Take it if you have to, it's useful.
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you have to. If you're looking for a challenge, this class is probably not it, although that's not saying that it's easy to do well in this course either.
Take it if you have to. Not great
Take it if you like linear algebra.
Take it if you like math or if you're an engineer
Take it if you need it.

Take it only if you like proofs.
Take it with McConnell. He's awesome.
Take it with Mihai!!!! Mihai is awesome <3 He always gives out summary sheets that are really helpful for revising and he's just a really adorable and funny person in general. Take it with Mihai!!!!
Take it!
Take this class if you have to, but avoid it until they get preceptors who know how to teach because even the head of the class was confused by her own solutions.
Take this course if you have to.
Take this course if you need to know linear algebra.  Like most math classes at Princeton, there's a lot of work if you want to do well.
Take this if you have to and do the problem sets and practice exams.
The class is good overall, but I'm not sure I would recommend it to someone who's not an engineering.
The course is great if you enjoy math! If not, it will probably be very time-consuming but very instructive.

The material itself is not challenging though the tests are so be careful you have a full understanding of the concepts presented.
This class is hard, time intensive, and intellectually unrewarding. That being said if you have to take it then you certainly should
This class is pretty dry and difficult if you aren't a super math-type person.  Not worth taking unless you have to.
This class isn't going to be miserable, but it will probably be boring and not particularly enjoyable. Do the psets and think about the material.

This class requires a different mindset than most other math classes such as multivariable calculus. Pretty interesting once you understand. Definitely learn to master True/False questions because they will always bog you down.
This class will help you understand linear algebra.
This course is simply a course that you have to get through. It is not particularly interesting or engaging, but it is necessary. If you do not have to take it, then don't.
This course seems intimidating but is actually manageable and a lot of learning.
This is a good course if you put the work in. You learn a lot about a really interesting subject in mathematics.

This is a hard course. You're probably required to take it. It's not as bad as MAT 201, but it's still hard. Try not to get behind, because you'll probably never catch up. Don't take it if you don't have to.

This semester, the quizzes and exams were considerably harder than those posted from years previous.  Not just for this reason, but as a result of noticing the overall trend in the quizzes/exams:  the fall seems to cover the more important parts of the course in more detail, as opposed to testing for abstract knowledge.  Much different way to think than calculus; geometric intuition can be poor, considering a lot of math is one in 3  dimensions.  Take this class in the fall, if you have the luxury of deciding which semester to take it.  If you just need a math distribution, take multivariable instead.  The material in 201 is much more applicable to other departments, and, although difficult, is tested in a very straightforward manner, unlike this class.
Try and get Rudolfo!  He's funny and a great teacher.
Try to do the course readings over summer or winter break if possible, because the course, like all MAT courses, moves fast, and you can fall behind with just one class behind.
Try to get Mark McConnell.
Understand the concepts, not just formulas, because it really helps with the True/False.
Very challenging, tests are really hard, unless you did decently well in 201 this is going to be a rough ride.
Very useful class!  There are many good teachers -- ask for help if you need it!
Watch Adrian Banner videos if you're lost

While I would not take this class unless it was required (either as engineer, or econ math track, or interested in math) I think it's taught well and not too difficult. I enjoyed it being a mathy person and it seems like a great survey course on linear algebra!
Work with other students on problem sets, do practice exams for the exams, and try to get into Mihai Fulger's section!
Would be good to take a linear algebra course before this course.
You have to take it. Don't take this class for fun.

The final especially was substantially more difficult than anything we had been exposed to earlier. Although I had a great teacher, I hear the quality varies A LOT, so shop around for the best ones.
You probably have to take it. It is not particularly difficult, and some of the material is very interesting. Do the problem sets well and you will be well prepared for the midterm and final
You will have to teach many of the concepts to yourself and keeping up with the material is KEY.
You're probably taking this because you have to. If you just like math, don't be intimidated - it's a super doable class if you put in some effort.
a lot of people take this class because they feel too high and mighty for 175.  in most cases, that is a mistake.  spare yourself the trouble if you're not a physical sciences person

prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese I
prereqs: CHI 107 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Designed to develop further the student's overall language skills through reading and discussion of contemporary affairs published in Chinese newspapers.

title: The Mathematics of Magic Tricks and Games
descrip: See website

title: Communism and Beyond: China and Russia
reviews: A great course for anyone interested in modern Russia or China. The workload is quite manageable: there is a 10-12 page paper in lieu of a midterm and a 10-12 page one in lieu of a final. The reading load is somewhat heavy (i.e. 150-250 pages/week), but most of it makes for enjoyable reading. The structure of the class is twofold: the first half gives you the historical background of both Russia and China, so if you've taken HIS 360, HIS 362, or HIS 325 you'll get a nice bit of review. The second half deals with the legacies of Communism, including ethnic tensions, the environment, inequality, and health. The worst part about the course is that it tends to attract toolish, bombastic WoodyWoo majors who have nothing better to do than shoot off their mouths during the precepts. My advice: do the readings (they usually don't) and use them to call them out in class. Professor Kaple is very nice, knowledgeable, and quite approachable, but she doesn't intervene in class when people start spouting BS. In short: take this course if you have even a vague interest in Russia or China, but be prepared to engage in verbal combat with toolish Woodywoo majors.
A terrific course!  You'll learn so much, and Prof. Kaple is wonderful.
I LOVED this course. If you are interested in communism/China/Russia AT ALL, take it! Do take note, though - this is more of a history class than a sociology one.

It's a lot of work and much of the preparation for class discussion/written assignments/exams revolves around the readings, of which there is no small amount. But in the end you get an idea of the sweeping effects of communism in two major global powers. If that's something you'd want to sink your teeth into, then go for it.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Professor Kaple is the best! You will learn so much and love it!
Take the class if you want to get smart on China or Russia
descrip: This course focuses on the communist experiment in the Soviet Union and China. The first half of the course presents the political, social and economic histories that characterize the USSR's and China's particular path to communism. The second half of the course focuses on the consequences of communism by examining each country's demographics, environment, social structures and so on.

title: Methodology of Spanish Language Teaching: Seminar and Practicum
reviews: Although for most of you it wil be a requirement, this course can be really productive and working with prof. Bruzos is really thought-provoking and  stimulating.

For all students (graduate and undergraduate) who are fluent and accurate in another language and intend to teach it in the U.S., it is a great opportunity to not only go through methodological contents, but also discuss very practical issues related to teaching a foreign language.
If you are taking this course because it is mandatory for you, do not go to the course with prejudices. You will learn a lot and eventually, I can ensure you that you will enjoy it.
If you're interested in second language acquisition, you can't go wrong!
take it.
descrip: This course is an introduction to key terms and ideas in the field of second-language acquisition and core issues in teaching modern foreign languages, with special attention to Spanish and Portuguese. Students will develop and practice skills and techniques of teaching foreign languages, selection of content and materials, evaluation of student performance, and self-assessment of their own pedagogical practices. The theoretical foundation will be applied to the teaching of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). The teaching of culture and the use of new technologies will be also considered.

title: Structural Geology
reviews: If you are considering geology as a track, this is an essential course because it provides much of the foundation for field work. But even if you're not, it's all very interesting and fun anyway. One of the more time consuming courses though, so be prepared for that.
If you're willing to put in the effort and are interested in Geology this is a great class.
Take it.  Hands down.
This course was amazing. It's a good idea to start the lab reports early, so that you have a chance to ask any questions you have!

Tons of work, but best class ever. Blair is the dream scientist. He's so into his work and so fun and makes you want to be so into your work and so fun. If you love learning/science/geology/working hard and playing hard, take this class. Possibly my all time favorite at princeton!
prereqs: One semester of college-level calculus, one semester of college-level physics, and one semester of college level geoscience are required. Open to freshman with permission of instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the physics and geometry of brittle and ductile deformation in Earth's crust. Deformation is considered at scales from atomic to continental, in the context of mountain building, rifting, and the origin of topography.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
reviews: I would advise taking it if interested in labour economics.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: Do you love science? Are you insane/masochistic and want a really difficult course? Here you go!

I would try and prepare the student for the pace of the course and for the time that the problem sets and the lab reports involve. I think this course is for relatively fast learners and therefore I would advise the student to attend lectures and precepts during shopping period to see whether it is a good fit for them. I would also advise the student to do either MAT 201-2 or MAT 203-4 as this really helps with the second semester of Integrated. I would finally advise the student to enjoy what is definitely a unique and somewhat revolutionary introductory science class!

It is hard and a lot of work, but If you are up to the challenge and want to do major in the natural sciences, do it. It is awesome and totally worth of your time. Also, you will make good friends, and you will belong to this awesome community for a long time.

It's a very difficult class but is an incredibly unique opportunity. Try it, see how it is, and if it's for you, it'll be one of the best courses you can take. The teachers are incredible and sincerely want to help you. Talk to students who've taken it in previous years, but on the whole, it's an amazing class.
It's hard, but if you stick with it, you'll learn a lot of fascinating stuff.
Make sure you know the math and don't fall behind.

Not for everyone, but if you're ready for it, take it. Recommended if you're going to take it seriously and love science. If you're worried about your GPA, first, don't worry about your GPA. If you're still worried about your GPA, don't take the course. But really, you should take the course.
Take it.

Take this course if you truly want to be challenged and have your perception of how science in the real world works changed forever. The labs are amazing this semester and you should definitely go for it if you think you can handle the workload. At this point you should have gotten better at computer science and make sure you are ready to be challenged in all parts of the course.

Think before you take this class. Please. It's not worth of for most people, especially the way it's organized now. If you have a string background in physics, math, and COS....then take it. If not......well......try to not die.

This class was probably one of the hardest things I?ve done in my life. The workload is immense, the nights long, the labs endless, and the expectations higher than you can first imagine. I didn?t know I could work this hard ? I worked pretty darn hard in high school, but this is simply another level. That being said, it was entirely worth it. The beginning is overwhelming, and in my opinion the material actually gradually increases in difficulty throughout the year, but you get better at it: you learn how to use MatLab, you get used to writing in Latex, and you learn how to write labs and do problem sets more efficiently. The professors and the other students are utterly amazing ? and I think it?s safe to say there?s nothing else like it. In my opinion, it?s completely worth it, but be willing for it to define your freshman year.

This course is mostly similar to the first half of integrated, with the main change being that the laboratory component was a bit more interesting.  The workload is significantly variable, as there are weeks with minimal workloads followed by weeks with unexpectedly difficult and time-consuming problem sets (up to 20-30 hours at the maximum).  Time management is essential.
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across 4 departments with the following faculty involved in teaching the course: W. Bialek, J. Shaevitz (PHY); O. Troyanskaya (COS); H. Yang (CHM); C. Broedersz, T. Calhoun, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI Fellows). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session each week.

title: American Mysticism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Analysis of Big Data
reviews: . I really enjoyed this course. If you don't know much about statistics besides t tests, this will be "eye-opening." It's a great introduction to modern statistics and machine learning. The "Big Data" title is kind of misleading. We did learn about how to handle massive and high-dimensional data sets, but you don't have really large data sets to handle in assignments. I would have called it Introduction to Machine Learning or something like that. I mean, it is a core requirement for the certificate. Maybe Professor Liu would take offense to that name, since his focus was on the statistical foundations for inference, prediction, etc. The assignments were quite gnarly, but very rewarding. I'm sure the course will get more streamlined in future iterations.

A little bit too much time was spent on reviewing comparatively basic material, such as least squares regression, which should have been covered in pre-requisite courses, but overall the quality of lectures was fantastic. A lot of the material that was covered, such as Lasso regression, the EM algorithm, and MLE models were very interesting. However, it may be difficult to pick up R if you don't know it already.

Apparently lots of people didn't like Han Liu when he taught ORF 405, but he was very good this semester. (Probably improved a lot since ORF 405 was his first time teaching a Princeton class.) Would definitely recommending taking this class, although it may overlap with the COS "interacting with data" if you've taken that. HL's presentation of the material is clear and the pace isn't too fast. Most people will find the material very accessible; this isn't a "wtf is going on" class.
Courses like this are what make Princeton graduates so valued in data-driven fields.
Excellent lecturer (Han Liu) - gives very good intuition behind some theoretical results. Does not bog down the course in too much theory etc. Good applied homeworks.
Great class, reasonable workload.

I'm sure they'll get the class cleaned up, since this was the first time it was offered and it was basically a trial run. Han really cares about his students, which I've almost never seen out of a professor. Gets to know everyone and wants everyone to do well. Take it if you know how to code and are good with stat.
More of a statistics course than one focused on working with big data. Take it if you have a strong desire to know more about statistics/predictive analysis/machine learning.
One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton, hands down. This was the first year, too, so it will only get better over time.

Take a class with Han Liu, he is one of the best professors I have ever had, he actually cares about teaching you. This class is challenging but you will actually get something out of it that you can use in the real world.
Take it, but make sure you have time to commit to the problem sets. they are hard but worth it.
Take this! It's a useful class and the workload is very manageable.
This was the first year he's teaching it, and I expect it to be a much better organized course next year, since he was trying out a few things to see what works best this year.
prereqs: ORF 245.
descrip: The amount of data in our world has been exploding, and analyzing large data sets is becoming a central problem in our society. This course introduces the statistical principles and computational tools for analyzing big data: the process of exploring and predicting large datasets to find hidden patterns and gain deeper understanding, and of communicating the obtained results for maximal impact. Topics include massively parallel data management and data processing, model selection and regularization, statistical modeling and inference, scalable computational algorithms, descriptive and predictive analysis, and exploratory analysis.

title: Contemporary Drama
reviews: If you are interested in learning more about theater or enjoy reading plays, I highly recommend this course.
TAKE THIS CLASS! It's amazing, Tamsen's amazing, the readings are amazing. DO IT!
Take it!  Or take anything with Tamsen!
Take this class and PDF if if you are not an English major! It is very little work and you will love it!

take this class
descrip: This course will look at a range of British and American drama from the second half of the twentieth century to the twenty-first, with an emphasis on the developments of the last twenty years. Questions will include the relevance of drama in a culture of mass entertainment, and drama as a response to history, place, and social trauma.

title: Master's Project II
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.

title: Advanced Optimization
reviews: I recommend this course to anyone whose research interest is related to optimization, statistics, or machine learning.
I strongly recommend this course.
If you're interested in algorithms for convex optimization and Bubeck is teaching this class, take it.
Make sure you understand each upper bound and lower bound proof in the gradient descent method and follow the lecture! If possible, read the suggested paper posted in the notes!
This course is much more heavily weighted on convergence rates and optimality bounds than on the actual algorithms, so keep that in mind when selecting courses.
To have a good basis in topology.
prereqs: Prerequisite: linear optimization.
descrip: A mathematical introduction to large-scale optimization and stochastic optimization. Topics covered include the analysis of diverse gradient-descent algorithms such as sub-gradient descent, Nesterov's accelerated gradient descent, FISTA and mirror descent, as well as a discussion of complexity lower bounds a la Nemirovski. These methods will be compared to the semi-definite programming approach and applications to high-dimensional statistics and machine learning will also be discussed.

title: 20th-Century Japanese Literature
descrip: Readings in selected texts in modern Japanese literature.

title: Elementary Arabic II
reviews: ARA 102 is much easier than 101, so don't worry about it getting much harder than it is at the beginning.
Arabic classes take up a lot of your time- meeting 6 times a week and about 2 hours of homework a night. But I am really impressed by how much I have learned in a year.
Arabic is a great language and all of the professors are really good. Only take it if you are willing to put in the work. If you are, then it is a really rewarding class to take.
Arabic is a lot of work, but if you really want to learn it, it's well worth the time and effort.
Be prepared for a lot of work, but it's worth it
Be prepared to do all the homework and practice as much as possible!
Do all the homework, and don't worry if you're struggling. Arabic takes time.
Don't fall behind in homework

Dr. Bell is an excellent teacher who makes learning Arabic enjoyable.  I highly recommend this course if you are comfortable pushing yourself to learn the vocabulary and grammar at a quick but comfortable pace.
Go for it!
I would encourage them to find outside times to practice speaking.
I would recommend this course to anybody who is interested in learning arabic.
If you are interested in Arabic and have the space to take it, do so.
If you want to learn Arabic, definitely take this course and make sure you get Eva. She is demanding and has high expectations but you will really learn the language.
Just know that it's a lot of work, but none of it is too difficult if you're dedicated and interested in the language.
Just know, its a decent amount of work. You have to like it to get through a year.

Keep up daily with the homework, grammar concepts, and vocabulary - the class is definitely manageable from day to day but is hard to catch up to, so stay on top of everything so that tests don't surprise you, in a bad way!
Keep up on the daily homework and practice with whomever is available especially your teacher.

Learning any new language is difficult each poses a grammatical and syntactically challenge. Arabic is not different; however each language also rewards the hearty effort to face these challenge a rewards best experienced than told by me.
Take it! Eva's a great professor who's truly passionate about helping her students, and Arabic is a wonderful language with a ton of culture behind it. !l`rby@ mmtz@
Take it.  It's hard but worth it.
Take the class!
Take this class, be prepared to work hard. But practicing with the professor during office hours is really helpful!
This class is hard, especially if you lack background in Semitic languages. It is also very much worth it.
prereqs: ARA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course continues the study of Modern Standard Arabic and spoken colloquial Arabic commenced in Arabic 101. Emphasis in class is placed on active use of grammatical points introduced in the book; reading and writing increasingly longer texts; further vocabulary acquisition, and continued practice in listening and speaking Modern Standard and spoken colloquial Arabic.

title: Food Matters
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Saints and Martyrs
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Life Cycle of Behaviors
reviews: A really great course with excellent lectures, very clear expectations for the exams, and a completely manageable workload.  Readings came from a variety of shorter books, rather than a textbook, which allowed for a variety of perspectives.  The lectures were humorous and presented material very clearly and with the right amount of detail.  The lectures review individual studies that are important to understanding the role of the brain in development, in animals in humans, and tests focus on understanding of these processes rather than memorizing details.
Definitely take it! Asif is great and you will learn a lot!
Fun class. Very experiment-focused, both in lectures and on exams. Tests are not about memorization but about experimental design.
Good
If you do nothing else, go to lecture and pay attention!

If you're interested in the development of behaviors, this is the best possible way to learn an amazing collection of information. Prof. Ghazanfar does great in bringing in all kinds of sources and still making it a unified coherent class. One of the most useful classes I've taken. It's also a pretty chill class - not too time consuming, and not stressful. The time you put in pays off - so - just take it!
Really interesting, unique, engaging class. I couldn't recommend this class any more. It finalized my decision to be a psychology major. Professor Ghazanfar is awesome.
Take it. It's definitely a class worth taking, even if you're not a PSY major.
Take this course!
This is a course unlike any other offered and you should definitely take it!

Though I have not taken many other PSY classes, this seems like a unique way of synthesizing and presenting information from several different areas of the field. The course did so in an interesting and engaging manner, consistently demonstrating its relevance to everyday life.  The professor is also great and really tries to ensure that the class material addresses the students' interests and needs.
Very interesting course--TAKE IT!
prereqs: Any 200-level (or higher) PSY, NEU, MOL, or EEB course..
descrip: The goal of this course is to illuminate the interactions between the brain, body and behavior over the course of development and how this shapes a species' evolution. We will first explore developmental events at the cellular level that are shaped by parental behavior. We will then see how these events influence the developing circuits of the brain. Finally, we will learn about influences at the level of niche or culture, where the changes that organisms make to their environments and to themselves influence and modify the patterns of behaviors exhibited in the next generation.

title: Roman History - Problems and Methods
descrip: A seminar that introduces graduate students to current methods and debates in Roman history and historiography. Provides a chronological overview of the history of Rome and her expanding empire from early times (8th century BC) to the end of the Severan era (AD 235), accompanied by the study of a wide variety of ancient sources, including texts, inscriptions, coins, material culture, art, and archaeology, and the methods commonly used by modern historians to analyze them. Students acquire the basic tools needed to do research in Roman history.

title: Computer and Electronic Music Composition
reviews: This course is what you make it to be. Ask lots of questions and set aside some time to really do the assignments.

You have to be somewhat self driven to figure out how to do some things code wise, and to think of projects to work on, but if you are interested in doing this sort of thing, that isn't really a problem!  You can also always get help when you run into issues you can't solve!
take this class
prereqs: MUS/COS 314 or Permission of the Instructor.
descrip: A composition workshop class, in the context of the Princeton Laptop Orchestra (PLOrk) and also the traditional sound studio. Emphasis will be on the student's creative work, composing both "fixed media" works and live electronic/laptop music. Students will also work extensively with professional composers and performers, both from Princeton and elsewhere, performing new works as members of PLOrk.

title: Topics in Paleoecology, Paleoclimatology, and Paleoceanography - Environmental and Biotic Effects of Volcanism
descrip: This course concentrates on the use of marine microfossils in relative age dating and developing high-resolution age control (biostratigraphy) integrated with magnetostratigraphy, chemostratigraphy (stable isotopes), rare and unique bioevents (e.g., species extinctions, species evolution and major species population changes) and radiometric dating. This integrated high-resolution stratigraphic scheme is applied to sequences across geographic regions and oceans in an effort to correlate and identify age equivalent intervals globally.

title: Style and Rule
descrip: The question of style, from the perspectives of linguistics and literary criticism. Readings in theory, ancient and modern; case studies from the history of English, from other languages, and from other media; much practical exercise in imitation, impersonation, forgery, etc.

title: Society and Its Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Research Seminars
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; fourth-year students for 596; and fifth-year students for 597. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Masterworks of European Literature
reviews: Definitely take this class--I loved it.  The readings are long and can be dense, but you really feel a sense of accomplishment and that you've read something that makes you a "special" person.  There were 3 papers which you could pick your own topic for, which was great.  Sitney is a really interesting guy, my preceptor was great, and I feel like I learned a lot.

Devote a minimum number hours of reading time per week for this course even if you'll anticipate that you can't finish a book. The more you read, the more you'll see connections between the texts. Start writing assignments early so that you still have time to read the text being discussed in lecture during the week that the paper is due.
If you like literature, take it. If you haven't learned how to do close readings, this is a valuable skill for analyzing literature. Don't be too scared by the big reading list.

Take it. The reading is awesome, if you stay engaged with the course, you can get away with not doing all of the reading some weeks when you are very busy. Just do you best to do all of the reading and stay engaged and it is very very fulfilling.

You should be prepared to do a lot of work. It isn't a course you can blow off, and you should be very interested in the material and be willing to commit a lot of time to it. That being said, if you're interested and willing to do the work, it's a great course and I totally recommend it!
descrip: In this course we will examine the major forms and themes of Western Literature since the Renaissance: the drama, essay, lyric and novel. We shall read major works by British, Spanish, French, German, Russian, and American authors, considering the unique contributions of specific nations and languages and the transformations of themes and genres over a span of five hundred years.

title: America Then and Now
reviews: Be aware that it's a lot of reading, and that the lectures won't help you much.

Be prepared for long boring lectures and a lot of reading. Easy to get a solid B  but preceptors don't tend to give A's on papers. I would take only to fill EC requriement, if there's a better class you can do that with avoid AMS.

Definitely take this course!! It's brand new and still getting some kinks worked out, but it's really great having a couple different professors from a couple different departments so you can get a good view of various approaches to American Studies.
Depending on what your looking for I would maybe recommend it.
Did not require too much work and was generally interesting
Do not take it.
Do not take this course unless you just want to read a collection of interesting articles.
Do not take this.
Do the readings
Do the readings, listenings, and watchings.

Don't be afraid to tackle new ideas in the papers, since that's really your opportunity to learn new things you haven't explored before. And meet with your preceptor for guidance on the papers, too, because they're happy to help.
Don't take this course unless you really want the AMS certificate.
Don't take this course.
Don't take this.  Lectures are very sloppy.  There are many better classes out there - don't waste your time on this one.
Don't take this. Hated it. Awful. The material is random and common sense. Professors are very disorganized, does not seem like a real Princeton course. Precepts are a waste of time.
Don't, unless you can focus all your energy and time to making connections on your own
Focus on the readings and papers as well as participating in precept.
Get into Cheng's precept.
Go to every lecture, at least read one or two texts for each week
Go to lecture you won't regret it.
Go to lecture-- they're interesting. And be open minded when it comes to writing the papers and discussing things in precept. I also enjoyed the field trips.
Great course overall.
Highlight important parts in the readings.
Honestly I'd say take it to fulfill your EC. It's not that interesting and American Studies as a whole is very abstract, but it gets the job done for a relatively minimal amount of work.

I sincerely hope for every student interested in American Studies that they revamp this course. Regardless of your political ideology, the rampant bias in the class is criminal for an introductory course to a field that is self-defined as broad-based. Only Professor DeLue is decent (albeit flaky) while Professor Hartog is an ideologue and Professor Cheng beats her agenda and opinions into you (for lack of a more professional phrasing). The greatest irony is that some of the course's final readings address and critique the rampancy of politicized bias in American Studies, even as the professors support and continue that so eloquently lambasted trend. 

Aside from the bias, I feel betrayed by the actual topics of study. For a course titled "America: Then and Now" there was remarkably little of either the "now" or a comparison between "then" and "now." As most of the material originates in the 20th century, if not solely its second half, then there is arguably little of the "then" as well. In summary, history seemed to be laid by the wayside in favor of what amounted to sociology. The topics are certainly worthy of study, though they exist beyond the officially stated goals of the course as many of the phenomena had remarkably little effect on the trajectory of the United States compared to events such as the American Revolution, Jacksonian Democracy, Reconstruction, the Great Depression, and World War II. Despite the majority of the discussed material coming in the post-war years (1950s through the present), almost nothing was said about the Cold War!

In short, do not take this class unless they revamp it and replace or rein in the professors.

I think that the biggest problem with this course is that it doesn't know what it wants to be. It seemed at times that it was a course about American Counter-Culture, which would be an interesting course. However, the excessive focus on counter-culture hurt the quality of the class because it also attempted to be about America in general.

I thought the class was a bit disjointed, but I think the professors will work out the kinks over time-- after all, this was the first semester the new course was offered. Lectures varied significantly in quality and overall weren't that useful. Precept discussions were pretty good. I thought Sarah C. was an excellent preceptor; try to get into her class if she is teaching again!

I took this course in it's very first year and while interesting, it was rough around the edges and not always particularly coherent. That being said, it has a lot of potential to be great. It all depends on how much you want to put into it. If you can commit to going to all of the lectures and reading the majority of the materials, you'll have a great experience. If you're not willing to, don't take this course, because you won't get anything out of the lectures and precepts if you haven't read.
I would advise the student not to take the course if they wanted to learn a lot.
I would advise them to participate in precepts in order to get more from the course.
I would highly recommend it as an interesting introduction to American Studies and to thinking critically about American culture.
I would not recommend taking this course.
I would recommend for people taking an EC but not strongly

I would say talk to your preceptor as much as possible when it comes to writing the essays - they are a major part of the grade, but it is easy to answer the essay prompt incorrectly because the directions are so unclear.

I would strongly advise them not to take the class as it currently is. Unless a lot of thought is given to how the material can be more clearly presented and how the assignments can be more closely linked to the class information there are serious problems with this class. Not worth the cost of missing out on a different class here.
I'd recommend this if you need an EC. The four papers seem like a lot, but they're not that bad because they're fairly short and theres a broad range of topics to choose from for each.
If you are considering this class and the topics are of interest to you, you will not be disappointed.
If you are looking for an EC, this is fine to take, although it isn't a very good/interesting course.
If you don't want an AMS certificate, stay away. If you are certain you want the AMS certificate, I'm still not sure you should take this course.
If you want the certificate, this introduces American Studies well.
If you're looking for an EC, look elsewhere. If you're looking for an introduction to American Studies, this is pretty good.
Interesting but very all over the place.

Interesting if you are looking for a course with a new topic each week. Keeps you interested week to week, but is still in its early stages of development (The year I took it was the first of its teaching) so sometimes it is hard to see how the topics relate to each other, if at all.
Interesting material if you're interested in American history but want to hear it from new perspectives. Get ready to hear a lot of bs in lecture though.

It is somewhat of a survey course and a bit all over the place but it is not particularly difficult. Do the readings because there are so many of them that it is nearly impossible to cram for the final.
It's a decent class. No need for lectures but read.

It's a good fifth class if you're looking to knock out another distribution requirement and you're generally humanities-inclined. Should come, though, with a goofy, bs-y academia warning label attached. Lecturers are passionate but construct of class is a little scattered.
It's a good way to get the EC out of the way without having to take philosophy or psychology. The writing assignments are pretty short and easy.
It's not bad if you have to take it for the certificate, the readings are a lot but are also pretty interesting.
Keep up with the readings and pay attention to the themes of the course.
Lectures are often dull, often lots of reading, papers are uninspiring.
Light work, high reward. Interesting topics. You'll learn about Supreme Court cases and art and literature and ethnic groups and much else.
Make sure your prepared to sit through and pay attention through an 80 minute lecture/precept.
Not a lot of work. Get Professor DeLue as a preceptor and this course will be enjoyable.
Not too bad, but can become tedious throughout the semester. Interesting subject matter and worth an EC.
Not too hard - this course will be better the second time around.
Pay very close attention to the lectures
Pretty interesting, not too much work. Nothing radical, but fascinating. Not hard. Take it! But only if you're doing the AMS certificate.
Read the readings and maybe ask preceptors for help on papers. I feel like since they are grading it, they will give good advice. This is something I forgot to do.
Solid class.  Good EC.  It was good the first time around, but I would bet that it will be much better the second time around.
Some of the readings and assignments were enjoyable, but a lot of the larger organizational logistics and broad concepts of the course need ironing out before I could recommend AMS 101 to anyone
Take it
Take it - interesting, and not a super heavy workload.
Take it if you need an easy EC.  Nothing intellectually stimulating and no need to go to lecture really.

Take it, especially if you're interested in critically engaging with the idea of the United States and understanding this country better. Be aware that the class is truly interdisciplinary, and so you will be pushed to do a number of different kinds of academic work.
Take it. It's easy.
Take it. keep up with the readings though. and take notes.
Take the course.
Take the time to write thoughtful papers and go to lecture, skim readings. Get Maeve!
Take this course if you're interested in American Studies, but make sure to go to lecture.
Take this course if you're looking for a relatively easy EM that's also an interesting look at American Studies.
Take this course.  Easy.
The course is very broad--understand that the  course offers a series of snapshots instead of a unified "timeline" of America. e

The course was a little disorganized and the material did not seem to flow in any logical order. Many of the readings were interesting but often did not seem to connect to the theme of the given week.

The course's organization made it somewhat difficult to follow. Obviously, it is new. I liked some of the assignments and some of the readings. The lectures were the worst part. Otherwise, it wasn't very difficult, and I learned some things.
The paper topics can be a bit tedious and annoying, but the readings and lectures can make you think about the major themes in American culture in a whole new way.

The texts were all really good, the lecturers stimulating though a bit harried. Course is still coming into itself. You will learn a lot, be pushed in your ideas about america. Not necessarily an easy class. paper grading is a bit hard.

This course encourages you to explore a lot of different types of mediums that say something about the identity of America. We read a fiction novel, autobiography, journal essays, newspaper articles, visited campus archives, visited the art museum, listened to music, looked at art, watched snippets of plays and movies, and visited the 9/11 Memorial site. You really get to explore different aspects that speak to what America is.
This course is good to take if you really need to fulfill the distribution requirement, but it was very jumbled and disorganized, and I did not feel like I learned a lot.
This course might get better as this was only the first year it was taught. Although the professors are good the course is very disorganized
This is a good class to fulfill an EC requirement. However, it is a lot of work so you must be engaged in the material and not expect that it's going to be very easy.
Try to space out the readings rather than doing them on the final day.
Unless you have to take this course to gain entry into the American Studies Certificate Program, I would not recommend it.
Yes--an easy EC.
don't take it
get into elizabeths precept

if you cannot do all of the reading, make sure you read the intro, topic sentences, and conclusion, otherwise you may be lost in a lecture that is literally focusing specifically on that reading. And not following a lecture is seriously detrimental because these lectures are valuable sources of information and tools to understanding the info.
its a good class
meh
readings were interesting, but the course as a whole wasn't.
see above.
take it
take this course ! best EC ever.
descrip: This course introduces a selection of signature ideas and debates that made the nation what it is today and what it is becoming. Objects of study range across multiple media, including texts, images, works of art, music, performance, and film, and draw from the diverse fields of literature, history, political science, art history, economics, law, cultural studies, and the history of science. The course attends to how knowledge about America has and continues to be produced, disseminated, and consumed, emphasizing the cognitive processes associated with the invention and delineation of America.

title: World Literature: Comparative Cosmologies
descrip: This course on literary worlds and world literature begins with an overview of premodern cosmological thought; develops tools for thinking cosmologically in the modern age; and then pivots to a series of modern literary works, asking what kinds of worlds they build. We will do cosmological analysis on texts that live in a world "beyond" cosmology, asking what they tell us about the history of ideas of the world and the concept of "world literature." Novels from Europe, Asia, Latin America; all readings in English translation. Graduate students who enroll will be asked to do extra or more extensive writing assignments.

title: Imagining Other Worlds
descrip: See website

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: Definitely take this course! Very interesting presentation of French culture as well as grammar fundamentals. I found that my speaking and listening skills improved a lot in this class.
Do the homework and assigned readings and you'll be fine.
Don't bother spending a lot of time with the movies and readings when studying for the tests. Just know the gist of what they're saying.
Expect that half of your class just won't care. For those of you who will fall into that lazy section of the class - just be respectful. Don't walk in late every morning, it's not very gracious.
Great course if french isn't perfect but want to learn more

I've taken 4 years of French in high school, which definitely made the course a little less difficult.  However, I definitely was exposed to material I have never seen before. The point is without previous experience, this class could be quite difficult and could require a lot more studying.
It is a fun class and the work load is totally manageable! Take it!

Madame Ambrogelly is a very fair, sweet, and enthusiastic professor. She really tries to accommodate everyone and does a good job of teaching the material. My biggest advice to you would be DO THE DAILY HOMEWORK. There is a level of personal responsibility in doing the daily assignments even though they are not collected or graded, but I cannot stress enough that if you really want to learn this language and do well in this course, you must do them, and ask the professor any questions you have. As long as you do the work and are regimented about it, you should do very well in the class. The class is very fair.
TAKE THIS COURSE. Madame is the coolest person on the planet. You will want her to be your best friend.
Take French 107! It's an awesome class.
Take it!
This is not a rigorous course. You are gonna do great if you have a clear understanding of french grammar.

Whether this is a required course for the language requirement or simply the next step because you're interested in learning French, 107 with Ambrogelly is a great class.  It's a lot of fun, but don't underestimate how much work will be required of you.  It's easy to get behind, so make sure you do the assignments as scheduled.
With language classes, the professor really makes or breaks the class. Try to get Ambrogelly! She's the sweetest.
You should take this course.
try to speak in french as much as possible
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103, or special permission..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material.

title: Water in the Atmosphere
prereqs: Background in atmospheric/oceanic sciences..
descrip: Despite the paramount importance of atmospheric water vapour for climate, our understanding of the processes that regulate its distribution and changes within a changing climate remains incomplete. This course analyses observations and discusses theoretical approaches, both basic concepts and novel ideas, to the problem. Course is for graduate students with a background in atmospheric and/or oceanic sciences, and students are encouraged to provide contributions from their own research experiences that are related to the course topic.

title: Intermediate Czech II
prereqs: CZE105.
descrip: A continuation of CZE105. Advanced grammar topics, building of vocabulary through studying Czech word formation and reading challenging samples of Czech literature (prose, poetry, drama). Continuing practice in oral communication. Three hours per week. Prerequisite: CZE105 or with instructor's consent.

title: Costume Design
prereqs: This course is by open enrollment..
descrip: An exploration of the various aspects of Costume Design for the stage. Studio projects will be designed to coincide with other theater and dance courses and currently scheduled productions. Critical discussion will explore the relationship between dramatic texts and design ideas.

title: Women and Film
descrip: This course will explore the role of women filmmakers in European cinema from World War II to the present. We will examine the way film artists (directors, editors, set designers, etc.) have identified with the visual image specific to the art of cinema and national cultures. It will include Varda, Cavani, Wertmuller, Potter, Campion, and Holland among others. Emphasis on cinematic, socio-ideological perspectives on the role of women in film.

title: History of European Fascism
reviews: Great class. Professor Rabinbach is excellent, and the nature of the class depends a lot on the other students in your seminar.
I would absolutely take this seminar.  It's an important and interesting topic, and is led by a fantastic professor.
If you're even slightly interested in the subject, you'll get a lot out of this class. Take it if you can!
Take it! Rabinbach is an incredible professor, and the topic is endlessly fascinating.
Take it. It's not easy, but you'll learn a lot
Take this course if you're willing to put in the time to do the readings and stay engaged in class. The material is incredibly interesting and Professor Rabinbach is unbelievably knowledgeable.

This course was excellent, one of the most intellectually stimulating I have taken at Princeton. Readings were fascinating, class participation was high, professor was great and the assignments were very fair. I would recommend this class but only to students who are willing to participate in fiery debate in class and who are willing to do a lot of reading before seminar. Do not take this if you are just looking to fulfill a HA req.
This is a great course. If it's ever offered again, I highly recommend you take it
descrip: This seminar will survey interwar fascist movements and regimes with a special emphasis on Nazi Germany. Topics will include the genesis of fascism as a response to political and cultural crisis, the role of ideology and culture, and Nazi society in peace and war. The seminar will focus on past and present historical perspectives.

title: Divided We Stand: Economic Inequality and Its Discontents
descrip: See website

title: Women and Gender in Islamic Societies
reviews: I think that this is a good course if one has some prior knowledge about Islamic societies, so that they can learn more about the "unconventional" aspects of certain Islamic societies (at least, they were unconventional to me).
Interesting readings, films--great complicated subject matter

Make sure you have time to read the readings before registering for this, because you will shortchange yourself if you cannot do the readings. Plus 3 hour discussions are a little bit difficult if you're not prepared.
Read all the books, it can be very stressful if you don't.
The title of the course is misleading, if one expects a balanced overview of women in Islam
This class is a reasonable place to start if you've never encountered the topic before.
descrip: This seminar focuses on issues of gender and sexuality in Islamic societies, past and present. Readings are drawn from the fields of history, religious studies, anthropology and sociology. Readings also include a wide range of texts in translation, including novels and poetry. Films are an integral part of the course. Topics include: women's lives; women's writings; female piety; marriage and divorce; sexuality and the body; and women and Islamic fundamentalism.

title: The Arts of Japan
reviews: Definitely take this if you're interested in Japan or art!!
Take it, and dive in
descrip: ART 217 surveys the arts of Japan from the pre-historic period through the present day. Painting, sculpture, and architecture form the core of study, though we will also examine the critical role of other forms, including calligraphy, lacquer, and ceramics. Throughout the course we will take close account of the broader cultural and historical contexts in which art was made. Our topics include the ongoing tension in Japanese art between the foreign and the indigenous, the role of ritual in Japan's visual arts, the re-uses of the past, the changing loci of patronage, and the formats and materials of Japanese art.

title: Studies in Japanese Religions - Issues in Scholarship
descrip: This seminar will provide an intensive introduction to Japanese Religions past and present and examine key issues in recent scholarship as well as some classic studies. The course is designed for students planning to take general exams, teach, or simply acquire a background in this field. Topics may include interactions of Buddhism with local religious culture; the emergence of Shinto; monastic and lay Buddhism; philosophical issues; contemporary spirituality; death ritual; and religion-state relations. Readings will be in English and Japanese. To some extent, topics may be chosen to accommodate participant research interests.

title: Seminar on Education-Theory and Practice
prereqs: Prerequisites: See Teacher Preparation Program requirements. Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Seminar taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402). Students investigate the processes of curriculum development and implementation, develop learning goals and rubrics for assessment, study national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, examine current philosophies and effective practices, reflect on their work and evaluate their performance as practice teachers.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: If you've had training in French but want to get comfortable speaking and listening to the language, this is the course for you. Also if it's been a while since you studied French, this is a great course to familiarise yourself with the material again.
Not bad
Practice speaking as much as possible, and do a lot of exercises to memorize how to form and use the different tenses/verb conjugations.
Read the book, and study for the exams.
You get out of this what what you put into it.  If you work hard and stay on top of the work, you will learn a lot and make the most of the class.
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Contemporary African Art Since 1980
descrip: See website

title: America and the Melting Pot
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors if they have already taken COS 398. B.S.E candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Studies in 19th-Century Literature and Culture - Heinrich Heine und Sigmund Freud
descrip: The coincidence that Heinrich Heine died in the same year when Sigmund Freud was born (1856) functions as the point of departure to study the elective affinities and interrelation between a poetic and a scientific approach to phenomena such as the dream, the language of the unconscious, passions, wit, memory and the afterlife of religion and myth in modernity. Starting with Freud's explicit references to Heine in his book on Witz, the seminar will study the hidden traces of their affinities: 1. Heine and Freud read Shakespeare, 2. Fictious and scientific dreams, 3. Comparing their Moses-books, 4. Gods and ghosts, 5. Passions and paintings.

title: Advanced Analysis of Environmental Systems
reviews: It would be helpful to know some MATLAB before taking this class. Professor Hedin and Professor Celia are both very knowledgable and helpful when answering questions.
Take this course! It is a challenge but it is also very rewarding!
i learned a lot but if you haven't taken beyond MAT 104, I would recommend taking this for a grade.
take good notes and come to class.
prereqs: Prerequisites: Mathematics equivalent to MAT 104 or instructor's permission; and Chemistry equivalent to CHM 202 or instructor's permission; and Biology equivalent to EEB 211 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Humans are increasingly affecting environmental systems throughout the world. This course uses quantitative analysis to examine three of today's most pressing issues: energy, water, and food. Each issue is examined from perspectives of natural and engineered ecosystems that depend on complex interactions among physical, chemical, and biological processes. The course is an introduction for students in the natural sciences and engineering pursuing an advanced program in environmental studies. We emphasize quantitative analyses with applications to a wide range of systems, and the design of engineered solutions to major environmental problems.

title: Seminar in Global Health and Health Policy
reviews:
1) The workload is pretty light
2) Still, I learned more in this class than in most others at Princeton
3) Mahmoud is a boss
4) Shenk shines
5) The course is excellent. Just pay attention, participate in discussions, and enjoy!
Amazing course. It's not often you have the chance to sit down, learn, and spend an entire class discussing. It's a class based on learning for the love of learning. take it!
Awesome course to take with two brilliant professors! Especially recommended for GHP seniors.
Best class I've taken in the global health program.
Definitely take it!  The professors are great, and you really get to engage with others about important and current health policy issues.
Definitely take this course. The professors are amazing.
Don't blow off this course. Get all you can out of it because it is really a privilege to get to learn from Prof's Mahmoud and Shenk.
Great course! Thursday night seminar time might be off-putting but totally worth it
I would definitely take this class. This is what college is supposed to be like: learning from your peers because you are genuinely interested in the subject (not for grades).
If you're interested in issues pertaining to global health - either from a molecular biology or from a policy standpoint - this class is a must. There really is something in it for everyone.

If you're interested in pharmaceuticals, enjoy speaking in front of a class, and don't find a 3-hour night seminar, go for it. However, the class glosses over many important policy issues directly affecting healthcare workers, such as the Affordable Care Act, so don't expect to get much of that out of the class.

One of the best classes I've ever taken at Princeton. Don't take this class for granted. Stay engaged throughout, because that's how you'll get the most out of the class. Do the readings you can, and pay attention(!!!) to each others' presentations. Invest intellectually in this class; it's worth it.
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT. Incredibly useful course, and the instructors are awesome.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!!!
Take this course.

The professors don't actually teach; the entire class consists of student presentations. If you don't like subjective evaluations or some students talking just for the sake of getting their 40% participation grade, then don't take the class. Otherwise, the topics are super interesting. You get out as much as you put in from this class. But I definitely felt frustrated with the way the class was run and don't think the class is designed in a way that gives every student an equal change of performing well. The professors are biased towards science majors, so although it's supposed to an interdisciplinary course, and the professors say that the class would benefit from the perspectives of policy majors, econ and others, that doesn't always get reflected in the class dynamic...
The readings are short, so take the time to do them. Become involved in class discussion.
prereqs: GHP 350 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This seminar will examine four major topics in global health. Potential topics include: the importance of patents in healthcare; AIDS in America; synthetic biology and biosafety; vaccine safety; the business of biology; the state of US healthcare; healthcare in emerging economies; and drug discovery and development.

title: Ecologies of Practice: From Cosmopolitanism to Cosmopolotics
descrip: This course will provide an introduction into the pragmatist tradition of Science and Technology Studies and Actor-Network-Theory and will invite students to reflect analytically and visually on their relevance and limits for the design disciplines. Taking a pragmatist approach, we will scrutinize design practice as complex ecology involving actors with variable ontology, scale and politics. The second part of the seminar will be dedicated to a very specific exercise of following, analyzing and mapping a controversy of design, urban or architectural nature.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Beginner's German II
reviews: As with all language courses, if you want to improve your abilities, you'll have to do a fair amount of work and practice both in class and outside of class.
Definitely take this course
Do it!!! (Assuming they keep the profs the same.) 101 with Rankin and 102 with Arya is fantastic combo!
Go for it. And make sure you're proactive.

I took this course because I want to learn German. I had already completed my language requirement, so I can't comment on how the course is if that's your aim. But, if you really want to learn German, then Angi is the way to go!
I would emphasize the importance of being consistent in dedicating some daily time to the materials of the course.

I would strongly recommend taking this class. If work is done regularly, it is not challenging at all. Studying for the tests and completing the written assignments should not take up more than 30 minutes per day.
I would tell another student that since this is a graduate section, more of the emphasis will be on translation, reading, and comprehension, rather than speaking.
If you are going to take this course, be prepared to participate a lot in class.
If you've taken 101, definitely take this course!
Instructors for German are good...but you do have to stay on top of your individual studying outside of class.
It's a language course. German is taught well here.

Pretty straight forward 102-level language course.  The instruction quality of the German department is fantastic.  Be prepared to put in at least a half hour a day (preferably more) to really learn the language.

Recognize that this is a graduate student section, therefore speaking and listening knowledge will not be as fully developed as in undergraduate sections. On the other hand, the reading and translation skills are very very developed in this class.
Sign up for Hannes' section!
Study a little every day
Take it.
The German department is pretty awesome; definitely take it.
There is definitely variation between the instructors, but both of the German grad students I learned from were excellent.
You should take this course.
study more vocab
prereqs: GER 101 or permission of instructor. About 12 students per section. Normally no credit is given for GER 101 unless followed by 102..
descrip: Continues the goals of GER 101, focusing on increased communicative proficiency (oral and written), effective reading strategies, and listening skills. Emphasis on functional language tasks: learning to request, persuade, ask for help, express opinions, agree and disagree, negotiate conversations, and gain perspective on German culture through readings, discussion, and film. Participants are eligible to apply for Princeton-in-Munich, GER 105-G, June, 2013. The afternoon section, restricted to graduate students, follows the basic syllabus with added emphasis on reading skills.

title: Culture of Individualism, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Ecology and Conservation of African Landscapes
reviews: Be prepared to work really hard and get no sleep and constantly be working and not really understand why you're doing what you're doing.

I think you should do it, be prepared to put up with really long days.  Andy and Paula are both great, they're good professors and really cool people!  You'll learn a lot from this course.  It kind of comes off as easy at first, but it's really not, so don't come in with that expectation.

I would tell them that it's a LOT of work but that it's definitely worth it and it's so great to work to get of Mpala for a while. It was also extremely rewarding to work with community members on an issue they cared passionately about.
One of my favorite classes because of the integration in Nairobi, but also the game drives were super fun. Could use more direction from the professors about assignments.
Really interesting course with great lectures, but a lot of time in the field and writing up analysis.
prereqs: Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya.
descrip: Only six percent of Africa's land area (containing a fraction of its biodiversity) is protected, and these areas are rarely large enough to sustain wildlife populations. Mostly, wildlife must share land with people also facing survival challenges. This course will explore how wildlife and people interact in Kenya, where new approaches to conservation are being developed. Lectures will cover the ecology of tropical grasslands and first principles underlying conservation and management of these landscapes. Field trips and projects will examine the dynamics between human actions and biodiversity conservation.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Revitalization of America's Cities
descrip: Seminar focuses on the evolution and revitalization of America's cities. Course concentrates on the public policy and real-world dynamics that help explain the origins, fortunes and fate of cities; examines the lifecycle of cities and their neighborhoods, the forces that drove their decline, the policies and players that have spearheaded their revival, the reasons why some communities have yet to recover, the public policy conflicts and community tensions that arise when revitalization and gentrification get traction, and the potentially transformative impact of the recent economic meltdown.

title: The Evolution of Human Language
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to the Study of Gender
reviews: Check which professor is teaching that semester, because the course varies very greatly as the professors do.
Come in with a solid foundational knowledge of the theory.
Focuses a lot on lesbian mothers. Take if you enjoy gender theory.
Great class, definitely take it!
He's a speedy one. Try to keep up. And stop him to ask questions often.
Interesting course, but depends greatly on your professor
Prof. Rivers was a visiting professor, but he was fabulous. If he ever teaches the course again, though, absolutely take it.

Take it -- although Daniel Rivers will not be teaching it again because he is leaving, I have heard that all of the other professors who teach this class are just as fantastic as he is. Definitely take this class!! It's pretty good even if you're not getting the certificate and just need an SA.
Take it! Unfortunately Prof. Rivers is leaving this semester, but I'm sure the GSS dept. will find another professor that will do a great job as well.
Take this if you are interested in an overview of gender and sexuality issues that doesn't just focus on the American white middle class and pays real attention to the lived experiences of women
The instructor changes every year so I don't think any advice would be useful.....
This course depends on the professor for assignments, topics, and the amount of reading.

This is a class on women and feminism, not on gender. If you are interested in the history of American feminism, this is the class for you. If you are interested in gender or LGBT history, take a different course.
Try to keep up with what he is saying in lectures.  The information is important but sometimes you don't hear it all because he goes so quickly.
Well, since Prof. Rivers will be gone, I think the next class will be very different. You should still take it though.
ask for Professor Rivers' syllabus :)
descrip: This course will introduce students to some of the key concepts in gender studies. We will look at current debates in gender studies, explore the history and theory of feminist movements for social justice, both in the United States and globally, and explore the history of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities in the United States. Students will be asked to think through these topics with an intersectional lens, asking how categories such as race, class, sexuality, and gender operate in conjunction with one another in people's lives and through shared cultural beliefs and structures.

title: Art and Politics in Postcolonial Africa
reviews: Liking this class is subjective. You should have a strong interest in either modern art or present-day African socio-economic matters. And even with that, an open mind is very key to enjoying the course and professor.
Only take it if you're actually interested in art.
descrip: This seminar examines the impact of the IMF's Structural Adjustment Program, military dictatorships, and political crises on artistic production in the 1980s, and the dramatic movement of African artists from the margins of the international art world to its very center since the 1990s. How familiar or different are the works and concerns of African artists? What are the consequences, in Africa and the West, of the international success of a few African artists? And what does the work of these Africans at home and in the West tell us about the sociopolitical conditions of our world today?

title: International Security Studies
descrip: Central topics in security studies, including the causes and nature of war, deterrence, alliance formation, military doctrine, civil-military relations, arms competition, and arms control.

title: General Physics II
reviews: A class I would strongly avoid taking, though you probably have to. However, don't let this class steer you away from engineering, or a specific discipline.

A good general physics course. Go to precepts and ask questions if you do not understand the material. Not that much required work, but I found doing more practice problems before each test to be very helpful.

A much better course than PHY 103 in terms of interesting material and labs, but this year's examination style, format, and inconsistency detracted from its value. Obviously take if needed; otherwise, it's an interesting physics course.
Always show up to precepts.
Amazing Class but avoid bad preceptors!
Be prepared to put in a lot of work going over the chapter yourself.
Better than PHY 103. Still, don't take it unless you have to.
Beware the lab grading, if they haven't overhauled the system. Make sure you understand the concepts; they might take some time to sink in, especially if you don't "get" math and/or physics.
DO IT!

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU ABSOLUTELY HAVE TO. If, for instance, you are trying to decide between BSE/AB COS, go with AB and save yourself the pain of going through PHY 103/104. Physics was honestly the worst experience I've ever had at Princeton. Don't make the same mistake I did.
DON'T TAKE THIS UNLESS YOU ARE AN ENGINEER. Also, content is much harder than first semester.

Do not take this class unless you have to. Try and switch into a good preceptor early on- I tried to do so, but they wouldn't let me since every other precept I wanted to switch into was full, and I think this very negatively affected my performance in this class.

Do not take this course unless you need to. It can be extremely time intensive (seven hours of class/week plus about another seven hours of work) and not very enjoyable. The professors seem to assume much prior knowledge of physics and prepare the material accordingly - making it rather difficult if you haven't had any physics before. Even those who have had lots of physics before find it rather hard.
Do the work, go to lecture, ask questions!
Do-able amount of material. Try to work with other people in the class; it will help.
Don't buy the hard copy of the textbook.
Don't get behind.
Don't recommend it.
