Don't take it if you don't have to or if you're not very good at physics and math already.  You could feel overwhelmed.
Don't take it unless you absolutely have to.
Don't take it unless you actually like physics, or it is very painful.
Don't take it unless you have to.

Don't take it. Seriously just stay away. Then again, if you're considering taking it, you're probably an engineer who hasn't placed out of physics, and in that case you're in for an awful semester. Sorry.
Don't take it. Worst class ever.
Don't take unless required.
Don't take unless you have to.
E&M doesn't have to be terrifying. Oh, and try to get Juan by any means necessary.

E&M is an interesting but difficult subject. If you're planning on taking 104, be prepared to put a lot of time into the problem sets, labs, and studying for exams, but make sure to go to office hours or find a friend if you need help.
EASY CLASS. TAKE IT. LOTS OF FUN.

Every BSE student needs to take this class, but be prepared to learn all the material on your own especially if you don't have a good preceptor. Also, don't do Monday labs since you will rarely ever know the information to be able to do prelabs ahead of time.
Find a good preceptor! It makes a difference.
Get La Porta as a preceptor
Get Professor La Porta as your preceptor and go for a night lab. Use office hours if you need help, and start prelabs early.
Get a good preceptor

Get a good preceptor (Page or Meyers) and go to McGraw if you need help. The exams are pretty short and simple, so a lot of your grade will depend on the final. Don't take unless you are an engineer and need it for your requirement (if not an engineer, take the easier physics).
Give someone else your clicker to get you the points because lectures are dumb. Get a good preceptor.
Go to office hours, I didn't and I really regret it.
Go to precept and start problem sets early!
Go to the review sessions before exams.
Good course. Make sure to attend lectures and precepts. Study a lot for final exam, and do not fall behind.
Great course, you have to take it
Hard course, make sure you have enough time to do all the work if you want a good grade.
Harder than 103. Do the readings in order to understand the material and work with other people on the problem sets and homeworks. It sucks but you'll get through it.
I don't see why you would take this course unless you're an engineer or interested in physics so take it as it's worth. Not particularly fun, sort of stressful, but what other choice do you have...
I liked it more than I thought I would, but its still one of those classes. It's better than 103 though!
I really enjoyed this class, other than some of the labs which were boring and seemed pointless. The material was very interesting however and the assignments were not overbearing.
I think it is a very comprehensive class. A good way to fulfill an engineering requirement.
I would say definitely take the course, but it will be a fair bit of work.
I would say that the textbook is helpful, and that preceptors seem to want to help as much as possible. Use them as a resource!
If possible, do not take this course.

If you are considering taking 104 for any reason other than that you need to (because it's a BSE distribution requirement), I would advise against it. It is a difficult course, despite what you'll hear from a lot of people. Before I took it, I had heard that it was easier in a lot of respects from 103. It's not. If you're good at physics, you'll have no difficulty - it's not really a hard course as long as you can grasp the concepts. But I personally found it challenging. The homework, while not a lot, was often time consuming. Definitely make sure you get into Lyman Page's precept if you can. That will make a world of difference. He's a great preceptor, willing to explain any questions. He provides clear explanations and always shows up to office hours on time.

If you are majoring in the sciences, you should take PHY 103/104. I believe that the calculus included in this course actually allowed the preceptors and lecturer to go into greater depth about the physics behind certain phenomena. Otherwise, if you are a BSE student and do not have AP credit, you will need to take this course.
If you aren't an engineer, don't take
If you can, PLACE OUT OF PHYSICS !!
If you don't have to take it and want to take physics, take PHY 101/102 instead.  The material won't be trying to beat you to death the whole time.
If you have AP credits, USE THEM. Don't "gain a better grounding", it's just not worth it.

If you have to take this course, be prepared to start the homework early, make sure you find a good preceptor who you can understand, go to office hours, and look at the old quizzes and tests when studying for exams.
If you learn how to use the equations you will do fine on the test.

If you're BSE and you didn't place out with AP Physics or take 106, you're going to be here. You're going to have to deal with it. E&M is interesting, though! As always, shop around to find a preceptor you like. Vikram Duvvuri was great, I strongly advise getting into his precept!
If you're BSE or some science major take it because you have to; wouldn't recommend it for others though.
If you're an engineer, take it over 106.  You'll be happy you did.
If you're in the class, then its probably required. So have fun with it.

If you're not required to take the course, I wouldn't recommend it. The labs are lousy (although Andrew Hartnett is a great AI) and the lectures are underwhelming. If you do take it, though, GET DR. LA PORTA FOR PRECEPT. HE IS ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. Also - if you have the CBLI option instead of the 4th quiz, do it! It's easy, and even more fun than I thought it would be.
Interesting and well structured.
It is a solid course.
It is required for all engineers so it is an exercise in making sure that one really understands all of the material.
It's a decent class. It teaches you well. You should take it if you think you want more of a challenge than 102.
It's good enough that you'll survive and learn what you need, but be sure to do the readings and go to precept, because unless you've taken E&M before, you'll be lost.
It's hard, but you have to take it, so just deal with it. If you study you'll do fine!
It's not too bad - just keep up with your reading and prepare adequately for the quizzes.
Just another boring intro requirement that becomes difficult because of the geniuses that take it that should be in a higher level course.
Just try your best and after the class, if your an engineer, you will be done with physics!!
Keep doing problems.
Keep up with the material and use your resources. Lecture isn't particularly helpful, but if you get a good preceptor, precept can be. If you make friends in lab, it becomes much less unpleasant.
Knowing what i know now, I would take this course again.

Learn the material as you go even though you are not responsible for it. The class is poorly structured in that all term you do not need to truly understand what you are being taught and then in the final you need to know everything from the term.
Love this class!
Make sure you are on top of everything as it gets hard to catch up if you are behind.
Make sure you go to every lecture and find an instructor you like and respond well to. Also read the book!
Make sure you spend a lot of time with the material
Memorize all your formulas and you will do decently well. I would only take it if you have to.
More interesting content than PHY 103.
Never take this.
Odds are that this is a requirement for you, in which case I'm sorry.  But if you don't absolutely have to take this class, don't.
Office hours are important.
Only if you have to
Only take if required.
Only take it if you have to.
Only take it if you have too. Incredibly poorly structured.
Only take this course if you have to for a requirement or are very interested in physics.
Only take this course if you have to--you learn some interesting things, but it's also A LOT of work.
Physics is a hard topic so you will be challenged. I would only take this class if its a requirement.
Please don't unless you have to for your major. Definitely don't do it as your STL.

Prepare yourselves for the most unorganized class at Princeton. Tests take multiple weeks to be graded, whereas COS and MAT classes seem to be able to grade just as many in one or two days. Classes barely teach the material and quizzes test you on material you were never taught in class.
Read ALL the recommended chapters of reading, as they really help understand the material.  Do the practice problems, and do the homework!  Also, be sure to get a good preceptor from the beginning.
Read the book and put effort into it. I you don't understand something, go to office hours. The preceptors are really nice and helpful.
Read the text and do book problems before starting homework or taking practice quizzes.
Read the textbook over the weekend and do a lot of practice problems
Similar in workload as PHY 103, make sure you don't fall too far behind each week or risk being totally lost on the handwritten HW and exams.
Spend lots of time on this course

Stay on top of the readings, go to your preceptor's office hours, and check in with yourself at the end of every week to make sure you are understanding the concepts. If you get behind, it is hard to catch up.
Study effectively.
Study throughout the year!

TAKE PRECEPT WITH LA PORTA! (Seriously! He's the best!) Also, pray the class is less poorly organized than it was for us this semester. Oh, and I'm sorry in advance about the labs... Take this class only as a requirement or for La Porta.
Take it because you have to! Not that bad. Similar to 103.
Take it if you have to. Don't slack off.
Take it if you have to. It's fun, but a lot of time to just take it for funsies.
Take it if you have to...I had La Porta as my preceptor and enjoyed that a lot. That's really the only reason I got through physics.
Take it if you like physics, it is way better than 103. E&M is way more interesting and fun than mechanics!
Take it if you must.
Take it if you need to. I'm sure there are better physics classes to take if you have only an interest.
Take it if you're BSE.  Premeds should stick to 102
Take it if you've taken 103 - a good course, requires a lot of work.
Take it only if you have to, or if you are really really interested in physics. Keep up with the readings.
Take it only if you have to.

Take it only if you're an engineer and need to. If you have to, try to get La Porta as a preceptor. He communicates the material engagingly and helps you understand not just the math, but the actual physics.
Take this.
Teach yourself the material and go to office hours.
The class is a lot of work.

The course is challenging, but there are some benefits. It does go beyond some of the basic high school physics, and the lectures are pretty cool. And though it is hard to really learn every topic to the extent that you feel like you could solve any problem, you do learn something every unit which is probably the biggest take-away.
The course is pretty well run. Read the book. It helps.
This course isn't too bad. If you put in the work, you won't be disappointed.
This course will push you differently than physics 103. Make sure you do well on weekly quizzes and understand information before the class moves along.
This is a good course that will teach you a lot about our world.
Try to work on the practice problems more often.
Unless you have to take this course because you're an engineer, don't take it! Pre-meds, take 102!

We had a lab scheduled a week earlier than it should have been. Problem sets were all over the place. I cannot in good conscience recommend this course unless it is a prereq for you. Hopefully Tully is not teaching it again or has gotten his act together.

Worst course I've taken so far. Professor Tully's lectures were not useful at all. Find a good preceptor - Meyers seemed good when I dropped in on 1 precept but don't count me on that; he calls on students to participate in class so you always have to be alert and on top of your shit. Vikram was pretty terrible, we had on average 5-10 people (out of 30 enrolled) show up to every precept. And then there were a few times where he didn't even show up to precept.
Wouldn't take again. Slightly easier than 103, though that may be because of the structure rather than because of the content.
Yes, If you are at all curious about physics.
You should really only take this course if you need to; there are many more fulfilling courses at Princeton.
You will survive, eventually. Just work through the pain.
You're probably taking this class because you have to, so just do it.
awesome
do practice problems from the chapters the exams are on in the 50s and 60s because they tend to be on the exams.
go to precept
if you don't need it as a requirement, i don't think you would find it very interesting.
study everything
take it especially if it's with Professor Tully.
take with a different lecturer

way better than PHY 103; Tully is super nice and chill about everything; Lyman Page is a legend and a must-have as a preceptor (MIT PhD, Wikipedia page, Shaw Prize) since he really engages you in the material and is extremely nice. Also, Laurentiu as a lab AI is the classic -- you'll need to have him as a lab AI to know.
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This calculus-based course is primarily geared to students majoring in engineering and physics, but is also well suited to majors in other sciences. The goal of the course is to develop an understanding of the fundamental laws of physics, in particular, electricity and magnetism, with applications to electronics, optics, and new challenges in renewable energy sources.

title: Innovating Across Technology, Business, and Marketplaces
reviews: Absolutely necessary for anyone looking to be more than a technician or developer in the technology industry. The mentalities and lessons gained through this course will definitely shape the way I think in the future about my career and the company I work for. Guest lectures are FANTASTIC and the JP's are solid learning material as well. Find a group of people you trust early on and think lots about the company. Don't sweat the write-ups beyond a few hours of deep thinking. Invest time and effort in the reports.
Definitely take this course -- you get great insights into what it takes to start and run a startup. Where else will you get to hear from Jack Dorsey in such a small setting?!

Fun course; the professor is interesting, the normal lectures are thought-provoking, and the guest lecturers are often famous. Grading is haphazard, so I would recommend PDFing the course. (Although I don't know how generous the course ends up being, with final grades.)
Great P/D/F course. The guest speakers are some of the greatest minds and biggest people in their fields.
If you are in CS and want to do a startup, you must not miss the chance of taking this course.
It's a great course with a light workload, except for the midterm and final paper. Take it if you are interested in entrepreneurship and want amazing guest lecturers.
Look into it - if it seems like there will be good guest speakers and you like the idea of a project, go for it.
Make sure you are interested in startups, since that is what 95% of this class is about.
PDF this class for much less stress, otherwise the arbitrary grading is annoying.
Professor Singh seems like a good person and has great stories to tell (and also brings in some cool guest speakers), but the course lacks focus and is very disorganized.
Really interesting course, but gets repetitive after a while. The midterm and final take forever, but other than that, its not that hard.  Gets annoying sometimes though.
TAKE IT. Hopefully the kinks in the course will get ironed out, but not only are some of the guest lecturers phenomenal, but JP himself is a joy to listen to, and you get a lot out of every lecture.
TAKE IT. You learn tons and the workload is very reasonable.

TAKE THIS COURSE -- Cannot emphasize enough. One of my favorite courses so far, with absolutely fantastic guest speakers. Great guest speakers. Jack Dorsey, Padma Warrior, Peter Fenton, Fred Wilson, Paul Graham, John Hennessey. Look these people up.
Take it if you know you want to be an entrepreneur, or if you think you might want to someday. If you're more interested in big companies, this course is still interesting but not as useful.
Take it if you're interested in startups
Take this course. It is a very interesting course and it is probably one of the only courses at Princeton that truly teaches entrepreneurship.

The lectures in COS448 have a humanist perspective and are really interesting, but most of the work in the class is a Lean Launchpad-style project graded based on wholly different expectations which are not explained in detail. The instructors provided several processes to introduce objectivity grading the project but subsequently disregarded them; I spoke with many students who received overwhelming positive feedback about ideas that they had already lost confidence in -- on the other hand, the lectures (both by the instructor and guests) were among the best I have ever attended at Princeton, and I learned a lot. I'd take this course P/D/F, take the lectures seriously, and chill out for the rest of the class.

This course is definitely a mixed bag.  The guest lectures are great and you'll get to hear from some pretty famous people like Paul Graham and Fred Wilson, who give really excellent advice.  However, the course as a whole is fairly disorganized, and instructions for the assignments are often very ambiguous and released very late.  The course also focuses too much on the role of CTOs in large tech companies, which isn't really relevant to college students who probably won't occupy those kinds of roles for many years.  While you can learn some interesting things in this course, ultimately I think you'd do better reading some of the excellent literature out there on startups and actually trying your hand at starting one yourself.

This is a good course to take if you're a COS major who's looking for a relaxed way to get a departmental. This class is very little work - there's a bit of reading which you can safely skip, a couple of short responses due every week, and a final project (which is the biggest component of the course, but isn't /that/ big).

You'll learn some potentially useful stuff about the mechanics of entrepreneurship (raising capital, hiring people, ...) but don't expect it to be life-changing.

The guest lecturers are a big draw for this class; in the past we've had such luminaries as Jack Dorsey and Meg Whitman. However, there's no way to know in advance who the guests will be, and some are definitely better than others.
Very good course. Definitely take it if you are at all interested in startups or working at the juncture of technology and business.

Worth it for the wonderful guest lectures. The structure of the course -- the regular lectures with Prof. Singh and the memos, which seemed irrelevant -- could be majorly improved; grading is mysterious and never clarified. But still take it if you're interested in startups

You gain valuable industry insight in this course. Overall, this a good course for entrepreneurs, but guest speakers tend to overlap in their talking points. Professor Singh also challenges you to always think about "why".
prereqs: COS 217 or COS 226 or equivalent..
descrip: Course teaches engineering students about issues tackled by leading Chief Technology Officers: the technical visionaries and/or managers who innovate at the boundaries of technology and business by understanding both deeply, and who are true partners to the CEO, not just implementers of business goals. Focus will be on thinking like a CTO (of a startup and a large company) from technology and business perspectives, and on software and Internet-based businesses. Industry-leading guest speakers provide perspectives too.

title: Materials in Civil Engineering
reviews: Good course, Professor Scherer makes materials and atoms interesting.
Most likely you have to take this course-- its not too bad if you start the lab reports early!
Only take this if you need to or are significantly interested in the subject.
Reading the notes is more important than the lectures. Give yourself time to do the lab reports, because they take time!
This is a great course! Really pay attention in lecture and ask questions. Professor Scherer is so nice and you'll learn a lot more by engaging than reading the notes later.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Lectures on structure and properties of building materials including concrete, steel, asphalt, stone and wood; fracture mechanics; strength testing; mechanisms of deterioration (corrosion; freeze-thaw cycles, pollution). Labs on brittle fracture, heat treatment of steel, strength of concrete, mechanical properties of wood.

title: Advanced Hebrew Language and Style II
reviews: Take it if Esther's teaching!!!!
Take it. You'll enjoy it and learn if you want to.
descrip: Readings in Hebrew culture, exploring the underlying tensions in identity among Israeli Jews: tensions in religious identity (ie. Ashkenazim versus Sephardim/Ultra Orthodox (Chareidim) versus Secularists), political identity, age/generational identity, and personal identity. We will analyze these issues within the context of contemporary short stories, modern poetry, newspaper articles, and cinema/theater.

title: Readings in Classic Chinese Short Stories
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of reading and writing.
Don't expect to improve your chinese.
I strongly recommend this course to anyone who's interested in improving their Chinese skills and especially those who want a basic exposure to classical Chinese. Also Professor Chou is awesome.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning about Ming Dynasty short stories and you feel that your Chinese is extremely strong and that you possibly have experience with classical Chinese. Try to do the readings and take notes to remember salient points from each week. Stay on top of the weekly written assignments.
If you can handle the readings, take it!
If you enjoy practicing Chinese, improving your writing, and reading some really interesting/edgy short stories, you'll really like this class.  Professor Zhou is awesome!

Keep in mind that this course is often taken by people with an extensive background in Chinese. For example, a huge portion of the class had either been born in China or spent a significant amount of time there. It's good, because they really take the discussion to the next level, but also a little disheartening.
Don't let this prevent you from taking the course, though. If you have any interest in Chinese society, history, culture, literature, or language, this is worth it!
Take it!
Take this if you are proficient in Chinese but want to extend your language skills

This is a really fun course to take, if you aren't afraid of fairly large amounts of Chinese reading. There are English translations to all the readings, but the class isn't really worth taking if you're not going to read the original Chinese stuff. Class and precept are fairly easy, main challenge is just finishing the reading on time and also weekly short essays.
descrip: Focuses on reading and discussing selections from Feng Menglong's Sanyan, the most popular and well-known collection of Classic Chinese short stories published in the late sixteenth century. One class, two hours of discussion, conducted in Chinese. Prerequisite: three or more years of modern Chinese, or instructor's permission.

title: Introduction to Global Pentecostalism
descrip: Pentecostalism is the fastest growing religious movement in the world, spreading especially in Africa, Asia, and the Americas, having a major impact on the religious, social, and economic practices in those regions. This course looks into the religious and cultural sources of the movement from its birth in Los Angeles in 1906, focusing on such distinctive features as healing, expressive bodily worship, "speaking in tongues," and its special appeal to people on the margins of society.

title: Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: It's the usual advice -- Work hard on dynamic optimization, and the application of dynamic optimization techniques to all sorts of (possibly non-standard) problems.
Nothing.
Work hard.
descrip: This course is the second term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include classical and Keynesian theories of cyclical fluctuations; the determination of employment and real wages; credit markets and financial stability; and stabilization policy.

title: Arts of Protest, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Retrieval, Discovery, and Delivery
reviews: A bit dry, but does have a lot of good content if you're interested in it.
A good course that lets you sit back and explore some critical thinking on the subject, rather than cramming problem sets and programming assignments into the semester.
A little bit dry and go to office hours before turning in problem sets, but all in all, a good class as far as computer science departmentals go.
Don't take it just for a departmental. If you are fascinated with the topic, go for it. However, I warn you to try to take it with someone besides LaPaugh because the lectures aren't so great.
Good class to try out if you haven't taken many upper-level COS classes. But beware it's really boring.

I found about half of the material very interesting, and the other half fairly dull. This class does have a final project which is pretty open-ended, so you have the chance to build a cool application if that's what you want.
Interesting course. Not too much work, especially compared to other COS classes.
It doesn't take a ton of time at the beginning of the semester. Be sure to start the project early.
Material was interesting but problem sets were a lot of work. Lectures were not very engaging either.

She seems to not care that much about the class. She knows the material just fine but somehow makes it seem dramatically more boring than it is. Information retrieval is a very cool subject but this class seemed focused in all of the wrong places. A more enthusiastic and engaging teacher could have made it into a great course
Take it, but definitely go see her for office hours and such instead of going to class.
This is an interesting course. Do the problem sets they will help you in the exam.
prereqs: COS 226.
descrip: This course examines the methods used to gather, organize and search for information in large digital collections (e.g. web search engines). We study classic techniques of indexing documents and searching text and also new algorithms that exploit properties of the Web (e.g. links) social networks and other digital collections, including multimedia collections. Techniques include those for relevance and ranking of documents, exploiting user history, and information clustering. We also examine systems aspects of search technology: how distributed computing and storage are used to make information delivery efficient.

title: Laboratory in Molecular Biology
reviews: Bleh. Do it if you have to. Learned some cool things, useful for thesis.
Definitely try to keep up with the experiment (and experimental rationale) at every point. Don't fall behind! Explore some primary literature, you'd be surprised at how useful some papers can be.
Definitely work on the lab reports as often as possible. I did at least an hour a day, and my drafts were still a little shaky.

Do not be afraid to ask the TAs if you have questions about the projects! It is better to confirm a procedure than do it wrong and mess up the experiment. Also, make sure you understand the concepts behind each experiment!!

Don't take this course unless you have to. Study for quizzes. Get lots of people to read your lab reports before submitting them. Take draft workshops seriously. Understanding the rationale for your experiments will help you write a better lab report.
Good course.
I would only take this class if you are a MOL major. The lab reports are a lot of work.

If you are taking this course, you probably had no other choice. Anyway, just make sure you have your drafts written by the due date each week, it will save you a lot of time later, and grant you a good grade.

If you're not a MOL major, RUN AWAY NOW. The worst part about this course is that you feel lost ALL THE TIME. You have to figure your way out at your own grade's expense. So much work is involved, and you hate every second of it. Never again.
In order to get an A, you would probably need to talk to every single grader beforehand. This is clearly not possible, so you just need to be perfect.
It's not bad, enjoy the labwork.

Just shut up and bear through it. As long as the Molecular Biology department continues its mission to make its concentrators as miserable as possible, this course will be problematic. Again, I want to stress that the instructors are not to blame.
Make sure to read Gammie's 2007 paper
Only take if MOL major

Only take this course if you are a MOL concentrator (there are much better STL's for that distribution requirement). If you do take this course, prepare to whine and cry over two 25-pg lab reports; they suck both your time and soul. Plus, the grading was very strange.
Put time and effort into your drafts beforehand and keep on track!

Since you probably have to take this class as a molecular biology major, or as a substitute for another class - you might actually want to consider other core labs - in the case that it doesn't change next year, get ready for a very poorly organized course and do not harbor too high expectations. The biggest advise is probably that you do not waste your time with showing your drafts to TA's but take them directly to Prof. Snyder because she is the one probably who prepares the rubric. There is still going to be subjectivity in your grading, because one TA thinks this way, the other that way, but at least you can argue later that Prof. Snyder read your draft and made such and such comments. For the quizzes, focus more on the lab manual than the lectures and be ready to catch tricks. Do not expect a generous curve, I don't even know if they give out 30% A's in this course. For your own sake and for a good grade, look at the primary literature they provide very carefully and try to produce a paper similar to that one. Try to ask for help whenever you can, I would say from Prof. Snyder in this case. Try to attend lectures, they are helpful. I really do hope they revise the course and make it a better one.
Start early and use the TAs and professors for help. Half of the battle with the lab reports is figuring out what you need to include so ask questions and try to figure that out early.
Start the lab report early! The instructors are very specific about what needs to be in there, so in order to get a good grade, show one of them a draft to give you feedback!
Take if required. Start the lab reports early. They take forever.

Take it! I mean, you probably have to but its a fun class with only two graded assignments which means most of the year is a breeze. Teaches a lot about paper writing and paper reading by proxy. Dont forget to make sure your lab journal is well organized and has imaged pasted inside!
Take it, and just be ready to do the drafts on time.

The lab reports are the most significant chunk of your grade. Start early on the lab reports and don't fall behind! You won't be able to do it all in the span of 1-2 days, so keep this in mind when you plan out how to distribute your workload.

The two lab reports are stressful, obviously, but if you partner with a friend and have friends in your lab section, Core Lab can actually be super fun! I enjoyed it a lot, even though the grading is quite harsh. Also, Aleks and the TAs are awesome
This class is a required course and takes up much of your time, but it's not a bad course if you pay attention.
This course will give you a very good foundation for any future work in molecular biology.
Try to get as much feed back on your drafts as possible.

Unfortunately there is no way around taking this course for MOL majors. This course needs MAJOR reforms. For one, scientific creativity should be encouraged rather than attention to trivial details that that would EASILY be corrected during peer review. scientific insight is basically IGNORED and the graders just want you to include mindless regurgitation of controls and infuriatingly complex and hard-to-guess criteria for how much detail to include in the materials and methods section as well as some TRULY arbitrary expectations for what is absolutely important information to include in an introduction. If nothing is done to correct this program before you have to take this course, you're going to be in for a frustrating time.
Unless you need this for a degree in the MOL department, I would suggest looking elsewhere for an intensive laboratory class.

While there was some hiccups getting the first lab report ready, the second lab report came along more smoothly - which is the point of core lab anyway! It was a great lab course, and taught you much much more than the MOL214 labs. This course really prepares you for your thesis if you are MOL and while it is time-consuming, I don't think there is a much better way that it could be taught. Professor Snyder is an excellent lecturer!
Why would you ever take this course if you weren't a MOL bio major?
You will learn everything you need to do bio research, but it'll be a hard, time-consuming course.

You're probably taking this because you have to. It's an interesting class, but there's a lot of work. Just keep on track and reach out to the professor when you need help. Prof. Snyder is super friendly when you go talk to her.

a great alternative core lab option for chem majors, especially if you're doing something biochem or synthesis related for independent work. the instructors are extremely helpful and work hard to make sure the grading is objective.
prereqs: MOL 342 (or permission). This course is required for Molecular Biology Majors..
descrip: The major objective of the course is to introduce students to a variety of tools required to conduct independent research in the field of molecular biology. While completing original research, students will employ a number of techniques that are used by molecular biologists, molecular geneticists, and biochemists. Upon completion of the course, students should have gained an understanding of how, when and why certain techniques and skills are used in a research setting. In addition, students will learn to write a research report modeled on the scientific literature.

title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
reviews: All the material is presented through lectures.  Go to them.  Then, review your notes after lecture.  It's worth the extra effort.
Excellent, definitely take this!
Good class, but challenging
If you are interested in quantum computing, its algorithms, and some implementation, I recommend that you take this course. Professor Lyon was a great lecturer.
If you want to learn more about QM in a decent way, take it
Keep up with lectures, go to office hours

Lyon is okay, not the best lecturer but he really cared about his students.  I'd say take it because the material is interesting, but get a good book (Mermin is a good one) and sign up for Berkeley's QC course on Coursera.  It will make it much easier to follow along in lectures.  Problem sets didn't take too much time, but were pretty useful in learning the material.  Try hard.  This class can be difficult.
Quantum computing is awesome.
TAKE THIS COURSE! I highly recommend Lyon and the course in general. PS... Lyon didn't have Friday class even though it's listed on ICE, so I got away with no Friday classes this semester!
Very interesting field. Be prepared to find textbooks to study with, but its worth it.
prereqs: A previous quantum mechanics course will not be required. Requires sophomore linear algebra at the level of MAT 202, 204, 217 or the equivalent..
descrip: This course will introduce the matrix form of quantum mechanics and discuss the concepts underlying the theory of quantum information. Some of the important algorithms will be discussed, as well as physical systems which have been suggested for quantum computing.

title: Early Japanese History
descrip: The World of the Tale of the Heike . Using a classical warrior tale, the Tale of the Heike , as its central text, the course explores social, political, and cultural developments of Japan from the 9th to the 16th centuries. Themes include development of state in early Japan, city and structure of Heian (Kyoto), flowering of court culture and emergence of warrior power, religion and art, and Japan's contacts with the world. The course aims to help students better understand the historical background of the Heike and to illuminate the cultural context in which it was produced and appreciated over the centuries.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Management of Public Organizations
descrip: Course equips students with knowledge of management and leadership concepts to perform successfully and responsibly in public organizations. Course begins with a discussion of the nature of public administration and moves to concepts of organizational theory, organizational structure, administrative reforms, and decision-making mechanisms. Course also examines the people side of government organizations as well as management and leadership roles within organizations. Recent management innovations in the federal government will be discussed and considered.

title: Intermediate Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian II
descrip: A continuation of BCS 105. Advanced-level class with emphasis on oral and written communication; reading literary texts of interest to students; films

title: Early China - Authorship in Early China
descrip: We examine the presence of the figure and voice of the "author" in early Chinese poetry, historiography, philosophy, and other writings. We discuss the composite nature of early texts; questions of composition and performance; the construction of paradigmatic authorial personas such as Confucius, the Duke of Zhou, Qu Yuan, and Sima Qian over time; the transformation of "authorship" with the rise of the imperial state; and the function of the "author" in the creation of early Chinese literary, intellectual, and political history. Readings are in primary courses, that is, classical Chinese.

title: Seminar in Medieval French Literature - Voices in Medieval French Narratives
descrip: This seminar will bring together literary and linguistic approaches in an interdisciplinary interrogation of the idea and manifestations of 'voice' in French literary texts from the twelfth to thirteenth centuries. The notion of 'voice' will be introduced both as a complex - yet elusive - concept spanning many different theoretical approaches (Genettian narratology, enunciation theory, gender studies, reception theory) and in its medieval materiality (representation of orality, use of vernacular vs Latin, manuscript paratexts). The seminar will then be divided in three main parts: 1) Voice and Genre; 2) Voice and Gender; 3) Voice as Concept.

title: Integrated Engineering Science Laboratory
reviews: Actually, the labs themselves were pretty interesting. During labs, Mike was very helpful. However, the grading ruined everything, and if you tried to talk to Mike outside of lab, he could be very hard to get a hold of. Grading is negative, not positive, i.e. there is no regard for the overall quality of your lab, just points taken off for random things that the grader decides is important. This means that even if your write a really great report, the grade is a total crapshoot. Given how much work is put into these lab reports (and however smart you are, it will be a lot of work), you would expect more care in the grading. The whole affair leaves a bad taste in your moth.

Are the handouts a bit rote and dull and sometimes only partially legible?  Yes.  Were the lab reports, especially when it was 6-8 hours a week for a period of time, sometimes a pain to write?  Yes.  But at the same time, were Keith Moored's classes a very useful tool to help better explain the underlying concepts behind the experiments?  Yes.  Was Mike Vocaturo an almost-perfect lab instructor who answered questions, made sure you weren't left hanging, and incorporated fun anecdotes into the procedures?  Yes.  And was the independent lab a fairly stress-free, worthwhile, and fun final project?  Yes it was.  As shown, the major pros outweigh the major cons.  Yet I'm pretty sure 99% of the people who take this course take it as requirement anyway.
Because there are no specific rubics as to how the TAs grade your work, it's always a good idea to speak to the TA about the write up just so you can get an idea what he/she is looking for!
Decent course
Expect to spend many hours on the lab reports and still not receive good grades on any of them.
Find a good lab group you work well with and will also enjoy working with to make those late night lab report sessions a better experience.
For most of you, the final project will be your first taste of independent work. It's definitely something to look forward to!
Have to take for MAE
I don't see why you would take this other than as a departmental.

I'm sorry. You obviously have to take this course. But if you don't have to take it, don't take it. One day it will be over and you'll look back with miserable memories about everything except Mike. Love Mike while you've got him- he'll make your life infinitely better (or as much better as it could be, at least).
If you're MAE you have to take it.

If you're considering taking this course, chances are you don't really have much of a choice in the matter as an MAE. That being said TAKE IT. The staff is spectacular, the coursework teaches you the empirical proof of the physical relationships you're learning about in your other courses, and best of all, you learn about digital logic!
If you're here you're MAE

If you're taking this, you've probably survived the thermo labs. First off, congrats! Second, spring lab is much better than fall lab, though plan your time carefully because the lab reports will take about 10 hours each week.
It's a lot of work in this class; just power through it and don't spend too much time chasing error propogation.
It's really up to the student to put in the time and go online to find information to learn how to write a lab
Lab is the worst part of sophomore year. Unfortunately you have to suck it up.
Labs can be interesting. Reports fucking suck. Did not get much from this class.

Mike will explicitly favor the athletes, so if you are one, good for you. Otherwise, just don't get on his bad side. He knows his job and will help you out if you aren't one of those people who keeps pestering him. 
Start your lab reports in time. Error analysis will kill you if you don't.
Only take if a requirement.
Plan on your lab reports taking more time than you think. Wouldn't suggest this class to a non engineer.
Pretty good course, the labs were a lot of fun.
Read the lab instructions way ahead of time!
Talk to Mike if you need any help.
There's really no good advice to do well on this course. Just take the most out of it.
This course is poorly run. Stick to the lab report website they give you as much as possible. Ask Mike questions since he can be very helpful.

Try to follow the online guide all you want, not sure it'll save you from arbitrary grading though. Definitely work together on the lab reports and ask for advice from previous weeks about your current lab.
Try to get an outline down for writing lab reports early in the year or else they will take obscene amounts of time.

You have to take it anyway. In all seriousness, please don't waste time trying to write good tech ref sheets and lab reports, because the grades are assigned in such a random and arbitrary fashion that any improvements you make will likely have no effect on your grade. In fact, certain suggested "improvements" may be viewed by subsequent graders as errors. And good luck finding the grader to negotiate points back.

Also don't waste time on the independent lab report. The median grade this year was a 98. That means half of the grades were within +/- 1% of each other. Do you really think all the labs were that well-done? Have fun with the lab, but don't worry about the report. The independent lab itself was great and very enriching.

I can only conclude that this course is some sort of bizarre MAE hazing ritual.
You have to, but you'll love it.
You probably will take it only if you have to, but really know what's going on behind each lab it's important knowledge.

You'll only take this course as an MAE requirement. Write labs clearly and start the reports early, and use Mike and Keith to your advantage. They know what they're talking about; you just have to ask for help.
only take this course if it's a requirement. it teaches you how to analyze data, albeit in a bad manner. it's a large time commitment and not too enlightening, unfortunately.
start lab reports early, ask questions
prereqs: MAT 104, MAT 202 (may be taken concurrently), MAE 222 (must be taken concurrently). Laboratory report grades from MAE 221 fall semester will be incorporated into final grade of MAE 224.
descrip: Students will conduct a series of prepared experiments throughout the year that will culminate in an independent project of the students' design involving fluid mechanics, thermodynamics and data acquisition tools. Preliminary experiments focus on pressure and Bernoulli's equation. Concepts learned will be applied in subsequent labs involving expanding flows and lift and drag measurements. Experiments will include internal and external viscous flows. Digital electronics including combinatorial and sequential logic, analog-to-digital conversion, digital-to-analog conversion, digital telemetry. Coupled oscillators will be covered.

title: Latin American Politics through Film
prereqs: Classes will be taught in English, but basic knowledge of Spanish would be desirable..
descrip: Latin American society, politics and economics have undergone dramatic transformations over the last 50 years. In this course, we will study the changing political landscape of these countries, leveraging the medium of popular media, including cinema and TV. We will watch and discuss films that portray central features of Latin American political life, such as colonialism, guerilla movements, military dictatorships and their aftermath, crime, corruption, poverty, drug trafficking and violence. In addition to readings, these films will provide a backdrop to animate our investigation of democracy and development in the region.

title: Structural Solid State Chemistry
prereqs: General chemistry or Advanced Placement; one course in thermodynamics..
descrip: Point group and space group symmetry, structure determination by x-ray, and neutron diffraction. Introduction to electron microscropy. Important structure types in metals and oxides. Pauling Rules, solid solutions, nonstoichiometry, and defect chemistry.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews: AMAZING. TAKE THIS COURSE.
Actually read the novel
Definitely keep up with vocabulary. It'll ease your ability to pick up the language.
Great class. Luis is a great instructor and you will come out of it feeling as though you've gained a better understanding of the Portuguese language and culture. Highly recommend.
I would advise another student to be active in class discussion since that will lead to great improvement.

I would advise the students to really study the grammatical structures on your own, and to also look for sources of further practice outside the class environment and resources. It will really help you develop a better understanding of the language and its different uses.
Put effort into every homework assignment; there are lots of assignments so every little thing counts. Don't be afraid to ask for help because Megwen is a great resource.
Significantly more work than POR 108. Otherwise, it's a good class.
TAKE IT. Life changing experience.
Take it! Be on top of the readings of "Azul Corvo" because they can be long. Also, take notes in the book as you go along so that you can remember your thought processes for the final paper.
Take it! Portuguese is a very interesting and important language, and it's great to study at an accelerated pace.
Take it, but take the class seriously and study every night.
Take it. No question
Take it. Take it. Take it.
Take the course, but read the book and meet regularly with the teacher to discuss your exams/papers.
Take this course!
The work isn't overwhelming yet you should be ready to devote time to it every night
This course is more time consuming than expected. It is not an easy way to round out senior year.
do it.
make sure you have time to devote to the class if you want to do really well.
practice by yourself!
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Junior Seminars
prereqs: Compulsory course for departmental majors in the fall of their junior year..
descrip: A special section of HIS 400 for junior majors returning from study abroad and for sophomores intending to major in History and to spend the fall term or year abroad. Normally required of all juniors in the fall term, the seminar serves to introduce majors to the tools, methods and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This seminar will concentrate on readings of colonialism, and encounters penned by adventurers, scholars and officials active in Asia and Africa between 1800 and 1950. Students interested in taking this course must contact History's Undergraduate Administrator (etta@princeton.edu).

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - Political and Economic Development in Africa
reviews: I would recommend this course to anyone looking to fill a Politics Distribution requirement and/or interested in development.
Maybe...
Take it for a more comprehensive exposure to social and political issues in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Take it!
prereqs: Introduction to Statistics, Introduction to Microeconomics, or Introduction to Comparative Politics.
descrip: This course covers major current issues in political economy of development with special focus on Africa. The course will be structured in three parts. The first part will cover broad macro political economy issues (e.g. democracy and development, historical legacies, Resource curse). The second part will focus on micro issues (e.g. property rights, clientelism, electoral accountability). The final part will draw mostly from the experimental literature in political economy and discuss policy prescriptions to improve development prospects (e.g. institutional reforms, information campaigns, foreign aid).

title: Topics in Differential Equations - Global Solutions of Nonlinear Evolutions
prereqs: For advanced level undergrads and graduate students..
descrip: We will discuss the question of existence of global smooth solutions of certain quasilinear evolution equations. These equations include plasma models and the water wave problem. The main techniques include energy methods and semilinear harmonic analysis.

title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology
reviews: 8:30 AM is just as bad as you think it will be. There is a lot of memorizing.
8:30 am is brutal, but try to always make it to class. It's really hard to learn material from a lecture that you weren't there for.
A ton of information. Choose wisely.
A tremendous amount of memorization -- not bad if you keep up, but a world of pain otherwise.
An overall fun course. It doesn't have to be a ton of work if you don't make it to be, as so much of the course is optional. Will need to work hard to get an A though.
Be prepared to work hard, but it is a very well taught course and a lot of fun if you find the material interesting and want to learn it.
Be prepared to work hard.  If you're interested in the sciences, this is a good introductory course to take.  Everyone involved is approachable, so don't be afraid to ask questions.

Be sure to go to all the review sessions and really take advantage of Dr. Rigel's office hours because he is really good at explaining the material. Keep up--record the lectures and take diligent notes.

Best way to do well is to sit there for half an hour everyday and just memorize the information in the slide. Otherwise you'll cram and freak out like all the other premeds in the class. This is a competitive class.
Bonnie Bassler is amazing
Cool as the class is, they do seem to emphasize memorizing little, specific things... which I personally just do not like because rote memorization is not learning.

Definitely take this class. Although it may be competitive (many pre-meds!), if you work at it, you will do well! Prepare for exams early and attend the review sessions/problem set reviews. They were often helpful.

Definitely take this course if you're interested in mol bio! However, if you're not a mol major or premed, you will be competing with mols and premeds, so just keep that in mind. However, if you're interested in mol, it's a great class. Awesome professors (shoutout to Bonnie Bassler and Mala Murthy) and very exciting material! Labs are pretty chill, too.
Definitely the most manageable of the pre-med courses!
Do all the readings and be on top of the material. Go to lecture and review every week. It's too much material to put off before exams.
Do it. Great course. Awesome information. Hugely important field.
Do not focus on the book, understand every single slide. If you are a freshman taking this course, make use of all the resources, go to office hours, find a TA that could help you.

Do the optional problem sets. Go to the weekly lecture review sessions and problem set review sessions. Find a group to study with before exams. Make sure you understand what's going on in lab, because that's very helpful for understanding certain lecture material.
Do the problem sets every week, study weeks ahead of time for tests (or study new material every week)
Do the readings. Skip lectures, no point of compromising sleep.
Do try to wake up and go...
Do well on the labs
Don't be afraid to use your resources, like the review sessions.

Don't procrastinate in this course! There's way too much material and it's impossible to do even relatively or satisfactorily well on your exams if you cram -- do all the problem sets as they come out each week, even if they're optional. Also make sure to attend the review sessions and any Q&A sessions because they are extremely helpful.
Don't take it Freshman Year. Also, don't think that because you have AP credits in Bio, it will be easy. It's not.
Don't take it unless you have to. It's horrible.
Don't take it.
Don't take this course.

Go to lectures. Don't buy the textbook. Take good notes, and check your understanding as you go. The material is not hard as long as you learn it slowly - you won't be able to memorize it all in 2 hours. Try and have fun.
Go to lectures. Don't fall asleep. Go to office hours and get help for lab and before lectures.
Go to office hours and do the problem sets because they are very helpful for the midterms!
Go to review sessions and the problem set sessions. Maybe one or the other if you're really pressed for time.
Go to the lectures.
Go to the problem set/review sessions!
Go to the weekly review sessions.
Good course to take
Good luck. You will need it.
Great course to take, isn't too tough. There are a lot of premeds in this class though
Great course. Definitely difficult, and its hard to stay awake during the 8:30 lectures, but I really enjoyed it
I enjoyed this course. The time sucks, but the labs can be fun and I thought the material was interesting. High amount of memorization though.

I liked this class because of the material and the instructors, but that doesn't translate to my doing well because I realized I am apparently horrible at memorizing, and that's basically what this class is.
I personally am not a fan of biology, but for the most part, the material is straightforward and presented well. A decent course overall.
I recommend this course for any student who is interested in biology.

I think almost everyone in my class was premed, which made it very competitive. In spite of your past experience in bio, i.e. AP and such, you have to really pay attention in class. Take good notes. They become very handy when the exams come. Don't focus on the book (I did not flip a page for the second half of the semester). Start preparing for the exams days in advance. Pay special attention at the beginning of the semester since you get a lot of information thrown at you, whereas the second half is more in depth on certain concept.s

I think this is a great course but definitely reach out to your TAs, go over your midterms with them, and try and pace yourself and do the readings. The course changes from year to year as the staff is very accommodating of students' desire to change, so I would say the best thing to do is to rely on the teaching staff as a resource. It's an interesting class and you should do well should you put in the effort and ask for help.
I took this class as a requirement, and did not particularly love it. There are many interesting topics, but unless you love biology it might not be the best class to take if you don't need to.
I took this class for pre-med and didn't expect much. It was actually much more interesting than I expected.
I would advise students that the class requires quite a bit of effort but that effort will be well worth it in the end.
I would definitely recommend this course. It's been a great experience, and it's made me seriously consider majoring in MOL.
I would recommend taking this course because it requires higher-level thinking above rote memorization. There is always help available, but due prepare to work hard!

I would recommend the class.  If you're not pre-med, you may want to take an easier STL.  There will be a lot of memorization and this year it was extremely disappointing because the final was not a proper assessment.  The lectures cover a lot of information so be prepared to try to process it after lecture is done.  Also, the grades are really competitive because it is a class filled with pre-meds.
I would recommend this course if you have an interest in the material or you love science.
I would recommend this course only to those who are pre med, or those who absolutely love biology.
I would recommend this course. Interesting and well taught. The virology module taught by Professor Enquist was great as well.
I would say DEFINITELY go to the review sessions and problem set sessions because they really help you solidify your understanding of the material.

I would take this course even if you don't have to. It's a great STL. Labs aren't very stressful, and the class is well organized. There's always some resource to help you. Don't slack off because some of the material is similar to AP Bio. You'll be really lost later on.
If it weren't for the 8:30 time-slot I would strongly recommend this course.  The material was genuinely interesting and presented in an engaging manner.

If you are considering majoring in molecular biology, then I would recommend this class. If you are taking it for fun, though, I would not recommend it, because this class moves at a very very fast speed and you are expected to understand everything very quickly before we move on. The lab reports are a large time commitment, and expect to spend two weeks studying for a test and then getting below a 50%, since the material is very difficult. If you have no biology background, then I would definitely take MOL101 before 214, because this class really expects you to have a strong foundation in bio. That being said, if you know you want to go into biology, this is a great class and you will be surprised by the amount of things you have learned by the end of the semester.
If you don't have an interest in biology, MOL, or something like that, don't take this as your STL. But, you'll probably enjoy this course if you're majoring in MOL.

If you have an interest in biology, this is a great course. Although there is a lot of material, the exams actually test problem solving to emphasize understanding instead of just brute memorization. Go to the lectures and study primarily from the powerpoints and your notes.
If you have to take it for your major, it's really not that bad. If you don't have to take it for your major, there are probably more interesting and engaging STL courses out there.
If you have to take it, take it.
If you're wondering if you're interested in molecular biology, or are definitely interested in molecular biology, it's a great course to take!
Interesting but a pain due to premeds

It actually isn't necessary to go to lectures, because everything is on lecturetools; just use all of the resources available, and this is a highly cumulative course so trying to memorize everything last minute is almost impossible.
It was a good class overall
It was fine. If you have to take it for a prerequisite, you have to take it, you have no choice.

It's a good STL for non-majors. It doesn't take too much work, and the material is pretty interesting. If you're MOL or CBE, you have to take it anyway. It's generally an enjoyable course. Just get ready to memorize a lot. But it's not solely memorization. Tests consist of a considerable amount of application and critical thinking. So it's not as easy as one would think, but still a very do-able course.
It's a pre-med req, but if you like bio, it should be pretty interesting.  Be open minded about lectures, and make sure to memorize ALL THE NOTES for the exams.  Every single word.
It's a premed requirement, but it's too large and unengaging. Didn't feel like a lot of the people cared at all
It's an intro course so there is a great amount of information. It's all very interesting though.
It's early so hard to stay awake. But labs are cool.
It's well-taught and interesting. LectureTools makes it easy to follow along in lectures, which, though at 8:30am, are definitely worth going to.
Its not bad if you take good lecture notes. Early mornings suck but the class isn't hard. Do the problem sets.
Its very early in the morning!
Jaclyn Schwalm was actually the best. Make sure you get her and ask her tons of questions. Also make sure you go to lecture and take notes. The tests are mostly lecture based.
Keep up with the material. There isn't a lot of work to turn in, so it is easy to get behind. The problem sets and past exams are useful in studying for the exams.
Keep up with the reading and lectures. The material builds up quickly.
Keep up with the reading, go to lecture, and do the problem sets. Otherwise, you will do poorly.

Labs are chill. You get 45 minute breaks where you can go to late meal. Also, exams are only ever on certain material from lecture (never the book). Make sure you go to the review sessions so you know what is important.
Learn the material on your own. Its interesting and lectures won't help much.
Make sure you have time to dedicate to this course and study well for exams.
Make sure you start preparing early for exams--they are very specific.
Make sure you study the specific terms and titles on the power point slides. These will ultimately be more useful in the exams.

Mol is tough of course, but if you read and do the problem sets it helps a lot.  Take it for a pre-req or pre-med, but other than that you may want to find an easier science course.  But if you have to take it it's a good class.
Never having taken anything more than freshman bio, relatively easy course.
Not super difficult for a "premed course". Go to lecture.
Only take it if you have to. Not very stimulating.
Only take this course if you are Pre-Med or set on majoring in Biology.  Unless the presentation of the information is changed, it is not enlightening enough to spend so much time on.
Only take this course if you are interested in it.  It is a great course but you need to be willing to put the effort into it.
Pay more attention during lectures and take good notes. You'll need to memorize it later.
Probably a requirement if you're considering it, but I enjoyed the class.
Read and look at the slides regularly. I would repeat this 100 times if I could without being obnoxious.
Really Boring class.
Really pay attention during lecture and take good notes.

Record lectures. Without Bonnie Bassler teaching you this course, the usual professors will do little to engage you. At times it will be hard to follow, so make sure you go back over your recordings and pick up what you missed. Don't fret if you miss lecture or sleep through/during it - the course is like that and isn't really that enjoyable. Don't take this unless you want to go further in Molecular Biology or other related academic fields. It's honestly not worth it, and if you just want to get some basic exposure to biology take MOL 101. The students in this class are all very competitive, and it can be an emotionless/disengaging learning environment at times. After all, it's a premed/bio weed out class - what else would you expect?
Study consistently to keep up.
Study hard. Learn from Young Kang and Dowon Dan Kim
Study more than the day before for exams. Pay attention in lecture, and take full advantage of lecture tools.
Study!!!!
Study, study, study.
Take advantage of all the resources offered.

Take if you're pre-med (cuz you have to). DO ALL THE PROBLEM SETS EVERY WEEK. They aren't graded or turned in, but they help so much. Also 8:30 lectures are a bitch, but go to them and if you can't stay engaged, at least go into robot mode and just type whatever words you hear. You will thank yourself dearly come cram time the day before the exams.
Take it
Take it as your hardest couse, definitely don't take it with 5 courses
Take it if you are majoring in molecular biology or thinking about majoring in molecular biology.
Take it if you have to or if you like MOL Bio.
Take it if you have to. I don't see you getting much out of it if you don't plan on focusing on biology here.
Take it only if you need to.
Take it!
Take it, most likely because you have to. But it's interesting even if you don't need to take it.

Take the course if you need it, but MOL 214 is not the most exciting biology course. Also, this course alone is not a good indication whether or not you like biology. Do the problem sets even if they are not graded because they get you used to extrapolation-type of questions on exams; they don't contain exactly the material that's on the exams, but they're as close as you can get.

Take this class, but hope that Prof. Gitai is not the lecturer.  Go to every single problem set review session and lecture review session if possible.  Do the reading.  Labs are generally straightforward and interesting.
Take this if you are considering a major in MOL!

The class is super interesting, and not impossible to do well in. Try as much as possible to pay attention during lectures; LectureTools is a great resource, but only if you've filled in notes to look back on.
The course is definitely interesting, though there is a lot of material covered, which sometimes makes it seem overwhelming.

The course was fantastically organized, and labs were wonderful. The emphasis was really on thinking critically like lab researchers, and the material was much more interesting when presented from that point of view. I took the development module taught by Professor Tilghman, which was so complex and fascinating!

The material here could be a little dense and dry, so you have to do your part to keep up. Some of you will find this material more interesting than others, and therefore it may come more easily to some of you than others. I suggest study groups and working together. Remember the textbook! It explains things very clearly, and it is a good reference if you feel your notes are not specific enough or clear enough. GO to review sessions as often as you could. It forces you to recall the material that you learned over the week. Do the problem sets! It may be tempting to shove them off because they aren't graded, but they're really good practice and indicators of how well you understand. Lastly, don't be afraid to ask for help. The professors are great and approachable. This course is tough, but you have a lot of resources--friends, reviews, teachers, psets--so you know, use them.
There is a lot of material covered in this course and it is definitely helpful to have at least a good foundation in some basic molecular biology concepts.
There is so much material. You will feel overwhelmed often. Just try to keep up with the readings. And go over the lecture slides as much as possible.

This class is challenging. Study weekly. Try to get Dr. Schwalm for lab; she is super helpful!!! Do the problem sets weekly. I had to read the textbook to understand lecture, but a lot of people got through the course without ever reading it.

This class really challenges you think in a certain way, different from the critical thinking in humanities classes. If you're not premed or don't need this as a prerequisite, find a different class to fulfill a distribution requirement because although the labs are really awesome, there is a TON of material covered in this premed-heavy class.
This course is hard yet completely doable.
This course should only be taken by students with a background in biology.

This is a challenging course, but worth it if you put in the time and effort. It really helps to go to the review sessions and to do the HW, even if it doesn't count. It is also really helpful to review lecture material on a weekly basis, because its really easy to get behind, and the first exam creeps up on you. Start early when studying for the final.
This is a highly structured class. Very organized. Take advantage of every learning tool offered to you in this class.
This is a pre-med class. And if it isn't for CBE requirement, I wouldn't take it. If you don't have to take it, don't. take MOL215 or integrated science instead.
This is not a class you can just BS so if you take it, make sure you work hard!
This is probably a pre-req for pre-med. Try to keep up with all the information, and you'll be fine.
Try to figure out what is actually going on instead of purely memorizing
Why would you take this unless you're premed or you really want to learn about DNA RNA and Proteins?
Work through the material every week and do the problem sets.
Yes, attend review sessions and do the homework assignments.
You learn a lot past AP Biology. Take the course.

You're probably looking at this class as a pre-req, not out of interest, so you may just have to grind through this course. Gitai is an AWFUL lecturer who makes the material more confusing than it really is and who fails to interest you in the material. The labs are great though.
a great intro mol class with a lot of support.
be prepared because it is not an easy class.
not a fun of class. info tested on exams was super nit-picky just to get a distribution
take it and try to stay awake in lecture. or dont go
very detailed, reading unnecessary
prereqs: Open to undergraduate students only. Graduate students and auditors must have permission of instructor..
descrip: Important concepts and elements of molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology, are examined in an experimental context. During the last two weeks of the semester, topics-based sections will be taught by different faculty members in the following areas: cell biology, virology, genomics and development. This course fulfills the requirement for students majoring in the biological sciences and satisfies the biology requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: Genius
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Art of Adventure, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: If you want to become very comfortable speaking Chinese and are willing to work very hard, you should tkae this course.
Not ideal. Maybe wait.
Stay on top of the vocabulary and it's not too bad.

This course focuses on increasing your Chinese vocabulary and fluency by engaging with complex concepts present in contemporary Chinese essays, short stories, and films.  The schedule does include 5 hours of class per week, but it is quite flexible.  I found this course to be a good way of maintaining and improving my Chinese without adding too much work to my schedule.
Work hard, and it would be one of the more fulfilling courses at Princeton.
the caliber of the class -- at this level -- suffers when other students are less interested in improving their chinese.
prereqs: CHI 403 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of 403. Reading and discussion of scholarly writings in the fields of Chinese literature and modern Chinese intellectual history. A weekly written assignment will be required.

title: Theory and Practice of Arabic to English Translation
prereqs: Minimum of two years of study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course trains students in the practice of translating Arabic texts from a wide variety of genres into English. Attention will be given to both theoretical and practical problems of translation for research and professional ends.

title: Advanced French
reviews: Course is good to take and very interesting.
Definitely take 108 instead of 107 if you can test into it.
Do the readings and practice grammar regularly.
Do the readings, participate, go over the grammar outside of class.
Do the readings.
Do your homework. It'll help.
I would recommend it definitely.
I would recommend taking this course instead of 107 if you are interested in doing less grammer exercises and learning more about French culture and history.
I would tell them to make sure they prepare a little each day after class rather than waiting to study the night before an exam.
If you enjoy the French language and have spoken it before, this class is a wonderful, fairly easy addition to a course schedule.
If you like French, take the class. It's not very difficult, though some assignments can be time consuming.

If you need to finish your language requirement, I would really recommend taking this class. This class was very well organized and really helped us all improve in our French. I would recommend taking French 108 in the spring if you are not fluent in the language, since it is taught differently in the fall vs. spring, and the spring class goes through the material a little slower to make sure everyone understands, but it wasn't done too slow to be too tedious.
It is a lot of work, so make sure you keep up.
It is a quality french course. Try to get Mme. Perrier. She is well organized, nice, and helpful.
It's a very solid course, nothing too unexpectedly terrible or unexpectedly wonderful, will teach you a lot of grammar
It's not a bad class. Murielle is awesome.
Pay attention to the syllabus, due dates sneak up on you.
Perrier is a fair grader and decent prof.  She tries to make class fun.
Put in effort and you will do well.
Review grammar consistently, little grammar mistakes on tests can add up.
Take advantage of Professor Perrier.  She is very helpful and friendly.  Also, don't fall behind, pay attention to grammar, and commit yourself.
Take it if you like french!
Take it if you need it, and not if you're looking for a fun language class,

Take it! Especially with Perrier because she's so wonderful. She gets that we are students here with a lot of work and does her best to give us a lot of time for each assignment. Plus, discussions are hilarious. We are always laughing and I only learn if I'm having a good time.
Take it! Having the independence regarding the grammar homework is nice, and the readings are far more interesting than what you get at the 102/103 level.
Take it.  Especially if you have to fulfill your language requirement, but even if you don't.
Take this class
Take this class and professor
Take this class!! And you'll be lucky to get Madame Perrier!
The course is truly excellent. I had originally intended to take 107, but if a student were given the opportunity to take 108 instead, I would highly suggest it.
This is a good class to take to review French if you have taken it before

This is a good course and Madame Perrier was a great instructor. She really helped make the course interesting and not just another language course, though it is still a required course and certainly had a little bit of that stigma.
This was a great French course. The workload was not overboard at all. I would recommend taking it.  The movies and readings were all very interesting.  I learned a lot about French culture.

Use the review pages in the CP in studying for the tests; they thoroughly cover what is on the tests. Don't be embarassed to ask a grammar question even if you know it is something you have learned previously.
You have to put effort into this class to make the most out of it.
You need to take this for the language requirement, so just do it. It's not fun but it's not bad either.

You pretty much have to take this course, and it won't be bad for the most part. Just keep in mind that the tests won't necessarily be reflective of what you know in the course and that it can be quite a bit of work from time to time.
be prepared to work more outside of class, and the in class is more discussion
do the readings
keep up with grammar so you don't have to cram for exams.
this class is very discussion oriented
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Director of French Language Program..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. We'll take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates: national identity, immigration, relationships with the Francophone world and former colonies, the role of the State in the shaping of the nation, etc. We have selected a variety of authentic materials (films, videos, music, newspapers articles and literary texts) and carefully incorporated them into our curriculum so you'll develop your ability to communicate in French.

title: Introduction to the History of Art: Renaissance to Contemporary
reviews: Attend all of the lectures. They contain material for the exams and are genuinely helpful. Rather than not attend the lectures and spend twelve hours the night before looking up the artworks, you can just attend the lectures, take good notes, and do really well from just reading the notes you took on the pieces.
Commit the artworks to memory as they are introduced, as that is the most important element of the course, in terms of grading.
Definitely worth taking
Excellent survey course. Broad in scope, yet still accessible, especially if you want to gain knowledge on art history!
