For those with some art history experience or interest, this class may not be as fulfilling as one in a more specific topic. Otherwise, an interesting if somewhat dizzying look at a wide range of cultures and time periods.
Go to all the lectures and do the readings! Make flashcards for exams and start papers early.
Go to every lecture but don't worry about trying to do everything. The readings are definitely helpful but focus on the papers rather than the book.

I absolutely loved this course and would definitely recommend it to others. Even if you would never consider majoring in art history and have no previous experience in the subject, I think it is SO important to have some exposure to the discipline of art history.  Not only is it important to have some knowledge of art history as a generally educated person, it also opens up a whole new way of thinking about the world that you would have never previously considered. If you just want a brief overview of the most important movements in art over the past 700 years or so, take this course!!!! Most of the lectures are taught by the expert in that topic from the Princeton art history department, so it's a great way to get exposed to the department in general. It's also not a difficult course - go to lecture, take good notes, scan the readings, make a few good points in precept, and study the list of works you need to memorize for the exams. There are also two short papers, but those are a breeze. Would be easy and interesting to PDF, but also fine to take for a grade. Overall, highly recommended!
I definitely learned a lot about art history by taking this course. Lectures are good, tests and essays are easy, and you'll learn about art; what more could one ask for?

I liked this course, a lot. If you allow that it will not be a continuous or building system of knowledge, and enjoy general exposure, I would recommend the sequence. Memorizing all these images and names and dates is not pleasant.  But this is a great course to PDF, especially if you just want to be a well-rounded person, with a *bit* of knowledge about art, architecture, etc.
I would recommend any student who is interested in a survey of art in the modern period to take this course.

If you a very good a memorizing, then this is the course for you.  It never really goes into deep detail about any one movement or work of art, but rather just scratches the surface.  I think if you really want to gain a greater appreciation for art, then this is not the class for you.  I would also recommend using a P/D/F for this course.
If you enjoyed ART 100 and want to learn more about recent artwork, you should definitely take this class!
If you have to choose between ART 100 and ART 101, take ART 101. Get really good notes, focus on the detailed meaning of the artworks. Go to Alsdorf's office hours. She is amazing and so charming!
If you like art and want to take a course that gives a good general overview of art from the Renaissance to present, go for it.
If you want to learn about Art History you should take the class.
It is a really great course, especially if you are interested in learning about art. I now feel that I can go to an art museum and appreciate what I am looking at.
It is not as easy as it seems. Graded a little too harshly and unfairly at times. Definitely not an easy A.
Just enjoy the amazing opportunity with this class. There is a phenomenal art museum here that you become very familiar with.
Keep up with the textbook readings at least, as they are extremely informative
Lectures are the most important part, go!
Make sure to attend lecture. I learned more about the course through lectures than the readings. This course is an easy class, if you're good at memorizing dates.
Make sure you attend every lecture and take great notes.
Not too difficult, fun course. Great for PDFing, but wouldn't be too bad to take for a grade either
One of the most intellectually valuable courses at Princeton.
Study your paintings.
Take it before you graduate!
Take it if you like art history, and go to all the lectures! Only do the reading that's required for precept. The rest is unnecessary.
Take it.
Take it.  It fulfills a distribution requirement, isn't a TON of work, and is very interesting.  It would be pretty difficult, however, if you are especially bad at memorizing things.
Take this course! The writing assignments are manageable. The readings are interesting.
This course gives you a fantastic overview of art history and you study a lot of interesting works. Seriously worth taking!

This course was a very interesting summary of art from the 1500s to today. I can now go into a museum and feel like I know what I am looking at rather than being completely lost. I would definitely encourage you to take this class if you ever plan on going to a museum for the rest of your life.
This is a good course to take for anyone who is interested in art in general.  It provides a broad range of knowledge without being too much work.
Worth taking, although there was a large emphasis on memorization.
take it, fun times
take this if you want a brief intro to art history
descrip: An introduction to selected periods and works of art and architecture from the Renaissance to the present as well as an introduction to the discipline of art history. Two lectures, one preceptorial.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Race and Public Policy
reviews: Attend his exam review sessions. Study your heart out for the final--it was so hard. AND THIS CLASS HAS BOTH A FINAL AND A TERM PAPER--careful. You don't need to buy any of the books
Beware of the final paper along with a final exam, 20-30 page research paper doesn't sound terrible since it's at the end of the semester but it really is too long.
Don't buy the books, great class, learned a lot. The paper and essay at the end are killer though.
Everyone needs to take this course
Fantastic course.  The final paper is a lot of work though, so start early

For future students, I would say that this class takes a lot of work so don't fall behind because then you'll be overwhelmed. But a lot of it is repeated from past studies in high school of the material, but there is just more to the knowledge for this class. But Prof. Massey is a distinguished scholar in his field, so it is great to be able to hear his lectures.

I am neutral about this course. Definitely do not waste your money buying all of the course books. He focused a lot on the history of race instead of modern policy issues. I thought we would be looking at modern policy in and out of the US, which we did not focus on.

I learned a lot about the history of white and black race relations in the US. I am disappointed that I didn't learn anything about other race issues. I also disliked that the class essentially was all about pure memorization and not critical analysis or deeper thought.

I would strongly recommend taking this course. The only issue with it was the fact that, because Douglas Massey is not a full-time professor, he was not very accessible and I felt completely alienated from him. He seemed to come in for lecture and leave, without really engaging with the students. However, that did not prevent him from providing us with top-quality material.
If Mike Wu and Dowon Kim recommended, it should be possible to take it
If you take this class make sure you go to every lecture and take notes. That is all you need to do relatively well in the course.

Massey is perhaps the most esteemed scholar in this field so it's great to take a class with him, however, A LOT OF WORK at the end. Be aware that this class has weekly reading responses, an in-class midterm, 20-30 page Dean's Date paper, and a LONG closed-note, timed, take home final. Everything was actually reasonable and not too much work up until the final paper and exam. The final covered a ridiculous amount of material and was time crunched. This class is interesting but I'd only recommend taking it if the final exam goes back to being open note like it used to be.

Massey's not a great lecturer and the final paper is too long, but the subject material is interesting.  Also, even though the course is called "Race and Public Policy," it only focuses on African-Americans.
Material is very interesting. This class will give you a new perspective on life in the US.
Pretty interesting, going to all the lectures is key, but they're crazy fast and detailed and if the workload is still a final and (20-30pg) research paper I'm not sure it's worth it.
Professor Massey does a great job presenting the information- you will definitely leave the course with a solid understanding of the relationship between race and public policy!
Really interesting course. More of a history course than a policy or sociology course. Start the final paper as early as possible!
Start early on the paper.
Take it if you're willing to put in a ton of work at the end, and are genuinely interested in race in America.

That 20 page paper is NOT a joke. I wouldn't recommend this class for juniors because you essentially have to write a second JP in a quarter of the time. The material is interesting though, readings are really just supplementary.

The exam material was entirely based off of lecture material.  The lectures were rather dry, and you didn't really even need to go to lecture as long as you look at the lecture notes.  The 20 page paper was such a pain though and did not need to be that long.
This class was excellent and I suggest it strongly for anyone interested in this kind of topic.

This course covers things that you need to know in order to be a well-informed citizen (of any country, but especially the United States). It's not much work, but I think the information and concepts I learned in this class were some of the most useful in any of my classes at Princeton.
This course is fine, but bear in mind that it is actually just focused on African Americans
This is a very interesting course and is extremely well-taught.  Begin working on the paper before reading period, though.  It is 20-30 pages and can be a lot of work.
idk
if u haven't taken a class on race then take it otherwise no need. not a lot of work at all.
descrip: Analyzes the historical construction of race as a concept in American society, how and why this concept was institutionalized publicly and privately in various arenas of U.S. public life at different historical junctures, and the progress that has been made in dismantling racialized institutions since the civil rights era.

title: Race and Medicine
reviews: I liked it. Professor Rouse was great!

If you're ok with a very laissez faire kind of teaching style then this course is great for you. If you're interested in learning about disparities the final paper is a great chance to do some research into what you want to learn about.
Take it if you want a fairly low-stress EM. A good class to p/d/f
Take it only if you like anthropology. Even then, beware.
Take it!
great course if you want to learn about the problems of healthcare and minority groups
descrip: In 1998, then-President Clinton set a national goal that by the year 2010 race, ethnic, and gender disparities in six disease categories would be eliminated. While the agenda, called Healthy People 2010, was a noble effort, many of the goals were not met. This course examines what went wrong. For a final project, students will be asked to propose their own solutions for eliminating health disparities.

title: Compiling Techniques
reviews: By the time you take it, it will have received a much-needed makeover.  Hopefully it will no longer be in a language that has been dead for ten years and will actually be about modern compilers.  August is an excellent professor, but he was up against some pretty dry material.

I would recommend against taking the class with Professor August in its current state, but it's not being offered next year, and there apparently will be changes made to the course when it's offered again.  Lectures were incredibly dull, but the programming assignments were quite interesting.
ML is one of few decent programming languages, which makes the course seem nice. Compilers are interesting. But supposedly the course will change in future years.
Make sure to learn ML well, it is very helpful for the assignments.  Participate and ask questions in lecture.
No
Not yet, August mentioned that this course was in the process of being reworked. Wait a couple years.

The course will supposedly be changing a fair amount from this semester, so I don't know that any advice I can give will carry over very well, but I will say that the course is not easy, but it is rewarding, especially if you take the time to carefully implement each piece of the compiler over the course of the semester such that the whole thing works together at the end. If you do and it does, it is something you can really take pride in.

The material of this class is centrally important to CS, and is very interesting (if it's the sort of thing you're into). However, the lectures and textbook are rather unhelpful, so I would highly recommend figuring out another way of learning the material if you take this class. Alex Aiken (from Stanford) has an excellent series of lectures on YouTube that cover ~80% of the material in the class.
Wait til its overhauled in 2014.
Wait until the course is revamped. Don't take it if it's still written in ML, and/or deal with the front end for more than 20%.
it's changing completely after this semester so take it when it comes back and it should be amazing then
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Understand the design and construction of compilers. Concepts include syntax analysis, semantics, code generation, optimization and run-time systems. Translation of imperative languages (such as C), functional languages (such as ML), and object-oriented languages (such as Java) will be studied. Students will implement a complete compiler for a small language.

title: Pre-Columbian Peoples of Tropical America and Their Environments
reviews: Dolores is incredible! She is like a grandma to her students, very caring and supportive. You will get a chance to grind crops and visit indigenous communities. Ilean was much stricter and less organized. Although you do visit excavation sites and the ancient city of Panama, she can be demanding in a short amount of time.
Ilean does not understand how to teach college students; Dolores, on the other hand, is legit. She knows so much and is extremely nice and approachable.
Ilean's course was not great. Dolores' course was well taught and quite fun.
It can be dull at times, but overall is a good course
It's boring, but also easy
Not my favorite course in Panama, but some of the labs and field experiences are pretty cool and the overall semester is worth it.
Split up the readings, especially for the second part of the course if the reading load is still intense. And study early for the exams so you don't have to stress at the last minute.

The Panama semester program is a package deal, and this class is part of it. While this particular class was not my favorite, I would HIGHLY recommend the semester in Panama. It is a wonderful experience and a much more realistic way to practice science than any course offered on campus.

The first half of the course was very easy and fun, if somewhat simple. The second half of the course was cool because you get to travel, but had way too much crammed in (readings, lab reports, fieldwork, intensive lectures, and studying) and so felt very stressful and frustrating.
This course provides an interesting survey of the Pre-Columbian era, and allows for several great field trips to archaeological sites.
You will absolutely adore Dolores. If you have Ilean make sure you asked for detailed instructions as soon as she assigns anything.
divide up the readings between the students in the class
prereqs: Prerequisites: 211, and 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring Semester in tropical ecology program in Panama..
descrip: The pre-European history of Amerind cultures and their associated environments in the New World tropics will be studied. Topics to be covered include the peopling of tropical America; development of hunting/gathering and agricultural economies; neotropical climate and vegetation history; and the art, symbolism, and social organization of native Americans. Field and laboratory experiences will incorporate methods and problems in field archaeology, paleoenthnobotany and paleoecology, and archaeozoology.

title: Philosophy of the Cognitive Sciences
prereqs: Three prior courses in philosophy..
descrip: The course will consider selected issues in the intersection of philosophy and cognitive psychology.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese I
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, listening and speaking. Reading materials include novels, essays, etc. Video materials are also used to enhance listening skills. The goal of this course is "advanced" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.

title: Introduction to Metaphysics and Epistemology
reviews: (Boris Kment) The topics covered are interesting and give you things to think about. Lecture is good at giving enough of an overview of topics. The workload is generally pretty light. Overall, a great class that isn't too hard but isn't boring either.
A fantastic way to knock out a distribution requirement and learn about some of the most important problems in philosophy. Kment's not a great lecturer so drink lots of coffee before class.
Although this course is very little work, the readings are very dense. Make sure you are interested in the material before taking this course.
Always read ahead, even if it makes the lectures less interesting.  Being prepared to discuss the material makes learning both easier and more enjoyable.

An interesting course that covers many intriguing topics. Also, it's not much work, so it makes a good distribution course. It is fairly open-ended with many of the topics, leaving you to choose which arguments you find most compelling.
Awesome lectures!

Definitely the easiest EC out there. Zero work if you decide to PDF it, a little more work if you take it for a grade. Lectures are pointless and I didn't go. Didn't do any of the reading if it wasn't relevant to what I wanted to write my essays on. But I learned a lot writing the essays. There are only 3 and they aren't too long, (500, 1000, 2500) and you can write on whatever you want to which is nice. I am not PDFing but there is no way I get below a B in this course. Try to get Michaela as a preceptor,  she is super cool and very helpful.
Do the weekly readings!
Don't go to the lectures. Just do all the readings and find a preceptor that you like.
Don't take it unless Rosen is the professor. I learned more from a handout he created in previous years than all this semester's lectures combined.
Easy B without much work at all if you need an easy distribution requirement.
Go to lecture and do the readings!
Go to lecture.
Good introduction to philosophy, although don't expect it to come from the professor.
Good introductory class to philosophy. It will help you learn how to write clear arguments.
Grading is very linked to which preceptor you are assigned.

I had Kment for this course and he seemed very nice but was not an engaging lecturer. It was very difficult to pay attention in class, even though I really tried. I ended up PDF'ing this class, even though I had a B, simply because I could not manage to remain engaged in the readings.

I had heard this class was awesome with Gideon Rosen. I had Boris Kment. It was ok. Boris is good, but I wouldn't describe his lectures as "awesome" by any stretch of the imagination. Material is good / thought-provoking though.
I would not advise another student on taking this course, though I heard Professor Gideon Rosen was supposed to teach this course, and I heard his teaching was amazing and worthy of taking.
I would recommend this course as an introduction to philosophy.

If you are interested in philosophy, definitely take it. It's not demanding and is thought provoking. If you're closer to me on the spectrum, though, (that is, looking for a less-demanding distribution requirement) you can still take it, but be prepared to get frustrated with your inability make any clear conclusions or any strong arguments. PDF it.
If you are interested in philosophy, this course is highly recommended, for it lays out the groundwork for other courses here.

descrip: An introduction to central questions of philosophy, such as: Does God exist? Is there an external world full of material objects, or is this belief based on an illusion? Do human beings have free will (so that they can be held morally responsible for their actions)? In the past, bread has always nourished and never poisoned us, but do we have reasons for thinking that that will be true tomorrow? How can we ever be sure that the future will resemble the past? Are human beings material objects, or immaterial souls, or something else altogether?

title: American Political Institutions
descrip: This seminar is part of the two-course sequence of the core curriculum in American politics and provides an introductory survey of American political institutions. Provides an overview of the various problems for which institutional solutions are sought (e.g., problems involving collective action, delegation, and social choice) as well as a detailed assessment of some of the scholarly literature that investigates political institutions.

title: God of Many Faces: Comparative Perspectives on Migration and Religion

descrip: Immigrants often experience discrimination in areas of destination. Religion can strengthen their sense of worth, particularly when the circumstances surrounding departure from the country of origin are traumatic, as with exiles and refugees. We take a comparative approach and use examples from the United States, Asia, Europe, and Latin America. The course broaches questions such as: how does religion transform (and how is it transformed by) the immigrant experience? When is religion used to combat stereotypes? Are there differences between the way men and women or dominant groups and racial minorities understand religion?

title: Special Topics in Statistics and Operations Research - Optimization Seminar
descrip: Algorithms for approximate dynamic programming/reinforcement learning come in a number of styles. This seminar will survey the literature on the theory supporting the convergence of different algorithms on different classes of problems drawing from computer science, engineering, economics and operations research. Each week will consist of a presentation by one of the students that offers a convergence proof for a particular algorithm/problem class.

title: Artist as Idea: Leonardo to Warhol
descrip: The Artist as Idea, from Leonardo to Warhol. Seminar will explore the myth of the artist in Europe and the U.S. from the Renaissance to the present. Topics will include ideas of the artist as a privileged social being, notions of artistic temperament and "genius," the gendering of the artist, modernist myths of bohemianism and madness, and the postmodern artist's engagement with mass media. Analysis of self-portraiture, artists' writings, representations of the studio, and artists in film. Case studies will include Leonardo, Michelangelo, Artemisia Gentileschi, Rembrandt, Delacroix, van Gogh, Picasso, Pollock, O'Keeffe, and Warhol.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Social Entrepreneurship for Policymakers
descrip: Over the last 20 years, the emerging field of social entrepreneurship has taken new approaches to problems in education, waste management and global public health. This course focuses on types and stages of different social enterprises (non-profits/hybrid organizations/for-profits), will evaluate nature of capital available from grants to patient capital to market-return investments. Course seeks to equip students with a framework for understanding how: 1) social enterprise can complement traditional provision of public services and 2) new markets are being created that deliver clear social benefits while generating returns to investors.

title: The Brain: A User's Guide
reviews: A lot more work in terms of memorizing facts than is apparent at the beginning.

Beware that when Barry says "you don't need to know this much detail" he is often wrong.  The final exam featured two pages of material that he explicitly said were details we wouldn't need to know.

Also, be sure to read the textbook as you go along through the semester: there is nothing covered in lecture that isn't in it, but there's a lot you should know for the exams that isn't covered in lecture.

descrip: The course provides a basic introduction to neuroscience, especially as it impacts upon practical issues: mental disease, drugs, neurological disorders, development, learning, memory, etc. It is intended for students who are not planning to concentrate in the life sciences. It is hoped that some students may get stimulated by this course and decide to concentrate in aspects of psychology, biology, philosophy, or engineering as they relate to mind and brain.

title: Religion, the Sciences, and the Arts: Luther to Leibniz
descrip: From the Reformation to the late Baroque, religion, the sciences, and the arts are entwined in an intricate yet volatile bond. Standard historical accounts tell the story of the sciences' and the arts' growing emancipation from religion. At the same time, religion itself is involved in far-reaching transformations of its own. This course aims at shedding new light on these developments while providing an introduction to the main trends of the period. We will explore the controversial endorsement of scientific learning; Luther and the historical study of the bible; More's Utopia; the case of Galileo; Leibniz' influence on the arts.

title: Writing History
descrip: The craft of historical writing. As older notions of objectivity come under attack, what narrative options exist for historians? Course focuses on recent work by historians experimenting with new forms of narrative writing and considers the boundaries between fact and fiction, the use of first-person narratives, and the limits of historical speculation. Course also examines how journalists, novelists, and film-makers narrate the past to ask what literary lessons they might offer academic historians. In a series of structured assignments, students experiment with different ways of writing about the past.

title: Seminar in Normative Ethics
descrip: Ethics, in its broadest sense, is the study of what it is to live a good life. This course will explore the role of social identities--such as gender, race, ethnicity, profession, religion, and nationality--in shaping and evaluating a person's life. We shall discuss both the nature of social identities and the ways in which identities affect what we owe both to ourselves and to others.

title: Special Topics in Environmental Engineering and Water Resources - Cities in the 21st C:the nexus of climate, water and energy challenges
reviews: Gaining some prior knowledge on urban physics and chemistry would be helpful.
Good course if you are interested in urban problems
Great class to take PDF. The atmosphere is relaxing, you learn, you participate, you practice reading, discussion, and presentation. Cool topic that is increasingly relevant as well.
descrip: This is a reading course where students will have one assigned reading per week that will be discussed in class. The readings will cover a range of topics related to the urban challenges in the 21st century, focusing on energy, water and climate challenges and how they converge in urban areas. Enrolled students need a background in hydrological and atmospheric sciences to fully benefit from the readings; interested students should email the instructor to discuss this prerequisite.

title: E. M. Forster and Virginia Woolf
descrip: E. M. Forster and Virginia Woolf were life-long friends and arguably one another's best "critical" readers. We will test the validity of this argument by reading Forster and Woolf with and against each other. Our objective will be to see where they agreed or how they differed on the pressing cultural and artistic questions of their time: about what social and political traditions (the family, the class system, the Empire) were worth preserving or should be abolished, about feminism, human sexuality, and about the character, the form and the future of modern fiction.

title: Topics in Popular Music - Analysis of Popular Music
descrip: This course examines the issues involved in analyzing rock, funk, hip-hop, and electronic dance music. Topics considered include form, texture, technology, production, harmony, voice leading, rhythm, virtuosity, imagery, and transcription methods. Requirements include weekly response papers on reading/listening assignments, analytical exercises, and a term paper.

title: Matters of Attention
descrip: Attention, regulating what enters consciousness, lies at the nexus of perception and action, aesthetics and ethics. This course will move from a history of changing ideas about attention, through current research, and on into the implications for seeing and experiencing as modes of being. Since works of art can be understood as reified requests for attention, we will take them as important case studies in the investigation of what attending has meant and can mean.

title: Topics in Organic Chemistry - Methods for Complex Organic Synthesis
reviews: Always pay attention to possalbe proposal ideas dropped during lecture.
If you're at all interested in organometallics, you should definitely take this class.
Keep up with the course material and read the references given in the note packets.
graduate students in organic and organometallic laboratories should definitely take this course
descrip: An in-depth discussion of transition metal-catalyzed reactions commonly used in modern organic synthesis (e.g. cross coupling, olefin metathesis, asymmetric hydrogenation, etc.). Emphasis will be placed on the topic of selectivity (chemo-, regio-, and stereo-) and its mechanistic basis. The historical development, scope, and limitations of the methods are discussed. A prior course in organometallic chemistry (CHM 521) is recommended.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Development Strategies in Latin America from the 1940s to the Present
prereqs: Some background on Development and Social Issues would be helpful.
descrip: This course aims to provide undergraduate students with a comprehensive picture of the most important transformations undergone by Latin America in the last decades. The re-democratization process from the 80's came when Latin American economies tended to face high inflation and low economic growth, shaping new challenges. After two decades in struggling to find new paths of recovery and stability, the years 2000 brought new light to Latin America. This course will portray these different phases using country examples to illustrate this trajectory. Emphasis will be given to Brazil because of its impressive social and economic turnaround.

title: Economic Sociology (Half-Term)
descrip: An introduction to economic sociology seen not as a subordination of sociology to economics but as the sociological explanation of economic phenomena. It focuses on alternative accounts of phenomena that most specialists have explained using economic concepts and theory. In particular, it seeks sociological explanations of production, consumption, and distribution, and transfer of assets. After a general orientation to economic sociology as a whole, the course explores economic activities in an unconventionally wide range of settings including households, informal sectors, gift economies, and consumption.

title: Community-Based Performance
reviews: As with any theater class, don't be afraid to express yourself or your ideas. Try to suspend judgement and be sure to research thoroughly before classes with guest speakers.  You'll get A LOT more out of talking with them if you know about their past work, their interests, their methodologies.
Definitely take this class! Learn about a new type of theater and be inspired!
Erica Nagel is so nice and helpful! If you're looking for a low-stress but intriguing class, this is for you!
Take it if you want a class that will constantly inspire and get you moving (literally).
Take this course! Professor Nagel is absolutely wonderful.
This is a great class - Erica is a fantastic teacher. The work load is manageable and she is upfront about what she wants from you. Erica brings in fantastic guests as well.
prereqs: Enrollment in this course is by permission of the instructor. Please email Professor Erica Nagel to state your interest in the course at: enagel@Princeton.EDU.
descrip: This hands-on seminar will explore contemporary theories and practices of community-based performance, investigating contemporary theatre, dance, and music groups that use these methods. The course will also interrogate the sometimes fraught politics of community-based performance, including questions of authorship, authority, authenticity, and artistry. Offered in partnership with the Community-Based Learning Initiative, this course will offer hands-on experience in the process of creating community-based performance projects, and facilitate opportunities to build artistic relationships with local community organizations.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Course offers a broad treatment of macroeconomic theory and policy issues, using the formal methods of modern macroeconomics. Topics will include long-run growth and development, labor, consumption, savings and investment decisions, the role of expectations, short-run fluctuations and stabilization policy, inflation and unemployment, trade and exchange rates. The course is advanced, so that: (i) having had some introductory course in macroeconomics is a prerequisite, and an intermediate-level one is best; (ii) the course requires a solid command of microeconomic theory (511 c or d) and good comfort with algebra and calculus.

title: Sociology of Science
descrip: Science is a critical part of our modern world. But how is it actually done? And how does it affect our daily lives? Placing science in social context is essential to understanding it as a process, as an institution, and as a powerful and influential force in society. With examples such as controversies over cold fusion and HIV-AIDS research, the practices of genetic testing and brain scan analysis, the questions of nuclear weapons and climate change, forms of expertise and public policy, this course will introduce you to the exciting and growing field of the sociology of science.

title: Independent Work
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
reviews: If you intend to pursue cognitive neuroscience research and want a broad introduction to the field taught by those who know it best, this class is a must.
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format combining theoretical, experimental, and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include systems and cognitive neuroscience, perception and attention, learning and behavior, memory, executive function/decision-making, motor control and sequential actions. Diseases of the nervous system are considered. This is one-half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: International Trade II
descrip: A continuation of ECO 551, with emphasis on current research issues. Topics vary from year to year.

title: Social Movements and Contentious Politics
descrip: Explores the study of social movements as well as other forms of unconventional collective action aimed at achieving or preventing social and political change (riots, demonstrations, strikes, terrorist movements, etc.). After examining various approaches to the field, we will investigate a number of issues of abiding concern within the field: repertoires, violence, repression, and the transnational dimensions of mobilization. Finally, we will turn to empirical applications in the study of revolutions, democratization, and nationalism.

title: Introduction to Augustan Literature
reviews: A good first college Latin course if your high school had a rigorous Latin program. If your high school Latin was less intensive, you might be better off in 108.
Great literature, which is enough of a reason to take this course.  Also, Feeney is fun to have in class, but to get the most out of this class you have to want to work at it.

If the students are interested in Classics, I would definitely encourage them to take the class because Professor Feeney is just such an awesome example of a Princeton professor. If they are unwilling to actually have the patience to do the translations though, this class may not be for them.
It's awesome.  Love the works.  Ask questions because, more often than not, Prof. Feeney has a mind-blowing answer.
Just have fun with it. Latin is to be enjoyed.
Keep on top of the translations and don't let them get away from you.
Professor Feeney taught the course with clarity and wit.
Take a class with Feeney!
Take this course with Dennis Feeney.  He is a legend.
prereqs: LAT 108 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: A reading course in Augustan prose and poetry. The chief objectives are (1) to develop an ability to read and to appreciate Latin literature; (2) to become familiar with some of the literary themes of the age; and (3) to learn about the social and cultural world of Augustan Rome.

title: France Today: Culture, Politics, and Society
reviews: Definitely take it! It's a great class, very engaging, very well-taught, and really helps you learn to speak more confidently and better in general.
If you take this class, you should be prepared to speak up, because that's the best way you'll learn.
Take it! Christine Sagnier's the best!
Take it! You won't regret it.

This class is not about writing, it's about speaking, so be prepared to participate!  Even if (or maybe especially) if you're nervous about speaking in French, I'd recommend this course because Sagnier does such a great job of getting everyone to practice.

This is a great French course. I was personally in over my head (I didn't take 215 and had only taken 1.5 years of French before, though at an accelerated pace), but even for me, I learned a lot, because Prof. Sagnier was so supportive. The material about French society is really interesting and relevant. I only wish there were more vocab quizzes, so that we could quantify the amount of new vocab we learned.
Workload isn't too hard, but be prepared to contribute during discussions! And have fun :)
take the class! sagnier is amazing and its not too much work.
prereqs: FRE 108 or equivalent; FRE 207 recommended..
descrip: This course is designed to develop students' linguistic skills and broaden their knowledge of contemporary French society. Discussions and essays will cover a wide range of topics drawn from economic, political, social and cultural aspects of France and the francophone world. Current affairs will be discussed in class on a regular basis. The course will provide intensive language practice and students will improve their communication skills by completing a research project, to be presented orally and in writing, on a topic of their choice. Course material include readings, videos, films, francophone television and web-based activities.

title: Topics in the Politics of Writing and Difference - Cuban Literature of Slavery
prereqs: One 200-level SPA course on literature or culture or instructor's permission..
descrip: A course on the relationship between Cuban literature and slavery. Explicitly "Cuban" literature emerged from the literary salon of Domingo del Monte, a 19th century reformist with ties to British abolitionism, and early works focused on the island's massive slave industry. We will read several anti-slavery novels, emphasizing ties to transatlantic Romanticism and sentimental literature, and generic conventions more generally. Also: the only known Spanish-language slave autobiography; an oral history from an ex-slave; the diary of a bounty-hunter; psychoanalysis, and modern Cuban representations of slavery, including films.

title: Senior Project
descrip: Students conduct a one-semester project. Topics chosen by students with approval of the faculty. A written report is required at the end of the term.

title: Topics in Analysis - The Einstein equations under surface symmetry
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor..
descrip: I will give an introduction to the analysis of the Einstein equations under spherical (and more general surface) symmetry in the context of both gravitational collapse and cosmology, discussing in particular scalar field and collisionless matter (Vlasov) models. The state of the art on the celebrated cosmic censorship conjectures in this setting will be presented.

title: Readings in Classical Arabic Literature
descrip: Topics vary according to students' interest. Some possible topics: poety, narrative prose, "adab."

title: The Gothic Tradition
reviews: If the reading list appeals to you, I would recommend taking the course. Professor Alliston is great in a small seminar structured course, but I'm not sure if her style would work as well for a larger lecture format.
Take it if you want to.

There is a lot of reading to do, especially since in addition to the main novel, you also have articles. Make sure to read enough so that you can participate during discussions and write essays for the midterm. Everyday we had a discussion question due, but that wasn't that difficult/didn't take too long. The creative project option for the final can be very fun. Overall a very interesting class and she gave interesting lectures! Stay on top of your reading/spread it out so you don't cram it too much. The workload isn't too bad as long as you don't have too many other reading-intensive classes.
This is pretty good literature course, at least in its seminar incarnation.
take it. have fun.
descrip: The purpose of this course is to analyze and understand the cultural meanings of the Gothic mode through a study of its characteristic elements, its historical, aesthetic, and political origins in eighteenth-century English and German culture and thought, its development across Western national traditions, and its persistence in contemporary culture, including film, electronic media, clothing, social behavior, and belief systems, as well as literature. Films, artifacts, web sites and electronic publications will supplement readings.

title: Religion and Law
reviews: Definitely take this class if it is offered again.  I think Professor Kaye is leaving soon, so if he offers it again -- definitely take it ASAP.
Definitely take this class with Professor Kaye! A lot of interesting readings. Not necessarily the easiest class, but very enjoyable and you will learn a lot about contemporary issues.
TAKE THIS!
Take this class. Do it. Favorite class at Princeton so far.
This class was fantastic, and if it is offered again I would recommend it to everyone I know.
This is the best course I have taken at Princeton so far!
descrip: A critical examination of the relation between concepts of "religion" and "law," as they figure in the modern state. The course will survey theoretical tools for thinking about these issues and their historical development before applying them to case studies in Europe and the Middle East. With the benefit of these comparative studies, and a new historical and philosophical insights, we will then address religion, politics and law in contemporary America.

title: Natural Disasters
reviews: Definitely go to all the lectures because it will help you to really understand the material.
Don't blow this off, it's not an easy A. And the more you put in, the more you'll actually learn.
Don't slack off on the labs.
I would take this course if looking for a relatively simple STL with an interest in cool labs like volcano making!
If you don't get to lectures, try your best to stay on top of your reading, or you will be super swamped later.
If you have any interest in geosciences, this is a good course.
If you like this kind of material, or are looking for a laid back lab class, take it.
Make sure to go over the lecture notes in order to do well on the tests and take time into completing the labs.
This is the perfect class to fulfill the STL requirement. It's interesting and not too much work either.
definitely take this course. it's actually interesting and you completely get out what you put into it.
descrip: An introduction to natural (and some society-induced) hazards and the importance of public understanding of the issues related to them. Emphasis is on the geological processes that underlie the hazards, with some discussion of relevant policy issues. Principal topics: Earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunami, hurricanes, floods, meteorite impacts, global warming. Intended primarily for non-science majors.

title: Metaphysics - Medieval, Early Modern, and Contemporary Theories of Substance
prereqs: This course will be taught jointly with John Morrison (Barnard College, Columbia) with half the meetings being held at Princeton and half at Columbia..
descrip: We will discuss theories of substance from the medieval, early modern, and contemporary eras. Guest speakers will visit the class.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Growth, International Finance & Crises
descrip: This is a macro, international finance-oriented development course, which will focus on the political economy of policy decisions. It will cover the following themes: 1. GDP growth and volatility; 2. the size, composition, and influence of international capital flows; 3. sudden stops in capital flows and financial crises; 4. the domestic and multilateral response to crises, including the role of fiscal adjustment, external financing, and debt restructuring; 5. We will draw on several country case-studies and students will be encouraged to undertake short research assignments to deepen their own policy interests.

title: Combustion
descrip: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, oxidation of hydrogen, hydrocarbons and alternate fuels, pollutant chemistry and control, transport phenomena, laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames, turbulent flames, ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena, flame stabilization and blowoff, detonation and blast waves, droplet, spray and coal particle combustion, principles of engine operation.

title: Computer Music: Compositional Applications
descrip: Composing and performing with laptops, solo and in ensembles and laptop orchestras will be explored. Members of Sideband will visit to teach and discuss strategies and aesthetics.

title: Republic of Fear to Divided Land: Iraq, 1958-2008
descrip: This course examines state-society relations in Iraq since 1958. It focuses on Ba'th regime dictatorial rule until the overthrow of Saddam Hussein, considering the state's formal and informal institutions of power, its use of ideologies and political symbolism, the management of the economy, the Iran-Iraq War, 1990-91 Gulf War, and the regime's relationship with Iraqi tribes, women, the Shi'a, and the Kurds. It concludes with an assessment of the dictatorship on Iraq's political and social culture after regime change. The thematic approach allows for a broader comparative perspective of state-society relations in the Gulf region.

title: Histories and Themes in Mexican Religion
descrip: This course is a thematic exploration of Mexican religion from the sixteenth century on. Students will read secondary and primary readings and will think through concepts like: "popular" and local religion; "spiritual conquest" vs. religious negotiation; visual devotional culture; and spiritual geography. They will learn about histories of: religious orders and Native Americans; religion and "American Baroque" religiosity; the impact of Bourbon Reforms on religious practice; the Church and state in the post- independence period; and popular participation in religious rebellion in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

title: Rabbinic Literature: Law, Religion, and History
reviews: If you are willing to start the papers early, it's a great class to take but if not, it can be a bit stressful. Good class though.
May not be for everyone, but I absolutely recommend it for those who are interested in Jewish religious tradition (or even, peripherally, Christian tradition, given how interconnected the two are).
Yes! Take this course!
descrip: Rabbinic literature (the Mishnah, the Talmud and midrashic texts) is crucial for reconstructing the religious culture of late antiquity as well as for understanding most subsequent forms of Judaism. This course focuses on the skills required for reading these classical Jewish texts in translation, on situating them in their historical context and in relation to Roman culture, Christianity, and Zoroastrianism, and on tracing developments in the rabbis' legal concepts as well as their construction of creation, redemption, sexuality and God.

title: Advanced Economic Theory II
descrip: Topics vary from year to year. See 511.

title: Milton
reviews: DO THE READINGS.  If you do this, everything else will fall into place.

Definitely take this course.  The readings are not overwhelming, but are all very rewarding.  The lectures are great.  Even if you don't have a specific interest in Milton or English poetry, take this class anyway- it's good for its own sake.
Give Milton a chance! Re read everything a million times- especially Paradise Lost.
I would advise students to go to office hours if they are struggling with Milton's language.  I was struggling at first and would have had less difficulty if I had sought help in advance.
I'd highly recommend taking this with Prof. Leo - he really knows what he's talking about, and he makes a difficult work manageable and interesting.

If you are interested in taking a class on Milton, definitely take it with Professor Leo.  Though the amount of work is light, so you have time to read closely and carefully to really savor Milton's language.
Prof Leo is very enthusiastic and will help you learn how to read Milton in an amazing way. Take any class with Russ Leo but especially this.

Prof. Leo is an incredible lecturer and a professor who really lets the students guide the precepts.  He one of the few professors who is honestly open to and encouraging of asking the 'big questions.'  His enthusiasm and sincerity make his lectures enjoyable and he is a very accessible and helpful instructor.
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take it, even if you know nothing about Milton.
Take it. One of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Take the course! Professor Leo is great and the material is fascinating.
Take this is you know something about how to read literature.

The great thing about this course is that the reading load is very manageable because instead of spending a week on one novel, you'll spend six weeks reading Paradise Lost. If you're looking for an in depth and engaging English course with a very manageable reading load, I would recommend this class. Second semester seniors will appreciate this course a lot, because you can get a lot out of it, accomplish all the reading, but still have time to work on your thesis.  It does take a while to get used to Milton's style, but Professor Leo is super helpful, and always willing to meet for office hours.

This course not only taught me a lot about Milton and early modern England, but it also helped me because a better writer and thinker because Professor Leo was willing to work closely with his students and give considered feedback on everything from posts to papers.
descrip: We will explore John Milton's entire career, largely as poet, but also as prose writer and thinker: a lifelong effort to unite the aims of intellectual, political and literary experimentation. In doing so Milton made himself the most influential non-dramatic poet in the English language. We will spend much time with Paradise Lost, regarded by many as the greatest non-dramatic poem in English or any modern language; we will encounter Milton's profound, extensive learning and his startling innovations with words, and in ideas of personal, domestic and communal liberty.

title: Econometric Theory II
reviews: A very interesting class for those interested in theoretical econometrics.
Nothing in particular.
Take it if you want to go to graduate school.
This course can really inspire a student to learn more about econometrics.
Work hard.
descrip: This course begins with extensions of the linear model in several directions: (1) pre-determined but not exogenous regressors; (2) heteroskedasticity and serial correlation; (3) classical GLS; (4) instrumental variables and generalized method of movements estimators. Applications include simultaneous equation models, VARS and panel data. Estimation and inference in non-linear models are discussed. Applications include nonlinear least squares, discrete dependent variables (probit, logit, etc.), problems of censoring, truncation and sample selection, and models for duration data.

title: Irish Comic Fiction from Swift to Roddy Doyle
prereqs: The social, historical and cultural context for the works will be explained as part of the course..
descrip: Irish history may be tragic, but much of the Irish fictional tradition is comic. Why have Irish writers produced so much of the funniest prose in the English language? This lecture course, which does not require previous knowledge of Irish literature takes a broad sweep from Jonathan Swift's savage satires, through fantastical folk tales, to the dark humor of James Joyce, Flann O'Brien and Samuel Beckett, the anarchic farces of Caroline Blackwood and Molly Keane and the defiant wit of Roddy Doyle.

title: Israeli Humor and its Roots
descrip: This course explores in Hebrew the roots of Jewish and Israeli humor that reflects values and self image. Sources include Biblical, Hasidic and contemporary stories, films, TV series, web sites, songs, etc. Classes will be conducted in Hebrew.

title: Gilded Age and Progressive-Era United States, 1877-1920
reviews: Definitely take it if you are interested in the material. Not too difficult a class and the professor is very passionate about the subject.
Do the readings

I would take this course only if you are very interested in the turn of the century and like primary source material. It's a course that history majors will likely enjoy, but probably non majors will dislike it.
If Rix is teaching and Moses isn't precepting, it is a good class to take.
It's an interesting time period but the class is a boring, mismanaged mess. Rix is nice and the quality of the primary sources is not nearly enough to redeem things.
Take it
Take it!
Take it. Especially if you do not know that much about the Gilded Age.
Take this course if you're at all interested in the time period - not very much work and will give you a really thorough background.
You should take this.
descrip: This course introduces key themes in U. S. history from Reconstruction to 1920. We explore changing understandings of individual rights and the role of the federal government in protecting liberty and equality; industrialization, the modern business corporation, and changing labor conditions; local self-government and civil society; westward and colonial expansion; the challenges posed by urbanization and immigration; the "New South;" Populism; Progressivism; reform experiments; modernism; and World War I. Period film screenings and campus Gothic architecture tour optional.

title: Macroeconomics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: Another one of your core courses, so you may not be super interested in the material. But it is better taught than the other core courses and you will enjoy many parts of it. There aren't too many finance certificate slackers in this one so definitely stay on top of your work.

As someone who loved ECO 101, I was really excited coming in, but I was quite disappointed when we ended up doing more micro than macro. It isn't too much work, much less than 310, but it wasn't that enlightening in my opinion.

Eh. Both 310 and 312 are better courses in my opinion. Although the instructor is very clear and all of the course material presents an interesting mathematical treatment of current macroeconomic models and research, the course is pretty unorganized. 1. The TA lost my midterm for a few days, which was pretty nerve-racking. 2. The problem sets are often ambiguous and don't always fit the format of the models in class (not to mention often reduce to just doing a bunch of algebra), and are sometimes graded in an arbitrary manner. 3. The midterm didn't differentiate students very much, so even 90% was in the B range. Overall, take the course for the material and instructor, not the coursework.
Go to class and precepts

I was non-math track and was forced to take this class because of a scheduling conflict with 301, and at the beginning I was really afraid.  That scheduling conflict turned out to be a huge blessing in disguise, after taking this class I feel like I actually understand some things about macroeconomics, rather than just having memorized some graphs and trends.  Honestly, one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton, and almost 100% due to the excellence of Ben and the preceptors.  Great class, very challenging, but highly recommend.
If Moll is teaching and you want to learn Macro, take this class.
If Moll is teaching this course, take it. Its as good as an upper level Econ course could be, and he is extremely accessible.

If you're good at math (particularly, solving systems of equations) - take it!!!! Ben Moll is fantastic and a very very nice, smart guy. I've heard this course is more challenging with him than the other 311 prof. It was built around deriving stylized versions of macro models in the literature, and it was very interesting, but pretty difficult!
It's interesting material, but difficult so be prepared for a lot of work
Its very useful material even if you are not an economics major.
Make sure you love economics and math before taking this course (gauge with how you liked ECO 310)

Not as hard as 310, but less interesting (in my opinion) because none of the macro models really work at all.  I'm not sure if from a pure learning perspective if I really got more out of this class than my friends in 301 that had a way easier time of it. But it wasn't a struggle either so maybe its worth it.
Not very useful if you want to get in industry rather than academics. you probably want to take ECO301 instead, like professor Moll suggests.
Take it if you are an econ major who likes mathematical models. Otherwise you won't find this class interesting at all.
Take it if you're math track econ. The material doesn't have many real world applications, since macro is more of a religion than a science.
Take it with Professor Moll.
Take it!
Take it, spend time during the semester going over models.
Take it.
Take it. It is interesting and you will learn a lot about macroeconomics.
Take this class if you want a taste of real macroeconomics.
Take this class with Prof. Moll and Chris Moser, if offered. That duo knocks it out of the park, and I'm not sure it would be as good of a class without them.
Take this course if you have to; it's not one you want to do for fun or general interest.

The models can be interesting, but the course is not very well organized or presented. Problem sets are haphazardly written and graded, and exams don't really make sense. Not going to say "don't take it," but it could definitely have been much better.

The professor (Ben Moll) was great. My preceptor (Chris Moser) was great. But the material fell short. It was boring equation manipulation for most of the time. But overall, all of the instructors had a good sense of humor, were very friendly & approachable, and made the class bearable.
This is a great course. It does a great job at teaching macroeconomic models without being too complicated or too watered down.
This is a really interesting class to take, even for general interest; I'd strongly recommend taking it with Moll
i wouldn't take the class if its not required, or if you're not really interested, but I liked the class
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 and MAT 200 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course examines the determinants of long-run economic growth, short-run business cycle fluctuations, and the conduct of monetary and fiscal policy. The first part of the course develops a framework for the analysis of households' consumption and savings behavior and firms' production decisions, and uses that to analyze long-run growth and financial crises. The second part of the course extends that analysis to examine business cycle fluctuations, including inflation, unemployment. Current issues in macroeconomic and financial policy are discussed throughout.

title: Entrepreneurial Leadership
reviews: Any student who wants to know how to bring people together to accomplish a task should take this course.

Focus your time on the Kotter, RBS, Drucker, and Prof. Lidow book readings.  Start the paper earlier than you expect.  Listen very carefully to the guest speakers.  Learn as much as you can from your team members.

For those who want to start a business, take it . Prof Lidow will offer you a lot of help on the road to become a great entrepreneurial leader. For those who don't want to start a business, take it. You will know yourself and others better through this course and how to be your best self.
I loved this course. It's tied for my favorite at Princeton. Absolutely take it.
I would highly suggest this class.
Just sit back and enjoy. You will learn a lot, especially if this is your first class in entrepreneurship.
Keep up with the readings so the class discussions are actually helpful and relevant. Commit yourself to the group assignments too in order to succeed.
Take it. Buy into Lidow's philosophies and you will be a happy student.

The assignments are just meetings that are very time consuming. They eat up your schedule because you have to have 2 meetings a week. Further, you don't learn that much in class. Overall, it's not worth taking.

This class is not a breeze, you will need to do work, but you will want to do the work. 

It is very enjoyable.
This is a great course to take and very fun. If you take it early, you will get chances to apply what you learned to the leading of clubs and organizations you are a part of.
YOU MUST TAKE IT!!
take it before you graduate
take it but it actually takes up a lot of time - you get out what you put in
prereqs: Interest/passion in discovering how an idea can become a real company. This course is not open to students who took the same class, as EGR 495 Special Topics in Entrepreneurship: Entrepreneurial Leadership..
descrip: The mission of the class is to enable students to successfully create and lead enterprises by teaching the basic skills required to be a successful entrepreneurial leader. This class compliments EGR 491 "High Tech Entrepreneurship" which focuses on 'giving birth to a company', by focusing instead on enterprise 'early child rearing'. The basic skills taught fall into three major categories: how to create and manage powerful relationships, how to know and manage yourself, in addition to understanding how organizations work as they evolve from the idea stage to become value producing, self-sustaining enterprises.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: Do not take it with Professor Freidin.
Do not take this course with Freidin. It's such a turn off if you're actually interested in linguistics.
Don't take it if Freidin is teaching it. He's a nice guy, but not a good teacher.
Don't.
Even if you think you're not interested in linguistics, it's good to try it out and see what it's like
Good for a blow-off course, very minimal readings and day-to-day work. Freidin's lectures weren't the best but his precepts were a little better.
Huh?
I would not in any way recommend this course to anyone.

I would say that this course is interesting for somebody who is interested in the material, but not a good bet for someone who is just taking it to fulfill a requirement. The material is often very abstract and presented in a confusing way for someone who has never taken it before. Although the grading is very fair and the professor is very approachable, I would not take this course as an easy way to fulfill a distribution requirement...I struggled a lot with it.

If Freidin's teaching it, I recommend against this course, as you'll go through a lot of unnecessary pain trying to understand him. Otherwise I recommend it, the material is very interesting. Linguistics is cool stuff, you'll never think of language quite the same way again.

If you have to take this class with this professor, listen carefully to what he says in class and take more notes than he recommends. Otherwise you'll miss things he expects you to know on tests and problem sets.
Interesting material, but I would not recommend taking this with Freidin.
It is unlikely that I would recommend this course to a friend.
It's a good distribution requirement. Not too much work.
It's not an incredibly difficult course, but just be sure to look at who is teaching it because apparently that makes the experiences in the course night and day.
Lectures were disorganized, to the point that they were largely useless.

Only take this course if you feel self-motivated enough to learn on your own, because unclear lectures won't teach you the material. There is some interesting material here, but it's muddled by frustration and boredom.
Speaking to Professor Friedin at office hours was perhaps the most beneficial part of the course. Understand the material before coming to lecture.
Steer clear.

Take this course if you are at all interested in linguistics. It can be a bit dry and disorganized, but if you want to see if you like the subject, take it. Some people LOVE it, but they already know who they are and don't need any prodding.
Think long and hard before taking this class.
This course is not much work, but the material is very uninteresting.
This is an interesting course.

Try to go into office hours if you don't understand what's happening in lecture. He won't help you with questions directly associated to the PS, but still gives some guidance. Keep up with the readings, they'll help you through lecture.

Try to keep up with the course and make use of the list of terms Professor posts every week, they are really helpful. Meet with Anton, he is really helpful, if you don't understand something especially if it is not in the book.It is an interesting topic as well, so anyone who is interested in the dynamic of languages should try it.
With this professor, do not take.
You have to teach yourself everything. The material's relatively interesting, but try the class with a different professor.
avoid this class like the plague if Freidin is teaching.  he is a horrible teacher and should not be teaching undergrads at this school.
don't take this as an easy course--it's really only good for people who are actually interested in the mechanics of linguistics
wait two years - let them fix the course before you try to take it
descrip: Introduction to the major areas, problems and techniques of modern linguistics, providing an overview of what is known about human language: its unique nature, structure, universality and diversity.

title: Theory of Algorithms
reviews: Algorithms are a very important part of theory. Also, this class is probably the second most popular theory course. Wayne makes great slides that are tremendously useful.
An awesome class, and with Prof. Wayne, covers lots of very useful topics.

Arguably my favorite course I have taken at Princeton.  (I say this a COS major with an interest in CS theory.)  Be prepared to think a lot, and sometimes not arrive at the right answer - but I can't recommend it highly enough.
Be prepared to spend time writing clean proofs, but Wayne and the TAs are very helpful.
Don't take this course unless you know you have an incredible amount of time to devote to the material and don't mind the hardest course ever.
Even if you're not very good at the math side of COS, this is a must - you'll struggle through it, but you'll love it anyway.

Go to all lectures, read all the material, go to all the precepts. GO TO OFFICE HOURS. If you like the theory side of COS, this course is a great overview of topics. I've heard a few horror stories about the course when other professors besides Kevin Wayne have taught it, though.

Go to office hours every week.  Look at the problem sets as soon as they're released so you can be thinking about them whenever possible (even while you're walking to class).  Lecture slides alone are helpful, but lectures are much, more helpful.  I would highly recommend the course WITH PROFESSOR WAYNE; I've heard bad things with other professors (Tarjan, Chazelle).
I really recommend this class taught by Wayne. However, be prepared for a consistent workload.
I strongly recommend this course if Kevin Wayne is teaching it.

I would recommend the course. My advice for students would be take the course if they know a lot of other students who will be taking the course because group work in assignments seems essential to success in the course (to check answers with other students, to work through solutions and proofs in detail, etc).
If Kevin Wayne is teaching this, I'd recommend taking it.

If Kevin Wayne teaches this, I highly recommend taking it. The course varies a lot depending on professor, but algorithms is definitely a useful topic to study, and probably the best option for that second theory course. That said, be prepared to put most of your time into this class, so don't take too intense classes along with it.
If taught by Professor Wayne, it's a great way to get a theory course and I was very pleased with the course.

If you have the opportunity to take this course with Kevin Wayne, absolutely do it. It's a decent amount of work and occasionally very stressful. Don't take it as part of an over-full course-load (especially don't take it with Graphics and independent work).

If you need a theory requirement and are not terrified of mathematical thinking, this is your choice.  It is interesting, well prepared/presented, and actually useful which is more than can be said for most of the other theory classes.  This will be the class you spend the most hours worrying about every week so plan your schedule accordingly.

If you need another theory and you had fun (if not necessarily an easy time) in 340, take it! I like Professor Wayne, and the problem sets aren't too bad. The TAs also did a good job. The lenient collaboration policy makes it less stressful than it could have been. I feel like my proof skills have improved a lot!

If you think you might have difficulty with the material, make sure to stay with the readings, go to all available office hours, and find people to work with as soon as possible. If not, I think you'll really enjoy the material ? it's a bit tough, but extremely fascinating.

If you're willing to put in a ton of work, you will get a lot out of this class. Prof. Wayne is extremely hard working and fair, and the material is very interesting. But be warned that it can consume an enormous amount of time.
It's a great course! You will learn a ton. this class really makes you feel like you know computer science. The only thing is that the problem sets are VERY time consuming.

Kevin Wayne is great! He's super organized. Also, I highly recommend collaboration. Some questions require a "flash of insight", and having people in the group makes that "flash" take place earlier/with higher probability.
Obviously time consuming, but also rewarding and interesting. Would highly recommend taking it with Professor Wayne, but not sure about any other professor.
Problem sets take a lot of time. Take it with friends. Make sure to brush up on your proof technique.

Professor Wayne is an excellent professor, and the class is very well-structured. Although the problem sets took me an extremely long time, the material was very interesting and I learned a ton. The first half of the course, when we had problem sets every week was difficult to manage. The second half of the course, when we had problem sets every other week, was much more manageable. Do not take this with other time-intensive CS courses.

Professor and TAs refuse to grant aid and offer conflicting responses to basic questions. Lectures incomprehensible and problem sets are trash; evaluated arbitrarily and are full of errors. This course is the culmination of the race towards the bottom that is the computer science department. Take it if you wish to suffer.
Strongly recommend.
Take it if it you find algorithms interesting, or if they will be necessary. It's a lot of work, but you learn everything.
Take this class if you enjoy solving interesting algorithmic puzzles. Although, be sure not to underestimate the workload. This class kind of resembles 340 on crack.
Take this class if you like theory and proofs.
Take this class if you like theory. Very good class.

Take this course if and only if you like theory and algorithms and don't have other large commitments. It is a tough course, but incredibly rewarding. You learn how to design algorithms to solve problems.
Take this course if you're interested in theory.
The lectures are great. The homework is worth the time. Don't care about the grades too much

This course is a LOT of work every semester, but the instruction and the material apparently vary quite widely based on the professor.  Professor Wayne was fantastic, with great textbook and lectures.  The precepts were very useful, definitely go if you don't understand the types of problems in that week.
If you struggled in 340, expect this course to take roughly as much time as the rest of your courses put together.

This course is maybe the most difficult course I have taken.  Every problem set was a struggle.  But, I have also learned more in this course than in almost any other COS course, and I feel that COS 423 more than many other courses has prepared me well for work in this field beyond college.
This course is not easy. If you're interested in more advanced algorithms, you should definitely take it.
This is a hard course if you don't have a background in this field. Also, use the course slides more often. I found that out a bit late.
Unless you love long hours spent on frustratingly opaque problems, I would recommend that you look elsewhere.
Worthwhile class.
prereqs: COS 226 and 340, or permission of instructor.
descrip: Design and analysis of efficient data structures and algorithms. General techniques for building and analyzing algorithms. Introduction to NP-completeness.

title: International News - Covering the World
reviews: I think he was a visiting professor but if Witte ever comes back.. take it!!
If Griff is ever teaching a course again, TAKE IT!!!!!
TAKE IT
The class is great but you need to really enjoy writing as you will be doing A LOT of it, in addition to spending time reporting - it eats up a lot of time.
take this class. you will not regret it!
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: Foreign correspondents must immerse themselves in the places they cover, while maintaining enough perspective to tell a story that resonates with far-away readers. We will analyze examples of international reporting to see how they do this. Students will learn what it takes to cover the world beyond our borders at a time when genuinely enlightening international affairs coverage is desperately needed. Writing assignments will encourage students to explore unfamiliar surroundings, even within Princeton.

title: Roman Catholic Moral Theology
descrip: An introduction to contemporary Roman Catholic moral theology. Part I provides traditional background, focusing on the moral manuals used in the Sacrament of Penance. Part II examines the roles of natural law, Scripture, tradition, and the magisterium in Roman Catholic thinking. Part III considers the evaluation of human acts, the cultivation of virtues, and the responsibilities of persons in community. The course ends by taking up disputes over feminism and homosexuality.

title: Nathaniel Hawthorne and American Exceptionalism
descrip: This seminar will examine the Democratic Review (1830s-'50s) writers and their ideas, ideas that have come to be known as "American exceptionalism." The seminar will read and discuss at length Hawthorne's nuanced and ambiguous contributions to the theory.

title: Diffuse Matter in Space
reviews: Highly recommended for those who are interested in astrophysics. Very useful materials to learn.
Pay attention to the lengths of the assignments, and get an early start on them, especially if they are long.
Remember to do reading carefully before class and prepare questions.
descrip: Subject of course is the astrophysics of the interstellar medium: theory and observations of the gas, dust, plasma, energetic particles, magnetic field, and electromagnetic radiation in interstellar space. Emphasis will be on theory, including elements of: fluid dynamics; excitation of atoms, molecules and ions; radiative processes; radiative transfer; simple interstellar chemistry; and physical properties of dust grains.The theory will be applied to phenomena including; interstellar clouds (both diffuse atomic clouds and dense molecular clouds); HII regions; shock waves; supernova remnants; cosmic rays; interstellar dust; and star formation.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences IV
reviews: I mean, if you've made it this far, why stop now? It is seriously better than last year, though. I imagine this semester must be easy for those who are also in organic chemistry, but if not, it's still pretty decent.

I would recommend this course to those who have taken first year Integrated Science but were disappointed by the lack of biology in the first year to take the second year sequence. The second year is really intensive on the biology and biochemistry. Fortunately, the problem sets in the second year are more manageable than those from first year Integrated.
