If you haven't taken orgo before this semester, I'm warning you that it will be a whirlwind of information. It's insanely fast paced but I think it's worth it in the end to get credit for both Orgo and Biochem (at least for MOL majors).
If you've made it through the first year of ISC, this will seem easy.

It's ISC biochem, so if you have seen orgo, you're fine, if not, be prepared for some unpleasantness. The neuro stuff is cool, although if you really are interested in neuroscience, take an actual class.
Take ISC
Use the textbooks, especially the biochem textbook because it has excellent diagrams of glycolysis and the tca cycle.
if you have gotten this far in ISC you already know what is going on.
prereqs: Students are expected to have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 235..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, genomics, evolution and neuroscience. This is the second course in the year-long multidisciplinary integrated science sequence. Multiple faculty will be involved over the year: D. Botstein, M. Murthy, E. Wieschaus (MOL), J. Rabinowitz (CHM), P. Andolfatto (EEB). 2 hrs and 40 min of lecture, one precept (1 hr 50 min), one evening problem session.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: I feel sad you won't ever get to work with Yakub. I would have taken this course again next year if he had been the one teaching it. Having said that, TAKE EPICS. It is one of the best kept secrets at Princeton. You learn oodles and grades are secondary. The class is also barely any work.
I would say make sure that you stay on top of your work, and try to get to know what others are doing.

I'd recommend this course because you're actually doing something practical, rather than theoretical problem sets or readings. It gives you a chance to think outside the box and devise innovative solutions to problems with a larger group of students.
Love it
TAKE IT!!! EPICS is amazing, unlike any other course at Princeton.
Take it if you are interested

Take it! Professor Littman is the nicest and most supportive professor ever who will let you take the initiative to do something new if you want to. Note though that this is unstructured. So you will get what you want out of it.
Take the course if you've an interest in the specific project.
Take this course if you want to gain hands on experience working on an engineering project, and want to help shape a project or bring a project to a higher level.
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Risk Analysis
descrip: This course aims to develop the ability to use analytic frameworks in the formulation and assessment of public policy. We consider many different analytical techniques with an emphasis on decision-making under uncertainty. The emphasis is on how to apply the models to different public policies rather than on how to derive the theoretical underpinnings of the models. Most of these models are solved in Excel or other software packages. Techniques include: Probabilistic risk analysis (event trees, Bayesian decision theory); Decision Analysis; Monte Carlo simulation; Linear programming; and Markov chain models.

title: Homer
reviews: Absolutely take it.

Be ready to put a lot of time in the class. You read a lot of lines per night, and since you have class 4 days a week, it is a HUGE time commitment. Translate with a friend so that you can split looking up vocab, since the page flipping is where most of the time goes. That being said, reading Homer is pretty awesome. If you like languages, definitely take it, just be warned.

By the end of the semester, we were having a greek assessment every monday, which required pretty intense studying. These filled my weekends and kept me from spending time with my other coursework. If you are going to take Homer, do not expect to devote yourself very much to any other course.
I would recommend this course for concentrators.
If you're reading Greek, read Homer (read: take this course)
Infinitely more work than 105, but you will definitely improve your abilities in the language. Be warned, however, of the amount of time this class will consume (~2 hrs a night)

It's a hard course. Make sure you prepare, never miss class, and see the professor if you need help. Always remember that you're reading a great text. If you like Greek or you like Homer, take the class!
My main problem with the class was that I didn't think Prof. Brumbaugh's instruction was helpful or interesting.
This course is great for learning to read Homer. The frequency of assignments and exams makes the course strenuous so take care to never fall behind.

This course takes a LOT of time! be prepared for long hours of translating for homework and really try to keep up on vocab. Falling behind is not difficult and nearly impossible to recover from. Try to have fun...it makes the translating less painful!
This course will take more than an hour a night.  You will come out of it a true scholar of Greek.  It's Homer, what more could you ask for?!
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: An initiation into Homeric poetry, this course is intended to provide students with fluency in the language, meter and cultural sensibility of Greek epic. We will read significant excerpts of the Iliad and Odyssey, as well as seminal scholarship and essays about the nature of Homeric epic.

title: Writing Cultures: Ethnographic Facts and Fictions
prereqs: This course presumes prior familiarity with sociocultural anthropology. It is particularly appropriate for junior and senior anthropology majors writing JPs and Senior Theses and for anthropology graduate students writing up field research (dissertation-related and otherwise). Non-anthropology students with some anthropology coursework are also welcome: this course is most appropriate for students with a special interest in ethnography and/or in one or more of the other genres we will be discussing (e.g., history, fiction)..
descrip: Comparing ethnography (anthropologists' signature form) with related nonfiction genres (history, journalism, memoir), we focus on questions about truth and "truthiness": about evidence, expertise, credibility, and authority and about literary form (e.g., voice, metaphor, and technical jargon). We consider how different genres are recognized as such in acts of evaluation by expert and lay readers; and what their distinctive evaluative standards allow or disallow. Throughout, we seek fresh ways of thinking about the ethical dilemmas of ethnography and related genres by juxtaposing them to the ethical dilemmas of fiction-writing.

title: Atmospheric and Oceanic Wave Dynamics
descrip: Observational evidence of atmospheric and oceanic waves; laboratory simulation. Surface and internal gravity waves; dispersion characteristics; kinetic energy spectrum; critical layer; forced resonance; instabilities. Planetary waves: scale analysis; physical description of planetary wave propagation; reflections; normal modes in a closed basin. Large-scale barclinic and barotropic instabilities. Eady and Charney models for barclinic instability, and energy transfer.

title: Versailles: Court and Culture from Louis XIV to Marie-Antoinette
reviews: Professor Schr?der is a phenomenal teacher and this interdisciplinary course based on studies of the arts, literature, politics, and history creates a comprehensive narrative to understanding Versailles as a cultural institution. Do take the course and savor it!

Professor Schroder is very keen on discussing material that interests the class, and therefore sends around a survey before the first meeting to learn what people want to study. The blackboard posts can be a little tiresome, but overall I would definitely recommend taking this class.
Take this class!  It is very rewarding and a truly comprehensive look at Versailles.  It is surprising how relevant many of the readings were to modern life and especially life at Princeton...
Take this--Schroder is wonderful and the material is fascinating.

This course was the best course I have taken at Princeton. Professor Schroder is a very hands-on, knowledgeable and likable professor with reasonable expectations for his students. The subject matter is also fascinating and offers an in depth look at a time in French history that I only had a shallow understanding of before. Take this class, especially if you're looking for a French course that isn't too heavy on the literature.
descrip: Three hundred and fifty years ago, the young king of France, Louis XIV, transformed the modest hunting lodge of Versailles into the site par excellence of absolute monarchy and court society. This course will study the making and meaning of the palace and its gardens, and analyze some of the manifold cultural artifacts associated with them. Readings, both literary and non-literary, will be complemented by various visual resources, ranging from original engravings to websites and films.

title: Forms of Literature - Literature and War
reviews: Do the readings before class - it might make sense for you to flag more pages with things you want to discuss. The more you think about things, the better the class will be for you.
If you like war a lot or literature a lot then you will be decently engaged. If not then I would steer clear.
This course has a lot of reading and can be challenging, but the material is very interesting.

This is a great class for anyone interested in war and media. It covers all forms of war media from memoirs, documentaries, and news reports to novels, poems, and TV shows. We had great discussions and were able to enjoy and appreciate the material. I would definitely recommend this course - especially to someone looking for fun, unstressful discussions.
descrip: How is The Iliad related to "The Hurt Locker"? What does "The Charge of the Light Brigade" have to do with an online combat blog? This course will explore the desire and failure to record the experience of war. What can the techniques, tropes, and tragedies to which we have become accustomed teach us about the way war is represented in literature and film? We'll read poetry, novels, memoirs, comics, blogs, and watch documentaries and films about both the First World War and the contemporary conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan to think about media, representation, and the literature of conflict then and now.

title: Motor Control and Learning
reviews: Ask questions. Engage yourself as much as possible. Dr. Taylor grades very fairly and encourages students to present opposing points of view.  His perspective is unique and provokes a re-assessment of your assumptions.  For example, one study investigated the concept of positive contagion, and, while some laughed at the idea and considered it pseudoscientific, he thought of a relevant marketing application for the findings.
Definitely take this course!  It is really interesting, Professor Taylor is great, and it is very fairly graded and has a very manageable amount of work! Highly recommend.
Eh, it's alright. Not terribly difficult, but not terribly engaging.
Good class to take for the neuro certificate

I definitely recommend a neuro background for this course; you go into detail about the different motor circuits and pathways. That said, you really get the chance to engage with the literature and think how to improve previous experiments/test the dilemmas discussed in class.
If you are interested in neuroscience and motor control, this is a great way to learn more about it.
It is difficult and a fair amount of work, but really rewarding and cool subject material. Taylor is a great, engaged, receptive professor and a talented lecturer.

Take this course if you can. If you have hated Psychology/Neuroscience up to this point, Professor Taylor will change your mind. The material is solid and scientifically verifiable and at the very least, it highlights interesting results that provide excellent topics of extracurricular discussion and explanation for certain life phenomena.
prereqs: PSY 255 (Cognitive Psychology).
descrip: In this course, we will examine how the nervous system controls movements, how the brain handles enormous computational complexities of movement, how motor skills are learned and consolidated, and how the motor system influences cognition.

title: Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer
reviews: Complete the reading before class, start the homework early, and go to office hours if you have questions.
Don't be late.
Don't show up late or you might be asked to leave.
Focus on the office hours, even if (or especially if?) it's to the detriment of your actual attendance of lectures.
I would say that to do well it is important to stay on top of the material by reading the notes and book.
It is a great course for understanding heat and mass transfer. It is especially good if taken together with some sort of fluid dynamics class.
N/A
Prof.'s lecture notes is a great way to get some basic ideas and then read the textbook to get a deeper understanding of course materials.
Read Deen to get context for Cliff's lectures and you will get more out of them.
Strongly recommended.
The lecture notes posted online are easier to follow than the textbook, so take advantage of them.
This is a great course with a great professor.
descrip: A survey of modeling and solutions methods for processes involving heat and mass transfer. Topics will include convective and diffusive transport, conservation equations, scaling principles and approximation techniques, forced convection, multi-component energy and mass transfer as well as buoyancy and turbulent driven transport.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: It is mandatory, so just take it when you have to.
NA
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: Anyone with a general interest in Finance should take this course. There's virtually no math, so you don't have to be an Econ student to take it, though it may help.
Do the readings he tells you to and just enjoy the lecture!

For anyone interested in finance, particularly financial markets in Asia, this course is a must-take. It's quite different than any other course I've taken, but I learned a lot of different approaches to investing and how to think about investments in both the long and short term.
Great ECO departmental without too much work. And you actually learn a good amount.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in the topic.
Lots of reading
Only take if you have a genuine interest in capital markets.

Take the class, participate. It's not hard to do well if you do the readings and closely track Asian markets throughout the semester. Take good notes during lectures, because they'll really help for the final essays
Take this if you want to learn something about Asian economics
This is one of the best courses you can take if you are interested in finance and buy-side theory.
prereqs: For those who are unable to register because the course is full, please contact Professor De Swaan directly (jdeswaan@princeton.edu). Juniors need special permission from instructor to enroll..
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and the policy decisions faced by the Chinese and US governments relative to existing global imbalances.

title: An Introduction to Engineering
reviews: A good 5th course if you're an Engineer and are still undecided.
Attend lectures and be open to the information presented.
Definitely take it, it is a great 5th course, especially for engineers!
Enjoy it!
Fun PDF course! It helped me in solidifying my departmental choice, and the labs and lectures were chill yet informative.
Great class. Take it.
I enjoyed it; after taking it, I know that I probably won't enjoy cos or mechanical or electrical engineering. Don't expect to find out much about ORFE though.

I regret taking this course. Sure I wanted a survey of the different engineering departments, but the lectures were not engaging enough, the class had no work, and it was PDF only, which all made it hard to pay attention. The first two weeks of class were for one brief overview of each department and honestly, those first two week were the most helpful. Maybe sign up, go to the first two weeks, and then drop the class. I was disappointed with the ORFE presentation, though, since the professor actually went into an optimization problem instead of giving an overview of the department. For the rest of the semester, emphasis is placed on CBE, MAE, and ELE. You can take the class if you want an easy course that you can just do work for other classes in. Otherwise, do not take the class. It's a waste of time and I wish I had not wasted one of my precious Princeton courses on it.

I thought it was very helpful to get a survey of the different engineering departments.  Even though I was already leaning towards ELE or MAE, this class helped me to make a decisive decision for my major.

I thought it would help me choose a department, but it didn't really help much. If you want an easy (no-work) class, it's good, but be prepared to be very bored in the 6 hours per week of mandatory class time.

I would be cautious of taking this course because many find it boring and a waste of time. If you really need help eliminating an engineering major or seeing what one is like then take it. Otherwise stay away!

I would not recommend this course - one could get out more by actually taking a departmental engineering course to eliminate/open one option. I don't think very many people's decisions were influenced by this class.
If you are not sure which type of engineering to declare, this class will help you!
If you do not know what type of engineering to do, you should definitely take this course to explore the opportunities possible.
If you need to pick between ELE or MAE this is definitely for you!

If you're just looking for a 5th class, I would recommend finding an easy distribution requirement instead. This class is really a waste of time. You could get distribution requirement taken care of in the same amount of time.
Only if you really want to learn about the different engineering disciplines.
Pay attention and you might get a lot out of the class. It is a good fifth class but do not put much faith in its ability to help you choose your major.
Remember that this class actually takes up 6 hours of your life weekly. Being engaged in the material is important if you want to make use of your own time.
Super easy class. 4 hours of lecture each week that you don't have to take notes on and a lab. Helpful in choosing which branch of engineering and a credit for no work.

Take it if you want, but it's probably not going to change your mind about your major. I don't think it really helps. One guy made electrical sound really cool, but I don't think it's actually going to be like that, but it made a lot of people sign into the major. I don't know. Up to you.
Take the class if you are completely ambivalent about what engineering you want to major in - it'll help you out.
Take this class. Great course that will help you decide where your engineering futures lie! Amazing lecturers!
This is a good course to take if you are unsure about your engineering major or just need an easy fifth class.
Very low workload; most of the topics covered were pretty interesting; helped give a feel for the different areas of engineering

Very useful, even if you are pretty set on a major, as I was. Even so, it lets you consider which certificates to look into, where you want to specialize, and which breadth classes you want to take. A good way to understand what problems modern-day engineering researchers deal with.

While EGR 194 is good to get brief looks into what each department deals with, the nature of the course is such that there is little in-depth exploration of concepts/lab work that seem probable in the future of a major in that field, save for a few good labs, so taking this course alone might not solidify whether any certain field is "right for you." I would recommend at least looking into actual intro courses in other engineering fields to take alongside EGR 194.
take it for interest
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the various disciplines of engineering. It is a project-based sequence (Energy Conversion and the Environment, Robotic Remote Sensing, and Wireless Image & Video Transmission) that covers engineering disciplines and their relationship to the principles of physics and mathematics.

title: Tragedy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Main Street USA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Geometry and Architectural Representation
prereqs: This course is designed primarily for freshman and sophomores who are interested in gaining introductory experience in design and drawing. This course will help prepare students for ARC 204 and upper-level studios..
descrip: This course sets out two goals: the first is to understand the theories and techniques of geometry in architectural representation; the second is to develop the student's drawing sensibilities through 5 thematic drawing projects engaging both digital and manual techniques. Each new theme will be introduced through a lecture, tutorial, and discussion including a number of specific readings related to the topic at hand. The second class will be an individual desk crit to discuss the development of each drawing project. The third class will consist of a group pin-up review of each drawing experiment.

title: The Modeling Complex
descrip: The modeling complex refers to a category of architectural thinking and working that stretches from the Renaissance to the present. It includes those practices and processes that privilege a dynamic temporal and spatial relationship between architectural things or objects and their effects in the world over time. Things, objects, effects will be studied through readings in theory from architecture, art, philosophy, mathematics and the sciences, and through the examination of case studies.

title: Theories of Literature and the Environment
descrip: Environmental criticism, also known as ecocriticism and "green" criticism, is a rapidly emerging field of literary study that will be crucially important in upcoming decades, especially as our present environmental crisis unfortunately worsens. This course explores a range of works from modern environmental critics, beginning in the 1960s and ending with the ongoing explosion of interest in the field in the 21st century.

title: Financial Econometrics
reviews: A very nice course. If one keeps following the book as well as go through the lecture notes, I am sure that person would do well
Assumes familiarity with R program, useful for statistical analysis of financial data.
Be prepared to commit much effort, but worth it if you are interested in the statistics of finance
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on homework. But you'll likely learn a fair bit.

Core course so you don't have much of a choice. The teacher deserves to be praised for producing lecture notes. But wrriting lectures notes that are not too boring for some and accessible for others with the breadth of the Mfin class seems like an insoluble problem. Lectures have a negative added value. Much more efficient to stay at home and work through the content on your own
Course begs for prior econometrics experience given disconnected assignments and no formal precept.
Dedicate a lot of your time to the course during the semester and read the material a lot. Otherwise it is nearly impossible to stay in touch with the topics.
Go for it, you will learn some basic intuition and principles in financial econometrics. Professor Fan is very helpful and involved.
Go to office hours.  Fan's office wall is covered in accolades, but he is patient and nice to people who are terrible at stats.
If you want to have an insight into the econometrics world, you should try this course
It's a very important and great course to take. The professor is great, and the preceptors are helpful.
It's interesting topics taught in a mediocre way. If you know it it's a good review, otherwise go for something else.
Never leave assignments until the last minute they are extremely time consuming and often take weeks to complete.
Nicest prof ever, great TAs, well-run course. However, the problem sets are ridiculously (and needlessly) time-consuming, which leaves virtually no time to study the course material.
Some amount of familiarity with R programming will be helpful.
Take it if you are good at R.
This course is interesting and very useful for students who are interested in finance and statistics.
This course required lots of input, but is very useful.
This is definitely one course that all finance students should take. It is clearly structured and will bring your knowledge of financial economics to a new level.
Worth taking if you are interested in financial econometrics
You can learn a lot of things from the course
You don't have the choice, do you.
You will go over a lot of material, but 100% understanding of the material is unlikely.
interesting class.
required for Mfins - majority of the class is Mfins.
descrip: Econometric and statistical methods as applied to finance. Topics include: Overview of Statistical Methods; Predictability of asset returns; Discrete time volatility models; Efficient Portfolio and CAPM; Multifactor Pricing Models; Intertemporal Equilibrium and Stochastic Discount Models; Expectation and present value relation; Simulation methods for financial derivatives; Econometrics of financial derivatives; Forecast and Management of Market Risks; Multivariate time series in finance; Nonparametric methods in financial econometrics

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.

title: Special Topics in the History of Science, Technology, and Medicine - Global Science
reviews: I recommand taking it if interested in global history or history of science.

If you are at all interested in the History of Science, you cannot do without taking a class with Professor Gordin. You should make it a priority to take one of his graduate courses, and if there aren't any available, to try and form a reading group off the back of one of his undergraduate courses. He will always match the time and effort you put in, and will give you feedback in the most conscientious manner. If you need a credit for the soon-to-exist global history certificate, you should definitely take this.
If you have even just a passing interest in history of science, take this course.
N/A
Take it. Invest yourself in it. It's worth the effort.
Take this class. TAKE IT.
Take this course - the reading are very manageable and Prof. Gordin is a wonderful professor.
descrip: A distinctive feature of science (in its multiple designations in different cultures) is its geographical unrootedness. Historiographical schools over the past fifty years have experimented with designations for science's trans-local qualities - national styles of science, international science, cosmopolitanism, the Republic of Letters, and so on - with varying degrees of success. This graduate seminar explores the utility of taking a global approach to the history of science. We will explore recent scholarship on topics spanning from colonialism to translation, oceans to hygiene, nationalism to military technology.

title: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition
reviews: Absolutely take this class if you are even remotely interested in computers and/or music. You will learn a great deal, and have a blast making really cool art. Highly recommended!
Definitely apply if you're interested, although they seem to favor COS and MUS majors. It's a lot of fun and you learn tons about stuff you wouldn't learn in any other class.
If you do not have a COS background I would not recommend this class.
Interesting course. Take it!
MOST AMAZING COURSE EVER.  Dan and Konrad are great and they'll help you TONS even if you've never coded before.  So fun to learn about electronic music and play with all their gadgets... :)
Take PLOrk!
Take it
Take it! It was fun and I learned a lot about computer music, and will definitely pursue more in the future.
experience with cos would be extremely helpful.
prereqs: Instructor's permission. Application available in the Music Dept. office..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer and electronic music in the context of the Princeton Laptop Orchestra (PLOrk). The music and sound programming language ChucK, developed here at Princeton, will be used in conjunction with Max/MSP, another digital audio language, to study procedural programming, digital signal processing and synthesis, networking, and human-computer interfacing.

title: Cities and Suburbs in American History
reviews: A little disorganized, and the books are a bit too heavy on race relations, but overall you learn a lot and if you're interested in urban history and doing a little bit of primary source research, it's a GREAT class to take!

Go to lecture, and try to group them by theme, because sometimes they don't always relate to each other well. Good class if you want an introduction to urban planning.

Go to the field trips and LISTEN. they are a good way to learn more about American culture and urban planning. BEST part of the class

I mostly really enjoyed this course. I enjoyed the readings because most of them wove history into a story which is much easy for me to remember and think about than just textbook history. I struggled with the papers and exams because I'm not used to thinking in a historically-analytical way but I would not say they were hard in general. I loved the two field trips to New York we went on and I wish I had attended more of the supplementary documentary screenings Prof. Isenberg arranged. Prof. Isenberg is a wonderful professor who is very interested in the material but also in what her students have to say and what her students are interested in studying. She's very kind, responsive, engaging, and helpful. I did not feel Nabaparna was a good preceptor so try to get Professor Isenberg's precept if possible.
I would say that this is one of the best classes I have taken here to the extent that I have decided to try getting an Urban Studies certificate.
If you have any interest in the subject take this class, it's very challenging, but quite relaxed at the same time. Be prepared to do a lot reading though.
Pick five-page paper topics you like.
Yes.
its hard.
descrip: From the colonial era to the present, this course weaves together a comprehensive history of American cities and suburbs, cutting across social life, politics, economics, culture, and the built environment. Topics include urban planning and design, public and private spaces, social experience, urban investment and disinvestment, the metropolitan economy, politics and policy, arts and culture, city leadership, and the participation of ordinary people in shaping urban and suburban life.

title: Independent Research Project
prereqs: Students MUST sign up in room 121 during course selection period..
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member. Open to sophomores and juniors.

title: The Chemistry of Magic
descrip: See website

title: America and the Melting Pot
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis for Economics
reviews: A very reasonable statistics course that inspires real understanding.

As far as statistics courses go, I think this is one of the better ones Princeton has. You really learn a lot of statistics, and you can feel confident leaving the course. I like how we do a lot more things by hand in this course, so I feel like I actually understand statistics and am not just trying to figure out how to program things. I do recommend going to lectures, because Professor Mueller does a good job, and it will prevent you from having to do much outside reading. If you go to and pay attention in lectures and do the problem sets, you will do well.
As intro stats classes go, it's pretty good. Mueller is a decent professor, and the course is graded fairly. But don't expect to learn any STATA.

Better than most stat classes, is what I can tell from my own class experiences vs. comments from friends that complain about OTHER stat classes!

Ulrich is hysterical.
Definitely go to McGraw for help on problem sets!
Do lots of practice exams and make sure you thoroughly understand concepts
Do the problem sets.
Don't get Stata because you don't ever need it. Take this course if you need to take a stats.
Get ready for a hell of a ride.
Go to McGraw for help with the problem sets as the tutors are very helpful and explain the material well.
Go to lecture
Go to office hours. The professor is very helpful
Good class for an intro to stats. Not terribly difficult if you go to lecture and do the homework's.
Great statistics course to take if you have to take one.
I think Mueller is a great guy and this is important stuff, so take this class!
I would recommend the class if you need to take statistics for some reason. Although I didn't like the material, Mueller's lectures definitely helped make up for it.

If you can avoid it, don't take it.  If you have to take it for ECO pre-requisite, be ready to do lots of tedious algebra.  Stay up to speed on concepts and derivations, because getting behind makes class essentially useless.
If you have to take an intro stats course (or want to), and don't feel comfortable with the level of math in ORF 245, this is a great choice.
If you need to take stats, choose this.
If you want to take a statistics course, I definitely recommend it. Go to lectures, most of the questions asked on exams stem from lectures.

If you want to take an Econ major you don't really have a choice but I would still take this stats over Woodrow Wilson Stats or Pol Stats as they are both very coding heavy whereas this is more math based.

If you're not so sure about your math level but are still interested in taking an engaging, challenging statistics course, take ECO 202! Work hard, ask questions and it will pay off well. Very helpful materials and quantitative thinking skills for any other courses that use statistics or data.
It will be difficult but this course will actually teach you how statistics work vs. just teaching you how to use a software.

It's a fairly straightforward and simple statistics class. It does not go in depth into the theory of the statistics or into the derivations of the equations, so if you do better learning how things works as opposed to just the 'things', I wouldn't recommend it. Otherwise, the class was not terribly strenuous.

It's a good class- go to McGraw for the problem sets if you need to, and if your preceptor is not good, find a preceptor who is good (i.e. David, if he's still teaching for this class) whose precepts you can attend during the week.
It's boring, but not much work and easy enough to pull a B.
Its fine if you need it for your major...its easier than POL345 or ORF245, but if you just want to take an easy stats class, you're better off with either psych stats or soc stats.
Keep up with material
Lectures with Mueller can be dry at times, and problem sets can be tedious; still a good stats course overall
Make sure to attend every lecture and ask questions about difficult problems and tests and homework. The professor and preceptors are extremely approachable.
Make sure you read the class notes.

Material in this course is not presented in a clear fashion in my opinion! Find someone who has already taken stats in some fashion to ask for clarification when necessary. The textbook is also not very helpful. Spend the time before doing problem sets to ensure that you understand the material of the week conceptually!!!!!! It will really help to make the problem set go faster, make sure that you don't get further and further lost during the course of the semester, and make studying for midterms easier.
Mueller was awesome.
Nice way to take stats if you don't want to be forced to learn R.
Only issue was it felt like every single answer to the practice problem tests were incorrect. It was impossible to know if you were doing the questions right because the answers were always wrong.
Only take this class if you have to.
Only take this class if you're a prospective Econ major
Pay attention in class.
Prof. Mueller is very understandable and brings otherwise dull material in an interesting way.
Start early on problem sets and work in groups.
Statistics are important for everyone. I'd recommend the class.
Statistics is statistics. Wish there had been more real world application, but I guess that comes later on in one's studies at Princeton.
Stay on top of the material. A solid understanding of proofs will be useful.
Stay on top of your readings and go to office hours.
Take it if you have to.  If you don't, then don't take it unless you are really interested in statistics.
Take it if you need it as a requirement. Fairly painless

Take it if you need some background in statistics.  Professor Mueller is a very interesting person, although he is a bit eccentric at times.  You'll have to do a decent amount of work to be able to do well in this class.
Take it with ulrich, he's great
Take it. Will learn the basic stats you need for life.
Take it. You'll learn a lot.
Take this course with Professor Mueller! He is hilarious and also very well-educated in his subject. The material is not too difficult, and the workload is manageable.
The course was much more difficult than I expected it to be, but compared to other stats classes, I still would have taken this one.

This class is all right. Only take it if you have to (for a prerequisite or such). The exams can be pretty difficult and so can the problem sets but Professor Mueller let us work in groups for the problem sets which helped a lot.
This is a great stat course to take.

Though not a particularly engaging topic, the lectures are definitely worth going to. On the other hand, if you do decently well on the assignments/understand the assignments, precepts don't tend to be useful.
Ulrich Mueller has great lectures. Makes it interesting.
Understand concepts, don't just plug and chug. See the big picture. Read the book before lectures!
Yes. Definitely take this course for any stats requirement. It is the best one offered.
You have to take this class for Econ and it's going to be an absolute grind.
You know if you have to take this course, so just suck it up and go through it. It won't be as bad as you may hear if you are committed to the course.
You learn a lot about stats in a very clear way.  Professor Mueller was very good- the class may be much more dry with another professor.
You will be expected to understand what the formulas mean, instead of just knowing how to use them.
don't get behind on the concepts!
don't take to pdf.
go to lecture
go to precepts and office hours
good class. stats didn't click for me but it wasn't painful. no coding like in other stats classes
grit your teeth and make it through. it's not too hard, just deadly boring--but is probably as good an intro-stats class as you could expect to get.
i would only take this class if it were required
so hard.  Lectures made me more confused.  But Mueller is an engaging lecture,r its just a boring subject and the proofs he did were way over my head.
study hard and cumulatively
prereqs: MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to probability and statistical methods for empirical work in economics. Probability, random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation and hypotheses testing, introduction to the regression model.

title: Religious Authority in Modern Islam
descrip: How far reaching is the "fragmentation" of religious authority in modern Islam? How have traditional religious scholars sought to rearticulate their authority in conditions of radical change? On what basis do "new religious intellectuals" make their claims to authority? How has the state shaped structures of religious authority? What is peculiar to modern Islam so far as conceptions of and contestations over religious authority are concerned? These are among the questions this seminar seeks to examine.

title: Linguistic Semantics
reviews: If you are interested in linguistics, you should take this course.
If you get excited about resolving ambiguities in sentences, or if you love logic, or if you love thinking about how people understand sentences (or think that you might!) - take this class!
It helps to take other linguistics classes (especially syntax) before this one.
It will be easier if you have a basic grasp of math/CS terminology (talking about functions etc.) It's lots of fun, and quite rigorous for what sounds like a very "fuzzy" subject.
prereqs: LIN 201.
descrip: An introduction to central issues and leading theories of linguistic semantics for natural languages. Analysis of specific linguistic phenomena (including: anaphora, quantification, and tenses) will be used to illustrate the interaction of syntax and semantics, the relation between language and the world, and the role of linguistic meaning in communication and understanding.

title: Analysis I: Fourier Series and Partial Differential Equations
reviews: All math majors should take this class.
Definitely take this course as a good introduction to higher level analysis.
I thoroughly enjoyed this course. Take it if you need a Real Analysis course.
I would strong recommend this course if you are thinking of pursuing a math major at Princeton and/or if you are interested in the mathematics behind probabilistic sciences.
If you're a math major not particularly interested in analysis, this is a great way to take the real class out of the way. Also, Jon Fickenscher is a great teacher!
Take it not only for Fourier analysis, but the cool insights into other parts of mathematics.
This class is hard but interesting.  Just plan to spend a lot of time on problem sets.
prereqs: MAT215, 218, or consent of instructor..
descrip: Basic facts about Fourier Series, Fourier Transformations, and applications to the classical partial differential equations will be covered. Also Fast Fourier Transforms, Finite Fourier Series, Dirichlet Characters, and applications to properties of primes.

title: High-Energy Physics
reviews: This is a very good course.
You will be able to calculate Standard Model cross sections. Very helpful for a general overview of particle physics, used for decscribing the real world.
descrip: An overview of modern elementary particle physics and the Standard Model. Specific topics include: weak decays, W and Z physics, deep inelastic scattering, CP violation, neutrino oscillations, Higgs searches, with an emphasis on areas of current interest. Course also covers concepts in experimental tools and techniques.

title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Geometry. Specific topic details provided when course is offered.

title: Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: Definitely worth taking if you're interested in the subject matter.  Great way to skip out on chem core lab.
Don't fall behind.
Don't take it unless you have to or have some burning interest in Materials. It'll pretty much do little to interest you in materials if that interest is not already there.

HE IS AWESOME AND FUNNY.
He is the best lecturer I ever had. He  is funny to drag my attention to the course all the time. But, it was also in depth and informative. Be prepared to enjoy!!!
If it's taught by Arnold, take it.
If taught by Professor Arnold, I would highly recommend.

If you have any interest in materials like crystals or metals then you should take this course.  However that is all the course covers, crystals and metals and how they behave under certain conditions.
If you're a sophomore thinking about CHM - TAKE THIS CLASS! Then you can do the MSE core lab, not the CHM one. DO IT. Plus, the certificate is pretty straightforward for a chem major.
Not a terribly difficult course. As a chem major, I was expecting more chemistry and less engineering, so I didn't find it particularly enjoyable.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton. Arnold is amazing, and you should take this class. Particularly good for CHM majors, although only the first half of the class is really chemistry-based.
Take if interested in materials. Good introduction, does not go very much in depth, but covers a wide enough range of things for you to get a feel of material science.

The way Prof. Arnold teaches this class, it is biased heavily towards the mechanical properties of materials. As a chemist, I would have appreciated a bit of a broader scope. He's a fun lecturer though. Take it if you're interested in materials--not much else to say here.
This course is extremely interesting, but the people who take it are very competitive. If you are willing to compete for a good great then, I recommend it.
This course is pretty good. For MAE's I would recommend taking the MAE version, as I was a bit disappointed with the treatment of stress/strain.

This is an interesting class. It will integrate different concepts to teach you about materials. Be comfortable thinking both qualitatively and quantitatively. Start problem sets early. Be ready to think in three dimensions easily.
Yes, if you want to get the certificate or are just generally interested.
You will learn a lot. Pay attention - especially to things you're interested in. Super helpful class! Make sure you take it with Prof. Arnold!
fun class to take, learn a lot about world around you.
this is definitely a decent class and an easy way to get a certificate
prereqs: Calculus, physics, and chemistry. Course will expect some level of organic chemistry; students to carry out some basic derivation of equations. Freshmen should speak with course instructor for approval to enroll..
descrip: An introduction to the structure and properties of important current and future materials, including metals, semiconductors, and polymers. Emphasis will be placed on the phase behavior and processing of materials, and how structure in these materials impact their macroscopic physical, electrical, and thermal properties.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese I
prereqs: JPN 306 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: This course is targeted to students whose Japanese proficiency is at an advanced or superior level. In this class students will (1) learn Japanese business manners and speak and write business Japanese, and (2) discuss various issues in international relations focusing on Asian nations, using dramas, short novels and editorials. Through these activities, students will develop critical thinking skills as well as Japanese language skills.

title: Theories of Secularization
descrip: This course surveys debates about the meaning and extent of secularization since around 1650. We will pay particular attention to the secularization of political norms and institutions. In the first unit, we will consider the early-modern shift from theological conceptions of reality to naturalism, from public sanctity to private faith, and from revealed to civil law. In the second unit, we will consider theories of secularization from the 19th and 20th centuries that emphasize the superficiality or failure of these shifts. Finally, we will consider two influential defenses of secularization.

title: Hellenistic Philosophy
prereqs: At least one prior philosophy course, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course surveys the three main schools of post-classical Greek philosophy: Epicureanism, Stoicism, and Skepticism (Academic and Pyrrhonian). While the contributions of these philosophers in all three divisions of philosophical study recognized at that time--dialectic or logic, philosophy of language and theory of knowledge; ethics; and physical and metaphysical theory --will be included, the emphasis will be on dialectic, physics and metaphysics.

title: Advanced Research Methods
prereqs: SOC 300.
descrip: Designed as an extension of SOC 300, this course will be of particular help to students interested in questions of research design. Students will gain greater proficiency in deploying data, in using case studies more effectively in their research, and in writing up the results of a research study.

title: Comparative Bureaucracy
descrip: A seminar dealing theoretically and empirically with the role of bureaucracy as an integral part of the political system, with an emphasis on the relation of the governmental bureaucracy to other governmental institutions (political parties, executives, legislatures) and to nongovernmental institutions. All aspects are treated comparatively. The course covers different methodologies to the study of bureaucracy.

title: Atomic Bombing and Firebombing Cities in World War II: Morality, Science and Race
descrip: See website

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: EPICS is a really unique course at Princeton. It's almost more like an extracurricular than a class. There is no work outside class and you just work in small groups on an ongoing project.

I would recommend this class if you are looking for something different than your normal course work. You can work together with students to solve problems you may not normally come across in your daily life.
TAKE IT.  Prof Littman RULES
Take this class if you don't have much engineering experience but would like to learn. It's fun and not too demanding.
definitely take this course.  It is very easy and gives you an opportunity to learn about mechanical things, even if you aren't an engineer.
prereqs: Completion of EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: The World and Britain c. 1830-c.1960
descrip: During the second and third quarters of the 19th century, Britain reached the apogee of its global dominance but from the 1870s, while its empire continued to expand, its position was increasingly challenged. In the aftermath of two World Wars, the empire dissolved in only 50 years, and Britain itself experienced successive "invasions". After 1945, onetime "colonial" peoples settled in Britain in unprecedented numbers; the country joined the EU, and increasingly accepted Washington's lead in foreign policy. This seminar re-examines these shifts and their British and trans-continental implications.

title: Introduction to German Philosophy
reviews: Honestly, just keep an open mind, pay attention in lecture, and make sure you find time to do at least some of the reading. The reading is hard, but if you think long enough and listen to the professor's explanation, that "aha" or "wow that's pretty cool" moment when you realize something is truly satisfying and worth the interpretive struggle.

I thought it was a great course and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants an EC that probes deeper questions about knowledge and meaning, rather than psychology. You'll walk away understanding where the major arguments in a lot of Western metaphysics are situated.

If one is not interested in German philosophy, one should not try to do the readings and struggle unnecessarily. However, any social scientist or humanist would benefit from taking the course, and the readings always got me to think.
If you are at all interested in going somewhere with German philosophy or metaphysics, this class offers a great foundation. Very thought-provoking.
If you are looking for a very cursory reading course in German philosophy, this course is a good idea.
If you have any interest in philosophy and are willing to read difficult texts, you should certainly take this course.

If you're looking for a very good intro to German philosophy or Western thought in general (especially if you don't want to take HUM), TAKE THIS CLASS. There is little to no work other than readings, and you will do fine if you GO TO LECTURE.
It is a wonderful class. It will be hard at times, yet the grading is fair, the writing workload not so great (except for the Final anyways), and it will be fun.

It is incredibly difficult, the readings are almost impossibly dense. If you want to make the effort, pourciau is a good lecturer and the selections are important material. A LOT of work if you don't want to feel completely swamped
Skim the readings before lecture and then try to read them in depth as time allows.
Take it and don't be scared that the material will be too hard. Professor Pourciau is great at explaining even the hardest theory, but make sure you go to all the lectures.
Take the time to wrestle with the readings.
Take this course! This is a great crash course. Just be prepared to consult alternative texts if the material becomes too deep!
Very interesting course! Readings and concepts were definitely difficult sometimes, but very rewarding and fun to think about.
good intro-philosophy class (German intellectual more importantly)
take it if you like philosophy at all and are determined
descrip: An introduction to the German philosophical tradition from the Enlightenment to the present through the study of its major figures (Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Wittgenstein, Heidegger, Adorno, Luhmann). This course offers a survey of German intellectual history, which engages directly and closely with the original texts. Domains to be explored include metaphysics, aesthetics, the theory of knowledge, political philosophy and philosophy of language.

title: Principles of Macromolecular Structure: Protein Folding, Structure and Design
reviews: Great class. Learned a lot.
Great course. You will learn a lot about very fundamental protein science.
I would definitely recommend taking this course if you are interested in thinking about proteins and how they function.
If you have even the slightest interest in this course, you should take it. It was very interesting and very well done. Even if you are  an undergraduate, I highly recommend it.
If you're interested in protein structure, take this course.
Take it.

This course is very interesting for those that want to learn about protein folding/design. I think this course would be of particular interest for chemistry or molecular biology students, but would also be useful for students interested in computational biology as it pertains to protein folding and protein structure prediction.
great course, very specific focus but it has broader applications
descrip: This course will be taught from the scientific literature. We will begin the semester with several classic papers on protein folding. As the semester progresses, we will read about protein structure, stability, and folding pathways. The latter part of the semester will focus on recent papers describing new research aimed toward the construction of novel proteins from "scratch." These papers will cover topics ranging from evolution in vitro to computational and rational design. The course will end by discussing the possibility of creating artificial proteomes in the laboratory, and further steps toward synthetic biology.

title: Introduction to Islamic Law
reviews: Not a stressful class and Prof. Modarressi is a legend! Knows everything about the subject and is a very kind and thoughtful professor.
Only take it if you're interested in the subject, otherwise you may fall behind in the readings and/or not pay attention in class, as it's very easy to do since it's not really a seminar.
Take this class, do all the readings, and go to every seminar.
descrip: A survey of the history of Islamic law and its developments, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to term with the challenges of modern times. It will focus on issues in constitutional and personal laws that have the greatest relevance to the modern era.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, examination, or other evidence of accomplishment will be required. Students generally spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.

title: Topics in Automorphic Forms
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Automorphic Forms. Specific topic information provided when the course is taught.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: Absolutely recommended
Be prepared to do a lot of reading to get the most out of this course
Read the papers before attending the class.
descrip: Macro implications of micro imperfections. The "cleansing" effect of recessions and the impact of allocative versus aggregate shocks. Recent models of consumption and empirical tests of risk-sharing. How the distribution of income or wealth affects aggregate growth and fluctuations. Role of imperfect credit markets, distributional conflict and political economy. Endogenous, skill-biased, technological change and human capital accumulation; implications for growth and social mobility.

title: Topics in 19th- and Early 20th-Century Music - Music and Dance
descrip: This seminar concerns the relationships and non-relationships between music and dance in ballets from c. 1830 to c. 1930 as well as in several much more recent works conceived by the choreographer and director Mark Morris (MM) for the Mark Morris Dance Group. (One of the seminar leaders, Tina Fehlandt, is Morris's assistant.) The focus of the course, broadly speaking, is to challenge existing conceptions about ballet by exploring lesser-known repertoire, analyzing the manner in which leading composers and choreographers of the period have been constructed by historians, and assessing their works on their own terms.

title: Readings in Chinese Literature - Chinese Theater, 900-1900
descrip: An introduction to Chinese opera from the Song until the Republican period. Opera texts will be read in conjunction with issues pertinent to cultural history: the architectural history of the stage, the urban and rural environment of opera, the global circulation of opera, the relationship between religious ritual and literary performance, as well as issues of physicality, sexuality, gender, patronage, and class. Primary texts will include the Yuan opera Zhao shi gu er (and the Voltaire play Orphelin de la Chine), Tang Xianzu's Mudan ting, Li Yu's Qingzhong pu, Kong Shangren's Taohua shan, and Chen Sen's novel Pinhua baojian.

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
reviews: Definitely take it if you can. It was a privilege to be able to take this class twice.
Definitely take this course if you play an instrument.
Great course.
Have a group that you will enjoy playing with and that have the same dedication to the course as you do
I highly recommend this class.
If you are an instrumentalist, you should not leave Princeton without taking this course.
If you enjoy chamber music, at least consider auditioning for the course. It is a great way to develop your skills as a musician, with a piece and a group that you get to decide.

If you're even slightly considering this course as a relatively accomplished musician, definitely take it! It's a lot of fun. Serena was very refreshing to work with and I felt that this was one of the most personalized courses I've taken at Princeton. From being able to choose the piece that you want to work on, to working closely with the coach there is ample opportunity to have discussion and productively work on a piece in a group-specific way. It's a great way to continue chamber music into college and there are so many talented musicians on Princeton's campus!
Revamps your approach to music, playing with others, and rehearsing.
Take it - the instructors will probably be amazing, but just make sure you have a good group.
Take it with a good mixed group.
Take this course!
The best course you can take at princeton as a musician.

This is an amazing class and a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. You will grow so much as a musician if you take this. Serena Canin was a brilliant coach with great ideas and pretty high expectations, which really helped my group come together by the end. The week leading up to the performance was stressful, but I can't express enough how rewarding it felt - at a certain point near the end, I just felt that my group clicked, and our piece started to make sense and come together.
take itttt
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition. Auditions will be held on Thursday, November 15, 2012, 6:00 - 9:00 p.m. in Room 102, Woolworth Center. Only complete groups may audition. No exceptions will be made for students abroad or absent for any other reason. Students will be allowed to receive credit for the course twice and to audit the course only once. (Signup sheet is on the Bulletin Board near Room 101 Woolworth.) Contact Gregory D. Smith (609) 258-6078 or gsmith@princeton.edu for further details..
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Methods and Concepts in Electronic Structure Theory
prereqs: Introductory courses in quantum mechanics, linear algebra, ordinary and simple partial differential equations, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course derives how and why chemical bonds between atoms form, leading to the creation of molecules and condensed matter. State-of-the-art electronic structure theory methods are discussed and compared in terms of strengths, weaknesses, and numerical implementations. Students will learn how to predict molecular structure, qualitative character of the electron distribution (hybridization), and relative chemical bond strengths directly from a simple multi-electron wavefunction. Condensed matter electronic structure will be introduced via band theory, followed by an analysis of the pros and cons of modern density functional theory methods.

title: Born in the U.S.A.: Culture and Reproduction in Modern America
reviews: Definitely take if you get the chance. It can blow your mind. Needs more boys for the male perspective!

Definitely take this class, whether or not you think you're interested in issues about reproduction. It's more than worth it, and getting to know Professor Armstrong is a gift in and of itself, besides that you get to learn about fascinating academic material.

Definitely take this course with Professor Armstrong. I learned so much about reproduction and would take it again if I was not graduating!!! The assignments are fun, the readings are fascinating, and the discussions are really illuminating. Reproduction is a huge part of human lives that we do not talk about-- this course sheds light on amazing aspects of human culture, science, and medicine. It has also influenced the way I think about my own experiences and pre-conceptions relating to reproduction.
One of the top three classes I've taken at Princeton.  Take it!
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!! IT'LL BE YOUR BEST DECISION EVER
Take it FOR SURE, even if birth and pregnancy gross you out, because it's about much more than that.

Take this class! Regardless of your background or academic interest, everyone has something to gain from this class. It seems like a lot of work, but the papers are very short and Professor Armstrong is very flexible with due dates (haha). My favorite class at Princeton, by far! I cannot recommend it highly enough.

Take this course!!! It will make you reconsider how you feel about reproduction. Though it usually is very heavy on female students, male students should take as well. This topic is important for everyone and Prof. Armstrong will take you on a journey that will enlighten and make you think critically about your expectations of norms and values.
descrip: Reproduction is a basic biological process, as well as a fundamental one for all societies. While the biology of human reproduction is universal across time and place, cultural norms and social institutions powerfully inflect and shape the experience of pregnancy and childbirth in every society. This course investigates the history and sociology of reproduction, focusing on the contemporary United States, but with an eye toward other societies for comparison. How, why, and for whom does birth matter? How do reproductive practices reflect gender, race, and class? The course examines the culture, politics, and economics of reproduction.

title: Topics in International Relations - International Strategy
descrip: Analyzes and compares national security strategies, military doctrine, alliance policies, and foreign economic policy. Examines how international structure, domestic politics, leadership psychology, etc. contribute to policy outcomes. Studies how strategies act as stabilizing or destabilizing influences in the international system. Topics include great power strategies before the two World Wars, American Cold War containment strategy, China's Cold War strategies, and factors for stability and instability since the end of the Cold War.

title: The World of Late Antiquity
reviews: Awesome class, Professor Tannous is the man, wish he was teaching another class next semester
Awesome class. You should definitely take it, even if you are marginally interested in history.
Consider taking this course even if you're not interested in history. Professor Tannous makes the material interesting and accessible.
Do it!
Do the readings and study for the midterm and final.  Go to the professor's office hour to ask help for a possible paper topic.  Drop in for fun also.  He's a really nice person who would help,
Go to all lectures.  Good notetaking is the key to doing well on exams, which are straightforward.  Background readings are not necessary.
Great class, great professor. Take it.
I would 100% take this, no matter what major you are. It is an awesome course!

I would highly recommend this course if you've ever been interested in history, and especially if you'd like to learn about the factors that shaped a lot of the Western World, along with the Near East.
I would recommend this course to any students interested in the Roman/Byzantine Empire or/and Islam. It is a great class and I would definitely recommend it.

If you have the time to take a class with Jack Tannous, you should do it! He is one of the most caring professors here. He wants to make sure that everyone in the class does well and understands what is going on. He's extremely approachable and full of information. Of course, this course is going to be good to you if you put in the time, but it really is not strenuous. You won't regret it!
If you take this class (and you should!), try to get Jack as your preceptor. It would make a world of difference.
Just take it and do the readings it is an interesting time period.
Professor Tannous is such a sweet, kind, and brilliant man. I am so happy I took this course.

Tannous is absolutely amazing. Hands down best History class taken at Princeton.

Tannous is the bomb.  The class is fun, interesting, and easy.  Great HA, great way for history majors to fulfill their premodern requirement.  Go talk to Tannous-- he will literally talk your ear off about anything and everything and is actually a fucking genius.  He speaks a billion languages.  Can't say enough good stuff about him.

The workload is great for people who need to get an HA out of the way, but I really think everyone would enjoy this class.  I'm a History major so maybe I'm biased, but I think it's such an interesting period of history and it's presented so well that everyone would have a good time without getting swamped with work.
Unreal.  Wish Jack Tannous was teaching a class in the fall that I could take.
Yes
take it!
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course will focus on the history of the later Roman Empire, a period which historians often refer to as "Late Antiquity." We will begin our class in pagan Rome at the start of the third century and end it in Baghdad in the ninth century: in between these two points, the Mediterranean world experienced a series of cultural and political revolutions whose reverberations can still be felt today. We will witness civil wars, barbarian invasions, the triumph of Christianity over paganism, the fall of the Western Empire, the rise of Islam, the Greco-Arabic translation movement and much more.

title: Portuguese Language and Culture through Cinema
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will examine a number of recurring cultural topics in Portuguese-language cinema from Africa, Brazil and Europe, such as personal transformations of characters against the backdrop of political turmoil, unusual representations of urban spaces and movement between centers and peripheries. We will situate works within their socio-historical context, explore linguistic regionalisms and registers and analyze cinematography and the process of literary adaptation. Discussions, readings, vocabulary exercises and papers will further increase students' fluency in written and spoken Portuguese.

title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture
reviews: As long as you're willing to invest time, you'll get a lot out of it.
Nicola is great! The workload is a bit much if you try and do everything, but it is worth it if you're trying to get better at Portuguese.
Take this course if you are interested in improving your writing abilities.
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: Europe in the World: Monarchies, Nations, and Empires from 1776 to the Present Day
reviews: .A decent HA but if something else seems interesting go with it instead.
A good P/D/F option, I would just recommend attending the lectures to keep up.
A great HA if you're looking for one. A great course in general though I'm not sure how well it will measure up to other HIS classes.

A solid HA --  Cannadine's lectures are great but readings are pretty boring. In the end you'll probably forget the details and be sick of themes like "the persistence of the old regime" and "the invention of tradition," but overall it was a decent course.
Amazing course to fulfill an HA requirement.
As long as you do the readings, especially for precepts, this is a great course.
Awesome history course if you need to fulfill a requirement or are a history major.  Great global history that everyone should know.

Cannadine's lectures are amazing. Good course for non-history majors especially if you're looking to fulfill a distribution requirement. For history majors who want more depth (this class was VERY broad), this will give you a good sampling of monarchies all over the globe (which is interesting) but doesn't go deep enough to really debate historical issues thoroughly.

DO NOT TAKE if you're a history major. there is no independent thought required, cannadine has a very antiquated perspective on colonialism, and if you are at all interested in issues of race or decolonization this class will just be a giant exercise in frustration
Definitely take it - not too much work (although a lot of readings) and gives you a good foundation in a lot of work history.
Definitely take this class, it is interesting and Professor Cannadine is amazing.  Do the readings, you'll fall behind if you don't and it will get you in trouble for the final.
Don't obsess about detail when taking this course. The most important things to remember for the final are the general themes, with some points of detailed evidence to back it up.
Fascinating course, Cannadine is an amazing lecturer.
Focus on lecture material and pay close attention to readings.
Focus on themes, and having a background in European history is useful.
GREAT COURSE-Preceptors are amazing!
Go to lecture, listen in precept, and pick a few of the readings to do (thoroughly) before each exam. This isn't a hard class to get a B in if you're looking for a distribution requirement.
Go to lecture. Very good lecturer
I would definitely recommend taking this course. Try to get in Professor Cannadine's precept if you are truly interested in the subject matter.
I would highly recommend this class, just make sure you discern what your preceptor wants so you don't get embarrassed in class.
I would recommend reading the precept readings and summing up the arguments for yourself, and making sure you attend all lectures or at least get notes for all of them, and get Alden as a preceptor!
I would recommend taking this class.
I would recommend taking this course if you are interested in the subject matter.

It's a pretty standard intro level course. It's nice if you're looking to avoid having to write papers, because there's only a midterm and a final.

Take the course!
Take this course! Work load is minimal and the topic is interesting.

prereqs: P/D/F option not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course offers a global history from an unusual perspective: that of the nations and empires ruled by monarchs and emperors (and sometimes empresses) across the years since the American and French revolutions, which are often seen as the events which ushered in the modern world of republicanism and democracy. To be sure, many thrones have crashed and crowns have passed away since then; but monarchies are still with us today, from Japan to Britain, Swaziland to Sweden. This course will explore both the anti-monarchical trends that have thrived since 1776 and 1789, but also the surprising extent of royal resilience.

title: Economics of Development
reviews: A very easy econ course that is pretty interesting too. I just did other school work during the lectures
Certainly not the most exciting course, but there is some interesting material and the class is pretty laidback.
Easy course!
