prereqs: Students should satisfy all of the three requisites below: ECO 101, ECO 300 (or 310), ECO 302 (or 312). Students that do not satisfy the criteria may take the course only with permission from the instructor..
descrip: This course is divided in two parts. The first examines why some countries are so much richer than others, and critically evaluate different explanations for this phenomenon on theoretical and empirical grounds. The second part deals with selected microeconomic issues related to life in the developing world, examining theories and data on education, health, credit and other topics.

title: German Intellectual History - Compassion, Pity, Empathy
reviews: A good place to practice German and not too much work. Some readings are more difficult than others, and they take some time. The topic is interesting though and it's a nice small class.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: The discovery of the mirror neurons (that are regarded as neuronal resonance mechanism to engender embodied simulations within the relation to the other) has initiated an epoch of empathy in various sciences (brain research, psychology, sociology). Since the term empathy stems from a translation of the German word Einfuhlung (in aesthetic theory around 1900), the seminar will examine the recent idea of empathy (1) in front of the horizon of its prehistory in the humanities and (2) in comparison with related ideas like pity and compassion.

title: Principles of Quantum Mechanics
reviews: A great class. Sondhi is one of the best lecturers you'll ever have. But be prepared to put in 10-15 hours of work into each problem set.

A. Only take this course if you are willing to devote the entire semester to Quantum Mechanics. The problem sets take about 25 hours each and you will need a team to solve them. Professor Sondhi is available to help you but he moves extremely quickly and it is easy to fall behind. This course is all math- the entire idea is to learn to do quantum mechanics before studying what it is. A course in differential equations would be helpful but it isn't necessary. Learn how to use Mathematica to solve very complex integrals.
Anyone interested in physics beyond the minimal level and willing to put some time into it should take this class

Because this course is a departmental, you most likely have no choice, but you learn a lot of very useful but challenging quantum mechanics concepts throughout the course, such as QM formalism applied to a free particle, harmonic oscillator, finite/infinite square wells, etc.. Be ready to use Schrodinger equation in various situations. Please stay on top of it throughout the course!
Dedicate enough time to this class and it will become easy.
Definitely take it if you've enjoyed other physics courses in the past. Particularly, if you're coming from 205, the workload of this class should seem easier in comparison.

Definitely worth taking, but it's not for the fainthearted. It's not an easy course, but it's worth it if you put in the time. I've definitely heard that the quality varies vastly with professor, so make sure to check on that as well.
Do lots of problems.

Great course! If you're a physics major, you are required to take this, so enjoy it! Professor Sondhi gives nice lectures, but goes quite quickly. He covers all but about three chapters of Griffiths in one semester. If you are not a physics major, but are just interested in quantum mechanics, then by all means take this class, but be aware of who you'll be taking it with and what you want to get out of it.

If you're a physics major, you have to take it. If you're an engineer, and you want to learn the basics of QM, this is a good course to take. Sometimes you can get a little bogged down with some very silly algebra, but it gives you a good foundation.
If you're considering taking this course, you're probably a physics/astro major and therefore have to take it.  But don't dread it!  Quantum is awesome and Prof. Sondhi is an amazing professor!

It is crucial to prepare for lectures in advance. I might recommend getting/renting another textbook to supplement Griffiths. This is also a very competitive course, with some of the university's brightest students.
It's a fair bit of work, but it's definitely worth it.
It's tough, but very rewarding.  Sondhi's a great teacher, and the textbook is good enough that if you read carefully you can work out how to do most the problems yourself.
Make sure it's Sondhi
Set aside a lot of time and do the readings (although not necessary to do so before the relevant lecture).

Sondhi is a great lecturer, very on top of the material, very good at answering questions, and funny. The problem sets are usually interesting, but sometimes a bit frustratingly computational. Overall great course though.
Super interesting. For most, it's the first exposure to quantum, which is a fascinating subject. And Sondhi is great. Though be comfortable with working through frequent nasty algebra/integrals.

prereqs: MAT 204 or MAT 217 and PHY 205 or PHY 207. If PHY 104, PHY 106, or ISC 234 have not been completed, one of them must be taken concurrently..
descrip: This is the Physics Department's introductory quantum mechanics course. Its intent is to present the subject in a fashion that will allow both mastery of its conceptual basis and techniques and appreciation of the excitement inherent in looking at the world in a profoundly new way. Topics to be covered include: state functions and the probability interpretation, the Schroedinger equation, uncertainty principle, the eigenvalue problem, angular momentum, perturbation theory, and the hydrogen atom.

However, if one knows that one is a non-technical major, this is a rigorous and very interesting course to take.
If you are not good with sciences and really need a lab take it, but be prepared for a disproportionate amount of work to the grade you will receive. There are other labs that you can PDF.

On the other hand, the material is highly relevant to just about everything and can often be interesting.
It's not a blowoff course
Learn a lot on own

Take it for your ST.

This is a pretty good STL for non-technical majors, but your engagement with the information will always dictate how you feel. The labs aren't too bad, the lectures by Wang are interesting, and its not overly demanding.

descrip: This lecture and laboratory course will acquaint non-science majors with classical and modern neuroscience. Lectures will give an overview at levels ranging from molecular signaling to cognitive science with a focus on the neuroscience of everyday life, from the general (love, memory, and personality) to the particular (jet lag, autism, and weight loss). The laboratory will offer hands-on experience in recording signals from single neurons, examining neural structures, and analysis of whole-brain functional brain imaging data.

title: Introduction to Statistics for Biology
prereqs: MAT 101 and 102, or MAT 103, or MAT 104.
descrip: An introduction to statistical models, methods, and concepts with a particular focus on applications in biology. Real data sets will be analyzed using a statistical software package in order to gain an understanding of how statistics is used in practice. Topics to be covered include probability, experimental design, point estimation, hypothesis testing, Bayesian statistics, and the application of these topics to modern biological studies.

title: The Environment: Science and Policy
reviews: An informative survey course. I'd recommend it if you're interested in the material.

DO NOT TAKE IT. IT IS TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE. There is NO policy involved. And they do not advertise how much work this will actually be. It's also so poorly taught. It's disorganized. First time course was offered. Disorganized at some points.

The preceptors were great though.
I would hesitate to take this class if it's taught in the same way next year.
I would not take the course.

It's a pretty easy departmental for Woody Woo and not too much work. Definitely worth your time.
Light workload. Take it for the WWS core course requirement.
Not too much work, and covers many interesting topics in environmental policy. Take it!

Take it, only if Mauzerall isn't teaching it. Honestly SUCH AN IMPORTANT TOPIC. EVERYONE NEEDS TO KNOW THIS STUFF. Wilcove is the best lector at Princeton.
Take it.

Take this class for Wilcove's half, and then seriously consider dropping for Mauzerall's half. Wilcove is one of, if not the, best professors at Princeton. He's funny, he's engaging, and (most importantly) he's very nuanced. He understands that not everyone is an idealist like him, that there are pragmatic policy barriers to the ideal environmental policy solutions, and is willing to work within those boundaries to create optimal policy. He's also very open to listening to the other side -- as a conservative, I felt that anything I said would be taken under consideration fairly, although perhaps not agreed with. Mauzerall has the opposite problem. She's a very nice lady who genuinely cares for her students. But she's extremely idealistic and ignores how policy actually gets made -- her version of policy is "businesses should self-regulate themselves and be altruistic," which is nice, but not very plausible. As a conservative, I felt that anything I said would be almost attacked, so I didn't talk very much. It would have been nice to see the other perspective on climate change/ozone layer, even if she tore down the science behind the deniers -- but not even knowing what the deniers are arguing makes everyone less equipped to go into the world with a grasp of the science behind the policy. Lectures were also hard to follow at times, particularly the science. Wilcove's section was perfect. Mauzerall needs to encourage more arguments from the other side -- even if she wants to bring them up for the sake of destroying them, that would be preferable.

Talk to Mauzerall or Wilcove before taking the class, and if they seem like they have a clear direction for the course, then you should be in for an enjoyable semester. Otherwise, it might be best to avoid this class.
They need to fix the exams, problem sets, and organization. Wilcove is great though.

This course is largely a survey course in environmental issues, for students who seek a broad but not deep education. If you are looking to dive more in-depth into particular issues of, for instance, climate change, you should seek a smaller seminar course. However, the course is informative in opening your eyes to the wide breadth of issues that environmental policymakers must consider.
This course is not very engaging and does not relate science to humanities students very well.
This course needs work.

This was the first time they taught it and it was still really good, and given how good both professors were in precept I'd be shocked if they don't fix the problems that there were by the time they teach it again.
Unless they do some serious revamping of the course and give it much more structure next year, do not take it.

Unless this course is structured very differently, or Wilcove takes over the entire course, don't take this course. The first half (taught by Wilcove) was fantastic. But the second half was a mess. The scientific explanations were terrible or absent and few example problems were provided. It was so starkly different in quality from the first half that it completely ruined the course.

Unless you are taking this course for a distribution requirement, it might make sense to PDF it.  The disorder of the instructional approach, and the tediousness of the "homework assignments," made it very frustrating for someone who had just taken it to learn about issues of environmental policy.
Wouldn't recommend this course unless you need it for a requirement.
You should take it! A reasonable amount of work but all interesting and not repetitive.
brace yourself for the second half of the semester
dont take it

i would recommend waiting a few years until the professors figure out which way is up. 
take a different class if you are trying to do the ENV certificate
there are probably better ways to fulfill the requirement but i would take it again
this is an interesting course and i bet it will get better as the professors figure out what they want the students to take away from it.
descrip: This course examines environmental policy and its relationship to a set of critical environmental issues including: management of natural resources (eg. fisheries and wildlife), control of transboundary pollution (eg. air pollution), management of the global commons (eg. stratospheric ozone depletion and climate change) and sustainable development. Students will explore the science underlying these issues as well as current policies and the range of future policy responses.

title: Economic Experience in Cultural Context
reviews: A fun mixture of anthro, econ, philosophy, and writing that while not serious or extremely legitimate, definitely valuable.

A very interesting topic and a very nice, engaging professor. However, the amount of readings can vary wildly between weeks, and the journals should be viewed as coherent mini-essays rather than any journal you would actually write.
Be sure to do the reading and try to make connections across readings from different weeks.

I would say its a very interesting, philosophical class with a light work load and pretty relevant / intriguing material. I would recommend someone going in with basic economics and anthropology, because having neither of those I was lost a little bit in the lingo and basics of the course. It would be an interesting course to audit!
Take this course!! I think someone from any major will really benefit from having this class!
This is a great, fun, interesting course.  That Professor Lederman has such an interesting research background is an extra plus (the fun stories!)
great!
take it!!!
prereqs: No specific prerequisites but a previous course in anthropology would be helpful..
descrip: This course explores the social and cultural contexts of economic experience in the US and around the world. It considers how the consumption, production, and circulation of goods--today and in times past--become invested with personal and collective meanings. It pays special attention to symbolic and political dimensions of work, property (material, intellectual, and cultural), wealth, and "taste" (i.e., needs and wants). Additionally, course participants do a bit of anthropological fieldwork by learning to draw everyday experiences systematically into conversation with more familiar academic sources.

title: Chaucer
reviews: I would strongly recommend this course to other students, probably mostly English concentrators as the material is somewhat dense at times. The size of the seminar really allowed us to learn as much as possible over the semester and ask questions when we were curious about specific matters.
Professor Cole is the best professor I've ever had, you will not regret taking this course.
take it
descrip: Look up Geoffrey Chaucer in the Urban Dictionary, and you will find an entry describing him as the original urban dictionary, a "medieval poet" whose Canterbury Tales "is a collection of stories filled with plenty of swearing, slang, and fart jokes." In this course we will read and discuss that Chaucer--the brilliant, hilarious, dirty poet of the Canterbury Tales. We will enjoy this fun, often moving text while learning about the poet's artistry, both the literary traditions he so deftly works over, and the sexual, political, and religious issues he so astutely figures and, as is so often the case, perverts.

title: European Politics and Society in the 20th Century
reviews: Do all the readings. The lectures are not enough on their own. Take good notes, which can be hard sometimes, but try, because a lot of important stuff gets said in between people voicing their opinions.
Do the readings.  They are excellent.
Good survey of 20th Century European political history
I highly recommend this course. Both professors were great and the readings were interesting. The readings are manageable and the exams were fair.
I would say take it if you need to and it is definitely interesting, however, this course tackles broad ideologies rather than specific, concrete historical information.
It's okay.
Just do your work because this class has a lot to offer.
Take it if the material interests you and you know how to read smart.
This course has a lot of reading - form a study group for the midterm and final or else you'll be lost! Also, prepare to understand abstract terms like "national character" and "political culture."

This is a seminal class if you are interested in politics and Europe. I would highly recommend this course as Professor Suleiman is an absolute expert in his field and did a wonderful job of choosing Professor Mehnert, an expert historian, to balance his narrative.
Try to find a different historically oriented social analysis course, if that is what you are looking for.
Try to stay consistent or split up readings; they definitely do add up if you don't stay on top of it.
descrip: The course aims to cover the critical developments of twentieth-century Europe and the consolidation of democracy in European countries. It will deal with the legacy of the two world wars, Nazism, Stalinism, the Cold War, the legacy of colonialism and decolonization, the birth and development of the European Community, the development of the welfare state, the problems confronting the European Union (immigration, enlargement, political institutions, military role, and the single currency), and the varieties of democratic institutions in Europe.

title: Optimal Control and Estimation
descrip: An introduction to stochastic optimal control theory and application. It reviews mathematical foundations and explores parametric optimization, conditions for optimality, constraints and singular control, numerical optimization, and neighboring-optimal solutions. Least-squares estimates, propagation of state estimates and uncertainty, and optimal filters and predictors; optimal control in the presence of uncertainty; certainty equivalence and the linear-quadratic-Gaussian regulator problem; frequency-domain solutions for linear multivariable systems; and robustness of closed-loop control are all studied.

title: Language and Culture
reviews: A good SA for linguistics or anthro students; interesting and not something that Princeton offers often.  Prof. Mertz is very knowledgeable and helpful!

Although I don't expect this course to be offered with any degree of regularity, Mertz is fantastic, the class is a very manageable time commitment, and you learn a lot about how to think like an anthropologist.  Highly, highly recommended.
As long as you like the concept of destabilizing the obvious and looking critically into the micro level, take it!
Don't be discouraged if you don't understand everything at the beginning.  The material takes a little while to sink in.  Definitely stick with it!  It's totally worth it.

Don't be scared by the denser readings - they will get explained, and often the thing the author is trying to say isn't actually so difficult to grasp. Think of how language works in your personal life and connect it to the readings - it really helps to understand them! And do take the opportunity to talk to Professor Mertz - she is incredibly kind and understanding, not to mention an expert in this field!
Easy course, interesting material, and it's up to you how far into the readings you want to push yourself.
Hopefully Professor Mertz comes back as a visiting professor soon and teaches this course again!
If ever you see that Professor Mertz is teaching another class at Princeton, take it! You are in for a real intellectual treat.
It's very much dependent on how much you put into it/choose to get out of it
Professor Mertz was a visiting professor, but if you ever get to take a course on linguistic anthropology, DO IT. The subject is incredibly interesting.
Take it if you're interested in anthropology or need the requirements.  The linguistic components aren't huge, but it's an interesting overview of linguistic anthropology.
Take the course if you are interested in the subject.
descrip: Language plays a crucial role in our lives, providing the thread that connects us with others, conveys meaning, encodes power relations within societies, and much more. Through and within language, poets speak, governments rule, and we conduct much of our everyday lives. Today's linguistic anthropologists have built a synthesis of approaches that draws on many disciplines. This class examines the main strands of that synthesis, learning how to bring together the analysis of micro-level linguistic patterns and the study of language in broader sociocultural contexts.

title: Advanced Programming Techniques
reviews: A great course. Take it with Kernighan. He's an amazing teacher and is an extremely nice, down-to-earth guy. The project is what you make of it. Put in a lot of hard work, and you will be pleased with the results.
A must-have for CS.

As a COS major, this class should be a strong consideration. Kernighan always has interesting stories, and the project will teach you a lot and give you a sense of what group projects can be like in the real world.
As long as Kernighan is still teaching this class, definitely take it. He's an amazing professor. Get started early on your project! It's tons of work but very rewarding.
BEST. COURSE. EVAH. The project makes up for the mildly boring lectures and the difficult early projects. Do it, do it NAUWGH.
Be careful
Best course at Princeton
Building the project is a great experience.

Completing a large programming project will be a cool experience.  Find a project you like and a team you can work with, and start your work early.  If you do, then you shouldn't be rushed at the end.
Definitely take it because Prof. Kernighan is professor you should try to have if possible.

Definitely take this class. Kernighan is pretty amazing. He often tells interesting anecdotes in lecture.  Make sure you start on the project early. You will learn so much if you don't leave everything to the last moment!.

Definitely take this course, but make sure you either have other friends taking it or are willing to make friends since you'll need a solid group for working on your projects with.  The workload is totally doable and its one of the most enjoyable and rewarding classes I've taken thus far.
Don't let yourself get behind.  It'll burn you.
Final project is pretty cool. Lectures might not be the best (people either love them or hate them), but you'll learn through the assignments and projects! Kernighan's a pretty cool guy too!
Find a group of friends and take this class!! One of the best classes at Princeton, and Prof. Kernighan is a very entertaining lecturer.
Find a group that you work well with and have fun!
Get a good group together early on

Great class with the great Professor Kernighan. Didn't learn all that much from lecture but they were generally interesting for other reasons (war stories from Kernighan). The final project was useful and pretty cool.
Great!

I strongly recommend that CS majors take this course. Even those who are interested in coding/have CS friends who you want to work with. It provides great exposure to real-world programming and the environment in the software development industry.
I think most would agree this is a class every cos major should take before graduating.
If you are a COS major, it's a must-take. It really teaches you to learn how to make something from scratch. Such an invaluable skill.

If you have no other commitments during the semester and have ample time to lounge around, this is a stimulating, practical course you must take. If you have other important commitments (eg: a senior thesis to complete), COS333 is out of the question -- drop it immediately.
If you haven't really programmed outside of structured assignments, take this course. If you've done a lot of programming projects on your own already, this course isn't very necessary.
If you like writing code, or want to get better at writing code, take the course.

If you're looking for a whirlwind tour of a dozen different programming languages, web frameworks, paradigms, and the like, take it!  I think of this course as a high-level "introduction to computer science", and I personally liked it.  If you're looking for depth, this course is probably not for you.

If you're taking this course, it's probably either for the project or for Kernighan. However, it was my least favorite departmental this semester, and I felt that I didn't gain that much from the actual class--more from the deadlines it imposed.
It's a solid systems course, you get exposed to a ton of different aspects of computer science in the lectures, and the project is a good learning experience.
It's worth taking - just make sure all of your group members contribute somewhat equally to your project.
Must take: amazing professor and worthwhile final project.
Start everything early.
Take it for kernighan, get a good group
Take it! You'll learn a lot about web programming.
Take it, overall it isn't too much work, you learn alot doing the project, and Kernighan is a good professor.
Take it. Good way to fulfill one of the CS systems requirements.
Take the course. It's awesome. You won't regret it.
Take this class if you're wondering how to make some sort of application. Very very good course.
Take this class, it's the best and Kernighan is the man. Just make sure you have a good group for the project.
Take this course if you want to break out of the mold and be creative with programming.
The final project is an amazing experience. Take this class.

This class is a fun way to fulfill a systems requirement (if a COS major).  If you work on the final project with friends and start early, it should be really interesting and rewarding!  Professor Kernighan is great and really cares about his students!
This class is awesome, make sure you keep track of the frameworks he suggests checking out.
This class was really fun. Make sure you have a good group willing to put time into the final project and not someone flaky who is busy all the time.
This course is the closest you can get to real programming work experience and is definitely worth taking.

This course is worth taking for the final project alone. It's an amazing experience. That said, be warned that you will need to take the first half of the course seriously, since the grading of the assignments is rather harsh. Also, the more friends you take the course with, the better. With these qualifications, this is definitely a class that every COS major (and any non-majors who have the prereqs) should take before graduating.

This course runs at 2 paces.  The first half of the semester is extremely fast paced, with 4 to 5 assignments all due within a week of each other and information about each assignment overlapping in lectures.  Then, during the 2nd half, it runs extremely slowly because you have just one big project to work on.  You learn Python in the first half, which is extremely useful and it is annoying no other class uses it (it's really easy too).  The big project is invaluable experience working in a team, with languages you never heard of before, connecting backend and frontend work, github, waiting on others, organization, you name it.  Out of anything you do in Princeton, this will feel the most "real world"ish.  I personally did the course just to work on a final project.  That said, your idea either makes or breaks you.  My group flushed out our idea very well, but because it wasn't as "useful" as other ideas, we got penalized for it.  Still, it was awesome and I learned a lot.  Lectures in the 2nd half were uninspiring though.  VERDICT:  Take this course for the final project, expect a lot of work in the beginning of the semester, come up with an idea NOW.

This has been one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Great if you want some actual experience working on a somewhat-real software engineering project. I personally think it's worth it just to hear Kernighan talk about his own experiences, as he is such a brilliant and humble person. But definitely be ready to put a lot of time in on the project during the second half of the course.
This is a really great course, but get a good group and make sure everyone works consistently on the project.

This is a true must-take for COS majors/concentrators. The ~six week project is the best part of the course, and the more you put into it the more you get out. Prof. Kernighan is also a great professor, and someone you can actually talk to and get to you. He makes a point of taking everyone's picture during lecture and learning everyone's name. Not bad for a lecture with over fifty people.

This is one of the classes that you must take while you're at Princeton.  Take it with Kernighan because he is a genius and super nice and he will learn you're name and say hi to you when he sees you on campus.  The programming assignments during the first half of the semester were actually somewhat challenging, so make sure you give yourself enough time.  The project was a great experience, especially if you've never done any software dev before.  Make sure you find a good group because you'll have to spend a lot of time working with them and rely on them for your project's success.

This is pretty much the one COS class here that introduces you to coding in the "real world," and is worth it just for the project. It helps to have a few friends in the class that you can work well with for 6 weeks without hating each other.

Unless you already have a lot of experience building real world applications (specifically websites or apps), I would say definitely take this course. Lectures and initial assignments are somewhat useless (although Kernighan is awesome), but the project makes the course worthwhile. I learned so much about web development and gained so much practical experience in the process that I have never had the time to get on my own.
Very good class. I would recommend it to anyone interested in computer science or with an entrepreneurial spirit.
You HAVE to take this course if you want to work as a software engineer. The breadth and depth of the material covered is amazing, and the final project is a really fun chance to be creative.
You owe it to yourself to take it just so that you learn the basic process of building a real product. But the lectures themselves won't do much for you.

You should definitely take this course.  Professor Kernighan is amazing. The group project will cause you to learn about "real world" programming and software engineering in ways not taught in other COS courses.
step 1) take 333,step 2) make an awesome project,step 3) ???, step 4) PROFIT!
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: This is a course about the practice of programming. Programming is more than just writing code. Programmers must also assess tradeoffs, choose among design alternatives, debug and test, improve performance, and maintain software written by themselves & others. At the same time, they must be concerned with compatibility, robustness, and reliability, while meeting specifications. Students will have the opportunity to develop these skills by working on their own code and in group projects.

title: Gender and Development in the Americas
descrip: This course examines gender as an integral component of socio-economic development in the United States and areas of Latin America. We give attention to processes of industrial restructuring on a global scale that have increased the participation of women in the labor force and transformed men's employment alternatives. The relationship between gender inequality and social order is a central focus. We give special attention to liberal and Marxian approaches in economics.

title: Economics of Crime and Crime Control
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310, and MAT 102 or MAT 103.
descrip: Covers the economic analysis of crime and the criminal justice system, including criminal behavior, law enforcement, crime prevention, sentencing, capital punishment, organized crime, and the war on drugs. The primary goal of the course is to develop economic thinking to gain insight into the behavior of the key actors (potential offenders, potential victims, and the many parts of the enforcement system) that determine crime outcomes. The last third of the course analyzes and evaluates policies to prevent or reduce crime.

title: Vergil - Eclogues
descrip: After an introductory session on the pastoral, we will read the entire collection, reading each poem closely with attention to its relation to both earlier and later pastoral tradition. We will also explore issues of arrangement within the collection.

title: Environmental Law and Moot Court
reviews: Be prepared to make time for the work - you get much more out of this class if you come prepared.
Good. Take it only if you want to know about law, or need it for env certif. I took it as an extra course and didn't love it but now I know I don't want to go to law school, which is invaluable.
Great it you want to do law! Also very good for the legal side of environmental regulations.
Take if you want.
This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton - definitely take it!
descrip: Examining the relationship between law and environmental policy, this course focuses on cases that have established policy principles. The first half of the seminar will be conducted using the Socratic method. The second half will allow students to reargue either the plaintiff or defendant position in a key case, which will be decided by the classroom jury.

title: Cyber Security
reviews: Do NOT take this class
Don't take unless you have to. Professor is boring and unclear, is easily confused by simple questions.

I don't know about COS and ELE majors, but I found this course very frustrating for a distribution requirement. Terms were ill-defined and never really clarified, and most of the material was uninteresting to boot.
I would not recommend this course.  It was interesting but not taught very well.
If you are interested in the subject, maybe give it a try.
If you take the course, choose a project wisely (one that is less technical). It is less work and you might end up with a better quality report.

It dose not take a lot of time, and you do learn some interesting things about cybersecurity but the lectures are a bit boring though Professor Lee cares, it is still hard to focus on the material for the whole lecture because it does get repetitive. you mostly learn from reading her notes while doing problemsets.
Take COS 432 / Information Security instead. Read Security Engineering and you'll know what the course has to offer.

This course teaches you some very good basics about networks and security without reaching too much  depth. It's hard to gauge how you're doing in this course, and be aware that the final project can take a lot of time. Make sure to ask questions in this course and don't be shy to speak with Ruby  - she is extremely nice and loves to connect with students. You just need to make the first step.
Video tape lectures.
prereqs: No prior security knowledge required. COS109/EGR109 or equivalent..
descrip: This course surveys the technology underlying secure transactions and safe interactions in cyberspace. Topics include cyber security needs such as confidentiality, integrity, availability, access control, authorization, authentication, non-repudiation, trust, privacy and anonymity. Case studies include smartphone and Cloud Computing security, denial of service attacks, viruses and worms, social networks and cyber-terrorism. Related policy, social and economic issues are also discussed.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: This seminar is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course will be 25% oral presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: 20th-Century French Poetry or Theater - French Modernist Poetry
descrip: This course investigates Modernist poetics in France from mid-19th to mid-20th c. and seeks to re-evaluate Modernism in French literary history. Course will treat the topic at a variety of interrelated levels by exploring French poetry as part of the broad historical phenomenon of Modernism, while examining the specific ways it materialized in France as formal innovation and as response to modernity. Seminal poets such as Baudelaire, Mallarme, Apollinaire, and Cendrars, will be discussed as well as specific movements. Readings and theoretical questions will also address the complex relationship between avant-garde and Modernism. (In English)

title: Econometric Applications
reviews: A lot of hard work but very rewarding

Absolutely take this course! It is a truly excellent class, the most useful course I've taken at Princeton, and one of my favorite (if not my overall favorite) classes I've taken. The material will be invaluable to you on your JP/thesis, but it is useful far beyond that. The Professor is great, the problem sets are enlightening and are reasonable in terms of length, and you'll come out of it with a much better understanding of how economics empirical work is done.
An excellent course. Be prepared to work hard, but you will get a lot of out it.

Certainly worth taking to learn STATA for independent work. I'd suggest taking as a sophomore if at all possible, since it will make JPs a lot easier and a more useful exercise. Don't be scared off by the reviews saying how much work there is. Yes, there are a lot of long problem sets but you will spend about the same amount of time in total as for other classes since there is no midterm and the final is basically another take-home problem set.

If you're an economics major, you should really take this course! It is so helpful for your JP and senior thesis. After taking this I felt more confident as an econ major. The problem sets can get very long, but go to STATA office hours and work with other students and they won't be too bad. This was probably the best departmental I took, despite the heavy workload (mainly on Sunday nights when problem sets were due Monday). There is no midterm and one five-hour take home final. Farber is really into this course and teaches it very well.

It is a really useful course. It is a LOT of time for the problemsets, but you do learn a lot. just be prepared to give up a large part of your weekend, or stay up every Sunday night. but you learn a LOT and professor Farber is wonderful and excited about the course and really cares for students. Having a good TA matters because the Professor cannot do everything and I hope you have a TA that cares. Course is worth it in general though.

My problem with this course was pessimism; once I made up my mind that I didn't like this course I blinded myself to a lot of its lessons. Try to realize how useful the material is if you feel like quitting, and don't be daunted by grades.
Take it if you liked econometrics and want to learn interesting applications. Helps with junior and senior independent work.

Take it to be able to hear Farber ramble about economics--you learn a lot. Also the class in general teaches you how to look at data. I didn't know how much I improved until I churned out the last few psets and realized how much more confident I was in my avenues of inquiry as compared to the first week when I was paralyzed by simple cross-tab analyses.
Take it!
Take it! :D

Take this course. There is no better way to prepare for writing a JP. Assignments take 6 to 10 hours, so don't start on Sunday night. Take this as a junior so the econometric techniques are fresh in your mind when writing your JP. Also, Farber is a great lecturer and makes the material come to life.
The techniques you learn are very useful!

The weekly problem sets are a big workload but you learn a tremendous amount. Lectures are good (theory on mondays, examples on wednesday) and relevant to problem sets. Undergraduate Advisor office hours are a MUST for the problem sets, particularly in the 2nd half of the class.
This class is one of the best classes you will ever take, as long as you pay attention and try on the problem sets, you will gain a lot from this class.

This is a great course to teach econometric techniques but it's very hard and takes a long time to do the problem sets (4-9 hours for each one). Definitely take it if you're considering doing an econometric thesis.
prereqs: ECO 302 or ECO 312; Calculus. Course not open to freshman..
descrip: This course provides hands-on experience in the art and science of econometric analysis designed to help students to acquire and master the skills necessary to carry out their own empirical research in economics. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable economic models, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. A range of applications will be presented and discussed in class and on problem sets.

title: Integrated Building Systems
reviews: Mid-term assignment was never reviewed as group.  Final assignment should attempt to utilize vast amounts of hands and minds coming together to build 1 construct.
Take it.
recommend, only for the lectures   final assignment
descrip: An introduction to building systems and the methods of construction used to realize design in built form. First half of the course will be an overview of the primary systems, materials and principals used in construction of buildings and the fabrication of elements, through lectures and accompanying lab sessions. The second half will be an explanation of the means by which information is communicated from designers to fabricators, current standards in the practice of architecture, and practice's relation to changes in methods of fabrication and project delivery.

title: Intermediate Urdu II
reviews: If you would like to achieve proficiency in Urdu, this would be a great class to take.
Practice speaking!
Urdu is an important language to learn and Fauzia is great at teaching it!
Work hard for this course and you will get a lot out of it!
prereqs: URD 105 or equivalent proficiency. See instructor..
descrip: This is a continuing proficiency-based course which refines and expands previously acquired linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Focus is on expanding vocabulary, mastering more complex grammatical structures, and acquiring idiomatic expressions. Use of authentic Urdu materials from print and electronic media, literature, and films. Equal emphasis on all skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). Various aspects of the target language culture will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.

title: Contemporary African American Literature and Culture: Identity, Inquiry, and Instability
descrip: This course explores affective, existential, and speculative formations of blackness in the early twenty-first century U.S. Using a wide array of literary and cultural texts produced within the past 7 years--ranging from novels to web series and poetry to the so-called "New R & B" -- we will consider how contemporary artists, writers, and critics both reflect and create spaces of feeling, experience, and knowing through, alongside, and against dominant racial paradigms. Throughout the semester, we will interrogate the very meaning and viability of the phrase "Contemporary African American Literature and Culture."

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Great class if you want to improve your Chinese.
Great course. People always say Chinese is really hard but as long as you're willing to put in a fair amount of time each week for the assignments, it's not bad at all. Highly recommend.
If you really want to learn Chinese, you should take this course.
It is good if you are prepared to work a lot.
It's always easier for people who know more Chinese. Study hard and hope for the best.
Make sure you understand the proper usage of the vocab words in addition to their meanings!
Take it, though know it's quite a time commitment.
Take this class. Getting an A requires some serious effort, and there's classes everyday during reading period, but it's sooo worth it if you want to speak better Chinese.

Take this course if you have time to put into it and are really interested in the subject matter; the professors are great, really friendly and very helpful but it is a lot of work and the friday test is a serious drawback

This class is exactly what it says it is. It can get frustrating at times, and honestly will take up a lot of time out of your semester but it is worth it in that it will really help you improve your Chinese. You get out of it what you put in.
so much work but you're chinese will improve - but because there's so much material, you learn it quickly (cram) but you can also forget everything quickly; you get in what you put in
prereqs: CHI 405 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Continued reading and discussion of scholarly writings on modern Chinese literature. This course also exposes students to the social issues China has faced in recent years, while discussing various aspects of contemporary Chinese society.

title: Magical Realism
descrip: What is magical realism, and why has it come to define a trend in contemporary postcolonial literature? Focusing on the relationship between states and their subjects, this course aims to explore the mysterious process by which nation-states come to represent the people. In modern literature this concern is often explored by postcolonial writers, film-makers, and artists, who turn to magical realism to represent the relation between people and the state. We will assume a global perspective and our texts will be drawn from literature as well as visual culture, literary studies as well as anthropological essays on magic.

title: Oil to Ozone: Chemistry of the Environment
reviews: For sure!  It's mad chill, bro.
It's a great science course. Period.
It's very easy while you're in it, but if you're taking it for a good grade, can't guarantee you'll get it. If you're CBE, might not be a bad idea to take it senior spring.
Keep asking what questions will be on the tests.  This knowledge will greatly help you study.
Make sure you keep up with the readings. Just know the book inside out for the midterm and work diligently on the problem sets because the final is based completely off of them.
Quite a bit of work now. I loved the lectures though. Very fun to come to class. Grading is not very easy though.
Take this if you have to. It's definitely on the easier side of things, but Morel can be painfully vague in terms of grading.
go fast on the exams.
go to all office hours
good class to take, it is definitley chem heavy
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or equivalent. (Consult instructor.).
descrip: The chemical background of environmental issues. Topics include energy and fuels, greenhouse effect, ozone, air pollution, food production, pesticides, metals pollution, carcinogens and anti-oxidants.

title: Science and Global Security: From Nuclear Weapons to Cyberwarfare
reviews: Definitely take this course. You learn so much that is necessary to think about policy toward nuclear weapons, bioterrorism, and cyberwarfare.
I would recommend it.
Take it, it's so interesting and not an enormous amount of work.
Take this course. There were some hiccups in the first year, but it will just get better.
The course was pretty good and likely to improve with time, so if the subject matter interests you, I'd definitely check it out.

The material is fascinating. If you've never taken hard sciences at Princeton before, be prepared to attend all the office hours. I loved it though, and learned so much. One of few classes where I thought my time was worth it.
This course is a must for anyone in science that wants to learn how to apply it in a more broad political context.
take it.
prereqs: No prerequisites; MAT 103 highly recommended.
descrip: This course will provide students with a basic technical understanding of some of the critical technologies that are relevant to national and global security and will equip students with the skills to better assess the challenge of developing effective policies to manage such technologies. Case studies will inter alia include nuclear weapons and their proliferation, nuclear and radiological terrorism, space weapons, biosecurity and cyberware.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. Focus is on the determination of macroeconomic variables - such as output, employment, prices, and the interest rate - in the short, medium, and long run, and addresses a number of policy issues. Discusses several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Introduction to Kanbun
descrip: Introduction to the basics of reading Chinese-style Classical Japanese and its related forms. Texts: Literary and historical texts from both China and Japan.

title: Computational Neuroscience
reviews: A very good course that gives you a great feeling for current research in neuroscience. Professor Brody is a great lecturer. I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in computational science and applied math or quantitative neuroscience.
Go for it, and start eraly on your presentation.
Good PDF class

I found this course interesting but I probably wouldn't take it knowing what I know now. The work load is pretty light if you don't dive deeply into the papers.  I would have enjoyed more computational and less neuroscience.

If you're interested in neuroscience, even if you don't have much (or any) background in it, and you have some coding experience and want to see how it applies to neuro, definitely take the class. Professor Brody does a great job of guiding us through this complicated and diverse field, and the papers he's chosen are very interesting and generally accessible.
It's a cool way to be exposed to a lot of topics in computational neuroscience, and Professor Brody is a fantastic lecturer and cool guy.
Take it. The expectations are very high, especially for the presentations but you're supported all the way through by Professor Brody.
prereqs: MOL 410 or basic linear algebra, probability, ordinary differential equations, and some programming experience, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Introduction to the biophysics of nerve cells and synapses, and the mathematics of neural networks. How can networks of neurons compute? How do we model and analyze data from neuroscientific experiments? Each topic will have a lecture component, a computer laboratory component, and a paper presentation by students component.

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Random Processes
prereqs: MAT 385 (previously MAT 390).
descrip: Wiener measure. Stochastic differential equations. Markov diffusion processes. Linear theory of stationary processes. Ergodicity, mixing, central limit theorem for stationary processes. If time permits, the theory of products of random matrices and PDE with random coefficients will be discussed.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: !!! This class is good and requires similar amounts of work as 258, but the amount of repeated material and lack of conclusive knowledge learned left me a little disappointed.
Definitely attend all lectures and take good notes. The quizzes and exams are based mostly on the content covered in the lectures alone.
Do not take this course with Professor Niv - wait for the year that Professor Botvinick is teaching it.
Don't take it with Professor Niv. The material isn't actually as interesting as you might hope.
Go to lecture! Go to precept!
Go to lecture. Record the lecture and listen to it after so that you aren't confused when you're looking at your slides again
I didn't particularly get much out of lecture.  NEU 258 also dealt with many of same topics.
I found this to be an okay course. I enjoyed 258 much more. Expect to memorize lots of brain areas.
If you aren't doing the certificate, just do 258. The class isn't bad, but it doesn't add much either. It is extremely easy if you just go to lectures.
It is an interesting course, but make sure you take good notes.
It's an interesting class, though I'm not sure I'd take it if you don't have to take it for the certificate - you certainly "feel" like you learn a lot more in 258.
It's easiest if taken after you have a few years in neuroscience.  Take it senior year.
Only take it if you have to as a part of the certificate program or psychology degree or are very interested in the material.
Pay attention to lectures!
Pretty cool material, not a terribly challenging class
Start studying for quizzes early, so you can get your questions asked on Piazza. Get to know Professor Niv, she wants to answer your questions. Try to do the reading for precept early as well.
TAKE GOOD NOTES. You'll need them.
Take it already!
Take it if you have any interest in it at all, but be prepared to memorize a lot of information.
Take it if you're interested in neuro--it's a good overview, and 258 is not necessary beforehand.
Take it if you're interested in neuroscience/cognitive psychology.
Take it with Dr. Botvinik.
Take this class if you have to, but otherwise.... until Niv is replaced (Hopefully with Damon), don't go into it expecting too much.
The class was pretty interesting. If you liked 258 you will probably like 259.
This is a pretty relaxing course where you can pick up some knowledge about where research is at in the field.

This is a really fantastic class for anyone interested in neuro. Even if you're looking to fulfill an EC, take this because it's really worth it! Prof. Niv really gets to know all of her students individually despite the size of the class, and the material is really fascinating (it's neuroscience, so that goes without saying).
This is an interesting course, make sure you pay attention in lecture and you need to put the work in to do well.
dont stress about the textbook readings.
eh
exam format is vastly different from NEU 258 and is a little bit frustrating. but Professor Niv's lectures are very interesting and she does a great job of encouraging class participation
i thought that i would like this class because everyone said 258 was boring/memorisation heavy and yet i loved it .. but it turns out this class is truly boring and nothing but memorisation ..
record lectures to keep up
take if you're really interested in the brain
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention, language, memory, learning and decision making and executive functions of the frontal lobe. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed. Precepts will discuss primary literature pertaining to the topics covered in class.

title: Representing Illness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Nietzsche
reviews: A nice experience, though I think it would have been ever nicer if I had gotten into Nehamas' precept.  Nietzsche is not everyone's cup of tea, however, so make sure you know what you are getting into.
Definitely take this course!!!
Excellent class on Nietzsche. Analytic philosophy buffs--take, but beware.

I would definitely recommend taking this course to anyone with an interest in Nietzsche, or philosophy in general. Professor Nehamas is an excellent scholar of Nietzsche, and his lectures were always engaging.

If you are interested in German philosophy/literary theory/morality and ethics, I would strongly recommend this course. Prof. Nehamas is really excellent; easy to talk to, and informative. You could also easily take this course as your EM with no interest in philosophy and find it captivating.

If you don't consider yourself a philosophy person, this class might be very tough. It was for me. But it was also extremely rewarding. Nehamas is a fantastic lecturer and does a great job making sense of and giving structure to sometimes difficult readings.
If you want to learn about Nietzsche, this is clearly the way to go. It's a fine philosophy class, with a good intersection between ethics and metaphysics.

If you're interested in rounding out your knowledge of philosophy, you won't regret taking this course.  Nietzsche needs to be taken seriously, and this class is a wonderful way to learn about his philosophy.
If you're looking for a great philosophy course on an important philosopher, this is a good course to take.
If you're thinking about it, you should probably just do it. It's a great class!

Lectures are fantastic, if led by Nehamas. Those are the main reason to take the course: do not enroll if you plan on skipping lecture. Readings are great, but in too large of quantity for how dense they are. If you want to understand what you're reading, plan on dedicating >6-8 hours a week to reading.
MUST-TAKE for philosophy majors. Hearing Nehamas lecture is a privilege.
Make sure to keep up with the readings.
Start the essays early
TAKE THIS CLASS. Nietzsche's philosophy is interesting, and Nehamas is the best.
Take it if you have an interest in philosophy and philosophical styles of inquiry.
Take it!

Take it! Every intellectually serious student of modern occidental culture should know about Nietzsche, and Alexander Nehamas is one of the greatest of his readers and advocates any such students could hope to encounter.
Take it.
Take it. Read as much as you can. Try to get Professor Nehamas as your preceptor.
Take this course. It's been a life changing experience.
The course is excellent. Writing about Nietzsche is hard but reading him is very rewarding.
This course is more a literature course than a philosophy course and Nehamas's lectures are quite boring. However if you take it, take it with Tim! Great preceptor...
This is an excellent course in the sense that it can be very intellectual stimulating. However, you need to put decent amount of work into class in order to get more things out of it.

To go through Princeton without having been exposed to Nietzsche as taught by Alexander Nehamas would truly be a loss. You'll want Nietzsche on your bookshelf for the rest of your life, given the excitement Nehamas brings to the material. Strikingly few undergraduate course are taught on ONE philosopher. Nietzsche via Nehamas is a must.

Would recommend only if interested in this area of philosophy or have an inclination to challenge yourself. Material is dense and not easy to get through, although varying room of interpretation is accepted.
You wont' regret it.
definitely take this course
take it.
take this whoever you are
prereqs: At least one Philosophy course-not elementary logic. Freshmen admitted only after interview. Please contact Prof. Nehamas for an appointment..
descrip: An examination of Nietzsche's central views, including the role of tragedy, the place of science, the eternal recurrence, the will to power, and the primacy of the individual. We will also examine Nietzsche's ambiguous attitude toward philosophy and his influence on literature and criticism.

title: Current Research in Law and Politics
descrip: This seminar examines current research in law and politics across a range of specific research questions, methods, and research traditions. The seminar combines background reading on selected topics with presentation of current research by scholars in the field of law and politics. Participants are expected to participate in both the regular seminar sessions and the public law colloquium, complete assigned readings, and complete assigned written work.

title: Theoretical Ecology
reviews: Although it is a pretty difficult course especially if you haven't taken Diff Eq or Linear Algebra before, it is completely doable and well worth the effort! You will have a much better grasp and understanding of ecology after this.
Broad value in ecology and beyond. I particularly enjoyed the applications to international cooperation.

Don't take this class unless you are able to teach yourself mathematical concepts outside of class. Also, the course descriptions says you don't need to know any linear algebra, or differential equations. You do! 

This class is not worth it if you are just taking it to get an EEB departmental.
I hope your TA is helpful.
I would not take this class as a senior, unless you are ahead on your thesis.
I would take it - be willing to work

If you would like to have more math take EEB 424. I made the mistake of taking this class when I actually wanted a more math intensive one, but if you want to avoid math as much as possible take this, because it gives you a good foundation for EEB.
Rising juniors, take this course.  It will help you on your thesis no matter what you do.  Plus you're getting taught by one of the best professors in EEB.
Start the psets early, take a computer science class, and you'll do fine.
Take linear algebra and differential equations before taking this course.
Take the course if you are interested in ecology.
Work on the problem sets with some friends, and go to the TA for help when you need it.
n/a
prereqs: There is no limit on graduate enrollment..
descrip: Current and classical theoretical issues in ecology and evolutionary biology. Emphasis will be on theories and concepts and on mathematical approaches. Topics will include population and community ecology, immunology and epidemiology, population genetics and evolutionary theory.

title: History of the Balkans
reviews: If you are interested in this part of the world, or in Europe more generally, I highly recommend that you take this class.
It's a great class if you're interested in going in depth into the history of the Balkans. It's very approachable for non-history majors
this course made me realize what a sad state of affairs humanities academia is. probably not a bad thing
descrip: Southeastern Europe has always possessed a distinct regional identity. To say "the Balkans" is to conjure up a place that, while part of Europe, seems somehow apart from European history. What is it that has given southeastern Europe its distinctiveness? In this course we will answer that question by exploring the historical experience of the area stretching from Hungary to Crete, and from the Adriatic to Istanbul. We will start in the medieval period and take the story up until the twentieth century.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese II
reviews: I felt this was almost easier than third-year, but it's still quite a bit of work compared to first/second-year.
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, writing, speaking and listening.

title: Sociological Theory
reviews: DO NOT take this class unless you absolutely need to.
I might be a little hesitant to recommend this course to non Soc majors
I wouldn't recommend anybody to take it unless it was a requirement or they genuinely had an interest in the material. SOC 101 had a lot of the same material.
If you're not a Sociology major, stay far away from this course.
Only take it if you're a major and you have to. Recent authors are interesting, but the majority of readings are pretty dry.
Take it if you are interested in the foundations of sociology.
Take it if you're a SOC or PHI major--it can be pretty interesting. For everyone else, eh, there are better courses out there.

Take it. PFK is an amazing instructor and genuinely concerned about students. She invests in them and once you get past her abrasive exterior, she will invest in you as a person which is difficult to find amongst the busy professors at Princeton. She is a dedicated instructor, the most dedicated I have come across at Princeton. She will always make time for you; the trick is not letting her scare you.
Well it's mandatory as a Soc major, but I think even non-Soc majors would enjoy it.
You have to take it if you're in SOC so just do it
prereqs: SOC 101.
descrip: This course invites you to systematically review foundational texts in sociology. Attention is given to the formulation of concepts, hypotheses, and research methods. We explore social structure and action; change and conflict; norms and roles; social class and stratification; deviance; and the link between micro- and macro-sociology. We also consider phenomena such as modernization, urbanization, migration, industrialization, and global capitalism. Why does theory matter to contemporary politics and policy? These are among the questions we ask.

title: Topics in Music from 1400 to 1600 - Renaissance Music
descrip: The sacred music of Josquin Des Prez (c.1455-1521): masses, motets, musical styles, reception, performance practice, analysis, aesthetics.

title: Ethnography of Schools and Schooling
reviews: Even if you're not considering teaching, but are just mildly interested in education, take this course.

If you are interested in education in any sort of capacity, or even just want to reflect upon your own experiences, great course. Also great for people interested in ethnography because you get a small ethnographic experience.

If you are interested in education, this class will provide you with an interesting angle to understanding what goes on in schools. I walked away with a wonderful appreciation for the complexity of the issue, something that I thing is often overlooked in the 
education reform rhetoric today!
Speak up! Your particular perspective and experience is especially worthwhile in a class like this. And the more you give it, the more you'll get out of it.
Strongly recommended for anthro majors or anyone with an interest in education.
Take it if P. Klugman is teaching
Take it if you're interested in education policy and want a good perspective and a wide array of exposure. A lot of anthro though, and it is more work than you think (especially with the readings).
Take it if you're interested in schools or anthropology or both :)
This is a course that requires some work and attention, but it is very interesting and engaging.

This is a great class for anyone interested in teaching or school reform, especially urban US schools but also with global implications. The combination of close on the ground observation and analysis with a broader anthropological/sociological/education theory context allowed room for many perspectives that went beyond the usual anthro class (and the discipline's own limitations). The culminating mini ethnography was an amazing opportunity to see a variety of schools- comparing observations with classmates was a lot of fun- and Prof Klugman was always flexible and thought provoking. The course requires individual commitment and dedication, but is very rewarding and inspiring.
prereqs: Students should have a background (coursework or other experience) in anthropology, sociology, education or related fields..
descrip: Social scientists use ethnographic methods to describe and analyze the range and variation of daily interactions in schools. Ethnographic study allows researchers the opportunity to examine power dynamics that influence the daily life of students, teachers, administrators and parents. Vivid, critical ethnography helps us discover how cultural traditions, expectations, and opportunities are passed down to the next generation and how they impact school outcomes. This class will explore educational ethnography and students will complete observations hours in local schools and prepare a descriptive, mini-ethnography of a school community.

title: Reading Literature: Drama
descrip: This course is designed to teach students how to read plays as literature written for performance. Key assumptions are that every act of reading is an act of interpretation, that a good reader of dramatic literature engages in an activity nearly identical to that of a good director or actor or designer, and that a reader might learn from theater practitioners how to make critical choices based on close reading and a knowledge of theatre history.

title: Arts of Imitation - Translation in Theory and Practice
descrip: What is the relationship of translation to interpretation, to imitation, and to reading? How do practice and theory reflect upon and inform one another? Analyzing major essays in the history of translation studies from St. Jerome to Benjamin, Derrida, Spivak and Cheung, our course explores how translation has transformed our views of literature, literary studies, and the act of writing itself. Since in translation, more than in many other disciplines, theory and practice are inseparable, the course also includes substantial practice in translation itself.

title: Seminar. History of Photography
reviews: Be prepared for an intense study of a topic within the history of photography; realise that this is not a survey course. It's definitely helpful to have some sort of knowledge of photo history going into the course, at least a survey. The class is great, though. There is a lot of reading and a lot of looking involved, but you'll definitely learn a lot.

I would strongly recommend this course! Anne McCauley is phenomenal and is an absolute expert on the Pre-Raphaelites and Victorian photography! I didn't know anything going in and learned so much from this incredible professor! Take any class with McCauley if you can!

Incredible course! Don't think it will be offered in future years, but the London and DC trips definitely were the highlights of my Princeton experience. Professor McCauley is extremely knowledgable, but can come across as a bit intimidating, especially if your opinion doesn't match hers. But all the same, she's very funny and caring and will do her best to teach you about a subject she knows so much about.

Prof. McCauley is taking a sabbatical year, but if she offers this course again, TAKE IT. No matter how much background you have in art history, you will find yourself inspired, excited and motivated to take even more art history courses. It's shaped the way I think about various pieces when I walk into the museum and my perception of the field as a whole
prereqs: By application only through the course website. Previous coursework in nineteenth-century art history, history, or English literature would be helpful but is not required..
descrip: The founding of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood in 1848 occurred shortly before the take-off of inexpensive photographic prints in 1851. This course explores the intersections between the new painting, dedicated to "truth to nature," and photography as evidence of shared cultural, scientific, and intellectual values. Topics include the Great Exhibition of 1851; constructing celebrities; the Oxford movement and religious art; containing Empire and nature; machinery, labor and poverty; and envisioning the past. Featured are Ruskin, Cameron, Millais, Rossetti, Carlyle, Tennyson, Lewis Carroll, Dickens, Frith, Holman Hunt, and William Morris.

title: Law and the Study of Race
descrip: This is a graduate level seminar for students who want to use case law, legislation and legal history as a means of examining race and ethnicity in the Americas in the fields of literature, history, cultural studies, and sociology.

title: Poetics - Continuing Pastoral
descrip: A seminar on the continuing and transforming genre of pastoral from Theocritus to Michel Serres.

title: Topics in Number Theory and Related Analysis - Spectral Theory of Automorphic Forms
prereqs: For advanced level undergraduates and graduate students..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Number Theory and Related Analysis. Specific topic information provided when course is taught.

title: Shakespeare and Performance
descrip: This course focuses on the ways in which the performance conditions and conventions of early modern England shaped Shakespeare's plays and on the ways in which later performance conditions and conventions, including those of our own day, have continued to shape how the plays are produced on stage and how they are received. We will take every opportunity to see the plays on stage in Princeton and beyond (for example, the McCarter's Winter's Tale) and will take an occasional look at parallel issues raised by Shakespeare on film and video.

title: Expertise in Translation: Linguistic Encounters Across Professions and Disciplines
descrip: We usually think of anthropology as a translation across different cultures and languages, but encounters between different professions and academic disciplines also call for translation. In this course, we treat interdisciplinary and cross-professional exchanges as ethnographic sites, using methods from linguistic anthropology to examine the challenges of translating expertise across professional fields. We also explore different approaches to interdisciplinary translation, in the process developing our understanding of the broader interaction between language and culture.

title: Studies in Chinese Religions - Buddhism and Daoism
descrip: Survey of recent scholarship in the field, focusing on the schools of Chinese Buddhism, Tantric Buddhism, and interactions between Buddhism and Daoism. Readings primarily in English. Especially for students preparing for general exams in the field of Chinese Religions.

title: Risk Assessment and Management
reviews: Don't take it unless you need it. The course starts out very easy but the second half gets confusing.
Don't take unless you're really interested in the subject because Ning Lin isn't the best professor.
I would not advise any students to take this course.  It is not interesting and will not teach you anything you don't know.
I would tell CEE majors to avoid if they can - competing with ORFE students in a class this ORFE oriented was tough....
Npt a bad course but it will probably improve with time.
Pretty good introduction and use of material, but don't take senior spring
Um..don't take it unless you need to
if you want to learn more about probability/stats, take ORF courses.
prereqs: Basic probability and statistics course..
descrip: Fundamentals of probabilistic risk analysis. Stochastic modeling of hazards. Estimation of extremes. Vulnerability modeling of natural and built environment. Evaluation of failure chances and consequences. Reliability analysis. Decision analysis and risk management. Case studies involving natural hazards, including earthquakes, extreme wind, rainfall flooding, storm surge, hurricanes, and climate change, and their induced damage and economic losses. R statistical package used in problem sets and course project.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: Absolutely take a course in creative writing--fiction--if not to broaden the scope of your creativity to spend some time with the writers who teach it.
Darcey Steinke was my champion and one of the most supportive (yet still constructively critical) writing profs I had. Highly recommend!
Definitely take this course! You will come away stimulated and inspired.
I love creative writing courses; having taken four, though, I don't feel that Edmund White is the best instructor. Discussion and workshopping was shallow and disappointing.
I would recommend this course to others.
If Darcey Steinke teaches a course at Princeton again, I highly encourage you to take her class.
If Darcey's teaching it, take it: she will challenge you.
It's a workshop, so the quality of the course will depend a lot on the other students, but if you have liked fiction classes in the past then you'll probably enjoy it.
Start your stories early, bring your A-game.
Take it, but don't take it as a "5th class." While it's manageable, you won't get much out of the class unless you put in the work.

Take it. It's in the CWR department. You will get something out of it. Of course, classroom interaction depends largely on the chemistry of the students and the mood of the professor. Professor Eugenides can be critical, but if you're looking at advanced workshops, then that's probably what you're looking for (or should be looking for). You'll grow a lot more than you did in intro workshops.
Try not to leave your written story to the last minute. Do the readings because he talks about them in class. Be an active participant in class.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Exotic Quantum States of Matter
descrip: See website

title: Beginner's Greek: Attic Prose
reviews: Be prepared for random assignments, and make time each week to learn the stuff.

Greek is hard. But if you've taken 101, you have to take 102 as well. Be prepared for even more memorizing and much, much more complex grammar. Ford is lots and lots of fun. He makes the material really engaging, and he's a really nice guy. Beware, he's sometimes disorganized, and he moves really fast. The quizzes are pretty tough.
I would strongly recommend continuing with 102 after taking 101, and if the course is being taught by Professor Ford, you can be sure that it will be a worthwhile experience.
If you are legitimately interested in the material, Professor Ford is excellent and you will love the class.  But be prepared to work.
It is hard. It is a ton of work. I probably spent three times as much time on this class just to get a lower grade in the classes I wouldn't even study for. But it is worth it.

Stay up on the lessons: once you fall behind in Hanson & Quinn, it can be dense and difficult to catch up on. Make an effort to pay attention to all the tips on the genealogy of forms so you can build a more comprehensive understanding of the language itself.
prereqs: CLG 101 or Permission Of Instructor. Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year short selections of Attic prose will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations.
