The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Roman Literature: Selected Author or Authors - Ovid's Metamorphoses
reviews: Absolutely take it. Feeney knows a lot, so he will mostly (80%+) talk in class. But students are free to speak.
Definitely take the course, both for its content as well as to learn from Professor Feeney.

Do take it. Feeney is an excellent professor, and Ovid is an excellent writer. Don't count on much support for the actual translation-- ideally you will be comfortable reading Latin poetry by the time you take this class. Do be willing to ask questions in class, either on the translation or for discussion-- you will get good answers.
If you love Latin and literature study the Metamorphoses
Take it!
Take it.
Take this class!  Professor Feeney is excellent and the Metamorphoses is an excellent and influential work.
This is a course on (in my opinion) one of the best literary works of all time with a fantastic professor.
prereqs: LAT 203 or equivalent..
descrip: Reading selections from Ovid's Metamorphoses. The first book will be read complete, in later books we will read extensive passages in order to get a feeling for the structure and coherence of the work as well.

title: Financial Modelling
reviews: Review the slides before attending to class
prereqs: ECO 525/FIN 525 and ECO 526/FIN 526 (526 may be taken concurrently)..
descrip: Advanced asset pricing and corporate finance including a selection from: models of financial crises and bubbles; interaction between finance and macroeconomics, derivative pricing in incomplete markets; tests of asset pricing models and associated anomalies; models of investor behavior; financial econometrics, including tests of asset pricing models and methods for high frequency data. Pre-requisites: ECO 525 and 526 (526 may be taken concurrently).

title: Special Topics in the History of Philosophy - Nietzsche
descrip: Nietzsche's views on human intention and action, with reference to contemporary approaches to the same issues.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy: Applications: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: WWS 507b.
descrip: Provides hands-on experience in the application of econometric methods to policy issues. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable hypotheses, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. The course will be taught using a set of cases in which students apply quantitative methods covered in WWS 507b to data in order to answer specific policy questions. Emphasis will be placed on interpreting and writing about results.

title: Elementary Korean II
reviews: Definitely don't slack off. Although this isn't a demanding course, it still requires maintenance. There is definitely a time committment (you meet every day) but this is necessary for the course. If you want to be able to be fairly fluent in basic Korean, definitely take this course!! The teachers are really funny and very very helpful and nice!
Delightful teachers and you learn a lot!
If you have any ounce of interest in Korean language or culture you should take it!
If you think you might enjoy learning a language, Korean is a great option.
Must take if interested in learning Korean
Not as hard as it sounds, and you learn a lot. Just a matter of putting in a little study/homework time every other day or so. Plus the teachers are very nice.
Take it if you want to learn a little Korean!
Take it! It's not that much work and it's very fun!
Take it.
The Korean department is amazing!
The Korean department is the best language department at Princeton!
take it!
prereqs: KOR 101 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 101. Continued development of proficiency in basic communication.

title: Introduction to English Literature: 14th to 18th Century
reviews: Attend the lectures, really engage in the texts.
Do all readings
Do not take it if you are looking for a fun English class. It is a lot of work.

Do not take this course UNLESS you have to as an English major OR you happen to be particularly interested in reading Chaucer, Spenser and Milton. Otherwise, it is a pain to do all of the reading (there is a lot and it's difficult) and to write the papers. It's not a bad course, the professors and preceptors are very knowledgeable and dedicated to the material, but if you aren't (dedicated to the material) then don't take it if you don't have to.
Do you need this course to enter the English Department? If not, don't take it.
Don't give up during Chaucer or Milton, even though those texts are rather difficult to work through!
Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to.

Don't take unless departmental or strong interest in the literature. Try to take with Sophie Gee. Try try try to read at least one section of each work closely but you can get by, if you're smart, with reading very little of the texts. The final exam is HARD.

Eh. If you want a good sample of the English department, don't take this. It's a pre-req, and in the last lecture Prof. Gee told everyone this, by rights, shouldn't be an intro English course (it's a bit harder).
Good background, don't fall behind in the reading, and take advantage with precept.

I had heard really bad things about this class, but Sophie Gee was really good.  I don't know if it's possible to predict who's teaching this when, but if you have to take this (which I assume you do), she's quite good.
I would advise only taking this course if you are a prospective English major, or genuinely enjoy 18th century literature.

I would recommend doing all of the readings, as it truly makes the course fun and intellectually stimulating. Also, it is very helpful come papers and exam time to have attended the lectures and taken notes in precept, as it will come in very handy.
I would strongly recommend taking this class. Professor Gee is a brilliant lecturer, and she is very funny and interesting. You will learn a lot from this class.
I would tell future students to make interesting and unexpected arguments that are closely supported by the text.

If you want to be an English major or are even considering it, then take this course (because you'll have to anyway). Even if you don't want to be an English major, I still recommend it. You'll learn a lot of literature and learn to think and analyze critically.
It is possible to take this course if you are not an English major, but you may feel uncertain of its value afterwards.
It's a good survey course, and necessary for English majors.
Make sure you talk to your preceptor about the readings and the papers.
One of the best I've taken at Princeton.
Only take if you have to because there are much more interesting English classes
Only take it when you are SURE you're an English major. You can get away with taking it after your sophomore year.
Professor Gee is amazing! I had been nervous about taking the class because it sounded really challenging, but it was manageable, and I learned a lot!
Professor Gee is amazing. Even if you aren't an English major, you'll like this course.

Professor Gee is really great and brings up interesting points in lecture, but precept had a lot of awkward silence. Graded unnecessarily harshly for an intro class. The readings are interesting though, if you like poetry.
Sophie Gee makes the course wonderful. If you want to/have to read some of the best English literature, do it with Sophie Gee.
Stay on top of your reading! If you do, you'll really enjoy the course.

Take this course. Professor Gee is amazing, perhaps the best lecturer I've had in my first year here! Also, really really try to do all of the readings. I got a little behind and I regret that because they are awesome!
There are other classes that are easier if you are looking for a general interest class, but if you are truly interested in this material, this is a great class taught by an excellent professor.

This was a great class, and Professor Gee was a wonderful lecturer.  This course is very helpful for figuring out whether or not you want to be an english major.  The books that you read are some of the greatest works in literature, so it is always great to have an excuse to read them.
only take it if you want to be an English major and you have to
prereqs: First-year students welcome. English 200 is a prerequisite for entrance into the Department of English..
descrip: An introduction to the leading figures of earlier English Literature, including Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, Milton, Pope, and Swift; to literary history as a mode of inquiry; and to some of the questions that preoccupy English poetry, prose, and drama across four centuries: art, beauty, romance, desire, the will, the mind, God, sex, and death.

title: World Drama
reviews: Absolutely take it if you are truly interested in theater. If you are not open minded, though, you may find that the plays do not directly relate to you.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. It should not even be offered, at least with this professor who is so bad they should not even be allowed to teach here.
Do as much of the reading as you can and participate actively in class. Meet with Prof. Sandberg one on one if necessary.

Don't approach this class like your other english classes when writing anything. Don't be straitlaced because you'll seem like a square. Instead, ask a lot of questions and don't seem like you have any answers and you'll be fine.

Don't be afraid to talk in class! Professor Bob is super nice and will not judge you for making stupid comments. It was nice to see a sort of camaraderie grow in our seminar because everyone became so comfortable with speaking their minds in the end.

If you are interested in performance, this is a really important course to take - it will give you a broader perspective on what that term means outside of English and French.  Bob is an amazing professor and you should take a course with him if at all possible.

If you have any interest in theater at all, you will probably benefit a lot from this course. Professor Sandberg is one of the best professors here, and this course covers a wide range of theatrical traditions you have probably never heard of but all of which are fascinating and significant. Take it.
TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS TAKE THIS
Take it.
read everything because some of the plays are really great!
descrip: This course is a survey of classical and contemporary drama from Africa, China, India, Japan, and Latin America. Topics will include Noh and Kabuki, Beijing Opera, Sanskrit theater, Nigerian masquerades and a variety of selections from the rich modern Indian and Latin American canons. There will be trips to NYC and locally to see new theater works. The creators of these pieces, artists from Israel, Macedonia, South Africa and Chile, will visit class to discuss their projects as well as global theater.

title: Marcel Proust
prereqs: Classes are conducted in French and readings are in French. Papers can be written in English, unless student is a French major; in that case both papers must be written in French. Prerequisite: a 200-level FRE course or permission of instructor..
descrip: We will explore how Proust's work addresses issues great and small, such as art, memory, sexuality, war, spectacles, restrooms... We will read the two ends of "A la Recherche du Temps Perdu" (and more) and examine its influence in literature and broader cultures.

title: Organic Chemistry II: Foundations of Chemical Reactivity and Synthesis
reviews: Always keep up with the material and never fall behind. Do the problem sets! Orgo is kind of like math - you don't really understand what's going on until you PRACTICE.
DO THE PROBLEM SETS. Also learn everything twice.
DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE FRESHMAN YEAR YOU WILL REGRET IT. WHATEVER YOU DO DON'T GET BRAINWASHED INTO TAKING IT!
Definitely recommend staying on top of the material and finding help if you fall behind.

Definitely take this over 304b. From what I have heard about the other class, this one is way more enjoyable, especially with Sorenson who is awesome. Go to anything that David Siler or Jason Shields teaches--if Jason teaches the McGraw sessions again, go to every single one of them and you will do well in the class. Overall a great class and not too hard.
Do the psets, go to McGraw if Jason Shields is doing it.
Don't take it unless you're a chem major - also, if I could redo some things, I would probably either not taken orgo @ Pton or not be pre-med @ Pton.
Don't take unless you absolutely have to.

Even if you like biology, I would strongly recommend 304.  Professor Sorensen's enthusiasm makes lectures remarkably engaging, and his teaching style is artistic and clear; if anyone can make orgo enjoyable, it's him.  The workload in terms of problem sets and review tests seems less than for 303.  The biggest thing to keep in mind throughout this course is to look for recurring patterns and processes.
Find out how much Reider is lecturing before you switch over.
Go over the lecturre notes as soon as possible. The same day is best/ the same week is okay.

I assume you are only taking this course if you are CHM or pre-med. In that case, if you were a little put off by the way 303 went for you, give 304 a try. Sorensen and his staff do a much better job of engaging you in lecture and preparing you for the exams than Semmelhack does.
I really liked the synthesis aspect of 304 - it was exciting to learn about drug making.

I sat in on both Semmelhack's and Sorensen's course for the drop/add period and chose Sorensen for several reasons. His lectures are far more engaging (although they cover less material) and conceptually approachable. He brings a joy to the classroom that can be infectious, and students are overall more relaxed and eager to participate with questions and possible solutions to synthesis questions. That being said, the lectures rarely cover all that is in the reading, but the lectures are honed to a fine point in order to impart a conceptual grasp that allows the reading to make sense quickly. Sorensen's class rarely references the Sorrell textbook; he makes hand-written (with impeccable handwriting) sets of notes that cover everything in the course. These are incredibly easy to follow.

A notable difference between the two courses, which also led me to favor Sorensen, is that Sorensen has practice exams only stretching back to 2008/2009. I found it stressful in Semmelhack's class to know that there were fifteen years' worth of practice exams that I "could" do to be more prepared (and in some sense were necessary to be "fully" prepared) for his exams. With Sorensen's old tests however,  a much more manageable study schedule can be set. That being said, you may find that this doesn't provide enough practice. 

Sorensen's exams are bit simpler (or a lot simpler) because they are closed book with one front/back page of notes that you can bring. Since you can't consult old tests or the book or class notes, the test questions are designed to confirm fundamental knowledge and emphasize broad concepts rather than test your ability to recognize trick questions - which often seemed to be the case with Semmelhack exams. There are still "trick questions," but there is less a sense of an overabundance of material to draw on. 

Semmelhack's class, however, seems more interesting from an informational standpoint. The synthesis emphasis of Sorensen's class leaves things feelin

I took this course instead of 304B due to the suggestion of an upperclass who said Sorensen was awesome - and he definitely is! However, Reider was not as good and he teaches half of the lecturers so that made this class less appealing. However, I think I would still recommend this over 304B if you're looking from a change from Semmelhack. I liked Semmelhack as well, but not as much as Sorensen, and some people might prefer a different style of teaching (Semmelhack: projector   following along on pre-printed notes vs Sorensen: live lectures where he draws what he's talking about out on the blackboard and then posts his personal notes online afterwards so you can read through them at your leisure and teach yourself anything you didn't understand)
I'm definitely happy I took 304 instead of 304B, but I wouldn't recommend that anyone take this class "just for fun."
If possible, take this over 304B!!!
If you liked first semester of orgo, take it!
If you need to take this course, it's not as bad as everyone says it is, so don't sweat.
If you're willing to suffer through fall orgo and work hard, this is an awesome class.
It will be painful but actually study every week or even every other day if possible. Stay ahead.
It's definitely an interesting class to take, even if you aren't doing anything related to chemistry. If you like puzzles, this class is perfect.
It's not that bad! Take it with Sorensen.
Keep up with all the notes. Review them as soon as the come out. Make a list of all the reactions from the start of the semester to the end so that you can keep track of them.

Make sure you read the lecture notes. They're very straightforward (and not as long as they look!). I think Sorensen is waaaay better than Semmelhack, in case you're trying to decide. Much more engaging.
Make sure you study the notes after every class and keep up with the lectures

Organic chemistry is known for being challenging, so it is best not to procrastinate. Also, try not to take another very challenging course along with it because you might have to sacrifice some time to the other course, and that is not optimal for learning orgo.

Orgo is difficult.  You need to study consistently; try at least 30-60 mins/day (I didn't do this and did badly in the class).  Also, use Organic Chemistry as a Second Language by Klein!!  Prof. Sorensen is an excellent teacher; Prof. Reider has tons of fascinating experience to share.  Know the basics cold and then learn to apply them through synthesis, and take all the exams seriously.
Read all Sorenson's notes--you don't really have to read the textbook. Do all the practice you can. Go to precept, and make sure you understand NMR and enolate formation.
Review frequently and aggressively. Don't expect to just learn stuff the weekend before the exams.
Sorensen is an awesome lecturer.

Spend a set amount of time every week to review lecture notes/ class notes so that the reaction mechanisms are fresh in your mind. THis makes studying for exams much easier, since you'd be spreading it out throughout the semester. The lectures are very organized. Sorenson will make chemistry fun and Reider is just fun to listen to.
Start early on the Vanillin Nitration lab.  Try to get David Siler as a preceptor, and Lisa Yates would be a great lab TA.
Take CHM 304! It is a great continuation of CHM 303 with very interesting material.
Take for Sorenson! He makes organic chemistry so fun. Everyone should be exposed to this class.
Take it because of Sorensen's lectures.
Take it if you like organic chemistry. It's interesting material, but is difficult.
Take it! Sorensen is AMAZING!!!!! I found 2nd semester Orgo much more interesting than 1st semester.
Take it-- even if just for fun!
Take it. It's fun!
Take this course! Even if you're not pre-med, if you're interested in chemistry and problem solving, this class is a great one to take.
The course requires a lot of work.  It's interesting and well-taught, but is a very big commitment.
This class is a perfect continuation of 1st semester orgo. You take the basics and learn the most interesting mechanisms you can apply them to.

This course is pretty time-intensive, and definitely requires a lot of work if you expect to get a decent grade. If not required for a major or premed, it would likely be easier to fulfill requirements through other means.

However, if you have an interest in the topic, it is well-taught and engaging.
Time consuming, but Professor Sorensen and the rest of the staff were fantastic. Make sure you keep up with the material and get help if needed as soon as you can.

When going over the practice tests with the key (especially with the reactant questions), go find a TA.  There is often more than one answer and you shouldn't be too hard on yourself if you have a different, viable one.
You need to be able to devote a lot of time to it.

You need to be able to figure out two things to do all of orgo:
What is the most acidic proton, or basic site.
What is the most nucleophilic or eletrophilic site.
Don't bother learning any reactions, just be able to figure out those things and you'll do really well.

You probably have to take it, so take it. Sorensen is a really good lecturer and it's easier to get a good grade than 303, even though the material is harder. Definitely take this over 304B if you're not really interested in the biological side of organic chemistry. I also hear 304B is a lot more difficult.

You'll get as much out of this class as you put into it. Your grade will reflect your mastery (or lack thereof) of the material, and you only have yourself to blame if you do poorly. This course is a true test of whether you've adapted to college and know how to take responsibility for your work, because nobody's going to check in and make sure you're doing what you're supposed to. Exams could be a real wake-up call. Work HARD and try to enjoy the material because it can be interesting...

a good  class. glad I took it. both this one and bio one are much better organized than last semester. Sorensen and Hankster are awesome. reider not so much, but don't even have to go when he's lecturing.
do not buy a molecular model kit. read through lecture notes meticulously. Take sorensen's class.
don't take it if you don't have to.

if deciding between CHM304B and this class, TAKE THIS CLASS,
even if youre pre-med or MOL, you'll have biochem to learn bio stuff... sorenson and co. make orgo alot of fun so take it from them
it's organic chemistry.
strongly recommend over Semmelhack's class, but do not take if you don't have to.
this is a wonderful course to take if you enjoy chemistry, but be warned it is very difficult
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303..
descrip: This course begins by discussing the chemical consequences of conjugation and the Diels-Alder reaction. After a coverage of aromaticity and the chemistry of benzene, we then move into the heart of the course: the nature and reactivity of the carbonyl group, a subject that is central to both mainstream organic chemistry and biochemistry. Throughout this course, an effort will be made to demystify the art of chemical synthesis. This course is appropriate for chemistry majors, premedical students, and other students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Music and Madness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Nonlinear Dynamics
reviews: A great course. Offers the ability to learn interesting material without taking up too much of your time.
Definitely go to all the lectures. Professor Kevrekidis always have very interesting things to say. Do your final projects early!
Definitely take this course!
Does not require a really strong background in math. Take it if you want to learn useful tools.
If Prof. Kevrekidis is teaching it definitely take it, you'll learn a tremendous amount and have a great time doing so.
It's a fairly challenging course, but quite rewarding to understand.
It's a very fun class and you should take it.

Nonlinear dynamics is a fantastic subject and I loved this course! Moreover, I learned a lot! Be careful that the class starts slowly, but there will be many assignments near the end of the semester and the expectations for the final project are high.
Pretty excellent course. Give some thought to (and talk to Prof. Kevrekidis about) your final project early, so you can get the most out of it.
Take it and read the book--it's a classic.
Take it if you are interested in the subject matter. The professor will be a great teacher.
Take this if you're interested in learning more about non-linear dynamics.

The course was interesting- there's a very high education:work ratio. You learn a lot about nonlinear dynamics, in a reasonably-paced environment. The problem sets are very doable, and usually touch upon something nontrivial. I would recommend this class if you want to learn a bit more about dynamics. 

Not so "rigorous," as you might expect from something crosslisted with math. No real emphasis on proofs, which can be good or bad, depending on what you want. But it lays the foundation for further work.

This class is excellent and Yannis is a great teacher, but make sure that you ask if you are confused about more administrative things like when the homework is due and what to do on the final project, as there are few guidelines.
This is an awesome course! Professor Kevrekidis is a great lecturer and the material is really interesting.
This was a great course for anyone interested in learning more about dynamic systems. Math majors may find the course to be slightly lacking in rigor but overall it is still a fantastic course.
prereqs: Knowledge of linear algebra (MAT 204) and ordinary differential equations (MAE 305 or MAT 427). Some computing experience is required for this course..
descrip: An introduction to the phenomenology of nonlinear dynamic behavior with emphasis on models of actual physical, chemical, and biological systems, involving an interdisciplinary approach to ideas from mathematics, computing, and modeling. The common features of the development of chaotic behavior in both mathematical models and experimental studies are stressed, and the use of modern data-mining tools to analyze dynamic data will be explored.

title: Advanced Algorithm Design
reviews: If you are passionate about algorithms or need to satisfy the requirement do take this class.
Take if interested in algorithms (built off of COS 340).
Take this course if you are interested in theory.
This is one of the most mindblowing courses that you could ever take. Do it!
Worth taken,
descrip: Advanced methods of algorithmic design and analysis: data structures, network flows, and linear programming. Solution of linear programs: Karmarkar and Ellipsoid algorithms. Probabilistic techniques. A selection of topics from on-line computation, approximation algorithms for NP-hard problems, number theoretic algorithms, geometric algorithms, and parallel computation.

title: Topics in Postcolonial Literature - Postcolonial Cities
reviews: Definitely take this course! You will learn about cities and how they have been imagined in literature; but you will also learn how to think critically and thoughtfully about the texts and themes covered in class.
Professor Gikandi will change your life! Please do yourself a favor and take this class!!!!
Really good reading list, and Professor Gikandi is very interesting and knowledgeable.
The course is a bit of work, and a very literature nerd type. but a great class if you want to answer broader questions using literature.

The ideal English seminar. Professor Gikandi takes you seriously (no Blackboard posts just to make sure you do the reading, etc.) and if you take the course seriously by doing the work, you'll have a very positive experience.
descrip: Addresses the literature of several cities that have been central in shaping the modern imagination: Bombay, Cairo, Lagos, and Johannesburg. It will explore how the emergence of these global cities has transformed the meaning of urban landscapes and their representation in literature. The course will also examine how migrant writers from Africa and the Caribbean have transformed old cities such as London and New York. How does the city shape the form of writing? How does language itself transform the meaning of the urban experience? How does this literature challenge some of the leading theories on space and modern identity?

title: International Financial History
reviews: Professor James is incredibly knowledgeable about this field, and so the course is very useful if you're interested in financial history. Be prepared to sort through a lot readings to pick out the important points every week, although the reading load was never too much to handle and Prof. James always makes sure to point out the key themes at the beginning of class.
descrip: The course examines financial innovation and its consequences from the early modern period to present: it examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader processes of economic development and to state formation? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility?

title: Intensive Intermediate Chinese
reviews:
--It's fucking hard, as everyone knows, but probably worth it. That said, you HAVE to put in work if you want to learn the language and make use of the great resources provided.
--Study the lesson and grammar ahead of time so you can make the most of class
--If you're just in this for the grade, cramming works well; however, it really is a wonderful course and you should create a strict study/work schedule to make the most of it
--THE LECTURERS ARE AMAZING AND YOU WILL LOVE THEM ALL, almost as much as we love them
As long as you do the work and put in the time to learn the characters and practice the grammar, you can do well. The teachers are wonderful resources-- use them.
Be prepared for a lot of reading. If you don't consider yourself very proficient in Chinese going into it, be prepared to play a bit of catch up during the first several weeks.
Be prepared to put a lot of effort in, and grade deflation really hits this class hard. Obscenely hard.
Definitely stay on top of everything and study for weekly tests early!

Definitely take this if you are seriously interested in improving your Chinese ability. I had a great experience in this course educationally as well as socially. Getting to know the professors and classmates presented me with such a rich and rewarding cultural experience.

I started this year (pre-103) able to recognize a few words, speak a handful and write none. Now I feel quite comfortable with daily conversation and can read/write at least a thousand characters. Highly recommended to any heritage speaker, even if your Chinese sucks. Just be prepared to work.

IF you are a native speaker and you enjoy challenging yourself, you should take this class. The professors are guaranteed to be great, and you get a LOT of speaking practice as well as learning Chinese. Discussions are heated at times, and overall it's a great course. Fridays are a bit stressful though, as you can imagine.
If you're willing to put in the effort, then take this class. It is the best and your Chinese will improve dramatically.
It may require constant effort and work, but you will notice great improvements in your Chinese.
Lots of work, but classes are fun and Chinese isn't too painful to study for compared to say, MOL or PHY. My favorite class this semester.

Only take this course if you are willing to dedicate a lot of time to it. It's a very rigorous course, but if you're interested in Chinese, you will get a lot out of it. Don't take it just to get a credit out of the way because it's very labor intensive. It's very worth it though!
Put in lots of time
TAKE IT. YOU WILL LEARN A LOT. However, it is a lot of work, so be prepared.
Take it. Stay on top of things.
Take this course
Take this course! It's the same structure as CHI103 and it's a lot of work at times, but it's really rewarding. The teachers are really helpful and want you to succeed.
Take time every day to study a bit. Or a lot.

This is a great course to take if you have had exposure to Chinese when young but want to come to college and really learn it. There's no better place to learn Chinese than at Princeton, and this course is a testament to that. The teachers are fantastic, and although the class is intense, you will see a huge improvement in your Chinese over the course of the semester. While the teachers get particularly picky in this semester, you will learn how to properly speak, read, and write in Chinese. Make sure you are willing to study consistently and focus on the small grammatical details. You will lose points for even the slightest mistakes, because the teachers want everything exactly right, but you'll learn so much and build great relationships with the teachers and your classmates. I strongly recommend this course.
Work hard
Work hard everyday and keep up....otherwise you'll be doomed...
You'll have to Invest a lot of time into it, but it's worth it.
prereqs: CHI 103 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: An intensive course covering 105 and 107 in one semester for students who have finished 103 which covers 101 and 102. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills and the analysis of grammar. After 108, students are ready for third year courses.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese II
prereqs: CHI 301 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion in Chinese traditional philosophical thoughts and historical issues. Texts and essays written from Tang to Qing dynasty. Class discussions will be conducted in Mandarin Chinese.

title: Readings in Japanese Academic Style II
descrip: The second half of the two-semester course, which trains students in reading the particular style of Japanese academic writing. The second semester particularly focuses on academic writings from Meiji to the 1950s, including brief introduction of necessary Classical Japanese Grammar for this purpose. Course conducted in English.

title: Joan of Arc
descrip: See website

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Economics of the Welfare State
descrip: All advanced countries have extensive "welfare state" programs that provide insurance against economic losses, support people with low incomes, etc.. But these programs vary widely in extent from the relatively small US welfare state, to the larger welfare states of much of Europe, to the generous programs of Scandinavia. At the same time, there is heated controversy about the effects of such programs. This course surveys welfare state programs, including health care systems, across various countries, analyzes the debates over their economic effects, and looks at the political economy of reform in the US and countries such as France.

title: Religion and State Relations in Comparative Perspective
descrip: In this comparative seminar we examine models of secularism in contemporary Europe, North America, South Asia and the Middle East, and explore the implications of religion-state relations for the quality of democratic citizenship. We start with an overview of the relationship between religion, democracy and secularism and ask what role religion should and should not play in democratic public discourses. We then compare the institutional models of secularism. In a final section, we study the relationship between religious freedom and human rights, and the challenges religious laws may create for democratic and democratizing polities.

title: Microeconomic Policy
descrip: oh, dear

title: The Literature of the Past
reviews: Good first course on the classical world, especially if you're interested in history, the philosophical treatment of texts, and in literary analysis. There three things are explored through the course's focus on historiography, and they are handled engagingly and with clarity by Professor Feldherr. Take this course if you have an interest in literature or the ancient world!
Great class to take. It's obvious, but it's essential to read everything in order to get the most out of the class.

I enjoyed this course, and professor Feldherr is a great and engaging speaker. Just keep in mind that, although the course title is "Literature," 3/4 of the material is history. The focus and structure of the course itself is not like a history course (it's not about memorizing names and dates etc), but the actual material is mostly history.
I strongly recommend it to other Classics majors.
I would highly recommend this class to anybody who has an interest in the great works of the classic world, loves history, and is unafraid of a large amount of reading.
I would recommend this course for anyone who is interested in historiography and classical literature.
If you are even considering taking this course, do it! Professor Feldherr is really good, the class is not really hard, and the material is really interesting if you like classics.
Lots of readings. Good class. PDF it
Take this course! but don't get behind in the readings!

This course assigns a LOT of reading.  But Andrew Feldherr is a great lecturer and a very reasonable person, and the preceptors this year were fantastic.  Midterm and Final are straightforward, papers were very reasonably graded.  A really cool class overall, an excellent immersion in the classics, even if you basically only read Sparknotes and the passages you discuss in precept, like I did.

Though the description for reading (100-200 pages a week) sounds extremely daunting, don't let it scare you away from this excellent course on Greek and Roman literature. Due to its breadth, it really is more of an introduction to all kinds of literature, as you don't get to go really in depth. However, the readings are very easy to get through and this class is actually not that demanding with regards to work.
prereqs: No knowledge of Greek or Latin or ancient history is required. This would be an excellent first course on the classical world..
descrip: The historians of Greece and Rome produced some of the most exciting and influential writings to survive from antiquity. This course investigates how and why ancient Greeks and Roman authors represent the past. Substantial selections from the major classical historians, as well as from the epic poets who influenced and challenged them in preserving the memory of great deeds. Emphasis will be less on the value of these ancient texts as sources of information than on how historical writing develops in response to different social and political circumstances. No prior knowledge of Greek or Roman history or literature is required.

title: Experimental Methods in Political Science
descrip: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the theoretical and practical features of natural and field experiments. The course is divided into five sections. The first section will introduce students to the methodological issues. The second and third sections will focus on the design and operationalization of field experiments. The fourth section will introduce students to the analysis of experimental results and related econometrics. The fifth and final portion of the class will be devoted to student research.

title: Applied Quantitative Analysis
reviews: Every politics major should take either this or one of the Econ department econometrics courses. After taking this class you will get so much more out any paper you read in a politics class and you will be equipped with the skills to do high-quality research for your JP or thesis.
Great course for honing your quantitative method skills
If you're unclear on the math, or core concepts, get help immediately!
Marc isn't that great a professor yet but I think next year it will be taught by a different professor so that might be interesting!
Shop it, and if looks interesting, go ahead and take it.

TAKE THIS COURSE!! Ratkovic is amazing, by far the best stats teacher I have ever had. His explanations are extremely useful, and he focuses on application and theory. This course is a must for anyone looking to move beyond intro stats, bulk up on R, and learn valuable analysis tools that can help with JPs and theses.

Take this course if you are interested in a more intuitive understanding of statistics and to improve your skills with R.  Take ECO or ORFE classes to get a more mathematically rigorous and theoretical understanding.
prereqs: POL 345 or equivalent.
descrip: This course provides working knowledge of data analysis using regression models. The course will emphasize connecting substantive questions with real data, thinking through a research question, and presenting results in a compelling manner. Topics include multiple regression techniques, probit and logit models for discrete outcomes, and panel data analysis. Students will learn how to build and analyze a data set. Coursework will involve using R to analyze real data sets.

title: The Ethics of Love and Sex
descrip: An examination of the moral principles governing love and sex. Questions to be addressed include: Do we ever owe it to someone to love him or her? Do we owe different things to those we love? Do we owe it to a loved one to believe better of him than our evidence warrants? What is consent, and why is it morally significant? Is sex between consenting adults always permissible, and if not, why not? Are there good reasons for prohibiting prostitution and pornography? Everyone has opinions about these matters. The aim of the course is to subject those opinions to scrutiny.

title: Princeton Atelier - Sounding Boundaries: Interdisciplinary Alchemy in Music Theater
reviews: Fun class; be prepared to work hard and think outside the box!
If you're the leader type, take the course and see where your creativity leads. If you're not the leader type, you'll learn to be one.
This course is very open-ended and you'll get out of it what you put in.  Great for people interested in combining music with other art forms, like videography and theater.

This course was a really great way to expand the boundaries of what one might consider music performance; every piece that we created started out as being strictly about music, but quickly developed into music-centered performance art, in ways that played uniquely to the strengths of the creators.  It was fun to see the wide variety of projects that came out of a very basic assignment.
This was a fantastic course. I would take it again. There is never ending invention and creative development in a class like this.
prereqs: We encourage vocalists, instrumentalists and composers to apply (a third of the enrollment is reserved for applicants presenting a music-based work-sample) as well as filmmakers, choreographers, directors, dancers, visual artists, writers, etc., also students interested in applying an engineering or computer science background to an art-making process. Students may apply individually or as creative teams of 3. Applications and work sample required. For more information and application, please consult the Princeton Atelier web page princeton.edu/arts/..
descrip: Composer, guitarist and Professor of Music Steve Mackey and director and filmmaker Mark DeChiazza will collaborate on a new music theater work. The course will be an open-ended investigation into new ways of effectively synthesizing composition and performance of music with diverse arts disciplines to create new modes of dramatic expression.

title: Contemporary Chinese Society and Culture
descrip: This course surveys the history, culture, and society of the People's Republic of China from 1949 to the present. Using historical, literary, journalistic, ethnographic, and filmic texts, it seeks to provide understanding of people's lived experiences through recent historical turmoil and contemporary transformations. Apart from covering the impact of major events like the Great Leap Forward, the Cultural Revolution, and the 1989 Tiananmen protests, we will study topics such as memories of socialism, the rise of consumer culture and migrant labor, changes to Chinese families, cities, and popular culture, as well as the role of new media.

title: Special Topics in Investment Science - Trading and Risk Management
reviews: A must do course for anyone interested in teh area of Sales and Trading later.
Absolutely take it if its offered!!

Don't hesitate, if you get the chance to take this course, do so!! Villani is an ass kicker but that is what makes the course so engaging. He will intimidate and inspire you toward greatness (although no one will ever be as great as him).
Don't let this opportunity go: take this course!
I would recommend the course to anyone interested in finance.
If the class is offered again, take the course.
Impressive class, with a superstar. He's able to transmit his passion, you will not forget the class or look at the world in the same eyes.
Many market insights. Worth to take it.
One of the few saviors that make you think that maybe you haven't wasted 40k after all. I learnt a lot. Very good course
Poorly structured class
Take it.
Take it.  It's a great course.
This class is pretty disorganized, but you get exposed to a lot of interesting ideas. Not much work and you get to listen to some cool guest speakers.

This is a great course about trading and risk management. The professor is great and teach a lot of useful tricks we have to consider when we trade. You definitely don't get bored in the classes because the teaching style of professor Villani is really enjoyable. 

I also want to highlight the amazing job of the TA: Samy Jazaerli. He taught the precepts of the course and I have to say that they were breathtaking. He taught us the quantitative aspects of the trades' ideas Professor Villani talked about without neglecting the underlying intuitions. He always covered useful and interesting material. Besides, he didn't just repeat what Professor Villani had just talked about in the regular classes, but he actually added value to the course. He was the most dedicated TA I had in the entire school year. I couldn't have dreamt of a better tutor. He never came unprepared. His slides were outstanding and his explanations were excellent. As an individual who attended all the precepts, I can tell that he spent time preparing them in order to deliver the best explanations he could think of, using appropriate examples and illustrations. Several times, he built pricing and back testing tools from scratch. From a pricing tool to illustrate the risk of prepayment in mortgage-backed securities, to the simulation of a delta-hedging strategy to highlight the importance of transaction costs, to the creation of a delta-gamma portfolio as a refinement of commonly taught replication strategies. I am truly impressed by his dedication and hard work to ensure that students will learn out of his precepts. Professor Dario Villani as the lecturer and Samy Jazaerli as the preceptor was a tremendous combination. 

Unfortunately, Samy Jazaerly won't be the TA in the years to come but hopefully Professor Villani will still be teaching the course.

Those interested in trading must take this course - it's the most useful course that trains you to think like a trader. Seminars were interesting and there were plenty of great speakers (hedge fund managers, sales / traders).
Very good class if you are interested in trading!
Yes of course.
You should take or audit this class.

do NOT take this class as an elective! Auditing is the wy to go. This way you won't have to do the cumbersome problem sets and final year project but still benefit from the lectures with guest speakers.
great course for students who are interested in a career in trading
descrip: The course explores the modelling, measuring and managing of financial risk - i.e., differentiating between a good trade and a bad one. Emphasis will be placed on illustrating the modelling needs and strategies on the buy side vs. the sell side. Practical applications will be drawn from all asset classes. Convexity and time scale considerations will be addressed and risk management will be discussed with respect to RV and macro strategies. Coursework will focus on assessing risk/reward and identifying market opportunities. Entropy techniques and discretization issues will also be introduced. Guest speakers: experts from hedge funds and banks.

title: Archaeology of the Roman Empire
descrip: An introduction to the archaeology of the Roman Empire. Key themes include urban systems and lived experience, economies, agricultural production, resource extraction, trade, the army, and the provinces. Emphasis will be placed on methods of interpreting archaeological data by focusing on key sites and types of material, including hands-on experience with pottery and coins in the collections of the Art Museum. No experience in ancient history or archaeology assumed.

title: Animal Behavior
prereqs: Note that labs are very time consuming..
descrip: The course focuses on the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. Topics include the sensory bases of behavior, how complex behavior such as navigation communication, and learning is organized, social behavior, behavioral ecology, mate choice, cognition, and human behavior. Labs emphasize hypothesis formation and testing, using mammals, birds, fish, and insects. Students taking the lab are excused from precepts.

title: The Bible as Literature
reviews: A really great way to fulfill the LA requirement.  I feel I have a much better understanding of the Bible's history now.
Cool if you want to learn more about the books of the Bible

I loved this class, you find out so many things about the Bible that you might have found so dry and boring. I found new significant points about the Bible, and I appreciated this course for teaching me about them.
I would recommend it HIGHLY.
I would strongly recommend this course

If you have no Biblical knowledge going into this course, it is going to be hard. Most of the other students already knew the Bible inside and out, so I felt like there was a lot the Professor assumed we already knew that he glossed over making it hard to keep up. Make sure to do the reading, even when it's dry, because you will need to be able to do IDs on the final. You also need to attend lecture to do well on the final.
Take the course. D. Vance Smith is awesome.

This class covers about one Biblical book per lecture, hitting all the major ones from Genesis to Revelation.  You'll learn not only the literary specifics about each book, but also how the books relate to one another and how themes develop over time.  There were a paper and a term-identification exam for both the midterm and the final.  If you genuinely want to read and understand the Bible, I'd definitely recommend it.
Unfortunately, the lectures are very bad.
You'll definitely learn a lot about the Bible through this course, especially if you've never read it before.  Just don't expect to be too excited, intrigued, or amused by much of the material.
descrip: This course will study what it means to read the Bible in a literary way: what literary devices does it contain, and how has it influenced the way we read literature today? What new patterns and meanings emerge? This course will examine the structures and modes of the Biblical books; the formation of the canon and the history of the apocryphal or deuterocanonical books; questions authorship; its literary genres; histories of exegesis, interpretation, and commentary; the redaction, division, and ordering of biblical texts; the cultural, political, and intellectual worlds within which these texts were written.

title: Global Air Pollution
reviews: Go to class! Do the readings! and most of all..something we rarely get to do when it's not for a grade requirement...try to participate. You'll get the most out of the class this way.
I would, of course, start the problems sets early, and take advantage of Professor Zondlo's willingness to meet and discuss questions.
If you're looking for a CBE departmental, not a good choice because there are more interesting classes out there.

It's a technical course in a technical subject. A good choice for every environmental engineer, or those in related majors (CHEM, GEO, ENV, MAE) interested in the subject. I would not recommend it as a general interest course, as there is necessary math and chemistry knowledge and the course is not taught to be of general interest.
Take it if you are interested in the subject.
prereqs: CEE 303 or CHM 303/304 or Instructor's Permission.
descrip: Students will study the chemical and physical processes involved in the sources, transformation, transport, and sinks of air pollutants on local to global scales. Societal problems such as photochemical smog, particulate matter, greenhouse gases, and stratospheric ozone depletion will be investigated using fundamental concepts in chemistry, physics, and engineering. For the class project, students will select a trace gas species or family of gases and analyze recent field and remote sensing data based upon material covered in the course. Environments to be studied include very clean, remote portions of the globe to urban air quality.

title: The Literature and Politics of Encounter
descrip: See website

title: Translation Workshop: Spanish to English
reviews: Definitely take it. It will help you improve your own Spanish AND English and you will learn a lot about the Hispanic culture as well.
Good one to take.  Be dedicated to it though.  Read even if not necessary.  Think about your final project.  A lot.
Great course, especially if you are interested in bilingualism. Natasha is a great teacher and the seminars don't seem like they are really 3 hours.
Its great! Really fun and different.
Such a cool class! One of my favorites I've ever taken.

Take it in a heartbeat! Professor Wimmer's great, and very willing to take time to work on your drafts. The guests in the class are wonderful and the hands on translation is very fun. Great class, especially if you like Spanish literature!

This class is great in that it's one of those rare courses at Princeton that both has a very manageable workload and yet teaches you a ton about translation over the semester. Professor Wimmer is great, and it ended up being my favorite class this semester. Take it.
This class was really enjoyable, and a great introduction to the art of translation. Translating is not easy though!
give translation a try!
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. Reading knowledge of Spanish..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the practical act of literary translation and an exploration of the questions that the practice of translation inspires. Subjects of discussion will include style, context, the conventions of contemporary translation, and the retranslation of classics. We will begin with a series of translation exercises. Each student will then select an author and work to be translated as the central project for the class, and embark on the process of researching, contextualizing, and revising successive drafts. Readings and guest speakers will provide additional perspective.

title: Translating East Asia
reviews: If you have any interest in East Asian Studies or how translations are done, take this class! Prof. Kern makes the class exciting, and watching films, anime, and reading stories by Murakami are a plus!

Interesting course, though you should note that it's more about the theory of translation than practical translation itself. The reading load can be a bit long certain weeks, but if you have any interest in East Asia or translation in general, I'd take it.
Take it!

You don't need to be in EAS to enjoy this course. If you've studied Chinese or Japanese, are interested in translation practice, or even just watched/read anime/manga in high school, consider taking this course as an elective.
descrip: Translation is at the core of our engagement with China, Japan, and Korea, influencing our reading choices and shaping our understanding of East Asia. From translations of the classics to the grass-root subtitling of contemporary Anime movies, from the formation of the modern East Asian cultural discourse to cross-cultural references in theater and film, the seminar poses fundamental questions to our encounters with East Asian cultural artifacts, reflecting on what "translation" of "original works" means in a global world where the "original" is often already located in its projected "translation."

title: Landscape Art in China
reviews: Have some readings, movies about Chinese landscape art before attending the seminar will be quite helpful.
This course is great for those who are interested in the topic at hand. It requires a lot of active engagement and participation to make the most of the class, and I highly recommend it.
descrip: A course about Chinese concepts of nature and human nature, theories and traditions of landscape art. Weekly consideration of such themes as replicating and transforming the landscape; submission to/control of nature; landscape as political allegory; pilgrimage and exile; gardens and artists' studios; landscape magic in ancient China; endangered pandas, power dams, and the technology of modern art.

title: Topics in Early Chinese Art and Archaeology - Shang and Zhou Bronzes
descrip: The topic will be Shang and Zhou bronzes, with particular emphasis on technical studies, archaeology, and the application of western art-historical methods to ancient non-western material culture.

title: Water and the Environment
descrip: See website

title: Genetics
reviews: Any MolBio graduate student who can should take Proks from Tom for hundreds of reasons. The part on Eukaryotes was also very good, but might be less relevant to people who are not studying developmental biology.
I would advice a student considering this course to not be afraid to speak up and to meet with other students and discuss the articles before class to get a better understanding of the articles.
I would recommend to future students that you need to plan on keeping up on the readings in order to get the most out of the course.

If one can't express themselves well verbally, answering the professor's question when put on the spot will be challenging. This might lead to being graded unfairly and won't represent the students true engagement with the class.
It is difficult, but worthwhile.  And it is sometimes confusing.
READ READ READ the papers twenty times over.
Take notes in class, will help with take home exams.

The instructors are very good at guiding students through difficult questions to allow them to determine the answer on their own. This class is very helpful, but overlaps a bit with the subjects and readings covered in Developmental Biology.
This course should probably be mandatory for any experimental biologist. Forced participation is scary, but you will benefit from it immensely.
Work hard, be prepared and think clearly.  This class is a lot of work, but well worth the effort.
meet beforehand to discuss the papers with one another. this makes you feel more comfortable in class as you are called on at random.
prereqs: Undergraduates need permission of instructor.
descrip: Classes involve advanced discussions of the genetics and molecular biology of prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms; extensive reading of original research papers is required. Weeks 1-6: Prokaryotic organisms and their associated bacteriophages, topics include the genetic code, mutagenesis, gene regulation and protein synthesis. Weeks 7-12: Genetic tools and logical framework used in research in development, neurobiology, and quantitative biology of multicellular organisms. Examples from Drosophila, C. elegans, mouse and zebrafish will be covered. Topics include mutagenesis, genetic mosaics, transgenics, and knock-in technologies.

title: Japanese Society and Culture
descrip: During the decades after World War II, Japan became the world's second largest economy and a highly educated, technologized society. While Americans once regarded Japan as a land of "corporate warriors," today Japan has become known for its popular cultural critiques of environmental destruction and for a gentler variety of capitalism that has weathered economic downturns while preserving a high quality of life for its people. We explore key social issues in Japan today: the contemporary "birth strike," gender and popular culture, civil society, medical ethics, difference and disability, adolescence and education.

title: Fieldwork Methods (Half-Term)
descrip: This seminar deepens expertise about the logic and application of ethnographic methods by exploring the epistemological and technical issues surrounding ethnographic research, including in-depth interviewing, participant observation, community mapping, and other related strategies. This seminar is most successful when used to advance projects in the early or midway stages of implementation. Alternatively, the course may be used to practice qualitative techniques through exercises not necessarily related to a student's long-term research agenda.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: An ok econ thoery course. I was really interested in the information in the course but it wasn't presented in a very interesting way. Pesendorfer's lectures aren't really helpful (in part because the slides are so good and in part because he just reads them) and many people skip lecture. The psets and tests are based on the slides, not the book (which you could probably make do without). The psets are really annoying because of the no collaboration policy, but they are really well written and a good indicator of your understanding. Because of the no collaboration policy, precepts were useless because they only dealt with last week's stuff, so no one went. The curve is pretty good in the class...
Attending lecture and precept was very helpful for understanding the material. It's very tough to get the same grasp of the topics from just notes.

Be ready to work at least 12 hours a week plus attending lecture in order to do decently.  It is a dry course, but from my understanding it is ultimately more rewarding to take ECO 310 rather than ECO 300 or WWS 300
Bearable.
Cooler than just intro in my opinion, if you're into more rigorous application of math.
DO NOT take this class unless absolutely necessary. Highly disorganized and not very useful.

Definitely, but for a student (like me) who doesn't have a lot of math background, no.
There are a lot of math and engineering majors who take the course because it's "easy," which was not the case I faced.
Do not take this class. It is boring and easy. You will be able to do the problem sets without going to lecture or precept. Since this is the case, what are you paying for?
Do the readings.
Don't take it unless necessary.
Don't take it unless you have to for a distribution or are extremely interested in the subject material
Dont go to lecture
Dont take it unless you have to.
Dont take this unless you need to
Dry, boring material taught poorly.
Good intro to microeconomics.

Great course. Fun. Take it with Pesendorfer, it's really easy to get an A, and very little work. It's probably worthwhile taking this instead of (not after, but in place of) ECO 100, even if you didn't take AP Econ.
I don't know if this is typical for the class, but there was a no-collaboration policy for the homework with Pesendorfer, which I found to be quite aggravating and counterproductive.

I hear this is not a fair representation of Econ courses, but I took it and I hated it, so I'm not doing Econ anymore. The curve is really good, which is the only positive thing about this course. Try to get Doron as your preceptor. You don't need to go to class, ever.
I would recommend this course if you wish to gain a greater, more mathematical experience of economics than ECO100

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who has a firm mathematical background. You learn about how the things you learn in your classes get applied in real-life. I would still recommend if you don't have a strong background, but the semester may be a bit difficult. If you're confident with economics, no worries tho.

I wouldn't recommend because there are more interesting courses in SA to take than this. Unless someone is really interested in economics or getting a finance certificate, there is no need to take this course as I don't find the learning very engaging.
I'd take it if you want to apply some mathematical concepts to other fields.
I'd tell them to know your basic econ and to study up the first week as a solid foundation.
If you are interested in microeconomics and like math this is a great class.

If you are not an Econ or finance person, there is not much reason to take this course.  If you are interested in the subject I would recommend it.  Lectures are a bit dry, but the slides are very helpful in completing pests (warning, be wary of typos).

If you have to take this class for whatever reason its not too bad. Pesendorfer is a good professor, the material is interesting at times, and its not too much work. Just know that there is a really annoying no collaboration policy on problem sets which makes them much more stressful than they need to be.

If you like math and economics, this gives you a good overview of micro theory. If you don't, you won't like it. It's not ridiculously hard, although you'll definitely have to think on the problem sets and exams.

If you're WWS and deciding between WWS 300 and ECO 310, you should probably take WWS 300. I took MAT 175 before this and felt wholly unprepared. You can access the material with MAT 175, but you cannot do better than the other more math-inclined students.
If your just looking for an SA, than don't take this. I assume most people pretty much have to, though, as economics majors or for the finance certificate.
Important for the study of economics, which is an important discipline, so I think that this is a course that many people should take.
It was frustrating to not be able to collaborate on problem sets. Also, DO NOT buy the book.  It is a waste of money and the lecture slides are way better.
It's alright.  Don't buy the textbook if Pesendorfer is teaching, because he doesn't use it.
Keep up with material during the length of the course. Have fun!

Most people in this class are there because they have to take it (econ/finance). For math-track econ kids, this is  the easiest 31X class and will be pretty easy. If you don't have to take it, I would not recommend this class. Didn't really learn much.
Necessary evil if you're a math track econ major or working towards the finance certificate. Otherwise, avoid it. This class doesn't teach you econ at all.
Not too hard, interesting material.  If you like econ and math definitely take it
Nothing on the exams will come from something other than the powerpoint slides, so know them well.
Pay attention during lecture
Pesendorfer is extremely clear in his expectations and explanations, and if you put in the time you will get a lot out of this class.

Pesendorfer is not a bad professor, but he does not make the dry material very interesting. His no collaborating policy was very frustrating. I felt that being able to work with other people on the homework would have been beneficial to understanding the material. Some problem sets are easy, some are harder. I was able to do them without going to lecture, and reading the lecture slides on my own. The instructors were not very invested in the class... Definitely don't take this class unless it's a requirement.
Pesendorfer is the way to go. Exams are curved more than you might think.
Pesendorfer's slides are quite clear; attend lecture, and start the problem sets early.
Review the slides often. If you like micro and a bit of math, take it!
Start the psets early.
Take 300 unless you really like theoretical math and proofs or are getting the finance certificate.
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you have to. I can't say anything about the quality of ECO300, but this was sometimes painful, and sometimes OK.
Take it if you have to. Not a terribly difficult course, but don't expect to stay awake during lectures.
Take it if you need to in the Spring, way better than Abreu and the other class.
Take it in the spring. so much better.
Take the course with Prof. Pesendorfer

Take the course, it is not too hard if you are comfortable with multivariate calculus. The problem sets sometimes get pretty nasty with computation, which is especially crappy because there is a no collaboration policy so you can't check the nasty fractions you get for solutions. However, these don't count for much and the exams/material are pretty straightforward for the most part. It is basically impossible to get below a B (<4% scored in the C range on the midterm) and almost 50% gets some sort of A, so the curve is pretty nice.
Take this class if you need the departmental or the finance rec; otherwise, you should take some other economics class for general interest
Take this class if you need to.
Take this class! It's pretty good.
Take this course if you want to.
Take this course, but try to follow along in lecture.
Take this with Pesendorfer, go to lecture and try to follow along the whole way. Otherwise looking back on the slides later can be confusing.
The course was uninspiring, and the no-collaboration policy on the problem sets was annoying and prevented productive learning of the material.
There are some game theory parts that are fun. Though the concepts may seem obvious in lecture, applying them in psets and exams can be hard

This class is a lot of plug and chug and problem solving. However, if you want to get an A you need to know how to do the plug and chug but MORE importantly UNDERSTAND the concepts intuitively. Re-read the lecture slides before psets, midterms, and finals, and you will rock the course.
This class is kinda annoying.
This class is presented in somewhat of a confusing way, so be prepared to sometimes be frustrated and attend lecture and put in time to understand the lecture slides
This course is tough and not terribly interesting. No collaboration sucks a lot.
This is a course in which you won't fully benefit from what Princeton has to offer.

This is a hard class but it is better taught in the spring with Pesendorfer- so take it then. I think it teaches important material. The math itself is not at all hard-applying it and understanding the concepts is hard- you will never find yourself doing a lot of tedious algebra. The problem sets are hard to do and take time on your own-so start early. Do not lose hope and keep going!
Understand what is on the psets really well.

Wouldn't take it if it's not necessary.
This class should be called "Applications of partial derivatives."
math majors and cos majors could take it.
read the textbook before the class starts and maybe take a proof class too!
take it or don't. you won't be missing out. but if you want to take it, take it with pesendorfer
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT175 or MAT 201. Not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: Ethics and Technology: Engineering in the Real World
reviews: If you need an EM, take it. Could be fulfilled in an easier way though.
It's not a bad choice for an EM. You learn about interesting topics, but the grading felt arbitrary at times.
descrip: This course examines engineering as a profession and the responsibilities of that profession to society. Professional responsibilities of engineers are compared to those of lawyers, doctors, scientists and businessmen. Ethical theories are introduced as frameworks to guide decisions of technology implementation. Simple quantitative decision making concepts, including risk-benefit analysis, are introduced as a method for engineers to make ethically optimal choices.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I
prereqs: CHI 303-304 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion of selections from Chinese scholarly journals and newspapers on contemporary Chinese political, economic, and social issues.

title: Introduction to American Politics, Part I: Political Behavior
descrip: Part of a two-course sequence of the core curriculum in American politics. Provides an introductory survey of American political behavior through a sample of major theories and methods in the study of citizens' views and actions regarding politics. Course begins with consideration of classic studies and proceeds to current works.

title: Who Was the Last Samurai?
descrip: See website

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: Definitely a course worth taking. It's incredible how much Portuguese you can learn in such a small time frame.
Definitely take it if you have any interest at all in learning a new language. This is a perfect course.
Good and fun course
Take it if you want to learn Portuguese, but knowing another romance language makes it a bit boring/promotes laziness
Take the course if you want to learn Portuguese. The language itself is very interesting and the professor is very good. Also, it's not really difficult, but it is interesting.
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature and Culture - Feminist Thought in Twentieth-Century French Literature and Art
reviews: Be opened minded and ready to share your opinions.

It is a phenomenal class! Professor Wampole is a fantastic professor and the subject material is very interesting and relevant to modern-day life. I really enjoyed the class discussions. This is the best French class I've taken at Princeton!
take it!!
prereqs: A 200-level French course or permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course surveys the canonical theoretical writings on feminism in 20th-century France and Francophone countries, including texts by Beauvoir, Cixous, Kristeva, Irigaray, Conde, Wittig, and Tiqqun. Some topics addressed: pornography for women, debates on the veil and the burqa in the public space, the Dominique Strauss-Kahn incident, le manifeste des 343, cosmetics, parity laws, street harassment, maternity politics, queer politics, ecofeminism. We will explore these themes in texts, music, photos, films, and other visual media by Cahun, Nothomb, Darrieussecq, Denis, Djebar, Calle, Ernaux, and others.

title: Linguistic Universals and Language Diversity
descrip: The study of human language from the perspective of linguistic universals. This course will demonstrate that, contrary to initial impressions, languages of the world do not differ arbitrarily and without limit. All human languages share a common core (universals). We must explain why there are linguistic universals and how languages can differ (diversity).

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Be ready to speak in class
Best class for senior spring.

Definitely take it if you're interested in learning how to write poetry. I had no creative writing experience or background and found the course absolutely fascinating.  It's not too much work at all but it's very rewarding when you put in the effort and write a solid poem.
Fun and easy class, especially for engineers who want to diversify their classes a bit.
Go for it!!
Great class if you have a genuine interest in poetry!
I highly recommend any course with Professor Dickman.

I highly recommend this course. The workload is manageable, and the content is enjoyable. Even it you've never written poetry before, the format of the class is comfortable and allows you to learn a lot about writing effectively.
I would reading and re-reading the poems a couple of times.
I would recommend this class to anyone. Everybody at Princeton can benefit from a class which hones one's writing ability and requires creative, critical thinking.
If you want a good and light class, take this class with Paul Muldoon!

If you're even slightly interested in writing poetry, definitely take this course. Its going to be a lot of fun. If poetry is not your thing at all, take it anyway because you won't find an easier LA. You just need to keep in mind the deadline by which you have to apply to get into this course because no one tells you about it.

It won't take too much time but will be great fun. There were people in the class who have the talent to be professional poets someday; there were people who frankly couldn't write a poem to save themselves. Whatever your talent level coming in you can benefit from the class.
It's very laid-back.

Michael Dickman is absolutely amazing and he will get you thinking about poetry, so be open to his suggestions and his "shoves" so that you can unearth some inner poetry rhythms and get the most out of his wonderful instruction! Don't be afraid to explore your own style but also try the suggestions he and your classmates put forth. And write outside of class as much as you can!
Not that much work, but very interesting. Will help your writing, not just in poetry.
Only take it if you want to.
Poetry is super chill; you should take it whether you've had experience or not.
Probably best if you already know something about poetry and discussion.
Professor Dickman is a wonderful, engaging, dynamic artist whose enthusiasm for poetry is infectious.
Professor Smith is approachable and warm and gives very helpful feedback. If you want to surprise yourself and take new risks with your writing, this class is a great environment in which to do so.
TAKE IT
TAKE IT.
TAKE THIS COURSE!! Or any creative writing course at Princeton for that matter.
Take it
Take it if you're interested.
Take it with Michael Dickman if you can! If not...still take it!
Take it with Tracy if you can!
Take it.
Take it; do the weekly readings; come with questions.
Take poetry 202 with tracy k smith!!
Take poetry, but take poetry with Michael Dickman
Take poetry, possibly not with my professor.
Take this class with Professor Dickman! He is the absolute best and super funny. I LOVED this class.
Take this class!  It is a ton of fun and great even if you don't consider yourself a "poet."  Everyone can write poetry, and the professors are awesome.   TAKE IT!

Take this class!  You will have a fantastic time, you will write some poems, you will make some friends who write some poems.  Professor Dickman is the coolest guy around and the whole class is just so nice and stress-free it feels like it isn't even a class at all.
Take this class! It is a lot of fun and helps to stretch your creative muscles. Also, saving it for senior spring is a nice treat to yourself.
Take this course. Take it with Tracy. Trust me.
