This course is amazing. You get out of it what you put into it. It's great to give you an excuse to write poems. You don't have to be good at it at all to really enjoy the class. The work of the other people in your class will be incredible.
YES - if you don't love creative writing you will, if you don't think you could like creative writing and least try creative thinking!
great class! be prepared to workshop a lot of your work which can be intimidating
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing Program application (please visit the program website) by attaching four pages of original poetry or (optionally) a paragraph explaining their interest in the course..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.

title: Introduction to Later Sufism (ca. AD 1200 to present)
reviews: Any remote interest in philosophy? Thinking about Islamic theology? Sufism? Take this course.
Barry is great! Definitely take it.
Best course I've ever taken so far. Barry is excellent. Even if you weren't interested in Sufism, the way he lectures will blow your mind.

If you have any interest in religion whatsoever, are looking for a good EM class to take, or want to hear magnificent lectures, TAKE THIS ONE without hesitation!! It's really fantastic, and you learn so much.

Take it no matter what department you are in.  Traces of Sufi imagery and philosophical influence will begin to surface all over the place in books, movies, and art you see. The things you learn in this class will stay with you forever.
You have to take this class. I'm an Econ major and haven't taken a NES class since high school; even I found this course incredibly interesting.
descrip: Popularized through translations of world famous poets like the 13th century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. The Spring session of this two-term course addresses the overwhelming influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (d. 1240 AD) on all subsequent higher Islamic mystical speculation and poetical literature - as far as India.

title: Latinos in American Life and Culture
reviews: Definitely be note taker. Everything that is discussed in this class is relevant to everyday scenarios, hence it is extremely useful to know these things while also being better prepared for the term assignments.
I would recommend this course to other students. This course isn't originally taught by Edward Telles, so maybe with another professor it would be a bit more organized.
Take it! It's a great Sociology course.
Take it! It's interesting.

This course was very interesting. I would tell other students to take it but I would warn them that if Prof. Telles is teaching it again it may be disorganized and frustrating at times. But overall it was a fun and relatively easy class.
Use it as a gateway to explore key topics in Latino Studies, and to get involved with the program, which is a very worthwhile thing
descrip: This course will consider how Latinos are transforming the United States socially, politically, and culturally even as they themselves change in the process. Topics to be examined include the social and cultural significance of "Latino" or "Hispanic" as an ethnic or racial category, how Latinos fit into the American social system, ethnic and cultural identities, their educational and health outcomes, the implications of the unprecedented geographic dispersal of Latinos, and their growing contribution and impact on mainstream and other types of culture including music, literature, and language.

title: Health Psychology
reviews: Absolutely take this class - interesting material and not demanding or difficult.
Don't take it unless you're really interested in health/medical field
Easy SA pdf class
Go to lecture!! So interesting and so important. Textbook is important but it is a supplement to lecture not a subsitute.
Go to lecture, and you probably don't have to do the reading.
It was a solid departmental. Not too much work, but you do have to put the time in if you want a good grade. Good clear lectures on a wide range of relevant topics.
It's a good course because the material is interesting, but itspresentation could be better.
It's a super easy and interesting class for anyone interested in an upper level psych course or for anyone who is premed!
Memorize away!
Not a bad class, but probably not worth it considering the plethora of good classes you can take here. You ultimately don't learn very much, and the exams are a little trickier than they should be.
Not my favorite Princeton course, but not terrible.
Solid, interesting course. A little bit boring at times, but I'm glad I took it. Pretty easy departmental if you're a psych major.
Take it if you are premed and want a different perspective on medicine.

Take it if you're interested in health behaviors, stress, relationships between patients and doctors, and etc. Material is interesting, and tests are very straightforward and pretty easy (multiple choice   a few short answer).
Take it. Not much work but interesting subject.
Take this course if you want to know more about your health and health of society
Take this course!
Test material comes from lectures. It makes a huge difference going to lectures.
The lecture notes are very important for the test!

The material is very manageable and you will enjoy it if you are interested in psychology and its role in overall health. I really enjoyed it and the workload is manageable if you have other really demanding courses. The best thing to do is take good notes in class, it will help you a lot for exams. I say take it!

This is a very middling psych class. There are a few really interesting tidbits, but the rest of the material is either uninteresting or just intuitive. If you're premed, I suppose this is an okay class to take, but psych majors will find many, many more interesting ones that are more worth their time.

Use the study guides to study for exams. The exams are not too difficult, so it's not difficult to do average, but fairly difficult to do really well. Study the psych studies mentioned in lecture to work towards that A.
take it!
prereqs: One prior psychology course..
descrip: The objectives of this course are to understand the psychosocial processes that influence health and health care delivery. Topics to be examined are the psychophysiological and sociocultural bases of health and illness; pain; adaptation to chronic illness; stress; personality and illness; death, dying, and grief; substance use; health promoting behaviors; patient adherence; physician-patient communication; health care; and medical ethics and utilization.

title: Tropical Biology
reviews: Don't worry about the readings/textbook, and start thinking about projects early. Think of projects that will be easily accomplishable. That is more important than something you're interested in.
Great class! You get to do field work in the rainforest almost every day. If you pick a project that isn't too intensive, then this class is a lot of fun!
Great professor and a solid introduction to tropical rainforest ecology. Nit-picky grader but very knowledgeable.
I would recommend choosing a topic as early as possible, then going through all the possible methods of data collection with Prof Basset so that you can test it out in the field.

In addition to being part of a great program that I HIGHLY recommend participating in, this is a great class of its own merits. However, I would advise you to start thinking about potential projects early on (even before you get there, if possible) to avoid the paper-finishing rush at the end.
It was interesting to learn about tropical biology in this hands on environment.
Make sure to start brainstorming projects early. It really is important to get a head start.

Start thinking about what topic you would like to investigate right away! Organize your data and begin preliminary analysis every night. Commence researching the literature and the writing process as early as possible as it becomes stressful to manage all components of the scientific process individually at the last minute. Ask questions, Yves provides good feedback.
This course will make you a better science writer,
This was a great class. I learned a lot about tropical forests and fieldwork. Just be strategic with your time so that you end up with a paper that you're happy with.
Yves is a tough grader, but he is very nice. Don't let the number discourage you and talk to him about your project.
start on your project early!
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester tropical biology program in Panama..
descrip: "Tropical Biology" is an intensive, three-week field course given at four sites in Panama, examining the origins, maintenance and major interactions among terrestrial plants and animals. The course provides the opportunity to appreciate (1) floral and faunal turnover among four rainforest sites (beta-diversity); and (2) floral and faunal turnover along vertical gradients, from ground to upper canopy, at two rainforest sites (vertical stratification). Students carry out individual projects at the sites. Fieldwork is supported by six orientation walks that introduce participants to common orders and families of plants and arthropods.

title: Mechanics of Fluids
reviews: A good and interesting MAE departmental. Not so bad if you have to take it. Lex is a great lecturer.

As in previous years, the course moves extremely slowly. The lectures are clear and well-presented, but so slow that it becomes incredibly boring. MAE just doesn't seem to care if its students learn much. Problem sets and exams are straightforward applications of the methods learned in class, so almost all of the points off are from (1) careless errors or (2) not solving the problems with the exact methods they teach you (even if the answer is right). Other schools go a lot faster :(
Attend lectures, and spend the time on problem sets
Do the problem sets and keep up, material builds off itself.
Do your homework on schedule, and go to lectures!!! You will do the homework in half the time and won't necessarily have to read the textbook.
Go to precept! It will make the problem sets much clearer. Also, start the problem sets early, and read the textbook ahead of time.
Go to the precepts.
Great class, you learn a lot
Have fun taking this course!

I enjoyed it. The grading on some assignments was excessively harsh but overall, I think it was a really enlightening experience. That being said, do be honest with yourself about whether or not you're actually going to make it to 10 AM lecture. And if you do take the course...

********ALWAYS DRAW THE CONTROL VOLUME ON THE PSET/EXAM QUESTIONS******

If you're considering this course, it's probably because it's required. This is the easiest of the MAE departmentals you will take sophomore year so it's not much of a drag. Watch out, because the problem sets do eventually get ahead of the lectures, but it's still reasonable.

It is what it is. Preceptors were especially picky and took off points for little things such as not referencing where you got a physical constant from, such as the density of water. Exams were fast-paced but easy. However, if you are not strong in basic calculus, you are screwed - those students were the ones who probably got all the Cs. :(
Just make sure you can do the problem sets and you'll be prepared for the exams.
Make sure to do past exams. Read the book. For the final, go through all the problem sets and budget your time well because it is loooong.

Not going to lie, this course is easy.  It's the easiest departmental/required-pre-engineering course I've taken so far here.  And for those who strongly dislike the "memorize equations and plug and chug" methods of learning, you will strongly be displeased.  Yet for those looking to understand the straightforward basics for fluids without taking on too much of a load, it's great.  And because the lecturer, Professor Smits, is very engaging, the course is interesting even though it's easy.  For those in MAE, remember that you will most likely take this course simultaneously with MAE 206 and MAE 224, two courses which DO NOT use the "plug and chug" method and are much more abstract and challenging, so this course actually becomes a nice relief in a way.  You may be bored at times (i.e. the problem sets sometimes are so easy the preceptors have to separate students by taking off points for mislabeling graphs), but in my mind, the easy is good and Professor Smits is worth the time you put in.

Pay attention in lecture and use the worked examples in the textbook. They really help. Also, be careful in your problem solving--as with any physics class, questions get more and more complicated, and you need to keep your notation, axes, and other conventions clear to avoid absurd answers at the end,
Pay attention to your work. Draw control volumes. Small points add up.
Pretty interesting class, best sophomore MAE course in my opinion.  Pretty easy if you just do the psets.  Harsh curve though.
Probably one of the easiest MAE courses sophomore year. But that means that everyone does well.
Read the book and go to precept if you want to be able to do the homework.
Still only take if it is a requirement.
Take this course if you are interested in a good introduction to hydrostatics and simple fluid flows.

Textbook is all you'll need for almost all of the problems, and Smits is an excellent lecturer! Know all your assumptions and write down everything: coordinate systems, control volumes, etc. and you'll get all the points.
The course is taught in a very application-based fashion; the material is also very interesting
The courseload isn't too heavy. The first 4 chapter does have a bit of work behind them, but the psets become much easier afterwards.
This course is great! Good teachers, manageable workload, interesting material. I really enjoyed it though I guess you need an interest in fluids already to find it interesting.
This is a great course that is straightforward, well taught and interesting. It is also not very time or energy intensive.

This is a very interesting course and Professor Smits is an engaging lecturer. Problem sets are very manageable, although there is sometimes a down curve on midterms. If you're interested in introductory Fluid Mechanics, take it.
This is actually a great fluids class, and if you're interested and not in MAE, I would still recommend it.
This might be the one course in MAE I've taken so far that I would recommend to a non engineer.
Very important course for MAE. The subject is abstract, but it's necessary to know. Take this course to get a foundation in fluids, which is critical for the department.
Well taught, not too hard
You have to take it anyway.
You have to take it, so why are you asking me?
prereqs: MAT 104 and MAT 202. MAT 202 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Introduction to the physical and analytical description of phenomena associated with the flow of fluids. Topics include the principles of conservation of mass, momentum and energy; lift and drag; open channel flow; dynamic similitude; laminar and turbulent flow.

title: Fans and Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Mathematics in Engineering I
reviews: A better class than people try to claim. Really feel like I did learn a lot about solving differential equations.
Differential equations are incredibly useful, so if you are an engineer or a scientist, you should take this class.
Don't take this course with Kostin
Easier than Stone's MAE 305 class. The quizzes are reasonable. Just read over class notes and don't bother reading the textbook.

Easy if boring and dull. You probably don't have a choice if you're taking it as an engineer since it satisfies a MAT3XX level requirement. If you actually like/don't completely suck at math I've heard Stone's class in the fall is infinitely better.

Easy with Kostin - dont learn nearly as much as with Stone though (I usually don't care about that but actually kind of frustrating in this case). No midterm and all the quizzes / problem sets have very small grade distributions so you have no idea what your grade is going into the final
Fairly straightforward class. Keep up with material, otherwise you can get overwhelmed at the end.

From what I've heard, this class is great in the fall with Howard Stone.  If you need to take it, try to take it then.  He provides you will all of the notes that you will need.  Kostin provides you with nothing, not even a practice exam.  And the pop quiz system is stupid.
Go over the problem set problems as practice so that you can understand them and so that you can do them quickly.

Go to class and take good notes.  First half of the semester is deceptively easy and going to class is not useful. Then it gets hard and you need class notes to study for the final, which comes directly from those notes.
Go to the AI hours.
Great 300-level math class. Solving differential equations is a useful skill.

I think this class is well taught. Obviously you need to go to lecture because all the quizzes and the final come from things we covered in class. It's hard to judge how you're doing in the class because there is no midterm and a 50% weighted final so you also need to make sure you keep up with the material throughout the semester

I truly enjoyed the class.  It would probably be helpful to take this class with at least one friend to be able to talk through certain information that is difficult for you to understand on your own.
I'm really glad I took this course
If Kostin teaches again, I recommend taking MAE305 with him

If Professor Kostin is teaching again, then you should attend all the lectures and do the best you can to what he teaches. Go to his office hours since it they are very helpful and there are no precepts and the TAs are not informed as to what is being taught so are not helpful. The final and quizzes are straight forward and the homework is from the book. Learn the material from the notes given in class though.
If you want to learn about differential equations, then it is a solid option. Not the most interesting material in the world, but it is well taught and pretty useful.
It is an easy 300-level math course, but I wouldn't take it if you don't actually need it. Huge emphasis on the final (50%), so be prepared for that!
It's a chill course.
It's a little boring if you aren't interested in applied math, but it's a very good course if it's a requirement.
It's an excellent introduction to solving differential equations, although I believe Prof. Kostin is retiring after this semester.
It's no wonder this class is required for engineers. Attend lecture and put in time on problem sets
Keep all your homeworks and sit close during lecture.

Kostin has a very straightforward approach to presenting the material, which suited me well. I also liked the periodic quizzes compared to the traditional midterm. If you're really interested in applications for engineering you might prefer taking it with Stone.
Kostin was really nice and thorough. It's a shame he's retiring. I think the course might be pretty different with the new teacher.
Kostin's class is not very coherent or useful. Take it with Stone in the fall if possible.
Listen to what he says while he's writing because he always stands right in front of what he wrote on the board, making it impossible to copy down.
Make sure you understand his lectures because the book is almost useless. find him and go to his office hours if you dont understand something or else you are dead in the water.
Only take if it is a requirement.
Only take it if you have to
See if you can find the book's explanations to match up with what Kostin says.
So much easier than Stone's class!
Stay on top of the work and make sure you can follow the lectures thoroughly.
Straightforward course. Take it if you're not looking for any surprises, and would like to learn some applications of math. Less hard if you've taken some more advanced math before (like orf 309).

Take if required (but you already knew that didn't you?). Do not take if you are a math person (meaning if you want proofs and actual explanations for things, since Kostin does maybe 1 or 2 'proofs' the entire semester).
Take it if you must. Especially the ORF and CBE and MAE kids. The quizzes and hw are all super easy, but be warned THE CURVE IS HARSH!
Take it in the spring with Kostin.
Take it!
Take it! Sad that Prof. Kostin won't be teaching it anymore. He was amazing.

Taking diffeq spring semester with Kostin was way better than people made it seem. If anything, comparing to what friends did with Stone, this seems like the easier version of 305. Kostin is old school, but a good lecturer.

The course seemed to be of a similar difficulty to the other math classes I've taken (104, 201, and 202).  If you put in the effort, I think you can get a good grade.  I've heard that Professor Stone tends to receive better reviews than Professor Kostin, but that his version of the class teaches more and is much more difficult.
This class was great. Professor Kostin was one of the best lecturer's I've had the pleasure of listening to, although if he's retiring this year, I'm not sure who will teach it next year.
This course is rather dry. Not too much work, but some of the material can be kind of difficult though.
This was a tremendous class. It was not too difficult, and it was incredibly well taught.
Though the course is good, I don't see why you would take it unless you are really interested or it's a departmental. The workload is average.

Very good course for diff eq - practical yet enlightening. Apparently it's a lot easier than the fall version, so I recommend taking it in the spring with Kostin. You learn all that you need to know as far as differential equations are concerned in science engineering, and it's actually fun. Kostin is the man!
Very manageable class. The problem help session are extremely useful and the TAs and very good as well.

Whether or not you're not taking it with Stone in the Fall, make sure you get a copy of his notes. I felt infinitely more comfortable with the material once I had read through through them start to finish.
You're probable taking this because it's required, go to lecture, it's definitely helpful

You're probably taking it if you have to. Even otherwise, it's not bad at all. I tried to take it in the Fall because a lot of people said Prof. Stone is much better. While that might be true, I am very satisfied with Prof. Kostin's style of instruction and the class in general.
easy class.
prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 and MAT 202 or 204.
descrip: A treatment of the theory of differential equations. The objective is to provide the student with an ability to solve problems in this field.

title: General Chemistry II
reviews: 207 Prepared very well for this
Aaaaaaa. You're probably taking this course because you have to. If so, you're not gonna die but it's not great, either. If you don't have to, don't take it.
After taking CHM 201, relax, breathe, and jump into the material. It'll come naturally.
After this first year with the new professor, I think the class will be a lot better. We just happened to be the first group to go through it.
As compared to other general ed requirements, it's not too bad.
Avoid it at all costs.
Be ready to put in the most work on the problem sets and this will help you on the midterms/exams

Chan is the best! He is such an incredible lecturer. The course itself is alright. As a pre-med you must get through it -- while it is not impossibly difficult it does require a good portion of time and effort to get an A, I would say.
Chances are, you have to. Use the book to review, have fun in lab, and get to know your preceptor.

Chem 202 is a great course, and much better than Chem 201. I highly recommend the class to other students who have taken chemistry, especially if they are unsure if they wish to continue their chemical education.

DO NOT TAKE GEN CHEM IF YOU CAN PLACE OUT WITH AP CREDIT. That being said, it's not a badly-taught class. If you have to take it, you'll take it. If it's not a requirement, but you're interested in chemistry and you haven't taken AP Chem, you should take it.
Definitely talk to TAs and people in McGraw as soon as you are confused.
Do not take if you don't like chemistry. The class covers a lot of material and it is easy to fall behind if you do not stay on top of your work.
Do your work. Study.
Don't be afraid to approach professors and preceptors to ask for extra help.

Don't take it unless you have to. If you're interested in chemistry, there are better courses to try it out. If you've already done well in chemistry, there are more advanced courses that are more suitable. If you need an STL, there are more fun and interesting courses available. If you're pre-med, I'm sorry. Go to lecture, unless Rob is lecturing. Shop precepts -(Brian is excellent). Keep your labs in order so they're ready for the lab exam. Start your problem sets early.
Don't take this course looking for an easy A because you won't get one.Then again it's probably a prereq anyways if you're reading this review, So go on and give it your all!

GO TO OFFICE HOURS - they are very helpful and definitely not taken advantage as much as they should be!! Review problem sets for the exam. Spend a good amount of time on practice exams and, since they dont give out an answer key, don't be afraid to bug RPL for the answers!!
Get a good preceptor and lab TA as much of what you learn about chemistry will be from them.
Go to McGraw as much as possible for help on problem sets as the tutors will help explain the problem solving techniques better than preceptors and lecturers.
Go to lecture, go to McGraw, stay on top of the material because it all builds on previous material.
Go to lecture, go to precept, study, relax, and you'll do great!
Go to lecture, read the book, do practice problems in the book.
Go to lectures, do the problem sets. The professors are great, and there are so many resources to help you do well.

Go to precept!  And lecture.
For exams - the best preparation is going over homework and reading the textbook.
Go to precepts. They're so helpful
Go to the problem set review sessions!
Go to the resource hours
Go to the review sessions.
I did fairly well during the most of the course. I probably would have pulled a B , if it weren't for the final. :(
I recommend this course to students who need it for their major or who are interested in attending medical school.
I would advise them to do the textbook reading and make sure they utilize the resource center, mcGraw, and review sessions if they are confused.

I would advise them to pay attention to the work they turn in and make sure to collect it once it is returned to you. Oftentimes it can get lost and those things are really helpful when it comes to exams. Building a relationship with TAs is always good because it will be easier to come to them with any questions you may have.
I would recommend going to every lecture, every precept, every review session and reading every chapter and completing every homework assignment. The more that you do, the better your grade.
I would recommend that another student spend time working on the problem sets and to take good notes on lecture (also supplement your knowledge with the information in the textbook).

I would suggest this course but only to students who are genuinely interested in chemistry or have to take it as a requirement. But be warned, it is not an easy class and nothing like high school chemistry.
I wouldn't take it for fun, but it's a fine course
I wouldn't take this course unless you have a specific reason for doing so. If you put in the work and keep up with the course, then you can definitely do well.
If you are considering Pre-med, you must take this course. If you were in Chem 207, you might have to catch up on some topics that were not covered in Chem 207.

If you are interested in science, definitely take it. Of course, you can't take this course without having taken CHM 201 or CHM 207. It is less time consuming than CHM 201 in terms of the labs. I finished all the labs way before 4:30pm.
If you are not premed, or obsessed with chemistry,  I wouldn't highly recommend it.
If you do all of the problem sets and go to class you should do very well in the class.
If you enjoy chemistry at all, but don't have an AP credit, definitely take this course.  It was a good experience and I continued to learn a lot.
If you enjoy chemistry, take it and have a ball! If not, God bless your soul.

If you have any interest in chemistry definitely take it. Gen Chem 2 in my opinion is a lot more interesting  and enjoyable then Gen Chem 1. So if you are deciding whether or not to finish Gen Chem, I recommend taking this course.
If you have to take it as a pre-req, it's definitely one of the more enjoyable sciences. If you're not really into science though I wouldn't recommend it since it can get very difficult.

If you like science and chemistry, take it! Out of all of the general science courses I have taken at Princeton -- I have taken Mol 214, EEB 211, and Phy 103/104 -- this has by far been my favorite.  I would even recommend it to students who need an STN that interesting because if you get stuck you can't get help! which isn't always possible in Neuro, psy, or geo or other classes that give you stn distribution credit.

If you need the course for a departmental requirement or are generally interested in chemistry then it is a good class to take. If you aren't much of a science person then I don't think this class is for you.
It gives you a broad introduction to chemistry - if that's what you want/need, take it!

It is a good class to take, and it is not too difficult. The labs were interesting. The course covers a lot of information though, so keep up with the readings. Sometimes the topics seemed scattered and random.

It is a necessity to take this course for any type of pre-med, chem, major, or some types of engineering. Other students will not find it particularly engaging but more of a task that needs to be completed.
It is worth getting through Chem 201 if you didn't like it just to take Chem 202. I felt like I actually understood more of what we were learning and why different principles worked.

It's a gen chem course, but that shouldn't mean you should take it lightly. Granted, AP chem would have been much more manageable, but as a Princeton science course, this will challenge you. If you can, get Brian S. for a TA.

It's an introductory chem class and that's what you get.  There's nothing phenomenal about it but it teaches you what you need to know.  Outside of taking it for pre-med or a pre-req then I wouldn't really recommend it unless you're interested.
It's an ok course.

It's good considering it's required for almost all who take it, but there are probably better options if you just need to fulfill an STL. The professors and (most?) of the TAs are very helpful. Also, RPL's a sweetheart at heart.
Its very different from Chemistry 201.
Keep up with the material!  Getting behind makes it almost impossible to catch back up.
Keep up with the reading and do the problem sets!
Keep up with the reading, do practice problems, get to know your profs, and go to class (no posted slides).
Keep up with the readings and go to the resource center.
Make sure you take advantage of the precepts and labs and really try and understand what's going on in each.

Not a particularly exciting course if you do not engage yourself in thinking about chemistry in a broader context. Do the textbook readings to solidify knowledge of the material and you will be golden. If you already have AP chem, you should probably take orgo, or a higher level chem class.
Only do it if your premed, otherwise you could take a way more interesting class.
Practice!
Prepare for the final.

Professor Chan is a great and energetic lecturer who will make the subject matter interesting and entertaining. Professor L'Esperance is also an exceptional lecturer, very clearly and succinctly presenting the material. Labs are a great way to get hands-on experience, but you will be primarily doing titrations.
READ THE BOOK. and go to RPL for help.
RUN. Justing kidding, not too much more difficult that 201. The material is a little more tough but it's the same pace as the first semester.
Read from the textbook and work through their examples before class. You'll be fine.
Read the textbook chapters before the lectures.
Read the textbook when studying for exams.
Read the textbook. Understand the concepts. Also make sure to go over the previous year's exam for the lab written. Not being ready for that test can really screw you up.
Recommended
Recommended if you need it as a prerequisite for a major.  If you can place out of it with AP credit, however, then definitely do that.
Stay on top of the material all the time. The class goes quickly.
Study hard. Learn from Young Hoon Kang and Dowon Dan Kim and make you understand the qualitative stuff  in the beginning.
Study often, work with peers, attend all lectures.
Take it
Take it if you have to.  Do the readings and go to precept.
Take it if you have to.  If you don't, take it if you were good at Chemistry in high school.
Take it if you have to. If you don't, it's really not that interesting.
Take it, It's very easy and doesn't take up much time.
Take the problem sets seriously and get as much help on them as you can. They really help you understand what was taught in lecture.
Take this class, it is better than 201 (though not as good as 207) and get Brian as your preceptor!
Take this course, but read the textbook and don't go to lecture.  No need to.
Take this course. The professors are interesting and helpful. The workload is manageable. There are also endless opportunities to get help on problem sets, lab reports, and exams if you need it.
The course is fine if you keep up with the coursework each week.  Even though I took this class as a pre-med requirement, it didn't feel like a requirement because the class overall was so enjoyable.
The final exam is a killer!

This class is a requirement for many departments and for the pre-med track. It is not the best-taught course or the most interesting, but it serves the general purpose of a gen chem intro course. Take this course if you are genuinely interested in chemistry (as in you might major in it) or if you have to for a major or pre-med. Otherwise, there are probably more interesting specialized science classes to take that are more personal and positive (this shouldn't be your STL). On the plus side, the labs aren't that bad and are actually pretty cool.

This class was the central focus of my semester. I spent hours working on it, yet still couldn't score above average on tests. It's extremely challenging. If you can place out of it or take it at another school, definitely consider doing that.

This course is a necessary to complete the gen-chem sequence.  A lot of it is repeated from 207, so that makes things easier.  Doing the homework (which counts as an exam grade) and going to precept is definitely helpful.  Ask questions, and they will be answered.  Go to lecture too, especially for Chan, who tends to embellish and add information.
You get what you put into this class.  Do all the problem sets thoroughly and make sure you understand each and every concept.  Be proactive in your learning
You should take this course if you're considering any major in the sciences.

You're likely taking this course as some sort of requirement, but it is well taught and fairly graded. Make sure to keep up with the problem sets, and use the readings in the book when studying for exams.
You're probably taking this class as a pre-req. Just be sure to come to the Garnet Chan lectures - you'll enjoy them.
keep along with readings
read the textbook.
take it if you have to
take this course if you have any interest in pre-med/chemistry/love science
prereqs: This course is a continuation of CHM 201; also open to CHM 207 students. Students must have an AP score of at least 4,
descrip: Continuation of 201. Principles of chemistry; introduction to chemical bonding and solid state structure; chemical kinetics, descriptive inorganic chemistry; laboratory manipulations, preparations, and analysis. Fulfills medical school entrance requirements in general chemistry and qualitative analysis. Three lectures, one class, one three-hour laboratory..

title: Image and Imagination
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Seminar in Medieval Art - Medieval Image/Concepts of Authenticity
descrip: The course examines the notion of the authentic in conjunction with medieval images. It investigates the construction, reception, and theoretical grounding of authenticity of reliquaries, icons, and imprints on cloth or seals. These objects elucidate the shift from mimesis towards other artistic strategies (stylization, abstraction, bricolage). Rather than studying different modes of representation, we will focus on the very validity of representation in the Middle Ages and approach this issue from the viewpoints of history, anthropology, philology and visual studies.

title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
reviews: Do NOT overthink or work yourself too hard for this class--it's not worth it and you'll just give the professors more room to criticize your work. Extra effort rarely gets rewarded so just keep things neat and simple.
Do not structure your class schedule around the schedule of a desired partner - you will be assigned one.
Don't procrastinate on the lab reports or oral presentations ESPECIALLY if your particular lab is heavy on data analysis.

First off, some of the changes to core lab were good. There are fewer written/oral reports, for one thing. But your core lab experience will probably depend on your TAs, so hope that you get good ones. We were extremely lucky in that regard. Realize ahead of time that they may assign partners. Some people ended up with great partnerships and others got completely screwed over. Unfortunately, there's not much to be done about that. Overall, core lab could have been a lot worse. Lack of communication between the faculty and the TAs/students really got the semester off to a bad start. Hopefully that is improved in future years.
I don't think many students are in a position where they have a choice of whether or not to take this course.
If you are a CBE, you have to take this course but don't dread it too much. The course is a lot of work but you will learn a lot and get a lot of personal attention from professors and TAs.
It's a departmental and a lot of work, but be optimistic.
Meh. Does it matter what I say?

NOT as bad as I was expecting. Obviously a large part of that has to do with the reduction in the number of assignments, so I guess it depends on what they decide to do next time. Before you have to turn in a lab report or give an oral report, definitely talk to your AI or assigned professor about any questions you have, ask for their advice, don't just turn it in and see what happens -- there are so few grading opportunities that you really want to make sure you know what you're doing. The in-lab portion itself is very doable, and three hours usually passes very quickly.

Not as bad as it sounds. Rewarding class, though it does take a lot of time, especially when the written reports are due. Stay on top of things, analyze data as you go along, and work well with your partner!

Prepare yourself, core lab is coming. This course will make it plain that the faculty in this department DO NOT CARE ABOUT YOU. We are a nuance to them and because of that they will use this course to make you hate your life and they will laugh at your pain. If you go into this course knowing this, knowing that they will waste 90 minutes of your time every Monday, knowing that they will miss read the name tag that they force you to wear for 12 weeks (oh your name is Sarah? Prepare to be called Sassafras for the foreseeable future), knowing that you will be forced to answer ridiculous and tedious questions during your oral presentation as if you were presenting to 7th graders at a performing arts school rather than 3 Ph.D's, you will spend much less time ranting. Do not use this time you saved working, you'll be up all night at the end of ever cycle regardless, use this time to LEAVE THE EQUAD. Get out whenever you can. Run, don't walk. If you must walk do it quickly. You will spend so much time on this course only to have the professors pick you apart because of the color scheme you used on your powerpoint presentation that those few precious moments that you can spend away from this class, this major, and that building will be like an extra cloak beyond the wall.
Start early on the reports. Pay attention to minor details and formatting issues.
Take it only if you must
Too late now.
Well, it's a requirement. Don't slack, hopefully you can choose your partners.
You have to take it, but it is tons of fun. Enjoy the experience and try to learn as much as possible.
keep up on data analysis-don't save everything for the end. and meet with the tas and professors-they're willing to help
prereqs: CBE 246 and CBE 341 or equivalents..
descrip: An intensive hands-on practice of engineering. Experimental work in the areas of separations, heat transfer, fluid mechanics, process dynamics and control, materials processing and characterization, chemical reactors. Development of written and oral technical communication skills.

title: Intermediate Hebrew II
reviews: I would absolutely recommend taking it. Morah Esther will only be here for one more year.
I would encourage students interested in Hebrew to take this course.
If you are interested in learning Hebrew, then this course will provide you with ways to do so.
TAKE THIS COURSE. It's very easy if you just want a good grade, and it's very helpful if you really want to take advantage of all the materials Morah Esther gives you.
Take this course. Esther is fun, interactive, and brings interesting material to class constantly.
prereqs: HEB 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Completion of two-year textbook, Ha-Yesod, and reading and discussion of selected additional texts (newspaper, stories, poems, etc.) Extensive practice in conversation, writing and reading and tasting Hebrew literature.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Graduate Seminar in Biomedical Engineering
reviews: A great way to learn about the cutting edge of bioengineering research, even if you don't have a strong background in biology.
I loved this course--one of my favorite at Princeton. If you're interested at all in bioengineering, take this class!
This is the best class for Engineering students who are interested in bio-medical research.

best course at princeton. extremely interesting, survey into many different advanced topics in bioengineering, casual atmosphere. there's no work or tests but you'll end up learning a ton just for learning's sake.
take it! no work, just take it purely out of interest
descrip: The seminar will introduce current research in biomedical engineering to graduate students who have no or little background in the field. Its goal is to enable graduate students in science and engineering fields to assess how their research interests may mesh with current biomedical research. The seminar will begin with an introduction to the fundamentals of biomedical engineering, and then cover drug discovery and biomedical devices; micro and nanofabrication for smart materials; from DNA to cells/organs/tissue; disease control; electrophysics and electrical injury; and case studies.

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: Be prepared to participate in class. That's how you'll be able to get the most out of your experience.
It is fantastic, gets you speaking, teaches about different cultures, and is a lot of fun! Take it!

Take this class. It's intriguing, fun, and super interesting. The work load isn't overwhelming, and it's a nice break from the traditional SPA 108. It's just as valuable, too. In general, the language courses at Princeton are extremely well taught, but the content in this course is really relatable and enjoyable. This class features great films that you might not have been introduced to otherwise.
This is a great course to take if you're thinking about going into higher level classes or obtaining a certificate. It's a step above the intro classes but it's very doable and it's very fun.
What you heard is true, take the class if you can! Good movies, great professor (no matter who you have, I've heard they're all great), and a really reasonable amount of work.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission); or SPA 108; or SPA 207..
descrip: Spanish 209 is a course designed mainly to improve your speaking abilities while learning about Hispanic cultures and cinema. Moreover, throughout the semester there will be several writing exercises that will help you to improve your writing abilities. Every movie will be discussed in class. Additionally, each student will watch a supplementary film. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of all their linguistic skills, especially listening comprehension and speaking.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Every student in Science and Engineering major should take this course.
It is a required course, but the instructor does a good job of making the material interesting.
My advice to other students would be to participate more; the course is much more interesting as a discussion session than as a seminar.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Introduction to Swahili Culture
descrip: This is an introductory course to Swahili culture. You will learn who the Swahili people were and who they have become, who they are not, and what the term 'Swahili' may refer to. This is a multidisciplinary course that will be sourced from different texts, newspapers, booklets, films, music videos, pictures, guest presentations, handouts, web sites, and a taste of Swahili cuisine. Through these you will get a bird's eye view of the East African people as well as some other Swahili speaking groups and their cultures.

title: Introduction to Engineering Dynamics
reviews: Be prepared to give this course some loving devotion. It will be well worth it!
Be ready for a lot of time and effort to be put into the assignments and take home exams but the payoff is worthwhile. Always go to lecture!
Chances are, if you're looking into this course, you have to take it. Rest assured, Kasdin is one of the best professors you will have and this class will be manageable if you stay on top of it.
Departmental. The workload is kind of high to be taking it just out of general interest. It's basically a more advanced and powerful version of PHY 103.

Do your best to do the reading before class. But actually. It makes a huge difference and you will understand the material better and will thus be better at completing the problem sets. Professor Kasdin is a great teacher provided that you put in the time into the course and ask him good questions. Brace yourself for the last week of the course when things get very difficult.

Don't be afraid to solve problems the long way, you do the same amount of work in the end. Just work out the problems, you can't predict all the nuances in a problem before going through all the steps. Do some problems before lecture or they will offer you little that will stick with you.
Everything builds on the previous chapter so make sure you stay up to date on material. But you can learn a lot if you pay attention.
Find a problem set group!
Find precept help.
Get a study group. Start the psets early. Go to lecture. Realize that the exams are also basically just psets. Everyone is an MAE major.

Go to lecture. Go meet Kasdin and ask him lots of questions! Do problem sets diligently and read the book. It is a great class and everything that moves starts making a lot more sense after you take dynamics.
Good and well-taught class.
If you thought physics 103 was hard you're in for a treat... starts out pretty manageable but gets to be very difficult towards the end.

If you're interested in Dynamics, take this course! It is an MAE requirement, but Professor Kasdin is one of the best professors I have ever had and knows how to teach this material very clearly and solidly. It is a challenging course, but it is highly worth it.
Make sure you read the book. It is crucial unless you want to try to learn everything while you're doing the homework or taking the exams.
N.A.
Only take if it is a requirement.
Read as much as you can ahead of time. It is extremely difficult to catch up if you fall behind. It can take a while to get through chapter with a full understanding of the material.
Read the book
Read the book and stay up on the chapters or you will find the class extremely awful and the lectures a waste of time

Read the chapters before lecture, because he really leans on the assumption that you have read, also, dont attempt the problem sets on your own, go through them, figure out a way to try to solve each problem early in the week, and then go to office hours and ask them if that is the right way to go about it. otherwise when you get stuck, you will extend a problem set by 2 or 3 hours, for a problem set that already takes 5-7 hours to do.
Stay on top of material.  Do the readings. Pretty hard class, did not really enjoy it.
Such a great course! Awesome professor, well-written textbook and very interesting problems in psets!
Take it - you will have much better developed physical intuition and problem solving ability by its completion. And...WORK IN GROUPS! Or you will be miserable.
Take it if you have to. Otherwise, I do not recommend it.
Take it only if you have time to spend on it.
Take it, because you actually learn about physics using vector calculus...aka the right way. It's extremely challenging, so be prepared for late nights and a lot of frustration. But it's rewarding.
Take it.
Take it. Professor Kasdin is SPECTACULAR and the variety of physical problems, occurring in our world, that you end up being able to solve for are fascinating.

There is ALOT of algebra in this course - but if you push through it, you'll eventually get to the right answer. Don't give up on the questions, especially towards the end of the course with 3-D motion.

This course can be challenging, but never in an egregious way.  Kasdin's lectures are always engaging and his love and passion for the material can help fuel any of yours as well.  Plus, his textbook is there for any questions that aren't answered in class, yet is NOT an absolute, must-spend-10-hours-reading-or-I'll-fail necessity.  Following the trend, homeworks and exams are fair, though can be time consuming and some problems can be tough.  Yet when I say tough, it is in a way that makes sense and DOES NOT come out of left field, which is a very good thing.  Though most who take this take it as a departmental requirement, those who don't should look into it, to experience Kasdin's lectures alone.  For those in MAE, don't be worried.  At times it's hard but it's actually kinda fun.
Unless you are very good at math and have/want to take this class, I'd avoid it if possible.
Work with friends on problem sets, bounce ideas off each other. Study hard, and always start your work early.
use office hours. i personally haven't, but the professor is very friendly the one time i went and really helped me understand the subject matter. read the textbook, sit near the front in lecture.
prereqs: MAT 201 and PHY 103 and MAE 223 or CEE 205. Freshmen may take the course with the instructor's permission..
descrip: Formulation and solution of equations governing the dynamic behavior of engineering systems. Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics. Two and three dimensional kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies. Motion relative to moving reference frames. Impulse-momentum and work-energy relations. Free and forced vibrations of mechanical systems. Introduction to dynamic analysis of mechanical devices and systems.

title: American Art and Visual Culture - Picturing Limits in American Art & Visual Culture
reviews: Highly recommended, not a lot of work.
Take it.
definitely take the class
descrip: This course considers the myriad ways that artists and other image-makers from a range of disciplines, including the sciences, have confronted limits in the production of visual form, including limits of visibility, perception, space, time, medium, and species. We will explore the strategies by which limits are provoked, articulated, or suppressed in images, from visual articulations of the prehistoric past, including the world's first artistic renderings of dinosaurs, to images of animals, the earth's origins, evolutionary and geological change, and pre-modern peoples.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research II has to be taken before the General Exam.

title: Popular Music in Japan from the 19th Century to the Present
reviews: A great course that looks at all types of Japanese music (don't expect just J-pop)  The final paper allows you to study whatever facet of Japanese popular music you want.
Definitely take this class if you are interested in Japanese music, or just need a distribution requirement. The professor is very nice and always helpful.
Interesting seminar. Fair bit of reading/work but a pretty juciy topic and self-directed term paper.
Read all of the readings and listen to the audio clips. Participation in class also really helps you better grasp the information.
Technical music knowledge or skill is not necessary for this class, but if you don't have it you will need  a background in Japanese culture or social analysis.

This is a very fair class. Professor Manabe cares greatly about mutual respect and as long as you provide genuine thought and show enthusiasm and effort in weekly responses, papers, and class discussion you will do just fine in this class. As long as you do most of the readings and participate, the class will go well.
work heavy, but interesting subject. although it says that no music background necessary, it was certainly very beneficial for those who had a decent grasp of music theory.
descrip: What does popular music tell us about the social history of Japan? This course examines music from the beginning of Westernization to the present, including children's songs, military marches, enka, jazz, rock, hip-hop, reggae, techno, Okinawan pop, J-Pop, anime/video game music, and protest music. Through close listening, analysis of translated lyrics, and readings, we consider the role of music in forming national identity, supporting social movements, and defining subcultures. We also analyze musical aesthetics, including the ways they are shaped by language and technology.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: Communication is key.
Familiarize yourself with a book entitled 'Random Walks in Biology' and prepare to work hard
Get all that you can out of your rotations.
Go to lab.  Try to keep an open mind even if you think you wouldn't like the lab.
I would advise students to be open minded and proactive during their lab rotations.
N/A this isn't a course
Rotation
Take advantage of the rotations as a time to try things you may not have done before and learn something new.
n/a
descrip: Students perform research in the laboratories of potential faculty advisors.

title: The Just Society
reviews: Attend all the lectures, Paten is a really great lecturer and an incredibly kind person.
Consider whether you *need* to take it. It fulfills a requirement, but isn't especially interesting.
Definitely a very good theory course; maybe consider a different departmental if you've already taken several theory or moral philosophy courses.
Find another pol class to take. this is a philosophy class
Good class, though pretty minimal workload. Patten is a good lecturer and will do a very professional job of delivering whatever is promised on the syllabus.
I would recommend it to anyone interested in political theory or moral philosophy.  Justice is a really cool topic, and this class was very well done.
I would recommend taking this course - it's a great way to gain a basic introduction to justice in economics and different theories and ways of thought on the topic.

If you are interested in justice, it is a good survey course to take. The readings cover some of the most important works by Locke, Marx, Nozick, and Rawls, and remarkable critiques from people like Nagel and Cohen.
If you're interested in equality as a concept take the class.
If you're interested in political theory or think you might be, this is a great course to get your feet wet.  The material is well-taught and thought-provoking.
Invest in highlighters. And get ready to talk about some extremely hypothetical situations.
It doesn't have to be this course, but every student should take a course that examines issues of global economic and social justice.
It's not centrist, but oh well, it is the Ivy League.
Keep up with the readings and study/prepare for the midterm quiz, papers, and exam. Very interesting class!
Manageable amount of work, no expectations of prior knowledge of political philosophy, really engaging and interesting.
One of the best courses I have taken at Princeton. Tackles hard and relevant questions of economic justice and is wonderfully thought-provoking. Patten is amazing as well.
Read everything.
Solid course. You don't need experience in politics and it gives you a good understanding of the basic moral issues surrounding justice
Take it - relevant and necessary materials to know.
Take it if you like economics and philosophy.
Take it! Especially if you've never taken a philosophy or political theory class before!
Take it! You learn a lot and Patten is good.
Take it, it was a nice extra class.

Take it. This course is more difficult than it looks but as a Theory concentrator I would say it was the best theory class I've taken.  If I could do the course over again I wouldn't bother reading the huge chunks of Marx or Rawls.  Both are really dense and time-consuming.  I would attend lectures that focus on those two theorists and find summaries online of their key points.  Read the required readings that pertain to those theorists because they will #1 usually highlight the main points from each piece and #2 critique some aspect of the primary theorists argument.  Knowing the fine-print of any theory is not necessary... just know the main ideas and arguments against it. You can absolutely understand Marx or Rawls without opening any of their books.  Attend lecture so you know what's going on and can participate in precept, even if you didn't do any/all of the readings.
Take this class. You will not regret it as it will challenge some of your notions and ideas.

Take this if you are interested in political theory or economic justice. You will read Locke, Marx, and Rawls among others, so if you haven't read them yet, this could be a good class for you. If you have read them, consider another course because you probably won't be too engaged here.
This course would be an excellent first course in the POL department.

i felt like i got so much out of this course without having to do an exorbitant amount of work, as in other politics classes.  alan patten is also an amazing lecturer, and i've felt like i've learned so much!
take it
take it for a good intro  into locke, nozick, marx, utilitarians, rawls.  got a lot out of the semester.  great to pdf.
descrip: An introduction to theories of social justice and examination of their implications in areas of contemporary social and political controversy. The first half of the course introduces the problem of social justice and examines two classic positions, as articulated by John Locke (whose name is associated with liberalism, property, and capitalism) and Karl Marx (whose name is associated with the critique of capitalism). The second half of the course focuses on contemporary theories of justice. We will read authors such as John Rawls and Robert Nozick, and examine controversies over poverty, taxation, equal opportunity, and environmental justice.

title: Topics in French Literature and Culture - Les Miserables
reviews: Take it?Les Mis?rables turns out to be an excellent way to experience 19th century French literature, even though you are only looking at one book.
There is a lot of reading each week, but you do an in-depth look at the book. Great class discussion!
prereqs: FRE 207 or equivalent competence in French..
descrip: A detailed exploration of Victor Hugo's Les Miserables on the occasion of its 150th anniversary. We will pick out as many as we can of its uncountable threads, from military history to revolution and revolt, industrial expansion, religious and moral thought, antiquarianism, family relations, oppression and justice, the city of Paris, dialectal speech, sentimentality, romantic love -- in short, to grasp and appreciate a vast novel that contains all stories ever told. In addition, we will look at the afterlife of Les Miserables in different forms and places, from Yiddishland to Mumbai, from musicals to movies.

title: Formal Political Analysis II
prereqs: POL 575.
descrip: Further development of the analytical tools used in formal political analysis, with special attention given to the role of information, uncertainty, and dynamics in the design and performance of political institutions. Readings emphasize the current research literature. Typical applications include participation, legislative structure, political campaigns, multiparty government, and the interaction of economics and politics.

title: Markov Processes
descrip: Markov processes with general state spaces; transition semigroups, generators, resolvants; hitting times, jumps, and Levy systems; additive functionals and random time changes; killing and creation of Markovian motions.

title: Economic Development II
reviews: Absolutely recommend this course
Go for it. Not highly technical, for those who are considering auditing.
Really great course!
prereqs: ECO 562.
descrip: Selected topics in the economic analysis of development beyond those covered in 562. Topics are selected from the theory and measurement of poverty and inequality; the relationship between growth and poverty; health and education in economic development; saving, growth, population, and development; commodity prices in economic development.

title: The Sociology of Crime and Punishment
reviews: Definitely take it. Chancer is extremely knowledgable and you learn so much.
I just know I enjoyed it.
I would highly recommend this course if you are interesting in learning more about crime and/or incarceration in the US.

Really cool class to take if you're interested in crime because you get a rather comprehensive survey of the legal and judicial systems as well as broader sociological explanations for crime. Prof. Chancer also does a great job of making herself available for office hours and paper help. One midterm test and one final paper.
Take it! It's really good for people interested in law and criminology.
This is a good course for both Sociology majors and for those in other fields.  The material is interesting and the coursework isn't excessive.
extremely interesting and relevant.
interesting topic but class can get boring
it's alright
descrip: This course seeks to provide a sociological account of crime and punishment. Why do people commit crime? How should we respond to crime? How has crime policy changed over the past several decades? What are the consequences of recent crime policy? By reading classic and contemporary sociological research, policy analysis, and media coverage, we will explore the themes of crime and punishment in contemporary society.

title: Main Street, USA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Organic Chemistry II with Biological Emphasis
reviews: A lot of work, but very similar to solving puzzles. Understand the concepts and do as many practice problems / tests as you can.
Always keep up with the work. Ask questions if you don't understand something.
Attend lecture.
Awesome course.  Fascinating
Be prepared to place lots of time in this course, as the material can be challenging and difficult to understand.
Begin prepping for exams a week or more ahead of time so the mechanisms can feel intuitive.
Challenging, but extremely rewarding. Make sure you do as many practice exams and problems as you can and you'll get the hang of it!
Do a lot of practise
Do all of the practice exams. Read the textbook. Go to lecture.
Do the practice exams over and over!
Don't expect too much of yourself; go to all the review sessions and lectures and precepts even if you might be sick and tired of the class. Go to office hours too.
Don't fall behind, but if you do, use the textbook and when the test comes just go through the practice tests with your notes. Use lot's of post-its!
Don't freak out about orgo.  It's not that bad -- just put in the time, stay on top of the practice exams and ask lots of questions.  It's also extremely interesting.
Don't slack off first semester if you plan on taking the second because so much of it carries over.
Even though I dreaded taking organic chemistry - as I'm sure many of you do - I found that the material was actually manageable, and occasionally even fun, with these instructors.
I think the material is rather interesting.

I would highly recommend this course to any student who's taken CHM 303.  Great lengths have been taken to reduce pressure on students, like the fact that the homework is graded on completion and that the exams are open-notes.  A lot of people I knew took the general 304 for second semester organic chemistry, but I think CHM 304B is equally informative and enjoyable, and has some accommodations that 304 doesn't.
I would say definitely seek out help when you need it because there are a wealth of resources and the individual help is often pivotal in helping you grasp the material.

If you don't have the time for it, do not take this course. But if you do, you'll so learn so so much, and you'll be extremely prepared to hydrolyze any amide bonds you encounter during your Princeton career. Use the TAs, use the textbook, use Dr. Semmelhack. You'll be okay.
If you have to take it, take it. If you do not HAVE to take it- DON'T.
If you have to take it, take it. If you don't have to take it, don't take it. Simple as that.

If you have to take this course, then you have to take it, but be open and ask for help when you need - people in this course are actually really helpful when you show that you care to learn. Don't fall behind, because there is too much to learn so keep up with what's going on in the course. Try to find a good preceptor though, because it really affects your overall engagement in the course. Orgo is not a "I can do it if I cram" course so try to learn regularly, you will benefit the most in that way and go to Prof. Semmelhack for regrades, he is really helpful!

If you're looking at this class, it is probably required, so you don't have much of a choice. Very few people take Orgo because of general interest or for distribution requirements (there are less time-consuming classes for those). Orgo is very time-consuming but ultimately very rewarding if you take the time to learn the subject matter.

If you're reading this you know you have to take the class.  Semmelhack does a good job, but it's still organic chemistry.  Do practice problems, recognize patterns, ask questions.  Do well on the final and you'll get a good grade. Good luck!
It is an interesting subject, and I can imagine enjoying it under different circumstances, but it was extremely hard.
It's a great course. Of course, you'll only be taking it because you need to most likely. Semmelhack vs. Sorrenson is more a matter of personal taste.

It's definitely challenging, but I really like the biological focus. The last 3 lectures we talk about DNA/RNA translation/transcription etc. which is really interesting and brings the course all together!
It's not as hard as people say.

It's really manageable, as long as you keep up! Learn the mechanisms as you go along, and not right before the exam because each individual lecture really builds on each other. And go to office hours! Prof. Semmelhack is really friendly and helpful, and he will help clarify anything that might have seemed confusing in lecture. Really use them!

Keep up with the lecture material. Definitely do the problem sets and attend precepts. Before an exam, read the textbook especially for significant mechanisms and most important, do the practice exams.
Keep up with the lectures, and take plenty of practice exams! Orgo may be challenging, but it is a great course.
Make an index of all the different types of reactions from each lecture.

Most people take this course for a requirement.  It is extremely difficult, but you can get it done if you stay positive and put in steady work throughout the semester.  Some people may understand the concepts more quickly than others, but continue doing practice problems and practice exams, and you'll eventually get a better grasp of it.
None

Organic Chemistry consumes a lot of time, one should be prepared to give up whole weekends before midterms. Time management is essential and i wouldn't recommend skipping lecture unless you really enjoy going over the book in detail.
Practice alot, even if this means losing a bit of sleep.
Practice. Practice. Practice. That's the only way to do well in this class.
Recommend if interested in biology
Take it if you have to.
Take it; it's challenging but fun.
Take this class if you're interested in chemistry and understanding how organic chemistry works in our everyday lives, as well as in biology.
This course is really hard obviously but you know what you're getting into.
This is, as you probably know, a very difficult and time-consuming class. Do not take it unless you have to.
This semester is less about the basics and a lot more about the main reactions of organic chemistry. Pay attention and it will be pretty interesting.

This semester of orgo is similar to the last one. Work hard, reach out for help when necessary, form a study group if possible. You always have multiple chances to bring your grade up, so don't lose hope but always work your hardest. I found this semester easier on me conceptually because there was already a foundation built from last semester. Practice makes perfect so do a lot of practice problems and exams and you'll be much more prepared. Put in the work and you can do it!
Use the practice exams as preparation for exams; they're a great resource.
Very difficult, despite open note tests

While other college students complain about orgo, I think that orgo is one of the best managed classes at Princeton. The grading system is very forgiving and everyone involved in teaching the class is so enthusiastic about the material. I would recommend this class even to people who are not CBE, chem, or mol bio majors because it is so well taught.
Work hard and keep up.

You might be deciding which section of orgo to take. As someone who hasn't taken other biology courses, I think that this course gives you a great understanding of the chemical foundations of some simple biochemistry (enzyme catalysis, stability of DNA molecules, peptide synthesis, etc.)
You probably have to take this course. If you are deciding between Semmelhack or Sorensen, I think both are great, though I do prefer Semmelhack's notes.

You're probably taking this class as a pre-req or as a pre-med requirement, so this won't be terribly helpful to you. Sorenson is a more engaging lecturer, but Semmelhack is incredibly well organized.
don't procrastinate
keep up
sorenson's is easier take that .
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303. Course is open to freshmen..
descrip: The concepts introduced in CHM 303 will be extended to the structures and reactions of more complex molecules, with an emphasis on how organic chemistry provides the framework for understanding molecular processes in biology. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry will be illustrated, as often as possible, with examples drawn from biological systems. Appropriate for chemistry and engineering majors, premedical students, and students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Walden in Our Time
descrip: See website

title: Special Studies in the Nineteenth Century - 19th Century Poetry & Poetics: Historical Poetics
descrip: This course will focus on British poetry and poetics between 1830 and 1914 to ask how current debates about close reading and distant reading were anticipated by nineteenth-century discourses about poetic form. Our main concerns: historical prosody, poetry's ability to measure "Englishness," poetry and the public sphere, poetry and the spiritual. We will also briefly consider the transatlantic circulation of Victorian poetry and metrical theories. We will read poetry and prose by nineteenth-century authors alongside theories of language from the nineteenth-century and twentieth and twenty-first century poetic criticism.

title: Special Topics in Dance History, Criticism, and Aesthetics - The Critic as Artist
reviews: A fantastic course that will really make you reconsider criticism and its role in the realm of dance.

I liked this course because it was a mix of creative writing, creative non-fiction, personal narrative, journalism, and arts writing. I would recommend this course if you're interested in being exposed to many different writing genres. Your definitions of criticism will be challenged, but this will help you grow as a writer, thinker, and appreciator of art. To my surprise, taking this course actually helped me to become a better academic writer. I honestly think this course helped me write my English thesis, as it gave me a forum to experiment with my critical/creative writing. I was then able to apply these creative experiments to the writing of my academic thesis. Learning how to write a critical paper creatively really impressed my thesis readers, and I attribute that approach to writing to taking this course.
I would strongly advise another student to take this course if Claudia teaches it again. It is well worth the discomfort of any initial inhibitions.
Take it!
Take this course! It is interesting and fun. it will help you see dance criticism in a new way. Claudia is fantastic!
This course is great!
Yes.
descrip: Criticism is art. It therefore must aspire to reach the heights, depths and strange in-betweens it grapples with in the art of others. Yet criticism owes a singular responsibility to these others, and to the wider culture it seeks to interrogate. Our interrogation will be generated by dance and performance criticism, with forays into live visual art, theater and hybrid forms. Our meetings will be hands-on affairs, guided by student experiments. "Experiments" is a key word -- this class will function like a laboratory, open to all individuals with an interest in better understanding themselves and their world through words and art.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews: Always go to lecture. And go to your preceptor's office hours!
Anticipate doing a lot of work independently if you want to do well.
Attend lecture and do all the readings. Don't be afraid to ask for additional help.

Be prepared to be bored. Even if you don't have these instructors the material in general is incredibly boring. If thinking of taking for a distribution requirement, take something else. There are far more interesting SA's than economics 101.
Be ready to deal with a large quantity of information, and try to organize the information as you go.
Be sure to do the readings, they always show up again.

Consider taking the course in a different semester.  I have heard that this course is usually far more fun and interesting when taught by a different professor, although I can't vouch for the reliability of this hearsay.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH ADSERA. It is actually the worse course I've taken at Princeton, and perhaps even the worst in my life.
Do not take it with Adsera.
Do not take this class with Adsera. She is extremely unorganized and the material is presented in the most uninteresting way possible.
Do the problem sets on your own and make sure you know how to do all of them clearly. Do the readings, teach you more than the lectures will
Don't skip precept - it's so helpful to get a more in-depth view of the concepts presented in class, and most of the preceptors are very good at explaining things.
Don't take it with Adserda.  Wait for Bogan or another professor
Don't take it, unless you're like me and love economics and can stand it.
Don't take unless actually interested in Econ.
ECO 101 is a solid intro course. The problem sets are manageable, and precepts are fairly interesting, though lectures are a bit dry.
Every good Princeton student takes Econ, so give it a try. It helps your understanding of the way money makes the world go 'round

Every student should complete this course as well as Macro as the subject matter is very important and applicable to real life.  Adsera runs a nice course.  The math is easy for students with good math background, not a challenge for students with poor math backgrounds.
Exactly what you expect it to be--covers the basics pretty well. Professor Adsera's lectures are quite nice.
Expect to teach yourself a lot of the material, and work with others and consult the textbook for problem sets, because the lectures don't tell you everything you need for them.
Go to the lectures, because Prof. Adsera's descriptions sure beat taking notes from the powerpoint.  Read the textbook because it's the best way to get the concept.
Good SA requirement...course does contain information that is simply good to know even if your major has nothing to do with Econ.
Have all of your notes from lecture and precept organized for every week.
I would recommend this course given the material it covers, not because of the instruction.
I would take this course. If you study and do the reading you will be fine!
If you have to take it, take it.
