It's a boring class - if you don't want to go to lectures, she basically writes out the entire thing on slides anyway. But the material is interesting, I suggest reading on your own time and it makes the overall class more tolerable.
It's an alright course... not really so hard. A fairly easy SA if you need one.
It's useful to know.
It's very interesting and more applicable to life after princeton than other courses.
Macroeconomics is something everyone should take at some point to fully understand the basics of some of the most controversial topics today.
Overall macro is useful in understanding the workings of the economy at large and can be useful for a variety of fields as well as everyday life.
Overall this course is pretty terrible. Avoid it if you can.
Reconsider taking ECO 101 with Profesor Adsera - I have heard it is a lot better with Professor Bogan in the fall!
Take it a different semester
Take it for a good background in macroeconomics
Take it for an easy SA.
Take it to see if you're interested in econ. If you find that you're not engaged, drop the course as it becomes more burdensome without interest in the material.
Take it with Bogan.
Take it with another professor.
Take it, but with a better professor.

Take this course if you're interested in macroeconomics.  I cannot speak for how well Professor Bogan taught this course, but Professor Adsera is kind of engaging if you're interested in the subject.  The workload is not bad at all.  Make sure to pay attention in precept because some new concepts are actually taught exclusively in precept.
The material for this course is definitely interesting, and it does not require much work. Good course to fulfill the SA requirement

This course is fairly easy in the beginning, but be aware that later topics require a good understanding of the differences in monetary vs. fiscal policies and the effects of inflation/interest rates. A lot of later topics are also more explantion than calculation, so be ready to explain shifts with words instead of just plugging in numbers.
This course will provide you with a solid background in macroeconomics. I think it consists of material that every educated person should know.
This is a useful course information-wise, but if you can get another teacher it will probably be to your benefit. If not, the textbook will become your new best friend.
This is a very interesting course for pretty much anyone to take.
This is not a difficult course, but if you fall behind in the readings/lecture (you only need to do one), then it may be difficult to catch up as ideas build.
This teaches you good general knowledge. I finally understand the recession now.

prereqs: ECO 101 is offered both terms and may be taken before, after or simultaneously with ECO 100..
descrip: The theory of the determination of the level of national income and economic activity, including an examination of the financial system. Emphasis on economic growth and such economic problems as inflation, unemployment and recession, and on appropriate policy responses. Some attention is also paid to international issues.

title: International Migration and Public Policy
descrip: This course examines the historical and contemporary literature on international migration, the policies that enable or impede cross-national migration, and the consequences for the sending and receiving states as well as the migrants themselves. Drawing on contemporary international evidence, students will consider classical and contemporary theories of immigrant adaptation, language acculturation, and ethnic conflict from comparative international evidence.

title: Knowledge, Holiness and Pleasure: The Illustrated Book in the Medieval World
descrip: See website

title: American Economic History
reviews: A great class: good mix of economics and history, Professor Bogan is a great lecturer, and the material is well selected and truly interesting.
A solid econ departmental, but not the most amazing because the readings can be kinda boring.

Bogan is one of the best professors I've had; very knowledgeable and passionate about the material. You don't have to do all of the readings to do well. Focus on the lecture slides when studying for exams.
Bogan is the best lecturer at Princeton, and Economic History is an interesting and relevant field. Sometimes this course feels a lot like Part 2 of ECO 101, so make of that what you will.

Definitely take this course if you are an econ major. It is a great view of American economic history and will explain why certain presidents made the decisions they did from an economic point of view. It even satisfies a finance certificate course.
Go to review sessions
Good class.
Great course that will give you a new look at American history and build a solid foundation for understanding business cycles and monetary and fiscal policy.
Great course, not a crazy amount of work but does require weekly attention.  Also a great history class if you don't want to have to write history papers.
Great course.

Highly recommended. Bogan is fantastic and you learn a lot of interesting and highly relevant material. You need to put in a lot of work for exams, but you come out of this course with a really strong understanding of the material, particularly business cycle theory.

If you are at all interested in American History or Economic History, I would strongly encourage you to take this course. As a senior, I can say that this is one of the best classes I have taken in the Economics department.

If you enjoy Bogan's ECO101, you will LOVE ECO370 as it is similarly taught. Students who haven't had Bogan sometimes complain about her slides being too bright so I would recommend printing lecture slides. Do weekly readings (at least know main point via intro   conclusion) and ASK questions. There is A LOT of material to cover, so make sure to have a study guide to collect all info.
If you like Economics or US History, you will love this class. It's one of the best classes I've taken.

If you're bad at multiple choice questions, don't take this course.  However, if you're in for a challenge and want to really learn about american economic history, this course is well worth the pain. Just don't expect easy As.
It's a lot of material to deal with, and it can be dry or confusing if you're not economically inclined, but if you are it's definitely worthwhile.

It's a solid course, even for non-econ majors (although you'll want some econ background, and having taken another Bogan course is a bonus). Interesting material, and Bogan is a great professor. Don't buy the textbook -- at most get an old edition from the library.

Not a bad course, but not a great one.  Don't just take it because its Bogan - this is not Bogan at her best and there is a lot of work involved. That being said, if you do take it - GET INTO HER PRECEPT. It will increase your enjoyment and learning in this course exponentially (although also make your precept presentation significantly more nerve-wracking) .
Professor Bogan is a great teacher. The material in this class is interesting and the exams follow what was learned in class closely.
Professor Bogan is a stud

Split up the readings with other people and discuss/summarize them before precepts, since you only need to know the main points. You don't need the book--all the material on the final is from her lectures. One annoying thing is you need to remember little details--like court cases--because Bogan likes to test on random things as well.
Study with people, go to Professor Bogan's office hours, and think of every time period as though you were alive during it and had an opinion on what was going on. It will be worthwhile.
TAKE IT
TAKE THIS CLASS!
Take Judd Cramer as your preceptor, he prepares you extremely well for the exams.
Take it without hesitation.
Take it, take it, TAKE IT! Honestly has changed the way I think of American history and is by far the best class I've take here! Invest the time every week in the readings and you'll do great
Take it.
Take it. You'll enjoy it.
Take this class if you a quantitative person with some knowledge of Econ and need a history requirement but don't want to have to write essays.
Take this course if you want a high-quality overview of US economic history.  don't leave reading ot the last minute
Take this course! Especially if you liked Bogan's Macro. It's especially good for people that like econ but not math
Take this course! Professor Bogan is great, and the material is interesting. Try to get Judd as your preceptor if you can't get Professor Bogan.

Take this course. It will add context to other econ courses, and if you're interested in American history, this is probably the most useful part of American history to know. Bogan is a great professor.

The wording in her lecture slides are sometimes confusing so I would just suggest typing everything out that she says in class.

Precepts are probably the most useful portion of this class, especially if you have Judd as your preceptor. Go to his review sessions since they clarify everything in the course.
This course is especially good if you are interested in monetary policy.  There's quite a bit on the evolution of central banking.
This course is much less interesting than the rest of Bogan's courses. Like 90% of it is about railroads. Avoid if you can.

This is an excellent class! Bogan is a great professor and Judd is a great preceptor. The subject material is very interesting as well. There are no problem sets or essays (just midterm, final, precept presentation and readings). The "economics" of the class comes in when applying economic theory to American history by way of graphs (which are presented clearly in class). Definitely take this course!

This is much more an econ class than a history class-- a lot more theory than I expected, especially the second half of the semester which focused disproportionately on 19th century monetary policy. Nevertheless, it was very, very interesting and the readings were fascinating.   Exams were tough.  As a history major, I would probably advise other history majors to think carefully about taking it because it counts as a departmental but is not really a history class.

This was a very good course-- a good balance of econ and history (but the former is the part that's tested the most heavily). Bogan's awesome, but if you're looking for something more history-centric, this might not be the right class.
You can get by in the class by skimming the readings and paying attention to fellow students' presentations. Save their handouts as study materials!
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. These are firm prerequisites, NOT co-requisites. This course counts towards WWS disciplinary perspectives requirement..
descrip: Modern economic theory is used to analyze growth and fluctuations in U.S. output from colonial times to the present. The course examines the role of labor markets, property rights in land and labor, financial institutions, transportation, innovation and other factors in economic growth. Before examining twentieth century fluctuations, a week is spent on business cycle theory. Then particular emphasis is placed on The Great Depression and its relationship to the recession of 2007-2009.

title: American Spectacle: A Theater Conversation Beyond The Proscenium
descrip: In this workshop, students will create original writing that is in conversation with American theatrical traditions beyond the proscenium. We will investigate and engage American theatrical forms, such as the freak show, burlesque, courtroom drama, mega-church, street protests, violence as spectacle and more.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Axel is a very good instructor and his studio approach is very helpful in preparation for thesis. Although sometimes a little unclear his input is generally very helpful. He is always available when needed and engages with every student on a very individual level.
Don't get lost in trying to use/learn the software.  Think about what you want to do/accomplish with the software and then learn how to do that.
make sure you know exactly the research topic you want to pursue in this course, and maximize your technical strengths in your work.
descrip: Part two of a two semester sequence in which fundamental design skills are taught in the context of the architect's wider responsibilities to society, culture and the environment. Students acquire a command of the techniques of design and representation through a series of specific architectural problems of increasing complexity. Both semesters are required for three-year M.Arch. students.

title: Introductory Physics II
reviews: 0/10 would not take again
Avoid this class if you can
DON'T TAKE IT. Take physics over the summer or take 104.
Do the assignments and study for the quizes and exams with old exams and quizzes.
Do the readings and don't fall behind. Attend review sessions and study halls when available because that helps learn the material as it's presented, making problem sets and examinations much easier.
Don't go to lecture with Happer unless you have to take a quiz. In fact, don't take this class if you don't have to. I would actually recommend taking 104.
Don't take it unless you have to. All the damn premeds make the curve impossible.
Don't take it unless you have to. Pre-med course for sure.

If you have taken 101 then you probably have some idea of what this will be like...101, but harder. No vectors really, no kinematics, charges, atoms, light, em waves.

It really all depends on the professors you get. If you aren't learning from their teaching, spend the time studying independently and taking advantage of the McGraw tutors.
It sucks. But i'm assuming you are pre med...so you're going to take it anyways.
It was good if you like physics. Don't get much more out of it than just reading the book though.
It's just another pre-med class that we all have to take.
Keep up with the readings, and the class should be enjoyable even for people who don't usually like physics.

Many students thought it was useless, but if you attended class and paid attention, it was pretty easy and enjoyable. You don't even have to pay too much attention- just focus on the math, that is physics after all.
Much better than 101.

Only take it if you're premed, in which case I'll say I'm sorry :(
Only take this class if you have to.

PLEASE do not take this with Professor Happer! This class was very unprofessional - the grading breakdown wasn't announced until halfway through the course, the quizzes often had major errors on them that made them frustrating and didn't test us well, etc.etc.etc. If you're taking it, you probably have to - unless you have some deep abiding interest in superficial electricity and magnetism - but please don't take it with Professor Happer.

Premed course is a premed course. You take it because you have to. 
Otherwise I wish the faculty would up their game; the course has the potential to be very good.
Since it is a pre-med requirement, students must inevitably take it.
Stay on top of the problem sets and prepare well for quizzes.
Take it if you have to.
Take it!

The material is harder than 101, but it's interesting.  This semester the scheduling was weird.  Mondays would be review then a quiz, precepts would be material that would be tested the next Monday, and Friday lectures would be material a week or two ahead of the Monday quizzes.  Psets were due every Sunday.  You need to understand concepts on some level, but just as (more? sadly, maybe yes) important is memorizing and knowing how to use the equations.

This class covers electricity, circuits, magnetism, optics, special relativity, quantum mechanics, and then nuclear physics, so learning new material may make this more interesting than 101.  The pace is ~3 chapters every 2 weeks, and expect to get out what you put in.  On Fridays Professor Happer would present a couple chapters during one lecture, and then he would review before giving a quiz at the end of lecture the next Monday.  Labs are also more enjoyable than 101.
This class is difficult. I had to put a lot of effort into it but in the end, I'm happy that I took it.
This course sucks. Prepare yourself.
Try to keep your grade as high as you can for the final since the final seems to be a crap-shoot. Overall easier than PHY 101 but final was harder.

Unless you're premed or this is a requirement, don't take this class to fulfill an STL. Labs run over time and this class is full of over-achieving premeds. If you are taking this class, it really covers all you need to know for the MCAT and the weekly quizzes really help to reinforce the material.
don't take it unless you have to
keep up with material each week
only if premed!

prereqs: PHY 101.
descrip: This course presents an introduction to the fundamental laws of nature, especially optics, electricity/magnetism, nuclear and atomic theory. These are treated quantitatively with an emphasis on problem solving. The laboratory is intended to give students an opportunity to observe physical phenomena and to gain "hands-on" experience with apparatus and instruments.

title: Orchestral Music: Analysis and Performance
reviews: It's fun and pretty low pressure.
prereqs: Class limited to members of University Orchestra..
descrip: The course focus and repertory will be Wagner's Tristan und Isolde and French musical modernism from Debussy and Ravel to Poulenc. Drawing from the Princeton University Orchestra's spring 2013 repertory, the following works will be discussed: Wagner's Tristan und Isolde, Ravel's Daphnis et Chloe, and Poulenc's Gloria. See Reading List for related listening repertory and supplementary reading.

title: Environmental Challenges and Sustainable Solutions
descrip: Focuses on environmental challenges and sustainable solutions related to interrelationships between constructed and natural processes. Topic areas include resource conservation, sustainable practices, stormwater management, and habitat restoration. The format of the course is experiential learning with problem-solving research projects, lectures, and discussions. A central theme of the projects is to track the impact of land use and sustainable practices on the ecological balance of environments in and around Princeton's campus.

title: India before Europe: Politics, Religion, and Culture in South Asia, 1000-1857 A.D.
descrip: Far from being an isolated place, medieval and early modern South Asia was an important world region connected to Central Asia, Persia, and Europe by trade, politics, migration, and culture. Complex interactions between Indic and Islamic traditions shaped its popular and elite culture from the 11th century. This course provides an overview of the intriguing composite society and dynamic political culture of India prior to the British Victorian Empire and re-examines the processes by which the subcontinent was colonized by the British East India Company.

title: Islam in the West
descrip: See website

title: Formal Political Analysis I
descrip: A rigorous introduction to choice theory, social choice theory, and non-cooperative game theory. The course serves as the first formal theory graduate course and draws on mathematics at the level of POL 502.

title: Race and the History of Racism in Brazil: An Alternative to the United States?
descrip: See website

title: Epidemiology
prereqs: This is a required course for graduate students in the Health and Health Policy certificate program..
descrip: Course covers the basic concepts and methods of epidemiology and demonstrates how these can be applied to improve population health and reduce health inequities. Topics include: measuring the health of the population, understanding the causes of poor health, developing interventions for improving health, translating evidence into practice, and evaluating the impact of policies and programs. Key epidemiological concepts such as association, bias and confounding are covered, as well as the main epidemiological study designs.

title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices
reviews: A good fifth course- not a lot of work, lots of fun to be part of.
DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE! I can't dance at all and I had a ton of fun!!! It's really chill and a great to take if you need a fifth class or a distribution requirement.
Definitely, take this class. You will learn in a completely different way.

Do you love dancing? Do you love learning about other cultures and dance in those cultural contexts? Do you want to have a wonderfully kind and nurturing professor to guide you through your studies? Then take this course!

Don't do it for the academic experience; do it because, even for a beginner, it is an absolute blast and like no course you have ever taken or will ever take at Princeton. Our professor cares so much about us, our two drummers are amazing to have live at every class, and the progress you make will be so apparent.
Even if you have no previous dance experience, take it!  Classes are fun and Mama Dy is great.  The end of the semester showcase is also a lot of fun.
Everyone should take this class

I was very intimidated at the start of the class by the number of dancers in the class, but quickly learned that there were a lot of beginners as well. My advice would be to be upfront about any lack of experience, because Professor Harvey could and would provide special attention or help if necessary.
It's more tiring than you think.
Take it! It's a great course.
Take it! It's a great way to fulfill a distribution requirement, doesn't require a lot of work, and was so much fun
Take it.
Take this class!  You won't regret it!  Mama Dy is a great teacher and it's a lot of fun!
This class is amazing, and perhaps the most fun course I have taken at Princeton. Don't worry about your dance experience, anyone can take this class.
This class is awesome. You will seriously improve your dancing abilities no matter what level you are.
awesome class, you should definitely do this
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Politics/Culture During the Brazilian Military Dictatorship
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of independent work, and to yield the benefits of that!
Definitely helps if you know Portuguese or have spent time in Brazil, otherwise it would be very difficult.

For those interested in contemporary Brazilian culture and history, this is a must-go course. It is very challenging, since the issue demands the consideration of many social, cultural, political and economical aspects, but is definitely worthy.
If Princeton can lure Jim Green back again, go for it! A fabulous chance to take a course with a spectacularly engaging professor.
If Professor Green ever returns to Princeton I would certainly recommend his course to any history or politics major, or anyone with an interest in Brazilian history and society.
Speak in class and work hard on your research paper and you'll be fine, if not great.
prereqs: This course is open to undergraduate students and graduate students who fulfill one of the following requirements: (a) the student has intermediate knowledge of Portuguese; (b) the student has taken at least one previous course in modern Latin American history or a class related to Brazil; (c) the student has spent time in Brazil; (d) the student is convincingly motivated to learn about recent Brazilian history.
descrip: This seminar focuses on the political, social, economic, and cultural changes that took place in Brazil during the civilian-military dictatorship that ruled the country from 1964-85. Using primary and secondary sources, as well as films and documentaries, we will examine why and how the generals took power, the role the U.S. government played before and after the coup d'etat in Brazilian affairs, the multiple political and cultural forms of opposition that emerged to challenge authoritarian rule, the process that led to democratization, and Brazil's new role as a global player and an economic powerhouse.

title: Finance and Public Policy
reviews: Be sure to understand your basics well and the rest will follow.
Great course.  Shafer is a great professor who has brilliant knowledge in economics in finance and awesome experience.  He's also a very nice guy, very down to earth, despite his lofty credentials.

If looking for a fantastic approach to markets and where they succeed and fail, take this class. Prof. Shafer seems like a great teacher to do independent work with because he obviously likes to teach and has an approachable personality.
If you are interested in finance, I recommend this class.
Take it if this is offered. Great course and Shafer does a good job.
Take this if you are interested in the topic

This is a good course if you want an overview of finance and the issues it presents for public policy. If you already know a lot about finance or want a more technical course, this may not be for you.
participate and do readings on time
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101.
descrip: This course will examine the public policy issues raised by financial markets, including their role in allocating savings to investment, supporting economic growth, preserving systemic stability and pursuing non-economic objectives. It will examine the nature of theoretical efficient financial markets alongside the failures of real markets arising from instability of liquidity, asymmetric information, distorted information and the social, cognitive and emotional factors shaping behavior. It will assess government interventions to correct market failures and their unintended consequences.

title: From Luther to Napoleon: Early Modern Germany, 1495-1806
descrip: This course traces the tumultuous history of the German lands in the early modern period, from the reforms in the institutions of the Holy Roman Empire of the German Nation in 1495 until the abolition of the Empire during the Napoleonic Wars (1806). It is designed for students with some background in early modern German history as well as for those who have never done any German history before. Topics covered include the Holy Roman Empire, the Reformation, the Thirty Years War, the Peace of Westphalia, Frederick the Great and the rise of Prussia, the German Enlightenment, The French Revolution in Germany, and the Napoleonic experience.

title: Topics in International Relations - Human Rights
descrip: This course looks at human rights as a public policy issue. It considers debates over the definition of human rights; the possibilities and limits of humanitarian intervention; the ability of human rights activists and international actors to undermine dictatorial governments; and the impact of the laws of war. We will consider historical and contemporary cases around the world, including the Armenian genocide, the Holocaust, Bosnia, China, and more.

title: Language, Identity and Power
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Slavery's Afterlives
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar will focus on slavery's forms, structures, and logics. But, as the title suggests, it will also concentrate on those remnants of slavery that outlast its purported ends. We'll spend much of the semester surveying the boundary lines that are imagined to separate slavery and freedom (geographical, temporal, legal), bringing into question the times and spaces thought proper to each. Anchored in nineteenth-century America but extending into our own moment, our texts will address the entrapments of freedom, the life and death of the slave commodity, the racial protocols of the law, and the architectures of captivity.

title: Civil Liberties
reviews: As a math major who generally sticks to STEM courses, nevertheless I founds this class to be very engaging and touching upon in thought-provoking manners. Definitely worth taking.
Definitely take this class if you have any interest in law, the Constitution, or government. Very good class and you will definitely learn a lot.

I came in with a general interest in ConLaw, this ended up being not enough as the other people in the class did all the readings and the professor very strictly enforced grade deflation.  So I ended up having to PDF it and am hardly slacking to get a P.  If you are truly into reading and discussing court cases, this is for you.
I loved this course.   Take it so that you can be an intelligent person and because its interesting.

I'd keep an outline throughout the semester on different topic areas discussed and court cases that relate to each. Also don't be afraid to talk to your preceptor or Professor Whittington outside of class with any questions! This class is really founded on the questions you ask and how you interpret things, so always make sure you keep doing that.
Most people choose to take this with the other guy, but Keith Whittington is actually really great--and with a less big class you really get to discuss in-lecture as well as precept.
Requires a good amount of thinking and conceptual understanding. If you're interested in law, though, definitely take this course.
Take it if you're interested, but not a must-have.
Take it! A very interesting POL course.

Talk to the professor before written work is due to clarify expectations for the grading--he is much stricter than other professors I have encountered. Other than that, it is an interesting course and one I would recommend.
There's not too much work throughout the year, but the midterm is very hard.  The reading can also be tedious.
This coarse, if not taught by Robbie George, loses a lot of essential focus.
This course is pretty reading-heavy. Make sure you go to lectures and precepts, as the readings are difficult to comprehend on your own
This is an excellent course for someone looking to get a good understanding of the development of civil liberties in the US.
Would recommend the material but think that the structure is totally insane. Should absolutely be changed for next year.
You should definitely take this course. It will give you an in depth understanding of the roots and history behind  many contemporary issues. I'm very liberal, and my views were absolutely respected.
descrip: An exploration of how the United States has grappled with the limits on government power. The rights of individuals, and the justification for the use of force from the founding period to today. Topics include religious liberty, free speech, economic liberty, equality and personal autonomy, and security issues.

title: Cultural Systems - Proust, Freud, Borges
reviews: A really interesting seminar, highly recommended. Work load easily manageable.

Gallo is a good dude and if you're into the humanities it would be a shame to leave this school without reading some Proust/Freud/Borges for real. Seminar was oversized, though, so if you're not comfortable speaking up you could get lost
Great introduction to all three authors!
I enjoyed reading the books.  Professor Gallo has interesting things to say about them; your fellow students do not.

I would take it! I didn?t know anything about Freud or Proust but was interested in exploring them, and this was the perfect setting to do so. The workload is manageable, the assignments light, and the seminars interesting. Also a wonderful chance to read a bunch of Borges? short stories which are phenomenal.
Take it if you are interested in philosophy, psychology, and/or literature. This course is intellectually stimulating.
Take it! It's worth it for the Freud alone!
Take this class! It was great, but only if you like literature and don't mind Proust and Borges.
have fun!
descrip: An overview of three of the most influential writers in the twentieth century. All three were fascinated by similar topics: dreams and memory; sexuality; Judaism. All three also lived during traumatic historical periods. Proust during WWI; Freud during WWII; and Borges during Peronismo. Seminar will explore how these varied historical contexts influenced three very different theories of writing. Other topics include the writers and their relation to modernism, politics, and religion.

title: Philosophy of Social Science
descrip: The idea of religion figures in social science in many ways. For example, religious identities figure in identifying social patterns. One can offer explanations for religious beliefs or practices. And one can classify religious identities, beliefs or practices and seek to explain patterns among religions. In this course we will consider questions about what sort of concept religion is, what the right account of that concept is, what conceptions are presupposed in various approaches to social theory about religions, and what relation there should be between sociological accounts of religion and the accounts of adherents.

title: Democracy and Slavery in the New Nation
reviews: A LOT of work, but worth it I think
Fantastic course, just take it.  It's challenging, but if you like American history and you don't take this course, you're doing yourself an injustice.
Highly recommend this course, but prepare to dedicate a lot of time for mediocre grades, as it is extremely difficult
I would advise them to do all the readings before lectures and precepts.
If you have even a passing interest you gotta take this course.
It is a good yet challenging course. It presents a strong narrative that is useful for understanding the antebellum.
Read all of the primary documents -- it will be very helpful for the final exam.
TAKE THIS. Wilentz is hilarious. Great class, especially for history majors.
Take it if you like political history, because that is the main focus.
Take this class, but be prepared to work.
Take this course, if at all interested in American history.

This is a fantastic class. Wilentz is one of the best lecturers at Princeton, and the course material will allow you to consider American history in new ways. Wilentz is known for being a hard grader, so I'd recommend trying to not be in his precept if that is a big issue for you.

This was a fantastic course. Strongly recommend if you're serious about history. The workload is certainly more than other history courses, and it might be graded harshly, but the feedback you receive is superlative and I feel like i've become a better reader and thinker as a result of taking this course.
Wilentz pushes you to work hard, but you come away learning a lot.
descrip: An interpretive survey of U.S. history from the ratification of the Constitution to the Compromise of 1850. The course will emphasize intensive reading of documents and historical interpretations.

title: Topics in 18th-Century Literature - Jane Austen in Context
reviews: Definitely take this class!!!
Definitely take this course if you enjoy Austen. You don't know her nearly as well as you think you do!
Do all the readings
Enjoy!  Cherish the novels.  They're wonderful, and you can learn a lot.

For other students, I strongly recommend you have read most of Austen's works before you take the class, that way it will be more like review and keying in on he concepts rather than rushing to finish novel after novel.

I definitely recommend this course. It has a good mix of everything. It isn't an overload in terms of work, although there is quite a bit of reading, obviously. It's always great to have a professor that is just absolutely in love with the subject matter.

I really liked it it! Be ready to really read and engage Austen - if you don't like Austen, don't take the class. But you don't have to be a hardcore Austen fan to take it either - most people I knew in the class had either only read Pride and Prejudice or had read P&P and one other Austen book.

I would say maybe tackle one book before school start and set yourself a schedule to make sure you don't behind. Also watch some of the movies to help learn the plots and engage in the material. And do one creative project! :)
IT's awesome
If you like Jane Austen, or 19th Century literature, take it! Really great class!

If you're interested in Jane Austen, you definitely should take this course! You'll enjoy it. If you aren't particularly interested in Jane Austen, you should also take this course, because the course will give you a new appreciation for Austen's talent.

If you're into Jane Austen a bit and want to try an English class/an LA, definitely take it- it's a great class. Also, seek out your preceptor's help on your paper ideas- they are very helpful and will help make your argument stronger, so that you can write a better paper.
It's a little weird if you aren't absolutely obsessed with Austen.  But still worthwhile!
It's a lot of reading, but it's really really fun for anyone who loves being able to just read a good book for homework.
Only if you like Austen!
Participate in the class discussions!  You should get all you can out of this excellent course.
Perfect PDF class. Great, fun books, interesting discussions, and low work level.
Read all the books; keep up with reading weekly. You'll love this class; it's not too much work (aside from the papers and a slightly annoying take home final) and it's very interesting!
Take it!
Take this course, especially if you're already a Jane Austen fan looking to gain new perspectives on her work.
Take this course. Do it.
Take this course. It is a great exploration of Austen's novels and the work is not too bad.

There is a lot of reading to do. Make sure you like reading Jane Austen before you take the course because that is all you will be reading. Spend time on your papers. Get the norton critical editions.
You should absolutely take this course if you in any way even vaguely like Jane Austen
descrip: Jane Austen is the darling of popular audiences and high culturists alike. The inventor of the modern novel and a pivotal, inspirational figure in English literary history, she is venerated or despised with peculiar intensity--for being a brilliant stylist or a provincial bore, a benign aunt or a nasty spinster, an instrument of tedious and oppresive normality or of dazzling and expansive fabulousness. We will test such views by studying all of Austen's novels, paying close attention to the context of 18th-century literature out of which she develops and contrasts her achievements to recent film adaptations.

title: Shakespeare II
reviews: Absolutely fantastic. This class not only teaches a lot of Shakespeare, but it teaches it so engagingly that you want to go to lecture every day. Also, since you're only reading one play a week, the work load is not overwhelming (even if it might seem like it from the syllabus).
Definitely take this class. Shakespeare is even more of a genius than you think, and the professor is awesome.
Definitely take this course, but be prepared that it is a lot of work. It was never overwhelming, but requires you to commit to the class
Don't be intimidated by how much work this looks like it has. Yes, there is a lot of work, but it's all very manageable, and even enjoyable. You'll learn a lot, and Shakespeare is amazing!

Go to every lecture because Dolven is very engaging and will get you thinking. The class is as much work as you put into it and extremely rewarding. Take it if you want to read Shakespeare, no matter your department.
Great course. Prof. Dolvin makes even the most Shakespeare-averse people get pretty interested in the books. Actually reading the plays helps on the tests.
I would advise students to get an early start on reading the plays, particularly if they are relatively new to Shakespeare's language.
If you are at all interested in good stories, big questions, small questions, or just plain old good writing, take this course!

If you have any interest at all in Shakespeare, take this course. Jeff Dolven is an amazing lecturer with very interesting and engaging ideas on Shakespeare's plays. The lectures were always fun and informative. It was really cool to notice and talk about all the subtleties of Shakespeare's language. I definitely recommend this course. Take it!
If you're interested in taking a Shakespeare course, do it with Professor Dolven.
It's good, but you simply have to keep working throughout the course. You can't just shoulder the burden in reading/finals week.
It's more work than the average class, but so worth it.
Lectures can be a little theoretical, but fun course if you like English and reading Shakespeare
Make sure you actually read all of the plays
Read the plays! More than once.
Take it -- phenomenal lectures.
Take it and start flagging quotes ahead of time. read the plays twice each week--once before 1st lecture and a second time before precept
Take it!
Take it!  Great readings and great professor.
Take it. Even better readings than Shakespeare I.

Take it. Professor Dolven is an amazing lecturer and a great person. The preceptors are all really intelligent and friendly, if you like to perform or watch performances there's a troupe that puts on scenes about every other class, and the plays you read and discuss are really fantastic. Take it.

Take this course, no matter who you are! A knowledge of Shakespeare is so invaluable.  The lectures are great and actually fun.  There is a troupe of actors that performs scenes from the plays.  This was an excellent course, even for non-English majors.
Take this course. There is a fair amount of work, but the professor and material are great.
The course is phenomenal.
Try to stay on top of the readings.  Watch the videos that are posted as supplementary material on BB.
descrip: A survey of the second half of Shakespeare's career, from Hamlet to The Tempest. We will follow him to the bottom of the great tragedies, and then, in the late romances, partway back.

title: Imagining Diasporas and Homelands
descrip: Why do people sometimes long for homelands that they have never personally experienced? Is this longing compatible with integration in new surroundings? In the first part of the course we consider the complexities of the paradigmatic original diaspora: the Jewish diaspora. In the second part of the course, we consider how the concept of diaspora has been expanded to include other groups in an age of widespread migration, displacement, and increasing global connectivity. Here we will consider, among others, the Palestinian and Armenian diaspora, as well as how concepts of Jewish diaspora have been modified and revisited.

title: Stochastic Calculus
reviews: Definitely take it. It's worth it.

I have spent the longest time in this course this semester and have learned the most. Brownian motions and stochastic calculus were a lot of fun and Prof. van Handel has the magic power to make them even more attractive.
Take this course. For people who enjoy maths though and who are rigorous.
Two thumbs up !
it's hard work but very rewarding. make sure you have taken the prerequisites
prereqs: Prerequisite: ORF 526 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to stochastic calculus based on Brownian motion.Topics include:construction of Brownian motion; martingales in continuous time; the Ito integral; localization; Ito calculus; stochastic differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; martingale representation; Feynman-Kac formula.

title: Topics in 20th-Century Literature - Musil/Bernhard
descrip: Robert Musil and Thomas Bernhard offer two of the most provocative critiques of the relationship between narration and the construction of subjectivity in all of twentieth-century literature. The first half of the seminar will be devoted to a reading of Musil's The Man without Qualities, the second to a series of novels from the first half of Bernhard's career: Frost, Gargoyles, The Lime Works, and Correction. The primary focus of the course will be a comparative critique of the practice of narrativity and the construction of subjectivity in these texts; in the seminar's second half we will also focus on Bernhard as a reader of Musil.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture I
prereqs: KOR 302 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: The 4th-year language course is designed to accelerate students' proficiency to the high-advanced level and to promote a deeper level of understanding of Korea and its people. A wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues are covered through the use of various media resources (e.g., dramas, films, songs, commercials, newspapers, websites) as well as short essays. Classroom discussion are conducted in Korean.

title: Traveling Modernism
descrip: This course explores the translingual conditions of modernism in a comparative study of European, Chinese, Russian and Asian-American literature. Beginning with the "wanderer in the metropolis" in Hamsun's Hunger, we will focus on narratives of physical displacement and simultaneous inward turn in Kafka, Lu Xun, Nabokov and others and analyze them in conjunction with ethnography and visual arts. Taking the writers' involvement with foreign languages and other literary traditions seriously, we will place them in a global context where they engaged in direct or implicit dialogue about self and other, migration, colonial dislocation, etc.

title: Analysis & Visualization of Large-Scale Genomic Data Sets
reviews: Brush up on some basic statistics and machine learning concepts!
Definitely a great course to take.
If you are in the comp bio filed or would like to learn how statistics and computer science are used in studying genomics, definitely take this course.

If you are interested in learning more about what professors students in computational biology are doing it is a good course.  If you are looking for a skill based course this is not the course for you.
Not a lot of work, great introduction to genomics. you really need to want to be there--they do very little to compel you to learn the material.
Read the papers! You won't get a thing out of this course if you don't.
Really work to find a well-defined and manageable project.
Take it if you're interested in the subject; great professors and great readings!

This is a really great introduction to the current research in genomics. However, even though the description says that you do not need to have a very strong background in biology or computer science, being familiar with these areas, in addition to statistics, would be very helpful.
descrip: Introduces students to computational issues involved in analysis and display of large-scale biological data sets. Algorithms covered will include clustering and machine learning techniques for gene expression and proteomics data analysis, biological networks, joint learning from multiple data sources, and visualization issues for large-scale biological data sets. No prior knowledge of biology or bioinformatics is required; an introduction to bioinformatics and the nature of biological data will be provided. In depth knowledge of computer science is not required, but students should have some understanding of programming and computation.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: Conservative Political Thought
descrip: Conservatism stresses the values of religion, tradition, authority, family, virtue, and property. By pairing classic with contemporary texts, we will explore and interrogate its various aspects, including traditionalism (Burke, Kirk, Weaver); constitutional conservatism (the Federalist, Kendall, Rossiter); associationism and anti-statism (Tocqueville, Nisbet); the friend-enemy distinction and neoconservatism (Schmitt, Burnham). To close we will treat tendencies whose relationship to conservatism is controversial (Straussianism, libertarianism) and will consider issues on which conservatism is often at a loss (race) or divided (economics).

title: Policy Issues and Analysis of Nonprofits, NGOs, and Philanthropy
descrip: Examines policy issues at international, national and local levels. Provides groundwork on nonprofits, NGOs, and philanthropy that can be followed with specialized courses on management and program evaluation. Emphasis on understanding how philanthropy, nonprofit, and NGO sectors operate, their niche alongside private and public sectors, revenue sources, impact on society, and converse effects of society and its institutions; the policy making process. Explores impact of reliance on government or overseas support for Third World NGOs; faith-based service provisions: accountability and transparency; advocacy; and government regulations.

title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Do NOT miss lectures.

It's a tough class, but not impossible.  The lectures are excellent and are relevant to anybody interested in the field.  I was not too happy with my 208 and 305 experiences, but this class made quantum much more understandable and satisfying.
Prepare to be very heavily engaged, at least as an undergraduate. It's hard to balance the work needed for this course with other course work, JPs/thesis and the like.

Take the course.  Huse is a great lecturer and covers a lot of interesting topics, some which are not usually seen in QM courses.  We covered the density matrix formalism, the Dirac equation and its applications to atoms, the Hartree-Fock approximation, second quantization, and introductions to some modern research topics like the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis.  He also presented a very clear treatment of the "measurement" problem, which caused me to adjust my viewpoint.  Take it.  You won't regret it.
Take this class as a continuation of PHY305, and also take it with ELE 456 to really get a good sense of quantum mechanics. The problem sets will take a long time but they reveal deep insights!
Take this class only if you have time to spare...
Take with friends. Learn a lot.
The course was great. It is the first course quantum course after which I can naturally relate the mathematics with the quantum physical phenomena. I highly recommend it.
This class is a significant jump from the undergraduate quantum curriculum here, but the material covered is extremely important and relevant to current research, and the class is well worth taking.
Tough class if you do not have sufficient physics foundation. But the content is rich and you really can learn advanced knowledge in quantum mechanics.
Worth taking, but need to work in groups on the homework. Often it took two or three of us to understand fully what he was asking for.
definitely take the course. just be prepared for some painful algebra.
expect to spend much time on it.
descrip: This is a one-semester course in advanced quantum mechanics. The emphasis will be on systems with many degrees of freedom: dynamics, mixed states, entanglement, measurement, coherent states.

title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Financial Engineering - Energy, Commodity, and Fixed Income Markets
reviews: A bit redundant with fin 521. Fin 521 is better at fixed income but does not have commodities.
Excellent course, excellent lecturer (although lecturer might change). Very quantitative so familiarity with basic financial modelling and stochastic calculus is important.
ORF 335 provides good background, much of the math is covered between SDEs and taking expectations. Good course to take, leave plenty of time to do the problem sets, especially MATLAB problems.

Only take if you know you can handle the math! The course is significantly harder than ORF 335. It would probably be useful to have taken a class on stochastic calculus beforehand. Prof. Coulon is a great lecturer, though, and a really nice guy too.
Strongly recommend if you want to learn more about modelling in commodities

The professor is GREAT. He really spur the interest of his students. It a very good course if you want to learn more about fixed income and commodity derivatives. Besides, the lecture notes are excellent.
take the course if you are interested in financial math and its application in different asset classes
technical course, great to develop a foundation in fixed income and commodities
prereqs: ORF 335 or instructors permission required.
descrip: This course introduces the unique features and mathematical models used in commodity (energy, metals, agricultural, etc.), and fixed income markets (bonds, rates, swaps, etc). While interest rate markets are a well-established field, commodities are an increasingly important asset class for financial institutions, policy makers and many investors. Mathematical finance approaches developed for stocks can be adapted to understand price behavior in these more complex markets. Topics include: energy prices; storable vs non-storable commodities; power and emissions; short rate models; forward curves and calibration; option pricing techniques.

title: Analysis III: Integration Theory and Hilbert Space
reviews: Difficult material, but rewarding!
Take it. I'm glad I did
Take this class, but be prepared for a lot of work and for material beyond just "integration theory" and "Hilbert spaces."
The course is extremely useful, although it will probably change much when Professor Nguyen is not teaching it.
Yes, take it! It's very hard but not unreasonably so. If you took MAT 335 and survived this course shouldn't be unreasonably difficult.
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of Lebesgue integration in n-dimensional space. Differentiation theory. Hilbert space theory and applications to Fourier Transforms, and partial differential equations. Introduction to fractals. This course is the third semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Financial Regulation, Crises & Macro Policy
descrip: The course will focus on the origins & consequences of financial crises, discussing the efficacy of preemptive & reactive policy responses based on fundamental questions including: Are financial markets efficient or susceptible to bubbles? What is the difference between bank liquidity & bank solvency? What is the relationship between financial regulation (i.e., Basel Accords) & bank CEO incentives, capital arbitrage, securitization & credit rating agencies? What is debt-overhang, how does it impact employment, GDP & inflation? What are roles and limits of fiscal & monetary policy in a financial crisis? How does politics shape/distort policy?

title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu II
reviews: Expect to learn a lot and develop a rich vocabulary for a first year student, but also have fun.
Fauzia is amazing. Take it!!

I loved taking Hindi with Fauzia. She is an extremely fair and fun teacher to learn a language from. Even though class is four times a week, it was my favorite class to go to and was always enjoyable. She teaches the material really well and is very kind in working with her students to make adjustments or extend deadlines if it is helpful for them. She is approachable if you ever have any questions and excited to teach. I also really like how she tried to incorporate culture into the class and often explained how the particular chapter we were learning would apply a conversation in India. I would highly recommend this course if you are the least bit interested in Hindi
I would advise that students keep up with the material really well and really take advantage of the help Fauzia provides.

If you are planning on studying Hin-Urdu at Princeton, take a class with Fauzia Farooqui. You will not be disappointed. This is coming from someone who advocates self-study over classes for languages (see the Anti Moon/ AJATT method). Her classes are the exception.
If you want to learn Hindi/Urdu, don't be afraid to take this class, its great.
Take this course with Fauzia. She is wonderful and makes the class fun and the Book is well written and gives you concrete ways that you will use the language.
This course is phenomenal. I would recommend it to anyone with any interest at all in Hindi/Urdu or south asian culture.
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course provides the second semester of training in Hindi and Urdu, allowing students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Equal emphasis is placed on both Hindi and Urdu, including writing systems, vocabulary, and culture. Course will focus on using language for genuine communication. Students will be able to read and write both Hindi and Urdu scripts, communicate in social situations, and narrate in all three time frames: past, present and future. Classes are interactive.

title: Framing American Art
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Language, Identity and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Literature: Fiction
reviews: Best English prereq to take. If Anjuli is precepting, definitely try to get her.
Definitely read all of the books! You learn something from each one.
Do all the readings and attend lectures, as they give you a different perspective on the material
I highly recommend the course, it is completely worth doing the readings!
I would recommend that future students stay on top of the readings and to not be nervous about sounding dumb in precept.

I would tell them that if they are interested in reading good books and would like an overview of the different types of fiction in the world, they should definitely take the class. If they are looking to dig very deeply into works, however, this might not be the class for them.
If you want an easier way to do your pre-requisite, take this class and take the professor's precept.

If you're interested in the English department or are looking for an easier, but interesting, course, take it. Try to stay on top of the readings, as most people in my precept quickly deteriorated into old high school habits when concerning novels.
It is work, but also a lot of fun.
Keep up with the readings and you'll have a very enjoyable time.
Pick the professor as your preceptor
Professor Wood is retiring this year so I'm not sure what the course will look like in the future. It would be hard to give advice just because Professor Wood made the class as great as it was.
Read all the books!
Read the books every week and enjoy the lectures.

Since the lecturer is retiring, it'll probably be an entirely different class next year if they have it.  So yes, take the class, the subject matter is fun and not heavy, and the precepts are usually scintillating.
Take Michael Wood's precept.  He's fantastic.
Take it with Professor Wood! He is the best professor ever!
Take it!
Take it! It's a fun class and one I really enjoyed. Just make sure to attend lectures/precepts as much as possible, they can really keep you up to date with the themes/ideas.
This course was interesting and the books were fun to read. Professor Wood is a great lecturer, but as he won't be teaching the course next year it may be different.

This course was phenomenal, the type of class I came to Princeton to take. The great Professor Wood is retiring so read up on whoever your next teacher is, but this reading list is terrific. It is a book a week, but on the really busy weeks it's not a problem if you're a bit behind. There are a few really short books (less than 100 pages) that give you time to make up anything you miss. Professor Wood was the best part of the course, but if the new professor seems strong, go for it!
This is an excellent course for anyone interested in getting an overview of English fiction. The reading list may change depending on the professor. Professor Wood was amazing!
This was the last class Professor Wood taught, which definitely may affect the quality of the class. However, I would take this course for the reading list.
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208, 209 and ENG 200..
descrip: This course is designed to provoke and cultivate an interest both in a range of very different forms of fiction and in the close reading of particular texts. The general argument is that we can enrich our understanding of the real world by knowing more about the alternatives to it and simulations of it that the human imagination has constructed over time. At the heart of the course will be the works themselves, from The Odyssey to contemporary graphic novels.

title: Independent Study
prereqs: Students MUST fill out the Independent Research Proposal Project form signed by your advisor & the dept rep. Hand in to E-211 E-Quad during course selection period...
descrip: Independent research in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and must result in a final paper.

title: Representing Illness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Statistical Learning and Nonparametric Estimation
reviews: A must take for anyone interested in statistics.
Definitely don't take it unless it's an absolute must! Hopefully another lecturer will be handling it from next year.
For students who are interested in statistical learning and nonparametric estimation this course is very useful.
I strongly recommend this course.
prereqs: ORF 524: Statistical Theory and Methods or instructor's approval..
descrip: A theoretical introduction to statistical learning problems related to regression and classification. Topics covered include: Principle Component Analysis, nonparametric estimation, sparse regression, and Classification and Statistical learning

title: System Design and Analysis
reviews: Car lab may have been infamous in the past, but if it ever was as bad as has been rumored, it is now one of the best course at Princeton.  The project-oriented practical experience provided by this course is extremely valuable and thoroughly fun.  I strongly recommend this course, even for those who do not have to take it.  All you need is some basic circuits (ELE 203) and software (COS 126) experience.

Carlab was one of the most rewarding experiences of my Princeton career, Although you will be spending a LOT of time in lab, there are only lectures in the first couple weeks of class and no midterm or final. That being said, make sure to start early and work often. It is much better to spend a couple hours in lab everyday rather than pull all-nighters right before the assignment is due, as you never know what will happen since you can't really put a definite number on how long each assignment will take. Good luck!
Do stuff early.
Start early.

Take car lab. It is completely reasonable, very fun, and you get a lot of great resources. As a design course, it will take a lot of time, but the professors try to reduce that time to actual design and debug, not time wasted on unfamiliarity with equipment or the car itself.

This course is a lot of work, but it is definitely worth it. You will learn more than you ever thought was possible. Everyone is very helpful in the lab which takes some of the stress away. Start the projects early and make sure you will get along with your partner.

This is the best course offered at Princeton. The hours can be long, but you won't noticed because what you're learning and building in this class is incredible. It's extremely flexible, there's more than enough help, and you'll gain a fantastic sense of how to build a completely integrated system, from sensors and hardware to programming and debugging. Again, even if not ELE, consider this course! It will prepare you for anything.

Very fun if you like building things. Start early, work often. Take the time on your own to try to debug. Learning to think carefully/independently about problems in the early projects makes the independent project much easier.
prereqs: ELE 206 and ELE 301. Permission of instructor..
descrip: Comprehensive, laboratory-based course in electronic system design and analysis. Covers formal methods for the design and analysis of moderately complex real-world electronic systems. Course is centered around a semester-long design project involving a computer-controlled vehicle designed and constructed by teams of two students. Integrates microprocessors, communications, and control.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic II
reviews: I went into Arabic learning how to read and write it. I entered intensive arabic hoping to able to learn to speak Arabic. Intensive can get very difficult as the material you cover goes by fast. It is a strong commitment.

I would recommend the course for either students who have some basis of Arabic from home, or for (graduate?) students who know a few languages already. The pace of this course is at times somewhat demanding, but overall in the year saves valuable time compared to the basic 101 and 102 courses.
I would recommend this class whole-heartily if Nizar is teaching it. You go through the whole al-kitaab book in 2 semesters, and have an interesting time doing it
Take it! The professor is a great role model , highly knowledgable, and you can learn a lot from him.
Take knowledge seriously and sincerely.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 103..
descrip: A continuation of 103. The second semester of a full-year language course designed specifically for students who already have some familiarity with any dialect of spoken Arabic. Graduate students who are primarily interested in learning to read Arabic are also welcome. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills.

title: Intensive Intermediate German
reviews: Although the class will move quickly, you will learn a lot of German, and you'll have a great time doing it.
Anyone after GER 101 should seriously consider this. It would be a great experience to improve German, and summer program in Munich will be very exciting, too!
Definitely take 1025 if considering moving up from 102.
Do your hw and stay on top of things, you will do great!
I recommend this course.
I would recommend learning the vocabulary early... then studying for the tests would be so much easier and less frantic!

If you are a student that gets easily intimidated by other students, I would not recommend taking this class. Some of the people that take it really are too competitive and make things unpleasant for everyone else. If you don't mind that and can be successful in spite of it, take this class! You'll learn a ton about German in a very short amount of time.
If you care about German, definitely take this course. Put time into it and you won't regret it.

If you want to quickly improve your German or if you are considering the Princeton in Munich program, definitely take this course. Although, the 8:30 time can be rough, the advantages of the course are well worth getting up a little earlier.
If you want your German to advance along, then I'd recommend it.
It takes a lot of time and work, but if you want to learn German at an accelerated pace, do it!
Keep up with the work, don't cram before the test, and you'll be fine.

Once you get used to the 1h20mins a day, it's not so bad and doesn't feel so different from 50mins a day. Going through grammar and vocab so quickly in the first half of the semester requires some good time management, but all of the assignments are very reasonably. Everybody gets to know each other really well in the class. I'd say it's definitely 'cost-effective' and worth it, since you get two credits for one course.

Take it! It might depend on who's teaching your class, but for me (I took it with Frederic and Hannah) it was a great experience and I think I felt like somehow it was less work than 1.5 classes. Taking German at Princeton is awesome. Do it!
Take it! but sometimes 8.30 in the morning is really a chore.
Take it-it's definitely worth it, especially if you're serious about German.
Take this class!  It's a lot of work which seems overwhelming at times but the instructors are awesome and the students are awesome too so it's a great break from content-heavy lecture courses!

Take this course if you have any desire at all to improve your conversational abilities. The class is very fast-paced; you will finish all of the grammar from Wie geht's by the end of the seventh week of classes, so be prepared to study constantly and copiously for the four grammar exams (50 percent of the grade). The exams themselves are very similar in format to the 101 exams so there are few surprises there. There are three papers throughout the semester, all of which are quite manageable (two one-pagers and one three-page final paper). Don't be afraid to speak up in class; it will help you improve your speaking! Most of all, just be sure to pace yourself, especially during the first half of the semester. Overall, if you're debating between 102 and 1025, choose this class!
Take this course. Don't do 102 but do 102-5. You're here to learn, and this is the way to do that. All of the German department staff is wundervoll.

The class is indeed quite difficult as on top of homework every day one really should be reviewing material regularly to keep up. That said, it was very rewarding and I recommend it to anyone who wants to quickly improve their German skills.

Think very very carefully about taking the 8:30 section. It isn't just a matter of will power. Don't martyr yourself! Getting out of bed is one thing, but being alert and attentive that early is a whole other thing. I know that some of my classmates handled this extremely well, but I literally have no idea how. Just be honest with yourself.

If Rankin is teaching it, that'll be amazing. I was consistently frustrated with how mismanaged my 90 minutes were. Time, especially that early, is seriously precious.

Having said that, you'll still learn a ton, and this is the most efficient way to learn German. Even though I mostly hated GER 1025, I learned a lot, and am still going to Munich to do 107.
This course is hard, but very much worth it.

This course is phenomenal. I could not recommend it more. Your language skills will develop rapidly. Also, it qualifies you to study in Germany and pursue internships and such if you wish to continue your study of German.
This is the best way to learn a language. Intense study for more than three hours a day (with a trip to Munich) is the best way to learn a language.
prereqs: GER 101 and permission of instructor. Enrollment by invitation only, following an interview with the course instructor; interviews are normally offered to students in GER 101 attaining a grade of A or A-..
descrip: Intensive training in German, building on GER 101 and covering the acquisitional goals of two subsequent semesters: communicative proficiency in a wide range of syntax, mastery of discourse skills, and reading strategies sufficient to interpret and discuss contemporary German short stories, drama, and film. Intensive classroom participation required. Successful completion provides eligibility for GER 107 or, in exceptional cases, for 200 level courses. Participants are automatically eligible for the Princeton-in-Munich program (107-G), June, 2013.

title: Graphic Design: Visual Form
reviews: Definitely take this course.

If you have any interest in graphic design, you should definitely take it! Reinfurt is really awesome and it is a fun class overall. The assignments can take as long as you want them to, but overall I'd say it is not particularly demanding.
It definitely helps to takes some time on your own to figure out Illustrator and Photoshop, so that you can more easily execute your ideas for the projects.

This class is not very "practical" in terms of teaching graphic design principles that you could use for a job (though we do learn Illustrator) but is interesting in that it looks at the intellectual roots of graphic design. It's more about spatial thinking than about graphic design as most people know it.
This was a great course! I really enjoyed the work and I feel as if I've developed as both a designer and a thinker afterwards. The workload is fairly large but not intimidatingly so.
descrip: This course introduces students to techniques for decoding and creating graphic messages in a variety of media, and delves into issues related to visual literacy through the hands-on making and analysis of graphic form. Graphic design relies on mastering the subtle manipulation of abstract shapes and developing sensitivity to the relationships between them. Students are exposed to graphics from the late 19th-century to the present in slide lectures. Studio assignments and group critique will foster an individual ability to realize sophisticated forms and motivate these towards carrying specific meanings.

title: The Politics of Development
reviews: A fairly good survey course
Definitely recommend it for anyone looking to fill a distribution requirement or interested in development.
Do the readings, makes the class worth it.
Great course to take if you're thinking about politics or interested in ideas of development.
Have Colby as a preceptor and split readings with friends.

I would really recommend taking this course, especially if you are interested in development. This course weaves in economic, political, cultural, and ethnic factors to explain this process, while offering a variety of viewpoints and perspectives.
I would recommend POL 366 (Politics in Africa) over this course.
I would take the course if you are interested in doing a lot of work.

If you are interested in development, this is a tremendous course to take. If you have been or are going to a developing country (or are interested in humanitarian work), this will be especially interesting for you.

If you are interested in the theory side of developmental politics, definitely take this.  Its a bit of a survey course in the sense that you go through a new theory each week on how development is affected.

If you're between this course, International Relations, and American Politics, take this course with Lieberman. You'll learn a lot about an area we dont often study, its pretty fun, and extremely interesting. Having a background in economics/politics/history definitely helps as this may be a bit challenging as your first POL course. Also there are a LOT of readings but theyre good and you dont need to do them all to do well.

If you're interested in international development, I would recommend that you take this course.  Also, keep reading notes, because come finals time, you are definitely not going to want to redo all the readings.

If you've yet to do your WWS core course, this is a solid pick especially if you're  interested in development. Main qualms are the somewhat strangely designed assignments and the country research (which can be dull if you aren't especially interested in your country). But otherwise you should be fine.
Professor Lieberman is a good lecturer and gives a good overview of different theories of development.
Take it as a sophomore or junior.

Take it if you are remotely interested in development. Many big issues get discussed in this class; the topics covered will at least get you start thinking about some of the most complicated problems in the developing countries and  the relationship between developed and developing countries.
Take it if you need it, but not super interesting.
Take it!

Take this class!  If you're at all interested in development, I think you'll find it worthwhile, especially if you've been to/worked in a developing country.  Professor Lieberman is also really approachable!
Take this class- it will change the way you view the world.

Take this class. Everyone interested in development should absolutely take this class, it is about 100 times more interesting than the economics of development and makes you more informed about the world in general. It made me feel more compassionate, less naive and more critical and was one of the most engaging classes I've taken at princeton. Try and keep up with the readings and go to lecture and the papers will be easier.

Take this course if you're interested in developing countries. There's a lot of emphasis on sub-Saharan Africa, and if you've taken African Politics there might be overlap. Fascinating overview of many facets of development, if you haven't had much exposure before. Average quality of teaching and precepts, but the material is perfect if you're interested in the course description. Covers a bit of everything.
Take this course! It is extremely rewarding and engaging and not too difficult. Do be sure to do the readings, because they are a strong focus in exams and readings.
Take this. Especially compared to the other WWS options if you are majoring there, this is the way to go, no questions asked.
Take. One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton.
There's something in this course for everyone, whether they're interested in politics, economics, health, or education.
good
prereqs: Not open to freshmen without permission of instructor..
descrip: This course investigates the key political drivers of human development through careful consideration of theory and comparative analysis. Topics include state-building, colonialism, ethnic conflict, global integration, multi-level governance, and global public health.

title: The Improvising Ensemble
reviews: A wonderful learning experience!

Absolutely take this course. Even if you aren't feeling that confident about your improv abilities, most people are coming in a little uncomfortable. As long as you have strong technique and are willing to listen attentively, you will do just fine. Tony is a great guy who will make you think about music from a different angle than you're probably used to and that is a great experience.
Definitely take it if you are an accomplished performing musician-- no better opportunity to interact with best musicians on campus from different backgrounds,...
Don't take the course if you want to learn improvising techniques.
Dr. Branker is a super cool and chill professor who is also a wonderful musician - take his classes if you can!
Have fun, and express yourself!
If you are looking for a course to just jam and have fun - this isn't the course for you. This is more of an eye-opener class to different modes of improv.
It's not just having fun improvising, you're actually going to learn things. So it's fantastic. Good musical intuition definitely helps. I would maybe say that it's even necessary.
Not all that creative if you have any jazz or improvising experience to be totally honest
TAKE IT!
Take it if you want to be immersed into a musical setting in which you are totally edged out of your musical comfort zone. You will learn a lot about yourself as a musician!
Take this course! It's easy and fun and I learned a lot. Worth it....also it's P/D/F only and fulfilled an LA requirement.
This course is not difficult but it will be very boring unless you are genuinely interested in the topic and want to engage in discussion.
This is an ideal PDF class, a lot of fun, and tremendously helpful musically whatever your background. Take it!
