prereqs: Application and permission of the instructor..
descrip: A course designed to provide instrumental and vocal students with opportunities to reimagine the process of creative music-making through the use of improvisational concepts and activities in group collaboration. Course will feature several guest lecturers/performers and concert presentations focusing on the creation of collectively improvised performances.

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: (Half-Term) - From the Anthropology of Security to the Ethnography of Policing
prereqs: Undergraduate students interested in taking this six-week course may enroll with instructor's permission. Up to five advanced undergraduates can be accepted. Contact myee@princeton.edu for more information..
descrip: Questions of security and insecurities have become prominent in contemporary societies and anthropologists have recently developed research programs approaching the theoretical and political implications of this evolution, including on immigration policies. Yet few empirical studies have been conducted on these issues, and most of the ethnographies of policing have been carried out by sociologists, criminologists, and political scientists. This six-week course will bring together these theoretical and empirical approaches of security and policing from various disciplinary perspectives.

title: Dance Technique and Anatomy of Movement
reviews: Be prepared for an amazing semester.

Be ready to think anatomically about dance.  It can get challenging to think about all the different muscles and bones we have, but it's so worth it to have that sophisticated understanding of your body.
Definitely take this course, and be mentally invested in your time in the studio, and you'll grow so much in such a short period of time.
I would recommend this class to all Dance certificates and people interesting in exploring dance and their body.
If there is one course that you take during your four years here, make it this one.
This class is absolutely amazing, and will work wonders for your dance technique as well as your physical life outside the studio.
You won't regret it if you have a real desire to understand and maximize the potential of your body!
even if you are not a dancer, this course helps you learn about your body, your movement habits, and how to protect yourself from injury. the lessons are invaluable
take it to learn about movement in ways you had never heard of .. the professor is amazing don't miss your opportunity to work with her!
prereqs: DAN207, DAN209, DAN219, DAN220 or equivalent dance experience..
descrip: This course weaves dance technique class with movement laboratories to facilitate an understanding of movement that questions limitations and inspires individual expression. Technique class will integrate ballet and modern techniques while emphasizing values of exploration and risk taking. Movement labs will integrate research in dance kinesiology, somatic techniques and functional anatomy to understand both the potential and limitations of the skeletal and neuromuscular systems. Together these classes will provide freedom in all genres of dance technique and give students knowledge to turn limitations into strengths.

title: Post-War French Social Theory
reviews: I will advice students to do the readings and take critical notes of Prof. Hammoudi take of the text. Also, I will advice any prospective student to engage  the controversies raised by the text through active participation in class discussion. I think that some of the concepts we engaged only became clear or clearer in class discussion.
This course tackles difficult material, but is well worth the effort.
YES
if you really enjoy philosophy, take this. not ideal for the average anthropology major. half the class was graduate students, so if that makes you potentially unsettled, don't take this.
descrip: Using the works of thinkers such as Sartre, Merleau, Ponty, Aron, Ricoeur, Levi-Strauss, Foucault and Bourdieu, the course will present students with some of the conflicting images of Western society as viewed by these thinkers. This course will introduce students to these authors with emphasis on their departure from traditional schools of thought and the consequences of their ideas on the production of knowledge about societies. Topics will include: relation of social thought to literary criticism and theories of social description.

title: The French Enlightenment
reviews: Fantastic!!
I recommend this course to any interested student. Professor Bell's expectation for quality work will push each student to strive create and perhaps achieve better papers and thoughts.
If the topic is of your interest, defiinitely take it.
If you're interested in the readings, take it.

Professor Bell is a fantastic lecturer and seminar leader. He gives good feedback on the papers. He split the seminar into two sections, a discussion of the previous week's readings and a small mini-lecture, an arrangement I like.

Some of the readings were really great and interesting (the novels/satires), others were drier and more difficult to get through... I would recommend this class if you're interested in the works of Rousseau, Voltaire, Diderot, Montesquieu, etc. This seminar focuses more on the written works than the history, though.

Take it! Very interesting to studies of 18th century France, prerevolutionary thought, etc. Found it to be an interesting complement, too, to Linda Colley's survey course on 18th century England as many enlightenment authors engaged with England as a political model.
Take this course - one of the best history seminars available.
descrip: The French Enlightenment was one of the most intensely creative and significant episodes in the history of Western thought. This course will provide an introduction to its major works. Each class meeting will consist of a two-hour discussion, followed by a 45-minute background lecture for the subsequent week's readings.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - American Environmental History
reviews: A lot of people like this course, and it's great for seniors - but you will be engaged as much as you want - so it's not necessarily typical seminar style.
Every student at Princeton needs to know the material that is covered in this course.
It is usually difficult to get into the class, as it is very popular, but if you can get in, definitely take it!
Make sure you want a class with a lot of reading because this is a lot of reading
Take it! You will get out exactly as much as you put in - the Poppers will meet your interest with insights and wry comments. Highly recommended.
There is a lot of readings and the seminars sometimes seem like they are going on forever. Eh.

You can read the books on your own time, and get the same thing out of it; or you can take the class, get an easy grade, but sacrifice 3 hours of every week to watching a married couple argue with each other.
descrip: Explores the diverse connections between America's national development and natural environment. It examines how the U.S. originated, then expanded to cover a continental land mass, and the ways that expansion changed the nation. It analyzes how, why, and with what consequences major parts of the U.S. economy--for instance, farming, energy, services and government--have grown or in shrunk. It looks at how and with what results the U.S. has incorporated different ethnic and racial groups. It shows how, why, and with what outcomes it has historically globalized and conducted its foreign policy, and offers insights into current landscapes.

title: Introduction to Jewish History: Museums and Memory
descrip: This course covers Jewish history from the ancient period through the present, and across various geographies and contexts, using as its lens the tendency for Jews to reflect upon and record their experiences through a variety of documentary and archival forms. We will reflect on Jewish modes of consciously recording customs, cultural contact, violence, migration, and displacement, and the ways in which later Jewish communities interpret and understand the material they have received from the past. A focus on museums and their construction of memory will be a centerpiece of the course.

title: State, Democracy, and Society in Twentieth-Century European Political Thought
descrip: Situated at the intersection of the history of political thought, public law, and social theory, this course examines the ways European thinkers have argued about how, if at all, democratic ideals can be realized in the circumstances of modernity, social complexity and modern capitalism in particular. Evaluation of their arguments about the political forms, especially types of states, and the bases of social integration, nationalism in particular, that democracy might require. Special attention is paid to the evolution of the welfare-state, its critics from Hayek to Foucault, and attempts to save it on a supranational level.

title: Topics in STEP: Greening the US Energy Economy: Meeting the Tech., Policy & Investment Challenge
prereqs: A high level of understanding of energy technologies (basic physics), energy markets, US economic history and discounted cash flow economics will be helpful but is not mandatory. Students with limited background in these areas will need to devote time to background readings..
descrip: Transitioning the US to a clean energy future will involve massive capital commitments in fossil energy, midstream infrastructure, natural gas electric generation, environmental compliance investments and commercial renewable energy technologies. Developing strategies to guide these investments requires integration of technology, public policy and commercial structuring. This course will provide a broad understanding of the key sectors that comprise the US energy industry including commercial technologies, market drivers, regulatory and public policies and sources of financing, financing metrics and risk analysis.

title: The Human Comedy of Anton Chekhov Off and On Stage (In English Translation)
descrip: What is it that endows Chekhov's art with its ability to transcend divides, ensursing its lasting pertinence? Could it be that the secret lies in his unprecedented insight into the theatricality of the human predicament and the role of laughter in it? This course will undertake a comprehensive overview of his mastery of the short story in its development to arrive at a better appreciation of his theater. Unconventional literature cannot be taught conventionally, hence this collaboration between a literary scholar and a theater director.

profs.name: Jorge Alejandro Mendez Seijas, Course Head

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: A surprisingly small amount of work for an upper-level language class.
Although there is some grammar, mostly this class learns through literature, which is fun
It's a good course, and not too time consuming.
Jorge will not be here next year but take this class.  It is not that much work and you will get a lot better at Spanish.
None.
Small classes make it fun if your prof is good
Take it if you're interested in improving your written grammar. Otherwise, you might want to pick one more focused on spoken spanish.
This is a great course for students in an advanced level of Spanish. If you like to practice your writing, you will have a huge opportunity to make it even better.
prereqs: SPA 207 or SPA 209; or another 200-level Spanish course with instructor's permission. Students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score, can take the course only with instructor's permission. Offered both semesters..
descrip: Spanish 307 is an advanced composition course. Its main purpose is to develop and reinforce students' writing and speaking skills in Spanish throughout the study of complex syntactical structure, and a series of drills based on a variety of texts and audiovisual materials. In addition to appreciating the writing style by great Spanish writers, the students are encouraged to incorporate in their writing assignments personal opinions and impressions. By the end of the semester, students will see their Spanish language skills reinforced, particularly those related to their writing.

title: Financial Crises
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 202 or equivalent..
descrip: In this course we will use economic theory and empirical evidence to study the causes of financial crises and the effectiveness of policy responses to these crises. Particular attention will be given to some of the major economic and financial crises in the past century and to the crisis that began in August 2007.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Policymaking in Diverse Societies
descrip: This course investigates how ethnic diversity influences the policymaking process in democratic societies, with a focus on Europe and the United States. We will first address why and how ethnic diversity shapes individuals' and groups' beliefs, preferences, and behaviors in ways that shape the formulation of policy. Next the course will examine the consequences of ethnic diversity on policy areas that all societies confront (such as redistribution and economic development) as well as policy areas that emerge as a result of diversity (such as affirmative action or immigrant integration).

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: Definitely a good class to consider. There is a lot of reading, but nothing truly unmanageable. It is noticeably more work than FRE108 was.
Good Course.
If you want to continue French, learn about some French literature, and don't want intensive grammar, then 207 is a great class to take.
If you want to develop both your ability to read and speak French then this is the course for you! A great introduction to French literature.
If you want to get better at French, take it
It's a good class. You do readings, discuss them in class, and write essays. Not a lot of grammar, which is a good thing.
It's good to improve your French.  If you took AP in high school it's probably the right level for you.  It's interesting and not too much work.
Keep up with the grammar book on your own
Know the material because Professor Lee is so passionate about it that weak analysis or laziness won't fly.
Stay up to date on the readings in order to get more out of the daily discussions.
Take it, there's not much work on a daily basis other than readings and it's a pretty good class.
Take it.
Take this course to better develop your French skills. Do the readings and go to class!
This is a fun course to take. It defintely is not a grammar course, but we read fun stories and watch movies.
This is a great course for improving your French language skills, as well as getting into critical analysis of French literature and film.
Would recommend taking the course with Dr Lee
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: Archaic and Classical Greece
reviews: Awesome course if you're interested in Greek history!
Definitely take this. It's pretty easy, and Flower is an outstanding lecturer. He makes the material fun and engaging, and he's such a nice guy.
Do it if you want the HA requirement.
Do the readings; they will give you almost everything you need, while Professor Flower will provide the rest and answer any questions you might have.

Even if you have never learned ancient Greek history before, take this class! Professor Flower is so engaging, so the lectures are never boring. The readings - Herodotus, Thucydides, etc. - are also great. The material covered is all things you should know.
Go to lecture, you don't want to miss Professor Flower's great lectures
Good HA to take.  As it is with many intro level courses though, the curve isn't great.
Good PDF course.
Great class, not a lot of work, very interesting
Great course.  Not hard if you do the readings and take good lecture notes.  Flower knows how to organize history surveys.
Great survey course of Greek history.
Great survey of Greek history, very informative, very interesting.
I would definitely recommend staying on top of the readings and coming to precept prepared. Also, be open-minded to think of things in ways that you hadn't previously.
I would definitely recommend taking this course.  If you do the readings and attend lecture it is easy to do well.
I would recommend this class for people outside of this major as well.
I would recommend to absolutely attend all lectures, but not worry terribly about being too in depth with the readings; just scan and get a general idea, especially when he assigns a lot.

I would say it is definitely worth your time and is enjoyable. The reading is not overwhelming and is at many times enjoyable. If you have any interest at all in ancient Greece it would be worthwhile to take this course.
I would strongly recommend that you take this class, definitely attend lectures and try to do all the readings, because much of the assigned material is very interesting.

ITS A GREAT COURSE. the first day, we were told that we would be given enough reading to keep us interested and learning, but not an overload, and that's been kept throughout the course. definitely one of my favorite classes at Princeton-- its awesome, its great, you'll have fun learning about greek symposiums aka parties. learn a lot, and prof flower is great
If you have any interest in learning about ancient Greece--take this class!
If you like ancient history, take this class. Flower is fantastic, and loves the subject so it feels very real. Not too hard, either, so if you need a relatively easy HA go for this one.
If you're interested in Greek History, definitely take this course.
Keep up with the readings and you'll be fine.
Know the reading.
Take it if interested.
Take it!

Take it!  Being a COS major, I honestly just wanted to fulfill a distribution requirement, but I ended up really liking the class and looking forward to lectures! Prof. Flower is adorable and really enthusiastic about the subject. Readings are semi-optional (but interesting!) -- just go to lecture.

Take this class if you are interested in Greece but not in taking the time to learn Ancient languages/be a real Classics major.  The topic is great, it is well taught, and the workload is quite manageable.

Take this course!! Professor Flower is an excellent lecturer and makes the material very interesting.  The reading is very manageable and the two quizzes help reinforce the material before the midterm and final.  As a science major, this was by far the best history class I have taken.
Take this course.

The course is a very engaging evaluation of Greek history ranging from pre-history to Alexander the Great. For anyone interested in Classics, taking the course is highly recommended. The instructors make the past history relevant to modern times and make it easy to compare to other societies and periods.
This course is definitely worthwhile- go for it!
This is a great course taught by people who really love the subject. I would recommend going to lecture and doing all of the readings, they really do help.
YES take it! Prof. Flower is such an amazing lecturer and the information was so interesting
provides a great base for history.
take this class
descrip: The social, political, and cultural history of ancient Greece from ca.750 B.C. through the time of the Peloponnesian War (404 B.C.). Special attention is paid to the emergence of the distinctively Greek form of political organization, the city state, and to democracy, imperialism, social practices, and cultural developments. Emphasis is placed on study of the ancient sources, methods of source analysis, and historical reasoning.

title: Princeton and Slavery
reviews: Take this course if you are willing to do a lot of work. If you are excited by research and know that you will feel a sense of accomplishment after constructing a history of the university than you will enjoy this class.
take it.
descrip: Research seminar focused on Princeton University's historical connections to the institution of slavery. The class will work toward creating a report that details the slave-holding practices of Princeton faculty and students, examines campus debates about slavery, and investigates whether money derived from slave labor contributed to the early growth of the school. Class will meet in Mudd Library.

title: Geological Constraints on Climate Sensitivity
descrip: Earth system and climate sensitivity relate changes in greenhouse gas concentrations and other radiative forcers to changes in temperature, both in Earth's past and in the future. The Cenozoic record provided by paleo-temperature and paleo-CO2 proxies can constrain these parameters and thus also the projected response of the planet to human-induced changes in greenhouse gas concentrations. This course will explore the concepts of climate and Earth system sensitivity, the methods and records of paleo-temperature and paleo-carbon dioxide proxies in the Cenozoic, and the statistical challenges of inferring sensitivities from these proxies.

title: Light, Camera, Action
descrip: See website

title: Approaches to American History
reviews: 60% of grade is precept. Show up on time, come prepared (having done careful reading), and you will do well

Absolutely hands-down take this class, especially if you are a history major!! This is probably the single most helpful course you could take in your first two years here for anyone that's going to be working with primary documents in any field. And if you ever have the opportunity to take any course with Rebecca Rix, absolutely do it!!!
Do not take this if you're not a HIS major.

I came into the course thinking I wanted to major in History and that the class would convince me even more. Unfortunately, it had the exact opposite effect and I am now majoring in something else. The guest lectures are interesting and a good exposure to other Professors in the department, but they often feel unrelated or irrelevant to the material discussed in precept or on the essays, which is the bulk of the course. I do in fact enjoy reading primary sources, which was another main reason for taking the course, but the ones in the course packets are EXTREMELY dry (think trial records, tables of wage statistics..) which really put me off this kind of history research. Precept, which is 2/3 of the class, was also boring - try to get into Prof. Rix's precept and not Prof. Thompson's if you can. As strange as the format of the essays was (about half your argument needed to be made in the footnotes) I did enjoy the challenge of learning to write in a new style.
It's a good course to take if you are interested in majoring in History. Participation is a huge factor in the grade.
Make sure to read the readings carefully-- mark the ones that are particularly important/ discussed a lot in precept, because those readings will be helpful to you when you are writing your paper.
Read over the readings over a couple of days instead of just the night before. It helps to have those extra hours to think about the sources before coming to precept.

TAKE THIS CLASS. It's a lot of work but so worth it, whether you are a history major or going into a different department. These are skills you need to have. Also, get Professor Rix as your preceptor. You will thank your lucky stars - she is the best editor, adviser and precept leader I have had at this school and that is saying something.
Take it! It's great.
You don't need to be a future HIS major to love this course.  If you like writing, close reading, and precept, this is a course for you.
it's a lot of reading, but it's manageable.
prereqs: First priority is given to Sophomores..
descrip: An intensive introduction for history concentrators, particularly those who plan to take their independent work seriously. Students will immerse themselves in documents of three events: the making of Upton Sinclair's "The Jungle" in turn-of-the-century Chicago; the Denmark Vesey slave uprising conspiracy in 1820s Charleston; and the Stamp Act crisis over taxation and imperial authority, 1765-66. Interpretation of documents, framing of historical arguments, and construction of historical explanations will be stressed. Lectures introduce a basic vocabulary of analysis.

title: Fundamentals of Queueing Theory
reviews: A fair class... hard material but easy grading. There's not really much to say about it except that it's kinda like an extension of ORF 309.
Definitely worth it! If possible, they should read the material before hand, makes it easier to follow during the lectures

Difficult class - be prepared to tackle math!  May not be of interest to non-major, but very strong ORF course if you are interested the operations research side of the department. Prof. Massey is a great professor.
It's a comfortable environment to gain more understanding of applied probability
Prof Massey is super nice and you can feel free to ask him anything you don't understand. Be prepared to handle maths, mainly probability. A study group is recommended.
Read over lecture notes after lecture to make sure you are on top of what is going on. Challenging but then you feel like you actually know something once you are done with it.
Take it if you like ORF 309.
Take it! A lot of application to 309 material.
The course is very math-y, so if you didn't have the greatest time in 309, this is a very difficult course. Go to office hours and actually understand the material-- it helps a lot.

This course is harder than ORF 409 and caused me more late nights than ORF 309 did. It's an interesting and rewarding class but only take it if you're willing to spend a solid amount of time on the work
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental results of queueing theory. Topics covered include the classical traffic, offered load, loss and delay stochastic models for communication systems. Through concrete examples and motivations we discuss the theory of Markov chains, Poisson processes and Monte-Carlo simulation. Fundamental queueing results such as the Erlang blocking and delay formulae, Little's law and Lindley's equation are presented. Applications are drawn from communication network systems, inventory management, and optimal staffing.

title: Hispanic Studies: Introduction to Cultural Analysis
prereqs: Another SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to the analysis of contemporary cultural texts (narrative, poetry, film, photography, painting, music) from Latin America and Spain, with the support of various theoretical ideas (metafiction, intertextuality, death of the author, the other, mourning and melancholia, the uncanny, orientalism). The course's main objective is to provide students with a set of strong analytical skills, which will be of great help in 300-level literature/culture courses.

title: Architects in Quest of the Ideal City
descrip: See website

title: Tropical Agriculture
reviews: It's a great class! Cheryl is so warm and friendly, and has so many experiences from which to learn from.
One of my favorite classes in Kenya, because we got to talk to farmers and really felt like we were doing something.
This class is truly like no other. It's so interesting and fun and engaging and I am so glad that I was able to participate in it. Cheryl is the best!

This is a great course!  Taught by some of the coolest people I have ever met.  It's back-loaded, but that might have been good because it was the last course in Kenya and you're usually burnt out at that point.  The labs (field work) involve talking to farmers and going out and visiting real farms, so that's a really cool learning experience.....take it,
This was a really great course!  I think they should try to do stuff like this (more courses intersecting with the community) more in the Kenya study abroad program.
prereqs: EEB 211 and EEB 321..
descrip: Kenya has some of the most diverse set of crops and farming systems in Africa allowing students to compare productivity, diversity, and ecological processes. Students will spend their time exploring the varied agro-ecosystems, crops, livestock, climates, and soils under which agriculture is practiced in Kenya. The course includes key readings and discussions, intensive field sampling, GIS applications, and modeling. In addition, students will be exposed to the various ecological processes and ecosystem services provided by or interfered with by agriculture. Limited to students in the Tropical Biology and Sustainability Program in Kenya.

title: Optimal Learning
reviews: Enjoyable topic, even for a non-ORFE. I thought the project was the most interesting part.
Great class, new field, great material, you'll learn a lot
I would take this class if you need a departmental elective. Pretty straightforward and not that difficult.
Only take if you're interested in the OR side of ORFE. A cool class, though -- you get to learn about a field that has been greatly impacted by Prof. Powell.
Optimal Learning feels repetitive at times, but the class establishes a good framework and develops useful tools for solving a fairly large array of problems.

Powell prefers looking at applications rather than probability/real math, so if you really enjoyed 309 then this might not be the class for you. Don't pay for the textbook, there is a PDF of it floating around. This is a relatively easy ORF departmental, if that is what you are looking for.
Take it you are willing to go to lectures and want to have few problem sets.

Take the class with a friend, that'll help when you have to pair up for the final project. The class was a good balance (workload wise) in that it didn't have a final. The final project was really interesting and Prof.Powell was very helpful in making the whole thing much more meaningful.
Take the course. Definitely read the text book since it closely follows what goes on in the course.

Take this course if you want to learn something that you can use in your every day life.  optimal learning problems occur everywhere and taking this class has really taught me how to approach these situations.
Worth taken.
start on the final project early!
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309.
descrip: Optimal learning addresses the challenge of collecting information efficiently when information is expensive. Applications include topics such as finding the best price for a product, identifying the best treatment for a disease, tuning the parameters in a bidding policy, or choosing the best player for a sports team. Students learn how to formulate a learning problem, identify a belief model, and quantify the value of information. The course covers online and offline learning problems, and introduces students to a range of policies for collecting information.

title: Beginner's French II
reviews: Be sure to complete the supplementary exercises. Even though she didn't check them, it was still good practice.
Do the homework, study everyday, and do well on the tests.
Feel free to ask for individual help from the professor - the class can move quickly, but the professor adjusts to the different areas the students are struggling with.
Go to every class
I mean you don't really have a choice do you....
I would definitely recommend taking french with Professor Hart if you want to take a french class.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has very little knowledge of French or none at all (like myself). Extremely helpful and easy to pick up.
If you really want to learn it, enroll in an undergrad section and take it 5 days a week.

If you took FRE 101, you have no choice but to take this as well. As someone who has taken quite a few other languages at Princeton, I can say that French (especially FRE 102) is not particularly well taught. If you really want to learn French, go ahead and take it. If you are not actually passionate about French, take another language or don't take a language at all.
If you're taking FRE102, I recommend Rachel highly.
If you've taken 101, might as well continue. Fun and fairly low-stress.
It is a great class to take
It's easy to do well on the tests but you need to spend a lot of time if you really want to be more skilled at the language itself.
Keep up with the grammar, and you should be fine.
Keep up with the reading and assignments, as they proceed at a regular but quick pace.
Listen and don't speak english in class
Participate. I had a fun class in which many of us participated and talked to each other, which really helped our learning and made me excited to come to class.
Practice daily and go to language tables! Immerse yourself in the language.
Professor Hart is amazing!
Rachel is a fantastic teacher - take it with her if you can
Read the textbook and really give effort in developing your ability rather than just try to get the grades.
Take this course to get a solid foundation for the language and have fun getting to know / laughing at 15 other Princetonians trying to speak French with you
prereqs: FRE 101 or Permission Of Instructor. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless FRE 102 is successfully completed..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to enable you to achieve intermediate communication proficiency in French. All four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing will be actively practiced in realistic communicative situations, through a variety of activities designed to help you strengthen newly acquired vocabulary and grammatical structures. You will learn to talk about events and people, construct narratives in French and develop reading and writing skills that will be a foundation for literacy in the target language. There is a wide use of authentic material from France and the Francophone world throughout the course.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research I is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Asset Pricing II: Stochastic Calculus and Advanced Derivatives
reviews: Go for it if you want to learn risk neutral/forward pricing, see variance reduction techniques.
Good course in basics of stoch calc applications to finance.
I would recommend this course to math or ORFE PhD students who are looking for a career in the academia. I would not recommend the course to MFin students.
I would recommend you to learn stochastic calculus before you take this class.

If you don't know the material already, prepare to be dragged into a vicious cycle of not understanding -> taking forever to complete the problem sets -> having no time left over to study -> falling further benhind... ad infinitum. My advice: convince the prof to make homework just 10% of the grade, and focus your time on studying. Don't waste hours on proofs and coding.

If you haven't seen stochastic calculus before, then be prepared for a wild ride. Course moves very fast so keep up to the extent possible. Preceptor is very accepting of students' inferior intellects.
If you want to learn stochastic calculus applied to finance as well as ways to price some derivatives , you should take this course.
It is a very good course. The materials are important. Both the professor and the preceptor are great.
Keep up with subject matter at beginning, the rest will build off of it.
Must do this one.
Start reading up on covariance matrices NOW.
Take it
Take it!
Take this class if you don't know much about stochastic calculus but don't except very advanced modeling or techniques if you are already knowledgeable
Take this class! The problem sets and exams are very fair, and Professor Rudloff is a very good teacher.

The subject matter is important for finance, and it could have been a great class if not for the average level of instruction. This class is all about stochastic calculus, and if you haven't had prior experience with that, good luck; you're mostly on your own. The professor, perhaps due to time constraints, doesn't do a thorough job of hammering into us the fundamentals of stochastic calculus before rushing on to advanced applications of stochastic calculus. Those of us new to stochastic calculus spent the rest of the term just trying to catch up, at times forgetting and having to re-learn basic stochastic calculus tools even as far down as Week 12. Then there were those who took fixed income and/or stochastic calculus in the Fall term and basically coasted through the semester and found everything easy, some finished the 80-minute midterm in 30 mins! It's not their fault of course. 

The professor was nice but I think she had difficulty understanding the troubles of someone who's completely new to stochastic calculus, especially those of us who've spent many years working and are not yet re-acquainted with basic calculus, much less stochastic. When you ask her really basic questions she sometimes finds it hard to explain in detail because the issue is too fundamental or obvious to her. The TA didn't seem like he cared too much about the class, although he is pretty good when he's there. He doesn't prepare for precepts and wings it, and he proudly states so - it usually works out but it leaves you with impression that it's a waste of his time, so you feel like it's a crime to intrude on him to ask basic stochastic calculus questions too.

The only thing that saved me from total ruin was help from classmates who've done stochastic calculus. Also get a good book and do some serious self-study.
This is the course that they should take.
Useful but a bit late for interviews.
Very doable course in stochastic calculus.
required course.  good introduction to stochastic calculus.
descrip: Course covers the pricing and hedging of advanced derivatives, including topics such as exotic options, greeks, interest rate derivatives and credit derivatives, as well as covering the basics of stochastic calculus necessary for finance. Designed for Masters students.

title: Calculus II
reviews: .Realistically, most people take this course because they have to. If you don't have to take it, avoid it. For a QR, look elsewhere.
Avoid this class if you can. If MAT 175 is an option, take that instead. From what I hear, they have actual teachers.
Do all the problem sets and go to the instructors if you don't understand something.
Don't take it unless you have to; the class is hard and none of the professors are very good.
Don't take it unless you need it. It's just a poorly taught course which sets unfairly hard exams. Unfortunate but true.
Get a good teacher. It will make or break class.
Go to McGraw and ask questions when you are unsure!
Go to McGraw, and youtube concepts (PatrickJMT and Khan academy taught me a lot this year).
Go to office hours.
I would advise another student to review notes often and stay on top of everything.
I would recommend this course, and would advise not relying just on lectures/classes in order to get all of the information but also reaching out to the outside sources provided.

If there's one thing you do before taking this course, it's downloading "Calculus Lifesaver" by Adrian Banner. My only regret is not getting ahold of this sooner than a week before the final. IT LITERALLY SAVED MY LIFE. You need to buy this book, I don't know why it isn't the textbook. Overall, this isn't a super hard course, but definitely a step up from MAT 103. Stay on top of things, and do lots of independent practice. Right before the midterm when we learn improper integrals, things ramp up a LOT. You NEED to do independent practice on improper integrals and series before the midterm or else you will not understand them well enough.
If you are interested in math, then this is a good enough course to get you started. If it is a requirement, then you have to do it.
If you don't have to, don't take it.

If you have not taken BC Calculus before, you should be prepared to put extra time in. Go to office hours for help with problem sets even if you only have a few questions because it will save you a lot of time.
It is often a necessity to take this course and I guess it depends on who the student gets as a teacher but Nick Reichert was great so I loved the course.
It will certainly help to have taken AP Calc in high school. I feel that a great part of this course was self-taught, so it'd be much easier if you've seen these topics before.
Just take it
Only take it if you have to
Professor Georgieva is very good.
Read textbook and use other resources. Do not rely on lectures alone
Stay on top of everything and review notes from earlier in the course.
Stay on top of homework!
Study. Study. Study!
Take it if you must.
Take it only if you need to.
Take this class if you need to complete BSE requirements. This course is much tougher than MAT 103 and no matter which preceptor you will end up with you will sometimes get confused.

Take this course right after 103 if possible. Avoid if you are not too interested in applications of mathematics. I personally took it hoping for some insight into theoretical math, but the course is really just a 'bag of tricks' course, showing you how to tackle particular formulas or equations that might crop up.

The course has its ups and downs. The first half of the semester is far more difficult than the second half, but with help from a tutor or by working through lots of example problems on the blackboard page the topics and concepts can be clarified.

The course is not extremely difficult. What you have to be careful of are the exams because they will have much more difficult problems than you will see in either the problem sets or the quizzes. As far as understanding mathematical processes, Nick makes those very clear and makes it simple to do problems that you see throughout the year on problem sets and quizzes.
The knowledge provided in this course is valuable for a variety of careers, and I would argue that it is worth the time spent.
This class is a lot more difficult than first semester calculus. The work is manageable though and there is a lot of support.

This is a course you will probably have to take if you are going into engineering. Unfortunately you'll just have to suck it up and use outside resources like Khan Academy and the old MAT104 website to learn the material.
Use of blackboard for studying.
Work hard
You should definitely read the textbook and to practice exams!
attend office hours, practice other problems if you have time
read the textbook!
take this preceptor
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Continuation of MAT103. Topics include techniques of integration, arclength, area, volume, convergence of series and improper integrals, L'Hopital's rule, power series and Taylor's theorem, introduction to differential equations and complex numbers.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - From the Blank Page to On-the-Air: Creating a Television Drama Series
reviews: Apply if you're interested! It's a wonderful opportunity.
Be prepared to work closely and a lot with your group members! Make sure the pilot idea you select is one EVERYONE is passionate about. SPACE YOUR WRITING OUT OVER THE WEEK.
Be willing to put the work in, since you'll only get as much valuable feedback as you put in effort.
Great class, take it if you want to write a pilot.
If this course is ever taught again, TAKE IT
Take it!
Take it.
if you want to learn how to write a pilot for tv, take this course!
prereqs: This course is limited to advanced writing students who have previously completed at least two 200-level writing courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: The class will serve as a writer-intensive 'boot camp' where students will be immersed in the process of creating and crafting a one-hour television pilot. Each class will include an instructional breakdown of the television writing process, followed by group discussions and individual in-class writing assignments. Students will be put on 'writing staff' teams, comprised of three or four members who, in collaboration, will complete a pilot script by the end of the semester. Though classes will focus heavily on writing, some attention will also be devoted to the business of television itself.

title: Climate Change: Scientific Basis, Policy Implications
reviews: Definitely take it! Prof Oppenheimer is a fantastic lecturer and really cares about the students.

For someone looking for an intro of both the science and the policy of climate change, good. For someone who is has spent time learning about on either one or the other, material may be a little redundant, that said, for such an important issue, I think it was still valuable to relearn/cement the concepts and issues relating to climate change.
Good course, but not highly technical.  Engineering and science major may feel the information presented is basic.
Great class!
I think everyone needs to take a course with Professor Oppenheimer at some point.
I would definitely recommend the course to other Geosciences majors.

I would not recommend this class, especially if you've taken environmental classes before. It is very similar, and doesn't really discuss anything deeply. If anything, CHM333 is more rigorous and I think teaches the science better. ENV201 was even more enjoyable. MAE226 is good as well and focuses a lot on adaptation/mitigation/technology.
I have no complaints about the professor. Precept is useless, but it often is for these types of classes. 
It was not difficult at all if you're used to science, and not too much work. If that's what you like, go for it. I personally like that too, but I learned absolutely nothing from this course. Usually that doesn't bother me, but I was very dissatisfied in this case because I felt the class had much more potential. Other environmental courses are much better.
It's a small class so you'll get a lot of chances to ask personal questions and interact with Oppenheimer individually. A bit repetitive in content, but great overview to the climate change issue.
It's pretty good and rather easy, but I don't entirely understand the hype.
Prof. Oppenheimer is a funny and engaging lecturer, and the class is very relevant to today and not too much work. Take it!
Really was bummed about this course. All the instructors are great people but I just got the impression that the course was lazily taught. Hopefully it will improve in the future.
Take it, if just to interact with Professor Oppenheimer. He's great.

The problem sets will take some time, but they're quite easy (at least after the first one or two). I found the midterm very difficult. You come away with a really good understanding of climate change and the big issues surrounding it.
This course is most useful, I think, for people who don't know much about the science or the policy and want to learn. For someone who knows a lot about both, it's not as useful.
This is a crucial subject to learn about, and this is an excellent class to do so!

This is a good class to learn about climate change and policy.  As a chemical engineer, I did not find the science particularly difficult to understand, although some of it was new to me, having never taken a GEO course before.  Professor Oppenheimer is a good teacher and I'm glad I took the course.

This is one of those classes that you should take if you can because the professor is just amazing. My only regret from this class was the lack of emphasis on policy, and some organizational problems.
very good-strongly recommend if you're interested in the topic
prereqs: MAT101-102 and either CHM 201-202 or PHY 101-102 or Permission of Instructor.
descrip: This course explores the causes and consequences of human-induced climate change, and the range of potential policy responses. By studying the natural climate system and how it is influenced by human perturbation, we will develop a quantitative understanding of how climate is expected to change in the future as greenhouse gases accumulate in the atmosphere. The course also examines scientific themes that should frame any public policy based on risk management, including irreversibility, uncertainty, and surprise. We will also examine the ways in which people, governments and other institutions are actually responding to climate change.

title: Statics of Structures
reviews: Branko is an incredible professor and you will definitely enjoy his lectures.
Chances are you have to take this, but it is a really good course! It made me happy that I decided to do civil (structural) engineering.
If you're a CEE major, this course is amazing! It is by far my favorite class so far and Professor Glisic is a great professor. Super interesting and practical knowledge.

If you're taking this, you likely need it as a departmental. It will be super enjoyable, will really change your perception of structural engineering, and will actually make you feel like an actual engineer who understands how structures work! It won't always be easy but you'll learn a lot!
It's time-consuming but well-taught.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Develops notions of internal forces and displacements, and instructs students how to design and analyze structures. Presents the fundamental principles of structural analysis, determination of internal forces, and deflections under the static load conditions, and introduces the bending theory of plane beams and the basic energy theorems. The theory of the first order will be developed for continuous girders, frames, arches, suspension bridges, and trusses, including both statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Basic principles for construction of influence lines and determination of extreme influences will be presented.

title: Advanced Questions in Photography
reviews: If you're interested in pursuing your photography, this is a great course to build your portfolio and undertake a substantial independent project
It's basically like taking an independent study course, but with guidance from a great photographer.
Take the class.
The quality of the course depends on the instructor. So research the instructor before deciding to take it.
prereqs: VIS 211 or 212 or 313 or VIS 315 or VIS 316.
descrip: Student- initiated projects in photography will be developed in close conjunction with the instructor. Each student will explore technical, formal and critical issues pertinent to their specific work. Emphasis will be on understanding and addressing social and historical context as well as presentation strategies.

title: Early Modern Philosophy
reviews: Easy/interesting way to get an EC. Garber is a great guy and knows the material really well. Not a stressful class at all yet still intellectually stimulating.
If you are interested in the topics, definitely take this class. You will read the books extremely slowly and carefully, and will really understand them.
If you're interested in the history of modern philosophy, this is an excellent way to explore the ideas that paved the way for folks like Kant and Hume.
Take this course if you have any interest in Early Modern Philosphy
prereqs: Open to upperclassmen without prerequisite; though previous coursework in philosophy, politics, or history of science. Students without previous experience in one of these areas should consult instructor.
descrip: Hobbes and Spinoza: Metaphysics, Politics, and Religion. Hobbes began a revolution in our understanding of the material world, human beings and society, and Spinoza extended it in even more radical directions. In this course, we will examine the interconnections between metaphysics and natural philosophy, politics and religion in these two original and highly influential thinkers.

title: Themes in World History, 1300-1850
reviews: N/A
You should take it only if you re considering doing at least 80% of the readings.
descrip: This seminar covers classical and contemporary debates and historiography of world history, from the making of world systems, to the rise and fall of empires, to global revolution and the onset of modernity.

title: Quantitative Investment Management
descrip: A survey of central topics in the area of investment management and financial planning. Integrating pricing methodologies with financial planning models. Linking asset and liability strategies to achieve investment goals and meet liabilities. We model the enterprise as a multi-stage stochastic program with decision strategies.

title: Computational Practices: Focus Sustainability
prereqs: Restricted to ARC concentrators or CEE Concentrators in the Architecture and Engineering track only. CEE students will need to request permission to add the course. No prerequisites are required except curiosity, and an interest in making and computation..
descrip: This design seminar explores sustainable design/analysis methods and methodologies through the lens of computation. Today, the general use of digital design technologies has moved away from the initial focus on representation of information and digital form towards the act of processing/computing, and thus it's integration into the design process. This seminar will focus on this advanced state and explore the design integration of computation for sustainable means.

title: Analysis in a Single Variable
reviews: A very good, enjoyable course if you can/want to do mathematical proofs. Much of the material is cumulative so don't fall behind.

MAT 215 is going to be at least a fairly difficult class. Prepare to spend many hours on the homeworks each week, as they are the crux of the class - by doing the homeworks, you not only learn the materials, but you learn how to write proofs, which is the reason this class is so crucial.
Make sure you have enough time to take this course
Take it if you want to major in math. Otherwise, don't (because it will screw up your GPA! :p )
Take it with Mark. He's the BOSS.
Very difficult and time-consuming for people who are new to pure math or proofs, and still difficult and time-consuming for those familiar with proofs.
descrip: An introduction to the mathematicsal discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Russian Classics On (and Off) The Soviet-Stalinist Stage
descrip: An examination of four 19th-century Russian classics (two dramas, two prose works) in their adaptation for the Soviet-era stage. After a survey of Soviet theater in 1920s-30s, two famous productions by Meyerhold from the mid-1920s will be analyzed along with their source texts: Gogol's Revizor and Griboedov's Gore Ot Uma. Shostakovich's scandalous opera Lady Macbeth Of Mtsensk, based on Leskov, will be followed by an adaptation of Tolstoy (students will choose between them): either Prokofiev's opera War and Peace, or several projects for Resurrection. Films and DVDs used extensively where available.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering
reviews: Read the abstracts before the talks, maybe even do some background research.
The graduate seminar is very useful to learn about current research being conducted in a number of different areas.
These seminars are valuable for learning about current ongoing research.
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Stochastic Control and Stochastic Differential Games
descrip: Review of (forward) stochastic differential equations. Introduction to Backward Stochastic Differential Equations (BSDE's). Stochastic control=dynamic programming, HJB equations and connection with BSDE's. Stochastic differential games=Nash equilibriums. Isaacs condition and BSDE's. Applications of stochastic control and stochastic games to recent research results in Finance.

title: Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies - 1968 Mexico - the Arts and Politics of Social Change
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission. The course will be taught in Spanish..
descrip: 1968 was a year of turbulence and creative political innovation throughout the world. The eruption of powerful student movements and counter-cultures produced a rich stage for thinking about the relations between arts and politics in the elaboration of social change. Although we will read about the events of 1968 that occurred in other places like Paris and Prague, this course focuses on the arts and writings related to the events that took place in Mexico. Social change, political innovation, and creative thought are themes that we will explore through essays, literature, and film related to the events.

title: Society and Its Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Public Finance II
descrip: This course examines the economics of the public sector, with a focus on externalities, transfer programs, social insurance, and publicly provided goods. Special attention is given to study of research designs and econometric methods used in applied analysis.

title: Acting and Directing in Musical Theater
reviews: Just take if you can.
TAKE IT!!!!!
Take this course! Professor Rando is absolutely incredible! If you love to perform or direct musical theater, take this class!
Take this course, John Rando is amazing!
This is worth every second.
This opportunity is amazing.  Anyone interested in musical theatre would be a fool to miss this course.
prereqs: THR 201, THR 301, THR 311, THR 366 or THR 411 or MUS 241 or significant experience in the musical form. Please contact the Program Director, Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@princeton.edu.
descrip: A practical, hands-on introduction to acting and directing in musical theater. The course will require students to prepare songs and scenes from selected musicals with an eye to how best to approach the particular challenges the scene presents.

title: Blood, Sex, and Oil: The Caucasus
descrip: The Caucasus has served as a contested borderland from time immemorial and has fascinated outsiders for nearly as long. It is today a tense and explosive region. This course surveys the history of both the north and south Caucasus. It begins with an overview of the region's geography, peoples, and religions. It then examines in more detail the history of the Caucasus from the Russian conquest to the present day. Topics covered include ethnic and religious coexistence and conflict, imperial rule, imagery and identity, literature, Sovietization, the formation of national identities, and pipeline politics.

title: Mineralogy
prereqs: Introductory Chemistry and one Geosciences introductory course (GEO 202, 203, or freshman seminar related to the field of geoscience) or instructor permission..
descrip: A survey of the structure and crystal chemistry of major rock-forming minerals. Topics include: symmetry, crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals, mineral thermodynamics, systematic mineralogy, and techniques of modern mineralogy.

title: Light in Artistic Expression
descrip: See website

title: Intermediate Japanese II
reviews: It's a lot of work, but if you enjoy speaking/learning Japanese,  it's absolutely worth it
Take it, but expect learning Japanese more on your own once you transition from Nakama to Tobira. Keep up with the grammar points.
difficult
prereqs: JPN 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: The course aims at a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points covered in JPN 101, 102, and 105. It is also intended to give students advanced vocabulary and expressions through aural-oral drills, readings, and written exercises. Emphasis will increasingly be on reading, but oral work will still comprise fundamental aspect of the course.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature will be discussed.

title: Topics in Labor Economics
reviews: As-is, take this course if you want to do labor economics.
descrip: The course surveys both the theoretical literature and the relevant empirical methods and results in selected current research topics in labor economics.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Anyone who is interested in entrepreneurship really should take this course.
Definitely take this course. Unfortunately, the current professor is leaving, but if you are still interested in entrepreneurship, go for it.
Enjoy it!
Great class to take! But Zschau won't be there next year... Also, this class attracts a lot of overachieving MBA types.
Great class. Unlike anything else offered at Princeton. Definitely worthwhile to take.
Holy shit this class was incredible.
Hopefully Zschau's replacement is a good one because this class was incredible. TAKE THIS COURSE!
I hope someone can replace Ed Zschau, but it will be tough. If someone can make the course similar, I would highly suggest it.
I know Zschau won't be teaching this again, but if the next professor is half as good you should definitely take this course.
I would highly highly recommend the course.  One of the best professors I had at Princeton.
If you only take one class at Princeton, take this one -- it was absolutely incredible, honest, life-changing, and practical. Don't miss out.
It's all about participation in class. However, still worth it to take it - so eye opening.
It's sad that Zschau is leaving us...

One of the best courses I have ever taken?Prof. Zschau is an amazing mentor, educator, and citizen. I was so happy to learn from him and the variety of speakers and sources from the class. The course truly changed my life.

One of the best courses I've ever taken. Personally, I was out of my comfort zone when taking this class, but it was definitely worth it. I learned so much, and I've met very few professors that command as much respect as Ed Zschau. You definitely don't need to want to be/be starting a start-up to appreciate what this class has to offer, and I think everyone should take this class.
Pivotal experience at Princeton
Prof. Zschau will no longer be teaching the course but I believe the content will still be as engaging. Strongly Recommended.

Professor Zschau unfortunately will not be teaching the course again. However, he has found a replacement who he believes in. You really learn a lot from the case method; the course teaches you how to think.

Professor Zschau's lectures (read: case studies) were fantastic.  I wish the class had been smaller to allow for better participation, often feeling like my hand was passed over routinely, but otherwise am hard pressed to think of any other lectures I've enjoyed more at this school.  It is unfortunate that this is Ed Zschau's last semester; I don't know who is replacing him, but hopefully they will be up to the task--Zschau has left large shoes to fill.  Regardless, I would still take this course, as the material is quite good on its own.
Start your papers early and think of a few pertinent points to raise in class after doing readings!
Stay engaged by reading all of the cases.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
Take it! You won't regret it!
Take it.
Take this course, the more you put in the more you get out of the course
Take. This. Course.
The best class I have taken at Princeton. Hands down. All because of Ed Zschau
The fella teaching it next year is super interesting and experienced.  Should be solid.

The reason this course was amazing was because of Ed Zschau. The new guy is impressive on paper, but he won't be Ed Zschau. Don't fool yourself into thinking that you're taking the same course. Now, EGR491 is just another one of the Keller Center's "sounds great learn nothing" courses.
This class will definitely give you a new perspective on life and business. I would definitely recommend this class.
You'll never get Zschau ever again, but this course is still unbelievable. An awesome senior year course.

Zschau's teaching is absolutely central to this course.  The way he commands the classroom totally inspires you about the course material.  I can imagine that now that he's leaving, the course - which is absolutely dependent on participation and teacher guidance - could lose its life-changing aspect.  Nonetheless the material is fascinating and the opportunity to reflect on companies growth is unique at Princeton.
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application. Applications are available at ACE-25 in the E-Quad. All applications must be completed and returned by November 27, 2012..
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologies for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Arts and Cultural Policy in Contemporary Cuba
descrip: This course will address the creation, promotion and consumption of art and culture in Cuba and will analyze the policy framework within which this takes place. It will examine the goals of the revolutionary government with respect to literacy and cultural democracy and will review how these objectives have been realized through changing circumstances since 1959. It will ask how cultural policy relates to diversity, emigration, tourism, the preservation of heritage, and the fraught histories of imperialism and nationalism.

title: French Literature: Approaches to the Language of Literary Texts
reviews: If you want a French literature course that will improve your command of the language, give you a chance to read interesting books, and won't be too demanding, take this one.
It's a pretty good class if you want to be exposed to a wide variety of topics in French literature. Be aware: there is a lot of poetry!
Lots of reading so don't fall behind... although not all the reading is necessary to stay on top of things. But do them if you can because they're great!
Take after 207 or after having recently taken a French course with lots of writing, reading, and SPEAKING. I hadn't taken French in years and it was somewhat difficult to participate fully.
Take it if you like literature and writing papers.
Take it! The readings are interesting and provide a great introduction to French literature and I felt my writing in French improved.
prereqs: FRE 107 or FRE 108 or Permission of Instructor. Course conducted entirely in French..
descrip: This course is meant to introduce students to great works of French literature from a range of historical periods and to provide them with methods for literary interpretation through close reading of these texts. The course syllabus is organized around common themes and generic categories. This course is invaluable preparation for more advanced and specialized 300-level literature courses. Classroom discussion and free exchange encouraged.

title: Intermediate Logic
prereqs: PHI 201 or permission of the Instructor..
descrip: Proofs of some of the principal results regarding first-order languages (and the theories expressed in them): Church's undecidability theorem, the Lowenheim-Skolem Theorem, Godel's theorems on the completeness of first-order logic and the incompleteness of arithmetic; because several of these concern the possibility of devising computational tests for semantic properties (logical validity, truth), an introduction to the theory of computability (Turing Machines/ recursive functions); if time permits, some properties of second-order logic.

title: Forensic Anthropology
descrip: An introduction to the techniques of analysis that biological anthropologists apply to forensic (legal) cases. Topics include: the ethical and moral considerations of international forensic efforts, recovery of bodies, analysis of life history, reconstruction of causes of death, and case studies where anthropologists have contributed significantly to solving forensic cases. Discussions will include the limitations of the application of DNA recovery to skeletal/mummified materials; various case studies including recovery of body parts from the World Trade Towers site; and uncovering gravesites in Bosnia and Iraq.

title: Darwin and His Legacy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Latin American Film - Poetics and Politics of the Third World
reviews: Don't try to do the readings in one sitting.  Talk to Prof. Guerrero outside of class--he is very helpful and a very kind person.

If you are interested in cinema, Spanish and issues of Latin America, take this class. Profesor Guerrero is an excellent teacher whose intelligence and respect makes this class not only one in which I learned a lot, but one that I thoroughly enjoyed.
Take it!
Take it, he's super nice and the class is extremely interesting.

Take this course if your'e interested in Latin America, politics, and/or cinema! It's a quite lovely course, and it is so much fun, but still challenging. The professor is amazing and the material is extremely interesting.
This class a very enjoyable way to learn about Latin America!
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of a series of critically acclaimed contemporary Latin American films, accompanied by readings that provide a theoretical and historical framework for its analysis. Topics to be discussed, among others: subalternity and the Third World; sexual and racial politics; postcolonial poetics; genocide; cultural hybridism and mestizaje; dictatorship and populism; biopolitical fantasies.

title: Cell and Developmental Biology
reviews: Covered essential information for molecular biology which I will certainly use in the future.  So glad I don't have to take it again.
Decently hard material but very interesting. I took it for general interest not as a requirement and it was very enjoyable and not as difficult as other MOL classes.
Departmental
Do not take this class unless it's required.

Don't take this course unless you're absolutely required to. Exams are brutal, and there's no way you're going to know everything they expect you to know. Try talking to professors; Terry's really helpful. I wish I'd talked to her earlier in the semester.
Good course -- I recommend. I would recommend to stay up to date on readings.

I did not do all of the readings, so that might have been helpful. Keep up with learning the material throughout the course because it is a lot to try to cram the night before an exam. Meet up with lecturers and preceptors to ask questions and discuss material!!

I mean. It is required. Never miss lecture. There is no way you can learn material on your own through lecture slides. Starting early on psets is recommended, but I have seen others do it in one night. Laura Terry is the master of questions. direct all questions to her and you are guaranteed an answer.
If you are taking this class, you probably had no other choice. Just try to keep up with the material and you will be fine.
If you have to take it (for MOL) - keep up with the material, pay attention in lecture, review regularly.  If you don't - why are you here?  Don't do it.
It is a LOT of material and molecules/pathways to memorize, so don't fall behind!

It's certainly a ton of work. Take this if you are awesome at memorization or if your love of cell and/or developmental biology surpasses the magnitude of your poor memorization skills. (I am not a MOL major -- equations are more my strength.) I definitely learned a lot of cool things, but it was a hit to my GPA. I would probably take it again if I had to redo though.
Keep on top of your material and don't fall behind. Understand experimental logic.

Keeping up with the lecture slides, readings, and working hard on the problem sets is essential. I did not check with people on the problem sets in the beginning and did not realize how much time they would take, but once I devoted more time to it, I was able to really enjoy working through them, often to my reward, and then I would quickly check over the problem sets with a friend.
Make sure you use the book as a supplement for lecture notes when you study
Memorizzzzzze
Read as much of the textbooks as you can, attend precept, and go over the notes as soon after lectures as possible.
Read the textbook readings
Start memorizing now.
Stay on top of the material and use the books as a tool.
Take it!
Take only if required. If lectures aren't required in the future then skip them and do the readings. They're more useful. Try on the problem sets. They helped me learn the most.
Take this class if you're interested in developmental biology. But also remember that celldev is everywhere, so you should take this course because of its wide applicability

This course gives you an excellent foundation for anything you will undertake in molecular biology. I do suggest making sure to keep up with the material, since the course goes quite fast and is very comprehensive.
This course is the hardest MOL departmental.
do. not. take. this.
only take if a MOL major
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345 is required..
descrip: The mechanisms that underlie development of multicellular organisms, from C. elegans to humans, will be examined using biochemical, genetic and cell biological approaches. The course will investigate the roles that gene regulation, cell-cell communication, cell adhesion, cell motility, cell death, signal transduction and intracellular trafficking play in the commitment, differentiation and assembly of cells into specialized tissues.

title: Topics in Social and Personality Psychology - Social Psychology and Social Change
reviews: A must-take class for PSY majors interested in the applications of psychology. The weekly reading responses are a lot of work, but they really help students understand the material.
Definitely take it - an important course for giving a practical perspective of psychology.
Great class. Great Professor. If you do not like writing, be wary but if you are trying to build up your writing skills a bit Professor Paluck will help you a lot.
If you're at all interested in social psychology and how it applies to the real world take it!
Take it!
Take it!  It is an incredible course.  You learn a ton about behavioral psychology and its impacts on policy.  Interesting for WWS and psych majors.  Challenging but fascinating.
Take it! Do all of the readings and try to always think about the bigger picture.

This is an awesome class. I would strongly recommend taking it, even if you don't have a background in psychology. The class material is directly relevant to real life and would help you form a more nuanced view of the problems facing our society today.

Work hard on the weekly responses. The readings usually aren't that long, so read them very thoroughly and analyze them as you read, which will help both for the response and for class discussion. Paluck is sometimes hard to pin down, but try to go to office hours as much as possible to discuss your paper.
prereqs: PSY 252, or students may e-mail the instructor to explain why they would like to take the class, listing relevant coursework, including research methods and other social science courses..
descrip: This course explores how social psychological theory and research have been used in the interest of social change, and how social change has inspired theoretical or methodological developments in social psychology. In short, it explores major ideas, theories, and findings of social psychology and their applied status. The course is organized around topics of social stasis and change, including intergroup relations, government and authority, identity and citizenship, environment, health, labor, education, and culture.

title: Senior Project with Design
descrip: Similar to 440 with the principle difference that the team or group project must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior project with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Molecular Simulation Methods
descrip: An introduction to molecular simulation methods, specifically Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics, for classical fluids and solids, with consideration of their application to problems in engineering, chemistry, physics, and biology. Course covers sampling in different statistical mechanical ensembles, classical potentials, specialized simulation mehtods for determining free energies and phase equilibria, and the prediction of properties of solids. For beginning graduate students and advanced undergraduates with some prior knowledge of computing.

title: Soldier, Worker, Mullah, Citizen: Labor and Social Welfare in the Middle East
descrip: Uprisings, revolutions, and social conflict in Western Asia and Northern Africa challenge our popular and scholarly notions. Deeply held assumptions need to be examined, rethought, and perhaps replaced. As a first step, this seminar explores the politics of labor and social welfare in the modern Middle East. We approach and discuss the class readings from a macro-historical perspective, which means taking patterns of change through time and space seriously, often going beyond the Middle East.
