These two intertwined subjects can point us in new directions for thinking about the region and the world in the 21st century.

title: Seminar in Modernist Art and Theory - The Origins of Abstraction
descrip: This seminar will take advantage of a major exhibition on abstraction to be held in winter 2013. Through close examination of original works and primary texts, we will investigate the beginnings of nonobjective art in its various iterations across Europe c. 1910-25. Why abstraction? What were the various motives and methods of its development? How could different philosophies and ideologies be projected onto this one form? Why did it have such repercussive effects across the arts? Regular study visits to MOMA will be involved.

title: Thesis Studio
prereqs: One course is required for all M.Arch. students. Completion of Pre-Thesis Workshops is required for entry into Thesis Studio..
descrip: The Master of Architecture Thesis is an independent design project on a theme selected by the student. The student begins with a thesis statement outlining an area of study or a problem that has consequences for contemporary architectural production. Marking the transition between the academic and professional worlds, the thesis project is an opportunity for each student to define an individual position with regard to a specific aspect of architectural practice. As an integral part of the design process, it is intended that the thesis project will incorporate research, programming and site definition.

title: Investigative Journalism - Watchdog Reporting
reviews: I would highly recommend this course to all Princeton students.
I would strongly recommend this class to any student even a little bit interested in journalism. It is a bit of work, but definitely worth it. One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton!

It's a ton of work, but it's worth it. You get so much more confidence and quite a few skills by the end of the semester that will come incredibly handy both in professional work and just as a citizen.
Take it. Now. It's an absolutely amazing opportunity to learn the skills of investigative journalism while also meeting and hearing from some of the best in the field.

Take this! If you have even the slightest interest in journalism, this is really a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. You get to meet so many fascinating journalists and you have the opportunity to hear the background of how they pursued really interesting stories. You'll really learn a lot from this course.
Well, the instructor changes every time but this was a very interesting class that taught me a lot about what records are public and how to go about pursuing information.
it's a ton of work...be prepared
this is a difficult class, plan on spending hours on the phone trying to get people to talk to you. Not always fun, but can be rewarding.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: Students will discover how investigative journalists unearth tales that might not otherwise be told and produce work that documents and improves the world around them. They will learn how to choose subjects, conduct interviews, obtain and analyze records, marshal facts and write hard-hitting, engaging stories. We will explore the role of watchdog journalism, the ethical obligations of journalists and how an investigative mindset can be helpful in other fields.

title: Art and Society: The Case of the Russian Revolution
descrip: This course will investigate the complex inter-relationships between politics, ideology, and aesthetics, and consider whether it is only governments and the policies they make that have the power to coerce artistic production, or whether artists can shape politics and ideology as well. In short: What does it mean for art to be political? The primary historical focus will be on Russian art before, during, and after the Bolshevik revolution, but comparative geo-historical cases will also be considered.

title: The Philosophy of Aristotle
descrip: Aristotle's Metaphysics.

title: International Political Economy
descrip: An introduction to the subfield of international political economy, covering basic topics in the politics of both trade and finance.

title: Readings in Renaissance and Reformation History - Books and Their Readers in Early Modern Europe
descrip: This course will work through a series of case studies in the history of books and readers. We will start by examining the ways in which texts were produced and used in the century just before the invention of print; look in detail at the invention of printing and its short- and long-term consequences; and investigate the impact of printing on a wide range of writers and readers--Latin and vernacular, male and female--down to the seventeenth century. Each week we will examine manuscripts and rare books from Princeton's rich collections, digitized primary sources and secondary literature.

title: Evolution and the Behavior of the Sexes
reviews: Eh....not as interesting as you would think. But you do get to tell all your friends you are in Sex Class.
Good class, you should definitely take it!
I wouldn't.
It's okay and interesting, but prepare to do readings.
Material is interesting, there is a lot of reading though

Take it if it's being taught as a seminar or if you're good at not getting distracted in class. The subject material has a lot of potential but it ends up falling flat. The final paper on the other hand is a lot of fun!
Take it, and make sure to do the readings.

The material is fascinating, so if you're at all interested in sex differences in humans and animals you should take this course.  However, be wary of what professor they get to teach it.  There isn't one professor who always teaches it and getting someone who's unfamiliar with Princeton/teaching the course can be a major drawback.

This is a really interesting class to take, whether it's for your STN or if you're an EEB major. The workload is manageable and Dr. Russell is really energetic, though sometimes disorganized with lectures.
descrip: This course, designed to capitalize on diverse student backgrounds, will use principles of evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology to examine mating strategies and their effect on social systems. We will draw examples from vertebrates, with an emphasis on group-living mammals, particularly primates and elephants. Topics will include mate selection, ontogeny of sex differences, sexual diversity, social bonds and cooperation, and intersexual conflict.

title: Complex Analysis with Applications
reviews:
It's a great course; definitely take it if Vlad is teaching. Lectures were very clear and well-organized, and he was very quick to answer questions. He's a very smart and likeable lecturer.

The only thing is, the book (Churchill) wasn't the best. However, I think the professor didn't like it much either, so it might change.
The problem sets are not enough- do more.
This class is primarily full of physics majors with lots of experience in math. Its easier than 203 and 204, but is still hard. Problems sets are about 12 hours a week. Vlad Vicol is excellent.

This is a good class to take if you want to learn complex analysis. Unlike the Stein course, it is slightly less abstract and we didn't deal much with metric spaces. However, this class is still completely rigorous, so expect proofs for every theorem. Homework problems were mostly computational (finding integrals, etc.) but not entirely brainless.
prereqs: MAT 201 and MAT 202 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of functions of one complex variable, covering power series expansions, residues, contour integration, and conformal mapping. Although the theory will be given adequate treatment, the emphasis of this course is the use of complex analysis as a tool for solving problems.

title: Advanced French Language and Style
reviews: Come in with exactly what you want to get out of the course and focus relentlessly on it.
If you want to take a French class without a terrible workload, this is it.
Take FRE 224 if you want an awesome literature class. Take this class if you want to brush up on grammar.
Take it! Martine will make your French better. Plus, this is a chill class!
Take this class if you want to improve your French in a laid back setting.
Take this course only if you really want to improve grammar. If you want to engage in learning French culture and other more lively subjects, try taking another course.
This is a less-demanding 300-level class, but if you want to do well you still have to work. I would take this class before engaging in a higher 300-level class.
take it! but not at 830 am
prereqs: A 200-level French course or permission of instructor.
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through comparative study of English and French grammatical and syntactic structures, literary translation, and reading of non-literary texts.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Advanced)
descrip: Considers theories and evidence to explain processes of economic development; examines theories of economic growth, and the two-way links between development and poverty, inequality, social institutions, and the family. Policy debates on education, health, and social policy, and governmental and international aid are also covered.

title: Computer Networks
reviews: A solid core CS course. Unless you have a strong reason not to take it, I would strongly advise all people interested in tech to take this course. Not only are the lectures solid and assignments relevant, but the network is now the backbone of communications globally and it is important to understand how it works. As always, don't miss lecture, though precepts are less necessary. Start assignments early, and know the Router is the hardest.
Do take it! The assignments are hard, but you only have one every 3 weeks. The class covers really interesting material that is increasingly relevant.

I came into this class after not taking COS 318, so I definitely felt at a disadvantage on the assignments.  First off, Freedman is an awesome lecturer, he runs fast through the material so make sure you are paying attention and can type fast.  Next, the assignments are absurd.  What you make really isn't that interesting, they take for-freakin'-ever (that's typical C programming though), and the assignments HAVE ERRORS IN THEM!  I cannot believe there were actual errors in the assignment that weren't fixed until someone told the instructors on Piazza.  That removed ALL incentive to try and start the assignments early because you'd hit a snag somewhere and it would be completely not your fault.  The response we got was "you guys should figure out these problems yourselves."  This is why people who took COS 318 were at an advantage, they were used to these kinds of situations.  Our year the assignments were made much easier, but they still took at least 2 all-nighters (it took me 4 straight all-nighters to finish the router assignment, look forward to that one).  The final exam was fully comprehensive, do not only study the 2nd semester.  Outside of absolutely horrible assignments and really hard exams, this was incredibly informative and useful in lecture.  VERDICT:  prepare to sleep in the Fishbowl (computer room in friend) for the assignments, but the information taught in lecture is really cool and interesting.  Recommend.
I recommend that people take this class, but it is not a good class to P/D/F.

I would recommend this class if you are an extremely competent computer scientist who enjoys programming in C on VERY long assignments. You should not try to take this class concurrently with other major computer science classes like OS or 340 unless you are extremely confident that you can handle it. This class is definitely something you should take at some point while you are here, but the time has to be right. When it is, I would recommend it.
I wouldn't take it again. Debugging networks is very tedious, especially in a highly virtualized environment. You need to code on a labpc (or a VM of a lab PC)

If Freedman is teaching it, don't think twice - just take it.  The assignments are difficult, but there are only three major projects and they are very well spaced out with plenty of support.  Lectures are great.

If you are a serious COS person with any systems interest, you should take this course. In this field, you need to know how the Internet works and why, and this course does a good job of teaching you that.
If you can, take this with at most three other courses in a given semester.  It requires quite a time commitment.
If you don't take networks, you aren't a real CS major.
If you want to learn how the internet works, take this class.
It's a challenging course, and be prepared to read the book and/or learn a lot of the stuff on your own to get a good grade.

Make sure to save enough time for assignments, they are really time consuming.
Do the previous exams to get familiar with the kind of questions.
Networks is an essential class for a COS major, but beware of the fact that you're pretty much left to figure things out on your own A LOT.
Networks is interesting. It might seem like a lot of random detail, but they make sense after a while.
Overall, top-notch course. If you want to get the internet, take it. Challenging assignments however; start early!
Start assignments early since debugging can take a significant amount of time, and give yourself plenty of time to study for the examinations.
Take it
Take it with Rexford.

Take this class with Rexford. The material is interesting and compelling, but her tests actually test your understanding, rather than your ability to commit the details of random insignificant protocols to memory.
The course teaches pretty important material about computer science, but is not the best organized CS course out there.

The internet is awesome, which is probably reason enough to take this course.  It's well taught regardless of professor, and the presence of precepts means that you'll learn more than in most higher-level COS classes.
The amount of time you'll spend on assignments depends very much on your experience with C.  After OS, this class is a breeze.  Totally takeable with just 217, but you'll be spending a lot more time on the assignments.  If you're picking between this and OS, definitely do this.

The material is really useful, although it's nothing you couldn't learn by reading the relevant manuals/RFC. The tests are disgusting; half of the points on our final came from an elaborate true/false section. The coding is stressful initially if you've only had 217, mostly because you aren't really given much help (such is life). Take it with a few friends and it will be much more bearable.
There are only three programming assignments in this course, so it works out to about half as much coding as OS. The material is also very relevant and interesting.

There are so many things about this course that seem designed just to annoy you and make it difficult to learn the material. I don't know if this is any worse or better than OS, say, as this is the only real systems course I've taken. But this is still terrible.
This is a good course; watch out for the router and TCP session projects (especially the former), and expect to memorize details for some protocols for the final.
This is a great class. It'll teach you more or less how the internet works. Start the assignments early, as they'll take a while.
This is a great course if you want to know more about how Internet works
This is a very relevant course. If you're interested in how networks (i.e. the Internet) work or want to learn how to add network functionality to your code, this is the course for you!
Very insightful course, but requires a lot of work.
Workload isn't too bad, the assignments are kinda big but spread out, and there are only 4 real assignments. I feel like I have a good grasp of networks now.
You need one of two things to do well in this class: a ton of programming experience in c or a ton of free time to spend on the assignments

You will definitely learn a lot of useful information about how the internet works in this class. However, be prepared for hard, often vague programming assignments. If you are good at managing your time, take this class. However, since they often give you 3 weeks to finish an assignment, each one require a lot of dedication. That being said, you will probably be proud when you get them to work.
prereqs: COS 217.
descrip: This course studies computer networks and the services built on top of them. Topics include packet-switch and multi-access networks, routing and flow control, congestion control and quality-of-service, Internet protocols (IP, TCP, BGP), the client-server model and RPC, elements of distributed systems (naming, security, caching) and the design of network services (multimedia, file and web servers).

title: Topics in Literature and Ethics - Modern Evil
descrip: This is a course on the problem of evil in the modern world as it is represented in works of literature and film. What is the nature of evil and how is it imagined? How can the noble ideas that define the modern world--justice and human rights, for example--be reconciled with the terrible events of the twentieth century: genocide, racial violence, and war? Why do good people do terrible things to others? What can reading books on evil in distant places teach us about ourselves? The course will explore how evil functions as a form of deep ethical violation and challenges how we understand the world and our relationship to others.

title: Metals in Biology
reviews: A very interesting course, even for non-chemical biology majors
Great introduction to bioinorganic.  Don't worry if you don't have any biochem background.
I would recommend other students to do more outside work and self teaching for this class generally, especially if the knowledge of biology is limited.
Interesting class, but unless you're really interested in bioinorganic chemistry it might not be the class for you.
Make sure you have a working background in biological chemistry. It becomes confusing quite quickly if you don't.
if you have taken inorganic and biochem and liked both, then you will like this. definitely recommend it, especially if Fiedler is teaching part of the course.
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 301/302 or CHM 303/304.
descrip: Life processes depend on over 25 elements whose bioinorganic chemistry is relevant to the environment (biogeochemical cycles), agriculture, and health. CHM 544 surveys the bioinorganic chemistry of the elements. In-depth coverage of key transition metal ions including manganese, iron, copper, and molybdenum focuses on redox roles in anaerobic and aerobic systems and metalloenzymes that activate small molecules and ions, including hydrogen, nitrogen, nitrate, nitric oxide, oxygen, superoxide, and hydrogen peroxide. Appreciation of the structure and reactivity of metalloenzyme systems is critical to understanding life at the molecular level.

title: The Chemistry of Color
descrip: See website

title: Advanced Turkish: Selected Readings in Historical and Literary Texts
prereqs: Students are expected to have a sufficient command of Turkish language (intermediate/upper intermediate level) to fulfill the reading and writing assignments. See instructor for further information.
descrip: This course introduces a wide variety of reading material (newspaper, memoir, letter, short story, diary etc.) to strengthen students' abilities in understanding and evaluating modern Turkish texts. Information on selected authors and their works will provide a general view on the Ottoman/Turkish cultural, literary and historical panorama. The analysis and discussions of the texts in class will serve to build fluency.

title: Introductory Printmaking
reviews: TAKE IT
TAKE IT! It, like anything, takes time, and it can be frustrating, but it's the best time I've had at Princeton. You'll laugh, you'll cry: it's about the wonder of discovery.
TAKE THIS!
Take it! Printing is cool
Take it, whether or not you've done art before, whether it's your freshman or your senior spring. Just take it. You won't regret it. This class changed my life.
descrip: This course introduces techniques of copper plate etching, and relief printing. Assignments focus on applications of various printmaking techniques, while encouraging independent development of subject matter. Critiques will occur throughout the term. Students are encouraged to draw regularly outside of class to cultivate themes and content applicable to their prints. Field trips to the University museum and the library's graphics collection will complement class work. Additional independent workshop hours required.

title: Advanced Logic
reviews: Attend lectures, go to precepts, have fun.
Do it.

If you haven't learnt any set theory, give it a go. If you've already taken mathematical logic (e.g. mat 305 or something) you might want to consider something else, though the later material in this class is new and quite interesting.
Recommended, fun course for math majors. If you are ever stuck, go to Prof Burgess' office hours - he is very nice and gives helpful hints on tough questions.

Take it if you're interested in foundations/set theory. Occasionally the material can get a little bit silly (large cardinals) from the perspective of modern mathematics, but most of it is at least interesting.
The course is very nice and describes interesting topics such as the axiom of choice and ZFC set theory.
This course is very interesting, and Professor Burgess really knows his stuff. The problem sets start out pretty easy but get much harder towards the end of the course.
Totally take this class if you see it available. Set theory is a subject that every mathematician should know something about, and taking it with Prof. Burgess, is the perfect way to achieve this.
prereqs: Some previous study of logic or mathematical maturity..
descrip: An introduction to axiomatic set theory, up to the proof of the consistency of the axiom of choice.

title: Ethics of Persuasion, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Soviet Literature, 1917-1965
reviews: I would strongly advise taking this course. It is very important that you keep up with at least the main readings for the week, however, it is often very insightful to read through the biographies as well.
Regardless of exposure to Soviet Literature, everyone should take this course because the works are very different from most novels produced elsewhere
Soviet literature is actually much more complex than you would expect, and you will gain a lot from it. Take it.

This is definitely a different kind of literature than what most are used to--lots of strange aspects to it. If you are just looking to pour over bourgie lit, this isn't the class for you. This class also has a large emphasis on the historical context of the period as well.
take this if you want a more modern reading course on russian literature. be prepared to fall in line with the professor's thinking in everything you do if you want to do well.
descrip: The course surveys major literary texts and trends in the half-century period between the Revolution of 1917 and the end of Khrushchev's Thaw. We will examine works by avant-garde authors, proletarian-minded writers, and those "fellow travelers" who continued to create under a Soviet regime increasingly hostile to them. In reading these texts, we will focus attention on major cultural topics such as: the avant-garde and the fate of art; the Russian intelligentsia and the Revolution; the political regimentation of culture; the nature and method of socialist realism.

title: Topics in Development - Making Government Work in Fragile States
descrip: Reformers exist in many fragile states but few are able to produce sustained improvement in service delivery or in the operation of core government institutions. This course focuses on a set of governance traps that appear to subvert fragile state turnarounds and strategies for escaping these. It also addresses handling of principal-agent problems in remote areas. At a broader level, it engages participants in thinking about patterns of state formation in 21st century, focusing on scaling up of reform in urban centers. We use biography and case studies to spur thinking, plus theory drawn from economics and political science.

title: Advanced Physics (Electromagnetism)
reviews: Be prepared to work hard if you haven't taken much E&M before! Also make sure to stay away from Writing Sem on Thursday nights for problem sets due Friday if you have a tendency to procrastinate / are really busy.
Course is good to take for majors, not so otherwise.
Definitely do the readings and practice problems regularly.
Definitely take over 104, although it'll probably still be mostly review from Physics C. Don't expect a very challenging class.

Don't stress out about the quizzes
Do the problem sets carefully
Read the book many times
Get a jump on the problem sets and readings early and they'll be easy. Read ahead.
Hard work but great if you're interested in Physics. Find a group to do psets with.
I would recommend attending problem set sessions, as they are very helpful, but not well attended.
If Prof. Hasan and Prof. Jones are teaching this course, do not take it. You'd have more fun learning about electricity by sticking your finger into a wall socket.
If you want to challenge yourself, take this course! The lecturers are good, the problem sets are not so hard (but you do need to put in effort).

Interesting and hard (at least for me). Workload is considerable. Readings can be long. If you take it with Hassan, be warned many of his lectures are not clear. Bill Jones is very clear and I loved his lectures, on the other hand. Friday quizzes will include problems that were due on the pset due on the same day, so this was very helpful. The psets help you keep yourself up to date with the course. Do the readings (try not to fall behind!), do the psets with enough time, and you will probably be fine with some work. If you cannot attend the problem sessions, the course is still doable. They are designed for students to collaborate on the hw problems. The semester I took 106, I had Writing Sem and a Wednesday night class, so I couldn't attend the study sessions, and I still survived.
It will be a lot of work at first, but you'll get used to it.  Read the book before lectures, and make sure that your vector calculus is strong.
It's a challenging class. But rewarding.
PHY 106 is less work than 105, but there is a much higher expectation for you to learn the material on the own.
Take it if you are interested in physics
Take it if you survived 105. Also, have some knowledge of multivariable calculus. If you don't, like I didn't, then be prepared to learn quickly.

Take this course. It is challenging, but it certainly gives you a ground for physics. I enjoyed it a lot more than 105. Also, the math details in this class are interesting and lead to improvement if your math is not up to par.
Take this. Good class.
The course is multi-calc heavy. If you are interested in physics by no means take it. It is entertaining but might take much time.

This course requires a lot of work because there are weekly quizzes and problem sets. Make sure you are comfortable with this format. If you want to do well on the weekly quizzes, read the chapters very carefully and make sure you understand every problem on the problem sets. The class isn't particularly difficult but the timing of the quizzes makes it rather hard to do well.
This is a good class.

This is a great course for potential physics majors or for anyone who would like to really understand electricity and magnetism.  Do not be scared, there is a reasonable amount of work, but the class is fun and you will learn a lot!
You'll learn more interesting stuff than in 104.  Avoid if Jones is teaching.  Hasan is a fantastic lecturer.
y challenging course, really worth it (i think).  but approach with caution, if your heart's not in it, it'll show.
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105..
descrip: This course features the classical theory of electricity and magnetism, with emphasis on the unification of these forces through the special theory of relativity. While the subject matter is similar to that of PHY 104, the treatment is more sophisticated. The topics also include DC and AC circuits and the electromagnetic behavior of matter.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: Senior standing is required for enrollment in this course..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers, subject to the consent of the faculty advisor.

title: Electronic and Photonic Devices
reviews: Ask enough questions and you'll be fine.
Be patient the first 2-3 weeks. Things will fall in place soon enough.
Go to Arvind's review sessions and Arash's office hours. They are both really nice and you will learn a lot.
Go to the lectures, they are super helpful. Prepare for labs in advance too as they will go faster if you know what you are doing.
I didn't learn much in this class. It's not much work. Labs are pretty fun though.
I think it is an interesting course but not super great or anything. Slightly above average.
If Prof. Gmachl is running this course, take it. The labs really help you learn about processing.

If you are an ele major, you have no choice. But if you are not, take this course regardless. You learn how transistors work on the very ground level. The course is pretty easy, no work, and relatively good grading.

If you're an ELE, you have to take it. Otherwise, I would certainly recommend it; it's not too much work, and the labs were quite enjoyable. While I didn't really love the material we covered, overall it was a well run course.

If your an ELE major, you don't really have a choice. If your COS, like me, its a good way to look into the ELE department to see if you'd like to major in it. The workload is very reasonable, and you'll have a better understanding of hardware too.
It's a great course! Make sure to start the homework early. I loved it, and you will too!
It's actually a very easy course if you don't over think things but be aware that if you miss a lecture or two, then the lectures actually will not make any sense subsequently.
N.A>
Not much work, interesting material albeit a bit unorganized

Okay, so this course wasn't the best taught but that's because it's Gmachl's first time teaching it.  She's not the best instructor but she's amazingly nice and really cares about her students.  Also the TAs in this class were excellent.  Overall, this class needs some tweaking but it has potential to be a great ELE departmental.
Pay attention in lecture! Go to the precepts! make sure you can talk about semiconductors as you go along and you will be great in the class.

Really fun class, lots of hands-on work and you learn the big picture - if you want more rigorous proofs of concepts then it's not for you. Professor is super nice and flexible about deadlines, so there's really no downsides to taking this class.
Really good class
Really neat labs, not as much work as some 200 level ELE courses. Gmachl's not the best lecturer, but on the whole a pretty good course.
Semiconductors aren't for everyone.  While I thought it was somewhat interesting to get a general idea of how they work, this course (combined with 201) also convinced me to be a COS major.

This course is an AWESOME introduction to the clean room, and making semiconductor devices the way they really do it.  Labs are so legit.  The course overall is very qualitative, so if math isn't your favorite, this course is perfect for you.

This is a very interesting course that will expose you to the design of integrated circuits on silicon and other semiconductor materials. This is very interesting material and the backbone of the technological revolution. As a computer systems and hardware guy, though, I wasn't "struck" by the material from this course. It was interesting, and I'm glad that I have an understanding now of how chips are implemented on silicon, but this wasn't one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Professor Gmachl, though, is definitely the most kind, caring, and thoughtful professor that I've had. She is fantastic!

This was an alright course. The lectures and textbook weren't the best, but Professor Gmachl and the TAs are great. So go to them if you have trouble with the material. That being said, I wouldn't take it unless it was required.

Well, it's required for EE's, so if that's you, take it. But even if you're just interested in semiconductors or have heard good things about Claire, I'd really recommend this course. It's not a lot of work, but you learn so, so much!
prereqs: PHY104 is a Pre- or Co-requisite. SEAS chemistry, physics, math requirements or equivalent. Elementary knowledge of circuits is required. Pass/Fail not available to EE majors..
descrip: Explores ways in which semiconductor devices harness and control electrons and photons to generate, store or transmit information. The basics of semiconductor electronics and photonics are introduced. We look at diodes, transistors, LEDs, solar-cells, and lasers, which form the foundations of integrated circuits, microchips, displays, cameras, etc. Nanotechnology, a recent addition to devices and systems, is introduced. Laboratory: fundamentals of micro and nano fabrication and fabrication of Si integrated circuits, semiconductor light emitters, quantum devices.

title: Biomolecular Engineering
descrip: A study of the design and engineering of biomacromolecules. After a brief review of protein and nucleic acid chemistry and structure, course will delve into rational, evolutionary, and computational methods for the design of these molecules. Specific topics to be covered include aptamers, protein and RNA-based switches and sensors, unnatural amino acids and nucleotides, enzyme engineering, and the integration of these parts via synthetic biology efforts.

title: Honors Linear Algebra
reviews: (Took it with Gunning.) Keep up with reading and look at the examples attentively - problems are often related/similar to those. Don't worry if you can't follow every bit in lecture - the proofs of the theorems aren't that important in the end. Try to visualize the concepts and think in intuitive terms to facilitate understanding. Taking it with Gunning will enable you to learn more topics in freshman year, which is good for math major and math enthusiasts in general.
A good class; differential forms are interesting.

Be prepared to work your a** off in this course. Keep up with the notes, attend office hours, and make sure you understand every proof on the problem set. All in all, putting in the work will hopefully get you the grade you want!
Definitely take this class - it may be hard in the beginning but gives you a good taste of high level math. I was not an IMO person and did just as well as they did.
Do all the readings, from lecture notes to course books.
Do the readings and homework.
For those who have taken MAT 215 this is definitely the course to continue. Those interested in more theoretical math can take this as well.
Good course to take but hard work and it may seem like too much to take in at times.
I found the material a bit dry at times, but I felt very satisfied and rewarded by the class. MAT 217 really challenges you to think rigorously.

I would definitely recommend this course. Although the problem sets are difficult and time consuming, every problem is interesting and worth the time you spend. And by the end, you feel like you've accomplished something in learning it all.
If you took 215 and enjoyed it, this is essentially the same class. It's a great introduction to the math major.

If you want to be able to carry out the calculations, 202 is the course to take. If you want to challenge yourself, 204 has some really tricky problems. If you have a solid background in rigorous mathematics and want to understand linear algebra, 217 presents the material in a clear cut and organized way. Despite its difficult, I believe it's a necessary course for any math major and anyone who's interested in the fundamental ideas of linear algebra.

Know how to write rigorous proofs before taking this class or figure it out before the midterm and you'll be in for a great class and an easy A since most of the class can't prove anything with any semblance of rigor.

Once you take this course, you'll feel you have a BIG advantage over other people in all math-related courses, because this course teaches you how to WRITE PROOFS. Not many people have been exposed to writing pages of clear logic -- and this exposure is crucial everywhere. If the "accelerated 215-217-218 in two semester" version exists, TAKE IT. It touches upon a large area and the education you take here is integral in both mathematics and proofwriting.
Recommended but only if you want a really fast course. Gunning makes it worth it though.
Take Prof. Gunning's one-year sequence of analysis and linear algebra. It's great, there's no need to spend three semesters on 215, 217, and 218.
Take it if you want to be a math major and have a bit of experience with proofs.  It's interesting stuff.

Take it if you want to be a math major, but also take it if you want to learn linear algebra in a way that doesn't emphasize the algorithms of how to do things, but more emphasizes why we would want to do certain things. In this class, we cared a lot less about matrices than the linear transformations underlying those matrices, for example.
Take it if you want to be a math major. It covers a lot of material!

Take this if you have experience with proof-based math and are interested in algebra. Also, if you are an intended math major. Expect ~12-15hrs a week in problem-set time. Try to work with other people.

This course is quite challenging, but is well worth it. Note that, with Prof. Gunning, this course is a continuation of his MAT 215 course and as such covered more multivariable analysis than linear algebra. The problem sets, although challenging, really do have interesting proofs and do help to develop your mathematical intuition further. Just be prepared to put in the work, and take advantage of the other resources, like McGraw and the tutoring sessions that are offered in Fine.

This course is relatively straight-forward if you have taken a rigorous math course previously.     Contrary to popular perceptions, I do not think it is at all necessary to take 215 first, especially if one has a background in proofs.  Though this class focuses on the theory, I found that I could do most of the problems in 202/204 after this class.  Strongly recommended for MAT, COS, and PHY majors, or to anyone who wants to learn more about an extremely elegant subject.

Work hard.
!!
descrip: A rigorous course in linear algebra with an emphasis on proof rather than applications. Topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, inner product spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, Jordan form, linear systems of differential equations, the spectral theorem for normal transformations, bilinear and quadratic forms.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Political Economy of Education Finance
descrip: Providing primary and secondary education absorbs over 20% of state and local government expenditures in the U.S. The magnitude of spending needs and the large disparities in economic capabilities across school districts create great challenges for financing public education. Financing schools has become an arena for debate not only about education but also about redistribution. Course studies the political, legal, and economic challenges involved in education finance and the diverse ways being attempted to cope with them.

title: Introduction to the Study of African American Cultural Practices
reviews: Come engaged. come ready to be angry with some scholars and commiserate with others

Copying and pasting my comments from above.

In summary, though, take it!!

I originally chose this course because I needed to fulfill a requirement for my AAS certificate. However, I stayed in the course because Imani Perry was such a good professor. 

Professor Perry is an engaged lecturer- I love how she speaks to students during lecture and really tries to make it feel like an intimate seminar. She was adept at integrating different aspects of African American culture into her lectures--- she synthesized our readings for the course and also integrated them with outside stories. She was dynamic and played music in class, films, and discussed folk lore. Because of her, I learned a lot about the history of the African American experience post slavery. I learned so much and left every precept feeling inspired.

Professor Perry was really helpful: she provided feedback on drafts of our final papers and was very encouraging. She was mindful to not only discuss the content expected in each paper but also the aspects of writing an argument or a clearly outlined paper. I don't know that I've ever had another professor (outside of writing seminar) who spoke in lecture about how to write a good argument and how to write a paper of that length. I really appreciated that.

Professor Perry's precept was one of the most enlightening precepts I have ever encountered-- the entire class was thoughtful and considerate. Everyone was engaged. Professor Perry creates an environment where you can feel comfortable to talk about difficult issues. She broadened my understanding of African American culture, but more important than that, she inspired us to have thoughtful conversations about issues of equality. The topics discussed in precept transcended the themes on the syllabus- we discussed music, culture, and even gay marriage. Professor Perry really inspired me and created a community. Outside of the classroom, the students would talk about the issues as we left class. I've
DO the readings and have an open mind
Do the readings
Do the readings! They're enlightening!
Eh. It's easy. You might as well take it.

Even if you can't finish the books in time for the lectures, make sure to read them eventually because they're all really important works in multiple disciplines, like English and the social sciences.

I know we don't have any choice in who our preceptors are, but if you're shy or timid in any way, or fear authoritative figures, try to take a course in which there is either at least one female preceptor or someone who is a little more (sensitive?). NB: I don't mean lax or lackadaisical; strictness is still important. But, I would have preferred it in a more gentle manner. I strongly recommend the course as a whole if you are an AAS certificate.

I mean if you're getting the certificate, you've gotta do it, but it's worth it. And Professor Perry is awesome. Also a really good course if you want to take an overview class on African American literature.
I would definitely take this course--with Imani Perry as the professor

If the course stays the way it is now, be sure to read as many of the books as you can before the lecture on it, even if you can only read a chapter or two. The lecture style is very interactive, and so the class flows a lot better if you come prepared with a question or two about the concepts presented in the readings.

Individual components of the course are really interesting, but it's really too broad of a subject to cover well in one semester. Don't go into it feeling like you'll get a thorough overview of AAS, and if you don't already have some background knowledge, it will probably be disjointed and confusing at times.
Not a bad intro course.  Obviously, it'd be cool if it were still taught by Cornel West but they tried to make it work so I commend them.
Take it if you're wiling to do all the readings, but be weary it is not a light reading load.
Take it with someone else.
Take it.

Take the course. Professor Perry is very insightful and clear. She may seem a bit disengaged in precept, or unprepared, but she really knows her stuff. Don't let the precepts turn into q&a sessions. They should really be more interactive than that.
Take this class. It's interesting. Imani Perry is fantastic.
Take this course, especially if Dr. Perry is teaching it. If you like interdisciplinary things, intersectional things, or studies of "culture," take this course. You will not regret it.

The class does have a lot of reading, but unless the nature of the assignments changes, not all the reading is necessary. It would be wise to give at least a cursory glance at each text, for precept discussions and also because the readings chosen are interesting material. If you enjoy reading and discussions, this is a great class.
The lectures are very interesting and I would definitely recommend that people go.
You need this for the certificate. Try to get in Imani's precept - that's probably better.
descrip: This course examines the past and present, the doings and the sufferings of Americans of African descent from a multidisciplinary perspective. It highlights the ways in which serious intellectual scrutiny of the agency of black people in the United States help redefine what it means to be American, new world, modern and post modern

title: Corporate Finance
reviews: I recommend to skim the papers (mostly in the part of Sraer) before going to class.
descrip: Introduction to corporate finance covering theories and empirical evidence about principal-agent models of firm managerial structure, takeover bids, capital structure, corporate governance; regulation of financial markets; financial markets and institutions with a focus on asymmetric information, transaction costs, or both; dynamic models of market making; and portfolio manager performance evaluation. Pre-requisite: ECO 525.

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Social Psychology
descrip: Introduction to graduate level social psychology for first year graduate students in psychology. This course will serve as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Tropical Ecology
reviews: Bring sunblock and enthusiasm!
Consider reading about the ecology of the destination beforehand, and bring any equipment you feel would be useful both for experiments and for general outdoor activity.
Get excited for it!
you guys are awesome!
descrip: This intensive three week field course takes place during January in a suitable tropical locality. Readings, discussions, and individual projects. The content and location are varied to suit the needs of the participants. Students provide their own travel funds.

title: Topics in Russian Literature or Literary Theory - Russian Film Theory
descrip: This seminar is devoted to theoretical writings and films of major Russian filmmakers.

title: History of Economic Thought
prereqs: ECO 100.
descrip: A survey of the history of economics, with an emphasis on the origins, nature, and course of leading economic ideas. This class aims to situate economic ideas in their historical context, thus providing a deeper understanding of economic life and theories of it. We critically appraise economic texts from Aristotle to 20th century writers, not solely out of antiquarian interest, but also for their insights into commercial society's foundational issues: the role of the state in the economy, the nature of human action and of the social good, and the social effects of property rights, prices, trade and the other defining attributes of markets.

title: Introduction to Latin American Cultures
reviews: I would not suggest this course. I don't think I got much out of it.
Not that great a class
Read enough so that you can participate in discussion if called on. Take notes in class, they will come in handy on the papers.
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to modern Latin American literature and culture. It focuses on the complex ways in which cultural and intellectual production anticipates, participates in, and responds to political, social, and economic transformations in the 20th and 21st centuries. Through a wide spectrum of sources (essays, fiction, poetry, film, and art), students will study and discuss some of the most relevant issues in Latin American modern history, such as modernity, democracy, identity, gender, memory, and social justice.

title: Instrumentation and Performance
descrip: The course is a study of the characteristics of individual instruments, including extended contemporary techniques and writing arrangements for chamber ensemble and for orchestra. Special attention is given to problems of combining voice and instruments. The arrangements written for this class are performed by the Composers' Ensemble at Princeton and the Princeton University Orchestra, and problems of performance involving notation, rehearsal, and conducting are dealt with.

title: Ecohydrology
prereqs: A first course in Probability and Statistics at the undergraduate level and an elementary course in Differential Equations at the undergraduate level..
descrip: The course is focused at the undergraduate level towards the understanding of the systems that control the circulation of water between atmosphere, soil, and plants. The course will address the dynamics of soil moisture and its relationship with the ecosystem structure. It will also study the impact of environmental conditions on natural ecosystems, plant strategies in water use, and hydrologic controls on nutrient cycles.

title: Data Structures and Graph Algorithms
prereqs: COS 423 or equivalent.
descrip: Topics selected from important recent results in the areas of data structures and graph algorithms. Possible themes to be explored include amortization, persistence, and randomness in algorithm design and analysis.

title: Dynamical Logics in Architecture
descrip: This course is designed as a workshop in architecture derived from material logics. Students will engage in a series of intensive design projects organized around exploring the new implications of the relationship of the part to the whole, force integration, analogue modeling, mass customization, the generic, etc. Ultimately, each project will work through the architectural performance of the complex interplay between material organization, program and form. The primary emphasis of the course will be the development of individual design/research projects, supplemented by background readings.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: The senior thesis is an independent study for individual students. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Students develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Students develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Students submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Buddhist Literature
prereqs: REL 225 or equivalent strongly recommended. Students with no prior background in Buddhism should expect to do extra initial reading..
descrip: This seminar will focus on the Lotus Sutra, one of the most influential Buddhist scriptures in East Asia. The Lotus Sutra asserts that a unifying intent underlies the vast diversity of Buddhist teachings and promises that all beings without exception can realize supreme enlightenment. We will consider the Lotus Sutra's origins in the Mahayana Buddhism of India and explore its major ideas and the controversies that developed around them, especially in China and Japan. We will also examine the Lotus Sutra's impact on East Asian Buddhist thought, practice, and ritual performance and its interpretation through art, literature, and social action.

title: Passive Aggressive Diplomacy: US-Latin American Relations
descrip: This seminar surveys US-Latin American diplomatic relations. The focus will be on old or recurrent historical myths and disparate perspectives on the nature of hemispheric links. Key Cold War crises will be reviewed, specially as they affect the present. Topics covered: The Clinton, Bush, and Obama administrations' approaches to democracy, security, and economic policies; and new issues in relation to the larger emerging countries (Mexico and Brazil) and Andean governance in the context of the current crisis of globalization and evolving crosscurrents of power in the international system.

title: History of Evolution
reviews: Anyone who is interested in historical evolutionary thinking should take this course. While readings were sometimes dense and philosophical, I believe that they reflect the widely interdisciplinary nature of the course. Beyond the science of evolution, the course looks at social and moral implications, as well as the guiding historical trends guiding changes in scientific thought.
DO IT! Also a good HA for premeds because you probably have a basic idea of most of the theories we learn about in class.

Definitely take this course with Prof. Milam. It is fascinating material, Prof. Milam is a wonderful teacher, and the course is both fun and interesting. It's also great as an introduction to the history of science and what that discipline means.
Highly recommend. There is much more to evolution than what we've learned in science textbooks.
I would highly recommend it.
If you need an HA to PDF, there are easier ones to take
Lectures are well prepared.
Only take if the subject really interests you, but if it does it's a fine course.
Take this class. Professor Milam is an amazing teacher and a great person, and the subject matter is fascinating.
YES!  I loved it.  Take for an HA or just for interest.  It was one of my favorite classes.
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators..
descrip: By interweaving intellectual and cultural threads, this course covers the history of evolutionary theory from Charles Darwin, and the scholars on whom he drew, to the late 20th century. We explore how biologists invested in evolutionary theory the capacity to explain our all too human nature and perhaps, therefore, to help us solve some of the world's most pressing problems. We also discuss how and why critics have attacked evolution as amoral and socially dangerous. In doing so, we investigate how scientists have negotiated the dynamic relationship between professional and public science.

title: Readings in American History: World War I to the Present
reviews: Have fun!
I recommend for Modern Americanists, and graduate students interested in political history.

If you are interested in twentieth century American history, definitely take this! If you are in another department and are interested in it, still take it! I was hesitant to move outside of my department, but Professor Kruse and the class were extremely helpful and made me feel welcome. I learned so much in this class and I'm definitely glad I took it.
It's a great course! Standard reading load, good professor, interesting materials.
The readings are long, but worth it. Prof. Kruse is a great resource for midcentry politics - and very approachable.
descrip: Fourth in a sequence of core courses in United States history, this course is designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to the literature and problems of American history since World War I.

title: Biology of Coral Reefs
reviews: AWESOME course. You get to spend 3 weeks on beaches snorkeling and looking at tropical fish! Could not ask for a better class. Maria, Sergio, Jenni, and Sam are amazing!!
Amazing class!! This was by far my favorite class I have ever taken. You get to go snorkeling every day off beautiful beaches. What more can you ask for?
Amazing course.
Consult Maria and Sergio extensively for a good idea for your projects- and choose partners that you work well with for the group project!

Definitely take it! Panama is a great experience, and this class is a lot of fun. Don't expect much time off (we were in class or traveling between field sites every day of the three weeks), but "class" means snorkeling every day, so it's hard to complain.

Find Nemo. 

Also, I would highly recommend finding a Coiba project that you can easily extend into a Bocas project by adding another interesting component. Most groups did this and it works much better than coming up with something new given time constraints.

I thought this course was well-run and well-taught. Don't be fooled--it is a lot of work, but it's mostly the very fun work of snorkeling over coral reefs! One week is spent on the island of Coibita without internet, AC, or constant power. I really loved this week, but some people were surprised, so go if you're the type of person who will enjoy this type of thing.
If you are going to Panama, you are going to love this course!

Most amazing course! You will see marine life on both the Pacific and Atlantic oceans, and on marine protected and non-protected areas. Maria and Sergio are awesome people! Get to know them well. Ask lots of questions to the professors and the TAs; they will provide incredible feedback. Be ready for oral pop quiz questions during the lectures so pay attention.
Not a great course.
This is as good as it gets. Look forward to it, and enjoy it. Pack light
This was a great experience from what we learned to conducting fieldwork.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: This field and lecture course provides an in-depth introduction to the biology of tropical coral reefs, with an emphasis on reef fish ecology and behavior. Each day begins with a lecture, followed by six to eight hours on the water, and ends with data analysis, reading and a discussion of recent papers. Students learn to identify fishes, corals and invertebrates, and learn a variety of field methods including underwater censusing, mapping, videotaping and the recording of inter-individual interactions. Each year group projects will vary depending on previous findings and the interests of the faculty.

title: Directed Research
descrip: During the third semester, each student writes a research paper under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Systematic Ethics
reviews: A superb philosophy course, especially if you are interested in philosophy.
Great overview course. Lots of material, but all really interesting. Just get into McGrath's precept!
I felt I didn't learn anything applicable in this course.  Take an applied ethics.  We often read disagreements about highly esoteric and meaningless arguments.
If you're inclined toward abstract philosophical thinking, take it!
It's not easy, but very interesting.
Take this course if you are at all interested in ethics. It will definitely force you to question your beliefs in a rigorous way.
The class is really interesting but the expectations for assignments are not really clear.
prereqs: One prior course in Philosophy.
descrip: A survey of major problems and developments in twentieth century metaethics, from G.E. Moore to the present.

title: Seminar in International Relations - Violent Non-State Actors in World Politics
reviews: Definitely take it.
Do the readings, engage in discussion.
It was a great class. Professor Carter is really flexible and happens to be at the forefront of this field. Very relaxed class for juniors and seniors struggling with independent work, too
This class is extremely interesting and relevant to current events. The material is engaging and manageable. Professor Carter is extremely knowledgeable and a great professor.
descrip: Violent non-state actors have become an increasingly prominent security concern in international relations. The events of September 11, 2001 quickly moved terrorism and insurgency to the forefront of U.S. security concerns. While the threat from violent non-state actors is relatively new as a top security concern for the U.S., many countries and regions of the world have long dealt with severe forms of political violence as a top security concern and a factor in everyday life. In this course, we examine violent non-state actors from several distinct angles and develop a solid understanding of their historical role.

title: The New Testament and Christian Origins
reviews: A good way to get an HA and an interesting subject.

As taught by Professor Pagels, this course is phenomenal. Whether you were raised reading these books or have never opened them before, this course will guide you to new insights about the New Testament (in fact, Professor Pagels argues that those who have not read the Bible have an advantage, because they are able to approach the texts without minimal bias). The papers and exams are relatively short and not terribly difficult, but they still guide you to learn more about the early Christian movement and the New Testament.
DEFINITELY take this.  Pagels is amazing and so fair with assignments.
Definitely take it.  You will learn a lot and it's not an incredibly intense class.

I thought this was a very eye-opening course on the early Christian movement, since I have never learned much about the topic before. I certainly think this would be an interesting course for anyone to take who is even mildly interested in religion.
I would advise them to take this course if they are looking for an easier course.
I would highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning more about their own religion or the history of the Christian religion in general.
I would not recommend students coming in to study the Bible for the first time. I believe some of the teachings, in a creative way, are taught to draw people away from what the Bible teaches.
I would recommend it.

If you're at all interested in taking a class about Christianity, whether you are a Christian or not, this is a really great class and you'll learn how to think about the religion with a different perspective.

If you're interested in Christianity from a secular perspective, this is a great course. Make sure to take it with Pagels, and try to get her as a preceptor, because she is great and you're also more likely to get engaged students with you.

If you?re interested in the early Christian movement, this course will be phenomenal. The workload is manageable to light, the lectures interesting, and the assignments straightforward. I found the topic fascinating and loved the opportunity to study and analyze the text of the Bible.
It was challenging in a good way for my faith, and helped me think a lot about questions that I wouldn't otherwise think about.
Pretty easy and interesting course with a low time commitment.

Professor Pagels is amazing and really cares about her students.  If you can take a class with her, do it.  This one is a really good introduction to the New Testament, but REL 252, which she also teaches, is probably roughly as good in that respect and CERTAINLY as good in terms of the professor.
Regardless of your religious background this course provides a very elementary understanding of Christianity from a New Testament perspective.
Take it!
Take it! Interesting readings, Professor Pagels is AWESOME.... great distribution requirement choice!
Take it, especially if you know very little about the Bible and Christianity to start with, you will learn a ton!
Take this course but be prepared to cover material a bunch of times and don't get frustrated when everything seems like speculation.
come prepared!
take it
descrip: This course investigates how the Christian movement began, using sources--Jewish, Greek, Roman, and Christian -- about Jesus of Nazareth and Paul of Tarsus; we read New Testament gospels, along with such recently discovered gospels as the Gospel of Thomas and Gospel of Mary Magdalene. We will discuss the formation of the NT collection; views of Jesus and his message; attitudes toward sexuality, gender, race, community. This course will also include reading and analysis of contemporary perspectives. Accessible to students new to these sources, as well as to those familiar with them.

title: Practice Teaching
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching (a minimum of 12 weeks) in a secondary school. Teaching is done under the supervision of an accomplished teacher and a program staff member who regularly observe and discuss the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and implementing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: Studies in Later Persian Literature 1200 - 1800 A.D.
descrip: Course acquaints students with the literature of the second great classical language of Islam and its legacy of epics, chronicles, lyric poems, mystical writings and imaginative tales from the traditional Persian-speaking world - including not only from present-day Iran, Afghanistan and Tajikistan but also from Anatolia, Central Asia and the Indian sub-continent. Continuation of NES 539. Treats the literature from 1200 to 1800.

title: Topics in Logic and Foundations - Computational Complexity
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will treat questions concerning fragments of Peano Arithmetic, their intuitionistic formulation, and related questions of the computational complexity of the functions of the theories.

title: Senior Independent Work
descrip: A one semester study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written report required.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced French
reviews: Be ready to work hard! This class counts as two courses and the workload reflects it. However, at the end, you will know how to speak French and will have a strong grasp on many difficult grammatical constructions.
Do not fall behind with the homework, as this is critical in order to keep up with the class.
Florent is amazing. So much energy and a genuinely nice guy. You never get bored and your French will improve SO much. I loved the class.
Practice going to french tables, listening on your own, etc
This class is definitely worth the work you'd put in. It isn't too hard. Just stay on top of things and participate!

Your French will GREATLY improve with this double course, so if that's what you want, then don't hesitate to take this. Florent knows his stuff and is super engaging. The homework might seem like a lot at first, but it gets better, and it's not as much as if you were taking two actual courses.
prereqs: FRE 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: FRE 102-7 is an intensive double course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Focus will be on reading and listening comprehension, oral proficiency, grammatical accuracy, and the development of reading and writing skills. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be introduced to various Francophone cultures through readings, videos and films.

title: Mathematical Logic
descrip: Propositional and predicate calculus. Goedel completeness and incompleteness theorems. Finitary methods.

title: Intensive Korean I
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. The credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing 2-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: The first part of Intensive Korean is designed for heritage students who have already had considerable amount of exposure to the Korean language and culture but have not received any formal instruction before their arriving at Princeton. It covers the 1st Year Korean material focusing on vocabulary building, grammar, reading and writing. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th Year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: Dynamic Meteorology
reviews: An interesting course if you are interested in what drives large scale weather patterns. Not very time consuming or difficult either.

This class isn't a lot of work and it's very interesting. 
Still, be warned: the material isn't easy. This is a physics class. Very quantitative, very mathy, conceptually difficult. 
That said, it's one of my favorite courses I've taken here - reminds me why I originally considered being a physics major. 
The class is basically about wind - the basic forces in the atmosphere, wind over mountains, the jet stream, fronts, thunderstorms, hurricanes, and more. More scientific than "what's the weather going to be tomorrow" - so maybe not as practically-oriented as I'd expected going in, but very cool.
prereqs: One 200-level math course or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course provides the rigorous introduction to the moving atmosphere needed to understand Earth's weather and climate. The fundamental forces of the atmosphere (pressure gradient, gravity, and Coriolis) and conservation laws (mass, momentum, energy) will be developed. Approximations relevant to Earth's large-scale circulation and regional-scale extreme events will be discussed. Important consequences of atmospheric turbulence will also be covered. Throughout, connections between dynamical equations and atmospheric observations will be strongly emphasized.

title: International Relations
reviews: Avoid it if you can.
Be prepared to do a lot of reading (interesting reading), but this is a great course that everyone should take just to be a cognizant global citizen.
Be prepared to read A LOT!!!
Be ready for a lot of reading and keep up with the readings!
Definitely a lot more work than I was expecting, but is interesting stuff. The reading load is pretty heavy, and Moravcsik is a harsh grader. Try to get Matteo as a preceptor.
Definitely take it!!
Do all the readings and be engaged for every assignment/reading/lecture/precept. It is an incredibly rewarding experience.
Do it. Wish I had taken it freshman year.
Do the readings, watch the films!
Don't take it if you have any other course with significant reading. If you're already familiar with the international system, you might not learn all that much. Otherwise, enjoy!
Excellent course if you want to learn about contemporary international relations theory.
Excellent course, very interesting and informative. Moravscik is a fantastic professor. But be warned; this class has ALOT of readings.
Go to office hours. Don't be afraid of Moravcsik. Be ready to spend quite a bit of time on readings. It is rewarding, though.
Grading can be arbitrary, but you will learn a lot if you put in the work.
Harsh and unreasonable grading, no PDF, preceptors are in general terrible, a lot of material and little support

I highly recommend this course with Professor Moravcsik, but make sure you are ready to do a ton of readings. There is a way to get around not reading them but doing the readings will give you a much better idea of the discussions at hand. The lectures are well prepared and interesting for all!
I learned a ton. Moravcsik is great. PDF it if you can because there is a TON of reading and the grading seems somewhat arbitrary.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone with an interest in IR or politics, for it will provide a solid base in the subject.
I would recommend this class to someone willing to read a lot and deal with seemingly arbitrary grading for a good lecturer.
I would recommend this course, it is imperative that you keep up with the readings, which are many, because they drive precept discussion and are helpful in preparing for the midterm and final.
If you want to take POL 240 I would recommend that you take it with Professor Moravcsik.

It's a very interesting topic and there's lots of ground covered, but the course (taught by Moravcsik at least) isn't very well structured and far more work than you'd expect in an intro course. Grading is fairly subjective, which can be frustrating because it makes even improving your work difficult to do. Take Gary Bass's Causes of War (or perhaps the other intro IR course -- I can't vouch for the other professor) instead.
Its a lot of work.  Moravcsik is a good lecturer but it is more difficult that with other professors.
Keep up with the readings in order to participate more in precept.
Learn pretty quickly to distinguish what the most important readings will be (usually theoretical), and start a glossary of key terms immediately. You'll thank yourself on the final.
Only take POL 240 with Moravcsik if you are willing to read a lot! However, the lectures and precepts are well worth it.
Only take this course if you're very interested in the subject. It's a very hard course, and you will have a bad time if you're not interested in international relations.
Only take this course with Moravcik -- he's incredibly engaging and you learn a lot. He expects a lot of reading though.
Professor Moravcsik is a great lecturer and preceptor. Strongly recommend for everyone, particularly WWS majors.
Stay on top of the readings. Print out the syllabus and cross them off as you go.
Take it
Take it - but dedicate a lot of time to it.
Take it if Moravcsik is teaching it. The reading load is heavy and not for the faint of heart, but if you can do it you will get a lot out of the course.
Take it sophomore year at the soonest - be prepared to do work but become a better person because of it
Take it when Professor Moravcsik is teaching it, he is an excellent professor.
Take it with the other professors.
Take it! It's an excellent way to be introduced to IR, and an enjoyable way to systematize your knowledge even if you're already in possession of some.
Take it, especially because it counts twice for freshman and sophomores wanting to be in the Woodrow Wilson School.
Take this course if you are prepared to do all of the readings each week. The readings are very dense but you learn a lot in this course.
Take this course only if you will be dedicated to doing all the reading each week.

The course provides resources such as lecture notes and discussion notes that are very much worth having a look at. Additionally, make sure to take careful notes as you do the readings--sometimes you may do them super-early to be able to finish them, and if you don't take notes, you're likely to be a little hazy on the details.
The course to take (with Professor Moravcsik) for students interested in the fundamentals of international relations.

There is a ridiculous amount of reading for this course. You cannot complete it all without taking away from your other courses. If you want a good grade I would only recommend taking this course if you had already done some of the readings prior to the course (that is the case for pretty much everyone I know who is doing well in the course).
This course had interesting lectures, but was primarily an IR theory course and was quite work intensive. 200  pages of reading a week, and harshly graded assignments.
This course is a challenging, time-consuming class. Be prepared for tons of reading. If you are not genuinely interested in politics or International Relations, consider taking another course.
This is a hard but very important course
This is a very fun and entertaining class.

This is one of the most incredible courses I have taken at Princeton. Pound for pound, I don't think I have ever learned so much in a class here. If you have even a mild interest in politics or international relations, you have to take this course. It will blow your mind and change your Princeton experience! Also, only take this is Moravscik is teaching it (he is brilliant).

This is one of the most organized and thoughtful classes I have taken. You have to take this if you have any interest in IR because Moravcsik's lecture are clear and engaging, the readings are thoughtfully chosen and thought provoking, and the precepts are amazing because Moravcsik provides you with precept questions and ideas to consider and prepare before percept so that you can get the most out of precept. This course is a must take!
Unless you have a very deep interest in international relations specifically i think it would be best to find a different politics class.
You're expected to know a lot of things, but the class itself is interesting and Moravcsik is intense but great!
don't worry too much about all the readings.  It is more important to understand the broad scope than the little details.
take it but beware of the readings.... a ton of readings that most people don't end up finishing anyways
take it.
descrip: This course is an introduction to the causes and nature of international conflict and cooperation. We critically examine various theories of international politics by drawing on examples from various historical eras as well as across security and economic affairs. Topics include the causes of war, the pursuit of economic prosperity, the sources of international order and its breakdown, and the rise of challenges to national sovereignty, and issues such as international environmental politics, human rights promotion, global terrorism, and the future of US foreign policy.

title: Russian Folklore
descrip: Explores Russian oral traditions and oral literary genres in English translation:Traditional life-cycle and seasonal rituals and songs associated with them; superstitions, charms, oral narrative poetry (byliny) and prose (skazki); chastushki, jokes; present-day popular culture; and relationships between folklore and literature. Focus on the role and meaning of Russian folklore as expressive culture and how it informs contemporary society.

title: Problems in American Cultural and Intellectual History
descrip: Issues and methods in the interpretation of American cultural and intellectual history, through the study of topics ranging from Puritanism to the present. Students may elect to take the course either as a reading or research seminar.

title: Princeton Atelier - Appropriation: The Politics of Intertextuality in Word and Image
