prereqs: Students with interest and background in the visual arts or in creative writing are encouraged to apply. Application is required. Art and/or writing portfolio may be required. For more information and application, please consult the Princeton Atelier web page princeton.edu/arts/..
descrip: Author Rick Moody and painter John O'Connor will lead an Atelier on interactivity and multi-disciplinary qualities of the contemporary arts. Classes will involve discussion of case histories; in-class assignments derived from a demonstration of how to 'make' certain kinds of intertextual work; and critiques of work made by students, Moody and O'Connor.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew
descrip: Students will achieve a basic ability to read the Hebrew Bible/Old Testamtent in its original language. During the semester, students will study the grammar and develop their vocabulary. Upon completing the grammar textbook, students will read large passages from the Bible from all genres.

title: Human-Computer Interface Technology
prereqs: COS 217 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Introduction to human-computer interaction, with emphasis on design, implementation, & evaluation of interactive hardware/software systems. Will examine a variety of input techniques (mouse, multi-touch, gesture, tangibles, bio-sensing, etc.), as well as computational mechanisms for creating sophisticated interactions (machine learning, signal processing, human computation, etc.). Also covered: interaction design, usability evaluation, accessible computing, ubiquitous computing, mobile interfaces, multimedia & gaming, others. Culminates in a team project involving design and implementation of an interactive system.

title: American Revolutions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Tonal Syntax
reviews: I would strongly recommend doing this course as it gave me a new perspective on the compositional process.
If you are taking this class, it's probably for the music major or certificate. So... if you have to take it anyway, take it with Dan. He's incredible.
Practice, practice, practice. Transcribe actual Bach pieces because you'll get used to the style much quicker. I didn't do that nearly enough until the very end of the course.
Take it
Take it as a follow-up to 206. However, be warned that the compositions involve much more personal taste.
Take it; you'll get more out of the in-lecture discussions than I did.
Take this class; you'll learn a lot.
This is a very useful course that should be taken.
prereqs: MUS 205 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: MUS 206 begins by making relevant connections between the modal counterpoint of the 16th century (studied in MUS 205) and tonality as it evolved in the 18th century. Fundamental tonal concepts will then be explored in later music including Chopin and Brahms.

title: High Energy Astrophysics
descrip: Selected astrophysical applications of electrodynamics, special and general relativity, nuclear and particle physics. Topics may include synchrotron radiation, comptonization, orbits and accretion in black-hole metrics, radio sources, cosmic rays, and neutrino astropysics.

title: Monotheistic Superheroes in the Islamic Tradition
descrip: The "monotheistic superheroes" in the Islamic tradition are the "brother prophets" who preceded Muhammad, the "seal of the prophets." These prophets include figures who have parallels in the Jewish and Christian traditions, such as Abraham, Moses, Solomon and Jesus. We will explore the history of the rich post scriptural Islamic tradition, both oral and written, that developed and expanded the "stories of the prophets" and made them into the "monotheistic superheroes" that they continue to be today.

title: Sociology of Sports
reviews: If you are interested in sports, this is a must-take class. A wonderful blend of sociology, sports history, and sports journalism/literary criticism. A gem of a class.
Take this class.  Professor is one of the most understanding faculty I have ever come across and the class was a joy.
Take this course if you are interested in sports. It's really great for a 5th class because it's not a lot of work and Professor Kornblum is awesome.
descrip: The course will focus on sports and athletes in American communities (not limited to communities in the U.S.), and including sports on the college campus. Students will be asked to write about their own experiences with athletics and to compare them to examples drawn from outstanding first-hand accounts of sports in different community settings. Readings, films, and class discussions will afford opportunities to appreciate the individual and social benefits of participation in athletics, as well as the risks and value distortions that competitive sports may entail.

title: Computational Methods in Plasma Physics
reviews: I would recommend not taking this course, especially if you know how to do a von Neumann stability analysis already. If you don't, you might learn something new.
Very helpful if you want to do some coding for physics, especially for plasma physics.
prereqs: Graduate students and seniors only..
descrip: Analysis of methods for the numerical solution of the partial differential equations of plasma physics, including those of elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic, and eigenvalue type. Topics include finite difference, finite element, spectral, particle-in-cell, Monte Carlo, moving grid, and multiple-time-scale techniques, applied to the problems of plasma equilibrium, transport and stability. Basic parallel programming concepts are discussed.

title: General Plasma Physics II
reviews: This course is essential for understanding plasmas and how they behave in real situations.
descrip: Introduction to Plasma Physics at the Graduate level. Principles and applications of magnetohydrodynamic and kinetic theory are discussed. These principles are fundamental to Plasma Science, and the illustrative applications are relevant to current magnetic fusion research and plasma astrophysics.

title: Tragic Drama
reviews: Take it -- Ford is awesome and the readings are definitely doable. Medea is fascinating!
Take it if you love Greek, but it's a ball buster of a course at times.
The class delivers fully on its promise to acquaint the student with tragic drama. I would recommend it strongly to all Greek students.
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A close reading of one Greek tragedy, with supplementary readings (in English and Greek) illustrating the genre and its context.

title: Britain 1688-1815: From Revolution to Global Pre-eminence
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course is designed for students new to British history as well as for those with some background. It will give you a broad understanding of a period in which Britain (which is smaller than Texas) came by way of war, trade, and political, imperial, financial and industrial changes to be the richest of the world's powers, claiming authority over a fifth of the globe. We shall look at the different cultures in Britain and Ireland, at the links with the American colonies and why and how far these snapped in 1776, at the slave trade, and at the ideas of the men and women who lived here.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS COURSE!!! As somebody with no dance experience and who avoided dancing like the plague beforehand, I emerged from the class with dancing as a new hobby. Aynsley is such an encouraging and friendly instructor, and she WILL make YOU like to dance.

Aynsley is an amazing teacher - she is super accessible and extremely willing to help. Her class is pretty easy but takes up a lot of time. Be prepared to wear sweat pants or pajama pants 2 days a week.
Definitely take it
If you've never danced before, take this class. It's awesome!
Such a fun class. Aynsley is an amazing instructor. Take it!
TAKE THIS CLASS. AMAZING.
Take it! Aynsley is the best and I really learned a lot about my body and movement in general.
Take it! Be prepared to work and think, but it's super fun!
Take it! It's a great class that's very fun, and really helps you learn how to move your body. There is some work, but it's not too much and it really does help you think about dance.
Take it! Super fun.
Take this class! Aynsley is great!!!
Take this course.  It changes how you view dance.  I'm not a good dancer but the professor is so good at knowing its only an intro class.  Have fun and be yourself and you'll do great.

The dance is mostly unstructured, so if you're interested in technique or a lot of choreography, look at a difference dance class. But Aynsley is so amazing, and if you go in with a really open mind, you'll learn a lot about yourself and have a lot of fun!!

This course is a great way to introduce yourself to dance.  At first, I thought the idea of dance as an academic pursuit to be a little silly.  However, by the end of the class I have a profound respect for dance and hope to incorporate it to a much greater extent in my life.  In that regard, this class may have been the most life-changing class I've taken.

This course was strange.  It was easy as heck, but it felt like a waste of time.  If you don't like art, you will probably hate this course, but if you do, you'll probably like it.  It was a good reprieve from other super work intensive classes, allowing you to sit down and close your eyes for an hour and shake out your frustration.  But then you remember that you are paying $50,000 for an education and are spending it walking with wobbly knees and feel disappointed in yourself.  The course is PDF only, which means you can't do 'better' than anyone else which is how a class like this should be run.  Assignments are extremely easy because it's asking for your opinion and feelings, which are simple to write about.  Attendance is mandatory, so don't think you can blow off class (which is 4 hours a week, plus a whole bunch of dance presentations you need to go to on Thursday and Saturday nights).  If the course is full but you still want to do it, just go to the first class anyway and get your name put down on a list.  Aynsley is awesome and the class might be worth taking just to hang with her.  VERDICT:  Nice break from hard thinking, but don't be surprised if you feel like you are flushing money down the toilet being in the class.
Work initially looks like more than it really is. I recommend you take it.
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, the class will be a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing, and discussing. Students will investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and the cultural questions surrounding it. We will explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as aesthetic questions, politics, identity, religion, and complex views of the human body.

title: Latin: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: If you have any interest in Latin whatsoever, take it!!!! Professor Kaster is one of the best teachers I've had at Princeton, very enthusiastic and encouraging, and of course a brilliant Latinist. The course teaches Latin very effectively and forces you to learn the language fast. Be sure to keep up every single day with vocab and grammar, though - even one missed day can throw you off, especially later in the semester.
It's fantastic! A huge amount of work, but an excellent class.
Review vocab everyday in little bits and pieces.
Take it if you are at all or ever were interested in Latin, but be prepared to work hard and learn a lot.
Take it. It's not hard at all if you just practice your flashcards every day for an hour or two. I did it and it worked.
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to the Latin language: LAT 103 covers the material of LAT 101-102 in a shorter time through increased class time. Students completing the course will be prepared to take LAT 105.

title: Physics of Plasma Propulsion
descrip: Focus of this course is on fundamental processes in plasma thrusters for spacecraft propulsion with emphasis on recent research findings. Start with a review of the fundamentals of mass, momentum & energy transport in collisional plasmas, wall effects, & collective (wave) effects, & derive a generalized Ohm's law useful for discussing various plasma thruster concepts. Move to detailed discussions of the acceleration & dissipation mechanisms in Hall thrusters, magnetoplasmadynamic thrusters, pulsed plasma thrusters, & inductive plasma thrusters, & derive expressions for the propulsive efficiencies of each of these concepts.

title: Topics in Modern Italian Cinema - The New Italian Cinema (in English)
reviews: Gaetana is a gem. If you're interested in Italian film or film in general, it's a solid course.
I likes this course.
If you're already interested in Italian films, then this course is a sure bet. One of the Italian seminar courses might be better suited to actually learning and improving the language.

Prof. Marrone-Puglia will make you love Italy and love cinema and love Italian cinema.  She has such a charming way about her and her knowledge of the subject (including interesting behind-the-scenes comments on 'the business') really make this class one of my favorite I've taken at Princeton.
Take it if you're into cinema. Just make sure you pay attention for the midterm and final.
Take it.
descrip: This course looks at the way Italy has expressed its cultural, political, and social individuality in major cinematic works from the 1980s to the present. Directors such as Bertolucci, Moretti, Tornatore, Ozpetek, and Benigni offer a panorama of a generation of filmmakers that has contributed to the renewal of Italian cinema. Topics will be drawn from current issues, and will include the Holocaust and questions of memory, terrorism, political violence, migration, gender ideologies, the Mafia. Emphasis on film style and techniques.

title: Image and Imagination
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Electromagnetism
reviews: A fantastic course, and a great theoretical topic. This is what all physics fields should be like, nice and logical! Expect normal physics-course level problem sets, although they're all doable. Much of the class is a review of 106, with some more mathematics thrown in.
Do the reading and homeworks.
Don't take it if you can avoid it- there are much better PHY courses out there.
If you are a Physics major, you'll have to take it. Staggs was nice and entertaining! Hope she will be teaching it again!
If you're very interested in physics, then it's an interesting course. There is some overlap with 106, so only take this if you want to go a little deeper.
In my opinion, this is the best of the upper level physics classes.
It's a really fun class and you should take it.
Sitting somewhere between classical and modern physics, E/M is probably the most accessible to non-physics majors.  If you are PHY you will have to take it, and if not it is a good STX...
Take it if you have to.
The material is very interesting and sometimes extremely elegant, but be prepared to work through a lot of vector calculus.
The overall quality was good but I did not find anything interesting in the work that I done.
The workload was somewhere between that of 301 and 305. Prof. Staggs has a very frantic lecture style that might make you anxious.
Very solid electricity and magnetism course taught using the Griffiths textbook. Most of the material from the first half is covered in PHY 106, while the second half material is mostly new.
You have to take it, it's nothing horrible but you won't learn as much in it as you will in some other physics classes.
You learn definitively new stuff probably in the last quarter of the class.
You probably aren't taking this course for general interest, you're taking it because it's required. It's material you need to know, so learn it.
eh you gotta take it if you're a physics major.
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Electromagnetic theory based on Maxwell's equations. Electrostatics, including boundary valve problems, dielectrics, and energy considerations leading to the Maxwell stress tensor. Magnetostatics and simple magnetic materials. Electromagnetic waves, retarded potentials and radiation. Familiarity with vector calculus is assumed.

title: Afghanistan and the Great Powers, 1747-2001
reviews: 3 hour lectures are not a real way to learn. But Barry is very supportive to any student expressing interest.
Absolutely take it if you have any interest in the region.  Michael Barry is a fantastic professor.
An interesting class.  Attend all of the lectures as they are extremely interesting and pertinent.
Definitely take it, just be prepared to manage your time
Do not take it if you can't sit through 3 hours of lectures.
Easiest grading I've ever seen.
Even though Barry doesn't check if you've done the reading, do it because it's fascinating
Go to office hours to get to know Professor Barry because he is such an interesting person to talk to!
Great instructor   interesting material = awesome course
I struggle to sit still for a three-hour class, however, if you are interested in the subject material, take the class!
If you enter with a strong interest in Afghan affairs, this course might be very rewarding.  Also, do not be taken aback by the 4 expensive pequod packets - you don't need to buy them.
If you need an HA take this.
If you only take one course at Princeton, this is it.
If you want a class that isn't a lot of work, at least outside of the 5 total days or so you spend writing/reading for the papers, and you're interested in the topic, then absolutely take this class.
It was a pretty work-light course with an interesting subject, but sitting through the 3 hour lectures was pretty tough.
Just take it!
Just take the class-- it's so worth it. He's amazing.
Maybe, if you are willing to actually sit through those lectures. DEFINITELY, talk separately with Barry, this is where he shines.
TAKE IT

TAKE THIS! I learned so much about Afghanistan and America's mistakes throughout the war.  I am much better informed about the Middle East in general and have a much better understanding of current event.s
Take it!
Take it! Barry is amazing!
Take it! Its hard to pay attention for 3 hours straight, but do your best because Prof. Barry has a lot to offer but if you aren't paying attention in class you won't get to hear what he is saying.
Take the class, you will not regret it.
Take this course at some point. It's worth it.
Take this course if it is the last thing you do. Professor Barry is the best teacher at Princeton. Go to his office hours for the coolest life stories and amazing conversation.
Take this course. You need to enjoy a class with Michael Barry before graduating. He's so knowledgeable about Afghanistan, with all of his experience in the country. You may regret not taking it.

This is an amazing course if you are interested in the subject or just history in general.  It requires a little self-dedication to keep up with the readings and to ask questions, but the professor is fantastic and you will understand Afghanistan in great depth by the time you are done.
pretty light workload.
you absolutely MUST take this course! I learned more about Pakistan and Afghanistan than I would have ever learned through reading on my own. The papers can be a bit rough, but the grading is fair.
descrip: Renewed in depth, NES307 traces the great powers' struggle to control the Middle East through the prism of Afghanistan, focusing on its social and tribal background and emergence as an independent kingdom in the 18th century, on the rivalries between Russia and Britain in the 19th century ("The Great Game") and those between the Soviet Union and the US in the 20th, concluding with study of Washington's support in the 1980s for Pakistan-based Islamist groups fighting the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, and the consequent rise of the Taliban movement allied to al Qaida from the 1990s to today.

title: Graphic Design
reviews: A really great LA. There's very little work outside of class. I'd recommend it to any one interested in typography/layout. Some experience with indesign is recommended.
Be prepared to put in a good amount of time doing the projects

Don't take it if you're thinking this is a course in graphic design as you think of graphic design. It's typesetting. You'll work with a printing press, a photocopy machine, and then InDesign. You'll be choosing fonts, sizes, line spacing, margins, etc. It's not much work out of the extensive class time for most of the semester, but expect to put in hours outside of class the last two weeks leading up to the day after lawnparties (spring, but fall people you can figure that out).
Don't take this course to learn how to do graphic design, it is more about the history and current use of typography.
Great course, take it!
Great! I loved Alice, this is an awesome introduction to typography and graphic design.
It's a lot of work, but if you are willing to do it, it is totally worth it.
Make sure you understand the readings you will be typesetting.
Only take this class if you really like typsetting. Also, don't underestimate the workload. It's like having a problem set due every week.
Take this class! It will change the way you think about type and the presentation of information.
take it take it take it.
descrip: This studio course will introduce students to the essential aspects and skills of graphic design, and will analyze and discuss the increasingly vital role that non-verbal, graphic information plays in all areas of professional life, from fine art and book design to social networking and the Internet. Students in the course will explore visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, type design, and image. Hands on production will include an array of do-it-yourself printing and distribution technologies, from letterpress and mimeograph to photocopying and websites.

title: Survey of Calculus
reviews: Class for non-math people. Take it if you don't plan on using too much math later on.
Do homework in groups; its very easy to make small mistakes! Also, staple your homework, and go to the review sessions.
For anyone who has not taken calculus and needs to know single variable for another major with the least pain possible.
Go to lecture--that's where you will learn everything for the quizzes and problem sets.

I would strongly recommend this class as a QR or if you need it before taking upper economics or for pre-med.  It was a great class, especially with Chen, Szu-Yu .  She is a great professor and makes the material straightforward and easy to understand.  Furthermore, her exams were straight forward with no tricks and problems pretty much right from the psets or class.  The psets may challenge slightly but if you keep up in class and study, it shouldn't be too hard.  The review sessions held by Minh are extremely helpful!  It was a great class!
I would take this class to fulfill the requirement.  It is easier than MAT 100.
If you're pre med and are trying to get the Math requirement out of the way this class is perfect.
MAT 102 gives you a good general understanding of calculus. It is easier than MAT 103 from what I've heard, but then again there are no 'easy' classes at Princeton.
good, basic calculus class.
prereqs: MAT100 or equivalent. Cannot receive course credit for both MAT103 and MAT102. Students who need to take further calculus courses like MAT104 or MAT175 should take MAT103 instead..
descrip: One semester survey of the major concepts and computational techniques of calculus including limits, derivatives and integrals. Emphasis on basic examples and applications of calculus including approximation, differential equations, rates of change and error estimation for students who will take no further calculus.

title: Dynamical Systems
prereqs: For advanced level Juniors and Seniors. Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course in Dynamical Systems will include differentiable actions of Z or R on manifolds, with emphasis on asymptotic properties of orbits, as well as stability (KAM theory), instability (chaos), and ergodic properties.

title: Latin Prose Fiction
prereqs: LAT 108 or equivalent with permission of the instructor.
descrip: To study the two surviving novels in classical Latin, Petronius' "Satyricon" and Apuleius' "Metamorphoses", as works of literary genius, as major influences in Western fiction, and as documents of contemporary society.

title: Molecular Spectroscopy
descrip: A survey of atomic and molecular energy levels and the Hamiltonians that describe them. The interaction of radiation with matter, including multiphoton effects and nano-optics. Examples include electronic and nuclear spectroscopy of molecules and crystals, electron spin resonance, microwave spectroscopy, and the uses of lasers in modern spectroscopic research.

title: Neuroimmunology: Immune Molecules in Normal Brain Function and Neuropathology
reviews: Definitely recommend! Not too much work, but you learn a lot.
Great class w Boulanger - but if you're not coming from a technical MOL background it can be a little challenging.
Great class-- do take!
Great course to take if you're a neuroscience certificate student.
Take It!
Take it, if you're willing to wade through some dense papers!
Take it.
This is a fantastic couse.  Prof. Boulanger is insightful and a great teacher.  As a non-science major I didn't find the readings overwhelming, though they were sufficiently stimulating.
Very nice seminar
You will develop the skills to be a better researcher.
prereqs: MOL 214 / EEB 214 (Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology); MOL 340 (Molecular and Cellular Immunology) and MOL 348 (Cell and Developmental Biology) would provide additional useful background, and may be taken concurrently..
descrip: In this course, we will explore the diverse and complex interactions between the brain and the immune system from the perspective of current, cutting-edge research papers. In particular, we will focus on the molecular mechanisms of these interactions and their role in brain development and function as well as their potential contributions to specific neurological disorders, including autism. In the process, students will learn to read, critically evaluate, and explain in presentations the content of articles from the primary literature.

title: Synthesis and Processing of Ceramic Matrix Composites
descrip: A comprehensive study of the processes used in synthesis and processing of ceramic composites. Three generic processing methodologies are contrasted: (1) powder consolidation and heat treatment (sintering), (2) conversion of molecular precursors (liquid or vapor) to ceramics, and (3) ceramic formation on organic templates. The objective is to provide a fundamental understanding of the processes for controlling properties through nanostructural design.

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation II
reviews: It's a lot like 207, but with two movies thrown in.  If you want to improve your Russian, you ought to take it.

Ksana's a great teacher and is really nice. By the time you take this class you'll have taken a class with her for at least a semester (and often more if you were in Petersburg), so you probably already know that. If you want to improve your Russian, take this class.
Take this.  It's certainly worth it to work on your Russian.

This class, like 207, is a ton of work, though I preferred 208 over 207 because there was more variety (a new author/movie every two weeks). I recommend that if you take this much Russian, you should seriously consider the certificate.
if you are taking 207 this is the natural course to take afterward.
prereqs: RUS 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 207. Translation and discussion of the literary texts (20th-century poetry) and the poets' biographies; review of selected grammar topics; work with a movie "Vostok-Zapad".

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: I'd definitely encourage students to take this course as it encourages a lot of research and new skills that haven't been previously taught in other studios.
Not for the faint-hearted.
do your own thing. make sure you produce stuff for desk crits. print business cards
they should be prepared for a lot of work and  a high level of challenge.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Beginner's Spanish II
reviews: A lot of people didn't understand why I would take a course with class 5 days a week and nightly assignments in my senior year. I learned so much in this class, and I regret not getting into good habits early--doing the work the day before it is due, attending Spanish tables, etc.
Definitely be prepared to dedicate a lot of hours and don't get discouraged by tough grading and the seeming randomness of how hard a test it.
Definitely take this course, and if you could get Professor Ramos I would recommend it even more.
Definitely! Very rewarding, if a lot of regular work
Depends on the professor, I got a great one which made the course manageable.
Distriburtion!
Do all the homework.
Do all your homework on time.
Do not hesitate to ask the teacher for extra help or request a tutor.
Do the day-to-day work and you'll be fine. Prof. Zetterstrand is a great!

Do the homework every day, study the vocabulary and grammar before you come to class, and try to think in Spanish the entire time you're in class.  All of those things will set you up to learn a lot from the course.
Don't expect everyone in the class to have had no spanish background.
Fine, not the end of the world if you have to take it. Marcia Olander is one of the best teachers I've ever had, but the course overall is ok.
Get a teacher you like
Get the most out of grammar in class and don't ask to go over vocabulary.

If you get the chance, get Professor Ramos. She is incredibly nice and understanding. She teaches well. However, English could sometimes be problematic because she doesn't always understand our questions right away. This leads to an extended review of things you did not ask for. Nevertheless, this should not matter the least bit as it is a very technical aspect of your learning experience.
If you have a chance take a class with Sylvia. She is wonderful!
If you're good at learning languages go for it, if not, you have to take it anyway for a distribution requirement so enjoy it as much as you can.
Keep up
Keep up with the grammar!
Marcia Olander is a very good instructor and I hope to have her next semester
Maybe take if you REALLY like Spanish, otherwise, I feel like there are better routes to learning Spanish.
Ramos is the bomb. She is a nice grader and makes her own exercises that are much better than the textbook.
Recommend taking it with Professor Olander.
Stay engaged throughout the semester.
Study a little each night.
Study the book before class everyday. It really makes a huge difference.
Study the vocabulary constantly with flashcards or else you will not be able to comprehend what is going on within the class.
Study the vocabulary in the textbook.
TAKE IT WITH PROFESSOR BOOKHAMER.
Take this class if you're interested in Spanish. Do the work and you'll be fine. Spanish is a beautiful language.
Take this class with Marcia Olander! Shes the man!

Take this course from Prof. Sylvia Zetterstrand. She is an excellent teacher, friendly, approachable, happy to be teaching students Spanish. You will learn Spanish well, and you will look forward to class every day.
Take this course, and take it with Profesora Baranksi!

The course is a bit harder than SPA101, but it's completely worth it. Attend Spanish tables as much as possible; they are a great way to practice informal conversational skills and apply the grammatical structures learned in class to a real conversation. Make sure you put the time in outside of class to study: memorize the vocab before each lesson using flashcards or whatever system works for you. Try to listen to as much Spanish as possible via YouTube or TV. All in all, one of the highlights of my freshman year!
The more effort you put in, the more you will get out of this class. Do the homework in preparation for class, participate actively, ask questions, and go to the Spanish table to practise speaking.
bookhamer is fun
class can get nitpicky on vocabulary, difficult to do well on essays
pick a good time to take it because you will have it every day
prereqs: SPA 101. No credit given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102..
descrip: The second course in the elementary Spanish sequence for students with little or no previous knowledge of the language. With its emphasis on the four basic skills (speaking, writing, reading, and listening), SPA 102 continues to provide students with the linguistic, communicative and cultural foundations to engage in basic daily life interactions in Spanish. Hispanic cultures are introduced through a variety of texts, including readings, music, art, video clips, and film. All of these sources provide the basis for classroom activities.

title: French Senior Seminar
reviews: Perhaps seek out the advice of Prof. Blix before you turn your paper in to make sure he likes what you are writing.
Totally worthwhile and not nearly as scary as it might sound combined with a thesis
prereqs: For senior concentrators in the Department of French and Italian only..
descrip: This course is designed to provide a formal environment for French senior concentrators to refine their command of literature, culture, and thought, as well as to foster their writing skills. In addition, the seminar helps prepare students for the department's final comprehensive examination. Major texts from the French and francophone traditions will be studied weekly, and, in addition to being discussed, will serve as bases for writing workshops. An important part of the seminar will also be dedicated to the art of translation.

title: Clues, Evidence, Detection: Law Stories
reviews: Absolutely take it!

If you're interested in criminal law or fiction, this is a great class. Professor Brooks is brilliant and a very good precept leader. Be prepared for substantial (and sometimes boring) reading though. The readings sometimes became too cumbersome.
Its ok, but not sure I gained much from taking it.

Not really worth the time, especially if you are looking for something enlightening. Super easy, though, if that's what you're looking for. Otherwise, take the reading list and read the material on your own time. The seminars add nothing.
Take this! Not too much work and great class.
This is a great EM to take, and if you at all find the law interesting, you will definitely enjoy the reading.
descrip: The seminar will look at stories in the law and about the law: court cases that turn on competing versions of a story, and how narrative "conviction" comes about, as well as fictional and non-fiction accounts of mystery, crime, investigation, and detection in literature and film. The course will introduce students to some issues in criminal law and procedure as well as to the analysis of narrative.

title: Russian Cinema
descrip: The course is intended as a general introduction to Russian film. It surveys landmark cinematic achievements from the eve of the 1917 Revolution to the present. The screening and discussion of individual films will serve as an occasion to address the broader context of Russian history and culture during this period.

title: Elementary Chinese I
prereqs: No credit is given for CHI 101 unless it is followed by CHI 102..
descrip: An intensive introductory course in modern spoken and written Chinese, stressing oral-aural facility and the analysis of structure.

title: The Western Way of War
reviews: Attend all the lectures! They're worth it.
Awesome course! Professor Centeno is fantastic, and the readings (if you do them) are pretty enriching as well. Would definitely recommend, especially if you are looking to fill the HA requirement.
Centeno is the best! As for the tests, be very specific in tying together the concepts with examples from the texts.
Centeno makes this course worthwhile. Easy to PDF this class.
Definitely take it!! Super interesting!
Do it
Do it!
Do the readings and attend every lecture.
Do the readings.  Really, it will hurt you during midterms and finals if you don't.  And please, start on Life and Fate earlier.  It's actually really hard to finish this book.
Do your reading.  It is useful and helpful.
Get ahead on your reading or else you will have no idea what is going on.

Great class.  Centeno is a great lecturer.  Do not be discouraged from taking this class because you "aren't that interested in war."  Cool parallels between sports and war for the athletic types out there.
Great course--heavy on the readings but Prof Centeno always tells you which parts are most important and VERY REWARDING!
Great professor and really interesting books! If you're looking for an HA, this is the one to take

I would advise them to start the semester long reading early and make sure to keep up with the weekly reading as well. If they do not have time to read all of the assigned reading, they should at least read the mandatory chapters that Professor goes over in lecture. Be sure to stay on top of the reading if you are supposed to present in precept that week and don't wait until the last minute to write your memo.
I would highly recommend it if you are interested in war at all. A great supplement to HIS354 with David Bell.
I would recommend this class to anyone that asks.
I would recommend.
I would say that it is a great course to take while at Princeton. It offers insight to a topic and issues that many people never consider. So insightful and interesting.
I'd say it's important to attend the lectures or you will find yourself in a hole when studying for exams.
If you like sociology classes, you'll probably like this one.
Lot of fun, lot of reading, take it.
Lots of readings. Find out what the format of the assignments will be. Centeno's lectures are very engaging.
READ the readings. Don't save it till the end.
TAKE THIS CLASS. The rumors are true this is an AMAZING CLASS! Also not hard at all, very doable, this is for you engineers who need a fifth!
Take if you want a straightforward, easy, and somewhat enjoyable class.
Take it - I PDFed it so I don't really have a strong opinion on whether or not to take this.
Take it if you are interested in war or if you need an HA. Grading is also very fair!

Take it no question. Centeno is an amazing lecturer, his reading selections are interesting, and the workload is not difficult by any means. The midterm and final are very reasonable. But really just take it for Centeno lecturing.
Take it!
Take it! It's fun and leniently graded.
Take it! Lots of reading so maybe PDF it if you're just looking for another class. But it's so interesting. Some parts are more relevant than others. We didn't go too far into contemporary stuff.
Take it, it's awesome!
Take it.

Take this class! Centeno is an amazing lecturer and the subject material is fascinating. It's not as easy a class as some people make it out to be though, so you can't slack off too much and expect to get away with it.
Take this class.  Especially if you like Sociology.

Take this class. Lots of reading but manageable, and Centeno is a FANTASTIC lecturer. Amazingly interesting and incredibly relevant subject matter. Try to get Rachael Ferguson as your preceptor, she's great.
Take this course! I think it has been my favorite course at Princeton, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone!

The class was a lot more work than I expected, but I enjoyed this class a lot.  I found the readings quite interesting and Professor Centeno is probably the most passionate lecturer that I've had at Princeton.  Definitely think about it if you're looking for an HA.
The readings are extremely long but still interesting. Probably a good class to PDF.
This was a great course, albeit more time-consuming than I expected. But I enjoyed it nonetheless.

You should take it, but it is a bit overrated. While Centeno is an absolutely phenomenal lecturer, some aspects of this course are frustrating. The reading load is excessive, expectations for precept memos are unclear, and the first third of the course seems very repetitive. Definitely worth taking for the lectures and second-half content. You will learn a new way of thinking and a different analytical perspective. Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading.
good class. a lot of reading but interesting.
take the course!!
descrip: A historical and analytical overview of war focusing on the origins and consequences of organized violence, the experience of battle, the creation and behavior of warriors, and the future of such conflicts.

title: Readings in Modern Korean II
reviews: For the written assignments, try to put some of your own thoughts into the writing (almost like a persuasive essay) rather than an objective piece of writing. Also, always do the readings assigned for each seminar because the discussions are always very interesting and you will not get anything out of the class if you do not read (there are only 1-2 readings per week). Everyone gets really involved in the discussion (and you will be left out if you do not read).

I highly recommend this course. I think that just as understanding what constitutes "The Great American Novel" is a critical part of understanding America and why things are the way they are today, reading the most prominent literary works in modern Korea will give you a much deeper understanding of Korean history and society. Also, the class was a lot of fun!
Take it if you want to learn more about Korean literature.
Take this course. Expect to write every week, but if you like reading literature and know Korea, definitely take the course.

This course is a lot of fun!  It does require time though because of the readings, analysis, and writing, but if you want to learn more about Korean culture and history in a non-history-class setting, this is perfect.
prereqs: KOR 402 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course is designed: to advance students' literacy skills to the Superior level (near native-like); to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, history and literature; and to further develop their critical thinking through reading and writing in Korean. Focusing on change in the Korean language in relation to history, society, and culture, the course covers a wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues through various media resources as well as documents written in Middle Korean, literary short stories and poems, traditional and modern.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Introduction to Graph Theory
reviews: Definitely take it because Prof. Seymour is great, just be aware that there is very very serious grade deflation in the class as most people get full marks on problem sets.

Don't take this course if you don't like or aren't good at writing proofs.

If you are interested in graph theory at all, and enjoy proof-based math, you will probably enjoy the course. I think most people would consider it relatively difficult, though, so be warned.
Good introduction to Graph Theory.  Seymour is one of the experts in the field.

Graph theory itself is really interesting, and Seymour's cool.  Problem sets are really easy for a 300 level math course, but be careful as the graders are nitpicky.  Sometimes lectures got boring, but in general they were good.

Hmmmm. Kind of hard to give advice on this one... Don't be deceived by the first pset if you take this course during add/drop; the psets will usually be longer. Professor Seymour will upload notes of the course, but often he will fall behind by 2 or 3 weeks, and you will be trying to solve the problem set without the theorems, unless you managed to copy all of them down, and understood anyways. This course is fun but it is more work than some people say.
If you are a fan of proofs, logic, discrete math in general, I would strongly recommend this course. Also if you are into computer science and find graphs and theory fun you might like this.
Invest time in it.
Problem sets were fun, and not very difficult.
Proof by induction gets tedious.
Take it.
The proof for this class is anything but boring, seymor is an excellent lecturer. I'd highly recommend it.
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204 or 217 or equivalent..
descrip: The fundamental theorems and algorithms of graph theory. Topics include: connectivity, matchings, graph coloring, planarity, the four-color theorem, extremal problems, network flows, and related algorithms.

title: The African American Prophetic Tradition
descrip: The quest for freedom has been a constant struggle for African-Americans in modern America. This course will explore the context of how a prophetic tradition emerged while the rhetoric and activism of leaders reflected efforts to dismantle the economic, social, and political disenfranchisement African-Americans endured in a racially hostile country. Drawing upon early anti-slavery sermons, speeches and other primary source documents which reflect the historicity of selected eras in American history, we will study individuals who embraced this prophetic tradition and strived to achieve full liberation in American society.

title: Earth Chemistry: The Major Realms of the Planet
prereqs: CHM 201, or equivalent; MAT 103, or equivalent..
descrip: The chemical composition of the major realms of the planet: core, mantle, continents, ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. Topics include the synthesis of the chemical elements in stars, the origin of the solar system and Earth, and the chemical differentiation of Earth's core, mantle, crust, ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. Also explores the global cycles of carbon, nitrogen, and other biologically important elements, their interactions with the geosphere, and their evolution through time.

title: Advanced Persian: Iran through Film
prereqs: Successful completion of PER 105, or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will engage students thoughtfully with modern Iranian society and politics through documentaries. Each week, students will watch a documentary and prepare for a lively in-class discussion of the issues. Students will be heavily exposed to colloquial Persian.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: Literature and the Arts
reviews: A phenomenal course. I really enjoyed HUM 216-217, and HUM 218-219 was a thousand times better. Embrace the format of a survey course and recognize its limitations, then take this course and enjoy every minute of it!

Expect to have too much reading, but don't be dissuaded (or even really intimidated -- just do what you reasonably can).  The lectures alone make the course worth it. They are consistently amazing. Our guest lectures (art, music) are also really fun.

I jumped on ship second semester without taking the first semester and the course was an absolute thrill and honor to take. The books we read could each merit a course of their own and the team of professors equally match the books in knowledge and enthusiasm. Though you may hear that this course jumps without lingering on each text long enough, the course is intended more as a gateway than an end. It is undoubtedly the best foundation and springboard to begin your studies at Princeton.
If you like Western thought and literature, HUM is a must.  If you like reading, HUM will be doable.  If one or neither of things apply to you, the course may not be for you.
If you love great thinkers, great books, and the Humanities, then by all means this course is for you. The reading is heavy but manageable, and lighter than the first semester.

If you want to contextualize any of your later studies in the humanities, take HUM. It is a challenge, but it is a worthwhile challenge. The professors are outstanding, the readings are classics, and you get the sense that you are a part of something special.
It will open an aspect of your experience as a person that you simply cannot access any other way.
It's a lot of work, but you don't have to do all the reading and you can still handle the exams/papers. Take it!
Read!
Read.  The class is great.  The class is amazing if you do all the reading.
Take HUM if you enjoy/ want a certificate in the Humanities. Take HUM if you like reading. If you are pressed for course time, then do not take HUM.

Take HUM only if you have some background in regards to the readings and are a good writer. Its' a lot of work, but the rewards are plentiful. Its a hard class, and eliminates any flexibility. I learned a lot, and it gave me a solid foundation.
Take HUM! It will be the best experience of your year at Princeton. I have made some of my best friends in this class and feel bonded to the students.
Take a precept with Freed-Thall or Ryan. They're great
Take it and do the work. You'll get so much out of it.
Take it if you want to gain a more critical understanding of the world. This course may not give you depth, but it will expand your horizons and help you think deeper on your own.
Take it!! have to take it!
Take it.
Take it. You won't regret it. The quality of the professors is incredible. You won't find an experience even remotely comparable to the HUM sequence anywhere else at Princeton.
Take the course.  It's a lot of reading, but is far more manageable than is widely reported, and is absolutely worth the effort.  Take the course.
take this course! you must be prepared to do readings otherwise you simply wont get as much out of it.
prereqs: Students who have not completed HUM 216-217 should submit an application (see the Humanities Council website) with a letter describing their interest in taking 218-219 and their background in classical, biblical and medieval studies. Deadline is December 6 for notification by December 10..
descrip: This team-taught double credit course is the second half of an intensive four-course, interdisciplinary introduction to Western culture that includes history, religion, philosophy, literature and the arts. It examines European texts, works of art and music from the Renaissance to the modern period. Readings and discussions are complemented by films, concerts, museum visits and special events. Although most students will have already taken 216 - 217, it is possible for students to join at this point if they have a strong background in antiquity and the Middle Ages.

title: The Civilization of the High Middle Ages
reviews: Do not take unless you have are fascinated already with the middle ages. It will not sustain your interest if you feel otherwise.
Dont take this unless you are really into the Middle Ages. You'll not engage if you don't
I would definitely take it if you need a history course and are interested in the middle ages. It's a fun class.
Make sure you like the topic before entering the class.

Not too intimidating, but very interesting. I don't think the class helps you grasp the billions of names of rulers very well - but since we didn't seem to need to know most of them besides a shortlist, it's fine.
Professor Jordan is fantastic. Take it. Also, not a lot of reading is assigned.
Take it.
Take this course. No matter who you are.
The best lectures you will hear while at Princeton.  Professor Jordan is incredibly entertaining and is THE expert of the Middle Ages.

This is a relatively easy and lighthearted class. A painless way to get history pre-modern requirement out of the way. Unless you need that requirement or have a real hankering for the Middle Ages, I'd stay away.
You can definitely choose how engaged you want to be in the course. Lecture is interesting but not necessary for anything that's graded
take it.
descrip: In lectures, to provide my interpretation (and a conspectus of differing interpretations) of the civilization of Western Europe, 11th-14th century; by the readings, to introduce students to the variety of surviving sources; through the paper, to give students a taste of doing medieval history.

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of empirical research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social science methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U. S. and in comparative perspective.

title: Algebraic Geometry
reviews: A very rewarding course but should be supplemented with a solid grasp of commutative algebra.
Algebraic geometry is bright, clean, and beautiful.

I really recommend taking algebraic geometry, although this is probably coming out of my interest in the subject itself than specific things about the course. If you get someone as cool and smart as Yu-Han as your teacher, then you're going to have a great semester thinking very hard and being asked difficult questions not just about math but about your life goals. Just be prepared to do some reading outside of the course books, since algebraic geometry is something you need a lot of exposure to before you get comfortable. Also, make sure you know commutative algebra to a certain extent?
I recommend taking the class if you are interested in learning algebraic geometry.
I took it under Yu-Han, nothing I say is relevant.
descrip: Introduction to affine and projective algebraic varieties over fields.

title: Topics in Discrete Mathematics
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Discrete Mathematics. Specific topic information provided when the course is taught.

title: Contagion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: Answered in ISC 233 evaluations
Don't worry about getting your grades back. It is a lot to grade, they will get to it. Focus your effort on the next assignment.
If you can take the heat, take the course.
Make sure you understand the math and don't fall behind.
Please refer to ISC 233 Course Evaluation for this answer!
See eval for ISC233
See responses to ISC 233.

This class was probably one of the hardest things I?ve done in my life. The workload is immense, the nights long, the labs endless, and the expectations higher than you can first imagine. I didn?t know I could work this hard ? I worked pretty darn hard in high school, but this is simply another level. That being said, it was entirely worth it. The beginning is overwhelming, and in my opinion the material actually gradually increases in difficulty throughout the year, but you get better at it: you learn how to use MatLab, you get used to writing in Latex, and you learn how to write labs and do problem sets more efficiently. The professors and the other students are utterly amazing ? and I think it?s safe to say there?s nothing else like it. In my opinion, it?s completely worth it, but be willing for it to define your freshman year.
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across 4 departments with the following faculty involved in teaching the course: W. Bialek, J. Shaevitz (PHY); O. Troyanskaya (COS); H. Yang (CHM); C. Broedersz, T. Calhoun, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI Fellows).

title: Energy Conversion and the Environment: Transportation Applications
reviews: Expect problem sets to take up some time!
If this is something that you are interested in, I would recommend it.
If you're at all interested in engines, take it!
Material was not intuitive to me, but I felt the class was very organized and the material is very interesting if its something you like. Mueller is very helpful!

Pretty great class despite what we've probably all heard from previous years. Mueller's a great lecturer. Psets and exams will probably take a while to get through simply because of the derviation-based nature of the class/topics, but lecturers are very thorough and balanced. Go to lecture (pay attention, take detailed notes) and office hours - Prof. M is very accessible. Consider taking some other classes which aren't too problem set heavy. Totally do-able for non-MAEs, but having a solid grasp of thermo and pipes (fluid mechanics) will help.

Prof. Mueller is a humorous guy who really knows his stuff. I'd say his teaching quality rivals, if not exceeds, that of Prof. Dryer's teaching quality. You actually learn a whole lot of stuff about engines, and they are actually practical.
Professor Mueller does an awesome job teaching MAE427. As a young/new professor he is motivated, engaging, and very accessible.

Professor Mueller might be the best lecturer I had ever had at Princeton. I is really funny, smart, and great at making you feel engaged in the class. Be prepared to work long and hard on the problem sets though.
Take it!  You learn a lot and it's interesting.

Take the course if Professor Mueller is teaching it! He was a great professor and his problem sets are reasonable. Very enjoyable course! The exams are difficult though. I would still strongly recommend the course.
This is a great course! It is definitely a lot of work, so make sure that you are genuinely interested in the course material before you commit to it.

You don't need to read Prof. Dryer's notes; Prof Mueller's are more than enough. Go to every class (so that you can fill in the gaps on his power point slides), and pay lots of attention! If Sili is still the preceptor, go to her Office hours asking for help/guidance (without her I wouldn't have been able to do most of the problem sets). She is amazing.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or equivalent, or by permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will develop an overview of energy utilization in and environmental impacts of current and future propulsion systems for ground, air, and space propulsion applications. Principles of advanced internal combustion, electric hybrid, and fuel cell energy conversion systems for ground transportation will be introduced. Relevant thermodynamics, chemistry, fluid mechanics, and combustion fundamentals will be stressed, and performance properties of power plants, control of air pollutant emissions, and minimization of resource-to application carbon emissions will be explored.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Political Economy of Global Energy
descrip: Economic growth requires constantly growing use of energy, the Middle East plays a vital role as exporters of hydrocarbons to the rest of the world. The course will cover: 1) Global energy demand and supply scenarios and the role of the Middle East; 2) The functioning of the global oil market and the potential role of major oil exporters; 3) The resource curse, economic diversification and the experience of the Gulf countries; 4) Oil, accountability and conflicts; 5) The global gas market and the role of Qatar; 6) Rational use of energy, renewable energy sources and nuclear energy.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
reviews: Amazing lectures! Extremely interesting material and the readings offer so many perspectives!

Be engaged in this course: go to the lectures, do the readings (they're incredibly interesting), go to office hours. If you take advantage of all the resources, this course can be one of the best during your time here at Princeton.

Definitely a great class you learn so much it really opened my eyes to new ways of thinking especially in terms of how history and countries in Latin America work. Try to do the readings as best you can, it is a lot.
Don't fear about taking this class! You will learn a lot, and it won't hurt at all!

Great course, really interesting subject material - Professor Karl is a great professor who is really engaged and approachable. The one drawback is that the lectures are too fast and it's impossible to write everything down - consider recording them and be ready to take furious notes the whole time.
I highly recommend this course to students interested in taking it. I do hear that Professor Karl is a particularly difficult grader though, I would try to get Melissa as your preceptor.
I wish I had taken this course my freshman year, because I probably would have been a history major instead. Take it.

If Professor Karl is teaching, this course is not to be missed! A fantastic, comprehensive overview to the history of modern Latin America. Although the course officially begins with the struggles for independence for Spain, the first few lectures give a nice overview of the colonial background for Spanish and Portuguese America since the 1500's. Throughout, Professor Karl focuses a great deal on Mexico, Brazil, and Colombia (his specialty), but other countries are brought in  when necessary (i.e. Chile and Guatemala for the CIA interventions of the Cold War era). The reading load is a bit heavy, ranging from 150-250 pages per week. Most of it is quite enjoyable, but pace yourself; you'll get a lot more out of the class if you do all of the readings. As for written work, there is one in-class midterm exam (three IDs and a long essay), a short (5-7 page) paper, and a 5 page take home paper in lieu of a final. If Melissa Teixeira is still precepting, try to get her; she's fantastic and an expert on Brazilian history. Grading was fair and commentary on written work was quite detailed. If you have any interest at all in the history of the region, take this class! You won't regret it.
If you are interested in history and have the time to dig into the material, this is a great course. This is not a throw-away course, so make sure you have time for it.
It's a good overview course and the work load is average- I enjoyed the course.

It's a lot of material, but pretty easy to do well in. Professor Karl is great and really approachable but the fact that the class is tasked with teaching an entire continent's 200 year history seems unfair to as good a professor as him. I took this class when writing my thesis and it was totally fine, in terms of work load. I just don't know how much Latin American history I know.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Honestly, Professor Karl is one of the most intelligent professors I have ever had the pleasure of coming across. The lectures throw a bit too much information at you, so I would recommend getting the survey textbook that they mention and following along with the historical events to fill in some of the gaps. 

It's not an easy class, necessarily, but it is incredibly rewarding!
Take if you want to learn more about the entire Latin American region. However, don't expect to just blow it off.
Take it!

Take it! Moderate reading load, very light workload, interesting stuff, and most importantly: endless resources. There is no professor in this University who cares about teaching and the student experience than Robert Karl. If you are at all engaged or interested as a student, he and his excellent preceptors will make this class a good experience for you.
Take it! You will not regret it at all! The professor and preceptors are very accessible and truly care about the well-being of their students. You will learn a lot, and it will change you.
Take this class! You learn a lot, but the readings aren't unreasonable and the material is well-structured.
There is a lot of reading, but it's actually worth doing because they are really interesting.

This course is awesome! If you are interested in Latin America, definitely take this course. Professor Karl is an amazing lecturer and professor, and you can tell he loves teaching and really wants to help students learn and do well.
This course is very interesting, but be prepared for a lot of reading.
This is a class you should take as much as for the knowledge as for the experience of being taught by Professor Karl.

This is a great course. I signed up for this course to fulfill my HA requirement, but came out considering a Latin American Studies certificate. Great lecture, interesting reading (a fair amount, but keeps you intrigued), and good precepts, if other students are engaged. Overall, I would definitely recommend taking this course, regardless of whether you think you would be interested in Latin America (by the end, you will be!).
Type your notes because you WILL NOT be able to keep up with the lectures otherwise. Karl is wonderful. Go to his office hours, he loves students.
yes, definitely.
you must attend lecture and take good notes to do well in this class.
descrip: This course surveys the main themes of Latin American History from independence to the present. The main focus is on the interaction between states and citizens, social relations, and economic development.

title: Arts of Protest, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Lucretius and Darwin
descrip: The focus of this course is the cultural impact of Lucretius and Darwin. We will devote several weeks to On the Nature of Things and On the Origin of Species before examining extrapolations and modifications of basic Lucretian and Darwinian arguments. At issue here is the particular suitability of these notions to their new contexts, and the limit to such appropriations. We will also discuss the specific cultural conditions that produced these two influential scientific writers.

title: Research Methods in Demography
reviews: I would recommend doing all the readings ahead of class to be better able to follow the lectures.

If you think of this course as a self-taught demographic methods course with a required but intellectually useless time period spent sitting in class each week you will not be disappointed. Otherwise avoid the course.

Our class met weekly (independently of the course) to review the material and additional practice problems that we sought out from the Hinde textbook and other materials, which I would highly recommend to future cohorts.
prereqs: POP 501/ECO 571/SOC 531 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Source materials used in the study of population; standard procedures for the measurement of fertility, mortality, natural increase, migration, and nuptiality; and uses of model life tables and stable population analysis and other techniques of estimation when faced with inaccurate or incomplete data are studied.

title: Topics in German Culture and Society - German Underworlds
reviews: An excellent class for non-German speakers especially to become acquainted with a number of German authors.
I would highly recommend any class with Professor Pourciau, especially seminars
Interesting material, but class itself is largely determined by the students in it. Take it with a friend. Pourciau is a great professor.
Take it! Pourciau is an amazing professor, and the material is just inspired!
descrip: This course will investigate German theories about what lies beneath: is it hell or the subterranean foundations that keep our world from collapsing? A product of nature or culture? The origin of art or the death of all that is human? And should we go looking for it under mountains, or at the center of the modern city? We will take our examples from the German literature, film, and philosophy of the 19th and 20th centuries, and we will use them to pose questions about the role of unseen depths in the history of German thought.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research (Half-Term)
descrip: This course will cover the essential topics of what constitutes responsible conduct in research.

title: Tragedy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Everglades Today and Tomorrow: Global Change and the Impact of Human Activities on the Biosphere
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: Be prepared to memorize a lot of experiments. Since neuroscience is a relatively new field, there aren't as many "core concepts" that have been established yet for students to memorize as in other natural sciences. Much of what is known / taught in this course is a list of all the experiments that have been done so far and what their data/results are/suggest.
Don't take it unless you have to.  Or have a super strong interest in neuro.
I would recommend that people take it with Botvinick.  Niv just isn't a good lecturer, and she detracted from what should have been an extremely interesting course.

If you took NEU258 this course complements it nicely.  The former is all about the physical mechanisms, places in the brain, names, history, and facts.  The later is really about meta topics like how we can reason through causality in experiments, how to probe models of cognition, current methods and tools, experiment design, etc.  It is an important course for anyone interested in the anatomy and function of the brain but also anyone interested in thinking about human and animal intelligence.
Make sure to understand the many experiments presented in lectures and the textbook.
Not a course where you can simply memorized material and pass - be prepared to do original thinking and try to become comfortable with working with very amorphous concepts.
Study with other people for the exam.
Take it!
Take the lab! It's awesome! Also, lecture material is the only thing that's tested, so go to lecture.
Take this class if you are required to, but as a general rule there are more interesting and inspirational psych/neuro courses to take.
Take this course! Even if you didn't take 258, it was a really fantastic experience.
Textbook is not necessary. Go to all lectures.

This course is really interesting and accessible to anyone. It's a good mix of biology and psychology. The written exams cover a lot of material, so you need to keep up as the class goes along. I would suggest taking the lab over the precepts.
Try not to take with Professor Niv if you can.

Understand the expectations and deadlines associated with each assignment very thoroughly (it's worth the time).
If you're a neuro certificate person, have fun!
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention, language, memory, learning and decision making and executive functions of the frontal lobe. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed. Labs will involve hands-on experience with behavioral experiments, fMRI, EEG and computational modeling, including design of the experiment, analysis etc.

title: Conservation Biology
reviews: Do the reading because most of it is fairly good and useful.
Don't take it unless you have to. Practicals take up a lot of time and the class itself isn't very exciting.
Even if you don't have a strong background in biology, this would be a good class to take.
I would advise them to take this course if they are at all interested in biology as it was my favorite of the semester.
Interesting material with not a lot of work
Lyndon is a wonderful professor, very approachable and always available. Also, he is extremely knowledgeable but doesn't come off arrogantly
Lyndon is great to listen to and stare at for 3 hours. He is passionate and very willing to help.

Stay on top of the readings and don't forget to do reading summaries each week. Note to Dr. Estes: it would be helpful if you were more vocal to the class about remembering to do the reading summaries, which you did towards the end of the semester.
Strongly Recommend
Take it! Good course and Lyndon is amazing.
Take it! Lyndon is very helpful and knowledgeable!
The three hour lectures are a bit difficult to get through, but the content is interesting. Because EEB has few choices in fulfilling distribution requirements, this may be one of the better options.
definitely a unique format, but very interesting
good lecturer
this class was fantastic and Lyndon really helps you get every point of the lecture.  It's long, but once a week makes it a nice break up in the average EEB 2 class and a lab.
very interesting if you want to know more what conservation biology is about.
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: An in-depth exposure to topics in conservation biology emphasizing the application of scientific concepts to our understanding of the problems that threaten endangered species and ecosystems. Topics include island biogeography, population genetics and viability, landscape ecology, reserve design, and endangered species recovery. To a lesser degree, this course will address some of the political, economic, and cultural aspects of conservation.

title: Elementary Korean I
prereqs: No credit is given for KOR 101 unless it is followed by KOR 102. This is a 5 day a week course..
descrip: Elementary Korean is designed for beginning students who intend to build a solid foundation for further study in the Korean language. The course provides four balanced language skills - listening, speaking, reading, and writing - needed for basic communication. It emphasizes the ability to use Korean appropriately, and introduces students to useful information concerning culture and daily life in Korea.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: CHI 304 is better at helping you solidify your previous understanding of Chinese than developing new capabilities. If you're unsure if you should continue studying Chinese, take the class so you realize you probably dont want to. Its dissapointing.
Chinese program is a great program. 3rd year teaches you advanced vocabulary so you can talk about current topics.
Do the daily homework.
Great course if you're willing to put in the work!
Hard, but take it.

I love learning/speaking Chinese. The course is very intense/hard especially since it meets everyday including Reading Period and it helps to study/do some work for it everyday. However, the teachers are all very good, passionate, knowledgeable, and helpful. Also, there are more opportunities for free discussion. I liked when the class structure deviated a little to catch our attention/participation more since sometimes it got repetitive. Films were interesting/fun. Also week by week the dictation quizzes may be on different days so make sure to pay attention to that.

I'd definitely recommend taking at least up to third year in Chinese. You cover a lot more topics besides those related to daily life, and even advance to the point that you can read some Chinese language primary materials.
It's a lot of work and time, but you continue expanding your knowledge of the language quite successfully. If you've taken Chinese before, you know exactly what you're getting into.
Princeton teaches Chinese really well. If you have just taken second year and are wondering if third year is worth it, the answer is yes.
Take it
Take it, but be ready for the work!
Third Year Chinese tends to take up a lot of time, but it is worth it. I really enjoyed this class and encourage students to take it.
Time management-- there is always a lot of work so make sure you're on track
Work hard throughout the semester - cramming at the last minute is not particularly effective!
for graduate students it is a reasonable balance

if you're willing to put in the effort and do all the work, this is a great class. the chinese teachers here are all great- enthusiastic and so excited to teach- and you can really see your chinese improving. i also love the small classes- its such a nice break from the big lectures.
prereqs: CHI 303 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of CHI 303, designed to improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of newspaper essays and commentaries.

title: Ecology and Epidemiology of Parasites and Infectious Diseases
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.

Do it. The course has its flaws, but it's part of a great program that is well worth it. Andrea and Andy are great, and you get to interact with them a lot more than you probably would in any course on campus.
Don't stress. Find a small project to do, because time is limited. It was very hectic, so prepare to not have any personal time

Good introduction to parasitology. You will investigate many systems. Be prepared to travel a lot by bus. Choose a topic that you will enjoy and have fun with it. Get to know the professors and TAs. The trip to the bat cave is amazing!
I was very disappointed by this course. It requires strong restructuring and more commitment by the faculty and TAs for it to become a legitimate Princeton class.
It's not very organized, but if you pick a good project, it can be a lot of fun!
Make sure to choose a topic that really interests you.
Not my favorite class in Panama, but I'd recommend the entire semester.
Not the worst, definitely not the best.

The benefits you get from this course may be related to the number of people who go. In our case, with 19 students, the professors were not at all active in getting to know us or engaging with us. If you want to have good interactions with them, you're going to have to work at it. Working on an independent project is a fun and useful thing to do.
Very disorganized this year, hopefully they will restructure the class next year.
Worst course in Panama's field semester.
work fast.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: An introduction to the biology of viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, worms, arthropods, and parasitic plants. The major emphasis will be on the parasites of animals and plants, with further study of the epidemiology of infectious diseases in human populations. Studies of AIDS, anthrax, and worms, and their role in human history will be complemented by ecological and evolutionary studies of fig wasps, measles, myxomatosis, and communities of parasitic helminths. The course combines lectures with daily field laboratories to explore the dynamics and abundance of parasite in a variety of host species in the Panama Canal zone.

title: Junior Seminar - Violence in East Asia: Literature/ Film
