descrip: This seminar examines violence and its representations in the East Asian context. Students will explore the social and psychological needs for violence, and investigate various mechanisms of violence and their justification and perpetuation. Important literary and cinematic pieces, and their incarnations in the popular culture are to be studied diachronically and synchronically. The course also aims to trace the interplay between the East Asian traditions and outline how they draw and diverge from one another, from their history in the premodern period into their contemporary remixing.

title: Introduction to Critical Theory - Dialectic and Difference
descrip: Through a comparative focus on the concepts of dialectics and difference, we will read some of the formative theoretical, critical and philosophical works which continue to ground interdisciplinary critical theory today. Focal works by Lukacs, Freud, Heidegger, Adorno, Derrida, de Man, Arendt, and Benjamin are included among the texts we read.

title: Psychology for Policy Analysis and Implementation
descrip: Course covers basic concepts and experimental findings of psychology that contribute to an understanding of the effects of policy on human behavior and well-being; and psychological factors that affect the formulation, communication, and execution of policy. Topics include a descriptive analysis of boundedly rational judgment and decision making, a consideration of social motives and attitudes, and an introduction to the ways in which agents influence and negotiate with one another, including an examination of the psychological roots of conflict.

title: Bob Dylan
descrip: Bob Dylan is one of the finest musical artists America has produced. Over a career that spans more than half a century, he has composed lyrics that estimable critics put on the same level as the work of Byron or even Shakespeare. His words and melodies have proved how art of the highest intelligence can also win wide commercial appeal. And his performances as well as his songs are deeply rooted in American experience and myth. This seminar will closely examine Dylan's work, and assess the claims made about it, while tracing its many circuitous connections to American history and culture.

title: World Literatures in French
prereqs: 200-level French class or permission of Instructor..
descrip: A survey of the literature of decolonization in the Francophone world. The focus will be on the invention of a critical and militant literature in 1950s and 60s North and West Africa, the Caribbean, and Viet Nam. Texts will include poetry, essays, novels, and films.

title: Structural Design
reviews: Be proactive in doing your homework. You will learn a lot more.
Do all of your homework and exams and seek help from your TA whenever things are unclear.
Don't be scared of it.
Stay organized, and keep a running list of equations with their variables defined.
Too much homework and exams.
descrip: Introduction to the design of building structures of steel, timber and reinforced concrete.

title: Reporting Latin America: Literature and Journalism
prereqs: Students should be able to communicate, read and write in Spanish.The readings are in Spanish. Discussion can be conducted in Spanish, English or both.
descrip: If Latin American literature was once characterized by its exuberant imagination, writers in the 21st Century are doing the opposite: to tell journalistic stories that research and question the limits of normality. Still mostly unread outside Latin America, the "Nueva Cronica" appropriates spaces that were traditionally beyond the competence of literary writing. In this course we will read a wide selection of Latin American literary journalism from Jorge Ibarguengoitia (b. 1928) to Daniel Alarcon (b. 1977) to understand its origins, sociopolitical functions, and the place it occupies as a textual tool to understand contemporary Latin America.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: Have undergrad calculus resources on hand, don't forget 501 material.
I would recommend other students seeking a PhD degree in MAE take this course.
It's a great maths class, a lot of work but you learned also a lot. Very useful to build a good basis to use in everyday research.

It's good for non-engineer student who wants to take some snacks on complex variables, PDE and numerical methods. It's OK if you haven't taken MAE 501, (maybe make you a little more struggling in homework and exam)
Make sure to spend enough time on the problem sets.
Set aside a lot of time.
Take this course ---- if Prof. Holmes is teaching it.
The quality of this course is so poor.
This course is quite a lot of work, but the content is worthwhile.

This is a great course and the instructor is great. My background is in Biology and did not take 501, but still benefitted a lot from this course. He was great in giving a really short reminder/ background where needed.
descrip: A complementary presentation of theory, analytical methods, and numerical methods. The objective is to impart a set of capabilities commonly used in the research areas represented in the Department and more broadly in engineering and the physical and biological sciences. Analytical methods will be emphasized, but standard computational packages will be made available and some assignments will be designed to use them. Topics will include Complex variables, PDE, Fourier and Laplace Transforms, and a brief introduction to numerical methods for ODE and PDE.

title: Metabolic Engineering
reviews: EVERYONE SHOULD TAKE THIS CLASS. It is the best. If you're choosing between Link and this class, take this one. Forreals.
Great introduction to metabolic engineering.
Math background is helpful.
Take it if you want to learn about a field of research that has academic and industrial importance, and if you like reading.
Take this, you will not regret it!
The course is a little more challenging than some of the others in the department, but it was very good overall.
only if you have strong biochemical background
prereqs: MAT 202, MAT 217, or equivalent. MOL 214, MOL 215 or equivalent. Designed for upper division students in engineering, chemistry, and molecular biology, or graduate students..
descrip: Introduction to engineering metabolism. The objective of this course is to introduce students to current techniques and challenges within the field of metabolic engineering. Specific topics include introduction to metabolism, transcriptional regulation, signal transduction, flux balance analysis, and metabolic flux analysis.

title: Physical Optics
prereqs: PHY 104 or ELE 351..
descrip: This course presents an introduction to wave dynamics and imaging. Topics include geometrical and Fourier optics, diffraction, microscopy, photography and holography. Modern methods to beat the diffraction limit, including near-field and computational imagining, will be discussed.

title: fMRI Decoding: Reading Minds Using Brain Scans
prereqs: All students should have prior knowledge of computer programming (e.g., COS 126). Prior experience with Matlab is extremely useful but not strictly necessary. Additionally, students should EITHER have prior experience with fMRI research and cognitive neuroscience (e.g., from a course like PSY 259 or PSY 416) OR they should have prior experience with pattern classification and data mining methods (from a course like COS 402 or COS 424). Students who are unsure whether they have appropriate background for the course should contact the professors..
descrip: How can we decode what people are thinking by looking at their brain scans? Over the past several years, researchers have started to address this question by applying sophisticated pattern-classification algorithms to patterns of functional MRI data, with the goal of decoding the information that is represented in the subject's brain at a particular point in time. In lectures, students will learn about cutting-edge techniques for finding meaningful patterns in large, noisy datasets; in weekly computer labs, students will use these techniques to gain insight into fMRI datasets.

title: Electronic Commerce
reviews: 100% recommend this class. Easily the most interesting class I've ever taken.
Be prepared to code. Kornhauser is very interesting and he invites great guests to lectures.
Great course.  Take this if you want to build something.
I already have recommended this class to a number of my friends.
Only take it if you really are interested in e-commerce.
Please don't miss your opportunity to take a class with Professor K! You will have a blast in this class!
Previous knowledge of computer coding.
TAKE THIS CLASS! DO IT!
Take it! Prof. K is brilliant and hilarious.
if you can code it probably isn't too bad.  Kornhauser is a great professor, take it for him even if you can't code.
pretty easy class
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent.
descrip: Electronic commerce, traditionally the buying and selling of goods using electronic technologies, extends to essentially all facets of human interaction when extended to services, particularly information. The course focuses on both the software and the hardware aspects of traditional aspects as well as the broader aspects of the creation, dissemination and human consumption electronic services. Covered will be the physical, financial and social aspects of these technologies

title: Seminar in Colonial Spanish American Literature - New World Historiography-Iberian Chroniclers in a Global Perspective
reviews: Take it. I doubt you can study colonial history with another professor better than Gruzinski. And you will learn way more than history - tools to enrich whatever your research interest is.
This class is useful if you are interested in colonial history from a global perspective.

This course is a (very) rare opportunity for those interested not only in the roots of Latin American history and culture (the colonial period), but also in thinking broadly about globalization, its origins and its actualizations nowadays.
descrip: Writing History from the New World: How XVIth century History, a provincial set of knowledges elaborated in Western Europe and Northern Italy, became, once applied and adapted to the New World, a discipline able to interpret non Western pasts and societies? The course will compare standard Humanist Italian History (Bruni, Machiavel, Guicciardini), Portuguese History of Asia (Barros, Couto) and the new forms of history writing appearing in the New World during the XVIth century. Special attention will be given this semester to figures like Cortes and Motolinia who begun writing Mexican and American History.

title: American Literature before 1825
descrip: An examination of the literature of early America from settlement through early nationalism. We read accounts of contact, narratives of captivity and slavery, sermons, revolutionary tracts, autobiographies, novels, and poems. We discuss the influence of individual texts within the context of intellectual, social, and literary traditions. Emphasizing the influence of Puritanism and the Enlightenment, the course examines American literature in relation to established accounts of American history. We also discuss how early American literature introduces new perspectives for thinking about contemporary life in the United States.

title: Seminar. Types of Ideology and Literary Form - Pornography, Gender and the Rise of the Novel in Europe
reviews: Seminars always depend more on the people in it than the prof or the topic. In this case, the topic was fascinating, and we built a good rapport with each other, leading to some of the most hilarious and insightful understandings of porn and the novel ever.

The readings are certainly never dull and the professor does a fantastic job in explaining the historical and cultural context behind each text. The blend of undergrad and grad students also makes for an interesting and different environment for discussion. Take it!

The requirements of this course are very reasonable, and the information/readings/discussions incredibly interesting. While taking this course- and afterwards- you will always have something scandalous to share with others, cloaked in the authority of academia.
descrip: Open to graduate and undergraduate students interested in understanding the origins of the modern novel, this seminar examines the profound historical, theoretical and formal connections between the development of pornography as a distinct category of representation and the development of the novel as a literary genre during the Enlightenment. We will also explore the continuing resonances of those connections today. Readings in current criticism, history and theory of the novel and pornography will accompany primary readings.

title: Irreversible Processes in Plasmas
reviews: This is the best course the plasma physics program has to offer.
descrip: Introduction to theory of fluctuations and transport in plasma. Origins of irreversibility. Random walks, Brownian motion, and diffusion; Langevin and Fokker-Planck theory. Fluctuation-dissipation theorem; test-particle superposition principle. Statistical closure problem. Derivation of kinetic equations from BBGKY hierarchy and Klimontovich formalism; properties of plasma collision operators. Classical transport coefficients in magnetized plasmas; Onsager symmetry. Introduction to plasma turbulence, including quasilinear theory. Applications to current problems in plasma research.

title: American Political Thought
descrip: This course surveys the history of American political thought, with an emphasis on both recurring themes, such as liberal individualism and religiosity, and resurgent conflicts such as over the scope of government power and the meaning of political equality. Topics include the Puritan heritage, the Constitutional founding, the Hamiltonian, Jeffersonian, Jacksonian, and Whig visions, the slavery conflict, Populism, Progressivism, feminism, New Deal/Great Society liberalism, the Civil Rights, Black Power, and student revolts of the 1960s, and the conservative ascendency of the 1980s.

title: Art in Ancient China
descrip: An introduction to Chinese art from prehistory to the 1st century BC. Our approach will be chronological and thematic, the themes including major media and also such topics as archaeological interpretation, ethnographic analogy, ancient technology, artistic invention, epigraphy, and the origins of pictorial art. Cross-cultural comparison will shed light on many of these. Studying artistic invention in different materials will help us think of artists not as passive users of immutably given techniques but as inventors of both designs and techniques. The format, two 90 minute meetings per week, is meant to allow a mix of lecture and discussion.

title: Special Topics in Statistics and Operations Research - Convex Analysis
reviews: Great course!
The material is interesting, but it can be dry at times. But the workload is low and you learn quite a bit about an underrated topic.
Very useful course for both theory and practice, strongly recommended.
descrip: Graduate introduction to convex analysis. Topics include convex sets, convex functions, convex cones, convex conjugates, convex duality, directional derivatives, subgradients and subdifferentials, optimality conditions, topological vector spaces, ordered vector spaces, extension and separation theorems, minimax theorems, fundamental theorems of asset pricing, economic equilibrium.

title: The Opera
descrip: The course provides a survey of opera from its inception in the 17th-century to the present, considering such issues as opera's relationship to its cultural context, contemporary stagings, opera conventions and singers (including the castrato), opera and literature, exoticism, and opera's representation of gender and sexuality. Classes will allow students to focus on close readings/viewings of specific scenes. Students enrolled in the course will have the opportunity to attend at least one performance at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Be prepared to work, but this and any other Chinese course are extremely rewarding.

Strongly recommended if you want to continue learning Chinese at a high level. Given that it's a heritage course, though, it's a bit more demanding given that you're being compared to "native" speakers. But that doesn't mean anything?you'll do fine if you put in some effort. Look forward to having more lively, fast discussions.
TAKE IT! especially if Professor Wang or Zhang are teaching it.
Take it if you have the time for it. It's much more time-consuming than your average course, but it is also immensely rewarding.
Take it!
Take it! It requires a heavy time commitment but you know what to expect every week.
Take it, but lots of busy work every single day. Your Chinese will definitely improve a great deal! All the vocab is extremely useful in everyday life.
Use the weekly study guides; they are extremely helpful in preparing you for the weekly tests.
You learn a lot, invest a lot of time too. You get out what you put in.
take it!!!
prereqs: CHI 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 305, designed to further improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of essays published in contemporary Chinese newspapers and magazines.

title: Topics in Arithmetic Geometry - Arithmetic Gan-Gross-Prasad Conjecture
descrip: This course covers current topics in Arithmetic Geometry. Specific topic information provided when course is offered.

title: Topics in International Relations - US Foreign Policy History
descrip: This seminar will introduce students to U.S. foreign policy history and approaches, with the emphasis on US foreign policy since 1945. The seminar aims to demonstrate the utility of historical analysis for consideration of contemporary foreign policy challenges. Topics to be explored include global trade, nuclear policy, military intervention, decision making, development and foreign assistance, human rights, Congress and bureaucracies, the presidency and war, diplomacy, international institutions and the Cold War.

title: Principles of Quantum Engineering
prereqs: (PHY 103 or PHY 105) and (PHY 104 or PHY 106).
descrip: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the basic principles that govern the operation of modern solid state and optoelectronic devices. The emphasis is on fundamentals rather than applications. The major portion of the course will be devoted to quantum mechanics and statistical physics with examples from solid state and materials physics and quantum electronics. This provides the basic background needed to understand the physics of device operations and also prepares the student for more advanced courses in solid state and quantum electronics (such as ELE 441, 442 and 453). For more details, see Undergraduate Announcement.

title: Contemporary Latin American Literature
reviews: Definitely take this class if you are interested in Latin American literature and learning about how the 1960's inspired national trends of resistance in both literature and art.  I loved it! Make sure to read though to get the most out of the class.
Do the readings.
I definitely recommend taking this class.

I would recommend the course to other students. I think the quality of the course will be determined by the students. It always helps to have students are engaged and genuinely interested in the material.
Take it! It's a laid back class that gives you the chance to engage in spanish literature / politics in english

Take it. It's a good introduction to Latin American Literature and Professor Draper teaches well. The readings were all in English, but you have the chance to read them in their original form, in Spanish, if you want. Not a lot of work.
Take this class, you?ll love it!
This course is relatively little work, but make sure you are interested in the material before signing up.
actually do the readings so you can contribute to class discussion
descrip: This course is an introduction to the study of contemporary Latin American literature and visual arts. Placing special emphasis on the changing relationships between aesthetics and politics, we will analyze the emergence of different contemporary genres and themes, covering the most important tropes and problems that have configured contemporary Latin American culture (from magical realism and testimonio to the present). Class will be conducted in English; readings will be available in translation and in the original language.

title: Studies in Religion and Philosophy - Heidegger, Levinas, and Ricoeur
descrip: This seminar considers arguments about transcendence, history, God, freedom, and ethics in twentieth century continental philosophy, with a special focus on the work of Martin Heidegger, Emmanuel Levinas, and Paul Ricoeur. Particular attention will be given to their respective claims about the relation between the self and others and to their respective readings of the history of western philosophy, and especially of Descartes and Kant, in making their arguments.

title: Advanced Spanish
reviews: A great way to fulfill your requirement--not too challenging but enough to help you improve and maintain your spanish skills.

Certainly not a bad choice, if you're interested! Also, SPA 108 is not overwhelmingly difficult - no worries. I feel that it's more of an opportunity to further develop what you've gained in years past. You're not bombarded with new material.
Definitely take the 105-108 track if you can. You learn more and do less busy work.
Definitely take this course, not only because it is required to finish your language requirement, but because it is a great experience.
Do the readings if you want to get anything out of the course.
Do your homework diligently.
Don't take it with Treme
Get Luis!
Go for it! Lucky for you, Mathew Treme is leaving so you dont have to worry about his horrible teaching.
Good for reading and writing, not for practice speaking.
Great course. Hopefully they've added credit for the grammar exercises, but if not JUST DO THEM. They are painful and terrible, but in the end necessary if you want a good grade on the tests.

I really enjoyed the course and I would recommend it, although you probably have to take it. It was far less work than I expected, coming from 105, but the assignments required a much more advanced and nuanced understanding of the spanish language.
I would make sure to spend time studying random vocab and verbs because even though we don't learn them in class they come into play on assignments.
I would recommend trying to get Souto-Portas.
I would tell them that unless you are great at Spanish coming into the course, you will struggle a bit
If you want to learn spanish/get your requirement, this is a fine class.
It is worth taking, and not too difficult if you put in the time.
It's very laid back but you do need to do the work. Overall a good class, especially considering you have to take it.
Just do the work and enjoy class
Not a lot of commitment. Definitely very interesting movies and readings that help in the development of Spanish.
Not too much work, pretty relaxed, good way to further your understanding of spoken Spanish.
Participate to the best of your ability. The best way to learn a language is just to use it. Don't be embarrassed since everyone in the class is learning.
Pay attention, and try to use the language and examples in class and in writing.
Prepare to put your best foot forward. The grading can be a bit tough, but it is manageable and I enjoyed the class.
Recommend Luis Gonclaves
Study, read the grammar manual and do the exercises.
THIS TEACHER IS THE WORST
Take it if you need it, but consider a higher level if all you want is to brush up your Spanish.
Take it with Maria!
Take it!
Take it, and go in with an open mind!  Even if you are just taking it as a requirement, I am sure that you will enjoy it :)
Take the class, but find the right teacher
Take this class with Luis. He is awesome, and the best teacher for this course.
The grammar exercises are useful to at least do before in class tests.
The language classes require more time than you would expect. Be ready to start editing your Spanish essays like you edit your English essays.

This class is great but not excellent, more of a gateway than a final destination. There is still a lot of emphasis on grammar, and I feel have gotten better at read and writing. However, I don't think this class helped me speak any better. Profesora Bono is a wonderful person but not a particularly engaging instructor.
This class is required for graduation, yah, but it's so much more laid back than SPA 105.
This course is less work (busywork) than SPA 105. There is also much more grammar - probably grammar you haven't covered before - which I think was helpful.
This course is what you make of it. It is pretty easy to get a decent grade with minimal effort, and it is pretty challenging to get a very good grade. Take it with Mariana Bono if you possibly can.
This is a really great class, especially if you have a good professor. The work load is very manageable.
Very good course for Spanish and a good prep for SPA  207.

You're going to have to push yourself really hard and be brave if you want to improve language skills while in this course. I would also suggest getting a language partner, going to the tables, watching movies, etc. if you're really serious about developing your Spanish.
do all the readings and grammar excercizes
take the course if you like to learn spanish
prereqs: Prerequisites include SPA 105 and/or satisfactory score on the placement test, or permission of Instructor. Offered both semesters..
descrip: SPA 108 is an advanced course that consolidates comprehension of oral and written Spanish and develops fluency and precision in speaking and writing. The course aims to broaden vocabulary and improve grammatical accuracy while providing students with opportunities to engage with current affairs, social and cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Course materials include short texts and audiovisual sources such as television interviews, songs and films. Students' personal production is encouraged through debates, role-play and group discussions. Students who complete SPA 108 will be qualified to take 200-level Spanish courses.

title: Introduction to Music
reviews: !!! Take this class if like music and need to get an LA out of the way. It's not hard if you go to class and actually listen. Professor Morrison does a good job prepping you for the exam and his lectures are some of the best on campus.
A decent if rather boring LA.
A good chill class that's still interesting and worth going to. I'd recommend PDFing and enjoying the view.
Always go to lecture. They're great.

As everyone else has said, this is a history course not an actual music course.  Material said in lecture might or might not show up on the midterm/final exam, make sure you study for those with someone who has good notes.  Same goes for the readings, so again, make sure someone you are working with has summarized all of them.  The readings are short, but I never got the book and therefore never did any readings.  The information is mostly boring, then a little bit cool, then boring.  It's nice to know this stuff, but I would rather learn stuff about music rather than memorize the birth and death dates of every single major composer since 1100.  That said, it's easy enough that you don't need to put much work into it.  VERDICT:  Neutral.  It's easy, but boring, banal, and there are other classes worth taking more.

At the end of the day, I wanted to tell the other students in the class (that perhaps didn't have as much background in music as I have had) that the great tradition of music is not like this and it can indeed be fun and interesting. And certainly not the tepid stew we were served in precept.
Attend lecture not only because it's important for the exams but because Simon is a great lecturer and very passionate about the material
Be aware that this class is not as easy as people say and there is very little theory.
Be sure to listen to the listenings early on. Trying to cram "listenings" is rough and confusing.
Before exams, spend an entire day or two going over your notes and the readings, and listening to the songs on the review sheet.  The finals are hard.  The actual class is very easy, though.
Definitely a good class for a P/D/F.  The exams have tons of memorization on them, but even for the final if you study the listenings and class handouts you'll earn a solid P.

Definitely take this class if you are interested in music history. The lectures are fantastic and there really isn't very much work you need to do during the semester. However for the tests you will need to study a lot. You will need to know composer birth and death years. It is very doable, just know that you will need to study to do well on the exams, even though the class isn't much work.

Definitely think about taking this class! It's very easy to PDF, not as easy to get an A, but still definitely worth your time. Simon is a great professor! Take if you have any interest in classical music at all. Also, a music background is extremely helpful but not necessary.
Do not take this unless you have extensive knowledge in music.
Do the readings for the precept - you'll get more out of the class
Do the readings on time.
Don't expect to literally clap for credit!
Don't think you can coast through this class. It requires preparation but it is also fun.
Easy class to pdf, but also pretty fun
Enjoy the lectures, get the general concepts, pay attention to the handouts.
Feel bad for the professors and preceptors who have to deal with all the second semester seniors.

First of all, this class is not as easy as "clapping for credit" may suggest. The exams required a great deal of studying, although there was very little work during the actual semester. I very much enjoyed the subject material that we covered, and Simon Morrison is a great lecturer. On the whole, I would recommend taking it, but don't go in thinking that it will be a piece of cake.
Go to lecture. PDF the course.
Go to lectures and precepts and you'll soak up a good deal. Fun class.

Good course. Take it if you want to learn the history of classical music, but don't expect to learn basic music theory or analyze the music presented in theoretical terms - that's what MUS 104 is for.

Great class - take it! Especially if you are going to PDF - all you really need to do is pay attention in lecture (Morrison is highly entertaining and a pretty great lecturer) and study/memorize for exams. OTherwise, not a lot work.
Great class, especially to PDF.
Great course to PDF. It's interesting while not overloading you with work
Great course! Take it!

descrip: Music 103 is an introduction to Western Art Music (works from 1100 to the present). The course defines the basic elements of music - pitch, rhythm, melody, harmony, and form - and the historically significant styles and genres of composition. Emphasis is placed on significant premiere performances, music and politics, and music and the other arts (film, dance, literature).

title: Political Sociology (Half-Term)
descrip: Systematic orientation, review of the literature, and critical analysis of theory and business.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Juniors only (except for sophomores who have completed EGR 251)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Social Contagion
descrip: See website

title: In the Groove: Technology and Music in American History, from Edison to the iPod
descrip: When Thomas Edison invented the phonograph in 1877, no one, including Edison, knew what to do with the device. Over the next century Americans would engage in an ongoing dialogue with this talking machine, defining and redefining its purpose. This course will track that trajectory, from business tool to scientific instrument to music recorder to musical instrument. By listening to the history of the phonograph, and by examining the desires and experiences of phonograph users, students will perceive more generally the complex relationships that exist between a technology and the people who produce, consume, and transform it.

title: Levantine Colloquial Arabic
reviews: Great course for improving your spoken Arabic skills, something which other Arabic classes here lack
It's a good course to take, and not too much work.
Take it!  A great way to improve your speaking skills in a more relaxed setting than ARA 301 or the more formal courses.
This is a good class to develop colloquial Arabic.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or equivalent..
descrip: An introduction to spoken Levantine dialect. Materials in the course are designed to promote functional usage of the language, stressing the vocabulary and grammar of conversation as used in daily life in the Levant, particularly Palestine, Jordan, and Lebanon.

prereqs: RUS 101 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The objective of RUS 102 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian: basic training in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehending the Russian language in a cultural context.

title: Topics in Architecture and Information
descrip: Geometry has dominated design representation and computational models for years. Many of the challenges related to the need to reduce the use of resources require novel models for computational design, reaching beyond geometry only. Scientific data visualization has progressed using computation for capturing complex phenomena in visual form. Architecture faces almost the reverse problem in shaping complex process through design. This advanced seminar will challenge the participants to develop novel design models in a computational design context.

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy II
descrip: Theoretical and empirical study of the public regulation and deregulation of rate of return, prices, and entry in public utilities and franchise oligopolies. Theory and practice of antitrust policy is examined, including some elements of antitrust law. In addition, regulation of product quality, advertising, and safety is examined. This course draws heavily on material developed in 541.

title: Digital Signal Processing
descrip: The lectures will cover: (1) Basic principles of digital signal processing. (2) Design of digital filters. (3) Fourier analysis and the fast Fourier transform. (4) Roundoff errors in digital signal processing. (5) Applications of digital signal processing.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Tiffany Sirois in E-212..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Transformations of the Self

descrip: An introduction to the mechanics of viscous flows. The kinematics and dynamics of viscous flows. Exact solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations. Lubrication theory. The behavior of vorticity. The boundary layer approximation. Laminar boundary layers with and without pressure gradients. Introduction to stability. Introduction to turbulence.

title: Law and Society in Colonial India
descrip: Seminar examines the formation of a new legal culture in India under British colonial rule. Its main interests concern the struggles over the establishment of liberal legal idioms, writing and legal codification, the making of the colonial legal subject, and issues pertaining to comparative law.

title: Nonlinear and Mixed-Integer Optimization: Fundamentals and Applications
descrip: Topics in convex analysis; unconstrained and constrained nonlinear optimization; duality theory; mixed-integer linear optimization; mixed-integer nonlinear optimization; modeling issues in process synthesis; and process synthesis applications in energy recovery, separations, reactors, and flowsheets.

title: Framing American Art
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: The Digital Turn: A Cultural History
descrip: Assesses the present state of computer-based design by situating today's digital turn within the long duration of the history of cultural technologies. Describes the technical logics of hand-making, mechanical reproductions, and digital making, and highlights the differences between digital variability, manual and artisanal variations, and the mechanical mass-production of identical copies. Outlines a brief history of the digital turn and of its theoretical and technological premises. Discusses the present state of digital design theory, and particularly the issue of digital indeterminacy and its consequences for the making of form.

prereqs: CHM 201 and MAT 104 (can be taken concurrently) or permission of the instructor.
descrip: The course uses materials balance, energy balance, and life cycle assessment tools to examine the environmental impacts of energy technologies. Environmental implications include those associated with water quality, air quality, land use, and climate change. The course first builds the tools for investigating energy technologies and then examines technologies including conventional fossil fuel combustion, advanced fossil energy systems, solar, wind, geothermal, hydroelectric, and nuclear energy. The course is focused primarily on scientific and technological principles, but socioeconomic aspects are also addressed.

descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. descrip: A survey of human development emphasizing the nature of children's minds and experience, developmental change, and the relation between child and adult mentation. How do children at different periods in development think, feel, and experience the world around them? Students will be involved in preschool settings.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Military Force Planning & Decision Making
descrip: Course introduces important issues of conventional force planning and military decision making and includes discussion of service cultures, doctrines, capabilities, and limitations. Broadly covers strategy, planning, readiness, force projection, employment, and logistics throughout the spectrum of conflict, including conventional war, the global war on terrorism and peacekeeping operations. Through theoretical and doctrinal readings and examination of selected case studies, course provides background essential for those involved in the study and practice of national security decision making.

title: Atmospheric Thermodynamics and Convection
reviews: Take good notes, which should be easy because the lecture is done entirely on the blackboard and is very well laid out. The textbook is really good for filling in gaps, since lecture does move fast at times.
Take it.
Very good introduction to atmospheric thermodynamics.
descrip: Thermodynamics of water-air systems. Overview of atmospheric energy sources and sinks. Planetary boundary layers. Closure theories for atmospheric turbulence. Cumulus convection. Interactions between cumulus convection and large-scale atmospheric flows. Cloud-convection-radiation interactions and their role in the climate system.

title: Cultural Evolution and the Origins of Language
descrip: The evolution of linguistic conventions is a kind of cultural evolution, and the evolution of the capacity for language must have been tangled up with the evolution of a capacity for having a human kind of culture. Lewis' Convention will be used as a point of departure for a tour through some of the more recent philosophical and scientific literature on the relationship between these two processes, including Skyrms Signals, Sterelnys Evolved Apprentice, Daniel Dennetts The evolution of language and music, and works by Goodman, Grice, Chomsky, Call and Tomasello, Enquist and Ghirlanda, Gergely and Csibra, etc.

Focus on lectures when preparing for Midterm and Final exams. The questions mostly come out of there.

Fun course, not too much work, and Turk-Browne is a great lecturer. I've heard that the quality of this course (and exam format) can really vary from professor to professor, though, so be sure to check evaluations of your specific prof before signing up. Turk-Browne is great!!
Go to all the lectures and pay attention to them, as they are mostly what you are tested on and they are just very enjoyable.  Make sure to use the syllabus for lab reports.
Go to lecture!
Go to the lectures! Making good lecture notes is more important than reading the chapters in the book.
I highly recommend the course. It's really interesting and the workload is really light. Don't buy the textbook. You don't need it at all. Just study the lectures.
I loved taking this course with Professor Turk-Browne. The workload was very reasonable and if you're looking for a good STL or looking to try out psych I would definitely recommend this course.
I will have considered taking another STL because the curve for this course is rather harsh.
I would absolutely recommend this course, especially to someone who needs an STL because it is not a hard science class the material is extremely interesting.
I would advise another student taking this course to attend lecture since they're enjoyable and cover the material that you are responsible for in terms of testing.

I would advise another student to take this class seriously because although it is interesting, it is not an easy A unless you try. I would also advise future students to study most from class notes and slides for the tests. There is barely any book or lab information on the tests.
I would definitely recommend PSY 101 to students who need to fulfill their STL, what could easily have been a chore really wasn't.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student.

I would definitely take the course. No matter the reason, if you're looking for an interesting class or a distribution requirement or its a prerequisite, it's definitely worth taking. I'd take it again just for the lectures if I could
I would encourage them to attend each and every lecture.
I would probably advise students to take a more focused psychology course.
If it's being taught by Nicholas Turk-Browne, don't waste your time with the readings -- it's not on the mid-term at all.
If you haven't taken a lab class yet this is a relatively easy way to fulfill that requirement.
Interesting lectures, take it if you want.
Interesting. Fairly easy. Take it.
It is a fine class, though the labs are pretty boring and sometimes feel like a waste of time.
It is a good class. Students should work with their Lab TAs on lab reports. Student should also be able to give concise answers on test.
It is a very interesting introductory course. The lab is definitely not as demanding as another science class such as chemistry/biology.
It was such a fun class!! Definitely take it! NTB was a great lecturer and super cool!!!! woohoo!!!
It's interesting
It's not pdf!
It's very easy to get behind in this class, so stay on top of lectures/labs!
Make sure you take it with NTB.
Overall, I thought this course was really informative, interesting, and (honestly) easy. Take this course if you're at all interested in science or need a stl requirement.

Pay attention in lecture, and take good notes!  The majority of the material on the tests comes from lecture, and is conceptual.  You generally don't have to memorize things or spend too much time on the readings.
Pay close attention in lecture and take very good notes on everything presented and discussed.

Professor Nick is AMAZING! He is very fun and always willing to meet students one on one. His active presence in labs and review sessions is really encouraging! His lectures are a lot of fun and very interesting! The textbook readings though are separate from what is presented in lecture, so there is a heavy load of information to remember.

Professor Turk-Brown is amazing, and lecture is incedibly fun and engaging especially if you have friends in the class. However, labs are very pointless (though easy). The exams (midterm and final) don't use the book at all, so you'd be fine just attending all the classes and existing in lab without a truly functioning brain. A good STL for sure.
Read the book; it actually does help, even if the exam material is on the lectures.
Really good course - go to lecture and lab, it's really interesting!
Start your lab reports early!
Stay on top of readings and focus on lectures when studying for the midterm and final. Go to the reviews for the midterm and final.
Study the Psychology 101 lecture notes
TAKE IT and don't look back.
TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Turk-Brown was amazing and I was genuinely sad to be done with the class.
TAKE THIS. THIS PROFESSOR ROCKS
Take for a fairly easy lab, or for general interest. You'll learn a lot, but it's not too much work.
Take it as a lab DR, a pre-req for psych, or purely for interest. A great class, at least if taught by NTB.
Take it for a good STL.
Take it if you want a general overview in psychology. Not a ton of work. It's a good distribution requirement.
Take it to fulfill your STL in an easy way!  Psych is intuitive so you won't struggle with concepts!!
Take it with Turk-Browne! He's the coolest guy ever and lectures are a blast. Go to all of them!!! And don't worry about readings.
Take it!
Take it! Don't read the book.
Take it, but be ready for the midterm and final. Go to all lectures, they are great! Nick is a awesome lecturer and all the lectures are interesting and engaging. Hard to get an A though.
Take it. Especially with Dr. Turk-Browne. And get Pam Mueller as your lab instructor. The course is an excellent introduction to the field of psychology.
Take the course with Professor Nick, but be sure to study hard for the midterm.

Take this as your STL if you are not a science-oriented person, or as pre-req for psychology. If you are looking for an interesting class just for fun/sheer interest, I probably would not recommend it just because I feel like there are other classes that are more interesting and have more interesting assignments. Turk-Browne's lectures were awesome though!
Take this class if it's with Prof. Turk-Browne
Take this course with Turk-Browne.
Take this course! Don't do readings but go to lecture.

Take this course! It's fascinating material and fun to learn about. Something that applies to real life for once! To be successful, you MUST attend lectures and take thorough notes. These are the things you will be tested on.
Take this course. It's a great STL, and with Prof. Turk-Browne, the lectures are all really fascinating.
Take this! If you need an STL, especially if you are not a science person, I would recommend this. It's very interesting, will provide you with information you'll use in all areas of study.
The course is fun and the professors are actively engaging and interesting. However, be prepared for a lot of material and not being able to remember quite a bit of it.
The lectures are really interesting - Professor Turk-Browne is great. The textbook reading isn't really on the exams so you only really need to know the lecture material.
There is not a PDF. I figured this out halfway through the semester.
This course was really interesting, and Turk-Brown is amazing and compelling--I doubt anyone thinks otherwise. Do it!
This is a good intro psych course that does not require much work. Nice introduction with a very interesting lecturer.
This is a really fun course! I recommend it.
This was one of my favorite classes this year. I would highly recommend taking this course.
Turke Browne is awesome, fair and a nice guy. Great professor, if you're going to take psych 101, take it when he is teaching!

Very easy course. Great for STL requirement. Professor Turk-Browne gives very engaging, fun lectures and presents a lot of interesting information, even though the course does not ever get deep into any one subject.
Very interesting course.
Very light workload, but the grading is pretty harsh.
easiest lab class
recommend
so much work
take this class!
they should take the course
very fun and engaging class. it's an easy STL if you need one, while still being very interesting.
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course is a pre-requisite for majoring in psychology and can also serve as one of the two lab courses used to satisfy the natural science requirement.

title: Quantum Optics
reviews: Definitely take the course, especially if you wish to take PHY 506 simultaneously. The two courses complement each other really well, and you get a much richer understanding of quantum mechanics from such an arrangement. Prof T?reci is also one of the best professors at explaining physical concepts.
Follow the lectures carefully, and read the material after lectures to reinforce learning.
If you are interested in quantum optics then take the course. Lots of useful lectures and not much "busy-work"

Information is presented logically and clearly, providing a strong conceptual basis for quantum optics. Students will also take advantage of computational tools to get numeric solutions and animate the dynamics of two-level systems, instead of having to solve all equations by hand. Background in E&M and Quantum Mechanics strongly recommended, although course is very rewarding.

It is a great introduction to cutting edge QED research and provides you with a solid understanding of what are the current big problems in the field, as well as a good grasp on the theory used to model those problems.The class does not assume an extensive background but builds a solid understanding of the Physics involved. One of my favorites at Princeton.
Review operator algebra!
descrip: Semiclassical field theory of light-matter interactions. Quantum theory of light, vacuum fluctuations and photons. Quantum states and coherence properties of the EM field, photon counting and interferometry. Quantum theory of light-matter interactions, Jaynes-Cummigns (JC) model. Physical realizations of JC model, case study:circuit QED. Quantum theory of damping. Resonance fluorescence. Coupled quantum non-linear systems.

title: Globalization and Development
descrip: The course examines the meaning and nature of development in a globalizing world. Topics include global inequality and underdevelopment, the role of states, social movements and international institutions in development, and the uneven benefits of globalization. The course reviews critical approaches such as dependency, world-systems, and comparative institutional perspectives, while examining development theories and practices in the context of historical social change since 1945, including most recently globalization, crisis, and China's dramatic rise.

title: Advanced Arabic II
reviews: Go to office hours!

I would absolutely recommend this to another student. It ended up being far more engaging than I first thought it might be. It's definitely not your regular learning by rote from a textbook language class and I think that's really great.
Professor Bell is such a wonderful professor and person.  He is so helpful and such a great instructor.  I highly recommend any class he teaches.
Take it if Bell's teaching: he's helpful, very kind, and an excellent teacher. He's always willing to go the extra mile and your Arabic will improve.
Take it.
prereqs: ARA 301 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Study of Modern Standard Arabic at the advanced level, continued from ARA 301. Attention given to speaking, listening, reading and writing, with special emphasis on grammar and readings in a variety of authentic texts.

title: Policy Research Seminar
reviews: Don't fall behind, otherwise you end up redoing a lot of work.  Invest yourself and get rewards!

If you're interested in the Great Society (which really only requires an interest in domestic policy in general, in my opinion), then you should definitely consider doing your independent work this way. While trying to do original research is frustrating or challenging at times, Prof. Zelizer does a great job of structuring the course to keep you on track, and Methods Lab with Peter Locke is excellent.
Prof Zelizer and Peter Locke are good ppl to take the course with. It was good to have time to work ahead on the JP.
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.

title: Contagion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis will be placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: Pro-Sem in Chinese & Japanese Studies - Medical Ethics in Early Modern Japan
descrip: Readings in primary sources on early modern Japanese medicine with a particular focus on medical ethics. During the semester we will analyze and translate selected readings, and discussed particular issues related to the practice of medicine during the Edo period (1603-1868). A working knowledge of classical Chinese (Kanbun) and classical Japanese is recommended. Texts in classical Japanese include texts written in cursive style (kuzushiji).

title: History of Anthropological Theory
reviews: Anthropology concentrators should look forward to this class!
Don't.

Go to lecture and record what you can from the lectures. If you don't like theory and abstract thought, this class is going to be brutal for you. THINK a lot before writing your essays; don't just write whatever comes to mind.
I hope you're not considering taking this if you don't have to. If you're an anthro major, you don't have a choice.
If Prof. Davis teaching, expect great lectures but very mentally frustrating essays.
If you are not an ANT major do not take this.
If you need this for your major, take it from Davis! She's really engaged and knowledgeable, and is amazing at clearing up confusion!
It's an interesting class, there are lots of reading, which if you do, improve your experience. You read most of the most important anthropological theorists.

No point taking if you're not an ANT major. If you are and Davis is teaching, look forward to great lectures, okay readings, but a manageable workload. Lecture isn't really necessary, just do the readings carefully before writing your papers.
Only would suggest this for Anthropology students.
Take good notes in lecture - Prof. Davis's explanations are very helpful!
Take it junior year.
The work is manageable, and you learn a lot
Try to do the readings.

Unless you're an anthropology major, this class might not seem so interesting. But I think more than ANT 201, this provides a better understanding of what anthropology is as a field. The readings are at times dense, but do them, or else lectures won't mean much.
You have no choice right?
don't take this course unless you are required to. in fact, i do not think you can.
only take if you like theory and/or are an anthro major
there is a lot of time and effort you have to invest to understanding the concepts, but a very good course.
prereqs: ANT 201 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is an introduction to fundamental theories and debates in social/cultural anthropology. We will examine the national and colonial origins of anthropology, considering how western encounters with non-western peoples in the 19th-20th centuries opened questions about human kinship, history, economy, religion, language, sexuality, and personhood that continue to shape the horizons of our thought today. We will study this inheritance critically, exploring the changing concepts, methods, and ethics of anthropological research and writing, and evaluate their bearing on questions of power, justice, and identity in the present.

title: Beginner's Italian II
reviews: As long as you pay attention and work diligently, this course will be both extremely enjoyable and informative.
As with 101, study for the quizzes! Make sure you're doing the homework daily so you retain the information.
Definitely keep up with the homework and ask questions!
Do the homework and participate.
I took the course as a senior and had no regrets. It was everything I hoped for - fun, manageable workload, and useful.
If you're considering taking Italian, this is a required course, but it is still interesting and definitely moves at a much quicker pace than 101.
It's a great intro language class, whether for fun or to fulfill language requirements.
Italian's fun! If you get a good teacher...
Participate
Read, Study, and you will fall in love with Italian!

Students should practice speaking the language outside of class, especially over breaks.  This is a good class to take if you need to fulfill the language requirement because most people are taking Italian for the first time, making it an even playing field.

Take Italian! The class is very fun and engaging and there's a lot of room for creativity in terms of projects, compositions, and even in the classroom. When the professors ask a question, it's fun to come up with a ridiculous response in Italian. Many laughs have been shared in the classroom.
Take it!
Take it! Do the work, and the class is not hard, but you learn a lot.
Take it. The Italian department is superb.
Teardo is a great teacher and a babe as well.
The teachers in the italian department on very encouraging, supportive, and fair.  If you work hard and seek help, you will do great.
This course is what you make of it. If you do the homework thoroughly and participate in class, you should be just fine.
Try to get Teardo. She is the best professor for this course.
take this to learn an amazing language! lots of athletes though.
prereqs: ITA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Further study of Italian grammar and syntax with increased emphasis on vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Skills in speaking and writing (as well as understanding) modern Italian will also be further developed. Some aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: The New Woman in British Drama, 1890-1915
descrip: This course will look at a sample of the more ambitious turn-of-the-century British drama that addresses the changing political and social roles for women and the arrival of the so-called New Woman. We will locate the plays in their immediate culture of performance, theatre-going, production, reviewing, response and promotion, as well as among the cultural assumptions and issues of politics and society in the time.

title: A History of Race in the United States
descrip: An introductory history of race in the U.S., including the intersections of racializations, as social constructions, with imperialism and conquest, science and explanation, gender and sexuality, and geography and place, and the policing of those taxonomies and their borders and violations.

title: Computational Finance in C++
reviews: Don't take this course to learn about C  . The official programming language is matlab. The course's title is MISLEADING. The lecture notes are usually shameful and NOT tailored to the course. Other than that, the techniques learnt in this course in order to price derivatives are ok.
Go for it if you want to learn how to use Matlab while learning financial pricing techniques.
Good for learning some basic and some complex finance techniques.
I personally feel there is large overlap with the course FIN503.

If you're hoping to learn and improve your C   programming, this is probably not the best course (most people used MATLAB). However if you're interested in computational finance and pricing models, there are some pretty cool concepts like Fourier transform pricing, stochastic volatility and jump-diffusion models, along with Monte Carlo methods, and numerical methods to solve PDEs.
It is an important but hard course.
Just make certain your expectations for the course are aligned with the professor.
Not for learning C
Please come and take this course as it will expand your way of thinking and improve your programming skills in the computational finance area.
Take this class if you don't want to work much and have some free time to learn C   by yourself

This class won't teach you to program. We need a programming class for MFins, but this isn't it. Hopefully the MFin powers that be will create a numerical methods class just like this one, and a SEPARATE class that actually teaches us C  .

Title of the course "Computation Finance in C  ". Teacher : "I don't know C  , I work in Matlab". All is said. A scandalous course. The "teacher" doesn't seem more knowledgeable that half of the class on the subjects he presents (cf Levy Processes "I discovered these things last year". Yeah we noticed), adopts the strategy of writing excruciatingly slowly simple formulas on the blackboard for 1h20min to kill time. The whole time you think, "Oh my God I paid 4k for this".
Yes if not taught by M. Lorig (or if he learns C   during Summer)
excellent, and great teacher. Technical, but able to give an intuition behind the equations.
prereqs: Junior & Senior enrollment by Instructor permission only--must contact instructor PRIOR to signing up.
descrip: The intent of this course is to introduce the student to the technical and algorithmic aspects of a wide spectrum of computer applications currently used in the financial industry, and to prepare the student for the development of new applications. The student will be introduced to C++, the weekly homework will involve writing C++ code, and the final project will also involve programming in the same environment.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: Course focuses on the models for pricing, hedging, structuring and risk-management of financial derivatives. Derivative securities are assets whose value depends on the value of other more basic underlying assets. Derivative securities are not only an important asset in their own right, but the central intuition provided by derivative securities pricing--the no-arbitrage principle--ties together many areas in finance. This course discusses the consequences of no-arbitrage for asset pricing and corporate finance.

title: Word and Image - Interconnected Narratives, Ancient and Modern
descrip: A seminar in cross-disciplinary and cross-chronological approaches. After considering methodological issues in studying relations between words and images and between antiquity and Renaissance, the course turns to its principal subject, the artistic presentation of multiple and diverse stories within single frameworks, whether visual (e.g., Pompeiian decoration, Isabella d'Este's studio) or literary (e.g., Ovid's Metamorphoses, Shakespeare's multiple plots). The class will ask how this matter of narrative, especially plural narrative, reflects on relations across media, disciplinary practices and periods of history.

title: Seminar in International Relations - Leadership and International Crisis
prereqs: Students should have taken Introduction to International Relations (POL 240)..
descrip: How do leaders make decisions during international crises? This seminar surveys prominent theories in the field including rational choice, psychological approaches, organizational and bureaucratic politics. It explores issues such as what leaders learn from past events; what strategies leaders use to signal their resolve to their adversaries during crises, and how they read the adversary's signals. We will pay attention to empirical questions, critically evaluate leaders' decisions; and will explore ways to make foreign policy arguments falsifiable.

title: Intensive Korean II
reviews: Focus on improving writing.
If you're a heritage speaker but still have some difficulty with grammer, writing, and some speaking, then take this class.

Take this course, especially if you are a 2nd generation Korean born in the states -- it is a more advance heritage track for such students. The coursework is not too demanding but it's honestly up to you how much you will get out of the class and improve your Korean. You will certainly get much better and very good training, but put in the time and effort yourself!
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. Credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing two-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: A continuation of Korean 103. This course covers the 2nd Year Korean material focusing on complex grammatical structures, reading, and writing. Journals are kept for writing practice. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: American Museums: History, Theory, and Practice
reviews: Have thick skin.
Take it. You get to go on field trips.
Yes
prereqs: Art majors should have had at least one 300-level course in the Dept. of Art and Archaeology. Students majoring in history, anthropology, public policy, and American Studies with an interest in cultural studies and museum work are particularly welcome..
descrip: This course is an introduction to American museums as modern institutions and to the challenges that they currently face. Through readings, field trips, meetings with museum staff, and practical exercises, students will explore how museums use objects to construct narratives; how they grapple with changing audiences and funding sources; and how they are touchstones for debates over societal values and collective memories. Although the focus will be on art museums, we will examine museums of natural history, material culture, and ethnography to better understand the collecting practices and displays of art museums.

title: Sociology of Religion
descrip: The sociology of religion asks questions about what people believe, how religion is organized, and how religion affects various aspects of social life. Understanding religion's changing role in society, along with all of its diverse manifestations, represents the central purpose of this class. Along the way, we will explore religion from a variety of different vantage points within the social sciences, and consider the influence of religion in different areas of social life including the family, race, immigration, and politics.

title: Automatic Control Systems
reviews: Definitely take this course and yes Prof. Rowley, lives up to all the positive reviews you're going to read. Basically Prof. Rowley is truly the ideal faculty member and I wish this was replicated in other courses - resourceful, in tune with the latest research in the field and introduces it in class, accessible, chooses enthusiastic TAs for HW and labs, and the labs feedback into the course and vice versa - but wait this is controls so Prof. Rowley is truly a master of control theory and understands how to make a stable system. And thus this course is very well taught, it probably can't get any better.

Definitely take this course if you have the time. The material is very challenging and will destroy you if you're not on top of it, but it's incredibly helpful as an engineering and very interesting. TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
I don't want to overrate this course, but I truly enjoyed it. Leave yourself enough time for the homework because each took me about 10 hours or so.
I thoroughly enjoyed taking this course. Rowley was an excellent professor and the material was interesting.
It's a really good class - you should invest lots of time into it - it will end up being really worth it.
Make sure to keep up with the material each week and ask questions if you don't understand something.
Rowley is a great lecturer. Take the class if you are interested in the subject matter, otherwise the class may seem like a lot of long and hard work.
Rowley's lectures and labs are great. One of the best courses in the department. Work early and hard on problem sets.
Start problem sets early and go to office hours!
Start the problem sets early and go to office hours if you are struggling
Take it! The book isn't really necessary, go to every lecture and pay lots of attention! And work on the problem sets with a group of people.
Take it. Just do it. Prof. Rowley is amazing.
Take this course if you can- it's fantastic.
This course is great. Rowley is great. It is a decent amount of work though.
This is a lot of work.

You probably have to take this.  One of the best departmentals in terms of organization and material.  Also one of the hardest so get ready to really work.  The problem sets are definitely manageable week to week but the exams are brutal.  Probably some the hardest exams I've taken here
You should enjoy Prof. Rowley's lectures. They are great.
anyone taking this doesn't really have a choice about it.
be sure to be very comfortable with using matlab to solve problems
do the readings before class.
hard class that takes a lot of time but it's very important and interesting
it'll be fun
really good stuff to know and it's taught well
take it!
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and to gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems in a laboratory setting.

title: Advanced Sculpture
reviews: Take this course!  Martha is my favorite.  Princeton is so lucky to have her and it is a really unique opportunity to take her class.
This course gives you the resources and the environment to intelligently being to explore and develop a body of sculptural work. If that sounds like something you are interested in, take it.
prereqs: VIS 203/204, or VIS 221/222, or VIS 231/232, or VIS 331/332 or instructor's permission..
descrip: In this course, each student will determine a specific theme that they will poke, prod and refine throughout the semester, ultimately completing three fully realized, thematically-linked sculptures and/or installations. While wood, metal and plaster will be readily available, various mixed media and experimental materials and approaches are highly encouraged. Regular individual and group critiques monitor the progress of each project. In addition, the class will collaboratively complete and install and outdoor public sculpture somewhere on campus. Field trips and image driven discussions will be part of the course.

title: Readings in Kiswahili Literature and East African Culture
prereqs: SWA 101 through SWA 107, or permission of instructor.
descrip: This advanced Kiswahili course will help students gain a higher level of language proficiency by applying grammatical skills learned in Elementary and Intermediate Kiswahili to topics addressing the language and culture of the Swahili speakers in East Africa. Coursework will focus on readings, writings, and oral performance activities on selected issues related to the history, geography, politics, language, literature, and cultural practices of the people of Kenya, Tanzania, and other Swahili speaking regions of Eastern Africa.

title: Topics in Brazilian Cultural and Social History - Music and the Atlantic World
reviews: I would certainly recommend this course. I think the topic is interesting and surprisingly interdisciplinary, giving insight on a number of other subjects. The professor was great, and the classes quite engaging.
I would recommend this course to anyone!

I would try and do some background research on Brazilian culture and music before coming to the course so that you have a better understanding of the material. I would also go to Bruno's office hours to find out more about what you're specifically interested in. The course is kind of flexible, though, so you should be able to explore your own unique interests throughout the semester.
It is a great course - go for it!
This course is great for someone looking to take a 300-level POR class because it deals with issues through the interesting and engaging lens of music.
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course focuses on major aspects of Brazilian music, history and society. How did vibrant and rich musical traditions emerge from the confluence of transatlantic diasporas? What are the potentials and limits of studying music as a way of generating insight into racial relations, religion, globalization, popular culture and national identity? We will discuss European and African diasporas; modernization (urbanization, radio, etc.); utopian explosions of the 1960s; the digital era. Students will experience some of the most exciting and memorable musical expressions of the past century, including samba, bossa nova, rap, and choro.

title: The Soviet Empire
reviews: An excellent survey course on the USSR with well-organized lectures and useful/interesting readings. I honestly enjoyed going to class and doing the readings. The midterm and final papers take a lot of work because the prompts are pretty difficult, and there's also a final exam, but the class is very rewarding if you put in the time.
I would advise the students to keep up with the readings, because Professor Heinzen really emphasized using the readings on both the final exam and in the two papers.
It is a good introduction to 20th century Russian history, but to get an accurate idea of how the culture developed, I recommend beginning with the class on 18th-early 20th century Russian history.
Its a good course that gives a different perspective of the Soviet Union
Take it if youre really interested in the soviet empire, then its very good. Do not take it for any other reason.
Take it, and do the reading.
There was a lot of work, a lot of reading, but you also learn a great deal if you put the time in. This is a great course overall.
This is a very informative and useful class to take. Lectures are engaging. Reading is heavy but interesting.

This isn't a very popular course for some reason and I don't know why. It was one of the only classes I have taken that wasn't recommended to me by someone and that I didn't take with any of my friends. The course work is fair, and the material is very interesting. I know I had a lot of false ideas about what Russia was like before the class, and now I know better.
descrip: An examination of the transformation of the Russian Empire into the Soviet Empire. Topics include: the invention and unfolding of single-party revolutionary politics, the expansion of the machinery of state, the onset and development of Stalin's personal despotism, the violent attempt to create a noncapitalist society, the experiences and consequences of the monumental war with Nazi Germany, and the various postwar reforms. Special attention paid to the dynamics of the new socialist society, the connection between the power of the state and everyday life, the bloc, and the 1991 collapse.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: History, Philosophy, and Religion
reviews: HUM was the best decision I made since coming to Princeton.

I would strongly recommend this class to anyone who wants to dedicate a lot of time to reading philosophy, analyzing great plays/works of literature, and getting lost in words.  Definitely make sure you are willing to make the commitment- the experience and your success are determined to the amount of effort you put in.
If you like reading, and only if you like reading, you should take this course.
Please see HUM 218.
Read the books.  Enjoy reading.  Be aware how much you actually have to read and the importance of giving each book its fair share of time.
Read, read, read...
See HUM 218.
Take HUM. It just gets better and better as the semester goes on.
Take it!
Take it! You definitely need to be interested in the material, but if you are, the workload really isn't that bad, cause you'll be doing what you love.
Take it. It's hard but so so worth it.
Take this course if you like reading.
Take this course!

Well, if you're reading this then you most likely took HUM 216-217. Things get ever better in HUM 218-219: the readings are more interesting, the professors are even more engaging, and you get even closer to the other students (you think you guys are close now? You just wait.) That being said, if you aren't keeping up with most of the readings in HUM 216-217 / you're not loving HUM 216-217, don't take this class. It changes, but it doesn't change that much, and your approach the class probably isn't going to change that much. 

If you didn't take HUM 216-217, and are interested in taking HUM 218-219, definitely give it a shot! Such an incredible, incredible course.
prereqs: See HUM 218.
descrip: In combination with 218, this is the second half of a year-long interdisciplinary sequence exploring Western culture from the 15th to the 20th centuries. Students must register for both HUM 218 and HUM 219, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for 219 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 218. There are no separate meeting times for 219.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
reviews: Be on top of your stuff, and be ready to learn. You have to do research on your own, because Prof. Garlock leaves you without enough information on purpose, since you have keep learning and do research when you go on to practice.

Be prepared to work long hours. Every week there is a new task, and you must fix your mistakes from the previous week. I found the work rewarding because by the end of the semester, your group has designed a ~70 story building. I would recommend this class to student who are very interested in the nit-picky details of designing a building. In this course, you honestly design everything from foundations, to columns, to beams, to walls, to connections.
Do not take this course until Professor Garlock has several more years of experience teaching the class or if another professor takes over the course.
Good class for structures-oriented students, whether you're on the structures or civ-arc tracks or not.

If you want to learn a lot from this class be prepared to work a lot. It's supposed to give you a taste of what engineering is like in the real-world, so if you are seriously considering a career in engineering, take it to get an idea of what to expect.
It's a good class. Definitely requires an interest in structural engineering.
