Only take this class if you want to be a structural engineer and are a fan of Professor Garlock.
Take this class.
prereqs: Students should have taken both CEE 312 and CEE 366, or have permission from the instructor..
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: Awesome course if you get Dondero as a preceptor
Be prepared to do a lot of work, but expect great satisfaction upon succeeding in the programming assignments.
COS 217 is hard but rewarding. If you are willing to get challenged take it, you will not regret it!

CS majors have to take the course. For anyone else who plans on programming seriously, you must take this course because it will give you an understanding of what your code actually does and what your computer does with it. The course is well-organized and well taught but demanding. Be prepared to spend five to ten times as much time on each assignment as COS 126 and two to four times as much time as COS 226 (although there are no exercises and there are fewer assignments). 

Dr. Dondero is extremely thorough and helpful and it would be wise to find out which precept he is teaching.

If the material does not come naturally to you, and you spent much more time than others understanding material in COS 126 or 226, be prepared for a rough semester.

Definitely take it.  Try to get Bob Dondero as a preceptor.  He is as amazing as everyone says he is.  It's a tough class and the assignments take a long time, but in the end it is very rewarding.  Larry Peterson is a decent lecturer and very laid back.
Definitely take this course if you are interested in what goes on in the inner workings of your executed code and your computer! It was challenging but a lot of fun!
Do not take this course lightly, it will consume your time. Pay attention in lecture and precept.

Don't freak out, programs are never as hard as they sound because they give you a lot of the component parts you need. Also, start early because towards the end of the semester, they introduce the next assignment before the previous is due, and then you're very confused and behind on the next assignment before you even start.
Don't take it unless you want to work ridiculously hard and not have a life.
Don't take it with Peterson. He doesn't know what a fair exam is. Other than that, it's a great course.
For the final, be sure to study all of the post-midterm lectures.
Get Dondero for your preceptor. He does MW 1:30-2:20 and 3:30-4:20 every year. Don't waste your time going to lectures. If you pay attention in precepts you will learn everything you need to know.
Get Dondero.  Seriously, you must.
Get Professor Dondero as your preceptor if you can.
Good course - learnt a lot. But be prepared to work hard. A D is very possible if you don't care about the course enough.
Great class, definitely take and get Dondero as your preceptor
Great course! Try to get Dondero
Hit the ground running and get very good grades on your assignments.
I recommend it to everyone who is interested in learning computer science.
I would definitely recommend this course if you're at all interested in computer science.
I would recommend this class, especially for those who are interested in computer science. I think that PDF is a great option for the class, and it's too bad that that's not an option next year

I would strongly recommend this course for a computer science major.  I would recommend this course to an engineer.  I would be neutral about whether or not a non-engineer, non-computer science major should take this course.
If you are interested in programming and like to know how things work, take this class.
If you're at all curious about how your computer works under the hood, take this class. You'll learn a lot. Though be warned that it can take quite a bit of time.

If you're liked COS 126 and you're not planning on being a COS major, take 226, 424, 402, etc instead.  Unless you really like computers (like I do), this class will most likely not interest you very much.
Interesting class.
It's a hard course. Be prepared to give in a LOT of coursework and make sure you love the course material.
It's a prerequisite...

It's good. Try to get dondero, his precepts tend to remain the same ones from semester to semester, but its not vital. All the other preceptors are trained by his book and are very good as well. If this is outside your department, consider PDFing-- it will save you a lot of time.
It's too much work to PDF.  Either take it because you're interested and willing to devote most of your semester to the assignments, or because you have to.
Make sure you are ready for this course; this course made me wish that I had already known C, or maybe that I took COS 226 before 217.  This class is hard.

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Obviously, it takes a decent amount of time and debugging can be annoying, but when you finish, you really feel like a power programming. AND MAKE SURE YOU GET PROFESSOR DONDERO AS A PRECEPTOR. DO WHATEVER YOU HAVE TO DO. Seriously.
Only take this if you are interested in the material.
Recognize that it will come to dominate your life.
Set aside time for the work. You'll learn a lot but things take a while.
Some of the topics could be rather dry, but I feel that this course provided a good introduction to programming systems.
Start assignments early and go to office hours.
Start on assignments early. Pay attention to lecture slides for exams. Attend all precepts. Try and get into Professor Dondero's precepts.
Start programs early and use modularity as much as possible
Start the assignments early
Start your assignments early

Start your assignments early. C and x86 assembly are remarkably easy to write subtle bugs in. I spent hours several times fixing stupid one-line bugs that had terribly huge effects to my code. Make sure to make use of your preceptor/lab TAs more than I did, if necessary.
Start your programming assignments early so you can take advantage of office hours. You will become a significantly better programmer through taking this course.
Take COS 217! It's a terrific course--one of the best I've taken at Princeton. I loved learning about computer systems and systems programming. Highly recommended!
Take it
Take it but be prepared to spend A LOT of time working.
Take it if you think you might be interested in architecture or OS. Also, I'd recommend ELE 206, which is better taught on the whole and lower level.
Take it if you're getting a CS degree or a certificate. It's quite time consuming and very frustrating at times.
Take it only if you are willing to spend 10 hours per week coding.
Take it! It is really interesting (and very useful) even if you don't have much programming experience (I didn't have much). The workload is fair and you really learn a lot in this class.
Take it. Programming assignments take a bit of time. You learn some cool stuff like assembly language though. Well taught and guided class.
Take this course - you learn a lot, although you have to work far more than in the majority of classes in the department.
Take this course -- it provides an excellent picture of how computers work and a broad knowledge of the C programming language.

Take this course if you're at all interested in learning about computer systems. Be prepared for a good deal more amount of work than 126 and 226, although I would definitely recommend taking it for the subject matter.
Take this course if you're interested in computer science beyond the introductory lab.
Take this course if you're interested. By the end of it you will understand how computers work on a much more powerful level.

Take this. Get Dondero. Win.
Seriously though, it's not thaaat much work
The exams are really unfair, so don't expect to do too well.

The midterm was challenging and made me feel pretty stupid since I had studied more for it than my other midterms but did worst on it. The ability to do assignments quickly or program did not at all help on the written exam for me. Overall the class was interesting but challenging, but I would advise against taking it unless you are smart or PDFing (like me).
This class is not as difficult as people will tell you (I'm not a COS major even) and it's actually really great. Don't be afraid and go for it.

This course is ridiculously hard. Avoid taking it with Peterson if at all possible, and getting Dondero as a preceptor is vital. But I'm not exaggerating when I say it is hard; I PDF'd, but I spent upwards of 25 hours on each assignment and a fair amount of time aside from that just to be able to pass. I guess the real question is: how much do you hate yourself?

This course is useful if you want to do any kind of systems programming; however, it's really boring.  The programming assignments are tedious, and they can be really short unless you get a nasty bug, which seems to happen often.

This course requires a pretty significant time commitment.  Expect to spend roughly 20 hours on some assignments (due roughly every 2 weeks), but also know that the time commitment is unpredictable (you never know how long it'll take to debug a 217 assignment).

This is a really good course for anyone who is interested in computer science. Be warned, the assignments take a very long time, so start early. Also, try your hardest to get Robert Dondero as a preceptor, he is amazing. If you are willing to put in the time, you will get a lot out of this course.
Unless you are a COS major or someone who is ready to make this class their number one priority who doesn't have other difficult classes, don't take it
Very difficult class that will take lots of time especially if you've never coded in C. Assignments take much longer than 226 and 126. Grading is tough. Make sure you reach out to Dr. Dondero.
Very difficult course, but good.
Work hard on the programs but make sure you study the material otherwise the exams are really difficult. Get Bob Dondero for your preceptor! This is a pretty difficult course.
You absolutely DON'T want to walk out of Princeton without doing COS 126, 226, and 217.
You will learn a lot through doing the assignments.
do not get akshay mittal as a preceptor
start everything early, and do the reading
take it if doing cos certficate.
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended) or score of 5 on the AP Computer Science Exam..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: The Rise of France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from the Beginnings to 1789
prereqs: Prerequisites: 107, 108, or equivalent or permission of Instructor. 207 strongly recommended as a co-requisite..
descrip: Two 90-minute sessions weekly, the first largely given over to a lecture format, the second for discussion and student oral reports. The course aims to present masterpieces of French literature, art, and architecture from the Middle Ages to the 18th-century.

title: Seminar. Renaissance Art
descrip: "Renaissance Cross-Cultural Encounters" examines European images of foreignness from 1400 to 1650. Organized chronologically, the class will begin by exploring the representation and perception of Jews and Turks and then consider how Europeans viewed the peoples and cultures of Africa, Asia, and the Americas. Through a study of primary and secondary sources and of works of art in various media, the course will consider how an increasingly global world impacted art production in the Renaissance, how Europe's encounter with foreigners contributed to the development of its own identity and whether the idea of race existed in the Renaissance.

title: The Economics of Uncertainty
reviews: Abandon hope, all ye who enter.
Do not take this course.
Go to lecture.

If you are thinking of grad school, take it. You're introduced to some rigorous material.

If you are not thinking of grad school, still take it.
Take it anyways.
Be ready to work hard though, because the people in the class are crazy.
It's a course for proud survivors from ECO 310.
Morris makes this a lively class.
Take it!
Take this class. It's very hard in my opinion, but eye-opening, especially the material on common knowledge and coordination.
Take this course if you have a relatively strong math background and like game theory, signals and information. It is one of the harder Econ courses
This course tends to get a little abstract. If you've taken 310 and seen some upper-level maths you'll be ok though.
This is a great course, though theoretical and difficult on a level similar to upper level mathematics courses.
prereqs: ECO 300, ECO 202 or equivalent knowledge of probability theory..
descrip: This is an advanced microeconomic theory course. Using the concepts and mathematical techniques developed in ECO 310, the following topics are studied: [1] Theories of choice under uncertainty. [2] Risk aversion and applications to insurance and portfolio choice. [3] Equilibrium under uncertainty with applications to financial markets. [4] Asymmetric information: moral hazard and adverse selection. [5] Applications to the design of incentives, contracts, contests, and auctions. Concepts in game theory are developed as needed.

title: Experimental Physics Seminar
reviews: Definitely take this course; it's fun and interesting, and it's a good third (or second if you only have 2) class to take 2nd semester senior year

I think it was a fairly remedial lab course, and I think it is a good course to fulfill a lab requirement for those taking 5 courses that semester. That said, the labs are not interesting at all, so it really depends on whether you want to go for interest or for an easy pass.

On one hand, electronics are cool and its PDF only. But I can't recommend this course, because it was basically a game of which groups get help from professor first. During the second half of the semester, we'd literally just sit and wait 2 hours for Tully to something on the computer for us that no one knew how to do.
Really fun STL! The hands-on aspect of this class is really really rewarding.
There is absolutely no work outside of class. It's the least time-consuming STL at Princeton.
This class is PDF-only circuitboard playtime. You may find yourself frustrated at times, but you'll do cool stuff.

This will be the easiest course you ever take at Princeton.  If you want zero work, zero assignments, zero exams, zero reading, take this class.  But be forewarned: You won't learn anything.  So don't expect to get anything out of this class other than a course credit.
it's mandatory pdf, would be pretty hard to get a d or an f, but not all that stimulating.
descrip: The seminar introduces students to the basic techniques of electronics and instrumentation used to conduct experiments in the physical sciences. The course begins by teaching a foundation in analog and digital circuits including programmable digital logic devices using an iPad interface for data acquisition. Students develop measurement techniques in a wide range of experimental areas.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: This class is available for 300-level credit, by application only, for any student who has previously taken two 200-level workshops in the Creative Writing Program. Students must have fluency in a language in addition to English. Applications must include 3-4 pages of either original literary translation or original work from their previous workshops. See the Creative Writing website for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Between Resistance and Collaboration: The Second World War in Europe
reviews: Do the readings before coming to lecture (like for every course, I guess). Start compiling a timeline and list of important figures as you are reading. But mostly, take advantage of the preceptor and the professor to explore the big theoretical questions of guilt, responsibility, justice, memory, etc.
Go to lectures and stay on top of the readings.
Good PDF class
Great course to take to gain an understanding of the European experience during WW2.
Great course.
If you are a history major, definitely take this course!
If you're interested in taking a class on World War II, or even just trying to get an HA, I'd consider this course.

If you're looking for a relatively straightforward history course with a very reasonable amount of work, this is a good option.  If you're looking for a course to challenge your thinking and prepare you for future work in history, I'd recommend against it.

It will give you a good idea of more of the social aspects of the war, most especially from and Eastern European perspective. Not my favorite course though - lecture could be boring, there's a lot of reading and it was sometimes difficult to create coherency between the two
Pretty easy history course on interesting material.
Reading-intensive but not writing-intensive.  A very interesting class if you're interested in World War Two.
Take it if interested
Take this class if you are interested in WWII and are good at history. Hope you get a good preceptor.

Take this class if you're into the subject or are a history major. If you're just looking for an easy HA and think "I know WWII, I've watched the History Channel before!" then you'll probably be disappointed. The course is also relevant to anyone studying 20th century European culture/politics, perhaps for obvious reasons.

Take this course if you are interested in the material. I learned a lot about WWII and the world. Precepts were really engaging but lecture could get a bit dry. The readings are great! Overall, I am really happy I took this course.
Take this course if you have an interest in European history!
The readings are not difficult and are actually  interesting.
The readings were very interesting, and I would really recommend this course.
This class was not necessarily what I was expecting but I'd recommend it.  Once I got used to Professor Gross and the format of the class I really enjoyed it.

This is a good course for people both interested generally in the period and for people looking for a HA course. The workload is not difficult, the lectures are interesting and the assignments are very fair if you go to class and do the readings!
descrip: In the broader context of conflict between fascism, communism, and liberal democracy, we shall examine various patterns and methods of occupation, collaboration, and resistance during World War II in Western and Eastern Europe. The Holocaust of European Jewry and the technology of terror will be discussed. We will try to ascertain how elites and different social strata were affected by the impact of war and occupation. Students will be asked to read historical studies as well as personal narratives by eyewitnesses and participants.

title: Object and Text in Premodern Japan
prereqs: At least one lower level course in art history, comparative literature, or Japanese studies, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar examines the dynamic interrelationship between objects and texts in premodern Japan, from the seventh through the seventeenth centuries. The series of meetings will introduce topics in a sequence that exemplifies the gradual layering of meaning and complication that comes from a culture with a strong classical awareness. We will examine a set of core themes in Japanese culture, such as love, death, nature, and enlightenment, as expressed in a range of mediums, including painting, gardens, lacquer, and ceramics, Chinese and Japanese poetry, imperial court and warrior narratives, and Noh dramas.

title: Introduction to Differential Equations
reviews: A good overview of solving differential equations. Especially if you are taking this as a physics major, it helps to have a more thorough knowledge than what is presented in physics courses.
Ask questions. During lecture. Interrupt her so you can catch your breath. Also, skimming your notes from the previous class right before lecture would be a really, really good idea.
Be warned: you will not prove anything (or hardly anything) in this class. Very unlikely to be satisfying for math majors.
Don't need to go to lecture, make sure you do all the readings though.
Dr. Taylor is great, she manages to pack in a great amount of useful material in a very short amount of time. Definitely worth taking, especially if she's teaching it as she's very helpful.

Even though it is not an explicit requirement for physics, this course should be taken by all physics majors.  The material covered is very useful for future physics courses and will explain/put into context many of the tricks used in PHY 205.
Fun, but can get tedious for pure math ppl
Gives a good overview of how to solve lots of differential equations. Good if you want an exposure to both proofs and applications in diff. eq.
Great course for any Physics student! You will learn a lot (not just ODEs) and lectures notes are a perfect combination of theory and examples! Take it sophomore year!
I didn't always enjoy this class while I was taking it, but looking back I learned a lot and there are some cool techniques.

If you have taken complex already and want to take a differential equations course that covers PDEs as well, take this course. The class goes through material more quickly than the MAE classes, but isn't too bad if you keep up.
If you need DiffEQ for your major, or if you're just interested in it for some reason, it's probably the most well taught Math class I've had a Princeton.
It moves really quickly.
Pretty good, thorough, diff eq class.  Basically what you would expect.
The pain is probably worth it.

There are no good reasons to take this course with Prof. Taylor. If you don't care for a rigorous approach, take Diff Eq in an engineering department. If you prefer rigor, take the math department version. This course tries to balance the approach and fails.

This class apparently varies on the professor, but with Professor Taylor (who is great) we spend 6 weeks on ODE's and 6 weeks on PDE's. I feel like I really learned how to solve a wide varieties of Diff Eq's, which is useful.
This is a fast class. Be ready. However, it is worth the effort. You will know well what you need to know once you are done.
take it, but its quite fast and rushed treatment of the material. If you want to study more applications and solving techniques, take MAE or other courses instead
prereqs: Multivariable Calculus (e.g. MAT 201 or 203)..
descrip: Whether you are interested in applied mathematics, engineering, or the natural sciences, a strong foundation in differential equations will imbue you with a better understanding of the physical world. This course will introduce you to the basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations, and discuss many applications, particularly to mathematical modeling in the life sciences. It differs from other similar courses (e.g. MAT 391& MAT 303) by striking a balance between theoretical issues (e.g. existence and uniqueness) and applied issues (e.g. numerical or analytical approximations).

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: It is a very nice course.
Very interesting material, definitely worth taking this class!
prereqs: FIN 501, FIN 522.
descrip: Course examines the concept of risk and its mitigation, and how the ideas can be applied in the practice of risk management for financial and non-financial companies. The basic toolkit draws on economics, probability theory and statistics, and they are integrated with more advanced concepts drawn from portfolio choice, derivative securities and dynamic hedging. Overall aim of the course is to demonstrate how the main concepts have practical applications.

title: Topics in Low Dimensional Topology
descrip: This course covers current topics in Low Dimensional Topology. Specific topic information provided when the course is taught.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: Absolutely take this course! Professor Garlock is an excellent lecturer and the assignments are easy if you keep up with them.
Don't wait to study for midterm and final last minute--you will save a lot of stress.  Also, this course isn't really that hard. Go to lecture and you can do well in the course
Even if you're not a civil engineer, I would consider taking this course.  There's not too much work.  There is, however, a little bit of over analysis on the topics discussed.
Great course -- definitely take it if you're interested in buildings and other structures.

Honestly- you can probably find a more enjoyable LA to take, so don't just take this class to get the distribution out of the way. It is a significant amount of work at the end of the semester even if you PDF it.

I recommend this course even if you are not a civil engineer; it will help you learn about the things you see around yourself all the time. The small scientific part of the course, the p-sets, are not really hard, so don't fear if you are not an engineer.
It's not too much work weekly, but keep in mind that there is a term paper and a final.
It's okay. Harder if you don't have some background.
Make sure you do the HW well.
Overall, I would recommend this course if you are looking for an easy course with some interesting structures (esp. for PDF).
Take for a grade! Do not PDF this class. It is too much work to PDF. For a grade, it is a fairly easy yet very interesting LA.
Take it if you want, it's not an outstanding course, but it's not bad either.
Take it! It's not much work, you'll learn a bunch and it's interesting.
Take it-- it's fairly easy
Take this class even if it is outside of your major.
Take this course and enjoy it

This is a really good course. If you're in CEE this is a great basis for talking about structures. If you're another BSE, it's a pretty good LA, and if you're an AB it's a really good STL. Everyone should take this course.

This is a very enjoyable introductory course, whether it's a for departmental requirement or just for general interest. It gives a great overview of structural art. However, the material is very broad and doesn't go very much in depth.
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through critical analysis of major works students are introduced to the methods of evaluating structures as an art form. Students study the works and ideas of individual structural artists through their elementary calculations, their builder's mentality and their aesthetic imagination. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities.

title: Programming Languages
reviews: Appel's awesome, take this class.
Be ready to do a lot of discrete math-type proofs.

Excellent class - undergrads who have taken 326 will feel right at home.  Proof assistants (Coq) are fascinating and a great experience.  Just know in advance that it's more about theorem proving and logic than programming languages.
I enjoyed this class and would encourage other students who are interested formal reasoning about programs to do so as well.

If you're interested in programming languages, or in formally-verified programs (which you should be - it's the future of reliable systems) you should take this class. Andrew Appel does a great job of making intimidating material accessible. It's also a good class to take to fulfill the theory requirement: since the proofs in the class that you write are all machine-checked, you know for sure if your answer is right.

That said, this class is not for the faint of heart. Problem sets consistently took 10-15  hours per week, though they were interesting and engaging (so much so that they distracted me from other work I had!)

Downside: the course could have been better organized logistically: deadlines were sometimes unclear, and it took a long time to get grades back
Surely take it.

The subject matter of this class is fairly specific: we dealt almost entirely in formal programming language semantics, using Coq to write computer-aided formal proofs. If you are interested in this, I can't recommend the class highly enough, it is well put together and organized, and the textbook is exceedingly helpful.
Useful and interesting.
prereqs: Undergraduates: COS326 or permission of instructor. Graduates: none.
descrip: Logic and formal reasoning about software, treating programs and programming languages as mathematical objects about which precise claims can be made. Basic concepts and techniques such as operational semantics and axiomatic semantics for specifying programming languages; structure, definition and properties of type systems; invariants and assertions for specifying programs. Use of automated tools such as interactive proof assistants, model checkers, and/or satisfiability-modulo-theories solvers.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Theories of Psychotherapy
reviews: An excellent course for students in any major.
Prepare well for the group project, and make sure everyone is on the ball about doing their part!
Take if you are interested, Comer is cool
Take if you're interested in clinical psych. I personally am not anymore, but I'm glad I know that.
Take it!
Take this course! Comer's great.

When I took it, this class included a group paper, and writing it was the single worst academic experience I've ever had. It was like writing a JP with five other people. Do not take this class if that is still a component. Otherwise, the material is interesting and Comer is good at lecturing and leading discussion.
With an interest in the material, this is a great class. Definitely involves work but its very manageable.
Write notes during the videos so that you can know how to write out the clinician's part for the papers.
good
take it to grow as a psych major
take it!!
take it. it's awesome. comer is cool. you'll learn a lot. i would only take it though if you are interested in learning about therapies, if not, take something else
prereqs: PSY 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course will examine the different theories, models, techniques, and settings that comprise the practice of clinical psychology in general, and psychotherapy in particular.

title: Contemporary Art: 1950 to the Present
reviews: Anyone and everyone interested in 20th century art should take this class.
Do the readings
Don't think it's a survey-level course. Hope the exams are different. Material is very cool.
Great class, especially if you want to learn the meanings behind modern art!
I would not take this course unless one already has a background in art.  It is not a friendly course for people who do not have experience in art critique.

I would take this course if you are interested in modern and postmodern art, and in particular understanding the art you would see in a contemporary museum today. It is quite informative, and very engaging. Professor Small is incredibly knowledgeable, but her workload is a bit more intense that one might initially anticipate, and her expectations are high, for better or worse.

If you like contemporary art, this course is decent.  Make sure you know what you're getting yourself into though because you're going to spend a ton of time with this stuff, a lot of which doesn't seem a lot like art at all.  I found for me it got less interesting after the novelty wore off, but you can decide for yourself.  The readings were not super necessary except for the ones for precepts, so the workload was fairly low other than the papers and studying.

If you think the topic might be of interest, I definitely recommend taking this course! I learned a lot about contemporary art. Now when I walk into a museum, I have a much greater appreciation of the work!

It was a great break from learning about science and other more down-to-earth subjects. So definitely take it, because you will learn how to think outside of the box. Definitely attend lectures - I successfully passed the course without opening the book once.
Lecture is particularly helpful so make sure you always attend lecture.
Make notes on the textbook as you go along; this'll help at the end when your scrambling to study.
Manageable workload (but both a final and a final paper); lectures worth attending.
Modern art is super conceptually, be prepared for what you are getting yourself into. The exams require LOTS of studying to do well. Have enjoyed other art survey classes much more.
TAKE IT if you want to learn why modern art is important, not too difficult but 212 would be a better 200-level introductory art course
Take the class, but prepare for some of the most ridiculous exams.
Take this course! You won't regret it!

Take your time with the readings, because they are complex. It also may be a good idea to keep an ongoing outline of artists and genres and definitions covered in class and in readings, since the material can become very cluttered in your mind by exam time.

The class does assume some prior knowledge of art history and the terms associated with the discipline, but if you have taken an art history class in the past and have an interest in contemporary art, this class will meet your expectations.
The subject matter of the course is very very interesting, but the readings were way too theoretical. Even though I pdf'ed the course, it still took up quite a bit of time.

You should probably only take this course if you're okay with thinking critically about artwork that on first glance looks like a pile of trash in the middle of the room. If you can deal with that, it's a great course!
difficult course. but a GREAT PDF
go to lectures
take it
descrip: A critical study of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of postwar art--abstract-expressionist, pop, minimalist, conceptual, process and performance, site-specific, etc. Special attention to crucial figures (e.g., Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Robert Smithson) and problems (e.g., "the neo-avant-garde", popular culture, feminist theory, political controversies, "postmodernism").

title: The History of Human Rights
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: This class will examine human rights in modern international history. It will explore the roots of human rights ideas in political theory and philosophy in the pre-20th century period, the emergence of human rights as a transnational idea in the last century, the institutionalization of humans rights norms in the United Nations and other international bodies, debates over the universality of human rights, human rights and U.S. foreign policy and human rights in the context of processes of 'globalization' and state responses to terrorism.

title: Innovation Process Leadership
prereqs: Understanding of the basic principles of science, engineering, technology and business. A keen interest in the role that creativity, ingenuity, entrepreneurial spirit, leadership and discipline play in the generation of new ideas/concepts and their transformation into successful products and/or services that can be commercialized..
descrip: In today's hypercompetitive global marketplace, innovation is the lifeblood of any business enterprise. This practical course exposes students to the fundamental aspects of leading the technological innovation process: from strategy formulation, idea generation, invention/concept development, through business plan preparation and decision making to commercialization, critical success factors, process optimization and corporate agility. It covers the basic practices required to become technology-savvy leaders in a complex technological society.

title: Animal Mind, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Mesoamerican Material Culture
descrip: This course explores the art and archaeology of Mesoamerica, including the cultures and regions of the Olmec, West Mexico, Teotihuacan, Oaxaca, Maya, and Aztec. From temple pyramids and carved stone monuments located in plaza centers to the broken ceramic sherds and stone tools found in household trash deposits, material culture comprises one of the basic resources archaeologists examine to understand past ways of life. The course will explore the inferences scholars make in the analysis of material remains as well as the ways in which material culture was integral to the making of ancient political, economic, religious, and social systems.

title: Rabbinic Literature: Law, Religion, and History
descrip: Course introduces students to the world of the talmudic rabbis, who created the classical and normative literature of Judaism. We will deal with the historical background of Rabbinic Judaism, the concept of the written and the oral Torah, and rabbinic literature proper (Midrash, Mishna, Talmud etc.) as well as with some major rabbinic concepts (God, creation, election of Israel, redemption). The course will focus on the analysis and discussion of primary sources.

title: International Trade Policy
descrip: Evaluates arguments for and against protection and adjustment assistance and considers topics chosen from the following: non-tariff barriers, dumping, embargo threats and trade warfare, and the political economy of trade policy formation. Special attention is given to trade problems of the less-developed countries, including North-South trade relations and commodity price stabilization. Prerequisite: 511c.

title: Microeconomic Theory II
reviews: I would recommend it if you are interesting in learning the material. You need to commit yourself to learning the material.
It's a really useful course for understanding better the theory of economics.
Just practice doing problems over and over and over again to get them down quickly.
Nothing in particular.
Very challenging and time consuming with a difficult curve -  I would caution taking this course as an undergrad.
Work hard.
descrip: This course is the second term of a 2 term sequence in Microeconomics.

title: For Your Viewing Pleasure: Gender and Sexuality in Contemporary American Theatre, Film, and Popular
prereqs: None..
descrip: For Your Viewing Pleasure considers what it means to be an ideologically invested spectator of popular culture in the contemporary U.S. Contrary to common stereotypes, viewers can consider politics, as well as gender, sexuality, race, and other identities in theatre, film, and television, and still enjoy themselves, as analysis and pleasure are not mutually exclusive. These forms both reflect and shape who we are as citizens. The course will sharpen students' instincts as fans and spectators, and provide tools to deepen the analytic skills they bring to their cultural consumption.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Agriculture & Climate Change: Feeding a Hot & Hungry Planet
descrip: By some estimates, agriculture contributes 30% of world greenhouse gas emissions, including its role in tropical deforestation. Reducing these emissions while producing the additional food needed for an expected 9 billion people in 2050 represents one of the great challenges of our age. This concentrated half semester course will explore the sources of agricultural emissions, agriculture's role in shaping world land use, the locations and causes of world hunger, and technical and policy options for meeting this challenge.

title: The Making of Modern France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from 1789 to the Present
reviews: Do all the readings.
Get ahead on the readings.
I don't know.
I hope that Madame Huet sees this: I loved your class and I have also learned a lot from you about French culture. Thank you for everything
I think this is a great class and I would encourage any other student to take it.
It will probably be very different without Huet teaching it so its hard to say.
TAKE IT !!!
prereqs: Prerequisites: FRE 107, 108, or equivalent. FRE 207 recommended as a co-requisite..
descrip: The course explores the last two centuries of French cultural history, focusing on key periods of political, literary, and artistic life, from Napoleon to de Gaulle, from Balzac, Baudelaire, and Marguerite Duras to Albert Camus. Topics will include the Revolution and the Empire, Romanticism and Impressionism, Paris and the Belle Epoque, and the World Wars and decolonization. We will discuss texts, archives, films, and paintings.

title: Culture and Inequality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Computational Neuroscience and Computing Networks
descrip: An Introduction to the biophysics of nerve cells and synapses, the mathematical description of neural networks, and how neurons represent information. Course will survey computational modeling and data analysis methods for neuroscience. Topics will include representation of visual information, spatial navigation, short-term memory, and decision-making. Two 90-minute lectures, one laboratory. Lectures in common with MOL 437. Graduate students will carry out and write up an in-depth semester-long project.

title: Art for Everyone
reviews: Fantastic PDF-only class.

It's a great way to fulfill your LA requirement and explore an area you probably haven't explored before. It's also great because it introduces you to forms of art other than traditional drawing and painting.
Really hard class probably half of students will pass
You might find the avant-garde art stuff weird, but it's a lot of fun if you're looking for a super easy and laid-back course .
prereqs: Restriction: This course is not open to students who took VIS 472, Special Topics in Visual Arts - Art for Everyone.
descrip: This studio class will address the increasing social pressure on art to become more widely distributed, immediately accessible, and democratically produced. For the past fifty years, expanding definitions of what art might be fueled by a greater emphasis on active audience participation have encouraged an atmosphere in which anyone can claim to be an artist. Through studio work in a wide range of graphic and digital media, supported by readings and discussions, this class will take a hands-on approach to the question of whether art by everyone for everyone constitutes a dreamed-of utopia, a universal banality, or a cultural nightmare.

title: Topics in Number Theory - Modular forms and L-functions
reviews: The course presents some interesting material about number theory.
prereqs: MAT335 and MAT345..
descrip: Course will cover the classical theory of elliptic functions and elliptic curves, modular forms and modular curves, and Hecke operators and L-functions.

title: Contemporary Problems in Molecular Biophysics
prereqs: Open to graduate students and advanced undergraduate students only..
descrip: The course will present the chemical, physical, and mathematical principles underlying the intermolecular interactions of macromolecules, and introduce a wide range of physical and chemical methods for studying such interactions. Students are encouraged to bring their own research problems to class as case studies.

title: Qualitative Methods
descrip: This seminar provides a broad introduction to research design and analysis for political scientists interested in qualitative research and mixed-method research. The emphasis is on systematic measurement and inferential strategies when considering a few cases in-depth. Topics to be covered include case selection, periodization, comparative-historical analysis, the integration of qualitative and statistical methods, the design and implementation of field research, in-depth interviewing, and archival research. The class will critically practice the implementation of various techniques.

title: Reasoning about Computation
reviews: Be prepared for a challenge if you've never taken proof based math before. The pace is super fast.
Definitely take it with Braverman
Definitely try to take this course with Braverman. If you don't have a strong math or probability background, it's going to be a little rough. That said, you learn a ton.

Don't take it unless you absolutely have to or you're a math major. Take it with Braverman if you can. It's ridiculously difficult (particularly if you don't have the greatest math/proof-writing background), hard to learn, and there's not much partial credit/pset feedback.
Don't take it unless you have to. Huge time suck and the material is difficult

Even if you don't have a strong math background, you can still do well in the course. Try not to work in a group where there is a large difference in the skills of the group members, or else it becomes easy for one member to end up doing a lot of the work, which does not allow everyone in the group to learn the material. If the class is taught the same way as this semester, the material gets easier as the class goes on. Office hours are also really helpful.
Go to precept. They will randomly teach things in precept that they don't teach in lecture and then put those things on midterms because they're sly.
Good back ground of lots of stuff!
Good, interesting class. Even if you haven't touched proofs in high school, you can get a good grade IF you put the time into your problem sets.
Hugely challenging, but very rewarding. Start problem sets the day they come out and don't fall behind.

I had never done COS theory before and I found this course REALLY HARD.  The problem sets took me a good 20 hours each week.  Make sure you find a good group to work on them with.  That being said, you should take this as a COS major to be well rounded.  There is a lot of information that is helpful for understanding the theory behind everything we do.

I made the mistake of letting this course take too much of my time. Do NOT let it kill your other grades, because it will. You don't have to solve everything: chances are that if you can't get it, neither can half the class. AVOID KINTALI IF POSSIBLE, he's incredibly boring.

I personally loved this class, as the material was really interesting and Professor Braverman was an amazing lecturer.  The Psets each week were a lot of work, but I honestly had a lot of fun working on them.

I was scared after hearing horror stories, but I actually really liked this course! It presents a lot of different topics, and forces you to think... a lot (in a good way). Braverman is a great lecturer, and the workload wasn't as bad as people made it out to be (psets vary in difficulty, the longest taking maybe 10-15 hours and the shortest taking 1 hour).  Make sure you have a good group!!  Office hours are also helpful.

I'm not a COS major, but took this class because I was interested in the material.  I really enjoyed the class!  One of few classes where I actually enjoyed doing psets... it's just a bunch of puzzles!
If need be...
If you are a COS major definitely take it. Even if you're not, if you are interested in COS and like math, you will probably enjoy this course.

If you aren't strong in math (I'm not), this course is a huge struggle. It feels, most of the time, like trying to write with the wrong hand. The good news is it's often cool and made me really interested in theory. I just wish it weren't so stressful and so much of a "you-get-it-or-you-don't" type of deal. That's theory, I guess. You should take it as early as possible. Also: the course gets easier after the midterm. Make sure to read the book and go to office hours--I regret only going a few times.
If you like math.
If you like mathematical proofs, then you will like this course. If you don't, then don't take this course.
If you want to do proof based math, but are intimidated by the math department, this is a good class.

If you're a COS major, definitely take this course. I heard a lot of really scary things before taking it, but in retrospect, I am really glad I did. Yes it is very challenging unless you've been doing math competitions your whole life, but it is doable, and a lot of the material is actually very important (and much more fun than I expected). Definitely make sure you pick good partners for the problem set though; it will make your life a lot easier.
If you're a COS major, you're going to have to take 340.  Don't underestimate it, and definitely FIND A GOOD GROUP to do homework with.  That alone can make or break the semester.
If you've got to take it, take it. If you're a math major looking for an easy class, take it. If you're someone else, keep looking.

It's a lot of work. Some weeks are harder than others, but be prepared to think hard. It's also very good if you need to lern to TeX. You learn a lot, but it takes lots of effort. That being said, it's interesting and definitely things that are useful to know.

It's an interesting and useful class for math/cos majors. It's extremely difficult if you've never done proof-based math and in general if you're not a math major. I highly recommend going to Braverman's office hours: he's very helpful, and I always came out of them knowing exactly what to do to solve a problem I had spent hours worrying about before.
It's material that every COS major really should know. Take it with Braverman and Ilya if you can.
Keep up with the material and read the book.
Lecture attendance is not mandatory since the professor records them and posts them online.  This being said, I think they are quite interesting, and I think they help you stay engaged in the course.

No good way around taking it if you're a cos major - makes no sense that all cos majors basically have to take a course that's basically just math and not helpful unless you want to pursue theoretical cos. very hard class.
Only real option for fulfilling the theory requirement so take it. It isn't that bad and has some interesting material, but it mostly depends on your interest in the theory side of things.
Only take it if you don't have anything to do.
Pretty interesting material, good prep for CS interviews
Start assignments early, think about them in your spare time.
Stay on top of readings and assignments.

TAKE IT WITH BRAVERMAN (assuming that you have to take it because you're COS). As someone who was challenged by the material but still enjoyed the class, I can say that's completely because of how well Braverman taught it. Also, who you take it with (2 partners) is very important. If you aren't COS, and feel pretty good about your math skills, it's a great proof-based class to take that isn't as intimidating as the 200-level proof-based MAT classes.
Take it and expect some rough weeks. With good planning and office hour attendance, it shouldn't be too bad.
Take it!  As a non-math and non-COS major, I loved it.  Problem sets are fun and relatively little work.  Especially if Professor Braverman is teaching, I couldn't recommend it more.
Take it, but beware that it will take a lot of time and finding a good group could make or break your grade!

Take it, with Braverman if possible. Be aware that problem sets will be a lot of work, of a type that you probably won't be familiar with unless you've been exposed to Math 21x courses. I would favor taking it earlier rather than later, but probably after COS 226 (though this is not essential). A COS major can't and shouldn't avoid taking this course-- it's actually a good one as Theory courses go, and pretty much all of the others require it.
Take it. It's not that hard and it's fabulously interesting.
Take this course with Braverman. He's awesome. The assignments and exams are fair and actually require thought. You learn a lot.

This course is terribly, extremely difficult unless you are experienced with proof based math.  It is the kind of material you either get or you don't...it is very difficult to learn better just by studying.  However, you probably have to take it if you're a COS major, so find good PSET partners, start early, and good luck!
This course will likely be extremely time consuming, so start the problem sets early.

This is a difficult course if you're not innately comfortable with mathematics and proofs. Still, the challenge is worthwhile and it's a good theory class to fulfill COS requirements. Anticipate spending 6-10 hours on problem sets if you're not a math major.
This is a fantastic course that really trains you in different, creative ways to think and solve problems. Even if you're not very interested in COS, you will get alot out of this course.
Tough class. Make sure you get a good group.
Yes, this is a very difficult class for some, but it teaches you to think in a very unique way. Quite valuable skills. I recommend it. Fight through the hard times and you will gain a lot.

You should definitely take COS340.  Unfortunately, Braverman is not teaching it again next year.  Even so, take it and be sure to spend time making sure you understand the problem sets without the help of your group.  It will payoff come the midterms and final.

You will learn a lot. Take this class with Mark Braverman if you can. Go to his office hours, and DEFINITELY go to Shiva Kintali's offices hours (he will actually help you understand every tiny piece of material). Make sure you actually understand the problem sets, or else the midterms and final will be impossible. Don't be scared by this course. It is definitely doable, and you will learn alot, just be prepared to put a lot of time into it. It will dominate your semester.
you have to take it, or you dont
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics and probability will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling through topics such as dealing with uncertainty in data and handling large data sets. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.

title: Topics in the History and Theory of the Media: Artificial Life
descrip: What defines life? And where do we locate the boundary between its proper and improper instances, between the natural and the monstrous? First emerging in the early 19th century, the prospects of artificial life continue to provoke both exhilaration and anxiety today. By examining works of philosophy, literature and film over a historical period ranging from early Romanticism to contemporary nanoculture, this seminar explores humanity's desire to become like the gods, fashioning species, companions, and slaves at will, even as these creations menace us through their intractability and threaten to take on an uncanny life of their own.

title: Modern Jewish History: 1750-Present
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in modern Jewish history or history at all. Professor Dweck is an incredible professor - don't miss this class!
Even if you are not interested in Jewish history at all, this will probably be one of the best courses you take.
I would highly recommend it to students interested in Jewish history or looking for a class taught by a great lecturer.
I'm a history major and this is in all likelihood the best history class I've taken - as long as you're willing to give a solid effort. Dweck is engaging, smart, funny
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT! it was such a great class!!!! Dweck is amazing!
TAKE IT.  Take anything with Dweck.  He's incredibly engaged and fun and you won't regret being in his class for a second.
Take his courses!
Take it.  Prof. Dweck is awesome, the readings are great, and the workload is not overwhelming.  No-brainer!
Take this class! Dweck is amazing - by far the most engaging professor I've had here. Be prepared to read a good deal, but you'll learn a lot and enjoy the class as well.
Take your time expressing yourself, think slowly and dive in.
take it!
descrip: This course surveys the breadth of Jewish experience from the era of the Enlightenment to the contemporary period. Tracing the development of Jewish cultures and communities in Europe, the Middle East, and the United States against the background of general history, the lectures focus on themes such as the transformation of Jewish identity, the creation of modern Jewish politics, the impact of anti-semitism, and the founding of the State of Israel.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: Always use a piano when working. Play out the excerpts.
Being more engaging during lecture will improve your experience in the class.
Check reviews for the specific teacher, not just the class.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE IF B. WHITE IS TEACHING. You will learn NOTHING and you will waste your time. The only reason you will go to lecture is for fear of a pop quizz. Worst of all, this negativity will be associated with music, which should be something sacred and unblemished. This course was bad for my SOUL. AVOID B. WHITE AT ALL COST.
Do not take this course.
Don't take it with Barbara White.
Have fun with this class, it's a great way to find out about music that you've never heard of before.
I would recommend this to anyone who is not a music genius but who really likes music and wants to learn more about Tonal Harmony.

I would, because I still love the subject matter. I would caution them, however, because my love of the subject matter did not come from this course and the course itself taught me very few new things that I had not learned in high school.
I wouldn't take this course unless you have to.
If you are interested in music, take this course, but some of the work will have to be done on your own.

If you have good knowledge of theory, this course is likely too slow for you. But, if not, I think you'll find it's a very manageable intro and you'll enjoy listening to music, applying theory to practice. Most students do already have a solid background in theory, but the class is definitely doable even if not, and, you'll probably get more out of it.

If you take this course with Barbara White, I suggest not taking the course unless you have previous knowledge of the material. The class was very disorganized so don't expect to be learning what you need to know from the class. You'll be trying to figure it out on your own by reading the book and asking friends, and then even then, it might be difficult. Also, ear-training was super hard, and the program assigned to help was not helpful at all.
If you truly love music, take it with Dmitri. If you don't have too much experience but want to learn more than clapping for credit, this will suffice.

If you've taken 105, take this course, it's just as good.  If you haven't taken 105, make sure you do so that you can start to understand what you've been doing with your instrument, voice, composing, etc.. It's really a great course.

If your interests have been in music for a while, this is the course for you, but if you are just diving in without any prior knowledge of music in general, it will be quite challenging, especially ear-training, which was very difficult to prepare for in testing.
Make sure you don't skip class and do complete all your assignments because it will be good preparation for the tests.
PLEASE don't take with Barbara White; she was pretty awful (possibly the reason I'm not a music major) ONLY take with someone else.
Pay attention and do the work. Hard work pays off.
Play around on the piano--it's fun and you learn so much more.  Learn the pieces you're studying if you have time.
This course is much more manageable than MUS 105 if you, like me, have had little to no experience with music theory before. The performance aspect is really good, and lectures are engaging.
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of the instructor. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-level theory work, and should be taken by any freshman considering majoring in music, entering the Certificate Program, or taking upper-level music courses..
descrip: A continuation of Music 105, with an emphasis on the harmonic and formal principals of Western classical music. We will focus on modulation, chromatic harmony, and form.

title: Salafi Islam
descrip: Salafism and Salafi Muslims have irrupted on the global and Middle Eastern political scenes in the last decade, and are often described by pundits in the media as the enemies of the West and all that is modern. This course will interrogate such common, and mistaken, assumptions, looking more carefully at the medieval theology and law of the Salafi movement as well as the beliefs and actions of its modern and contemporary followers.

title: Topics in International Relations - US Diplomacy and the Persian Gulf, the Peninsula and Neighbors
descrip: Seminar examines the political, social, economic and strategic dynamics within "The Other Middle East": the members of the Gulf Cooperation Council and their primary neighbors, Iraq, Iran, Yemen and India. Course explores the context and complexities of the regional actors, how recent US policies have affected these states and the impact of the Iraq War on the region and on US influence and options. Topics include the role of religion, the growth of knowledge-based globalized economies, public diplomacy; the history of Saudi-Iranian relations, and the rise of regional actors, particularly Iran and India.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: For anyone not in the Teacher Prep program, this class may be a bit much or difficult to fit in because of the observations which go along with it, but otherwise it was very interesting and thought-provoking.
It's a ton of work!
Read everything, immerse yourself in psych thinking and take whatever angle you like - from TPP or from another discipline perhaps.
Set aside time for classroom observations.

Take this course if you are interesting in schools, education, teaching, etc. This class is also very interesting for anyone that wants to undestand what adolescents go through. Finally, it will allow you to reflect on your own school experience. If you are interesting in education, take this course!!!! Please!!!!!
This class is A LOT of work, but a great way for those interested in education to complete an EC.

This is a rough course to take during your senior year.  Be prepared to put in a lot of outside work - weekly response papers, going off campus and observing classes, and creating a lesson plan for one of the class meetings.

Time management is key because there are a ridiculous amount of papers for this class (weekly papers   3 observation papers   midterm and a final paper). It's not challenging at all, just busy work. The material is pretty interesting though. You won't get as much out of it if you're a non-TTP student.
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Others may enroll with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: The Great Russian Novel and Beyond: Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, and Others
reviews: Do the readings!

If you are interested in this course, please take it!! Professor Chances is a bit of an oddball, but in a really good way, and the content is amazing. Make sure you have time to do the readings fully, though, because I doubt you'll get much out of the class otherwise.

Take it. There's a lot of reading, but it's not hard. There are no papers and the exam is set up in a way that you are almost guaranteed to be able to write a decent essay on at least a couple of the topics you are offered, and you can choose from those. The precept is chill. Jen is great. Professor Chances is very friendly and knowledgeable. I kinda added this course on a whim, but I'm really happy I did it.
Take this course if you want to read lots of Russian Literature and discuss it with a great professor!

This is a fun course, and Prof. Chances is a phenomenal lecturer. I had a grad student as a preceptor instead of the professor, but she was surprisingly good too! Be warned, the readings are longer than she and the registrar lets on. I was forced to do triage and only ended up reading some of the works, but will go back and finish them later.
precepts are interesting, lectures can be repetitive sometimes, worthwhile if interested in russian lit
take it. it's a lot of reading but it's so much fun. the workload is not bad at all.
prereqs: Curiosity. Knowledge of Russian not required. Open to first-year students as well as to sophomores, juniors and seniors..
descrip: An examination of significant trends in Russian literature from the 2nd half of the 19th century to the Russian Revolution and a bit beyond. The course focuses on many masterpieces of 19th & 20th-century Russian literature. The works (mostly novels) are considered from a stylistic point of view and in the context of Russian historical and cultural developments. The course also focuses on questions of values and on the eternal "big questions" of life that are raised in the literature. Authors read include Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bely, Nabokov, and Kharms.

title: Elementary Turkish II
reviews: I would recommend anyone take Turkish at Princeton. It is thorough and effective but without the stress of Chinese or Arabic at Princeton.

TAKE IT!  Erika Hanim is awesome and Turkish is such a cool language to learn.  After only one year I have all of the tools that I need to translate almost any Turkish text. You definitely get out of this class what you put in.
Take it!
Take it.
You'll have a decent amount of homework every night and you'll have to work hard, but it's rewarding and you couldn't ask for a better language teacher.
prereqs: TUR 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Familiarity with all grammatical aspects of Modern Turkish. Reading text of moderate difficulty; developing communicative skills: ability to comprehend and engage in daily discourse; ability to write short compositions.

title: Cognitive Psychology
reviews: Attend lectures and precept - interesting, and you will do well.
Do not take if you don't have too.  Find another EC
Don't do it. Wait for a good EC. But if you're desperate, it's easy and low commitment to PDF.
Don't expect any interesting neuroscience, it's all pretty obvious and basic intro psychology.
Don't take it. Even if you have to, find a way around it.

Easiest final exam I've ever taken - done in 15 minutes. A really good way to fulfill the PSY requirement of the RIS certificate. Prof is old and slightly eccentric - doesn't like to call on you more than once in a class period, so I gave up raising my hand. Huge variety of topics covered, and you need a fairly good understanding of everything to do well on the weekly quizzes, but everything is multiple choice so if you're a good guesser you can get by with less.  READ THE BOOK, DEFINITELY.
Fun course for a distribution requirement. All tests are multiple choice and mostly based on memorization. Only a few hours/wk outside of class.
Go to all the lectures

I didn't find this course particularly interesting in terms of material, engaging in terms of lectures, nor challenging in terms of exams. The class wasn't bad either. Very average course, if you have to take it as a requirement, it wont' be painful at all and not very much time commitment if you're okay with a B . The curve is pretty rough though to actually get na A.

I took this class just out of general interest and I LOVED it. Basically, if you are the type of person who enjoys reading about studies and all sorts of (sometimes slightly weird) research, this class is for you. My mind was blown frequently by the stuff we talked about.

Mike Arcaro is a great, great preceptor. 

Take advantage of the review sessions.
(You will get a lot more out of precept if you show up prepared, just saying.)
I'd recommend taking a different Psychology course.  I was underwhelmed.
It's alright. Most of the material is just common sense. I don't feel like I learned much in this class at all.
It's interesting material, and the workload is not very heavy.  I'd recommend it.
Make sure to go to lectures and understand all the material. Take great notes.
Make sure you take good notes every class.
Only take it if you're (a) very very interested in the material or (b) not worried about how bad the lectures are...
Take good lecture notes and do all of the reading. You can't get through the quizzes / tests without it.
Take good notes. Read the textbook.
Take it! It's a great intro to psych.
Take this class if you have very good memory.
Terrible lecture! You have to learn how to scribble material furiously -- at speeds beyond comprehension. However, the material is interesting and if Mike is precepting, it is worth it.

The content is very interesting, however Osherson refusal to post slides on blackboard as well as adhering strictly to grade deflation policy can be a damper. I did not get much out of precepts as well, as they did not cover anything new,

Very easy class for an EC since quizzes/exams are short multiple choice. Always go to lecture because they aren't posted and take lots of notes. Also, make sure you keep up with book readings because you have quizzes every week.
Wonderful course! A lot of information, so be prepared to write at a fast pace.

lectures go FAST (hits you at the beginning) and the slides arent posted. precept quizzes are harder than you might think. overall i thought the material was fascinating though, and i enjoyed the class.
take it
descrip: The course will survey the major themes and experimental findings of Cognitive Psychology. We will address the question of how scientists probe the nature and underlying structure of human thought. Topics covered include attention, perception, imagery, memory, language, thinking, decision making, and cognitive neuroscience.

title: The Production and Consumption of Culture
descrip: Why is it so hard to figure out how much something costs in an art gallery? Who thought spending over $350,000,000 on John Carter was a good idea? Do you and your friends like the same music because you are friends, or are you friends because you like the same music? Why is it so hard (for everyone else) to have good taste? While you are probably familiar with analyzing and evaluating media content as texts (e.g. Was that a good book? or, Do you really like Two and a Half Men?), in this course we will be focusing on the contexts (i.e. the social, cultural, and economic relations) in which mediated texts are created and consumed.

title: Advanced Topics in Modern Architecture - Manifesto Architecture
reviews: Be well prepared to be a readholic!
You should prepare you paper in advance.
descrip: The history of the avant-garde (in art, architecture, literature) can't be separated from the history of its engagement with the media. It is not just that the avant-garde used media to publicize its work. The work did not exist before its publication. This seminar will explore the key role played by manifestoes in 20th century architecture and ask what happened to such calls for action in the digital age.

title: Biology of African Animals and Ecosystems
reviews: Dustin won't hold your hand.  You'll get a very good intro to East Africa and scientific writing through this course.
It was a really good course for anyone interested in learning how to write papers.  Be prepared to work really hard.
prereqs: EEB 211 and EEB 321..
descrip: Students will be immersed in an intensive field experience in Kenya gaining sophisticated training in fieldwork and biological research on African animals and ecosystems. In addition to this training, participants will observe and study organisms ranging from acacia ants to giraffes, go-away-birds to zebras. The course is designed to give students a broad, hands-on understanding of ecology, evolution, and conservation. Lectures include core topics in ecology and evolution. Students will gain experience with experimental design, data collection, and analysis. Limited to students in the Tropical Biology and Sustainability Program in Kenya.

title: Problems in Political Theory - Theories of Distributive Justice
descrip: In recent years, economic inequality has risen to startling new levels in the United States and in the world as a whole. The course explores the relationship between economic inequality and justice. It does so mainly by surveying at the graduate level several of the major approaches to thinking about economic justice. Four major approaches are discussed: (i) Lockean and libertarian theories of property rights and limited government; (ii) Marxian approaches to justice; (iii) utilitarianism; (iv) Rawlsian approaches. About half the course will be devoted to (iv), with a few weeks each on (i) and (ii), and one week on (iii).

title: Elementary Japanese I
prereqs: No credit is given for JPN 101 unless it is followed by JPN 102..
descrip: An intensive introduction to modern Japanese stressing oral-aural facility, but including an introduction to written Japanese.

title: The Anthropology of Law
descrip: Study of the relation between formal legal institutions and the social and cultural factors influencing their development. Western and non-Western systems compared in terms of their forms of judicial reasoning, implementation through law of moral precepts, fact-finding procedures, and dispute settlement mechanisms. Issues covered include judicial application of moral precepts, the relation of law to social relations, the development of the jury, Japanese conciliation, American family life and the law, and social science and Supreme Court decisions.

title: How Not to Go to Africa
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Ancient Philosophy
reviews: A great introductory class that is easy to follow.

A solid course.  Not too much work, but you will learn a lot.  Prepare to read a lot of philosophy that doesn't actually make a lot of sense, but you still need to talk about it.  (Everything is made out of fire! Discuss.)

Be prepared to have relatively disinteresting lectures, with some really interesting gems. Some people love this class, some hate it. If you don't love it right away, i would suggest switching to a different philosophy class.
Definitely take it, it's a great EC and Lorenz is  a great professor.
Good basis for PHI.  But not the most thrilling class on the whole.

Good distribution requirement, 5 essays, a final essay, and not too much weekly reading. If you don't know much about ancient Greek philosophy, such as that of Socrates and Plato, and would like to know more, this class is a good opportunity.
Good way to get a distribution requirement out of the way, and fun if you're interested in classics.
Good, intro-level philosophy course.
Great class
Great course to take if you've never taken a philosophy course but have an interest in philosophy or ancient history.  Don't take the course if you're not going to attend lectures/precept.
Great survey course. You will definitely get a better understanding of Plato and Aristotle. Professor Lorenz is great--try to get his precept if you can!

I think every educated person should know a bit about Plato, Aristotle, and the like. Take this course to gain a good overview of ancient thought. Philosophers may not be as nonsensical as you may expect!
I would encourage students to reread texts that they're writing about, and to attend every lecture, because they explicate the material clearly.
If you are considering being a philosophy major, take this class. If you want an introductory philosophy class, take it as well. It is not unduly hard and the material is interesting.
If you are looking for a course to fulfill your EC requirement, this is it!

If you have any interest in philosophy, take this class. The ancient philosophers have interesting views and ideas, and they're not overly complicated. This class is interesting and engaging without demanding too much time
If you're looking for an easy distribution requirement, this is it.  If you're looking for a challenging philosophy class, I wouldn't recommend this course.
Im neutral cuz I PDFed
It is a good class, either for P/D/F or a grade, and Hendrik is really interested in helping his students out and making sure that they understand the material.
It is a good introductory course, not especially demanding and good to get you thinking about the fundamentals of Philosophy.

It works for a distribution requirement, but Lorenz can be pretty boring.  Unless you're interested in this period of philosophy there are probably better ways to fill an EC.  It's an easy course but not a very interesting one.
Its a nice intro to philosophical thinking
One of the best courses I've taken. Get into the Professor's precept, it makes it a lot more interesting.
Personally this was not my favorite class, but if you like ancient philosophy you will like it. It's not a huge amount of work.
Strikes a rare balance of fascinating subject matter and relatively light workload.
Take it
Take it!

Take it. The lectures are pretty good and Prof. Lorenz is also a great preceptor. The readings are manageable and so are the essay assignments. There are definitely harder ways to fulfill the EC requirement, so do yourself a favor.
Take this class!  In fact, take any class taught by Professor Lorenz!  You won't find a professor more committed to the learning and academic success of his students!
Take this course.
