This class was a great EC. If you go to lecture and listen the readings are not necessary. While it seems like a lot of writing it really is not and you will thank yourself when it comes finals period and you have only a short take home essay.
This course is a great PDF course because you can just enjoy the lectures without being consistently frustrated with the organizational issues.
This is a great class for anyone interested in philosophy.  Professor Lorenz is a good lecturer, and the material is both interesting and useful since Plato and Aristotle are referenced constantly.
To keep up with the readings and take a lot of notes both before and during class in order to keep all of the details straight.
take the class, it is not overly difficult and Professor Lorenz makes it interesting.
descrip: This course discusses the ideas and arguments of major ancient Greek philosophers and thereby introduces students to the history and continued relevance of the first centuries of western philosophy. Topics include the rise of cosmological speculation, the beginnings of philosophical ethics, Plato's moral theory and epistemology, Aristotle's philosophy of nature, metaphysics and ethics. The course ends with a survey of philosophical activity in the Hellenistic period.

title: Information Signals
reviews: A lot of stuff taught (Fourier, delta function) will be used in Physics and Maths as well. It is a good course overall.
A very fun course! Shouldn't be too challenging for anyone with a technical background.
Don't take it unless you have to and don't expect to get out of lab at the prescribed time.
Don't take it with Cuff. The labs and problem sets are long and painful. Unless you're PDFing, it's going to be too stressful.
Don't take the course unless you are an ELE major or unless many changes are made to it. If you have to take it, start your work early, and try to go to the (very few) office hours available.
Don't take this course unless you know you are an ELE major! It's very hard and takes up a lot of time.

Don't take this course. The math is extremely hard, the labs are unnecessarily long and totally uninstructive and the p-sets take a long time to complete. If you are taking it (for ELE requirements or something else), then be prepared to put in a lot of time to really understand the material.
ELE201 is a good course to take even if you're not an ELE major. The material is interesting, it is not too much work, and Professor Cuff is an amazing lecturer.
Essentially a math course with an engineering focus. The material is very interesting, but be prepared to work if you haven't had diff eq/matlab experience.
Expect a hard course and expect a lot of self teaching, especially if Professor Cuff is the teacher. Use online courses at Stanford and MIT to help teach you the material.
Go to as many office hours as you can and work with people. This class is no longer as easy as it used to be!
Great course but be warned, the labs and problem sets take a very long time.
I learned a lot, but unless you make the effort to work with other people, don't take it unless you have to.
If they manage to fix up the labs, I would definitely recommend it. Otherwise, if you're not an ELE major, be wary about how much time in the lab you'll end up spending.
If you like easy, applied math, then take the course. If you hate frustration and terrible debugging experiences, don't. Also the graders actually have no idea about the material or how to grade it.
If you're not ELE, take this course if you're interested in information theory, control theory, or how to analyze signals in the frequency domain.

It started bad but with time it got better. IF you see any negative reviews then that's because at the beginning things were hectic with this course being re-structured.
It is not as easy as it used to be but you learn A LOT. GO FOURIER!!
Pretty good class but also challenging
Start the problem sets and labs early as they often take much longer than you think. Do outside reading too besides just the lectures.
Take it if and only if you're an electrical engineer or a computer scientist.
Take it if you are interested in ELE or COS (it is related). Also, the Fourier Transform is generally useful. It came up in my Linear Algebra and Physics: EM courses.
Take it only if you are an ELE major, not otherwise.
Take it only if you're interested in this material. I wasn't particularly interested, but some of my colleagues who were claimed to enjoy this course much more than I did.
Take it.

Take this course. Don't worry that our labs were too long...I'm sure they'll fix that for next year. The department really cares about these things and want us to be happy. The material is very interesting, though it really helps to have a bit of linear algebra to understand things.

The rigor of this course makes it suitable for those of the more quantitative mindset (although qualitative understanding helps tremendously for intuition). The entire course uses the concepts learned in the beginning of the year, so do not dismiss any questions or confusions you have about the first few weeks; they will come back to haunt you. It is a fascinating course that reveals a lot about modern technology, but with that comes a heavy load of difficulty.

This course is a great introduction to signals and real-world systems, and how to handle them mathematically.  But if you're looking for a course to teach you how to use Matlab, even though you do code in Matlab, this might not be the best course to take, because you really have to learn it on your own.
This course seems like more of a math class than an electrical engineering course.  It also has quite a steep curve, and requires a significant time commitment.

This is a hard course, unless you're a math whiz. If you're an ELE major, you don't really have a choice. If you're COS, like me, you'll get some experience with MatLab, but the topics themselves aren't that closely related to hardware.

This was Paul Cuff's first time teaching ELE 201 and it shows.  He was a decent lecturer, but the class wasn't too well organized, labs were too long, it was hard to gt help, etc.  Try and wait to take it with Kulkarni.

This was a very difficult, but rewarding class. Yes, problem sets and challenging and long. Yes, some labs will take a very long time to complete and sometimes focus on MATLAB programming instead of the concepts of the course. But I emerged from this course with a strong understanding of signals and systems. This was some of the most interesting material I've seen while at Princeton, and is vastly applicable to many different domains. I would recommend this course, but be prepared to work hard. I also found that Professor Cuff was not the best lecturer--check out Brad Osgood's Fourier Transform lectures from Stanford and Oppenheim's Signals and Systems lectures from MIT. You might also find Oppenheim's text helpful, as well as the Schaum's Outlines text on Signals and Systems.
This will eat a lot of your time. In reality, you need a decent grasp of Matlab, and be prepared to struggle with the calculus. Especially if you're a freshman.
You learn about the fourier transform. It's interesting stuff, class is pretty disorganized though.
prereqs: The prerequisite for this course is knowledge of elementary calculus..
descrip: Signals that carry information play a central role in technology and engineering---ranging from sound and images to MRI, communication, radar, and robotic control. This course teaches mathematical tools to analyze, manipulate, dissect, and preserve information signals. For example, many continuous signals can be perfectly represented through sampling (Nyquist theorem), which leads to digital signals. A major focus of the course is the Fourier transform. We also study linear time-invariant systems, modulation, quantization, and stability (Laplace transform and z-transform). Lab design projects in Matlab include a "Shazam" music ID system.

title: Intermediate Korean II
reviews: It's a natural followup to KOR105 in every way.
It's time consuming but rewarding. Especially if you take it with friends!
Just do it.
Know the extra grammar points he teaches that aren't in the textbook--they show up on the quizzes!
Take it if you want to continue learning Korean!
Take this class!
The Korean department is the best department at Princeton.

There's a lot of what might be called busy work, but it's pretty easy. On the other hand, deciding not to do it can make things pretty challenging, because at the end of the day, knowing the vocab and grammar points is what gets you your grade. All around solid class though, not too stressful.
prereqs: KOR 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 105. Continued development of four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) in Korean. Complex grammatical structures and irregularities will be taught while the basics are reviewed. Idiomatic expressions will be introduced; journals will be kept for writing practice.

title: Intermediate Syriac
descrip: Study of selected passages from various genres of Syriac literature. Knowledge of Syriac is required.

title: Topics in Science, Technology and Environmental Policy - Global Environmental Governance
descrip: Examines intl law & governance in the context of environmental problems. Considers the need for regulation under conditions of scientific uncertainty in issues such as climate change, bovine growth hormones, GMOs, fisheries management, biodiversity conservation, ozone depletion. Explores the efficacy of diverse regulatory approaches, mechanisms for scientific advice to policymakers & participation by business firms, NGOs. Considers intersections between environmental regulation (both domestic and international) with trade, investment, & multilateral development, aid programs.

title: Ancient Greek: An Intensive Introduction
reviews:
I think turbo greek is difficult for students with experience in Latin or another highly inflected language already, but almost too difficult to get full use out of for anyone else. I would recommend the regular two-semester Greek for a good foundation. When it comes to Greek, you really really do want a good foundation. 

The question is, do you want to build your beautiful house on quicksand or solid earth..?
I would advise this course to other students, but warn them that it is almost certainly the most demanding course I have taken at Princeton.
Take 101 and 102 instead, since this class is a bit much.
This class will take you on a ride for your life. Buckle up.
This course is very very hard, so know what you're getting into.
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to Greek grammar. It covers in one semester material usually done in the standard two-semester introductory sequence (CLG 101/102). Students who complete this course and then take CLG 105 in the fall will be able to complete the usual three semesters' sequence in two and can fulfill the language requirement by taking only one additional course, typically CLG 108. This course aims at providing a reading knowledge of Classical Greek, quickly.

title: Muslim South Asia
descrip: Religious, cultural, and political developments in South Asia, home to nearly a third of the world's Muslim population, have long exerted considerable influence on the greater Muslim world. This seminar is concerned with religio-political thought and movements in Muslim South Asia from the 18th century to the present. Topics include: Sufism; the impact of colonialism on Islamic thought and institutions; evolving Islamist trends from late colonial times to the present; and debates on Islamic law and the position of women in India and Pakistan.

title: Seminar in Observational Astrophysics - Redshift Survey
reviews: As an undergraduate, you should absolutely take this class if you have any interest in astrophysics. It's engaging and extremely small time commitment. 1.5 hours a week, and you only have one project - to give one presentation! Do it early, so you're done with work for the semester!
Ask how long the talk should be if you're not sure. Make every effort to time yourself appropriately.
Excellent course. Highly recommended.
It is worth to take the course.
Make sure your talk is pedagogical-- your audience knows about as much about your topic as you did when you started preparing. Walk us through it!
Take it if you're interesting in the subject matter!
The seminar was very useful, I definitely recommend it, specially for students interested in redshift surveys and galaxy evolution.
descrip: Students will prepare and deliver presentations on topics in observational cosmology, and critique and discuss each other's work.

title: Lighting Design
reviews: Definitely a huge learning curve if you're not a visual person or well-versed in theater tech - take initiative to figure some of that out on your own. Jane's very open to helping you out but it is too easy to sit back in this class and let the experts handle everything.

Definitely worth it if you are looking for something very different and for an LA. If you are a theatre certificate looking for classes in the department, it'd be a great shame if you missed out on Jane's awesomeness and this aspect of theatre.
If you have the opportunity to take this, don't think twice - just sign up.  Fun, light on time commitment, and incredibly well taught.
TAKE IT! If you're at all interested in theatre, TAKE IT. If you need an LA, TAKE IT. If you are a person, TAKE IT.
Take it no matter what! You won't regret it!
Take it! This class in really fun but also practical! Jane is super friendly and sets a really nice pace for the class. You learn everything you would need to do lighting for shows or performances.
prereqs: This course is by Open Enrollment -- please enroll through SCORE directly..
descrip: An introduction to the art and craft of lighting design for the stage and an exploration of light as a medium for expression. Students will develop an ability to observe lighting in the world and on the stage; to learn to make lighting choices based on text, space, research, and their own responses; to practice being creative, responsive and communicative under pressure and in company; to prepare well to create under pressure using the designer's visual toolbox; and to play well with others-working creatively and communicating with directors, writers, performers, fellow designers, the crew and others.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: Absolutely do not take this class if Professor Monge is teaching it.  It is not difficult but anyone with an actual desire to learn about human evolution will be extremely disappointed.
Do not take. It's easy in terms of the amount of work but it's not graded as easily
Do the readings, they are engaging.

Human Evolution is a fascinating subject, but this course was poorly organized. If you want to do well, you'll need to have taken other Evolution classes in the past. Additionally, you'll need to teach yourself almost all of the material by doing the readings/your own research, since lectures and precepts tend to be confusing.

I think it is a good EC and Janet Monge has some crazy stories, she has done a lot with her life and has really cool personal stories that she spends a lot of time talking about which is interesting, but at times can become frustrating. I think that if you havent taken a biology course at princeton this would be a relatively easy one.

I would recommend taking this class, but with someone other than Monge as the lecturer. The information this class covers is great to understand, however she was often a little misguided in lectures and we had to cram the most interesting topics into the final week of class. There is very little required work for this class, but the tests are graded pretty harshly.
I would say take this class!
If you don't mind disorganization, teaching yourself, and getting no guidance on assignments/exams, go for it. If you do, find another class.
If you even have a passing interest in human evolution, take this class!
It's a lot of work for a PDF class.
It's a pretty easy class to PDF, but if you actually want to learn something, then there are many better classes you can take.
Monge is crazy.  in a good and bad sort of way but is an easy B but a hard A.
Only if you want to be very diligent about paying attention b/c she puts you to sleep.
Prof. Monge is amazing -- take it for her.  She has a sense of humor (in addition to her funny manner about her) -- you'll be laughing in lecture, which is so refreshing!
Subject matter is somewhat interesting in the beginning but gets pretty boring towards the end
Take if you want a class to blow off or a very easy PDF class
Take it if you need an EC - pretty low course work, especially if you PDF. Hard to actually get a good grade though.
Take it.
Take it.  Very interesting.
Take this class
Take this class if you have a broad interest in human evolution.

Take this course if you know very little about evolution and want to learn about it through the lens of human evolution. Otherwise if you already know a lot about evolution choose a more challenging class.
There are better EMs. If you must take it, this is a rather interesting course, but do all the readings if you want to do well on the tests.
This class requires little effort.  If you go to class/precept, the assignments are reasonable and pretty predictable.
Very general overview of the subject, do not expect to learn very much
good EEB class
good class
lectures were not worth going to, i only took it for an EC, but from what i've heard, it seems like it was only worth it with alan mann
listen up in lectures.
no
only take if you want an easy EC
sure its a good EC
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications.

title: Introductory Photography
reviews: Be prepared for the time commitment. If you've never taken a photography class before, be ready to swallow your pride and buckle down to get good at it. It's more difficult than one expects, but if you actually care about learning photography you will grow in ways that you might not have imagined or expected.

Be prepared to put in more work than you expect. It can be difficult to find the meeting point of what is good photography to you and what is good photography for the professor, but producing work, in general, is very rewarding. If photography interests you at all, take this course.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time in the darkroom
Don't procrastinate. Enjoy and take pride in your work.
Get ready for the time to put into this class, but it's very rewarding!
Great class :D
If you like the idea of spending a lot of time in the darkroom developing film photography then take this course
It is a huge time commitment so do not take this as a fifth or sixth class.  Prioritize this as one of your core classes.
Its a good course, not very hard, you will learn about cameras and get new artistic perspective into the world of photography.
Make sure to keep up with the term projects because although it is a fun class it is also very time consuming.
Prepare to make multiple trips to print your photos, as the printer frequently runs out of paper.

Take it if you're interested! One of my favorite classes. Will eat up all of your weekends and probably more, so make sure you're willing to do that. Also note which precept you sign up for. For 2013 spring there were 2 B&W film precepts and 1 digital, not indicated on SCORE. Deana is definitely film and definitely awesome. If you are taking one of the B&W film precepts, it will be expensive ($50-100 plus the cost of a camera, either borrow one or it's around $100 to buy) but worth it. You will come away with so much knowledge and some really nice prints.
Take it! Printing is very time consuming but it was one of the best classes I took this semester.

Take this course. But be aware: it takes so much time to do but is so rewarding. Probably not advisable as a 5th class. Not a course you can slack in, so I wouldn't call it easy. But still so so great!
Talk to your teachers to understand what they want because the class is very subjective depending on what teacher you have.  Also make sure to stay ahead on your work or else it will build.
This course is (by nature) time-consuming.  The results are worth it but only take it if you are willing to make the time-commitment

This is a VERY time consuming course. I spent at least 10 hours every week (including the 3hr class) for this course. We had to shoot a certain number of rolls of film, then develop these films, make contact sheets, and make prints. It takes a lot of time, but it was definitely a lot of fun doing everything by hand and ultimately feeling proud about it.

Unless you have an ample amount of time in your schedule, I recommend against taking this course, for the simple fact that you will spend countless hours completing assignments in the Lewis Center (which is relatively far away from campus).
Working in the dark room is a lot of work - this is not an "easy" class!
You will need to put in a lot of time outside of class to print photos.
please take it
take this course if you are at all interested in gaining a deeper understanding of the visual arts (not just photography).
descrip: An introduction to the processes of photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of light-sensitive material, camera, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of the medium in relation to both student work and the work of guest photographers.

title: Water Quality Modeling and Analysis
reviews: By reading the book the class topics become very interesting.
If it is a reading course you will only really get out of the course what you put into it - do the readings consistently.
descrip: The course explores construction and solution of water-quality models for transport and transformation of pollutants in surface runoff, streams, lakes, estuaries, and groundwaters; and the basic principles of water quality modeling. It reviews existing models and the utility and appropriateness of various modeling techniques for analysis and prediction.

title: Construction and Interpretation
reviews: I enjoyed working with Professor Guy Nordenson and would suggest that other students work with him if afforded the opportunity, though this particular course was not necessarily stimulating. I would suggest that students if enrolled in this particular course be prepared to lend fearlessly and critically to course discussions, without hesitation.
I think that the subject matter of the course changes annually, so be sure to review the syllabus and course summary.  If it is appealing, take the course: Guy is very engaging.
bring your own agenda
descrip: This seminar will examine the relation of construction, structure and building services to the production of meaning through a series of case studies of buildings and bridges and as well as general surveys of the work of specific engineers and architects.

title: Rocket and Air-Breathing Propulsion Technology
reviews: An enjoyable course if you are willing to read the notes carefully. Be prepared for the exams to be much more comprehensive than homeworks.
Keep up with the material and ask questions if something is unclear.
Stay current with the material- there is a good amount of material for review for the midterm/final.
Take it.  It's rocket science.  Also, I highly recommend watching the "Uchuu Kyoudai" anime along with the course.  It gives valuable additional insight into JAXA.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222.
descrip: The study of principles, flight envelopes, and engine designs of rocket and ram/scramjet propulsion systems. Topics include jet propulsion theory, space mission maneuver, combustion control, and system components of chemical and non-chemical rockets (nuclear and electrical propulsion), gas turbine, ramjet, and scramjet engines. Characteristics, optimal flight envelopes, and technical challenges of combined propulsion systems will be analyzed.

title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Dissertation Seminar
descrip: This seminar welcomes prospectus and dissertation writers. At our first meeting, we'll establish a weekly schedule for pre-circulating work; at each subsequent meeting, we'll offer feedback on prospectuses, chapters, and articles.

title: East Central Europe in the 20th Century: History, Politics and Culture
descrip: In this course we will examine history, politics, and culture of East Central Europe after World War I. We will study a variety of institutions and cultural trends using narrative history, as well as literary essays and political manifestos.

title: Neuroscience of Being Human, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Race, Drugs, and Drug Policy in America
reviews: A great course for general interest in the history of drugs and drug policy.
A lot of sometimes uncessary work, but very interesting material and engaging lecturer
Be prepared to go to every lecture and do all the readings!
Definitely take it! Really interesting stuff! Also the final was pretty easy so dont worry about it! Annoying that there was also a term paper.

Difficult class, lots of readings, but very enjoyable.  One of my favorite classes that I have taken.  Strongly recommend, especially as a PDF because lecture is engaging and material is interesting, but there is a lot of reading.
Don't take this course unless you are prepared to do 300   pages of reading per week. The lectures are also overwhelming.
Fascinating material, great professor. Aim to take a course with Prof. Wailoo during your time at Princeton.
Good course.  Don't expect to sleep through it though.  Not a bad choice for PDF but also possible to do very well in it.
Great course! Really interesting lectures and readings. Take it!
I would advise another student to keep up with the readings because it allows you to contribute during precept and makes preparation for the exam a little bit easier!
I would advise them to take this course because it is fascinating, but be prepared to do a large amount of reading and a good amount of effort outside of the classroom.

I would definitely consider taking this course, however if you haven't got a lot of experience with writing history papers then maybe consider PDFing just because a lot of the grade is dependent on the papers and although the first is marked quite leniently, the second isn't.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the intersection between science, policy, and history.
Lots and lots of reading, and the papers are a bit tricky to write. Interesting material but a tougher course than expected.
Make sure to ask your preceptor for advice when writing your papers.
Reading intensive. Writing intensive at some points. My recommendation: do NOT take with another reading/ writing intensive course.

Skim the readings, except for the main one for the week. Try to memorize some of the material as you go, because not having a midterm means if you don't study until the final, you'll have a ton of information to go through at the end of the semester. Be original on the papers!

Take if you want an interesting course. Requires a lot of work but you don't always have to do all the readings (just skim), and make sure you write the papers on something that doesn't overlap with the material.
Take it!  It's a lot of reading but you'll learn a lot!!

Take the class and be able to analyze the material while still seeing the "big themes"--this might be easier toward the end of the class. The material isn't hard; it's fascinating and there is a lot to cover. Keep up with the major readings!
Take this class! This course is life-changing!
Take this class, do most of the reading, and spend a lot of time on papers. The most important thing is to have an original thesis for those papers.
Take this class.
Take this class. Easily the most interesting class that I have taken at Princeton.

Take this course! It is overall fascinating - great lectures, interesting readings, engaging precept discussions. This is the kind of material that you will want to talk about with friends and family outside of the course.
Take this course! Literally one of my favourite classes I've ever taken at Princeton! Professor Wailoo is amazing and his lectures are consistently wonderful. Take it!!
Take this course!!! If you're interested in race, policy, social inequality, etc... this class is really amazing.
Take this course, get Professor Wailoo as your preceptor and go to his office hours to ask him what he expects of his papers.
The readings will be tough to manage but the course is interesting.

There is too much work and too much dysfunction for me to recommend this course. If you plan to take this course, beware: lectures last 10 minutes over each time. At the end of EACH lecture you're expected to write a short response to a question on the material, before you can leave. The readings are brutal, and the amount of material you're expected to memorize is ridiculous. There are two papers, a 7pg and 17pg, and then an EXTENSIVE final exam. The lectures are chaotic and disorganized and I had trouble following Wailoo half the time. He switches between topics at a rapid pace and while I understand some of the points he conveyed (drugs are determined by social constructs, I GET IT okay), I still don't know half of the history of these drugs. Despite this, Wailoo is obviously passionate about the material, and this class has potential, it just needs some key changes!
This course will exercise your analyticall skills, which is good
This is the best course I have ever taken at Princeton.
Too much reading but interesting. The assignments are not that hard to get through, but seriously get ready to read a ton.
Very interesting, engaging, and very well prepared.  Be prepared to work though.
Wailoo is a wonderful lecturer. Try to read all the books over break or during down time, because they're really useful. If Dov is a preceptor, GET HIM!
You have to turn in little responses at the end of each lecture, and the quality of presentation is garbage, but otherwise it is a very intriguing class. Recommend.
You might not find the professor that engaging, but he does a very good job of choosing readings that will completely change the way you understand drugs and drug policy. Take it.

mayyyybee pdf it, don't take it for a grade under any circumstances. but really if you can tell yourself "a drug was invented, people thought it was great, uh oh---addiction and racism! now this drug is awful" then i think you understand the entire scope of this course.
take this class! Really interesting history class; Wailoo is a great lecturer and organizes this course really well; workload really pick up toward the end of the semester
very interesting material, lectures were good, dov grohsgal is a great preceptor
descrip: From "Chinese opium" to Oxycontin, and from cocaine and "crack" to BiDil, drug controversies reflect enduring debates about the role of medicine, the law, the policing of ethnic identity, and racial difference. This course explores the history of controversial substances (prescription medicines, over-the-counter products, black market substances, psychoactive drugs), and how, from cigarettes to alcohol and opium, they become vehicles for heated debates over immigration, identity, cultural and biological difference, criminal character, the line between legality and illegality, and the boundaries of the normal and the pathological.

title: Biological Physics
reviews: An excellent course which covers the most important new research topics in biophysics.

If you are looking to gain a broad understanding of the many interesting biophysical topics that are being researched, take this course! Not only will you gain a broad perspective, you will also get to delve into biophysics papers and discuss the material with the students and the professor. Prof. Shaevitz is a biophysics genius and can probably answer most, if not all, of your questions.
Take it! It's a great discussion class, the papers are interesting, and it isn't too much work.
Take it. Professor Shaevitz is a bro.

This course you should take it if you love discussing research papers, and it is very educational no matter whether your background is more geared towards physics or biology. Please be aware that readings will deal with biological concepts almost as much as physics, despite this course designated as a physics elective. However, Professor Shaevitz will look towards having you exploit your own background and not a generic one. I strongly recommend the course!

This is a great class that will teach you how to read original research papers present some of the most exciting aspects of biophysics, which is a lot more diverse than I would have thought. The seminar setting also offered me a glimpse into how a science classes would be like if they would have a precept. One of my favorite classes.
Yes!!!
prereqs: Introductory Physics (PHY 103/104, PHY 105/106, ISC 231-234).
descrip: Biological Physics is one of the fastest growing areas of physics. This course focuses on both experimental and theoretical physics approaches to understanding biological molecules, cells, and tissues. We will start with an overview of the forces present within a cell that govern the activity of enzymes and the motion of molecular motors and the cytoskeleton. We then move on to discuss physical processes on the cellular level that give rise to motility, tissue development and differentiation. Emphasis will be placed on both techniques and scientific concepts. Classes will be a combination of lectures and student presentations.

title: From the Arabian Nights to the Prince of Persia: Orientalism in Literature and Film
descrip: See website

title: Ethics and Public Health
reviews: A really engaging course. Professor Schwartz is incredibly approachable and invested. Reading load is completely reasonable, seminars are engaging. Just please be willing to talk in class - it makes it so much more valuable for both you and your classmates.
Do the readings otherwise you're wasting your time. Speak up in class or you'll be bored. Start the papers early, and you'll do great.

Easily one of my 3 favorite classes at Princeton - highly, highly recommend!

Seems very relevant to people with a wide range of future plans: law school, med school, policy jobs, pharma, general research all come into play!  Even someone with just a passing interest would be well rewarded by taking this course!

Great class! The readings almost always pertain to relevant and interesting topics.  Conversation was a bit dull at times but it's understandable.  It helped in a busy schedule when it was okay that you didn't do all of the readings, because looking at 1 or 2 in depth gave you a good understanding of the topic.  That said it was always better if you did read.  Take it!
I would definitely recommend that other students take this course.
I would recommend taking this course if you are interested in ethics and health policy. Papers are especially fun to write.
If you get a chance you should take this course.
Keep up on the readings and try to participate as much as you can.

Take it! Professor Schwartz is great and the course is really fun and interesting. It focuses a lot on public health issues in the US, which is interesting and different from many other GHP-related courses
This is a good course for people interesting in learning more about public health.

This was a great course. If you're at all interested in the topics of public health or the ethics of public health, take it. While the workload isn't too demanding, the material is interesting and thought-provoking. Professor Schwartz is a fair grader and is willing to work closely with students.
descrip: This course will examine issues at the intersection of ethics, policy, and public health, paying particular attention to the centuries-long tension between individual rights and the common good. Ethical arguments are increasingly visible in public health activities in the United States and worldwide, demonstrating the continued relevance of long-standing debates over the proper role of government in promoting the health of individuals and communities. The course will explore ethical, historical, and policy aspects of public health activities, and it will consider the relationship between public health ethics and bioethics.

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Economics of Health and Health Care
reviews: Although the course as a whole was somewhat disorganized, I feel that it was still worth taking.

As a sophomore, I came into this course as an Econ major and came out of it no longer being an Econ major. If you're really interested about health care then you should take it, but otherwise stay away, even if Professor Reinhardt is a good lecturer.
Definitely take this class if you are interested in health care in any way.
Don't read the textbook

Don't take it. I attended 100% of lectures and feel like I am leaving the course with no greater understanding of health care, econ, or the economics of health care than when I entered.  Uwe can be funny, but thats not worth struggling through painfully boring lectures in which he rambles on pointless tangents and teaches nothing.
Exams are hard. Don't be fooled by the lectures.
Generally very fun and informative. P/D/F it if you don't have a strong ECO background though. Exams depend on your having background knowledge of topics not discussed in class.
Highly recommend the course. Is not very difficult, and you learn a lot about healthcare. Reinhardt is funny and engaging.
I would definitely suggest that a student take this course. Reinhardt is an amazing and funny lecturer, and making the effort to pay attention in lecture is well worth it.

If Uwe's teaching this course, TAKE IT!!!!!! He has an incredibly deep and clear understanding of healthcare systems, from a large macro system persepctive to small hospital-level (or even doctor-level) details. Seriously, Uwe is the man. He's also hilarious. And this class isn't too hard. Definitely not very mathematical.

If you're an econ major, this will be a very easy course. If you want to learn anything you will have to do all the readings and stay on top of the material. It's easy to slack off, because the material isn't challenging.

If you're interested in the subject, you'll like it. Though the lectures can be a drain because although he tries to organize it, Prof. Reinhardt sometimes sits and rants the whole time. Some of it is good, but it can get tedious Monday after lunch.
It covers a very important topic in economics and I would take it.
It is very difficult, but necessary to learn about the Affordable Care Act and future of healthcare.

It's not your traditional course at Princeton--it's disorganized and fairly easy--but Uwe Reinhardt is fantastic and has done pretty much everything there is to do in the field of health economics and health policy so you will learn a ton.
Make sure to understand microeconomic concepts and focus on the problem sets

Make sure you're interested in healthcare econ. Reinhardt knows a lot of his stuff and it's cool to take a class with him, but he's also a bit random and sometimes distracted. Jo is a really good preceptor!
Not a terrible departmental.
Not many assignments and not a lot of work. Plus Prof Reinhardt is fantastic and the preceptors are great.
Only take this if you're already interested in health care, not if you want a survey class on it.
Reinhardt is a great economist, but an absolutely horrific teacher
Stay on top of readings.  Go to precepts.  Do psets early.

Take if you think you'll be involved in healthcare at all. The lessons learned here will benefit you more than any orgo class in terms of practicality (unless of course you plan to do medical research). Reinhardt's lecturing style isn't for everyone, but if you find that it works for you, I doubt you'll have a more enjoyable econ experience.
Take it for Prof Reinhardt, who talks sometimes less as an academic economist and more as an solid speaker of values and policy debates at a senate hearing
Take it if you are genuinely interested in health econ. Otherwise, probably not worth it.
Take it!
Take it, it is not a lot of work, and you will learn a lot about the healthcare system, which is definitely important.
Take this class if you are an economics major or just have an interest in health care! The lectures are hit or miss: either great or full of non-sequitirs...
Take this course if you're interested in the subject. Reinhardt's lectures are very entertaining, and the assignments aren't challenging.
Talk to other students personally to see if this matches your interests and skill set!
The final exam ended up being extremely math-heavy, which was not the impression given by the rest of the class.

The material is interesting and Professor Reinhardt makes funny comments but the lectures were very disorganized. Exams seemed to test our knowledge of things that had not really been covered in lecture or precept.
This course is kind of unorganized. During lectures he goes on a lot of tangents. I felt like it had a lot of potential, but I kind of got lost near the end.
This course really opened my eyes to the way the US health system works. I would definitely take the class over again if I could.
Trying to understand what was expected of us was incredibly stressful. Hardest final I've had to study for here because so much material.
Unless the structure of the class is changed, don't take it. Reinhardt is a great speaker and interesting lecturer, though maybe not in the context of the course lectures.
attend lecture!
incredibly interested and uwe is fun lecturer- not too hard to do well
take this!
prereqs: ECO 100 or equivalent..
descrip: This course explores aspects of health systems primarily through the prism of micro-economic theory and analysis. It will be structured around a well-known textbook on the subject. Students successfully completing the course should have a better understanding of this complex system which now absorbs 17% of GDP and will soon claim a fifth.

title: Modern Dance: Beginning/Intermediate Technique and Choreography
reviews: Don't be turned off by some of the awkward things you are asked to do in the technique classes. It gets less awkward over time and also the choreography/composition classes are worth it.
It is hard if you have little dance background, but its PDF only so if you are interested don't be scared off.

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
if you are just starting out with dance and are serious about improving as much as you can, TAKE THIS CLASS
Take it, it's fun :)
Take this class! It?s fun, minimally stressful, a good workout, and helps you learn about yourself as well as meet awesome people.
Take!
come in with an open mind because modern dance is just plain weird.
prereqs: DAN 219, equivalent previous training, or instructor's permission. Interview information: there is no application for this course. In order to assure correct placement, interested students should contact Professor Lazier (rlazier@) by email to schedule an interview during the time period of November 12-21, 2012..
descrip: Dance technique and choreography for beginning and intermediate levels. Technique class will start with awareness and coordination exercises designed to organize the body and prepare for more technical movement. Class will build in physical intensity culminating in phrasework that is vigorous and challenging. In choreography, students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's impact and content.

title: Great Moments in Computing
reviews: Do the readings early, explain your thinking in the written responses as much as you can, and participate in class. Don't be afraid to say you don't understand something.
If you want a better idea of where our field comes from, take the course!
Take it. The grad students are great and discussion is fun.
Take this class!

The course provides a great survey of the history of computer science. There was a distinct focus on computer architecture, but most areas were covered. At the end you have the chance to write an essay arguing why some other paper should have been included. We also has the option to write an application that related to one of the readings instead of the essay.

This course is a great way to understand how the field of computer science advanced to where it is today.  We truly cover a ton of "great moments" such as the foundations of cryptography, the halting problem, and many early computer architectures.  Sometimes the readings were a bit dense.  They definitely took more time than I expected, but that might be because of my lack of experience with computer architecture.  Overall awesome class, I highly recommend taking it!

This course is great for undergrads, especially ones interested in graduate school, in learning more of the history of computer science, or getting better at reading papers.  Discussion and then a final project.
Definitely take it - it's been one of my favorite courses at Princeton!
This course is really interesting and you learn a lot about a variety of areas of computer science. You should take it!
Wonderful and interesting course, a definitely course to take if you can.
prereqs: COS 217 and 226 or equivalent. Undergrads: Juniors and seniors only.
descrip: Course covers pivotal developments in computing, including hardware, software, and theory. Material will be covered by reading seminal papers, patents, and descriptions of highly-influential architectures. Course emphasizes a deep understanding of the discoveries and inventions that brought computer systems to where they are today, and class is discussion-oriented. Final project or paper required. Graduate students and advanced undergraduates from ELE, COS, and related fields welcome.

title: Biotechnology
reviews: Get ready to read a lot of papers! But very interesting ones at that.
Grading is somewhat arbitrary, and although the course material was interesting, the class wasn't really that interesting.  I was somewhat disappointed by this course.

I highly recommend this class! If you are a senior though, know that you will be working on your thesis at the same time you will have to present a paper for the class. Luckily the presentations are fairly low pressure, but when you are already under so much stress it does add up.

It is very interesting. Make sure you participate if you want to get a good grade. Attendance is also graded so make sure you show up. Many seniors took this course PDF because it is hard to get an A in the sense that you have to make sure that you do the readings every single week if you want to get a good grade. (which is hard to do while thesising). I think the subject matter is very important for any biologist to learn.

It's fine. It really depends on who the other students in the class are, since having lots of science background and lab experience and such will put you at a significant advantage in the course. There are definitely better departmentals to take.
Make sure you keep up with the readings and participate in class
Take it.
Take it. Be friends with Flint.

You should definitely consider taking this course for its interesting subject material, as Flint is a great professor who knows her stuff. As a molecular biology course, the biotechnology covered is generally from a molecular perspective but does dabble in the social/ethical perspectives of the technology.
a great class
take it!

take this course! professor flint is very nice and extraordinarily knowledgeable about various aspects of biotech (both the science and the policy). she provides good insight to what's happening in the field, and the course in general gives you a good appreciation for the rapid progress made in biotech.
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345, or permission of the Instructor.
descrip: This course will consider the principles, development, outcomes and future directions of therapeutic applications of biotechnology, with particular emphasis on the interplay between basic research and clinical experience. Topics to be discussed include production of hormones and other therapeutic proteins, gene therapy, oncolytic viruses, and stem cells. Reading will be from the primary literature.

title: Energy Storage Systems
prereqs: MAE 221 or Equivalent, Freshman Physics, Freshman Chemistry, Knowlege of ODE/PDE.
descrip: This is a survey course on energy storage systems with a focus on electrochemical energy storage. Fundamentals of thermodynamics will be reviewed and fundamentals of electrochemistry introduced. These fundamentals will then be applied to devices such as batteries, flywheels and compressed air storage. Device optimization with respect to energy density, power density, cycle life and capital cost will be considered.

title: Introduction to Media Theory
reviews: Came into it not knowing what Media Theory was--really interesting class if you can handle a fairly esoteric liberal arts class.  Professor Levin is also fantastic

Definitely take the course. I don't think I have had another professor that committed to making sure you understand the material and who always tries to find time for you even though he is extremely busy.
Take it
Take it!
Take it, unless you're an anti-modernist!
Take this class with Levin! There's a lot of theoretical readings but during class you'll get the chance to bring up lots of examples. Plus, he's a fascinating person to spend time around.
You absolutely have to take this course. I have never taken a better one at Princeton.
descrip: Through careful readings of a wide range of media theoretical texts from the late 19th to early 21st century, this seminar will trace the development of critical reflection on technologies and media ranging from the printing press to photography, from gramophones to radio technologies, from pre-cinematic optical devices to film and television, and from telephony and typewriters to cyberspace. Topics include the relationship between representation and technology, the historicity of perception, the interplay of aesthetics, technology and politics, and the transformation of notions of imagination, literacy, communication, reality and truth.

title: Molecular Biology of Eukaryotes
descrip: Discussion of gene structure and organization, chromatin and chromosome structures, mechanisms of replication, gene expression and regulation in eukaryotic cells. Emphasis will be placed on unique features of eukaryotic systems with examples from higher and lower eukaryotes.

title: Advanced Painting
reviews: I highly highly recommend taking this course. Favorite course at Princeton thus far! Changed me as an artist.
It's an incredibly unique class, so take it if you get the opportunity. It'll be a great experience. It will take a lot of time but it will totally pay off. Make sure you make the most of it.
Take it take it take it! If you're down for long hours painting and the most interesting subjects you can find, this is the best class out there.
prereqs: VIS 203, 204 or instructor permission..
descrip: This course is designed for students who are serious about painting and want to delve deeper into the question of "what" to paint. Through greater attention to the world outside the studio, this course will uncover subjects that correspond to each student's developing language with painting and emphasize direct engagement with the physical and metaphysical environment: objects, landscapes, atmospheres, emotions, or the passing of time. Both independent work and assignments will involve hands-on material instruction (preparing surfaces, color mixing, gestural techniques) as well as the option to paint outside the classroom.

title: The World in Bandes Dessinees
prereqs: FRE 207, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course explores representations of the World and History in major bandes dessinees (or graphic novels) published in French from the 1930s to the present, and produced by authors of various backgrounds (French, Belgian, Italian, Jewish, Iranian). Informed by theoretical readings, discussions will address key aesthetical, political, and ethical issues, including Exoticism, Orientalism, (Post)colonialism, national and individual identity, as well as the theory of reception, to critically assess the fluctuations of these visions between fantasy and testimony.

title: African-American Literature - A Sound Theory of Blackness: African American Literature & Music
descrip: An exploration of sonic theory and the African American literary tradition from the 19th century through the millennium with special emphasis placed on major debates in jazz studies and a critical (re)examination of blues ideologies, as well as the politics and poetics of R&B and soul, funk, Afrofuturism, punk, pop and hip hop. Course participants will place the work of a range of cultural theorists (Douglass, DuBois, Adorno, Hurston, Ellison, Murray, Baraka, Henderson, Williams, Mackey, Spillers, O'Meally, Griffin, Moten, Edwards, Radano, Nancy, Szendy, Perry, Weheliye, Neal etc.) in conversation with key works and epochs in black letters.

title: Themes in Islamic Law and Jurisprudence
descrip: Selected topics in Islamic law and jurisprudence. The topics vary from year to year, but the course normally includes reading of fatwas and selected Islamic legal texts in Arabic.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese II
descrip: This course is targeted to students whose Japanese proficiency is at an advanced or superior level. In this class students will discuss various issues in Japanese modern society and in international relations among Asian nations, using newspaper articles, editorials, dramas, short novels, etc. Through these activities, students will develop critical thinking skills as well as Japanese language skills.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: Anyone interested in the Teacher Prep program will get a lot out of this course, and I learned so much more than I realized was involved in the profession.
Get involved in TPP!
Take this course early! It's a big time commitment but definitely worth the work.
This class is really hard work, so don't take it unless you're very serious about it.  But if you are serious about it, you will learn more than you can imagine.
This class requires that you be fully engaged as a teacher-in-training. For many good reasons, it will consume your thoughts. Be prepared to work hard, but also be prepared for a profound journey.

This course is a lot of work, and shouldn't be taken just for the fun of it.  It is very much aimed at people who will be teaching within the next few years.  It is a very big time commitment - in addition to four hours of class a week, you have to do observations in schools and even teach a few classes yourself in a secondary school.  However, if you want to be a teacher, this class does a great job at preparing you.
Very time-consuming but if you want to be a teacher, a must take course.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of learning and teaching, including learner characteristics and needs, organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Required course work includes 18 hours of site-based field experience and evening laboratory sessions.

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: Be prepared to work!
Be sure to do all of the problem sets (even though some are dropped) and try to do lots of exercises and practice exams before the exams because practice is the most helpful!

Because this entire course builds and builds on itself, understanding each concept as it comes is really important. As for any quantitative course, practice problems are incredibly useful when studying for an exam.
DO LOTS OF PRACTICE EXAMS.
Do the psets long in advance and practice.
Don't be afraid to read the textbook. It seems intimidating at first but is very helpful.
Don't expect it to be easy but if you put enough effort into it will be worth it. Furthermore, read the textbook before going to classes.
Don't take it unless you have to. It's no fun. I hate math, btw.
Dont take if Fang Wang is the course Czar. Otherwise TAKE IT especially if you get the chance with Sema Salur, you will fall in love with R3.

Even if you are afraid of math or worried about the difficulty, I suggest that you take it! If you work at it, you will do well. And a recommendation--start your work early! Study early for tests! That will help you.
GO TO VICTOR'S OFFICE HOURS. He is very helpful and he knows how to explain things in very baby steps so that you understand them.
Get Sema Salur if possible and go to her review sessions. Go to office hours.
I recommend trying to take a look at the subject before the class as especially as you move further into the semester the topics get quite hard to understand.

I think the way I learn math may be different from other students. I tend to just listen and take notes during class and then process it later when I review my notes and do homework. It's a good idea to look through the textbook before the material is covered in class. My teacher was decent, but could have been better, so you'll do a lot of learning on your own. The class is pretty easy up to the midterm and even for a bit after that, it's not too hard. However, I thought the last two or three weeks were very challenging, especially since that's when you have less time to put into certain classes. Keep up and do the problem sets even if you don't have to turn it in. The final exam places emphasis on the end of the semester. Make a study group to check the answers on your problem sets. It's expected that most students get close to perfect on the problem sets as that is where you are solidifying what you learned.

If you don't need this course for a distribution requirement, I'd probably advise against. The material can be interesting, but there's a lot of work. However, if you find a really good professor and youre into the material, go for it.
If youre going into the sciences, take it, but know that its a miserable ride, even though the material is actually very interesting
In the first week of classes find a professor who you can really learn from and don't settle for in incompetent teacher.

Interesting (if you love calc), but no cake walk. Take advantage of office hours (especially before the weekend, since psets are due on mondays), and if you get lost after midterms ASK FOR HELP. I didnt, and I ended up having to learn the second half of the class in 2 nights before the final.
It is a good class to take if you are interested in math or need it for upper level classes.
It's a lot of work to fully understand the concepts, so be sure to give yourself time to do that in your schedule.

It's an interesting class, but take only if required. I think there are other classes that satisfy the quantitative reasoning requirement that are more interesting. For example, if you are really into math, take 203 or 215.
It's going to be a bit of work, but it is interesting material.
It's not a huge time commitment, and if you study you'll do well.
Keep up with the reading as you go.
Keep up. and do a lot practice problems.
Make sure you look for a good preceptor. This course is generally not well taught, and the final is brutally hard. Study hard, be organized, and rely mostly on your own reading of the book.
Most likely a tough class, probably don't want to take unless you need to.

Multivariable calculus is generally a very interesting topic, even if you're not looking to major in the math or sciences. It is difficult, but the workload is typical of the lower level math classes.
Only take it if you have to.

People that are really really good at math will take the good grades while everyone will feel like they failed even if they understood it. Don't take it unless it's necessary or you are really good at math.
Practice. Period.

Read all of the chapters covered in the course!  Reading the chapters is a great way of better understanding the material, which can get a little weird for one who has not had experience in it before.
Read the book and go over the material b yourself after classes.
Read the chapter before the class.  I did it for the first part of the semester, but then I stopped for the second half.  I should have kept it up all semester.
Read the textbook and go to office hours.
Read the textbook beforehand.
Read the textbook.
Selma is a good teacher the course is very hard though
Start the problems sets early.
Stay on top of your work. Concepts will build on everything perviously learned so be sure you learn things well.
Study for exams over a long period of time.
Take it if you have to, don't expect it to be particularly fun...
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you need it.
Take it with Prof. Salur!!!! She's fantastic!!!!!!! Do lots of practice problems before the exams and you will be fine!!
Take it; you'll feel smart. (and dumb at times, but when you figure out the problem, you'll feel smart.)
Take this course if you enjoy math (or are an engineer), otherwise avoid it.
Teaches you the basics of multivariable calculus, so if you're looking for that, take it. Nothing too inspiring though.

Test difficulty can vary dramatically! But, the curve balances things out. Regardless, be prepared to feel as if your soul is being crushed, especially if you are a social science/humanities person like me and is not used to the occasionally absurd difficulty.
The book is really useful for studying, and the problem sets are vital for doing well on the tests.
The final exam can be unexpectedly difficult. Do not rely on the past exams or the textbook questions. Or maybe that is just me.
This class will be a challenge. Make use of McGraw, office hours, review sessions, and anything else that is available because it will definitely help you.
This course demands that your MAT 104 skills aren't rusty. You might want to take 104 instead of 201 first if you have the option to do so.
This course is well taught, but the exams are very challenging.
This course isn't too bad, but you need to stay on top of the work because everything builds on itself.
Watch Adrian Banner's videos. It'll be so much better than anything else you can do for exams.

While the instructors were very helpful, the structure on the course is not the most straight-forward out there. It's not a fun class you take out of curiosity. It's mostly something you have to take and that inevitably makes it less enjoyable.
You are probably required to take it so just go ahead and take it.
do more than the homework to learn material
prereqs: MAT 104 or equivalent..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes's theorem.

title: Sociological Studies of Inequality(Half -Term)
descrip: This segment of the JDP seminar covers theory and research on social stratification, the major subfield in sociology that focuses on inequality. Course begins by reviewing major theories, constructs, measures, and empirical work on inequality. Weeks two through six focus on institutions that are expected to produce (and reproduce) inequalities, including families, neighborhoods, schools, labor markets, and penal policy.

title: Problems in Ancient History - Ancient and Medieval Numismatics
descrip: A seminar covering the basic methodology of numismatics, including die, hoard and archaeological analysis. The Western coinage tradition will be covered, from its origins in the Greco-Persian world through classical and Hellenistic Greek coinage, Roman imperial and provincial issues, the coinages of Byzantium, the Islamic world and medieval and renaissance Europe. Students will research and report on problems involving coinages related to their own areas of specialization. Open to undergraduates by permission of the instructor.

title: Advanced Social Statistics
descrip: Thorough examination of the linear regression model with a focus on both the theory underlying the model and the application of regression using contemporary software. Topics include 1) probability theory underlying statistical modeling and hypothesis testing in general, 2) assumptions underlying the linear model, 3) estimation of the model via least squares, maximum likelihood, and Bayesian approaches, 4) diagnosing violations of assumptions, assessing the consequences of violations, and remedying them, and 5) extending the model and estimation methods to other data settings.

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Government Activity
descrip: Analyzes government involvement in "market failures"; externalities (corrective tolls for congestion, environmental damage); "natural" monopolies (infrastructure- telecommunication, electricity-regulation and pricing); efficiency and equity aspects of excise and income taxes; and alternative social security structures and reform proposals in the U.S. and other countries. Prerequisite: 511c.

title: Contemporary Literary Theory
reviews: Do the readings; they're enlightening.
Don't be afraid of theory -- it can be difficult, but given close attention, it can be productively worked through.
It's hard as shit and might seem like bullshit at times, but it's one of the more interesting classes you'll take at Princeton.
Take this course as a freshman or sophomore; it will change the way you look at texts and the questions you ask while reading.
descrip: Survey of central debates in cultural and literary studies focusing on texts in contemporary theory that formulate an understanding of the self. Course follows shifts between structuralism, poststructuralism, psychoanalysis, and Marxism. As we begin to disentangle the meanings of what we mean when we say "I", we will inevitably analyze the relationships between subject and subjection, ideology and power, language and authorship, theory and politics. We will ground our analyses within particular literary, visual, and theoretical works, learning how to read cultural production as theory, rather than "applying" theory to selected texts.

title: Interdisciplinary Research - Ethnography and Democracy
descrip: Periods of democratic crisis have sometimes produced major reformulations of ethnography's purposes. In this seminar, we consider the discursive dualities of democracy movements and ethnographic practice that make subjectivity, representation, agency and authority entwined as both means and ends of inquiry. Conundrums of "stateness", the politicization of social knowledge and the juridification of social reproduction are also dually ethnographic context and content. We focus on key 20th century conversations before turning to 21st century dilemmas still unfolding.

title: Personal Identity
reviews: If you're interested in philosophy, take the course.
It's a study that comes from the professor's heart. You won't regret it.
descrip: This course will focus on the conditions for personal identity over time, with implications for the beginning and end of life. We will investigate what it is rational to care about in caring about survival or continued existence, and whether our account of what it is rational to care about should change if we discover either that (1) there is no human soul or (2) no self or subject behind our various conscious acts. The course will investigate what it is rational to care about in caring about one's future existence.

title: Time Travel
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Elementary Japanese II
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are interested; it will be hard, but if you are willing to put in the time you can get a lot out of it.  The curve can be difficult, especially if you're a native English speaker, but it's a great course.
Do all the homework and set time aside for extra practice.
Ganbatte kudasai ne!

If you are even thinking about taking this class, you definitely should. Although fast-paced, if you keep up with the homework, review a little after class, pay attention during drill sections and lectures, it is not overwhelming at all.
If you're interested in learning Japanese, do not hesitate at all!
Its a good class; the reason I am neutral is because it took a lot of time!!! Since I was a junior, I needed to focus on my JP, so my grade suffered.

Japanese at Princeton is so fun! It's a lot of work, but the sensei are there to help you. Go to office hours if you have any trouble, or if you just want to practice speaking and listening. Also go to Japanese Table to practice speaking and listening in a more natural setting.

The small class sizes mean you really get to know the sensei. You also get to interact every day with your fellow classmates; we've all become friends in my class, which isn't always possible in large classes. I took a semester of French here, and although the class was small, we didn't become nearly as close, possibly because the class was largely us responding to the instructor. In Japanese, you'll have conversations with a different classmate every day. The course itself facilitates total interaction between all students and sensei; a community.

Still not convinced? Talk to current students or the sensei themselves. This class has been my favorite here so far, so look into it!
Japanese is a fascinating language; it's very different from English.  Even more different than Chinese is.  I would highly recommend this as a language course.
Japanese is the best! The sensei's are amazing! A lot of work, but totally worth it; it was my favorite class of the day!

Most of the people taking this will have come from 101, so you all know how awesome the senseis are. But really, if you have the slightest interest in taking Japanese, take it just for the senseis, who are all amazing. I don't think I've heard of any other course where the students and professors get so close. This course feels pretty much like the natural extension of 101 and the only real difference is that the textbook changes to Nakama 2. I think this change is actually one of the downsides, as Nakama 2 seems overall not as well proofread or thought through as Nakama 1. But don't let that small detail affect your decision to continue Japanese.

One fair warning is that language course is extremely demanding. There is no easy way to learn language so anyone planning to take language class should be mentally prepared for that.

That said, this class is about as good as it can be. The instructors are very helpful and they make the class fun and interesting. And at the end of the class you can speak a new language (at the basic level of course), and this is very rewarding.

Take this course!  The senseis are incredible teachers and you learn an incredible amount over the course of the year.  It's a lot of work, but it has also been a ton of fun, since the senseis are incredibly sweet and often arrange all sorts of fun activities for us to do.  One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.

Take this language!  The Princeton Japanese program is absolutely wonderful!  I have come to love the Japanese culture even more than when I first started, and I have learned so much!
purinsutonnoRi Ben Yu noShou Ye hatotemosugoindayo!
Take, but it is not easy.
There are not many Japanese students at Princeton, but it is a very fun language to take.  Definitely recommend if you are looking for a language course.

This is a fantastic language course. You will work hard, but it will be fun and it will be worth it. Japanese is not as hard as you may think - it's actually very easy for English speakers to pronounce, for example. Don't be intimidated!
This is a great collection of professors and you are guaranteed to enjoy your time with the department, regardless of your grade - which you will need to work very hard for.

This is not a language to be taken if you are just interested in filling the requirement. It will demand a lot of you, in terms of the difficulty of the content and the variety of the assignments, which will make demands on your imagination as much as your linguistic faculties. All of that said, if you have time to spend on it, you will have pretty functional Japanese by the end of a year's study, which is enormously impressive given how difficult the language is. Prepare to spend a lot of time working on your multimedia assignments (speeches, blog posts, videos).

YOU HAVE TO IT IS AMAZING IT IS LIFE CHANGING.

... really tough though, btw, but if you work hard you can do well! And so worth it!! I wish I could just do Japanese all day for the rest of my time here at Princeton!!!

if you're willing/able to put in the effort, take it! i!!! f you're not, consider saving yourself a lot of pain and don't (i found it tough to balance junior independent work, upper level departmentals, and this)
perfect
prereqs: JPN 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of JPN 101, which emphasizes the basic four skills to achieve survival proficiency level.

title: International Relations of East Asia
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of reading. Difficult if you are not WWS or familiar with the material beforehand.

Christensen is an interesting guy, but the course should really be called 'IR of China and Japan', since that's all Christensen knows about.  Grading is also fucked up--they gave everyone Cs and B minuses on the midterm because they "wanted to be harsh."
Definitely take it if you're interested at all in IR or in East Asia! You'll learn so much about both.
Definitely worthwhile! Professor Christensen is incredibly knowledgeable and approachable (go to office hours!). The stuff you learn is especially useful and pertinent to current events today.
Do it.

Do not be fooled by the "150-200" pages reading list! One week it came up to 350 and there's often so much that one drowns in it. Only take this class if you've a real interest and passion and discipline to get through it. That said, it's a GREAT class that will be extremely fulfilling if you make it through till the end and go to lectures   do readings. Professor Christensen is very friendly and open to questions, though his importance in the academic   political world does seem a little intimidating at times.
Great class, great professor but a lot of work. Be ready to put in effort if you're taking this class.
Great course. Like any class, watch out if it is at 9am. A lot of reading, but a good deal of interesting stuff.
Great coverage of contemporary East Asian politics with a wonderful professor - very interesting, highly relevant.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND. Christensen is an amazing lecturer; pay close attention during lectures, do as many readings as possible (you'll need them for precept), and take it all in! Great overview of the history of East Asia and how it plays into critical issues today!

He is an incredibly engaging lecturer. He nearly never looks back to refer to his notes, and his words spill out so articulately it seemed like he were quoting a written work word for word. From his lectures alone you can tell the man is brilliant and knows more about the topic than probably anyone else. He seamlessly tied in readings into his lectures, proving that he prepared extensively for each 50 minute lecture. He stimulated intellectual curiosity and independent thinking by relating history to current events and asking us to find solutions to existing issues. It is because of him that I decided to major in Politics. I feel like a more informed human being after having taken this class. A MUST TAKE if you're interested in EA. Amazing course overall.
Highly Recommended
I could recommend it more wholeheartedly if the class were at any other time than 9am.

I enjoyed this; take if you have interests in East or South-East Asia and how the history of the region is relevant today. But it is a lot of work - one of the most demanding classes I've taken in Princeton - so watch out!
I greatly encourage taking this class! Be prepared to read many chapters of texts and discuss them by forming analytical arguments about what you have gathered throughout the course!
I would definitely recommend it--Christensen is a great lecturer and East Asia is such an important and relevant topic.
I would highly recommend if you want to do any work with Asia in the future.
I would take this course if you are interested in Asia at all.
If you are at all interested in the subject take it but be prepared to commit to it fully
It's a lot of work, but you'll learn a lot.
It's an interesting class but be prepared to be very knowledgeable about current day East Asian international affairs.
Not terrible if you're looking for a PDF, although I did not do well on the short answer, and had to put a little more into the last paper. Take it if you're interested in the region.
Professor Christensen is great - take this course if you're even the tiniest bit interested in IR and/or East Asia. There are just A LOT of readings so you need to prioritize well.
Really interesting class - definitely relevant in today's world.  Lot of readings, try to stay on top of them or form a note-taking group.  Prior East Asia knowledge helpful.

Recommend, but be prepared for all the readings. Christensen really makes you think about what you believe about international politics in East Asia in general; it's especially enlightening since he has done public service in the past.
Take it if you can do all the readings and get up for lectures. Otherwise, don't.
Take it!

Take it! Professor Christensen is the foremost China expert of the age. You'd be missing out if you didn't take a class with him before graduating. Seriously, people of his caliber are why you came to Princeton.

Take the course if you want to be able to think and speak coherently about East Asian international relations, but be prepared to do a LOT of reading. Professor Christensen is very interesting and knowledgeable, though lectures tended to jump around a lot.

Take this class! Professor Christensen's passion for and expertise in East Asian politics and international affairs is unparalleled -- and he enjoys sharing that with students.  There's a lot of reading and you need to stay on top of it to get the most out of lectures, but it's definitely worth the time.
Take this class. It's a lot of fun.
Take this course if you have any interest whatsoever in international relations or East Asia.

Take this course! You will learn a lot but it requires a lot of work and expect to commit a lot of time. Moreover, your grade may still not come out to be what you want but it is still a worthwhile course.

This class is definitely very work-intensive, but is so rewarding.  As someone who had no background in East Asia, I was super intimidated by the level of knowledge and expertise some of the other students had, but I found that by being actively engaged in the class I could do just fine.
