This is one class I can come away from saying I learned so much and I am so glad I took it.
This class was amazing, but be warned: it's a LOT of reading, a lot of content, a lot of history. Really enjoyable and informative if you're interested in East Asia. Incredibly relevant, as well.

This is a great course to dive into politics, international affairs, history and the current state of East Asia. A solid background is given in the first few weeks, and the professor and preceptor help build upon this foundation.
You could not find a better professor to learn from about international relations in East Asia.
enjoyable course but must have interest in US foreign policy
great class. take it if you are interested in east asia or international relations because you will learn so much. even though its hard it is worth it.
take this course
descrip: This course will concentrate on the Cold War and post Cold War international relations of East Asia. In the first two weeks we will cover general theoretical approaches to international relations and a brief historical backdrop of Western and Japanese imperialism in the region. In the following weeks, we will discuss the interaction between changes in the broader international system and changes in international relations in the East Asian region. The course will finish with discussion of implications of events and trends since the end of the Cold War.

title: Social Networks
reviews: A great course for anyone interested in social networks.  Go to lecture - Prof. Salganik is very good at explaining the (sometimes painful) readings and pointing out what is the take-away message.

ALWAYS go to lecture. I learned at least half of everything from lecture itself, it's really important! Also, go to office hours. Professor Salganik is great to talk to, and I wish I had found more excuses to go. And lastly, try to think of how you could apply the things you learn in this class to other aspects of school and life. The information is really rich and relevant. You could use it to help make the world a better place.

At its core, this is a sociology class pretending, and failing miserably, to be an engineering class. You would think the lectures are designed for middle schoolers, given the gimmicks and the ridiculous levels of repetition of trivially simple topics - we spent a solid fifteen minutes making itsy-bitsy-spider shapes with our hands in lecture one day, which was somehow believed would help us to understand the difference between weak and strong links and bridges in networks. Problem is - we already understand this, and making little hand shapes isn't going to help. Overall, a frustratingly condescending and vacuous course that taught me exactly nothing. Don't take it.
Attend all the lectures.  Really, they're engaging and informative, and will give you almost all you need to pass this course.
Do not take this class. It is so much harder than I expected. I stressed out majorly for a class I was PDFing for a distribution requirement.

Don't take this class unless you're just filling space in your schedule and PDF it because it is not worth your mind's time or attention. One of those classes where its so much common sense that the professor has to do absurd things like NOT CURVE any of the grades to get people to actually take it seriously. Not sure why Princeton hasn't got rid of this class yet.

Easy PDF, but not remotely interesting and very little substance to any of the topics. It was almost as if a 2-week section of SOC 101 was turned into a full course, but they forgot to add any more information. Look at the titles of the readings and you'll get a P.
Easy class, with extremely simple material.
Great, interesting course. Take it--it's relevant and fun.
I loved the professor!! He made the course!

I would recommend this course if you're looking for a straightforward SA. Make sure you go to lecture, almost all of the midterm at least came from things he talked about directly in class! Readings are pretty doable for the most part and the problem sets are easy

If you want a distribution, by all means take it. Again, it's not a BAD course. If you're interested in the topic, you might as well go as far into it as your heart desires, but just know that the course certainly expects a lot less of you than you might think.

If you're very very interested in networking (more in the engineering or statistical sense than the sociological), you will love this course. Was more stats based than I originally anticipated. However, the information is relevant to today. Precepts were not a strong point.
Interesting class for learning about social networks. Easy class for PDF and light workload.
Interesting class. Very chill, but make sure you go to lecture, cuz material covered in lecture is what you need for the exams.

It's a really easy class with minimal work. There's a lot of people PDFing so it's not that hard to get a good grade. Lectures are interesting but not necessary if you have too much work. I feel like you get what you put into this class so while you can get by with minimal effort, you may feel like this class is more rewarding if you try harder. Didn't feel like I learned much from this class other than reinforcing conclusions I already knew with formal studies. But I guess that's soc for you.

It's pretty harmless. You won't learn a whole lot, but you won't have to do a whole lot either, and some of the stuff you learn might be interesting, especially if you have a slightly more abstract way of thinking.

Least favorite class I've taken at Princeton. Not necessarily Prof. Salganik's fault, material was just simply a nuisance. Attempts to establish the study of social networks as a legitimate science got in the way of the truly fascinating ideas and concepts and the ways they influence the world around us. Most people can understand and appreciate these just as effectively (if not more so) without the unnecessary emphasis on quantification.

Make sure you have a background in information technology, computer science, or sociology. I felt it was too advanced without proper teaching for a beginner class. Also, the fact that it was cumulative made it even more difficult to know what was necessary to know.
Nice class to PDF. Homework is super easy and material is somewhat interesting

No matter what your major is, you should consider taking this course.  It is a fundamental course in how you look at the world, both in social and scientific contexts.  The work isn't that hard but the material is very interesting and useful.
Not a bad PDF course.
Organize the information from lectures.
Probably the easiest SA in the history of Princeton.
Readings are relevant to today's social networks, so it's pretty interesting.  You should take it.

Salganik clearly cares about students learning the subject well.  The readings are fairly interesting (although not all of them are necessary), and the assignments are not time consuming and do a good job of getting the main points across.  With that said, it is really easy to lose enough points to drop you done to a B on the midterm and final so spend a lot of time studying.  Consider pooling notes with other students.

Some people find the first lecture slow, but sticking with it paid off. You get exposed to an area of cool sociological research that's very relevant to many other fields (I'm a CS major, for instance), and the professor's a cool guy.
Take it if you are interested in social networks.

Take it if you're looking for an easy fifth class. If you're looking for a more rigorous study of networks, try something in computer science. 

If you go to lectures, you won't have to do the readings, which are more complex and take longer than the material as presented in lecture.
Take it, but be ready to process and pick out the more important facts from a large large large amount of information.
Take this class as a pdf. easy problem sets and read lectures to study for exams.

Take this class. I know it has mixed reviews, but honestly in this day and age a class like this is as relevant as COS126 but ten times easier. The homeworks are not checking if you're doing the reading (which are interesting but explained well in lecture if you don't have time to do them) but usually have to do with facebook or some social experiment. The lectures are not going to be the best lectures you've had at princeton, but because the subject is so interesting they are actually great -- social networks and digital connections are becoming so intertwined in our lives that understanding them is not only interesting but also important. 
As a sidenote - if you're the type of person who actually likes understanding the studies, I would recommend taking this class alongside or after taking a stats class just because a lot of the papers are statistical studies trying to prove associations.
This class is chill, and very interesting.
This class is interesting, the professor is great, and what I've learnt I've referred to multiple times during the class and since. Precepts really aren't necessary though.
This class is not incredibly difficult, and is actually quite interesting for a quantitative mind.
This class is pretty easy with only a little bit of work. Readings aren't really necessary, just class attendance. Homework is actually fun. It's a pretty good PDF.

This is an interesting and manageable course. Take good notes in class and go to every class, it will make your life much easier. Professor S is an interesting lecturer and clearly explains the concepts to you. It is a relevant and interesting class to take regardless of your major. Also, start on the problem sets early. They are not super hard but could take some time.

This is an interesting course. It will affect how you see your social network and be very applicable to different parts of your life. Stay on top of readings and have a study group. Take assignments seriously because they count for a big portion of your grade.
This is not an easy class by any means. But it is a great class. Do with that what you will...  (maybe PDF it?) It's definitely worth the effort, though.
This would make an excellent fourth or fifth class; it is interesting and well executed, but not too time consuming.
Very interesting course, would recommend taking. Course load is average/low, and its a really fun and interesting class.
Yes, I would recommend it. Everything was interesting, great course to pdf or take for a grade.
be prepared to have to read alot for the course, do not take this class if you like to procrastinate.
not worth it.
pretty chill and interesting class. take it
the material is interesting, but be very careful about not messing up the midterm
descrip: This course provides students an introduction to the study of social networks. We will focus on understanding the causes and consequences of patterns of social relationships.

title: Contemporary Music through Composition and Performance
reviews: Take it, it's fun and just one composition a week. Lansky is really chill.
Take this course if you would like to expose yourself to appropriate composers in the contemporary classical music world.
descrip: The course is aimed at performers and composers interested in deepening their understanding of the techniques and philosophies of contemporary and early modern music. Activities will include performing, analyzing, and composing.

title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
reviews: A great class by CBE standards. It's not too hard which makes it a nice complement to Core Lab.
Departmental. Don't be worried.

Finally, a good CBE course! Sundar is amazing -- it's obvious how much he truly cares about teaching well and about the students' understanding. The problem sets are fair, not nearly bad as those for Pipes, although you should be wary of the MATLAB problems, you might need some time to debug those. Take advantage of office hours, and try to make sure you understand the concepts behind the different types of reactors in addition to learning how to solve the different problems.

If Professor Sundar continues to teach this course consider yourself lucky. Sundar in simply amazing. He, unlike the majority of the faculty in this department, actually cares about his students and whether or not you actually understand the material. This course could have actually been a pleasure if it wasn't located in A224, the worst room on the planet, and if it was 3 50 minute classes.
It's not that terrible, but make sure you understand the conceptual stuff.
Make sure you understand "first principles!"
Of the required courses for the major this has been the best.  It feels most like what Chemical Engineering is about.
Perhaps one of the best chemical engineering classes I have taken. By the end of it, you've learned it so well that you don't feel like you even have to study for the final.
Pray that Sundar is teaching the class.
Read the book.
Students will probably enjoy this more than CBE341.
Sundar is so awesome!!!!!!!
Try to keep up with the readings, but read it after the lecture as a reinforcement rather than a foreshadowing.
Well, only CBE students ever take this.
Well, only a CBE would take this course, but it's definitely one of the more enjoyable core classes, if not the best.
You have to take it anyway, but this class is actually enjoyable. We had great TAs, though. Also, SUNDAAAAAAAAAR. <3
good course.  the book is actually pretty good, and so is sundar.  go to office hours if you need help with anything
you have to, no?
prereqs: CBE 341.
descrip: Introduction to chemical reaction engineering and reactor design in chemical and biological processes. Concepts of chemical kinetics for both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions. Coupled transport and chemical/biological rate processes.

title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Symmetry, Diffraction and the Structures of Non-molecular Solids
reviews: Do it!
I think whoever is interested in this subject should take this class.
The class is interesting and Dr. Cava explains the material well, take the class
descrip: Topics covered vary from year to year. The subject matter will be selected from among the following, related to the inorganic chemistry of solids: point group and space group symmetry, irreproducible representations, structure-property relations, crystallography, methods in X-ray, neutron and electron diffraction science, the structures of solids and molecules, the electronic structure of molecular and non-molecular solids, the optical, electronic and magnetic properties of molecular and non-molecular solids and their relation to crystal structure.

title: Topics in Poetry - Contemporary Poetry
reviews: I strongly recommend this class as a way to familiarize yourself with current poetry and to meet some extremely interesting writers.
If you're interested in poetry, take this. It was - by a long stretch - the best course I took this semester, and Prof. Kotin is wonderful.

Really amazing. If you love poetry, take this course. It gives you an opportunity to engage with poetry in a way unlike any other poetry class I've taken, giving you both critical and creative methods of studying poetry. Really just a wonderful class.
Take this course.  Josh Kotin is probably the best discussion-leader I have ever encountered and is one of the most likable and flexible and wonderful professors you could have at Princeton.
descrip: This seminar focuses on poetry books published in 2012 and 2013. We will read work by established and emerging poets, and attend poetry readings in Princeton (and possibly New York and Philadelphia). Poets will also visit the class to discuss their work and/or the work of writers they admire. Students will write reviews, rather than essays, and, in the process, learn about (and contribute to) the institutions that support and promote contemporary poetry.

title: Topics in Spanish Civilization of the Golden Age - Heroes and Heroines in Spanish Literature
reviews: Be prepared to read a bunch, but if you keep up the course is not hard. Christina Lee is a good teacher and she has interesting ideas. It is overall a fun course
Fun course, do all the readings.
I would advise other students to do the readings and to do background research on the heroes and heroines.
Prof. Christina Lee is the best and I strongly recommend this course
TAKE IT
Take it!
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or equivalent..
descrip: This seminar explores the discursive constructions of representative heroes of the Spanish-speaking world. Depending on these varying cultural values, heroes may continue to hold their status, be demoted to the rank of mere mortals, or in some cases, be deemed anti-heroes. Our aim is to understand the social function of the hero or heroine in his or her historical context and the specific circumstances that lead to his/her idolization and, in some cases, abandonment or re-discovery.
